HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
CADILLAC JUKEBOX (Hyperion, $22.95) may be the most incoherent of the crime stories that James Lee Burke has set in the Louisiana bayou country of the Atchafalaya Basin. At the outset, Dave Robicheaux, the melancholy sheriff's deputy who broods over this series, seems to have a hard but unambiguous mission: to find out whether a redneck named Aaron Crown actually killed a civil rights leader back in the 1960's, and to figure out what this old crime, for which Crown has only recently been arrested, has to do with the upcoming gubernatorial election. But the investigation is soon mired in the violent history of New Iberia and the complicated relationships of its politically inbred families. A subhuman beast of a hit man crawls out of the swamp to silence police informants, and everyone from the New Orleans Mafia to Dave's wife warns him off the case.
Since nobody reads these sprawling, sweaty novels for narrative sense anyhow, it hardly matters when the plot self-destructs. What matters is that Mr. Burke is on a writing streak. Characters as vital as Aaron Crown ("There's always one guy hanging around to remind us of what we did or what we used to be") and Jerry Joe Plumb (a mobster with an endearing love of great jukebox music) don't grow on mangrove trees. For all the dirt it rolls around in, Mr. Burke's muscular prose is full of grace. 
 Charles Todd, an American, has written a first novel that speaks out, urgently and compassionately, for a long-dead generation and a world he never knew. Set in England in the aftermath of World War I, A TEST OF WILLS (Thomas Dunne/ St. Martin's, $22.95) is both a meticulously wrought puzzle and a harrowing psychological drama about a man's struggle to raise himself from the dead.
Inspector Ian Rutledge, just returned from France with a Medal of Honor and a bad case of shell shock, is sent to the Warwickshire countryside on an assignment that a cruel superior at Scotland Yard is certain will unnerve him. A distinguished army colonel has been shot to death, and his best friend, a decorated young captain who is engaged to the colonel's ward, is the prime suspect. To make matters unendurable for Rutledge, whose sanity is iffy, the chief witness is another veteran, a traumatized wretch held in contempt by the villagers as a coward who "lost his nerve on the Somme and went to pieces."
Mr. Todd gives us a superb characterization of a man whose wounds have made him a stranger in his own land, and a disturbing portrait of a country intolerant of all strangers. Much more than a rural homicide is at stake here, which makes Rutledge's painstaking efforts to break down the hostility and prejudice that confront him everywhere all the more agonizing - and honorable.
You haven't been west in any meaningful sense until you've been to Blue Deer, Mont., for the annual rodeo called the Wrangle, a wild and woolly ritual captured in all its vibrating colors in GOING LOCAL (Hyperion, $21.95), Jamie Harrison's madcap follow-up to "The Edge of the Crazies." Although the schedule stays pretty constant ("bareback, saddle broncs, the clown's act, more saddle broncs, team roping and the ladies' exhibition"), this year's festivities also include participants' losing important body parts and being kicked to death by an enraged bronco.
Jules didn't fully subscribe to the heroic notion of the West," Ms. Harrison says of Jules Clement, the young sheriff who has to clean up this mess. Even during his own rodeo days, this sweetly cynical hero had recognized the glorious idiocy of it all, been amused by the ironies even as he flew through the air." That sense of detached amusement, which Jules clings to for mental health, almost fails him when he has to find out who willfully ran over an environmental lawyer and his girlfriend while they were out camping and tossed their bodies (along with their tent, their car and their dog) into the reservoir. But with the help of some eccentric cronies, Jules manages to find the killer, get the goods on a land-grabbing development scheme - and rekindle our delight in Ms. Harrison's offbeat sensibility and tart regional voice.
There are lots of cities where a burned-out New York journalist might recover from a career crisis, but Kennebec, Me., a decaying mill town with a population of sullen hard-core unemployables and a polluted river that runs insultingly close to the boarded-up shops downtown, is not one of them. Jack McMorrow, the depressed newsman in Gerry Boyle's LIFELINE (Putnam, $22.95), makes a lunge at emotional stability by hiring on with the local newspaper as a court reporter. His gesture backfires when he starts filing stories exposing the shady practices of an assistant district attorney, a woman whose pitiless code of judicial ethics ("Shovel 'em in. Shovel 'em out") leads to the death of a woman Jack has befriended. Although Mr. Boyle overindulges his hero's lachrymose guilt feelings, his style is poised and pointed when he is writing about the barren lives of the hopeless cases who rattle in and out of court, like milk bottles on a conveyor belt."
It took only two books for Dennis Lehane to stake out the blue-collar Boston suburb of Dorchester as prime territory for a new private-eye series. In DARKNESS, TAKE MY HAND (Morrow, $24), Patrick Kenzie, the brash young hero, identifies this turf as "my neighborhood. A tiny, mostly forgotten, hardscrabble place of three-deckers and faded A-frames, cubbyhole taverns and corner stores." As he did in "A Drink Before the War," the debut novel that won him a Shamus Award from the Private Eye Writers of America, the author nails the distinctive accents and character traits of the all-too-human working stiffs who pace out their lives between Carney Hospital and the Black Emerald bar. Although Patrick is stuck in an absurdly improbable case involving a coven of serial killers who have been secretly preying on the neighborhood for 20 years, the new sleuth may yet find his way around the block.

HEADLINE: Not With a Whimper but a Bang

BYLINE: By Dick Teresi; Dick Teresi is the co-author, with Leon Lederman, of "The God Particle."

 BODY:

THE END OF THE WORLD
The Science and Ethics of Human Extinction.
By John Leslie.
310 pp. New York:
Routledge. $23.
 
WHY THINGS BITE BACK
Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences.
By Edward Tenner.
346 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $26.
 For Hindus, the end of the world is an inevitable consequence of an ever-cycling universe. A "day and night of Brahman," or a creation-and-destruction cycle, lasts 8.64 billion years. We are now at the tail end of one. To the Hopi Indians, the "people of peace" who live on the edge of Arizona's Painted Desert, this is a time of koyaanisqatsi, or "world out of balance." The present world will soon come to a violent end, but Pahana, a messianic figure, will return to usher in a new one. Most Americans find such apocalyptic visions, with their acceptance of destruction, intolerably alien. We do not feel "at one" with the universe, as the Hopis, Hindus and others do. We try to control the universe, and everything will be fine if we play our cards right. If we don't, a transcendent but irritable God is waiting to sit in judgment on us. 
 Two new books by men neither Hopi nor Hindu offer apocalyptic views. The first, "The End of the World," by John Leslie, is traditionally Judeo-Christian, quietly filled with fire and brimstone, but couched in technological terms. Mr. Leslie, a professor of philosophy at the University of Guelph in Canada, says the end is very near. He cites technological villains: nuclear, biological and chemical warfare, destruction of the ozone layer, the greenhouse effect, pollution and disease, as well as "risks often unrecognized." Among these are volcanic eruptions, asteroid and comet impacts, an ice age due to the earth's passage through an interstellar cloud, a nearby supernova, collisions of black holes or neutron stars, and "chaotic" breakdowns such as a dissolution of the planet's biosphere. He also lists man-made disasters -- "green scum" (genetically engineered organisms), "gray goo" (tiny self-reproducing machines), accidental production of a new Big Bang in a laboratory -- and annihilation by extraterrestrials, among other things.
 Mr. Leslie's major premise is that the end is near because a "fair proportion" of all people ever born are now alive. He never commits to a precise figure for this "fair proportion," though for the sake of argument he always uses 10 percent. It is nowhere near 10 percent. Ronald Lee, a demographer and economist at the University of California, Berkeley, says the accumulative population is projected to be 110 billion in the year 2000, with 6 billion of them, or 5.45 percent, still living. Now, the first two humans were 100 percent of the total. Even a few generations later, more than 50 percent must have been alive. So that 5.45 percent looks pretty good. But why does this matter? Mr. Leslie says it is more logical to assume we are in the very last 10 percent of humans rather than, say, in the first 0.01 percent; therefore, statistically, we are doomed.
 It's possible that much of "The End of the World" is tongue in cheek. Mr. Leslie's prose, untranslated from the original Canadian, is sometimes as hard to decipher as his math. There are endless exercises in logic. Which is not to say that "The End of the World" isn't a fun read. But Mr. Leslie never really tells us where he's coming from, though he cites physicists like Frank Tipler and Paul Davies, who are known not so much for accomplishments in science as for their efforts at reinterpreting modern physics to make it conform to traditional Western religious beliefs. He then drops bigger names, including three Nobel Prize-winning physicists, leaving the impression that such people have joined his apocalyptic bandwagon.
 Have they? Mr. Leslie writes that "an all-destroying phase transition" consisting of "a bubble of 'true vacuum,' " produced by an ultra-powerful accelerator, could expand through space at nearly the speed of light, destroying everything. He cites the physicist Leon Lederman and David Schramm, an astrophysicist, as predicting that we should have the technology to build such a machine by 2100. Mr. Lederman, with whom I once wrote a book, says, "That was a joke, an illustration of how one can extrapolate ad absurdum."
 To be fair, Mr. Leslie is no scientist, and his scenarios are oddly comforting. He places us at an important time in history (the end) and promises us a speedy resolution to our story. We're not Hindus, with eight-billion-year recurring cycles. We like our universe built in seven days, and we expect apocalypse on demand.
 A less expansive but more original book is "Why Things Bite Back." The point made by Edward Tenner, a historian with a Hopi attitude, is not so much that the world is going to hell as that technology simply allows us to get to our own koyaanisqatsi faster. We are threatened not with catastrophe but with subtle reciprocal effects, which he calls"revenge effects." For instance, when X-rays were introduced in the 1890's, they became a sensation: "People with foreign objects lodged in their bodies, even those who suffered no pain from them, now asked to have them extracted -- a procedure that sometimes had fatal complications." Today ecologists herald the use of chemical dispersants to break up oil spills. Shorelines are saved, but the petroleum is broken down into minute globules that sink below the surface, where they interfere with the reproduction of much marine life. Bird watchers who have built nesting boxes for Eastern bluebirds find their nests filled with house sparrows instead. Now the North American Bluebird Society recommends wringing the sparrows' necks or putting them in a sack tied to a car's exhaust pipe.
 Mr. Tenner dwells, appropriately, on labor lost to the computer revolution. "For many users," he writes, "computer software seems related to hardware as Thomas Malthus believed population responded to food resources: software does not just match but eventually outstrips hardware in their respective rates of growth. Users who do not have enough computer power spend more and more time waiting for their systems to finish work." The author also points out the hidden cost of "peer helpers" -- general employees shanghaied into trouble-shooting computer systems. Mr. Lederman and I once lost an afternoon trying to figure out where his new networked computer at the University of Chicago was printing out a file. We crawled endlessly, following cables, before we found our printout in a distant office. Here was the discoverer of the bottom quark and the muon neutrino being paid to locate a 38-pound laser printer.
 But the author's best shots puncture our attempts to manipulate the earth. Technology allows large populations to inhabit flood plains, but 500,000 lives may have been lost in the 1970 Bangladesh cyclone, mostly because of settlements on reclaimed land that normally would have been left uninhabited. Why doesn't California discourage people from continuing to build in quake-prone Los Angeles? Because Federal earthquake relief in 1994 is credited with accelerating the state's financial recovery by a full fiscal quarter.
 No one is safe from Mr. Tenner's analytical eye. There is even a vicious attack on Smokey Bear, whose simplistic philosophy (a simplistic bear!), he says, promotes suppression of natural fires that clean out the undergrowth. The result is a giant tinderbox of a forest in America.
 I am writing not for policy makers but for people stumbling through a Rube Goldberg world and trying to make sense of it. And I am arguing not against change, but for a modest, tentative and skeptical acceptance of it," Mr. Tenner writes. He has amassed a staggering amount of research in "Why Things Bite Back," all of it clearly and succinctly presented. His truest remark is that no futurist "has ever lost business because of a wrong prediction." I predict we will see a lot more doomsday books. Mr. Leslie might disagree, arguing that a "fair proportion" of all the doomsday books ever published are in print today and thus the end is near. I doubt it. These books will continue to multiply as we approach 2000. Then, when the rubble from all the New Year's Eve, 1999, parties is cleaned up, some malcontent will point out that the new millennium does not begin in 2000, but in 2001. That will be the real apocalypse: an extra year of doomsday books.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: END OF THE WORLD, THE (BOOK); WHY THINGS BITE BACK (BOOK)

HEADLINE: A Hard Habit to Break

BYLINE: By Christopher S. Wren; Christopher S. Wren covers illegal drugs and drug policy for The Times.

 BODY:

GLOBAL HABIT
The Drug Problem in a Borderless World.
By Paul B. Stares.
171 pp. Washington:
Brookings Institution. $24.95.
 
SMOKE AND MIRRORS
The War on Drugs and the Politics of Failure.
By Dan Baum.
396 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
 
DRUG WAR POLITICS
The Price of Denial.
By Eva Bertram, Morris Blachman, Kenneth Sharpe and Peter Andreas.
347 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press.
Cloth, $48. Paper, $17.95.
 After nearly three decades and hundreds of billions of dollars, almost no one seems content with the war against illegal drugs. Prohibitionists keep blaming people overseas for America's addiction. Others propose legalizing drugs without explaining how legalization would work. Meanwhile, drug use among adolescents climbs, prisons overflow with dealers and users, and Congress cuts funds to treat the addicted. Americans look in vain to their leaders, who keep dodging the issue, especially in an election year. Now three new books suggest that most people who write about the subject aren't doing much better. 
 Of these studies, only "Global Habit," by Paul B. Stares, says something fresh. For the ordinary reader trying to understand why illegal drugs are such an intractable problem, the most rewarding book remains "Against Excess," by a Harvard professor, Mark A. R. Kleiman. (This 1992 study draws from a wealth of detail to stake out a pragmatic middle position between prohibition and legalization.) Still, Mr. Stares, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, brings an overdue perspective in focusing on the devastation that illegal drugs are wreaking beyond the United States. Though he is skimpy with anecdotes, Mr. Stares possesses a dispassionate intelligence, and he lays out all sides of a complex argument (a courtesy overlooked by the other authors here). He documents that drugs are big business, generating revenues worldwide that by one estimate exceed the gross national products of three-fourths of the world's 207 national economies. "Estimates of the value of all global retail sales of illicit psychoactive substances range between $180 billion and more than $300 billion annually," he reports, "making the drug trade one of the biggest commercial activities in the world."
 And, he notes, the appetite for dangerous drugs shows no sign of abating. Combined sales of heroin, cocaine and marijuana in North America and Europe, where the number of users has declined since 1980, still add up to $122 billion annually, while in other regions use is spreading. There is little incentive for dirt-poor countries like Peru or Burma to stop growing coca leaf or opium poppies when such crops make more economic sense than legal alternatives.
 Mr. Stares recasts the old supply-versus-demand debate into a question of negative and positive controls. Negative controls, like sanctions against drug trafficking, should be maintained, he says, but positive controls, including treatment and prevention, must become the dominant means of reducing production and consumption. He argues for serious international cooperation, with a worldwide monitoring network, international prevention and treatment programs, and other responses to contain the drug epidemic.
 While Mr. Stares looks ahead, the journalist Dan Baum looks backward in "Smoke and Mirrors" -- with as much disgust as anger. "For more than a quarter-century the United States has been on a rampage, kicking in doors and locking people up in the name of protecting its citizens from illegal drugs," he begins, in what becomes a polemic about Government perfidy. He calls the nation's drug policy "as expensive, ineffective, delusional and destructive as government gets," and he tries to prove this by revisiting virtually every police blunder and drug bust gone awry. If law enforcement is as abusively inept as he depicts, the untold story here is why Americans still support the war against drugs. At least 85 percent of them, according to a December Gallup poll, oppose legalization. Presumably they would not feel better off if the 110 tons of cocaine Federal agents and police interdicted last year were available on American streets.
 "Smoke and Mirrors" does not lack for colorful writing, packaged in a progression of self-contained vignettes that the reader is left to connect. The politics are fascinating, from the Nixon White House's effort to turn the drug war to political advantage to the Carter Administration's brief flirtation with decriminalizing marijuana. When he lowers his voice, Mr. Baum does make some trenchant observations, and those seeking confirmation that the war on drugs is a bummer will relish the failures he serves up. But everyone else may ask what the alternative is, and Mr. Baum never quite says.
 It makes sense to argue, as do the scholars Eva Bertram, Morris Blachman, Kenneth Sharpe and Peter Andreas in "Drug War Politics," that the use of illegal drugs should be treated not as a crime but as a public health problem. But this idea is hardly original (even the new White House drug czar, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, has spoken of fighting a cancer, not a war), and the authors' case is not well served by their think-tank jargon. For instance, the political argument over whether tax dollars are better spent suppressing drugs and pushers or rehabilitating addicts gets framed in terms of a "punitive paradigm" versus a "public health paradigm."
 Elsewhere, the authors may break new ground in political correctness, quoting a child-health specialist as complaining that "Just Say No" campaigns in schools "aren't sensitive to the number of kids living in environments where people they love and depend on are using and selling drugs." They also sound nave in asserting that some marijuana use in the 1960's counterculture "had echoes of the rugged individualism and rejection of state authority of America's mythic past." Mr. Stares comes closer to the mark in writing that "for some, initiation into drug use may have less to do with the sensation that is expected to ensue than with the desire to conform to the behavior of a peer group, to observe the fashion of the moment or to demonstrate one's independence from others and societal norms in general."
 It would have been fascinating to know where the authors of "Drug War Politics" differ on key issues like legalization. Surely four experts who feel qualified to write about drug policy can't all think alike. But their conclusions arrive as watered down as a diplomatic communiqu, and when it comes to legalization, they waffle. Again, it is left to Mr. Stares to observe that the legalization debate is meaningless because it means different things, including decriminalization, to different people. "The real issue is what degree of regulation is appropriate for the common good," he says. "Regulation can take many forms and be applied to different areas of the marketplace." Legalizing drugs, Mr. Stares believes, would entail substituting some problems for others that are likely to prove costlier to society.
 "Smoke and Mirrors" and "Drug War Politics" unwittingly underscore a recurrent problem in writing about drugs: the aura of elitism that hangs over the discussion of alternatives. Legalization is usually bandied about by affluent whites who can afford large mortgages to finance drug rehabilitation for their own children if the experiment sours. No such cushion exists in the ghetto for poor black or Hispanic children. The risks need to be spelled out. Would cocaine and its viciously addictive derivative, crack, be included in a legalization program? If marijuana became available to adults, would minors find it any harder to buy than they now do beer and cigarettes? If heroin went on sale, would the cities of the United States become meccas for international druggies the way that Amsterdam and Zurich have?
 However flawed the war against drugs looks, any alternative seems destined to fail unless it seizes the public imagination enough to be voted into reality. That means solutions that make sense not just to scholars and writers but also, for example, to young mothers, whose voices are conspicuously absent from calls to dismantle the barricades. When the subject is illegal drugs, the devil truly hides in the details.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Cultivating Blackfish Far From the Sea

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
WEIGHING in at less than a pound, Tony is not a particularly impressive year-old tautog, or blackfish. But to scientists at the National Marine Fisheries Service Laboratory in Milford, Tony's voracious appetite and accelerating growth are signs that New Englanders may some day be able to farm blackfish far from the ocean, for profit, and to allow overfished stocks in local waters to recover.
Tony and three other fish are the only survivors of the first batch of blackfish conceived and hatched at the laboratory in 1995, said Dean Perry, a fishery biologist who heads efforts at the laboratory to develop cultivation techniques for blackfish. 
 The high mortality was caused by rapidly rising levels of ammonia in the nutrient-rich tanks where the juvenile blackfish are first raised, he said.
Juvenile blackfish are placed in what are called green water tanks containing algae rich in fatty acids, almost microscopic brine shrimp and microscopic animals called rotifers. The tank's waters are heated to about 69 degrees Fahrenheit to speed up the growth of the fry.
Unfortunately these are also prime conditions for the build-up of ammonia, which is in the juvenile fish's excretion, Mr. Perry said. Fortunately a lot of striped bass aquaculture work has already been done, and systems are being developed to remove ammonia from green water tanks. If economical techniques can be developed to raise 10- to 12-inch blackfish (weighing 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 pounds) in 18 months or less, there's definitely a very lucrative market waiting, said Dr. Anthony Calabrese, of the laboratory.
Connecticut fishermen can only keep tautogs that are 14 inches or more (about 2 pounds) despite the fact that 10- to 12-inch live tautogs are in demand in Asian fish markets. In some markets blackfish will sell for as much as $14 to $15 a pound.
Because of Asian fish markets' demand for live tautogs, many fish traps are being set for them, says David Simpson, a State Department of Environmental Protection fish biologist. The tautog is already one of the five most popular recreational fishing species in Connecticut.
But the tautog is a slow-growing and slow-reproducing species. The fish, which may live 34 years, does not become sexually active until it is 3 or 4. Only a relatively small percentage of its offspring will survive each year.
Surveys have shown a dramatic decrease in the blackfish population in local waters, particularly over the last two to three years, said Mr. Simpson. And the state has just enacted regulations that prohibit fishing for tautogs from May 1 to June 14 when they swim in to spawn.
Aquaculture will never be able to replace the oceans' resources, but it can provide significant amounts of food while giving fish populations a chance to recover and rebound, says Dr. Calabrese.
Although the National Marine Fisheries Service Laboratory helped revive Connecticut's oyster industry, and is also trying to re-establish a Connecticut scallop industry, its $2 million budget was on Congress' chopping block this year.
The blackfish aquaculture at the laboratory, which began last summer and is the only such effort in the United States, has only cost the laboratory $3,000 in new capital expenses, said Dr. Calabrese. This covered new filters, and the cost of modifying 30-foot tanks once used to cultivate oysters.
If the $2 million yearly budget for the laboratory is again approved, the tautog aquaculture work will be continued, he said.
It may someday be possible to raise blackfish to restock local waters, said Dr. Calabrese. One of the things the laboratory is trying to develop is a genetic marker that would allow tank-raised blackfish and their descendants to be identified in the wild.
In the past the government spent a lot of money to produce juvenile fish that were released in the oceans and immediately eaten by predators. So if any restocking of blackfish is attempted, it must be shown that these fish are surviving and reproducing, Dr. Calabrese said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 833 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

HIGH FIDELITY
By Nick Hornby. Riverhead, $12.
Rob, the narrator, is so obsessed with pop culture that he has difficulty separating it from his real life. A London record store owner who has just lost his girlfriend, he is both severely immature and relentlessly self-appraising. Mr. Hornby captures the loneliness and childishness of adult life with "precision and wit," Mark Jolly said here last year.
 
THE RICHER, THE POORER: Stories, Sketches, and Reminiscences
By Dorothy West. Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.
Whether describing Martha's Vineyard or Moscow, sensitive children or stoic adults, the author brings keen observational powers and a mordant understanding to this collection, which ranges from her first short story, written when she was 17, to a much more recent essay in which she contemplates her own mortality. The last surviving member of the Harlem Renaissance, Ms. West, who is approaching 90, "has a naturalist's ear and eye for detail, an unsentimental view of human failings and a clear, crisp narrative style," Gwendolyn M. Parker wrote in the Book Review in 1995.
 
THE FAMILY ARSENAL
By Paul Theroux. Penguin, $11.95.
Just restored to print, this novel takes place among a small circle of terrorists in a dingy neighborhood of London in the 1970's. Including Hood, a failed American diplomat, all of them have embraced the Irish Republican Army for reasons that are probably more personal than political. In 1976 our reviewer, Lawrence Graver, called the book "an intelligent, absorbing thriller." Penguin has also reissued Mr. Theroux's earlier novel THE BLACK HOUSE ($10.95), in which an English anthropologist and his wife find their lives overtaken by a peculiar, perhaps ghostly, young woman. It is an ambitious but "inconclusive Gothic tale," Michael Mewshaw wrote in these pages in 1974.
 
MOVING VIOLATIONS: War Zones, Wheelchairs, and Declarations of Independence
By John Hockenberry. Hyperion, $14.95.
In 1976 an ordinary hitchhiking trip turned into an endless journey for the author: rendered paraplegic in a car accident, he was determined to overcome the limits of his new life. Now a television correspondent, he has written a "full-throated, driving and highly affecting book," Pico Iyer said here last year.
 
WHEN THE WORLD WAS STEADY
By Claire Messud. Granta, $11.95.
Emmy and Virginia are London-born sisters, but there the resemblance ends. Emmy, abandoned wife and world traveler, has always believed in free will; Virginia, in familial duty and divine providence. Their fictional odyssey makes for an "assured and engaging debut," James Marcus wrote in the Book Review in 1995.
 
TRUST: The Social Virtues and the Creation of Prosperity
By Francis Fukuyama.
Free Press/Simon & Schuster, $15.
The author argues that civic organizations not only promote democracy, they also boost the economy. Last year our reviewer, Fareed Zakaria, took issue with some of Mr. Fukuyama's points but found his analysis "dazzling in its intelligence and complexity."
 
THE AGE OF MIRACLES: Stories
By Ellen Gilchrist. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $11.95.
Rhoda Manning, a middle-aged, hard-drinking writer and frequent character in the author's fiction, appears in many of these 16 tales. Ms. Gilchrist "blends a sense of poignancy with an often outrageously Gothic humor," Diane Cole said in these pages in 1995.
 
THE FORBIDDEN BEST-SELLERS OF PRE-REVOLUTIONARY FRANCE
By Robert Darnton. Norton, $14.95.
The "pulping room" of the Bastille was the 18th-century precursor of the bureaucratic paper shredder. But the author shows that a large underground literary industry continued to publish Rousseau, Voltaire and many others. His is a "graceful, informative and humane book," John Sturrock wrote here last year.
 
DOSTOEVSKY'S LAST NIGHT
By Cristina Peri Rossi. Picador USA, $11.
Jorge is addicted to bingo, and being a suave European rather than a polyester-clad American, he goes to an analyst instead of Gamblers Anonymous. Jorge's musings on gaming and literature "are often eye-catching," Erik Burns said in the Book Review in 1995.
 
DIVIDED LIVES: The Public and Private Struggles of Three American Women
By Elsa Walsh. Anchor/Doubleday, $14.
The author examines the conflicts between the professional and personal lives of Meredith Vieira, a television news reporter; Alison Estabrook, a surgeon; and Rachael Worby, a conductor and the First Lady of West Virginia. The question of domesticity versus achievement is also at the heart of EINSTEIN'S WIFE: Work and Marriage in the Lives of Five Great Twentieth-Century Women, by Andrea Gabor (Penguin, $12.95). The subjects here range from the physicist Mileva Maric Einstein, whose famous husband appeared to feel threatened by her, to Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. Reviewing both books in these pages last year, Jill Ker Conway felt they gave insufficient credit to feminism but "will be useful grist for the theoretical mill." Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: Outsiders

 BODY:
To the Editor: The "summer people" syndrome that Suzanne Berne describes ("Strangers in a Familiar Land," July 21) is not limited to Cape Cod, but extends west at least as far as Lenox, Mass., where my wife and I recently vacationed.
The price of everything was two to three times as high as in major Eastern metropolitan markets (almost $200 a night for a no-frills room in an economy-class chain motel) and the year-rounders more than justified their reputation as a price-gouging "grumpy servant class" dedicated to parting the tourists from their money. 
 The few exceptions we found only proved the rule. On the basis of our recent experience in the Berkshires area we have deleted it, along with Cape Cod and the other highly touted Eastern Seaboard resorts, from our list of future summer vacation spots.
 
DONALD GRESCH
Lansing, Mich.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3010 words

HEADLINE: A New Taste for Postwar Co-ops

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THEY are often called "white bricks" or, simply, "plain vanilla" -- the flat-fronted apartment houses built in the 50's and 60's and early 70's on most major residential thoroughfares in Manhattan.
They are what the apartment seeker may think of as simply "postwar" -- despite the fact that the condominium towers erected in the 80's and 90's are postwar too. Built as rentals, many were later converted to co-ops. And until recently, apartments in these vanilla or beige or red-brick buildings -- buildings with their unmistakable triple-aluminum windows and their perforated screen "patios" and terrazzo-floored lobbies -- were, by and large, a tough sell. 
 "You couldn't give them away," said Janet Silver, who specializes in such buildings for Bellmarc Realty, a Manhattan brokerage firm known for offering moderate-priced apartments.
Buyers didn't like the way the buildings looked from the outside -- they weren't perceived as having "class." And beyond that, the buildings were castigated for their lower ceilings, their allegedly shoddier construction details -- like paper-thin walls and glued-on parquet-floor tiles -- and their kitchens and bathrooms, which reeked of their period, deemed unchic by acolytes of prewar buildings.
But things have changed. Faced with rising rents and a dearth of fine prewar spaces, apartment hunters are discovering the fine points of postwars: Many are cheaper, many have better views, many have garages and many have more-lenient boards, making tasks like simply getting in, or ripping out everything and putting in prewar details, a lot easier to accomplish. "Postwar buildings are surging -- because they had fallen farther and faster than the others and they had nowhere to go but up, way up," said Nat Plotkin, chief operating officer for S. Goodstein Real Estate.
Goodstein, which put up eight of these buildings in the 60's and early 70's as rentals, decided to start converting them to co-ops in the early 80's. In the mid-80's, as nonbuying tenants gradually left, the developers put the vacant apartments up for sale. When the market crashed, they changed their approach and rented out the unsold vacant apartments.
This April, those apartments were put on the market again. Prices for typical one-bedroom postwar units throughout Manhattan, Mr. Plotkin said, are at least 20 percent higher than they were two years ago.
But it's not only that prices are higher, realtors say. Apartments that just didn't sell -- for almost any price -- are finally starting to move.
"Remember that building that blew up in Gramercy Park?" asked Ms. Silver, referring to 32 Gramercy Park South, a postwar building that was the victim of a Con Edison steam explosion that spewed asbestos throughout the building. Even before the explosion the building had another problem -- inordinately high monthly maintenance charges. "We're even selling in there," Ms. Silver said. "People are buying everywhere."
As for postwar two-bedroom co-ops, the agent said they often traded at the asking price, with no negotiation. At 211 East 53d Street, a building put up by Rose Associates in 1958, "we sell that stuff in the first week," she said. At 170 East 87th Street, Apartment 11G went into contract quickly last month for $395,000 -- the same apartment that had sold in May 1993 for $251,000, according to the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate firm.
The trend is borne out in a survey of 1,172 closings completed last week by Mitchell, Maxwell and Jackson, real estate appraisers, for the Corcoran Group. In buildings built between 1945 and 1975, the average price per room citywide has increased from $52,178 to $54,553 in the last year. In a number of locations -- midtown east, Sutton/Beekman, Greenwich Village and Central Park West -- average room prices rose dramatically. In Greenwich Village, postwar room prices soared from $45,279 to $65,185 in one year.
Statistics released last week by Brown Harris Stevens, a Manhattan real estate brokerage, also show a marked trend in the larger postwar apartments. "Although prewar apartments are typically assumed to be more expensive than postwar apartments, this has not consistently been the case," said Larry Sicular, chief statistician for the company and co-author of its market report. In Manhattan's most expensive neighborhoods -- where Brown Harris does most of its business -- Mr. Sicular found that prices for 6-, 7- and 8-room postwar apartments "often exceeds the prewar price."
According to Dolly Lenz, Sotheby International Real Estate's top saleswoman, prices at the city's poshest postwars have soared within the last year. She named Imperial House, at 150 East 69th Street, as "a real white-brick building -- Liza Minnelli lives there -- with huge rooms, a circular driveway; a six-room apartment trades for $1.5 million."
The Sotheby's agent listed the Sovereign, a 1970's reddish-brown-brick building at 425 East 58th Street -- where two apartments were combined to make a $4.5 million, 6,600-square-foot 5-bedroom -- as well as 860-870 United Nations Plaza and 1001 Fifth Avenue, at 80th Street, as postwar buildings for millionaires. And, Ms. Lenz said, the buildings have waiting lists for apartments.
Mr. Sicular listed others: apartments at 857, 860 and 900 Fifth Avenue, all postwar buildings in the high 60's and low 70's, sold for over $2 million in the last 18 months.
EVEN at the low end, studio and one-bedroom postwar apartments without views, only a few years ago widely considered a drag on the market, are starting to move with alacrity, brokers say. Apartments that traded for as little as $85,000 are now trading for over $100,000.
And postwar apartments are selling faster than they were a year ago. On the East Side, they averaged 7.9 months to sell, compared with 8.2 months a year ago, according to the Real Estate Board of New York; on the West Side, they sold 9 percent faster than last year, in an average of 4.9 months.
"The most obvious reason for the surge is that rents in these buildings have gone up so dramatically," said Mr. Plotkin. "Three years ago, anyone signing a lease at market rate might pay $1,000 a month; now they'd be paying $1,600 to $1,700 a month. They might as well buy the apartment and stay in the building and have a totally secure tenancy." Mr. Plotkin argues that it's cheaper to buy than to rent. "And I'm not talking about after tax," he said. "I'm talking about before tax."
Mr. Plotkin furnished several examples of the price rise: at 201 East 17th Street, built in 1973, the Goodsteins have contracted to sell a one-bedroom apartment on the 24th floor for $130,000; in February of this year, the same apartment eight floors higher sold for $117,500. In November of last year, the same apartment on the 20th floor sold for $109,000, he said. (The most recent apartment sold belonged to the Goodsteins; the others were private sales.)
The Goodsteins, who decided in April to put their rental apartments on the market as soon as they become available, have put seven apartments up for sale. "We've closed on one," said Mr. Plotkin. "We have signed contracts on three more and we have accepted offers on two others, so there's just one without serious interest."
According to brokers, the smaller postwar apartments have become hot for several reasons: first, young people -- like Isabelle Wong, who just bought a studio co-op at 201 East 21st Street for $86,000, or Joseph Boggess who just bought a one-bedroom in the same neighborhood for $110,000 -- are finding they can actually buy an apartment for less than they would pay in rent, sometimes, as Mr. Plotkin said, even without factoring in the tax deductions for mortgage and maintenance.
Second, couples with young children -- couples still young enough to take on the permit and construction processes -- are buying several of these white-brick apartments and combining them, turning two one-bedroom apartments into a three-bedroom, for a lot less than they'd pay for a finished three bedroom. Then there are just the changing times, when the well-to-do are starting to live anywhere that takes their fancy: in a TriBeCa loft, a former sausage factory in Chelsea -- or a white-brick building near Second Avenue.
And there are other, more subtle differences. The boards in the white-brick buildings may be less stringent in admitting new residents and letting them do work on their apartments. And the staffs may be more cohesive than those in the newer buildings -- a subtle factor nevertheless mentioned by several new owners of apartments in postwar buildings.
"Look, these buildings were built 30 years ago and they're not trend-setting, they're not on the cutting edge, they're not glitzy," said Adam Rose, an executive vice president of Rose Associates, whose family has converted eight postwar rental buildings to co-ops. "But their operating costs are extremely predictable -- and modest. The doormen and building staff have been in place for a long time, and the buildings have settled into a very comfortable mode.
"They are what they are," he said. "No one's pretending they're going to win an architectural award, but at the same time, they're by no means embarrassing. It's just very solid and respectable housing."
Ms. Lenz of Sotheby International said one reason the postwars are booming is that "in a way, they're more practical."
"They have central or through-the-wall air-conditioning," she said. "Their systems are newer. Most postwars have 15-foot-wide living rooms, as compared with the tiny rooms in the 80's buildings. They have newer windows; they don't have leak problems -- and the buildings generally don't have summer work rules," which require that major alterations be done only in summer. In fact, Ms. Lenz said, "they don't have all the things that prewars have -- including the ridiculously tough boards that are getting worse."
In his comparison of larger prewar with same-sized postwar apartments, Mr. Sicular found that the postwar apartments that were sold tended to be on higher floors (because of the greater height of many postwars), that the postwars had better views (partly for the same reason) and that 70 percent of the postwars had maids' rooms, surprising because one tends to think that by the 60's, lifestyles did not include live-in help.
While many of the smaller nondescript postwars appear to be selling solely because they are cheap space, other postwars sell because of the differences Mr. Sicular found. Aside from the large prewar apartments facing Fifth Avenue, Central Park and the rivers, prewars generally don't have spectacular views. (Park Avenue's poshest apartments, after all, feature views of other Park Avenue prewar buildings.)
And prewars are old -- which is, to many buyers, a double-edged sword.
LIKE many apartment shoppers, Arlene Gray was convinced she wanted a prewar apartment.
"One of the reasons was that it was our understanding that with the construction of prewar homes one did not hear noises through the walls," said Mrs. Gray, who has just retired after 30 years with the city's Board of Education. "Prewar buildings seemed to me to have a character."
But after seeing a few prewar apartments -- the Grays lived in a nine-room house in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn -- she decided she "preferred new and shiny; the character shines through in the old buildings, but so does the musty smell and the amount of renovation required."
"When we looked at one of the bathtubs in a prewar I saw my husband cringe and I knew we'd have to change over," she said.
The Grays began looking for two-bedroom apartments, but ended up paying $325,000 for a one-bedroom, two-bath postwar co-op on East 56th Street near First Avenue. Before they closed on the 30th-floor apartment two months ago, the Grays spent time in the vacant space listening for noise.
"My husband wanted absolute quiet, and it's just not possible," she said. "There is an occasional rustle upstairs, but even he's a convert now. The building is very well constructed."
Another plus for postwars is the garage space often available underneath. "We have two cars, and my husband is delighted to park his downstairs," Mrs. Gray said. "I'm trying to figure out what to do with mine."
In the end, the couple decided to spring for the expensive 1,100-square-foot one-bedroom (they had looked at a two-bedroom in a postwar building on Sutton Place, for $30,000 less, but it had no view and was noisy), largely because of the size of the rooms, the renovated bathrooms, the balcony -- and perhaps most important, the view. "At night, we see the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building," Mrs. Gray said. "The view is worth everything."
Down in Greenwich Village, Michael Bolanos also treasures his view from the top floor of Georgetown Plaza, the 1967 postwar building at 60 East 8th Street, a co-op he says is run more like a condominium, with subletting allowed and the condominium-like provision that if the board doesn't like the person who wants to buy into the building, it must buy the apartment itself.
Mr. Bolanos, a young computer/Internet wizard who has been profiled in several newspapers' financial pages, bought his two-bedroom apartment in March and is proceeding largely to gut the place, knocking out the wall between the bedrooms and creating a huge master bedroom/media screening room, with an adjoining Japanese bath complete with shoji screens. He bought the apartment for $360,000. In January 1995, the same apartment two floors down, with presumably the same sweeping views, sold for $327,000. Mr. Bolanos's own apartment was in itself bought in 1992 -- at the depth of the recession -- for $299,000, according to the Corcoran Group, which made the most recent sale.
The ascending numbers, according to Barbara Corcoran, are at least partially caused by the diminishing supply of stunning prewar apartments. "People who two years ago hadn't considered looking for a postwar have nothing to see," she said. "They realize now that they may love the panache of the prewar and the sex appeal of a new condo -- but that they can get more space looking at a postwar."
Mr. Bolanos is delighted with his 1,400-square-foot apartment and initially compared it not to prewar apartments but to new buildings like Millennium Tower on West 67th Street, where two-bedroom apartments sell for over $1 million. Standing in his living room, which is stacked with the unhinged, painted trompe l'oeil hollow-core doors of his predecessor -- an interior designer who is helping him create his own look -- and which has a fluted faux-finish column lying, uprooted, at his feet, he outlined his strategy.
With electricians and designers and his own personal designer hovering nearby, Mr. Bolanos said he had told them -- he repeated it loudly -- they were to spend no more than $150,000 for the near-total renovation (the kitchen will stay pretty much the same as it was when he bought the place). The total, counting purchase price, would be $510,000, a figure he said he knows he could get back in lightning time, should he ever decide to put the place on the market.
Comparing his apartment to prewars, he said he thought his walls were actually thicker. (Later, he explained that he had looked mainly at prewars in brownstones, which were built as single-family houses and usually do not have the thick walls of prewar apartments.) He also said he thought the windows were better built, and certainly taller and glassier, permitting panoramic views like the ones he has from bedroom and living rooms -- one of the great views north over Greenwich Village and up to the Chrysler Building.
Mr. Bolanos, who consulted an astrologer over the closing date, said the apartment was, simply, "what I dreamt of all my life." Because the bank couldn't work it out soon enough to meet the date he wanted, he paid cash -- and got the mortgage later.
"This is a very cool place," he said. "The board president went along with me, and the doormen are convivial. And they've been really cool about the alterations."
ABOUT 17 blocks north, in the unlabeled area just north of Gramercy Park, Joseph Boggess, a fashion and makeup stylist, has also purchased a postwar apartment. But where Mr. Bolanos is relying on a crew of professionals -- and decorating in an earthy, Japanese style -- Mr. Boggess is doing much of the work at 245 East 25th Street himself and making his postwar apartment into a prewar apartment in terms of design.
Mr. Boggess is transforming what was a fairly boring space -- one walked right into a view of the front hall closet and then turned into a standard living room -- by adding little walls, putting in crown moldings around the ceilings, separating the rooms with French doors and, perhaps most strikingly, adding a paneled wainscotingaround the living room and the bedroom. The cost of totally renovating the $110,000 one-bedroom co-op apartment will approach $32,000, he said. A comparably renovated same-size prewar apartment, he said, might cost upward of $225,000.
What is unusual about his renovation is that it is so extensive for such a small apartment. According to Ms. Lenz, such "prewar wannabe" renovations are commonplace for the more expensive apartments. "About 80 percent of the postwar buyers do the whole prewar thing, with the crown moldings," she said, adding that two years ago she bought a big postwar apartment herself on the Upper East Side.
"I gut-renovated my place," she said. "I did everything you could possibly do." She said she had spent about $200,000 on prewar details and other renovations in her 1,700-square-foot, five-and-a-half-room apartment at 84th Street and Madison Avenue. "I put in moldings and pillars," she said. "I guess I subconsciously took the whole postwar building stigma thing to heart."
But now, she said, she's happy. "After all, I did choose to live here," she said, "and putting in the prewar touches gave me a better feeling about the whole thing."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 10; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 952 words

HEADLINE: HOME REPAIR;
How to Put Fluorescent Lighting to Its Best Use

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI 

 BODY:
IN 1938, the first practical fluorescent light fixtures were introduced in the American marketplace. These lights used less power and lasted longer than incandescent bulbs, so they quickly became the standard in offices, stores and industry.
Homeowners were less enthusiastic. They found the fluorescent light too cold. In addition, the fixtures were unattractive. Most people confined their use to places like kitchens, bathrooms or laundry rooms. 
 In recent years, however, manufacturers have worked to overcome these shortcomings. They applied the technology of triphosphor chemistry to develop tubes with a warmer glow. In an effort to replace the long tubes and unsightly fixtures, they developed compact fluorescents that are close to the size of an ordinary incandescent bulb, and they have screw-in bases so they can be used in standard incandescent fixtures.
A fluorescent tube differs from an incandescent bulb in structure and in the way it produces light. The inside of the tube is coated with a fluorescent powder called phosphor. The tube is sealed on either end with a cap that holds an electrode -- the cathode. An inert gas, usually argon or a mixture of argon and neon, and minute droplets of mercury are within the tube.
Current passing through the cathodes causes them to emit electrons that ionize (electrically charge) the gas. The ionized gas becomes a conductor allowing increased current (arcs) to jump from one cathode to the other. These arcs heat the mercury droplets into vapor that emits ultraviolet rays. The rays strike the phosphors on the sides of the tube and energize them into visible light. While all this sounds complicated, it happens quickly; the cathode discharges 120 arcs a second.
Besides the tube, fluorescent fixtures had two other components: a ballast unit and a starter. The ballast unit is essentially a transformer that controls the amount of current passing through the cathodes. The starter is a small metal canister with an inert gas and two bimetallic contacts enclosed in a glass bulb.
When the lamp is switched on, the starter allows current to flow from one cathode to the other so that they can warm up and generate a cloud of electrons. The ends of the tubes begin to glow, but no appreciable amount of light is generated. In a few seconds, the cathodes reach operating temperature and the starter contacts open. The current must now arc across the cathodes to complete the circuit, and the entire tube lights up. Once the lamp has started, the ballast regulates the current so the electrodes do not burn out prematurely. At first glance, it would seem that the compact fluorescents do not have the ballast or starter, but, in fact, miniature versions of these components are sealed in the glass globe.
Fixtures with starters are called pre-heat lamps, and they are efficient and reliable, if the starter is replaced periodically. Still, most people found the two- or three-second start-up delay annoying, so designers developed instant-start and rapid-start models.
Instant-start fixtures use a special ballast with a large transformer. The transformer generates a high voltage -- as much as four times the normal voltage -- that immediately arcs the current across the cathodes. Once the cathodes reach operating temperature, the voltage is cut back. Since the unusually high voltage can be potentially dangerous, most fixtures have an automatic cutoff switch in the tube sockets. This switch shuts off the power to the ballast whenever the tube is removed. Instant-start models can be easily recognized by the pin configuration at the end of the tubes. Instead of the usual twin pin contacts, there is only one pin at either end.
The disadvantage to the instant-start fixture is that the ballast is large and bulky. These units are being replaced by rapid-start models. In the rapid-start fixture, the ballast provides an initial low-voltage current that quickly warms the cathode. It then steps up the voltage to provide the necessary arc. Unlike instant-start units, the rapid-starts units use the standard double-pin tubes. Both instant and rapid-start units draw more current than the pre-heat models, but they are still more economical to run than incandescents.
W HILE most fluorescent fixtures are maintenance-free, occasionally problems can pop up. Sometimes a problem may be with the tube. For example, a light that frequently blinks on and off may be an indication the tube is near the end of its life. Try replacing it with a new tube. If the problem still persists, shut off the power and check the wiring.
Eroding electrodes will cause to ends of the tube to blacken. This is a sign that the tube is nearing the end of its working life and should be replaced.
Sometimes the tube ends emit an orange glow. This happens with pre-heat units as the cathodes are warming up. The warm-up phase and accompanying orange glow should shut down when the tube lights up. If it doesn't, replace the starter.
It's not uncommon for brand new tubes to flicker a little, but this should stop after a few minutes of operation. Constant flickering, however, may indicate that the ambient temperature is too low. Fluorescent lights work properly only when the temperature is at least 50 degrees. For low-temperature environments, you can purchase special low-temperature tubes and ballasts.
In some cases, the fixture may emit an audible hum. Usually this indicates a loose ballast unit that is vibrating against the fixture. You can correct this by tightening the mounting bolts. It may be, however, that the ballast has an internal short circuit. In this case, you'll have to replace the ballast with a quieter A-rated ballast.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Metamorphosis in Suburbia

BYLINE: By FRANK J. POPPER; Frank J. Popper, who lives in Highland Park, teaches in the Urban Studies and Community Health Department at Rutgers University.

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK

 BODY:
AMERICA is going global. America is going gray. How do the two trends play out -- and off -- against each other in suburbia?
Highland Park lies at the center of New Jersey, at the fringe of both the New York and Philadelphia metrowebs. It sprang up in the late 19th century as a streetcar appendage to New Brunswick across the Raritan River and eventually blended into New Jersey's vast middle-income suburbia. Today Highland Park has a population of 13,300, on 1.8 square miles. 
 The town orients itself along two intersecting main streets, Raritan and Woodbridge Avenues. Its businesses mostly group on or near the two streets, its homes mostly off them but an easy walk away. (The town has a large Orthodox Jewish population for whom the walking scale is a Sabbath convenience.) In less than a mile each that includes some residential stretches, Raritan and Woodbridge present 15 beauty salons, 15 car-repair shops, 9 car dealers and 4 banks.
The borough typifies the off-brand little mishmash towns where most Americans actually live. It doesn't matter if the towns are called cities or suburbs. Highland Park offers a small slice of the real America.
Like many such towns, Highland Park has become less provincial in the last decade, more open to national and global influences. In 1986 it had one bookstore; now it has three. The national financial revolution has eliminated two banks since 1986 and given the other four non-local ownership.
Food, always the most street-visible product of Highland Park, has become deprovincialized, too. The White Rose Diner gentrified itself with outside tile, the inside removal of cheesecake calendars and their replacement by thin-Elvis and '50's fin-car pictures. The town has two new health-food restaurants and a health-food store. New Chinese, Israeli, Italian, Spanish-Mexican and Thai restaurants have opened.
The town is starting to look more international. A decade ago it was almost entirely Catholic and Jewish, with a well-hidden black ghetto. Increasingly, South Asians, especially Indians, own its groceries and gas stations. Of its six video outlets (up from one in 1986), three sell only Chinese, Greek or Russian tapes. A recent high school graduating class of 80 had six immigrants from Taiwan, five from Russia, three from Korea, two from Poland, one each from Madagascar and Sierra Leone and four from Latin America.
Highland Park's native-born and earlier-immigrant populations are visibly aging. In 1986 the town had three bridal shops; today it has one. Some of the beauty salons seem to attract mainly an older crowd. The Homestead, a Cheers-like hangout in the Raritan beauty-salon district, took on the same look before its 1992 closing. School enrollments have dropped, particularly since the large Orthodox Jewish families tend to send their children to religious schools. School budgets have become harder to pass because the elderly often vote as a bloc against them.
The economic consequences of Highland Park's graying are beginning to tell. Raritan and Woodbridge have nine empty storefronts, plus a growing number of for-sale signs.
Despite the town's food fixation, it offers only two national franchises, Dunkin' Donuts and Blimpie. The national cholesterol, motel and big-box retail franchises appear in the commercial strips and malls nearby.
Highland Park cannot hope to retrofit Raritan or Woodbridge to compete. Instead renewal will come from using its exploding ethnicity and walkable scale to create new economic niches and mixes that strips and malls cannot match.
The prospects look good. The natural-foods restaurant abuts the Judaica shop. The Thai restaurant moves in among the beauty salons. It is the nation's oldest rite of social passage. In middle-income and suburban settings it usually works.
Highland Park will never become, say, a largely Korean or Russian American town. It has long been too polyglot -- too Jewish, Italian, African and Irish American -- for a monocultural outcome or even a mere multicultural one. Rather, Highland Park, like a lot of the country, is becoming transcultural.
Thus it no longer matters how many ethnicities can dance in the head of a small town. Nor is it so important whose family hit the boats and planes first. In America nothing sounds more hopeful than a foreign accent. No one has more ambition than a young immigrant. In Highland Park a small slice of the real America is getting new toppings.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Whitman in 2000? Not Too Early to Ask

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Governor Whitman spent lots of time in the last two years fielding the question about her Vice Presidential prospects. But the definitive answer, from elsewhere, came just before last week's Republican National Convention, and the answer was Jack Kemp. So predictably, yet not without reason, the political pundits and network correspondents moved on: What about the year 2000? they asked her.
It would be unseemly and not very good politics, of course, for Mrs. Whitman or any of her advisers to suggest that she would give serious consideration to a Presidential bid in four years. After all, Mrs. Whitman has vowed to campaign not only in New Jersey but around the country, for Bob Dole. Yet her close friends believe she will pursue the Republican Presidential nomination in four years, assuming of course, that Mr. Dole fails to defeat President Clinton in November. 
 The Governor took the opportunity last week to build upon her national base and lay some of the groundwork for a possible White House bid. She received plenty of air time, wielding the gavel as the convention's temporary chair and appearing on national radio and television news programs.
She also proved her loyalty to Mr. Dole and the party by not joining the protests of several fellow Republican governors, including George E. Pataki of New York, over abortion and immigration issues. She was noticeably absent from a news conference held by Governors Pete Wilson of California and William Weld of Massachusetts, on the convention floor, objecting to the platform. She did not mention abortion in her prime-time convention address.
Instead, she focused on her success cutting income tax rates, giving Mr. Dole's tax-cut plan some credibility and allowing her to broaden her support among Republicans.
But before she runs for President, Governor Whitman needs to win re-election next year and maintain her high ratings among New Jersey voters in a second term. She also needs to find a solution to the school financing problem that does not antagonize suburban parents and satisfies the New Jersey Supreme Court's concerns about the disparity between rich and poor districts. To maintain her status as a Republican star, she will have to make sure that her administration's fiscal policies don't blow up in her face.
The question then becomes not whether Governor Whitman wants a place on a national ticket, but can she capture the nomination of her own party when her stance on abortion rights alone has made her a lightning rod for criticism among the party's right wing?
One in eight of the convention's delegates described themselves as members of the Christian Coalition or as a Christian political activist. On the Christian Broadcast Network last week, as Pat Robertson talked about the religious right's victory in keeping the anti-abortion plank, a photo of Mrs. Whitman flashed on the screen when he mentioned the plank's opponents. To the religious right, she is an extremist, perhaps as much as the moderate wing views Pat Buchanan as an extremist.
The Republican Party's machinery, critical to the success of candidates in the Presidential primary process, is far more conservative than Mrs. Whitman. Look what happened to Bob Dole in the primaries. He wasn't conservative enough for some Republican primary voters.
And look at the party's platform adopted last week. In addition to the plank on abortion, the document opposes affirmative action and civil rights for homosexuals. Governor Whitman is on record favoring both affirmative action and civil rights for homosexuals. The plank also urges that welfare benefits to be eliminated to legal immigrants, as does the new welfare bill approved by Congress. The Whitman administration is seeking ways to maintain at least some public benefits for legal immigrants in New Jersey.
Many of the delegates who worked to create that platform are the same people who put together phone banks and control the get-out-the-vote efforts in Presidential primaries. Should Mrs. Whitman decide to enter the primaries, she is certain to face an uphill battle. Jack Kemp's selection as Mr. Dole's running mate has also resurrected his political career. If Mr. Dole does not succeed, Mr. Kemp would be more likely to win the party's nod four years from now.
"Four years is a very long time, and Dole may win, in which case, he might want a second term, or Jack Kemp may want to succeed him, and it may turn out that the timing is not right for her in a Presidential race," said Stephen A. Salmore, a Republican political strategist and professor at Rutgers University. "I think that she is interested in higher office, whether it is President, Vice President, or the U.S. Senate."
Former Governor Thomas H. Kean, who delivered the keynote address in 1988 and was similarly touted as a rising Republican star, said he thought Mrs. Whitman's future would stretch beyond New Jersey. "In political terms, she is very young," he said, "and I think that we will hear more on the national scene from Christie Todd Whitman."
For now, Mrs. Whitman will be working hard for Bob Dole, helping him erase President Clinton's commanding lead. No one doubts her loyalty or commitment.
If Mr. Dole succeeds, it will be interesting to see whether it is the conservative or the moderate wing of the party that takes credit. If he loses, Mrs. Whitman's political ambitions may depend on who gets the blame and who will control the Republican party in the future.

HEADLINE: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;
4-H Clubs Move Beyond 'Cows and Cooking' Image

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

 BODY:
Eleven-year-old Emily Wunderlich took her heifer, a Polled Hereford named Reba, to the Sussex County fair. They came home 4-H champions. To many people, that image -- a little girl leading a big animal and clutching a prize ribbon -- is what 4-H is all about.
But it's also about the Madagascan hissing cockroaches that Jean Flaherty exhibited in Sussex County this month and the ferrets that will be on display at the Bergen County Fair in September. It's about double Dutch jump rope at the Movers and Shakers Club in Hackensack, whose members have never been to a 4-H fair before in their lives. And it's about literacy and career preparation at the New Beginnings for Kids club at a Hackensack homeless shelter. 
 Talk to 4-H leaders for five minutes -- it may not take that long -- and you're sure to hear, "We're more than cows and cooking." They just wish more people knew it.
"Having the clover as an emblem is a two-edged sword," said Rita Natale, the regional 4-H agent for southern New Jersey. "People recognize it, but they recognize it for what it traditionally means. Like with the Girl Scouts, they think cookies. With the Boy Scouts, they think camping. With 4-H, they think farming."
But even in rural counties, clubs are likely to offer projects involving computers and remote-control cars along with the more traditional cow and craft programs.
"When people ask me what 4-H is, I tell them it's an adult who's interested in sharing something with five or more kids," said Judy Grief, a Bergen County leader. "It can be shoe repair. It can be dinosaurs. It can be oceans. It can be anything you want to do." In her case, it's Ther-Happy Pets, a club for children who want to take pets to visit the residents of nursing homes.
The programs that 4-H offers go beyond project clubs to include camping, public-speaking contests and small businesses like the Dairy Barn refreshment stand run by the Teen Council at the Sussex fair. If young people don't find their way to 4-H, the leaders will try to find their way to the young people, often working in collaboration with other community groups to make everybody's tight budgets stretch further.

Math in Disguise
In Cape May County, 4-H leaders have developed lessons in marine science for the nature center and the public schools. When children use lengths of clothesline to calculate the length of a dolphin or do a "whale blubber" experiment using cooking shortening, they are actually getting a dose of math in disguise.
In Somerset County, 4-H sponsors Careers and County Government Day, in which a child pairs up with an official -- the county engineer, a sheriff's deputy or perhaps a freeholder -- to learn what the job is like. In Newark, 4-H leaders used a Federal grant to set up an after-school program called the Soweto Academy in the Bishop Walsh housing project.
Everywhere 4-H goes, it takes its commitment to hands-on learning. A Rutgers Cooperative Extension statement says the mission of 4-H is to use a "learn by doing" approach to help young people become "competent, caring and contributing citizens of the world."
The roots of 4-H are in corn clubs for boys and canning clubs for girls that were established around the turn of the century to teach young people how to put the latest in science and technology to work on the farm and in the home. The club program became an official part of the Cooperative Extension Service about the time Congress created the agency in 1914; the term 4-H Club first appeared in a Federal document in 1918. By this time, 4-H had an emblem: a clover that had first been used, with only three leaves, by clubs in Iowa. References to three H's, head, heart and hands, first showed up in a statement of purpose for Nebraska clubs. Later the fourth H, health, was added.
But the agrarian society that produced 4-H was fading even at the time 4-H began. Over the years, the organization has shifted its focus from agricultural production to broader programs of youth development. By 1965, when a national 4-H policy committee endorsed expanding the program in urban areas, fewer than half of all 4-H members lived on farms. Today, nationwide, 12 percent of 4-H members live on farms. In New Jersey, the number is 3 percent.
"We haven't stopped serving rural America, but we're trying to serve urban areas, too," said Dr. Richard Clark, chairman of the 4-H Youth Development Department of Cook College at Rutgers University.
His department, which has an annual budget of $3 million provided by Federal, state and local governments, provides guidance for the state 4-H program while promoting flexibility in local projects. A key part of the job is making sure that volunteer leaders receive strong educational material based on research done at Rutgers and other universities.
More than 538,000 adult volunteers are involved in 4-H programs nationwide. In New Jersey, 4,300 adult volunteers supplement the work of the Rutgers extension staff, and more are always needed.
"If we had to rely strictly on professionals, it would not be possible to do what we do," Dr. Clark said.
The changes in 4-H programs have changed what it needs from its volunteers. Technical expertise is less important than a desire to work with young people.
"You don't teach them to raise a good cow," said Betty Jean Jesuncosky, the Cape May County 4-H agent. "You teach them to raise a good kid."

'Sportsmanship Is No. 1'
Keith Jones, the leader of Emily Wunderlich's club, Top O'Jersey Beef, knows that many of his club members will never grow up to be farmers. So, besides the basics of calving and tattooing, he tries to teach them responsibility, self-confidence and other lessons that will be useful no matter what they do. "Sportsmanship is No. 1," he said. "And unselfishness. I tell them no matter what happens, be happy for your peers."
Susan Murray-Flaherty never heard of 4-H when she was growing up in Queens. Then she moved to Sussex County, and her daughter, Jean, developed a passion for insects. Now she's leader of a club called BUGS (Bugs Under Group Study), sharing her home with hissing cockroaches, millipedes and the occasional tobacco hornworm.
Marge Cosh, leader of the another Sussex County club, the Wantage Sewettes, has been involved in 4-H all her life. "I'm 80 years old," she said. "My mother was a leader before me."
Barbara Milton, who is the 4-H program associate for Bergen County, has always thought of 4-H as an urban program. She first learned about it as a social worker in a substance abuse program in Middlesex County. Now, in densely populated Bergen County, she wants 4-H to reach out to "at-risk kids, wherever they are."
The problem, she says, is that the term "at risk" is divisive. "People are polarized by it," she said. "Sometimes it is translated just to mean the inner city. But suburban kids are also at risk."
Her efforts to expand the traditional 4-H base include a club at Hackensack High School to help students prepare for the Scholastic Assessment Test, the Movers and Shakers club at Trinity Baptist Church, where members receive health and cooking classes along with their double Dutch jump rope lessons, and the New Beginnings for Kids club at the homeless shelter.
New Beginnings, whose name was chosen by children at one of the early meetings, presents special challenges for 4-H, not the least of which is what to do in a club whose members might be able to attend only a few meetings before their family moves again. That means short-term projects: discussing endorphins and neurotransmitters in a lesson on how the brain works, making a club banner, learning about jobs involving horses from another 4-H leader.
Ms. Milton and Jeanine DaSilva, the club leader, say the club will succeed if it gives the children two things: a little stability in their schedule, and a glimpse at a range of career opportunities.
Using 4-H this way can save lives, said Ms. Milton, who grew up on welfare in Camden housing projects.
"My mom said it very clear," Ms. Milton said. " 'The way out is school.' I heard it very loud and clear. It's still clear.
"But we didn't know what 4-H was in Camden. A few weeks ago my mom called and said she was driving along and saw this green clover with a 4-H on it. And so she read the sign and ended up at the Camden County 4-H Fair. She had been born and raised there, and she had never been to the fair.
"And she called me, she was so excited about everything she had seen, and she said: 'Now I know what you do. Now I know what 4-H is all about.' "
"That's what I want to do, to take that green clover into communities that have never heard of it."

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: EAST HARLEM;
World's Fair as Architectural Prologue

 BODY:
THE Museum of the City of New York will take visitors back to the future with an exhibit titled "Drawing the Future: Design Drawings for the 1939 New York World's Fair," which opens Wednesday. The fair was conceived in 1935 by New York business executives to help alleviate the economic and social strains brought about by the Depression. It provided an optimistic vision of the future and employment for many out-of-work artists and architects, who were instructed to "build the world of tomorrow with the tools of today."
Among the structures whose designs are featured in the exhibit are the Aviation Building, the Hall of Special Events and the Chrysler Motors Building. Proposed, but never constructed, was the Micromegas Building (left), by the Austrian emigre, artist and science fiction writer Frank R. Paul. It would have been crowned by a giant figure dressed as a Roman centurion. 
 "Drawing the Future: Design Drawings for the 1939 New York World's Fair," Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, Wednesday through Jan. 19; Wednesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sunday, 1 P.M. to 5 P.M.; free, with suggested donation of $5 for adults, $4 for seniors and students and $10 for families; (212) 534-1672.
