HEADLINE: Borders Fall To Trade in Classic Autos

BYLINE: By KEITH MARTIN 

 BODY:
COLLECTIBLE cars live in their own economic world. In the late 1980's, when the Japanese yen was strong and the American dollar was weak, buyers flocked from Japan to snap up vintage Ferraris, Maseratis and other exotic autos in the United States. They also filled their garages with huge American-made gas guzzlers from the 60's.
At the same time, a generation of European baby boomers came of age and went shopping in America for the old Jaguar or Austin Healey that their parents had not been able to afford when new. Armed with relatively strong British pounds, Swiss francs and German marks, European buyers sent thousands of European cars back across the Atlantic to their ancestral homes. 
 Why were the European cars here in the first place? In the immediate postwar years, the American economy was the world's strongest by far, and the United States was the most lucrative market for sports cars and high-end luxury makes. Americans bought up to 90 percent of the Ferraris, Jaguars and MG's of that era.
But with the resurgence of a global economy in the 80's, foreign collectors descended on the American collector-car market, buying up sports cars at escalating prices and driving many American collectors out of the market. It was not uncommon to see Ferrari prices double in a year; one model, the Daytona coupe of '68 to '73, went from $25,000 to nearly $500,000 in five years.
As each collectible car was loaded into containers on ships bound for Japan or Europe, American collectors lamented that the cars were gone for good.
That has not been the case. The collapse of the overleveraged Japanese economy has brought high-end cars, along with exclusive golf courses and glittering office towers, back to the market. A flood of cars valued at $100,000 to $5 million has come back from Japan in the last year. These exotics are generally from collections repossessed by banks that had extended too much credit.
But while the Japanese are divesting themselves of top-dollar classics, niche markets have opened. Customized, ground-hugging "low riders" are popular, and savvy American dealers are snapping up custom cars at local meets and doubling their money through sales to enthusiasts in Japan. Another sales bubble has occurred with Alfa Romeo GTV coupes in the $8,000 to $15,000 range and Ferrari 246 GT Dino coupes at $50,000 to $75,000. The Japanese generally prefer closed cars to convertibles.
Collector cars also tend to move toward countries with favorable tax laws. There has been a boomlet recently in sports-car exports to Australia, since that country's tariffs on imported autos -- at least 50 percent -- do not apply to cars more than 25 years old. Consequently, pre-1970 MG's, Austin Healeys, Jaguars and the like sit on the docks of Los Angeles and Houston, bound for Brisbane and Melbourne.
As the global economy improves, both high- and low-dollar cars are likely to keep moving from continent to continent. But the Japanese are conspicuously absent from the high-end market, and they are unlikely to return until their banks have forgiven speculators' excesses of the late 80's.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN;
A Funky Renewal Transforms Fifth Avenue

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
Along Fifth Avenue, what was once a strip of empty storefronts, bodegas and Chinese restaurants with bulletproof windows is changing into one of Brooklyn's most eclectic commercial thoroughfares.
Several cafes, a new herb store offering root tonics and a number of antique stores have sprouted along Fifth Avenue, the main artery of the "other" Park Slope, a working-class neighborhood that was once Italian and that is now largely Hispanic. Near St. John's Place, Carmel Roker is doing a brisk business in roti and coco bread. An old funeral parlor on Fifth and President Street is now Mike & Tony's, a steak and cigar parlor. A few blocks south, a gay bar, an organic meat market and a shop specializing in Negro Baseball League memorabilia have opened in the last year. 
 Real estate agents, business people and community leaders say the renewal of Fifth Avenue, particularly between Flatbush and Ninth Street, is in large part due to rents that are much lower than on Seventh and Flatbush nearby.
And several dilapidated buildings have been rehabilitated in the last year with an infusion of public dollars. On the corner of Garfield Place, for instance, an abandoned building that was literally raining bricks has been renovated by the Fifth Avenue Committee, a community group, into apartments for low-income families. Last December, Irene Lore, the owner of Aunt Suzie's restaurant, turned the ground floor of the apartment building into Luna Park, a cafe and ice cream parlor.
To be sure, Fifth Avenue isn't trendy TriBeCa yet, or even the next Seventh Avenue, Park Slope's affluent marketplace two blocks east. But shopkeepers like Ms. Roker, a Haitian immigrant who opened Carmel's Bakery three years ago, are itching to go upscale.
"I'd like Fifth Avenue to be like Seventh Avenue," she said, standing behind a counter laden with coconut cake and sweet-potato pies. "Before, a business would open and close very quickly. Now you see business coming, little bit by little bit."
But Brad Lander, executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee, is more guarded about the prospect of swift gentrification.
"The mission of the Fifth Avenue Committee is to preserve the racial and economic diversity of lower Park Slope and to insure that all residents benefit from the area's development," he said, "which means to make sure low-income people are not displaced."
In this respect, Fifth Avenue faces a challenge not uncommon in New York City neighborhoods: how to revitalize a somewhat rundown strip without pushing it beyond the reach of the mostly working-class families who live nearby. Mr. Lander's solution is to make sure that residential rents remain affordable.
It was precisely Fifth Avenue's lower rents and decidedly funkier flavor that drew Catherine Blake, a former carpenter, from Windsor Terrace. She and a partner, Christine Marinoni, are sprucing up a storefront on the corner of Sackett Street and Fifth Avenue and turning it into the Rising Cafe. The restaurant, scheduled to open later this month, will serve coffee, snacks, wine, beer and, Ms. Blake hopes, poetry and song.
"I much prefer the atmosphere down here," she said. "There's a funkier feel. It's a little more creative and not as stuffy as Seventh Avenue." SOMINI SENGUPTA

Dr. Lyubisheva And Mr. Casey

Dr. Lyudmilla Valereyevna Lyubisheva, a daughter of Svetlana and Valery Lyubisheva of Nizhny Novgorod, Russia, was married yesterday to Lukas Casey, a son of Pam Lewis of West Hartford, Conn., and Robert E. Casey of Stonington, Conn. John Raabe, a Connecticut justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Lake Waramaug Club in New Preston, Conn.
Dr. Casey, 28, was until recently an eye surgeon at the Nizhny Novgorod Ophthalmological Center. She graduated from the Nizhny Novgorod Medical Institute. Her father, is the former chief of the regional highway patrol in Nizhny Novgorod. Her mother is a chemical researcher at the Nizhny Novgorod Regional Eye Clinic.

The couple met in Nizhny Novgorod in 1993, when Mr. Casey was working for the International Finance Corporation as part of a privatization team auctioning off businesses and farms.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
He's a Real Detective. And He Plays One on TV.

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
DURING his 25 years as a New York City police officer and homicide detective, many of them in the East Village, James Pelliccio has seen his share of bloody endings.
"I've probably stood over 1,000 dead bodies in my life," he said last week, sitting in a diner at Second Avenue and Fifth Street as he sucked on yet another cigarette, chased down by yet another cup of black coffee. 
 But as a character actor who often plays street thugs, blowhard cops or mafioso enforcers in films and television shows like "Bullets Over Broadway," "Law and Order" and "Married to the Mob," Mr. Pelliccio, usually ends up with a slug in the back or a knife in the gut. His character rarely makes it to the closing credits. "I must have watched my funeral a half dozen times," he said with a grin. "My mother still cries every time I get iced on film."
With his rough-hewn features, macho swagger and penetrating steel-blue eyes, Mr. Pelliccio, 45, has the kind of face that makes both criminals and casting directors quake. Mr. Pelliccio is "not exactly the boy-next-door type," said his agent, Michael Amato. His boss at the Ninth Precinct, Detective Squad Commander Arthur Monahan, agrees. "Whether you're good or bad, James isn't the kind of guy you want to meet on a street corner late at night," he said.
After a decade playing the wise guy, Mr. Pelliccio, whose stage name is James Reno, is "ready to diversify," as he puts it. Two weeks ago, he landed a role in the Off-Broadway show "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding." He plays Anthony Nunzio, the groom's blustery father, in the roving audience-participation farce that showcases a tumultuous Italian wedding.
But in a city awash with professional -- though mostly unemployed -- actors, Mr. Pelliccio finds that many directors, casting agents and fellow thespians don't take him seriously. Although he is a member of the Screen Actors Guild, his formal training is minimal and as a result, he says, he is often looked down on by other actors who see him as a moonlighting off-duty cop. "I may not have gone to Julliard," he said, "but I'm still up there like the rest of them pouring my guts out."
In a sense, Mr. Pelliccio has been an actor much of his life. Soon after joining the police force in 1969, he was assigned to a wide variety of undercover operations, playing parts ranging from drug dealers and mafia underlings to wayward street punks. In many instances, his acting skills have kept him out of harm's way. Not once, he said, has his cover been blown by a faulty performance. In one of his more sensational assignments, Mr. Pelliccio was sent to Sing Sing, where, dressed in prison garb, he pretended to be a convicted hit man set for an early release. He said he gained the confidence of an imprisoned crime boss intent on killing two former associates, and his work headed off the bloodshed and helped lead to the capo's conviction.
His first real break in the theatrical world came in 1981, when he stumbled onto the set of "Ragtime," which was being filmed on East 11th Street. He offered himself as a security guard on his own time, but after a few days watching the set, he was hired to play a turn-of-the-century beat cop.
Despite extensive work as an undercover agent, Mr. Pelliccio has found acting on stage nerve-racking. Just before opening in "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding," he did his best to keep cool but confessed to a case of butterflies. "I've been in gunfights where I was less afraid," he said.
The contradictions of law enforcement and theater are not lost on Mr. Pelliccio, who tosses out Tennessee Williams quotes and waxes philosophical with a wiseguy New Yorkese patter interspersed with expletives. In police work, he says, a good cop keeps his emotions bundled up inside; the opposite is true in theater.
"Acting has helped me get in touch with myself and feel O.K. with who I am," he said. "It's very gratifying."
Mr. Pelliccio, who was born and raised on working-class Staten Island, still lives there, a few minutes from his parents, Italian immigrants whom he describes as "Old World people who get teary-eyed just by hearing the name Joe DiMaggio." Nine years ago, after returning home from the set of "Married to the Mob," Mr. Pelliccio found a note from his wife, telling him she had left home with their two children. They have since divorced and Mr. Pelliccio acknowledges that the long, erratic hours of police work and his disciplinarian style have made family life, at times, difficult. His 16-year-old son, whom he sees on weekends, thinks of him as a Marine sergeant, he says.
"Cops have this fix-it mentality," he said, looking away. "They think they can sweep into a situation like a white knight and make everything fine in a snap."
Even for a self-described tough guy, maintaining two careers isn't easy. Last week, after a long day working on a homicide case, Mr. Pelliccio's exhaustion was apparent. On this night, he sniffled between drags on his cigarette, nursing the remnants of a cold he says he caught from "kissing 40 strangers" during "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding." Nattily dressed in a charcoal double-breasted suit and brown wingtip shoes, he explained that looking the part of a detective is half his job.
"Mind you, this isn't expensive," he said, tugging at his lapels. "I mean, if someone spits up or dies all over this, you don't want to wear it again. You never get the smell of a D.O.A. out of your threads."
Although he is long past putting in his 20 years and could retire on a full pension like many of his peers, Mr. Pelliccio says he's not ready to turn in his shield. "So much of my identity is tied to being a cop," he said, his hands, as always, gesticulating. "Leaving the department is not as easy as cutting off a boil."
He will, however, retire when he feels secure that he can make it as a full-time actor.
"All I need is the big break," he said, displaying a rare flash of vulnerability. His family is also eager for him to leave the police force. "They're proud when they see me on film or on stage," he said. "But more important, they don't have to worry about me getting killed in a blaze of gunfire."

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:

No 4-Footed Fare
 
Q. What is the policy on dogs riding on the subway? A friend of mine said the M.T.A. had told her dogs were welcome as long as their owners paid their fare.
A. It's so touching to hear a public servant laugh. Do dogs pay fares, was the question. You should have heard the snickers.
Dogs ride free, said Termaine Garden, a Transit Authority spokesman, but that doesn't mean they're particularly welcome. The only dogs unequivocally allowed to ride the rails are "working dogs," i.e., seeing-eye dogs or police pups. Transit Authority code stipulates that the only way you can bring an unemployed dog onto the train is in a container (preferably something other than a handbag, Mr. Garden said).
Violators can be ejected from the subway and fined $25. Through the end of July, 261 summoneses had been issued this year for subway dog smuggling -- about one a day.
What about other animals?
"I guess cats would be O.K. if they're contained," Mr. Garden said. "But no snakes or monkeys or anything. No way. Those are wild animals."
 
 
 
In Memoriam, Maybe

 
Q. I've noticed pairs of shoes hanging from New York City telephone wires. I heard a rumor the shoes had something to do with marking drug turf, but I've seen them all over the city. What's the origin or meaning of such a ritual?
A. A very good question. A sampling of several urban anthropologists came up with no definitive answers, but a handful of intriguing theories.
Jeffrey Fagan, director of the Center for Violence Research and Prevention at Columbia University and a longtime student of adolescent street culture, said the tradition probably dated to the late 1970's. His theory is that the shoes over the wires originally acted as a sort of tombstone, marking the site where a gang member or other local youth had died. "It's like a totem pole in Indian mythology," Mr. Fagan said.
His opinion was seconded by Bill Kornblum, professor of sociology at CUNY, who polled his research subjects from city housing projects about the ritual. "Friends would throw their sneakers up there knowing they'd be there forever," said Mr. Kornblum, adding that his sources thought the practice had begun in the early 1980's.
A researcher on Mr. Fagan's team, David Tufino, suggested a different meaning. Mr. Tufino, who grew up in Harlem in the early 80's, said the shoes were trophies and turf markers from gang or neighborhood fights. "They'd beat a guy up and steal his sneakers and throw them up there and have him go home barefooted," he said. "It meant you couldn't come into a neighborhood and leave with your shoes." He added that although the meaning might differ from neighborhood to neighborhood, memorials in Harlem were generally murals, not shoes.
Both Mr. Fagan and Mr. Korn blum cautioned that the shoes didn't necessarily mean a gang was active in an area, and said that the ritual, like many in urban areas, had probably become too widespread to retain any set meaning.
"It may have had a very specific meaning at one point," Mr. Fagan said, "but at some point it diffuses throughout the culture through mimickry or imitation or fashion. It's like the Rhodes Scholar at Oxford who wears baggy pants and unlaced sneakers to school."
 
 
 
Benvenuto

 
Q. On the corner of Broadway and 41st Street, I saw a group of starch-white sailors looking bewildered. Eavesdropping, I heard the mellifluous tones of a foreign tongue -- Italian, I think. Am I correct? Was the Italian Navy in port?
A. Si.
Since Tuesday, the city has been host to the crew of the San Giusto, a 450-foot, 8,000-ton amphibious-warfare and training vessel from Livorno. The ship, on a training tour of the United States, last called at the megaport of Norfolk, Va., and heads to Boston on Tuesday.
The San Giusto, carrying some 500 sailors, is docked next to the Intrepid, at Pier 86 at West 46th St. It is open to the public today until 7 P.M. JESSE McKINLEY

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Retirement Plan for Small Business Would Help the Boss, Too

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT the Auto World repair shop near here, a co-owner, Charles Sullivan, is constantly clipping how-to articles to help train his mechanics.
But most of the reports have nothing to do with fixing cars. They are about retirement, and they represent "a lot of ground-level work to educate them" on the need to save for it, he said. 
 In cajoling young mechanics to take the long view and invest in the company's 401(k) plan, Mr. Sullivan, who is 40, has been doing exactly what many lawmakers have long hoped that business owners would do. And Mr. Sullivan said a proposed law to create a simpler retirement plan would help his six workers save more and also enable him to set aside a lot more money.
But while the plan, which was approved by Congress this month, would probably achieve what lawmakers had hoped, increasing the number of retirement plans offered by small businesses, critics said the proposal would benefit business owners more than their employees.
That is because, unlike other pension and savings plans, the new program would not limit the amounts that owners could save for retirement based on how much their employees contributed into a plan. Critics of the bill fear that without the economic incentive, there will be no more Charles Sullivans, urging their employees to contribute, and that in the silence, workers will save less instead of more.
 Congress approved the new plan -- called the Savings Incentive Match Plan for Employees, or Simple -- on Aug. 2 as part of the bill that would increase the minimum wage. The plan was backed by the National Federation of Independent Business, the main lobby for small business, and some lawmakers said it was approved partly as a trade-off to win support from the group for the wage increase.
President Clinton is expected to sign the bill this month, and companies could start the savings plans in January.
THE new accounts would work, in one sense, like mini-401(k) plans, with employers matching the tax-deferred contributions made by their workers. Only businesses with 100 or fewer workers would be eligible.
The law would require companies, in most cases, to match dollar for dollar any amounts that employees donated, up to 3 percent of their salaries, with a cap of $6,000 a year. That would be fairly generous compared with most 401(k) plans, which typically match 50 cents to the dollar.
The questions about the possible impact of the changes are important because more than 50 million Americans work for companies with fewer than 100 employees, and only about one-eighth of those employers offer retirement plans, Labor Department figures show. About 24 percent of companies with 50 to 100 employees offer 401(k) plans, compared with 96 percent of companies with more than 5,000 employees, according to Access Research Inc. of Windsor, Conn.
Many workers at small companies are in relatively low-paid service jobs and find it difficult to save, and they have become more vulnerable in recent years as many cost-conscious employers have become less willing to provide fixed benefits for retirement.
The new type of accounts "will increase the number of companies with savings plans, without question," said Karen Ferguson, the director of the Pension Rights Center, a worker advocacy group in Washington.
"But the reality is that low-paid workers are still not going to be able to afford to save," she said. "Simple is simply an effort to strip the protections for workers so that their bosses can save more."
Indeed, in an effort to encourage business owners to adopt the new plans, lawmakers dropped an intricate series of fairness tests common to other types of retirement plans that limit how much managers can contribute into their accounts. The aim of the tests is to insure that plans are not "top heavy," created mainly to enrich the officers of a company. So the rules tied the amount that owners and managers could set aside to the level of participation by lower-paid workers. These rules, which made setting up savings plans complicated and expensive, often discouraged small businesses from offering any plan.
Now that small businesses will be able to set up plans without the limitations or extensive paperwork of the fairness rules, business owners will be able to put away up to $6,000 a year whether or not their employees save anything.
Joseph Blumenthal, who owns Downtown Sounds, a musical instrument retailer in Northampton, Mass., said the new rules would allow him to increase his tax-deferred retirement savings.
Each year, he has put $2,000 into an individual retirement account, his only tax-deferred savings vehicle. But if he had started a 401(k) or a traditional pension for himself and his four full-time workers, he would have lost the right to deduct the I.R.A. contributions from his taxes, because they can be written off only by people who are not covered by other plans.
Mr. Blumenthal also said that few of his employees, who make $18,000 to $22,000 a year, had shown any interest in saving for retirement. And if he had started a traditional plan and hardly anyone else had participated, his contribution into his own plan would have been minimal because of the fairness tests.
So, he said, Simple might be "a win-win plan" for his store because his workers would get a retirement program and he would be able to increase his own savings.
Mr. Sullivan, the co-owner of Auto World, said he would also increase his retirement savings to the maximum $6,000, up from the $4,200 he now contributes, an amount limited by the fairness tests.
Mr. Sullivan, who is married and has three young children, said he had read hundreds of the articles he clipped about the need to amass huge savings for retirement. He earns $57,000 a year, and he said he shouldn't be denied a chance to tap into more of the power of tax-deferred savings just because he owns part of the company.
He said that switching to the Simple plan, which requires little paperwork, from a 401(k) would save his company at least $800 a year in administrative costs.
As a result of his exhortations to his workers, three of his employees have set aside 3 to 5 percent of their pay in the 401(k). But one of Mr. Sullivan's employees, Wayne Peron, who is 33, said he was still contributing just 1 percent of his salary.
"I'd like to put more," said Mr. Peron, who is married, owns a house and has a 3-year-old daughter. "But right now I'm trying to figure out how to make ends meet with the mortgage and everything else." He said that once he paid off an auto loan next year, he would likely increase his contributions if Auto World switched to the new program, because of the higher company match.
MS. FERGUSON, of the Pension Rights Center, said that if most workers are required to save as a condition of getting contributions from their employers, many workers will never build much of a nest egg. And society could face huge costs in providing for them later.
But Jon Garvey, an Auto World mechanic who sets aside 5 percent of his salary, said the new plan would be better than nothing. He said that most small businesses were "running their operating expenses out to the penny" and that the plan might be the only type that many businesses could afford to offer.

 The Treasury will report the Federal budget deficit for July. It is expected to be wider than the $13.6 billion deficit in July 1995 because of special factors, but is still on track to end the year substantially smaller than last year.

 The Labor Department releases its report on initial claims for state unemployment benefits for the latest week.

FRIDAY
 The Commerce Department reports on new orders for durable goods for July. A decline of five-tenths of a percentage point is expected, after June's decline of six-tenths of a point. The June decline was concentrated in the aircraft sector.

HEADLINE: Rethinking 'Harm Reduction' for Glasgow Addicts

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: GLASGOW

 BODY:
Every day dozens of heroin addicts come into the office of Alex Meikle, a sociologist who has worked for six years in Possil, a low-income Glasgow neighborhood, which he calls "the heroin shooting gallery of the world."
They seek methadone treatment to get off heroin and help with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, or hepatitis C infections. And they tell heartbreaking stories of addictions that began when they were as young as 11, living in families where brothers, sisters and sometimes parents took drugs. 
 "We offer them a chance of sorts," said Mr. Meikle, an intense 36-year-old. "Those who show up are at the end of their line: Their immune system is gone. Their veins are collapsing. They can't shoplift, steal or deal drugs anymore, and they are wondering how did they get there."
Drug addiction in Scotland had been a problem for at least three decades, surfacing in a big way in the late 1970's and the 80's when heavy industries like shipbuilding and manufacturing collapsed, leaving legions of unemployed, including nearly 40 percent of the residents of the Possil projects.
Glasgow, a city of 650,000, recognized the dimension of the problem and took it on with a broad approach called "harm reduction." Drug addicts were given clean needles and the heroin-substitute drug methadone. The goal was to prevent the spread of AIDS from shared needles, and to reduce the drug dealing, shoplifting and mugging that addicts engaged in to support their habits.
But now the problem is back, fueled by a younger generation of drug addicts, and questions are being raised by many people, including former addicts, who assert that harm reduction has become another way of perpetuating addiction.
"Harm reduction really sounds good, but it doesn't work," said Kerry Condron, 18, who became addicted at age 11, smoking marijuana before moving on to heroin. She took methadone legally until she decided to stop it all a year ago.
"It simply adds to the resources keeping people on drugs," said Lorraine Fraser, 29, a former heroin addict who belongs to the Calton Athletic Group, an organization that advocates total abstinence.
Scotland's drug problem, one of the most serious in Europe, has received particular attention this year as a new movie, "Trainspotting," became a hit, first in Britain and then in the United States.
While places like Scotland, the Netherlands and Switzerland have chosen approaches that allow access to drugs by addicts, some in Europe now argue that those policies have failed.
Besides, many new addicts now shun methadone in favor of heroin cocktails, mixing heroin with temazepam, a tranquilizer in the same family as Valium. A result has been a significant increase in drug overdose deaths.
"Last year, 104 died of overdoses," Kevin Orr, a police superintendent and 31-year-veteran detective who is drug coordinator for Glasgow, said in an interview at the Strathclyde police headquarters downtown. "This is a big number. No other city in the United Kingdom compares with us. We have become notorious."
In a study conducted three years ago by drug counseling agencies, researchers found that Glasgow had 8,500 hard-core "drug injectors." Seventy percent were infected with hepatitis C, which can lead to long-term liver damage. The city says there may be another 24,000 who have a "lesser" heroin-shooting habit. Marijuana, hashish, cocaine and LSD are also common.
In New York City, with a population of seven million, Dr. Blanche Frank, an epidemiologist with the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services, estimates that there are 200,000 "narcotic abusers," perhaps half of whom use heroin.
"Heroin is the queen of drugs in Glasgow," said Dr. Laurence Gruer, 43, who heads the H.I.V. and Addictions Resource Center at the Greater Glasgow Health Board. "It's part of the drug culture in Scotland that shooting heroin is the most effective way of getting the highest buzz," he said in his office at Ruchill Hospital.
In the last four to five years, there has been a large increase in the number of drug users who contract infectious diseases like hepatitis C and B, AIDS or other medical problems like clots in their veins, legs and arms, and weakened heart muscles.
Law enforcement authorities have focused on tackling the drug supply problems at the source. Police action has expanded overseas. A senior drug enforcement intelligence official here said Glasgow's police were now working with intelligence agencies from mainland Europe and Latin America.
Last year Glasgow mounted a large anti-drug operation, resulting in the arrest of 6,000 dealers and users, two-thirds of whom were unemployed. Drugs with a street value of $8 million were confiscated. But many here say efforts like that one are sabotaged by the city's own approach to the drug problem, which involves confiscating illegal drugs and dispensing legal ones instead.
Maxie Richards, an Irish former schoolteacher who has turned her home into an addict reception center, argues that harm reduction has become a vested interest of the social service industry, and with only one purpose: keeping social peace at the cost of dispensing drugs. The condition for entry at her center is willingness to quit "cold turkey."
Sitting in her modest, one-story home in the upper-middle-class neighborhood of Bearsden, surrounded by eight addicts, half of whom have stopped using drugs (the others are in treatment on methadone), Ms. Richards and her supporters are uncompromising.
"Social workers have too much power as it is," she said. "Methadone gives doctors much more power either by dispensing it or threatening to withhold it. The whole harm reduction approach is our downfall if we stuck with it. It's like saying, If you have to take drugs we can live with it."
Ann Dott, 31, an unemployed former addict, said, "I had to learn how to ask for a different kind of help, because those who handled me -- the doctors, the social agencies -- were telling me I was a hopeless case, and I believed it."
She glanced at her 11-year-old nephew across the room and said: "I want him to know all that. I want him to see and hear, because the drug situation here is so big it cannot be tackled by harm reduction. I mean I can walk into every single pub in Glasgow and find the drug dealer."
In fact, Ms. Dott says, she has to look no farther than her own family, where her two brothers, her sister and her mother are all addicts.
"What I would like to do is get some of this money being spent and put it in a total abstinence program," she said.
Detective Orr agrees that the problem is huge but argues that harm reduction is an effective approach because no matter how big the effort to ban drugs is going to be, it will never totally eradicate drugs as long as people seek them.
"It was against the ethos of the police to carry clean needles or support methadone," he said. "We come from a political culture that believes in kicking doors. But the driving force here is the amount of death."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maxie Richards, far left, has turned her Glasgow home into a reception center for addicts willing to quit drugs. On the sofa, from left, are Janice Wilson, Susan Murray and William Blair. (Lindsay Robertson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Says Dole Tax Cut Could Inflate Deficit Woes

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton swung back hard today at Bob Dole's proposed 15 percent income tax cut, arguing that the Republican proposal would either balloon the deficit or force deep cuts in programs like Medicare and that his own proposed tax breaks were better and more affordable.
"The American people have a clear choice in this election," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address. "We agree on one thing: Americans do deserve a tax cut. But we must choose between a tax cut that responsibly balances the budget and one that puts our economy at risk, between one that is targeted to help working families pay for education, health care and other pressing needs, and one that is indiscriminate." 
 The President never mentioned Mr. Dole by name, and he referred to the Republicans only as "our opponents." But with Mr. Dole's proposal drawing support in public opinion surveys, Mr. Clinton's meaning and motive were clear enough: He has no intention of letting Mr. Dole one-up him in the tax-cutting debate, but also no intention of joining the Republicans in proposing large, across-the-board reductions now.
Although he insisted that he did not watch any of the Republican National Convention on television this week, Mr. Clinton obviously absorbed enough of its themes and potential appeal to feel compelled to recite once more his own proposals for a $500 per child tax credit for middle-class families, new tax credits and deductions to help finance the cost of college education and an increase in the earned income tax credit for the poorest working families.
The White House issued worksheets showing how such proposals could provide tax cuts of up to $2,000 a year for a family of four, depending on which combinations were used.
"My tax cut is limited in size," Mr. Clinton said. "It's worth $110 billion. Theirs is five times as much: $550 billion. We can afford ours. We can't afford theirs."
He added: "My tax cut is paid for with specific, tough budget cuts consistent with the balanced-budget plan. Our opponents haven't said how they'll pay for their tax cut yet."
In fact, Mr. Dole has suggested his proposed tax cut could be paid for through largely unspecified spending cuts -- that he says would not affect Medicare -- and through the economic growth that he says the tax cuts would help generate.
But Mr. Clinton argued the Dole proposal would end up either "bringing back those bad, old days of out-of-control deficits," or harm programs for the elderly, education and the environment.
In the Republican radio response, The Associated Press quoted Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma as saying the Dole plan puts its faith in Americans. "We think you know how best to use your money, rather than the Government," Mr. Watts said.
On vacation here in the Tetons this week, Mr. Clinton has affected a diligent lack of interest in the Republican proceedings, and ignored their contentions that he had presided over the nation's largest-ever tax increase. But he clearly cares about almost every nuance of them -- enough that his former pollster, Stanley Greenberg, who now works for the Democratic National Committee, and his sometime adviser James Carville, monitored a sample group of voters' reactions to Mr. Dole's acceptance speech as he was delivering it.
By highlighting his own proposals in the radio speech today, Mr. Clinton all but guaranteed timely news coverage of carefully calibrated White House responses to the Republican plan, without exposing himself to too many questions about his own proposals, or their chance for adoption by a Republican Congress hostile to him.
All year, under the guidance of his political adviser, Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton has made increasing use of the weekly radio address for just such attention-getting purposes. And the radio speeches have often been written with an eye toward projecting the President as being above the partisan fray.
For example, he ended his speech today by saying, "I look forward to discussing these plans before the American people in the coming months," and adding: "That kind of debate can only be good for our country."
Mr. Clinton wound down his eight-day stay here in Jackson with a sort of farewell dinner in his honor on Friday night at the Snake River Grill, a local hotspot partly owned by James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank. The host was Roger C. Altman, the former Deputy Treasury Secretary, and guests included the actor Harrison Ford, Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE FOURTH PARTY;
Green Party to Nominate Nader for President

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The Green Party is in the midst of its first Presidential convention, a low-budget event that will nominate Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate.
"We're not trying to make it the best TV show on earth," like the $30 million Republican convention just concluded in San Diego or the coming Democratic National Convention in Chicago, said Doug Heller, media coordinator for the four-day "Green Gathering '96." The convention opened on Thursday. 
 The convention is being produced for less than $25,000, and it will not feature any of the hoopla that could hurt the environment.
"We don't want balloons, the plastic, the horror," Mr. Heller said. Still, he promised "an upbeat experience."
The convention's 350 delegate-activists can attend seminars like "Green Alternatives in a Consumer Society" and "Eco-Feminism," in lecture halls and laboratories on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles. The nominating session is to be held on Monday.
Mr. Nader, 62, a reluctant standard-bearer, is this year's un-candidate.
Unlike major party candidates, the consumer advocate will not run television advertisements, take contributions or spend more than $5,000 of his own money, although supporters are spending heavily on statewide petition drives. Mr. Nader is depending on free news coverage to spread his message.
"Every four years, the choice between the bad and the worst gets worse," Mr. Nader said.
He does not even plan to run on the full party platform, said Mike Feinstein, conference coordinator and a Green candidate for the Santa Monica City Council.
"Rather than run on our entire platform with 150 issues and allow his message to be sidetracked, he is running on this core set of issues," Mr. Feinstein said.
The Green Party began organizing in 1984 and now boasts 29 elected officials in 10 states. Mr. Nader's name is already on a dozen state ballots, and party members hope to increase that to 30 and get him into the Presidential debates.
The party has moved beyond environmentalism to seek social justice, grass-roots democracy, nonviolence and an economy based on environmentally benign materials and processes and a share of ownership and control for workers and communities.
The environmentalist David Brower, the keynote speaker on the convention's opening day, said he was backing Mr. Nader, a longtime friend who "has never let me or the environment down."
Nobody expects Mr. Nader to be elected President, but polls indicate he has the potential to pull votes away from President Clinton.

HEADLINE: Judge Says Benefits Must Cover Partners of Gay State Employees

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 17

 BODY:
For the first time in the United States, a judge has required a public agency to extend to homosexual couples the medical, life and dental insurance benefits that married couples often have.
Judge Stephen L. Gallagher of Multnomah County Circuit Court ruled on Aug. 8 that Oregon Health Sciences University here discriminated against three gay employees by denying benefits to their domestic partners. Judge Gallagher said Oregon had to provide insurance to the partners of all gay state workers who sought coverage. "Constitutional law may mandate, like it or not, that customs change with an evolving social order," the judge wrote. 
 The decision could be stayed if the state appeals before Sept. 9. A spokesman for the State Attorney General's Office, Peter Cogswell, said the state would decide on an appeal by "the end of next week or the first part of the following week."
The ruling would not make Oregon the first jurisdiction to extend benefits to gay couples. The State of Vermont and about 50 county and city governments, including Boston, San Francisco, Seattle and Portland, do so. But all those jurisdictions offer the benefits voluntarily or because legislation forces them to.
The Oregon decision is significant, said Beatrice Dohrn, legal director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a national gay legal group based in New York, because it sets a precedent.
"Finally a judge has looked past the double bind," Ms. Dohrn said. "Until now we've just heard, 'You can only get married if you're heterosexual, and you can only get benefits if you're married.' "
Christine Tanner, a professor of nursing at the university, filed the suit, along with another nursing professor and a university pharmacist, in 1992. Ms. Tanner sought to get insurance for her partner, Lisa Chickandonz. "It was a long, slow process," Ms. Tanner said in an interview after the ruling, "and now we've attained fairness and equality under the law."
"For me, it was more practical than that," said Ms. Chickandonz, a midwife who is insured through her employer. "I was concerned. What if I became disabled and had no access to health insurance?"
Some conservative groups have denounced the rule. The chairman of the state chapter of the Christian Coalition, Jim Adkisson, said: "What's to say now that the courts can't do the same for someone who's married to two or three people? As an employer, I'm worried about the cost impacts."
Dan Kennedy, administrator of the State Human Resources Division, said the economic effects would be slight. "Other jurisdictions have extended their benefits," Mr. Kennedy said, "and it's had a very minor effect." He said his office had received no inquiries from state employees about coverage for partners.

HEADLINE: 'Wealthiest? Who, Us?' L.I. Villagers Exclaim

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: HEWLETT BAY PARK, L.I.

 BODY:
When Worth magazine published a list of the 300 richest towns in America this summer, people in this tiny enclave on Long Island's South Shore were surprised and a little dismayed to learn they finished second.
It was not, people here said, that they wanted to edge out Rolling Hills, Calif., a Los Angeles suburb, to be number one. Rather, they wished the list had never been published. 
 "This isn't Beverly Hills," said Stephanie Kaufman. "It is really a quiet community. It's not the kind of place that wants national attention."
Reactions were similar in neighboring Hewlett Harbor, which finished third. "Oh boy, I never realized I lived in that wealthy a community," said Harold I. Leviton, the chief executive officer of the Leviton Manufacturing Company and a resident of Hewlett Harbor for 50 years.
Another Hewlett Harbor resident, Richard A. Sloss, remarked of the publicity: "This is not the kind of thing I would like to see for any wealthy community, and I think most of my neighbors would agree. But I assure you I don't lose any sleep over it."
Mr. Sloss and others said they were astonished that the two areas, both incorporated villages since the 1920's, ranked so high. "You read about certain communities throughout the country and you get the impression they are much wealthier," he said. "Even on Long Island, I would expect places like Sands Point would lead the pack."
The magazine said it used 1990 census figures updated by economic and demographic trends to determine rankings based on average household incomes and housing values. Summer communities and neighborhoods within cities were not included. Many of the towns on the list are actually small incorporated villages.
Jeff Blyskal, a contributing editor to Worth who spent more than three months researching the article, said the two Hewletts were not the only places that questioned their high ratings.
"Wealth is in some respects a state of mind, and many people who are wealthy don't consider themselves wealthy," he said. "What we're talking about here is the disparity between people's perceptions and cold, hard numbers."
According to the ratings, Hewlett Bay Park, population 487, had an average household income of $348,500 and an average home value of $570,600. In Hewlett Harbor, population 1,270, average household income was $306,600 and average home value $572,700.
The top New Jersey finisher, Saddle River (4), and every other exclusive place in New Jersey, Connecticut and Westchester County lagged behind. In California, Beverly Hills (83) trailed Malibu (74). Palm Beach, Fla., was 85th, its wealth -- an average income of $148,700 -- diluted by its population, 9,894.
The highest Connecticut entry, New Canaan, with average household income of $173,000 -- too low to be offset by an average home value of $499,400 -- finished 63d. Darien (77), Weston (81), Greenwich (87) and Westport (124) followed. In Westchester, Scarsdale (30) finished highest.
It came as no surprise to people who know Long Island that village after village on Nassau County's North Shore ranked in the top 40. Few ever doubted, after all, that places like Kings Point (5), Oyster Bay Cove (9), Laurel Hollow (11), Muttontown (12), Old Westbury (13) and Sands Point (14) were wealthy places.
The shocker was that the South Shore produced not one but two of the top three finishers.
"That can't be right," said Leonard Wurzel, the Mayor of Sands Point, a village rich in estates and multimillion-dollar houses. "Nothing over there compares with Sands Point."
Even some real-estate agents familiar with Hewlett Bay Park and Hewlett Harbor were taken aback.
"We knew they were wealthy areas, but we didn't think they were tops in the country," said Susan Pugatch of Pugatch Realty Corporation in Woodmere. "Everyone in the office questioned it."
Another agent, Dolores Stern, said: "These are very nice, stable communities, but there's no flash, no glitz and no glory houses here. Where do they get these numbers? Either they're off or I'm dealing with much wealthier people than I know."
The two villages are gemstones of the Five Towns, an affluent area in Nassau's southwest corner not far from Kennedy International Airport.
Both are exclusively residential and have been prosperous since their beginnings nearly 70 years ago. "They were originally the Hamptons of New York City," said Morton M. Haves of Hewlett Harbor, a real estate agent. "It's the zoning that kept this area up."
The villages, which face each other across Macy Channel, are packed tight with a mix of Colonial, Tudor, ranch and modern houses ranging in size and design from the sturdy to the mildly stupendous.
Mercedes cars are as common here as Fords are in other neighborhoods. Residents tend to be lawyers, doctors, Wall Street financiers, business owners and professionals. Many work in Manhattan.
"Nobody comes in here and tells me their income, but I was a bit surprised that out of the entire country we were up that high," said Gerald H. Morganstern, the Mayor of Hewlett Harbor and a real estate lawyer in Manhattan. "We have a lovely community but it ranges from a quarter acre to one-acre zoning. The same houses would be worth a lot less 30 miles further out on Long Island, until you reach the Hamptons."
Two other villages in the Five Towns area, Hewlett Neck (17) and Woodsburgh (37), finished in the top 40.
Hewlett Bay Park's Mayor, Mitchell E. Sahn, said he found it objectionable to view his village in terms of wealth.
"At best it relies on stereotypes, and stereotypes reinforce the divisions so many of us are trying to overcome," Mr. Sahn said. There were, he said, "no mountains and rivers" separating the village from surrounding areas.
"Most of us would prefer to be mentioned for the expertise and the can-do nature of the people who live here," said Mr. Sahn, the managing partner of a fund that invests in Latin American securities. "Hey, talk about our high turnout at the last village election. Talk about us being one of the first villages on Long Island to go on the Internet."
Mr. Sahn said that during a blizzard in January he and a group of villagers "attempted to call very resident widowed or alone to make sure they had somebody's number with a four-wheel drive vehicle."
"If caring makes us rich, then we are very rich," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Monterrey Is Feeling Like a Big-Leaguer

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Joe McIlvaine, the general manager of the Mets, sat in Monterrey Stadium, chatting up fans in fluent Spanish and drinking in the scene of major league baseball, Mexican-style.
On Friday night, for the first time, a regular-season major league game was being played in a country other than the United States and Canada. And Monterrey, the proud host of a three-game weekend series between the San Diego Padres and the Mets, was putting on a show. 
 Thus, the mariachi band playing atop the third-base dugout. Thus, the endless stream of clowns dancing up and down the aisles, and the green, red and white Mexican flags waving in the bleachers.
A genuine surge of energy and enthusiasm and chants of "Toro! Toro! Toro!" rolled through the crowd of 23,699 not because of the presence of a matador but because of Fernando Valenzuela, the starting pitcher for the Padres and arguably the most popular son of Mexico ever to play in the major leagues.
"Man, I love baseball in Latin America," said McIlvaine, a veteran of many a foray into winter leagues across Central America and the Caribbean rim.
Suddenly all of major league baseball feels the same way, enamored of and intrigued with everything Hispanic, especially Mexico.
This nation, steeped in Spanish and Indian culture and associated more often with soccer, is suddenly viewed as a potential baseball gold mine, one filled with millions of untapped ticket and memorabilia buyers and, even more enticing, potential homes for the ever increasing number of expansion teams baseball hopes to field come the new millennium. Still, Len Coleman, the president of the National League, took pains to caution that Major League Baseball has not set a round of expansion after Phoenix and Tampa/St. Petersburg enter the majors in 1998. Nor would he call this series a make-or-break test for Monterrey or Mexico. Yet, said Coleman, "Mexico is not only on our minds but in our hearts. We love the enthusiasm and we relish the opportunity to explore the possibilities."
And, said McIlvaine, sizing up Latin America as a whole: "If I had to handicap the potential cities right now, I'd have to say Monterrey because there's already talk about it. You just don't hear anything like that about Venezuela, the Dominican Republic or Puerto Rico."
Indeed, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the chairman of the owners' expansion committee, put together an A list this spring and, ahead of a host of American and Canadian cities, put both Mexico City -- the capital, with 12 million people -- and Monterrey, Mexico's third-largest city with 3.2 million people.
The interest in Latin America in general and Monterrey specifically stems from a surge of restlessness and stagnation felt throughout the majors, thanks to decades of labor strife and increasing disenchantment with the game in the United States and Canada. For those reasons, growing the game tops the lists not only of owners but also players and a union that has traditionally supported expansion.
Certainly the growth could be done by increasing marketing within the contiguous 48 states and Canada. But, said the Padres veteran Tony Gwynn, "It is in the best interests of baseball to grow internationally."
Gwynn, a former union representative who urged Players Association officials to support the sojourn here, added: "Baseball's in prime position now to move forward and start doing some of the things we really should have done five years ago. They could take this game to another level and become a better game."
Just as other professional sports did, seemingly ages ago, compared with baseball. "You know how baseball is," Gwynn laughed. "We're always like the last ones to do things."
Now, though, the sport that prides itself on playing without a clock seems to hear one ticking. And the sense that time is running out has prompted the sudden extension of welcoming hands across the border.
So it is that the Padres, eyeing markets to their south, set out to do more than just offer ticket packages and bus services to fans from Tijuana and Baja California. Republican convention or not, the Padres jumped at the opportunity to spread their fan base to Mexico.
Not surprisingly, the Padres already have company. "We're definitely interested in doing something like this," said Roland Hemond, the senior executive vice president of baseball operations and, in a sense, an advance scout here for the Arizona Diamondbacks, a team not set to play until 1998. "No one's any closer than us."
Actually, Monterrey, located 143 miles from the border town of Laredo, Tex., is closer to Houston's Astros than the Diamondbacks. "I would guess the Padres, Astros and ourselves would probably be the three candidates in terms of interest," said Blake Edwards, the Diamondbacks' head of sales and marketing. "But I don't think anyone necessarily has to claim it. It's big enough to go around."
Don't blame Mexican officials for feeling territorial, too, as they think of more than just growing the fan bases of existing major league teams. "Tonight proved that Monterrey has the capacity, that Monterrey has the communications systems, that it has good hotels and good facilities to be in the major leagues," declared Pepe Maiz, the owner of the Mexican summer league champion Monterrey Sultanes.
Maiz is pairing with Juan Manuel Ley, the owner of the winter league champion Culiacan club, in seeking an expansion team. It will not be a first time for Maiz, who filed an expansion application in 1995, when the Diamondbacks and Tampa Bay Devil Rays were born.
Maiz admits that initial attempt had more to do with learning the process than with reality. After all, Mexico's economy was in a meltdown then. Though there are signs of recovery now, the peso still lags far behind the dollar, with an exchange rate of about 7 to 1.
The markets here obviously can bear little burden. The Sultanes' game tickets, for instance, range from $1 to $9 in American currency. This series saw a markup, but only to the equivalent of $4 to $18. A beer or a soda cost a mere 5 pesos, or about 80 cents. Hamburgers, generous in size, could be had for 15 pesos, or about $2. Plastic baseball helmets sell for 30 pesos.
"To create perfect conditions, to have a big-league circumstances at this point would be very difficult," admitted Roberto Magdeleno, the general manager of the Sultanes. "But we have to prepare, perhaps with foreign capital."
Maiz, whose investment in the future included a joint venture with the Padres to pump $100,000 worth of improvements into his park, remains optimistic. "As soon as the economy recovers, we have the potential to pay major league figures. And we know, sooner or later, Monterrey will get a major league baseball team. If not in the next expansion, then the next. We expect to be there."
So, too, do major leaguers, but with no small amount of trepidation.
"When you're so used to living in the States, coming here with the language differences, the cultural differences, to worry about the food and the water, it will be really hard to convince a guy to come here," said Mets stopper John Franco. "When you've got to worry about brushing your teeth every day, or leaving your family here when you go on the road, I don't know."
Indeed, precious few players brought their families on this trip.
"It's better than I thought it would be," Gwynn said. "People have been very friendly. But my own opinion is that they are quite a bit away.
"It will be trying to convince guys that this is a major league town."
Gene Orza, the Players Association's second in command, said: "I do view it as a problem, a real problem. But whether it's a transitory problem or one of a much longer duration, I don't know."
Yet such concerns still do not squelch the sense of inevitability. Said Orza: "Monterrey has the two principal ingredients for expansion: a lot of people and a lot of enthusiasm for baseball. Are economic standards today up to major league levels? It's hard to say.
"But players, for the opportunity to play true major league baseball, have always been willing to make sacrifices. And there are elements of this enterprise that make one hope this could be a major league city."

Toro!" -- for his nickname, Bull, on Friday night. (Associated Press) (pg. 4)

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1851 words

HEADLINE: WAGE VOLATILITY FAR MORE COMMON THAN EVER BEFORE

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Cole Grady was earning $52,000 a year as a technician at a herbicide plant in Muscatine, Iowa, including $15,000 in overtime. But then the overtime disappeared, and the Grady family abruptly entered the growing and uncertain world of fluctuating pay.
A change in technology eliminated most of the extra hours that Mr. Grady, 45, had come to count on as part of his income. Trying to make up the loss, his wife, Christine, 42, took a McDonald's counter job last year at $5 an hour -- but for 30 hours one week, 40 the next, 20 the third. She is never sure how much pay she will bring home. 
 "We have gotten into a situation where too much is riding on variable income, and that scares me," Mr. Grady said, ticking off the family activities already canceled, especially his cherished weekend auto excursions with his two teen-age sons to Chicago, Omaha and St. Louis.
The Grady family's experience illustrates a trend that is gradually spreading through the work force. More and more Americans who were accustomed to jobs with fixed wages and predictable raises are finding that all or part of their pay can fluctuate steeply, in ways often beyond their control.
Income swings traditionally associated with traveling salesmen and Wall Street brokers are becoming common in other occupations, too, and that could in time affect national behavior.
"You are forced to take life more day to day," said David Popenoe, a Rutgers University sociologist. "Planning for a child's education or the purchase of a home can be very difficult. What we think of as the future becomes economically compromised for many families."
The trend, so far, is only sparsely documented. While much attention and research has focused on layoffs, wage stagnation and income inequality, few studies have spotlighted the rise in wage volatility.
But several labor economists in academia have spotted the change taking place. And the Census Bureau, in an analysis for The New York Times, found that 54 percent of the nation's workers -- janitors through executives -- experienced serious wage and salary fluctuation in 1994, up from 49 percent a decade earlier.
"From the few studies that are available, it is becoming clear that in the 1980's and 1990's, there has been more earnings volatility than in the 1960's and 1970's," said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard labor economist.
Gyrating incomes have always been a characteristic of the American economy, of course. Until the 1920's, most Americans depended for their livelihood on farming, with its uncertain harvests.
Through the generations, salesmen and brokers have lived on commissions, a risky way of life that often brought the clever and the energetic far more than a steady salary would have furnished.
After World War II, however, the United States entered an era in which secure jobs at steady pay became the model. That is still the situation for many Americans. But in the last 25 years, this system has gradually unraveled, with unsettling consequences for many workers and opportunity and wealth for some.
Many workplace changes feed the volatility. Companies increasingly rely on outsiders rather than permanent employees, hiring them for relatively short periods. Temporary and contract workers, self-employed consultants and day workers now represent 10 percent of the American work force, according to the Labor Department, which attempted for the first time last year to count their growing numbers. The largest category -- workers farmed out by temporary help agencies -- totaled 2.2 million, up fivefold from 417,000 in 1982.
Linda Eskander, 42, who owns a brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, is one, having hired herself out through Kelly Services seven times since last fall. Needing time to renovate the brownstone so she can sell it, but also enough income to pay bills, she left her $32,500-a-year job as an administrative assistant at a real estate company, having learned, she said, that while many companies resist hiring, they are quick to take on temps.
Earning $15 an hour at Citibank and $12 at the Brooklyn Museum -- stints interrupted by days devoted to renovation -- Ms. Eskander's income this year will be roughly half what it was in 1995. "Without the demand for temps," she said, "I would not have been able to leave my steady job."
The change in the status of labor unions has also contributed to volatility. They once insisted on fixed wages and annual raises, setting pay standards in the process for many nonunion workers, too. But union membership and influence have declined for years, and unions today have become more willing to agree to fluctuating bonuses in lieu of raises. Last year, a record 45 percent of the workers covered by newly negotiated major labor contracts got onetime bonuses in lieu of raises.
Overtime also plays a role. Rather than hire additional permanent employees, many companies increase the hours of those already on staff in boom times, then cut back this overtime when sales decline. That is particularly the case in manufacturing, where average overtime hours fell by 10 percent as the economy slowed in the first half of last year. The economy then surged this spring and overtime rebounded, also by 10 percent, the Labor Department said.
Above all, corporate America is pushing the trend toward volatile earnings by trying to tie more workers' pay -- not only executives, but clerks and assembly-line workers as well -- to performance, their own and the company's. In a new survey of 750 companies by Towers Perrin, a management consulting firm, 27 percent said they would eliminate traditional raises over the next three years, substituting bonuses and profit sharing.
"If you have a bad year, you can offset this by cutting out bonuses, and if you have a good one, you can offer fat rewards," said Sandra O'Neal, a Towers Perrin executive.
So far, the heightened volatility in workers' income is not having the effects that economic theory predicts. Savings should be rising, as people put aside money to get through the downturns in their earnings, and consumption should be falling, as people cut back to what they can count on earning, as Mr. Grady is starting to do.
But Government data show just the opposite. The explanation offered is that most Americans affected by the change do not yet share Mr. Grady's concern that income volatility leads to lower incomes. Instead, many people use credit cards and loans to finance the valleys in their incomes, gambling on another peak soon to pay down the debt.
"These are people who built their spending patterns in the belief their incomes would be stable," said Brian O'Hare, head of Norwest Bank's credit card operation. "But they aren't stable."
Certainly, Dan Luria embraces this tactic. As a director of the Industrial Technology Institute at the University of Michigan, he takes home more than $4,000 a month in stable university salary; he supplements this with three or four outside consulting jobs a year, each paying a fee of $15,000 or so. "I basically go into the hole in debt to finance family spending," Mr. Luria said, "and come out of it when my periodic fees arrive."
In years when Mr. Luria snags fewer consulting jobs, his income can plunge by 15 percent or more, and the debts take longer to pay. "Psychologically, you try to throttle back," he said, "but what you really do is build higher interest payments into your basic consumption bundle."
For some -- top executives of major corporations, investment bankers and entrepreneurs -- sharply fluctuating income is a boon, not a burden, reflecting the huge rewards in stock options, bonuses and profits that are possible in an era that encourages risk taking. "Some of the new variability we are seeing is the variability that comes to the fleet and the strong," said James Hechtman, a University of Chicago labor economist.
Geoffrey Berliner, 35, founder of Berliner Pen in Manhattan, is certainly one of the fleet. Having earned a Harvard master's degree in religion, planning to become a professor, he dropped that career path, with its promise of steady income, after concluding that teaching jobs would be sparse. A year as a paralegal convinced him that job security as a lawyer would not be much better. So in 1990 he turned a hobby -- collecting and repairing vintage fountain pens -- into an enterprise. His earnings from selling pens have risen by as much 50 percent a year, to $110,000 in 1995 from $26,000 in 1990.
"A lot of people are put into a position these days of taking a gamble," Mr. Berliner said. "They feel more secure about living by their wits and abilities than in taking a job that might not last."
Tracking volatility in earnings is difficult. It requires questioning the same people for at least two or three years to determine their earnings patterns. The Census Bureau tracks such a group of 20,000 households -- 60,000 people -- questioning them every four months, and has results available for 1984 through 1994. From these data, it found that the earnings of 54 percent of the group -- an American cross section -- gyrated by at least 5 percent in one or more of the four-month periods in 1994.
The University of Michigan has been tracking a group of 5,000 families since 1968. Its findings are not yet updated for the 1990's. But Peter Gottschalk of Boston College and Robert Moffitt of Johns Hopkins University, both labor economists, found in a 1994 study of the Michigan data, work that was the first to recognize the trend, that earnings volatility in the 1980's was greater than in the 1970's, particularly for low-income people, who lost ground.
Though corporations have increasingly embraced variable pay plans as a spur to performance, these plans sometimes breed discontent among workers. Allied Signal, for example, instituted a pilot cash bonus plan several years ago for 5,000 of its 77,000 employees, most of them earning under $30,000. The bonuses averaged 4 percent of pay, but represented as much as 10 percent for some workers. When goals were not met and no bonus appeared, there was disappointment.
"Not getting the bonus was perceived as a pay cut," said Marc Greenberg, a spokesman for Allied Signal, "rather than a failure to meet goals."
The cash bonus plan will not be expanded. But others are being tried, including stock options for lower-level workers. Those who got them last year could exercise a portion today, paying $34 a share for Allied Signal stock that could be resold for $62.75 a share.
Mr. Grady, who has worked 15 years at the Monsanto Company herbicide plant in Muscatine, also participates in a bonus plan, even serving on a committee that helps set the goals that qualify the plant's workers for bonuses. But the $2,900 he received last year, representing nearly 8 percent of his $38,000 in base pay, was $1,000 less than he had expected.
"We all have a say in setting goals," Mr. Grady said, "but the people who make the final decision are not affected. They are in another pay structure with a different bonus plan, and that is frustrating."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRATS;
Democrats' Plan for Convention: Keep It Positive, and Presidential

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Acknowledging that the Republicans put on a well-staged spectacle, Democrats have set two goals going into their own national convention: to raise doubts about the tax-cut plan and moderate image the Republicans touted, and then use the President's aura of incumbency to reach out to independent-minded voters.
In effect, Democratic aides said, they hope to have President Clinton bring the Oval Office with him to the convention in Chicago at the end of the month, striking the kind of "above the fray" tone he has sought all year, by announcing executive actions and making scarce mention of his opponents. 
 The President's aides say his address accepting the nomination will sound much like a State of the Union Message, complete with second-term executive and legislative proposals.
And while Democrats say they will not be shy about hammering home the policy differences between their party and their opponents, they also say they want to avoid the kind of personal ridicule that the Republicans heaped on Mr. Clinton at their convention in San Diego. The Democrats believe that the sharp-edged attacks, while popular in the partisan environment of the convention hall, backfires with voters less anchored to a political party.
"I thought the Republicans crossed the line of singe but don't burn," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "I'm determined to the extent possible not to have the convention turn into a schoolyard playground rhetoric that aims at the personalities of people."
Mr. Clinton, in his weekly radio address today, began the assault on Mr. Dole's sweeping plan to cut taxes by $548 billion. While never mentioning Mr. Dole by name, Mr. Clinton said the proposal of "our opponents" could either balloon the deficit or results in cuts in popular programs like Medicare. He held out his own tax cut proposals for education and child rearing as preferable. "We agree on one thing," he said. "Americans do deserve a tax cut. But we must choose between a tax cut that responsibly balances the budget and one that puts our economy at risk."
Putting the final touches on plans for their own convention, Mr. Clinton's lieutenants insisted they were not rewriting them in light of the Republicans' generally successful attempt to package the just-ended San Diego convention into a smooth, made-for-television picture of harmony. But they were still putting finished touches on their program in an effort to insure that their four-day gathering in Chicago proves newsworthy and gives them a lift to match the one that polls suggest Mr. Dole received from his convention.
Convention planners announced today that Hillary Rodham Clinton would have a prominent speaking role at the gathering, taking place in her hometown, despite the controversies that have made her a polarizing figure. Clinton advisers said Mrs. Clinton had begun working on a speech three weeks ago, before Elizabeth Dole's star turn at the Republican convention, when she roamed the floor with a microphone and spoke reverentially of her husband.
Vice President Al Gore's wife, Tipper, will also have a speaking role, most likely immediately before Mrs. Clinton. Mr. Gore, of course, will make his own acceptance speech.
And Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana is to deliver the keynote address, featured as a young can-do Democratic Governor in something of the Clinton mold.
Like the Republicans, the Democrats will feature plenty of appearances by ordinary Americans, which they hope to use to highlight the themes of opportunity, responsibility and community that Mr. Clinton has returned to repeatedly since the "New Covenant" speeches with which he first defined his Presidential candidacy in 1991.
One night of the convention is being envisioned as devoted solely to Americans speaking about overcoming personal difficulties and the effect of government policies.
The Democrats said that the actor Christopher Reeves, who became paralyzed in a horse-riding accident would appear and so would a prominent Republican, Sarah Brady, who became an advocate for gun control after her husband James S. Brady was shot in the head in the 1981 attempt on President Ronald Reagan's life. The Democrats also announced that Alma Brown, the widow of the late Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, would be the honorary convention chairwoman. One White House official said that Capt. Scott O'Grady, the F-16 pilot who was shot down over Bosnia and had a speaking role at the Republican convention, volunteered to appear before the Democrats too, but was not under consideration.
In preparation for the convention, the Democrats will be seeking to rub away the afterglow of the Republican gathering. A new Clinton commercial is running in battleground states reminding voters of the Republican Congress that was in little evidence in San Diego. "President Clinton stood firm and defended our values," the commercial says. "But next year, if Newt Gingrich controls Congress and his partner, Bob Dole, enters the Oval Office, there'll be nobody there to stop them."
Next week, Mr. Clinton plans to recapture the public spotlight through ceremonies highlighting his signing of bills that raise the minimum wage and broaden health care coverage. He could also sign the welfare overhaul bill before the convention if Congress forwards it to him.
Then, even as the Democratic convention opens in Chicago on Monday, Aug. 26, Mr. Clinton will strive to stay in the news with eye-catching announcement made on an old-fashioned whistle-stop train ride. For three days he will cross West Virginia and the industrial battleground states of Ohio and Michigan by train as his surrogates, the Gores and Mrs. Clinton make the rounds of the convention. He is to arrive in Chicago on Wednesday night crossing Lake Michigan by boat from Michigan City, Ind.
Campaign officials say the train will provide a populist touch and serve to take the Democrats' campaign themes outside the convention hall.
The week is to culminate with the renomination of Mr. Clinton. The tone of his acceptance speech on Thursday night, aides say, will be much like that of his new book, "Between Hope and History: Meeting America's Challenges for the 21st Century." But the speech is also likely to contain several dozen new initiatives looking toward 2000.
The Administration is examining ways to revitalize the inner cities and create new jobs for the welfare recipients who will be forced off public assistance by the stringent new welfare bill. Mr. Clinton's economic team has also drawn up a list of small, focused tax incentives for the President to review in preparation for his address, in case he wants to bolster his anti-tax credentials to face Mr. Dole, who has proposed a sweeping plan to spur economic growth while balancing the budget and cutting taxes by $548 billion over six years.
