HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
Tuning Out the Campaign Will Be Difficult for Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Buoyed by their peaceful convention here this week, Republicans say the White House is within Bob Dole's grasp if he succeeds in a two-pronged strategy of convincing voters that his economic prescriptions would be a boon to all taxpayers and that President Clinton is so tainted by ethical questions that he should not be re-elected.
The Democrats, preparing for their convention in a week, are countering with an all-out offensive to convince voters that Mr. Dole's plan for an across-the-board tax cut while balancing the budget is irresponsible, and presenting Mr. Clinton as the leader whose stewardship has produced a relatively robust economy. 
 Not only are they eyeing each other warily, but both parties are also bracing for the expected emergence of Ross Perot this weekend as the nominee of his Reform Party. As in 1992, Mr. Perot is planning to spend millions of dollars in a burst of television advertising to try to set the agenda himself and offer himself as the only candidate who is serious about taking on the deficit.
Given the unusual closeness in time between the Republican and Democratic conventions, voters who have not paid attention to politics until now will suddenly be bombarded in the intense, and surely combative, 11-week run up to Election Day.
Even Democrats, who have had a significant lead in the polls, insisted they expected a close, hard-fought contest. "I think it's a tight race," Harold M. Ickes, deputy White House chief of staff, who oversees the campaign preparations, said in an interview. "We have our base at 25 or 26 percent. They have their base at 25 to 26 percent. And the rest is very, very volatile. It's a suspicious, insecure American public, and we are going through times of enormous social and economic change -- and none of us has a silver-bullet answer."
Citing new polls that show Mr. Dole closing in on Mr. Clinton's months-long advantage, Republicans contend that the race has become competitive, with Mr. Dole's economic plan, the convention here this week and the nomination of Jack Kemp for Vice President.
"Since the convention, the Colin Powell speech, Jack Kemp as V.P. and the economic growth plan, Clinton's been knocked down on his heels," said Mike Murphy, a strategist for Mr. Dole.
Yet for all the Republicans' bravado, and the professed nervousness of the Democrats, many analysts said in interviews that the post-convention exuberance among Republicans -- and any lift in the polls -- might be short-lived. Mr. Dole, who relinquished his Senate seat to campaign full time, still faces a steep uphill fight, they said.
The stakes are high, not only as Republicans try to reclaim the White House, but also in the struggle for control of Congress. Some Republicans openly worry that if Mr. Dole loses, it could cost their party the House and Senate, transforming their historic seizure of both chambers in 1994 into little more than an off-year anomaly.
That is why the Democrats are all the more aggressive in taking on the Republicans this year. So much so that before the convention hall cleared here on Thursday night, the Democratic Party was distributing a 12-page, point-by-point rebuttal of Mr. Dole's acceptance speech. And Mr. Clinton, in his radio address today, continued the offensive against Mr. Dole's economic plan, saying:
"Americans do deserve a tax cut. But we must choose between a tax cut that responsibly balances the budget and one that puts our economy at risk, between one that is targeted to help working families pay for education, health care and other pressing needs, and one that is indiscriminate."
For the Republicans, the first potential hurdle in their comeback strategy was this weekend, with the expected election of Mr. Perot as the nominee of his Reform Party at the convention in Valley Forge, Pa. While Mr. Dole's advisers publicly insisted that they were not worried about Mr. Perot and said he had lost credibility, they were concerned enough to plan a campaign stop in Pennsylvania on Sunday for Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp, on their way from Buffalo to Washington.
On Aug. 26, a Monday, Democrats will arrive in Chicago for their party's four-night, prime-time extravaganza, which is to deliver a message to the public that despite the smiling faces of moderation on the podium here, the Republican Party is controlled by extremists.
Mr. Dole's advisers were pleasantly surprised in the last two weeks by the fact that he kept trained on his tax-cut proposal, because he was known for lacking discipline on the campaign trail. After his emotional departure from the Senate in June, for instance, he squandered opportunities to present himself as a politician who made a daring decision to quit the Senate in his quest for the Presidency. As the clock is running toward Election Day, the Dole campaign's calculation for victory depends on its candidate's incessant pitches for his economic plan.
Some experts have long noted that Mr. Dole may face a struggle for a reason that is well beyond his control: Dissatisfaction with the country in general and the economy in particular is not at the level that has led voters to oust an incumbent party in the past. And several surveys showed that people who were unhappy were more critical of Speaker Newt Gingrich and Republicans in Congress than of Mr. Clinton.
"It would be quite exceptional for a challenger to defeat an incumbent with the economy doing as well as it is," said Samuel Kernell, a political science professor at the University of California at San Diego. "By Dole calling for the tax cut, he's doing something that's very dear to Republicans, but it's going to be a very hard sell in saying we could be doing better than we're doing."
Indeed, an examination of Gallup polls in the Presidential elections over the last 16 years shows that about the time President Jimmy Carter was defeated in 1980 and President George Bush lost in 1992, more than 70 percent of the public was dissatisfied with the state of the country.
Yet in 1984 and 1988, there was no such overwhelming dissatisfaction, and the incumbent parties held on to the White House. As of May, 60 percent expressed dissatisfaction.
Mr. Dole made note of his challenge upon his departure here on Friday, when he declared: "Beating an incumbent President is not easy -- but it's going to happen."
But advisers to Mr. Dole insisted that it might not be so hard to catch up to the President. Mr. Dole's cash-poor organization now is enjoying an infusion of more than $60 million that each nominee can spend before Nov. 5 -- money the campaign plans to use to counter Mr. Clinton's barrage of television advertising that began last year. Early next week, the campaign plans to begin a major advertising campaign to rebut assertions that the economy has rebounded.
"We have a competitive race," said John Buckley, Mr. Dole's communications director. "By our now being fully funded, we can tell the Clinton story in a way that raises his negatives."
Another boost, Mr. Buckley said, is that Mr. Kemp has long been liked by some Democrats for reaching out to minorities and to the downtrodden.
"To win, we have to have a unified base to go into the fall and cherry-pick Democratic voters wherever we can," Mr. Buckley said. "We've achieved both of those objectives in Dole's choice of Kemp as Vice President and with a successful convention."
Most of all, the Dole campaign is counting on the tax-cut plan to energize the party's base, give Mr. Dole a core message -- and address the general unease about the state of the country felt by some voters. Some of Mr. Dole's strategists compared the challenge before them to the successful campaigns against other challengers: the elections of Govs. John Engler of Michigan in 1990 and Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey in 1993. Both candidates put forward tax-cut plans that helped them come from behind to achieve upsets -- fueled largely by late-deciding voters -- against two incumbent Democrats: James Blanchard of Michigan and Jim Florio of New Jersey.
Mr. Murphy, who was a senior strategist both for Mr. Engler and Ms. Whitman and who is now working for Mr. Dole, said: "I've have experience in these races, so I've been very involved in driving the strategy. It's a classic challenger campaign: Guys like Florio or Governor Blanchard, for about a year before the election, their slogan is, 'I'm going to win.' And then the voters say, 'Wait a minute.' "
As for defeating Mr, Clinton, he said: "It's going to happen late against a weak incumbent. Republicans do well in elections where the referendum is on taxation and the economy."
Of the 10 largest states, only Texas was leaning toward Mr. Dole in recent polls -- and by only a narrow margin. But the Republicans plan for Mr. Dole to first close Mr. Clinton's advantage in about two dozen states that have traditionally been Republican strongholds in the South, the Great Plains and the Rocky Mountains. Once that is accomplished, he will campaign all out in the battleground states of the Midwest and, perhaps, where the President is well ahead: California.
The Democrats, meanwhile, have been quick to put down Mr. Dole's centerpiece proposal, ridiculing the practicality of cutting taxes significantly while balancing the budget. And they have been quick to dust off years of quotations in which Mr. Dole sounded skeptical of such supply-side notions.
But the Democrats are also trying not to be overly confident. Sounding alternately optimistic and worried, Mr. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff, said: "People, I think, are generally feeling better now about their economic circumstances than they were, say, a year and a half or two years ago. But they're still unsure about the future. And more importantly, they're unsure about the future for their children."
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, also wavered between sounding upbeat and nervous. After saying that the Democrats "do a good job of using the White House as a platform to play politics," he criticized his opponents for not taking better advantage of Mr. Dole's campaign troubles months ago. "They could have put this away in May," Mr. Reed said. "We were broke -- and we had problems in the Senate."
Though some conservatives complained that their positions were not featured prominently enough during the convention, many said the selection of Mr. Kemp would inspire them to work harder for Mr. Dole.
"We have a different Republican Party now with Dole and Kemp than anyone expected before they assembled in San Diego," said John H. Bunzel, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution, a conservative organization at Stanford University.
"The Republican Party has put forward an image that it hopes will reach out into every corner of America and transcend the hard edges of the Gingrich Congress," Mr. Bunzel said. "Whether or not they're going to be successful is what this campaign is all about."

Their mood was reflected on Thursday as they celebrated with, from left, Elizabeth Dole, Mr. Dole, Jack Kemp and his wife, Joanne. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1561 words

HEADLINE: Labor and Clergy Are Reuniting To Help the Underdogs of Society

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
More than at any other time in decades, religious leaders are making common cause with trade unions, lending their moral authority to denounce sweatshops, back a higher minimum wage and help organize janitors and poultry workers.
The clergy has not lined up with labor to such an extent since the heyday of Cesar Chavez, the charismatic farm workers' leader, in the 1970's and perhaps the Depression, union and religious leaders say. 
 Many in the clergy say they have rallied to labor's banner because the newly revived union movement is addressing what they view as the key ethical issues of the day, including the growing gulf between the haves and have-nots.
"People are becoming poorer and less secure in this era of downsizing, and capital has gotten tougher," said Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, former national president of the American Jewish Congress. "People in the clergy like me who grew up during the New Deal are going back on the warpath to try to defend the weak. Under these circumstances, where else would you expect the clergy to be but increasingly on the side of labor?"
Rabbi Hertzberg was among 57 ministers, priests and rabbis who held a news conference in Newark in the spring and signed a full-page advertisement aimed at pressuring a New Jersey dairy to settle a strike and criticizing its two-tier wage offer as too low to support a family.
One recent morning, 25 members of the clergy, several from New York and Chicago, prayed in front of the Case Farms poultry plant in Morganton, N.C., to urge management to sign a union contract and improve working conditions.
Labor-clergy coalitions have sprouted in New York City, Albany, Syracuse, Rochester, Boston, Detroit and Chicago, and a steering committee of 40 clerics is forming the National Interfaith Committee for Worker Justice.
In March, the New York State Labor-Religion Coalition, the umbrella group, organized a 40-hour fast in which more than 1,000 people in 10 cities, including some 50 members of the clergy, fasted to protest Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed welfare and health-care cuts.
"We fear for the future of our society where a very wealthy elite benefits from government policies while the endangered middle class experiences falling wages and increased economic uncertainty," said Bishop Howard Hubbard of Albany, co-chairman of the New York coalition.
Business executives are not happy about the alliance between labor and clergy. Many contend that labor disputes are not part of the clergy's mission. They argue that many in the clergy do not understand how a union can hurt a corporation's -- and the nation's -- competitiveness and that they often do not study the complexities of a dispute.
Marc Goldman, president of Farmland Dairy in Wallington, N.J., had some harsh words for Rabbi Hertzberg and other clergy members who signed the advertisement attacking his offer of $8.25 an hour and benefits to many new workers.
"None of the clergy who signed on bothered to contact us," Mr. Goldman said, asserting that his offer was similar to one the striking teamsters union had signed with other dairies. "Clearly, they were manipulated. I lose a certain amount of respect for clergy who represent themselves as interested in justice but deny someone justice by not hearing both sides before making up their mind."
The clergy's show of support for labor has taken many forms: sermons, petitions, pastoral letters, protest marches, meetings with management, sit-ins and Congressional testimony. And that aid has come from many quarters, from black ministers who labored in the civil rights movement, from priests whose siblings are union members, and from rabbis whose grandparents were union stalwarts as apparel workers on Manhattan's Lower East Side.
Religious leaders note that historically the clergy has lent labor a helping hand. In a landmark 1891 encyclical, Pope Leo XIII said that the right of workers to associate freely was fundamental, and he called on all employers to pay an adequate wage. Pope John Paul II has repeatedly praised unions in his encyclicals, as has the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops in pastoral letters. In Congressional testimony, John Cardinal O'Connor of New York has attacked management's use of permanent replacement workers because it "can make a charade of collective bargaining and a mockery of the right to strike."
The clergy's work with labor has grown markedly since last October, when John J. Sweeney became the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president on a platform of reinvigorating the long-moribund federation. The federation has doubled its organizing efforts, pushed for a higher minimum wage and tried to attract young people as union organizers.
John L. Carr, secretary of the department of social development at the United States Conference of Bishops, said, "A newly energized labor movement provides new opportunities to share our convictions and act on our teachings."
In recent decades, the clergy kept its distance for a number of reasons, including pervasive corruption in the teamsters and other unions.
In the 1960's, the liberal clergy was preoccupied with the civil rights movement. In the 1970's many clerics saw little need to help union members because they believed they were thriving for the most part.
"To some degree in the 60's, 70's and into the early 80's," said the Rev. Paul Sherry, president of the 1.5 million-member United Church of Christ, "religious leaders felt that working people, through the involvement of trade unions, were doing quite well, and the concern of religious people tended to be for very poor people. But after conditions began to deteriorate for working people in the 1980's, we see that we once again need to look at the concerns of working people."
The end of the cold war also fostered stronger labor-clergy ties. In the 1980's, many liberal clerics supported El Salvador's leftist guerrillas and Nicaragua's leftist government. Their relations with labor soured when Lane Kirkland, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s passionately anti-Communist former president, threw the federation's weight against the Central American left. Religious leaders say that Mr. Sweeney, who never had a reputation as a fervent warrior in the cold war, has sought to heal those divisions.
"We need these types of coalitions if we're going to be successful in helping working people," Mr. Sweeney said.
These days, 100 or so members of the clergy and of unions attend meetings of the New York City coalition when less than a dozen might have shown up two years ago. In May, dozens of clerics joined union-backed demonstrations throughout the five boroughs to protest plans to close or privatize city-owned hospitals.
In Atlanta, the Rev. Dr. Bennie Mitchell, director of labor relations for the 8.5 million-member National Baptist Convention, was arrested with a half-dozen other clergy members for sitting in at an Atlanta Kmart. They were protesting the company's failure to sign a contract and its practice of paying the work force at its Greensboro, N.C., warehouse less than workers at other Kmart warehouses.
"I was there because I have a mandate from whom I represent," Dr. Mitchell said. "Biblically, God is on the side of the oppressed. He led the Israelites out of Egypt to the promised land, and Jesus died for the oppressed."
Late last year, Rabbi Rolando Madelon of B'nai Jeshuron, a Manhattan synagogue, threw his weight behind a garment union's campaign and told the Gap that if it did not clean up an El Salvador sweatshop that made its clothes, he would tell his congregation that buying Gap goods violated Jewish ethical laws.
"Religious issues are not relegated to the inside of the synagogue or the church," he said. "We're discussing religious texts to make our faith relevant and to have something to say about the world in which we live. The Bible and the sacred texts have a lot to say about the sanctity of human life and the exploitation of men, women and children."
Rabbi Madelon's letter helped persuade the Gap to change its ways, company officials said, but the clergy has not convinced management to bend in a yearlong newspaper strike in Detroit. Indeed, managers at The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News were angered when more than 500 clergy members called for a boycott of the newspapers because they use permanent replacement workers. Bishop Thomas Gumbleton of Detroit has led civil disobedience efforts to protest the newspapers' use of such workers.
Tim Kelleher, the newspapers' senior vice president for labor relations, said: "We don't feel the clergy has any business getting involved in the labor dispute. We've hired 1,200 replacement workers. Many of them are members of religious sects. We feel these clergy are certainly not speaking for all members of their religious faith. They certainly aren't speaking for me, and I happen to be Catholic."
While many executives dismiss these members of the clergy as reflexively antibusiness, the clerics insist otherwise.
"By being supportive of trade unions, we do not intend to be anti-business," said Mr. Sherry of the United Church of Christ. "As religious leaders, we're trying to find ways to assist a society to become more balanced in terms of the way it allocates its benefits. We believe the balance is now against working people, and has to be righted."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Preaches Lower Taxes to an Audience of Firm Believers

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 17

 BODY:
Following the campaign trail laid down 10 years ago by another Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole came today to one of Ronald Reagan's favorite campaign stops, the Illinois State Fair, to preach one of Mr. Reagan's favorite messages: tax cuts.
"The President says the era of big Government is over," Mr. Dole declared at a frenzied and packed rally inside a show barn on the grounds of the state fair. "Well, it will be for him on Nov. 5, 1996." 
 "We are having slower economic growth than in any recovery in the country," Mr. Dole told hundreds of people who filled the show barn, waving flags, flowers and pictures of the candidate. "Think about it. It's a long, long time. They've given you lower wages, economic anxiety and the largest tax increase in the history of the world. And that's why they're going to go back to Arkansas."
At that, Mr. Dole's crowd -- one of the largest and most excited he has encountered in this campaign -- broke into a deafening roar of: "Send Bill home!"
Mr. Dole, with his running mate, Jack Kemp, took the stage today aware of a poll by his campaign, as well as other media surveys, that found evidence that the race had tightened markedly since the convention begun. He was also aware that the Democrats have began their own effort, leading up to their convention in Chicago next week, to portray Mr. Dole's tax cut plan as a threat to the deficit and to such programs as Medicare.
"They're trying to scare the American people about my pro-growth economic plan," he said. "The only people who are really scared -- you can almost see it in their faces -- are the Democrats in the White House."
Mr. Dole's crowd was made up largely of farmers, many of them Republicans, and many recalled coming to this same fair to see Mr. Reagan and President George Bush. Still, even given the Republican and agricultural roots here -- Mr. Dole grew up in Russell, Kan., also farm country -- the Republican Presidential candidate seemed startled by the vigor of his reception.
When he came to the part of the speech where he advocated a "flatter, fairer" tax system, he slipped and termed it a "fatter" tax. Mr. Dole grinned as his audience howled, looked down at the reporters at his feet and corrected himself. "Flatter, fairer and simpler," he said. The tax system, he said, is "fat enough."
Mr. Dole's appearance in what he called "the heartland" was framed by picturesque symbols of agriculture. Harvested stalks of sweet corn -- seven feet high -- were lined up against the stage. The stage itself was piled with bales of straw. For all the trappings, though, the site was quite genuine; a dairy cow show was moved out of the center this morning to make room for Mr. Dole's rally, which had to be moved inside because it rained.
Mr. Dole has been to Springfield before, and he used this visit today to invoke the names of both Lincoln and Mr. Reagan. At the conclusion of the rally, he and Mr. Kemp went to visit Lincoln's tomb.
Mr. Dole's aides also said they had decided, at least for now, to reduce the visibility of Elizabeth Dole. For the past two days, she has been on stage but has not spoken. Campaign officials, asked about this, said there was some concern that the campaign strengths of both the candidate's wife and his running mate could overshadow Mr. Dole's more laconic and less structured style.
Throughout the day, Mr. Dole and his aides were cheered by their reception here and by the results of their polling, which -- uncharacteristically -- they shared with reporters. They did not do that when Mr. Dole was trailing far behind Mr. Clinton. Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, laughed at Democratic efforts to link him with Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker. "Dole-Gingrich is over," Mr. Reed said. "It's now Dole-Kemp."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Listeners at the Illinois Fair, a favorite campaign stop of Ronald Reagan, responded enthusiastically yesterday to Bob Dole's call for lower taxes. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Sizing Up Dole and Company: Voices From the East Coast to the West

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
With the end of the Republican National Convention, Republicans, Democrats and independent voters around the nation reacted to the four-day event.
 
Peachtree City, Ga.
Move to the Middle Pleases Many
When the police get called in Peachtree City, the crime is less likely to be murder, rape or assault than driving under the influence -- in a golf cart. This 26-year-old planned community, 18 miles south of Atlanta, is a rapidly growing suburban cocoon where new homes cost an average of $180,000, the population is more than 90 percent white, and 4,000 families have purchased golf carts for use on the city's 68 miles of roadside paths. 
 It has been 20 years since a Democratic Presidential candidate won more than a third of the vote here. But for months, through the early jockeying and the primaries, residents were having difficulty building much enthusiasm for Bob Dole. The Republican National Convention seems to have changed that.
On the day after the convention, people interviewed here said they were impressed with the content and delivery of Mr. Dole's acceptance speech on Thursday night. They were thrilled by his selection of Jack Kemp as a running mate.
Above all, they appreciated the moderate, tolerant, inclusive tone of the proceedings, even if it had been scripted by consultants to produce just that response. As in most of Atlanta's exurbs, many residents of Peachtree City are transplanted Northerners who do not share the social conservatism embraced by native Southerners.
"I've just been fascinated that the far right didn't dominate like I thought they would, which is a relief," said Elizabeth L. Drinnon, a 42-year-old health physicist who was eating breakfast at Shadows restaurant with her husband and two sons. "It wasn't only Dole, but the whole platform they presented was so tempered. It was more what we wanted to hear."
As someone who tends to vote for conservative Democrats, Ms. Drinnon said she had been leaning toward President Clinton before the convention. "Now I'm more wishy-washy," she said.
Ms. Drinnon's 47-year-old husband, Jim, had a similar reaction. "I thought one of the highlights was Colin Powell's speech," said Mr. Drinnon, the director of environmental health for the State of Georgia. "I think he represents more of what the Republican Party is all about. He's not too far to the right or too far to the left. He has a very strong social conscience while also talking about the other issues we are interested in, like budget reduction, a strong defense and tax reform."
Both Drinnons said they had seen a new side of Mr. Dole in his acceptance speech. "He's very caring and has a real sense of humor," Mr. Drinnon said.
"When he said he expected Clinton to be in the hall any minute, I thought it was hilarious," he added, referring to Mr. Dole's assertion that Mr. Clinton had "tried to be a good Republican."
To Ms. Drinnon, Mr. Dole was "not as mean-spirited or as hard as I thought, and that made him more palatable."
A number of other Peachtree City residents made similar observations.
Before the convention, Guy C. Ellis, a retired insurance agent, said, Mr. Dole "didn't smile much." He added, "But from the time he named Kemp, he couldn't seem to quit smiling."
Mr. Ellis's wife, Mildred, said, "That had to be the wisest choice he could have made."
Both Ellises said the addition of Mr. Kemp to the ticket made them far more comfortable with Mr. Dole. "We formerly lived in Pennsylvania, about 90 miles from Buffalo, and we watched Jack Kemp play football his whole career," Mr. Ellis said.
While swinging at a playground with his 21-month-old son, Nicholas, on his lap, John C. Schmidt also praised Mr. Dole's selection of Mr. Kemp. "He didn't do what George Bush did," said Mr. Schmidt, a regional sales manager for a golf equipment company. "If anything happens to Bob Dole, God forbid, we've got someone with experience, someone who knows the process. And I think Kemp appeals to a broad spectrum of people."
Elizabeth M. Jones, a 31-year-old mother who moved here from Westchester County, N.Y., two years ago, said that Mr. Dole had given "an inspiring speech, very emotional." The speech, she said, helped persuade her to vote for Mr. Dole rather than for Ross Perot, as she did four years ago. "He came out fighting when he took on the teachers' unions," she said. "And he didn't play too much on the whole war hero thing."
Ms. Jones said she favored abortion rights but would support Mr. Dole, an opponent of abortion rights, because of his economic proposals, including his plan to cut income taxes by 15 percent. "You have to look at the whole package," she said.
If there was a clear convention loser in Peachtree City, it was the television networks. A number of people volunteered that they had switched from the networks to C-Span because of the commenting by network anchors and reporters.
"We like that C-Span," Mr. Ellis said. "They just let us watch it and form our own opinion." KEVIN SACK

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

NEW KITTENS
 The Beardsley Zoo, at 1875 Noble Avenue in Bridgeport, has a new attraction -- three 12-week-old lynx kittens. They are the first felines to be born at the zoo since 1986, when a Siberian tiger gave birth to triplets. The lynx kittens and their mother may be watched at play for a few hours each day at the zoo. 
 Meanwhile, special free entertainment programs for children are scheduled at the zoo's pavilion on the next two Saturday afternoons, when the Amazing Andy will perform magic, juggling and comedy.
Zoo hours are 9 to 4 every day, and admission is $4 for adults, $2 for older adults and children 3 through 11, free to children under 3. The number for more information is 331-1557.

NEW OTTERS
The Maritime Aquarium in Norwalk (formerly called the Maritime Center) has acquired a pair of nature's most playful species -- young North American river otters named Bell and Sprite after two islands in Norwalk Harbor.
Their new home consists of two pools, two waterfalls and a habitat that mimics a wooded shoreline. One of their favorite pastimes is sliding down a mud bank into the water. Underwater and above-water viewing puts visitors no more than 7 feet away from the animals.
Another exhibition at the aquarium will enable visitors to reach out and touch a shark. It's called a Shark Touch Pool, and staff members who are constantly in attendance say that these are harmless species of sharks, skates and rays. Stroking the back of a shark can be a reassuring experience for the visitor and although it has not been confirmed, probably feels pretty good to the shark.
The center, at 10 North Water Street, is open daily from 10 to 6. Admission is $7.50 for adults, $4.50 for children and older adults. The number for more information is 852-0700.

CHANGING FASHIONS
You are what you wear is a notion that is evident in the exhibition at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport through Sept. 8. "Try This On: A History of Clothing, Gender and Power" tracks 200 years of changing fashions and mores in the United States.
Victorian prudery is reflected in women's corsets and multiple undergarments. Parasols, gloves, hair-curling gadgets, bathing suits that covered men and women almost everywhere except the face, and dozens of additional examples of raiment are on display.
Changing perceptions about gender are examined during the Roaring Twenties, when women bobbed their hair, wore short skirts and pants, and very little underneath. A half-century later men grew their hair long and took to necklaces, loose flowing clothing and over-the-shoulder purses.
A number of products related to the world of clothes were (and some still are) manufactured in Bridgeport. Among those represented in the exhibition are Warnaco Inc., makers of corsets and underwear; Remington, makers of shavers, hair dryers and curlers, and vintage models of Howe and Singer Sewing machines.
The museum, located at 820 Main Street, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 4:30; Sunday from noon to 4:30. Admission is $5 for adults, $4 for college students, children 4 through 18 and older adults. Children under 4 are admitted free. The number for more information is 331-1104.

GOOD SEEDS
Wethersfield is the home of the red onion and many other tasty items offered to the public in seed form by Comstock, Ferre & Company, the Charles H. Hart Seed Company and other firms that have gone out of business over the years, or been taken over by larger competitors.
An exhibition titled "Good Seed in the Proper Season," on view at the Wethersfield Historical Society through October, examines the town's impressive agricultural history.
Because it is on some of the state's most fertile soil, adjacent to the Connecticut River, Wethersfield moved easily into being a center of the seed industry in the 19th century. Benefitting economically from Hartford's sizable population nearby, Wethersfield's seed growers and farmers prospered, changing crops to meet market demands. As the country grew, for example, wheat and other crops began to come in from the West, and tobacco became a more lucrative item for farmers in Connecticut.
Early onion farming of the 18th century to modern dairy farms are covered in one section of the exhibition, replete with such tools and machinery as a flax brake and wheel, corn sheller, seed drills and scythes.
Seed as a major industry in the 19th and early 20th century takes up a second section with displays of grain riddles, seed drying racks, germinators and oak seed bins. Patented seeding implements, photographs, seed catalogs, packets and broadsides are also featured.
The society is at 150 Main Street and is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 4, Sunday from 1 to 4. Admission is $2, free to children under 17. The number is 529-7656 for more information.

DANBURY FESTIVAL
The recently built Danbury green will be the site of the third annual Gasball Festival on Saturday from 11:30 A.M. to midnight. Continuous entertainment by two dozen music groups will be offered for alternating periods on two stages, artists will hold an exhibition of painting and sculpture, and local area merchants will present a wide variety of merchandise and food for sale.
Gasball, the name of a local art gallery that sponsors the event, is the nickname given to a huge, empty gray ball-shaped storage tank that sits at the edge of downtown and was used formerly to store gas.
The Gasball Gallery specializes in offbeat and avant garde works -- a policy that will be followed in choosing the art and music for the Gasball Festival. The rain date is next Sunday. The number is 790-6754 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

CORRECTION-DATE: August 25, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Guide column last Sunday about the "Back at the Ranch" concert in Montauk, held last Monday, carried an outdated reference to a beneficiary of the event. The Retreat, a shelter and counseling service for victims of domestic violence, declined funds from the concert because a performer, the singer James Brown, has been accused of assaulting his wife.

HEADLINE: Mystery Men;
Why the Choice of '96 Will Remain a Bafflement

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
BOB DOLE'S fellow Republicans extolled him last week as a man of convictions rooted in the sturdy heartland of America. He presented himself to the convention that nominated him (and the electorate to which he was appealing) as the champion who could restore to government old values like "restraint, honor and trust in the people."
He depicted the Clinton Administration as a crew "who never grew up, never did anything real, never sacrificed, never suffered and never learned." 
 It was that contrast in values and in personal history that the Republicans sought to emphasize in San Diego last week, almost completely avoiding public discussions of their highly conservative platform and indeed giving no substantial clues, except on economic matters, as to how a Dole Administration would act.
In fact, Americans are not likely to emerge with any reliable programmatic road maps from convention month, which also includes the concluding sessions of Ross Perot's Reform Party conclave in Valley Forge, Pa., this weekend and the Democratic convention in Chicago opening a week from Monday. Few politicians are willing to commit themselves in advance to more than a few specific policy initiatives, for fear that they will lose support, and Messrs. Clinton, Dole and Perot, specialists all in the soaring generalization, are harder to pin down than most.
All of them, Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton especially, are creatures of their times, and these times are the heyday of the pollster and the focus-group interviewer. Positions are formulated, modified, even reversed to fit the changing attitudes of voters. Pragmatism is king, and candidates learn quickly to play the chameleon.
The Religious Right may have dominated the platform committee and indeed the floor of the Republican convention, but its message was not the one that was seen on TV and its message is not the one Mr. Dole and his running mate, Jack Kemp, will be taking on the road this fall. They do not wish to debate the Democrats on abortion, for example, because they know that the country sides with the Democrats, not the Republican social conservatives.
Likewise, President Clinton was quite prepared, when his hold on office seemed to be slipping, to turn hard to the right, start stealing the Republicans' rhetorical clothes and even sign a welfare bill his associates disliked. For electoral purposes, he is galloping off in pursuit of the majority.
In addition, each of this year's candidates has peculiarities of character and strategic circumstance that contribute to the confusion.
Normally, incumbent Presidents have a track record they can be expected to build upon in their second terms. But it is hard to find common threads in a record that includes retreat from Somalia and involvement in Bosnia, unavailing support for homosexuals in the military and the abandonment of Federal guarantees for the well-being of poor children.
More than ever as the campaign unfolds this autumn, the nation will be asking, Who is the real Bill Clinton? and probably finding only an echo for an answer. All the more so because he cannot run for a third term. That means the inventor of what he calls the "permanent campaign," which makes re-election the prime driving force in government, will have to find a new dynamic to push him forward. Friends suggest that if re-elected, his eye will shift to his place in history.
If so, what does that portend? Perhaps he will conclude that curbing the deficit is not so important after all, and take a second crack at large-scale health reform, or re-reform welfare. Perhaps, freed of political constraints and faced with the threat of renewed chaos in the Balkans, he might change his policy on Bosnia for the umpteenth time and leave American troops there after the deadline for withdrawal passes, conveniently after Election Day has come and gone.
The Republican ticket is surrounded by no less ambiguity. Mr. Dole had to tack to the right during the primaries to cope with Patrick J. Buchanan, and he had foisted upon him by the convention a less supple, less inclusive platform than he wanted. So he promptly disavowed it, saying he had not even bothered to read it. But words can be weapons, and the Democrats can be counted on to remind him of the more extreme elements in the platform.
Mr. Dole is a compromiser by trade, a legislative conciliator, and he defended that approach in accepting his nomination. He said months ago that he would remake himself a la Reagan if need be, and he has more or less done so. A fierce foe of supply-side economics most of his career, he now proclaims himself a supply-sider, and he has a supply-side running mate, Jack Kemp, who in his turn has flip-flopped with embarrassing speed on affirmative action and immigration, to bring himself into line with Mr. Dole.
It is impossible not to ask whether Mr. Dole really means to try to cut taxes and reduce the deficit and defend Social Security and some other entitlements, as he promised to do. He has believed for so long that it was not possible to do all three, and he will be pressed hard during the campaign to explain.
It is impossible, furthermore, not to wonder where he would end up on abortion if he occupied the Oval Office. For electoral purposes, he sought to downplay the whole issue, uttering the word once in passing in his prime-time speech and drawing no contrast between his own position and Mr. Clinton's. Mr. Clinton will make more of the matter in Chicago and on the campaign trail, of course, which will make it much harder for Mr. Dole to avoid.
If elected, would he push hard for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion, as mandated by the party platform, to please his supporters on the right, as Mr. Clinton did, in mirror image, with gays in the military? Or would Mr. Dole concentrate on other matters and content himself with the nomination of judges opposed to abortion, trying to stay closer to the middle ground?
Foreign policy may not play much of a role in the campaign, unless major trouble breaks out in China, Bosnia or the Middle East. But even so, the voter who would like to know how he would deal with a post-Yeltsin Russia, a post-Deng China or a Bosnian blowup in December is unlikely to get very clear answers.
Nor is there much point in looking to Mr. Perot. As he has said repeatedly the last five years, he thinks the major parties have few solutions to the nation's problems. For his part, he continues to offer explanations of how he would go about looking for solutions rather than any concrete ideas. The voter seeking further elucidation is met mainly with aphorism and anecdote.
Beneath all this posturing and positioning, of course, there are genuine issues: how to cut entitlements without provoking a national chorus of outrage, how to increase productivity without increasing unemployment or underemployment and how to put welfare mothers to work when many lack any marketable skills or the education to obtain them quickly.
But they lend themselves poorly to dramatization in campaign commercials and sound bites, so don't expect Messrs. Dole, Clinton and Perot to draw any hard-and-fast blueprints for action in the weeks ahead.

HEADLINE: Off Their Marx;
If Right Is Center, Where Is Left?

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FREE-MARKET capitalism seems triumphant worldwide, the new consensus at the end of the century. So with President Clinton heading to his convention sounding like George Bush and Republicans now complaining about economic injustice, what's left of the left?
Well, it's regrouping, but with more vigor than conventional wisdom might allow. Its partisans warn of the dangers of elitist, utopian, one-issue politics and speak of a new commitment to organizational politics on a local level -- in the workplace, city council or neighborhood, where "real people" presumably live. 
 "The biggest mistake the left has made and continues to make is that it's fairly cut off from the currents of people's everyday life," says one of its new stalwarts, Jay Walljasper, an editor of the Utne Reader, a kind of Reader's Digest of the alternative press. "A lot of people might agree with the thinking of the left, but the vibe is that the left doesn't care about them, it's too intellectual, and instead goes off on crusades about identity politics and political correctness."
Today the goal of progressives -- as these more pragmatic leftists call themselves -- is to insure social justice and equality in a global economy dominated by multinational corporations, not governments. But how to do it, and how to overcome the elitist legacy of the past?
The collapse of the Soviet Union and the socialist alternative has pushed the world's politics to the right. Not only is Marx discredited, but everywhere, from Sweden to India, there has been a turn away from giantism and faith in government and its smothering bureaucracy as the best engine for economic development and social justice.
Even the welfare state envisioned by John Maynard Keynes, which fosters social safeguards in the free market, is in disrepair and may be irreparably broken. Social democracies like Sweden and Germany, which once seemed alternative models for the United States, are coming up against the limits of the state's ability to pay for social benefits in a globalized economy where a lack of competitiveness means the export of jobs.
"What's striking is that the left today really accepts the right's argument about the limitations of the state," says Francis Fukuyama of the Rand Corporation. "It's hard to find anyone who defends the idea of pursuing social equality through the power of the state."

 
 
Local and Global
 So the focus has shifted to local issues and global concerns, to non-governmental organizations and international environmental or feminist groups, aided by cheap communication on the Internet. But at the national level, as Mr. Fukuyama points out and the Democratic convention next week will surely demonstrate, the left is largely absent. (This is an irony, considering that "the left" as a label derives from national government; the term originally referred to the area where radical deputies sat in the post-revolutionary French assembly, as seen from the chairman's seat.)
Joel Rogers, leader of the leftist New Party, which has won some 100 local elections, mostly in the Midwest, said the left's new issues range from neighborhood topics like crime, schools and sustainable local jobs to the push for social fairness in access to health care, decent wages and a clean environment. The aim is to heal and recreate "civil society" on the local level, even if significant national power is for now out of reach.
With the American economy growing, real wages are declining for the non-college-educated workers who make up most of the workforce. Large factory towns -- where labor was easily unionized -- are being supplanted by smaller companies and branches scattered in suburbs and computerized, making it more difficult to lump workers into proletariat and boss.
But despite such practical obstacles to organization, Mr. Rogers, a University of Wisconsin professor, sees opportunity. "With this generation in economic decline, there's the largest potential market for progressive politics since the 1930's," he said. "But what the left in America needs and doesn't have is an electoral strategy," one that goes beyond waiting to see who the Democrats nominate. He said that is why in 1992 he founded the New Party, which claims 8,000 members.
Internationally, as Mr. Fukuyama points out, human-rights and leftist organizations mobilized to force the Mexican Government to moderate its response to the revolt of the indigenous people of Chiapas. But on traditional foreign-policy issues, the American left has surprisingly little to say, beyond a general opposition to American military intervention anywhere.
It has concentrated too much on racial and sexual politics, and too little on the general good, said Mr. Walljasper. "When the American worker was losing his or her birthright, a lot of the left was taken up with Central America," he said. "Community organizing doesn't offer the same glamour factor as dancing with the Sandinistas."
This inattention to local organizing and reluctance to touch the Communist-tainted issue of class in America "allows the Republicans, in an Orwellian way, to slam the Democrats as elitist," Mr. Walljasper said. "And it leaves the field open for the demagogy" of Patrick J. Buchanan and Ross Perot, who "connect with ordinary people" on issues that enrage them, like crime, wage stagnation and the heartlessness of big companies and global capital. Mr. Walljasper, a Midwesterner, said that during the Republican primary season it was Mr. Buchanan who spoke most effectively about the breakup of family farms and the environmental devastation wrought by corporate agriculture.
Trying to move away from so-called "identity" politics, which began with the black-power movement, many leftists are ambivalent about taking up racial issues. For their part, many blacks -- not to mention feminists -- fear losing the focus on group identity. Such differences of view recall those between the black-power and anti-war movements in the 1960's, when young whites were more concerned about Vietnam than Watts.
Daniel Yergin, who is finishing a book on this century's ideological and economic battle between the state and the marketplace, argues that the traditional left has lost much of its agenda. "The phrase 'free market' falls as easily from Clinton's lips as from Bush's," he says. "It's a hard time for those who are anti-market, so many people have turned away from economics to ethnic or gender studies to find some Marxist-like principles, and to fulfill the emotional yearning for opposition and idealism."
Others disagree. Katrina vanden Heuvel, editor of The Nation, who is trying to revive it as a mainstream magazine for left-wing debate, says the left is learning its lesson and focusing once again on economics.
The collapse of the Soviet model is a fake issue, she said, since the largest European socialist parties had repudiated it long before. More troubling are the problems European social democratic parties are experiencing in adapting to a changing world economy. It's not just the left struggling against corporate power these days, she suggests, but the state itself.
The American left has been liberated to think about new models, she said, and, like the American labor movement, is expanding after a period of decline.
"A left that puts falling wages and economic insecurity at the center has a chance to develop an alternative to the suffocating consensus that austerity is the future," Ms. vanden Heuvel said.
For Mr. Walljasper, the concentration on community, civil society and local politics stems from a new consensus that "small is beautiful," an idea originating in the environmental movement. It is an effort to restore the voluntary associations that Alexis de Tocqueville identified as emblematic of American democracy, but which are now in decline. The concentration on neighborhood is aided by the aging of a '60's generation that now owns property and raises children, and it dovetails with the conservative effort to devolve more power to states and localities.

 
 
Philosophical Strains
 There is no single theoretical foundation to replace Marx, but figures from Gandhi to Vaclav Havel and well-known feminists have been important in teaching that "the personal is also political," Mr. Walljasper said, and that societies can be reformed through many means. The politics of sexuality and identity are important, he argues, but they are "side dishes" to economics, the environment and human rights.
One paradox, notes Ian Hargreaves, editor of the New Statesman, Britain's best-known journal of the left, is that as the mainstream left moves to the center -- with Mr. Clinton in the White House and Tony Blair positioning the British Labor Party for its first turn in Government in 20 years -- "the Left with a capital 'L' doesn't want to know." The traditional left in Britain is so wrapped up in its own debates that it ignores Mr. Blair's proximity to real power, or disparages him for trying to become electable.
Mr. Clinton has been successful at economic conservatism while appealing to the cultural left wing of the party on issues like gay rights and abortion, but there is a constituency "for cultural rightism and economic populism," Mr. Fukuyama says, to which Mr. Buchanan, and not the left, has been appealing.
Mr. Fukuyama recently saw a billboard for a local television station that showed Fidel Castro on the left, Mr. Buchanan on the right, and a basketball player as the center. It is telling, he said, that "the guys who wrote the ad couldn't find an American politician who could symbolize the left."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

CAMPAIGN '96
Promises, Promises
Bob Dole, at last the official Republican nominee, played that old theme song, promising to "get the economy moving again." In his acceptance speech, after discussing values like family and duty, he moved on to the good stuff: lower taxes, zippy growth, a balanced budget, lots more spending on the military, down with the I.R.S., up with the I.R.A. And one thing is sure: The White House in a Dole era wouldn't be populated by those lib kids at home there now, that boomer elite, as Mr. Dole said, "who never grew up, never did anything real, never sacrificed, never suffered and never learned." Not like their daddies.

INFLATION ALERT
What Blips Up Can Blip Down
Traders woke from a sleepy August week to panic briefly on a report of a blip in consumer prices. They were up three-tenths of a percentage point in July, lifting inflation for the past 12 months to a whopping 3 percent. That and a report of strong retail sales, suggesting a heated-up economy, sent interest rates higher and stocks lower. Later, the Federal Reserve restored the status quo, saying industrial production edged up a mere one-tenth of a point in July, the smallest amount in four months. And new housing construction fell to the slowest level in four months. All that allowed traders to sneak off for their Friday golf dates. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week about where it began, at 5,689.45 points, up 8 points.
 
BUY AND HOLD DEPT.
Buffett Is It
Warren Buffett is America's second-richest man, in fact the world's second-richest man, according to Forbes magazine, which is to the super-rich what People magazine is to Gwyneth Paltrow and Matthew McConaughey. (The wealthiest individual, of course, is that Microsoft fellow out West who defined geek chic.) When Forbes checked in last month, Mr. Buffett had added $4.6 billion to his net worth in the last year, or $125,000 a day, every day of the year, including Feb. 29. But even brilliant stock-pickers suffer reversals. The shares of his investment vehicle Berkshire Hathaway have fallen 14 percent since their high in March, and earnings slipped in the second quarter. Perhaps the market agreed with Mr. Buffett's candid assessment in Berkshire's annual report that the company's market price had grown even faster than its intrinsic value. The stock won big on a doubling in Coca-Cola's stock price. (Berkshire's Coca-Cola shares are now worth $10 billion, or 42 percent of its stock holdings.) Even if Coke's big run is over, Mr. Buffett's composure isn't likely to suffer. When he buys, he typically holds, and then holds some more.

ENGLISH 101
And Watch Your P's and Q's
Suffolk County, on eastern Long Island, is going to vote on a measure to pick an official language, deciding that would insure economic advancement. It follows the lead of 23 states and 15 cities that have picked an official language. But the vote will not be a multiple choice -- a) Chinese, b) Farsi, c) English. Actually, that choice was already made by county legislators. One said, "If people want to partake of the American dream they have to know the language." Opponents say the county is overreacting to the 1.2 percent of its population of Hispanic origin who speak limited or no English. Whether or not the measure is the right dose of medicine, it is true that people "who know English do a lot better in their earnings and employment," said George Borjas, professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
 
PICKING UP ROOTS
Where Exactly Is Wall St.?
If the Big Board moves off Wall Street, what becomes of Wall Street? Perhaps it doesn't matter, because the street is less an address than a metaphor, like Detroit, which people refer to as the focus of the automobile universe even while car plants spring up in Kentucky. Still, the idea of Wall Street without the New York Stock Exchange takes some getting used to. The exchange, which has been at 11 Wall since 1903, is beginning to cast about for bigger quarters to accommodate a much-enlarged trading floor for the electronic era. It intends to stay somewhere in Manhattan, though not necessarily downtown. Tough luck, Jersey City.
 
BROWSER WARS
And in This Corner . . .
Compared to Netscape, Microsoft is in the uncharacteristic role of underdog, a position it does not want to get used to. The Netscape Navigator Internet browser is used by more than 85 percent of computer users for viewing pages on the World Wide Web. Microsoft is rushing to catch up with its Explorer browser, and the marketing war has begun. Microsoft's new version, available free on the Net, gives away subscriptions through Dec. 31 to the Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition, which normally costs $49 a year, and to the ESPNet Sportszone, which usually charges a la carte. "If you look at how Microsoft built their franchise in operating systems, it was by adding applications and locking people in," said David Smith of the Gartner Group. "Now content is the application."
 
MEDICAL SCHOOLS
Tune In, Drop Out
Medical students pay much money to attend Cornell University Medical College -- except when Cornell pays them to stay out. Granted, it's a cockeyed arrangement, but Cornell somehow overbooked the incoming class by 15 percent. That forced the school to offer a one-time-only sale -- a tuition-free year, worth $24,000. It is available to doctors-in-waiting willing to put off enrollment a year. A few signed up, but others, ever rational, figured that even a big discount was outweighed by the loss of a year's future earnings, and that's real money in a most lucrative profession. While Cornell and other schools are bulging, some specialists say American schools are turning out too many doctors.

MUTUAL FUNDS
A Marketing Advantage
Fidelity Investments intends to set up an insurance company to protect investors in its money market mutual funds in case of default by any of the security issuers. It would provide coverage of up to $100 million, a relatively small amount in light of Fidelity's $80 billion of assets. But that could be enough to give the company a big marketing advantage.
 
TECHNOLOGY
A Star Dims
Hewlett-Packard fulfilled predictions of a down quarter, ending years of above-average growth that made it one of the country's most-admired companies. Earnings fell 26 percent in the second quarter, and the company said some of its profit constraints could continue. "Our PC growth continues at or above the industry growth rate," Hewlett said. "But it is slower than when we were rapidly gaining market share." But Dell Computer, another technology leader, surpassed expectations, with earnings growing 58 percent. It enjoyed strong sales and lower chip prices.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Business Diary column on Aug. 18 about the market performance of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, misstated the estimated daily increase in his net worth in the last year. It was $12.5 million a day, not $125,000.

HEADLINE: In Defense of Federal Power;
Big Government Is a Check

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, a professor of American history at Columbia, is the author most recently of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:
All the sound-bite superficiality of the television campaign notwithstanding, a profoundly serious debate is under way in America this season. It turns on dozens of proposed constitutional amendments and laws to radically reshape our system of Government. These two essays are part of a series of "New Federalist Papers" commissioned by Richard C. Leone of the Twentieth Century Fund for a forthcoming book on what is probably the broadest challenge to the Constitution since its ratification in 1789.
 
THE CRIPPLING OF THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT IS ALREADY far advanced. The fiscal crisis of the last 15 years, in which both Republicans and Democrats have been complicit, has placed a financial straitjacket (deplored by some, quietly welcomed by others) on both the President and the Congress. The Clinton Administration found itself a prisoner of the deficit almost from the beginning. Public investment, the Administration's original proposals for health care and welfare reform and other initiatives were all its victims. The Republican Congress, ideologically committed to scaling back Government, has found the deficit its greatest ally in that effort.
But the assault on Government has moved far beyond the effects of the nation's fiscal torpor. A list of some of the changes on the conservative agenda last year suggests the scope of the threat: 
 * The balanced budget amendment failed twice, but it will surely rise again. If enacted, it would institutionalize what is already an informal brake on Government action by subordinating all public efforts to eliminate the deficit. Constitutional amendments are dangerous tools for establishing policy priorities. A constitutionally mandated balanced budget would dramatically weaken the Government's ability to promote prosperity and growth.
* Term limits, rejected by Congress last spring, are also likely to emerge again in the form of a constitutional amendment. Term limits would insure a consistently inexperienced Congress unlikely to counter the power of the President effectively and prey -- even more than today's legislature -- to the influence of special interests.
* Requiring supermajorities in both Houses of Congress for passage of certain legislation is another part of the anti-Government agenda. The Senate already, in effect, requires a 60 percent vote on most important bills now that party leaders have made the filibuster (for the first time in our history) a routine legislative tactic. The new House rule to require a 60 percent majority for tax increases would, if enforced, virtually insure the defeat of any measure, however vital, to increase Government revenues.
* Eliminating unfunded mandates, a process begun by legislation passed last year would, if taken to the lengths many conservatives are urging, destroy the most important form of leverage the Federal Government has over state and local authorities. Washington manages very few programs directly: almost everything it finances is administered to some degree by other levels of government, usually according to guidelines established by Congress or the Federal agencies. Some such guidelines are surely ineffective and counterproductive. But there is a critical difference between eliminating bad guidelines and eliminating the Government's ability to establish any guidelines at all.
* The Supreme Court has already edged toward restoring long-repudiated limitations on the ability of the Federal Government to act. Last year, it overturned legislation banning guns in the vicinity of schools; now it may be one vote away not just from changing course on such emotionally charged issues as abortion and affirmative action but from fundamentally redefining the limits of Federal power in a way that could undo decades of social and economic policy.
Taken together, these measures and other state-crippling initiatives threaten to leave the Federal Government so enfeebled that it would have little power to manage the economy, address social problems, protect the environment or do any of the other things most Americans have come to expect it to do. The current proposed reforms would move the United States toward becoming a Balkanized republic, with 50 semiautonomous governments. They would increase, not reduce, the number of bureaucracies with which citizens would have to deal and accentuate the regional, economic, religious, ethnic and racial differences that already divide us.
What, in fact, has been the principal concern of state governments in recent years? It has not, for the most part, been building better social programs; it has been competing with other states to attract jobs. So far, that has meant mostly various kinds of tax credits and job-training assistance. But without national standards that competition would quickly escalate into other realms: relaxing or abandoning environmental regulations, rolling back health and safety protections for workers, restricting the power of trade unions to organize, reducing taxes by eliminating social services to the poor.
At the heart of the debate is, of course, the question of where power should lie in a democratic society. Conservatives like to claim that they are trying to return power to the people themselves, a promise that resonates with one of America's oldest and most powerful political traditions: populism. But reducing the power of Government is not by itself a route to empowering ordinary citizens. Modern society has many centers of concentrated power, of which the Government is only one and not always the most important. The large interests that shape our world are more numerous and more powerful even than those the populists of the late 19th century decried: corporate bureaucracies, the great institutions of the media, banks and financial institutions, trade associations and lobbying groups, and many others. None of them have much accountability to individual citizens.
Far from restoring power to individuals, disempowering the Federal Government will do precisely the opposite. It will weaken the only national institution capable of checking some of the other large organizations that dominate modern life. It will leave individuals with even less control over their own fates. It is not the route to more democracy. It is the route to less.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A British agency gets the Sebastiani account, while a French one expands in Mexico and Brazil.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TWO agencies, one based in Britain and the other in France, are making news in North and South America.
The San Francisco office of the British agency Leagas Delaney has been awarded its first assignment separate from the accounts of its parent. And Publicis S.A. in Paris is acquiring controlling interests in agencies in Mexico and Brazil, as part of ambitious expansion plans that follow the termination of a worldwide cooperative agreement with True North Communications. 
 At the San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney, which was opened in March, the new assignment came from Sebastiani Vineyards, the winery in Sonoma, Calif. Sebastiani has named the office as the first agency to handle its account, with billings estimated at $5 million.
Jack Rooney, managing director of the agency's San Francisco office, said in a telephone interview on Friday that Leagas Delaney was selected by Sebastiani after a review that also included three undisclosed San Francisco agencies. The assignment brings billings handled by the office to an estimated $25 million, he added.
The San Francisco office will create campaigns for two lines of varietal wines produced by Sebastiani: Talus, priced at $5.99 to $8.99 a bottle, and Vendange, priced at $5.99 and below.
The San Francisco office is also continuing to work for two clients of its parent, which is based in London: Adidas A.G. and Patek Phillipe. An American broadcast, print and outdoor campaign for Adidas, carrying the theme "Feet you wear," is now being introduced.
As for the agreements Publicis has reached with the agencies in Mexico and Brazil, terms are not being disclosed. The Mexican transaction was announced late Friday and details of the Brazilian deal are scheduled to be outlined this afternoon in that country.
In Mexico, Publicis Group, the advertising agency unit of Publicis S.A., is buying 51 percent of Romero y Asociados in Mexico City. That agency has billings estimated at $10 million from clients like Nestle S.A., also a Publicis Group client; Kimberly-Clark and Reckitt & Colman.
Carlos Romero Hidalgo continues as chairman and chief executive of Romero, which was founded in 1951. The agency will get a new name, Publicis-Romero.
In Brazil, Publicis Group is buying 60 percent of Norton Publicidade, with billings estimated at more than $100 million from clients like Nestle, Wal-Mart Stores and General Electric and offices in Brasilia, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo; the agency also has an office in Paris.
Geraldo Alonso Filho continues as president and chief executive of Norton, which was founded in 1946. The agency, Brazil's 12th largest, will be renamed Publicis-Norton.
In a memo to employees, Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive of Publicis, said, "These acquisitions represent an important stage in our geographic development through our presence in the most populous and most economically promising countries in the Americas."
"Publicis's route to globalization is now clearly open," he added.
Publicis Group has offices in 58 cities in 21 European countries and owns Publicis/Bloom in the United States. Publicis Group is also collaborating on an ad hoc basis with the M & C Saatchi Agency in London, assisting that shop on the British Airways account.
"These are the concrete steps of autonomous international development following the end of our international development alliance with True North," said Seth Goldschlager, a spokesman for Publicis S.A. in Paris.
That reference was to decisions by Publicis S.A. and True North, which is based in Chicago, to terminate the agreement binding them to cooperate worldwide. But the two remain partners in Publicis FCB Europe, a joint-venture European agency network that covers 31 countries.
In June, members of the board of True North formed a special committee to try to resolve a rancorous two-year dispute between Mr. Levy and Bruce Mason, chairman and chief executive of True North, which led to the termination of the alliance. The two executives have argued over the management of the joint venture and policies on acquisitions.

HEADLINE: Louis Berger, 82, Who Built Engineering Concern

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Dr. Louis Berger, an engineer whose expertise in soil conditions enabled him to build highways and even airport runways effectively on soft ground, died in Manhattan on Wednesday after a short illness. He was 82 and lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and Verona, N.J.
The cause was congestive heart failure, according to the Berger Group, the company he still headed at his death. 
 Dr. Berger, known to most as "Doc," founded the company in 1953 and built it into a huge engineering, economics and environmental planning concern that employs almost 3,000 people in more than 70 countries.
Dr. Berger's professional success stands in sharp contrast to his modest beginnings. He was born in 1914 and raised, with three brothers and a sister, in Lawrence, Mass., where his father had a small glazing business. Money was so tight that he missed two terms of college because he was $100 short of tuition.
Still, he graduated from Tufts College in 1936, with a degree in civil engineering. He went on to receive a master's in soils and geology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1940, he took his first job, supervising construction of two large dams in southern Illinois.
In 1942, during World War II, Mr. Berger joined the United States Coast Guard, first designing waterfront facilities along the Mississippi and later commanding a Coast Guard base in Greenland.
When he returned from active duty, he went on for a doctorate in soil mechanics from Northwestern University and then joined the engineering faculty at Pennsylvania State University. In 1952, Dr. Berger gave up his professorship and opened his first consulting office, in Harrisburg, Pa. His first big assignment was to design part of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the first turnpike in the United States.
A year later, he opened a second office and began chasing international as well as domestic clients, often training local people to work with him. Since then, the Berger Group, which is based in East Orange, N.J., has been involved in the design, planning and construction management of more than 100,000 miles of highway, 2,000 miles of railroad, and numerous bridges, airfields and other projects in some 120 countries.
He helped design the Rangoon-to-Mandalay Road in Burma, the 2,000-mile Trans-Amazon Highway and the Ovda air base in Israel. He saved the Navy more than $100 million by finding a way to use locally available stone to build a runway at U Taphao, Thailand, the largest military base in Southeast Asia.
Dr. Berger bowed out of the formal management of his company in the 1980's, but never stopped working on projects. In recent years he helped create a complex computerized design system, and supervised the building of the Second Bangkok International Airport.
Louis Berger is survived by his wife, the former Annette Block; two children from a previous marriage, Fredric Steven Berger of Chevy Chase, Md., and Jane Tallents Stonborough of London; two brothers, Samuel, of Stoughton, Mass., and Abraham, of Glendora, Calif.; a sister, Miriam Cohen of Israel; three stepchildren, and two stepgrandchildren. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Jobless Trends Show U.S. Falls As Others Rise

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Unemployment in the United States has dropped by almost half in the last 15 years while in Japan, Germany and other competing countries jobless claims have risen, with little sign of improvement.
The long-term trends emerge from detailed figures that the Labor Department has just published, covering the last third of the century. 
 American joblessness peaked at 9.7 percent in 1982, the second year of the Reagan Administration. It declined steadily for the next seven years, then rose again to 7.5 percent in 1992, the year Bill Clinton was elected President. Then it dropped again, falling to 5.4 percent in July.
Through the 1960's and early 1970's, Japan kept its unemployment rate at less than 2 percent, breaking that barrier only in 1976. A steady rise in the next two decades pushed it to more than 3.5 percent this year.
France and West Germany also had histories of low unemployment in the 1960's and early 1970's. But in 1975, West German unemployment more than doubled, to 3.4 percent. In France there was also a sharp rise, to 4.2 percent from 2.9 percent.
Since then West Germany's rise has continued, reaching 6.5 percent last year. That percentage does not include the former East Germany, which has been united with West Germany throughout the 1990's. German Government figures show the same trend for the united country.
French unemployment reached 11.5 percent last year and Italy's 12 percent -- more than twice the American rate. Figures for Japan, Germany, France and Italy have continued to edge up in 1996.
Britain's joblessness peaked at 11.8 percent 1983 and has since dropped, but only to 8.3 percent.
John Howard, director of international policy and programs for the United States Chamber of Commerce, saw the difference in trends as a sign of economic strength. But Mark Anderson, director of international trade for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., argued that "There's a different focus of the government, especially in France, Germany and Italy. They focus more on a fairer distribution of income and not on throwing someone on the street to work for whatever wage he or she can get."
