HEADLINE: Storm in St. Kitts, as a Cocaine Case Churns Politics

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BASSETERRE, St. Kitts and Nevis, Aug. 15

 BODY:
It started with a large shipment of cocaine into this tiny Caribbean country two years ago. The resulting scandal helped bring down one government, which was criticized for having done too little to combat drug trafficking, and now threatens another, which is suddenly under attack for supposedly having done too much.
Several people, among them two sons of a former Deputy Prime Minister, have been arrested in the case and accused of working with Colombian cartels to ship cocaine to the United States. As a result, Washington recently requested the extradition of three of the accused drug traffickers, who have begun a legal and political counteroffensive in an effort to remain here. 
 The case is proving a severe test for the 46,000 people of this sleepy federation of two islands, the smallest nation in the Western Hemisphere, 250 miles southeast of Puerto Rico. Though politics here normally focus on matters related to tourism and agriculture, drugs have now become "the main issue in this country," Prime Minister Denzil L. Douglas, who took office a little more than a year ago, said in an interview.
The criminal charges and the political crisis stem from a shipment of cocaine into St. Kitts in September 1994 that resulted in the killing of one son of the Deputy Prime Minister at the time, Sidney Morris, and the arrest of two others. The ensuing controversy forced Mr. Morris to resign and led the governing People's Action Movement to call early elections.
In that July 1995 balloting, Prime Minister Kennedy Simmonds, who had led this country since independence from Britain was achieved in 1983, went down to defeat. He was replaced by the opposition St. Kitts Labor Party, whose platform promised "a government truly committed to fighting the scourge of crime and drugs that has overtaken our country" and greater cooperation with the United States.
The new administration's determination to take a tougher stance against drug trafficking has won the praise of American and British officials. "They're trying to do the right thing, and need all the support they can get from the United States and other interested parties," said a diplomat in the region.
But cooperation with the United States has brought with it a high political and economic cost, especially on the extradition question. "We've been criticized by the opposition, which argues that we would be violating the sovereignty of this country by giving up our citizens to the United States," Mr. Douglas said. As in other Caribbean island countries that have gained independence from Britain in recent years, any action viewed as a cession of sovereignty is controversial here.
In late May, the United States Justice Department charged Charles Miller, Glenroy Matthew, Clifford Henry, and Noel Heath with conspiracy to smuggle cocaine from St. Kitts to the United States. Mr. Henry was arrested in Miami; the other three are free on bail here in connection with related local charges, but neither they nor their lawyer responded to requests for comment on the case.
Since extradition papers were filed, there have been periodic demonstrations against the Government's decision to go ahead with proceedings despite the absence of a bilateral extradition treaty with the United States. Many of those involved have been neighbors of the accused men or beneficiaries of their largess, a law-enforcement official said. Officials and diplomats said there is evidence to suggest the accused men have helped organize and pay for the protests.
St. Kitts has also been swept by rumors that the accused drug traffickers, perhaps with a mind to carry out a coup, are secretly training a private army, an idea Mr. Douglas derided. "I have no notion at all that a private militia is being established," he said. "This country is too small," at 104 square miles, for such an activity to go undetected.
Because of its small size, St. Kitts and Nevis has not generally been used as a transit point for air shipments of cocaine from Colombia. Rather, local agents of the cartels have used the islands' territorial waters as a gateway to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, a route that has recently regained importance as a result of quarrels between Colombian and Mexican traffickers.
Mustering the political will to stand up to drug trafficking cartels has proven difficult even in large Latin American countries like Colombia and Mexico. But, as one diplomat in the region put it, "The very size of these small Caribbean countries is a factor in the ability of their police forces and their coast guards to go up against the resources the cartels have."
Government officials here, for instance, estimate the local extradition proceeding will cost them at least $250,000 in legal fees, since the Attorney General's Office has no lawyer on its staff with expertise in that area and has had to seek outside counsel. In contrast, the Attorney General's entire budget for this year is $340,000, according to Government documents.
An official here said the United States has made a commitment "to assist, and although we have not seen the money yet, I think we will."
Also, the country's police force has only 325 officers. Some police officials have reportedly been threatened by accused drug traffickers, and some local residents, all of whom insisted on not being identified, say the drug traffickers have encouraged members of their own organizations to enroll in training programs intended to beef up the force.

 BODY:

Western Power Blackout Underlines System Flaws
As a handful of electrical lines in southern Oregon sagged in the summer heat and shut down this month, blacking out power to more than four million people in nine Western states, engineers at the Federal Power Authority in Oregon neglected to make a brief call. 
 The momentary lack of coordination between big utility companies led to the second major voltage collapse in six weeks and offered a warning about the vulnerabilities of a system moving quickly toward deregulation and competition. [Page A14.]
 
9-Letter Word for Puzzle Makers
Puzzlers, take note: The biggest clue to doing crosswords in the 90's may be a nine-letter word that starts with a "C" -- computers. Computer-generated puzzles are expanding the crossword business, and individual puzzle writers have developed sophisticated programs. [D9.]

Editor Leaves Advocate Magazine
Jeff Yarbrough, who served for four years as editor in chief of The Advocate, has left the gay news magazine. Word in the industry has it that Mr. Yarbrough was discharged, but Mr. Yarbrough said he resigned. [D9.]

A change in the Government's rules on television-station ownership has spurred a ferocious race among broadcasters to lock up as many stations as possible. The appetite for expansion has been particularly intense among companies with the largest stakes in television programming: the networks, particularly NBC and Fox. [D10.]

One survival tactic that would almost surely never occur to a big magazine company like Conde Nast is to canvass subscribers for contributions. The Whole Earth Review wrote to "subscribers and friends," asking for feedback and help in raising $600,000. Robin Pogrebin: Publishing. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Election-Year Posturing on Drugs

 BODY:
Elections invariably bring political maneuvers to help politicians look tough on drugs. This year is no exception. President Clinton has asked Congress for a 67 percent increase in American financial support for Latin American counternarcotics programs. By a close vote, the Senate recently agreed, paying for part of the $92 million increase by transferring $53 million that had been designated to aid the world's poorest citizens. The shift is doubly shameful, and should be reversed.
What could be tougher on cocaine than fighting Latin American drug trafficking? Almost anything, and the Senate and the President know it. The Senate has long been skeptical of counternarcotics efforts in Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. The President's drug czar, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, has said American counternarcotics programs in the Andes have not made a difference and called for new ideas. 
 Since President Bush declared war on drugs seven years ago, the United States has spent at least $1.5 billion on efforts to wipe out cocaine at its Andean source. The program has supported some of Latin America's most brutal police and militaries, although it has improved in recent years by emphasizing police over military efforts. But it has not dented the flow of cocaine. Since 1989 the amount of coca under cultivation has increased. There is no indication that the cocaine supply in the United States has decreased. On America's streets, the price of cocaine is lower, and its purity higher, than when the war began.
After the United States had spent more than half a billion dollars in seven years to fight drugs in Colombia, President Clinton announced this March he could not certify that Colombia was cooperating effectively with American counternarcotics efforts. The drug trade is so profitable and so mobile that the only solution lies in better treatment and policing in America.
The amendment to transfer the $53 million, sponsored by Senator Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican, provides gravy for counternarcotics efforts abroad, which had already been given the biggest increase of any foreign program.
The Coverdell cuts come in two valuable programs for helping the world's poor, which have already taken large recent reductions. A $25 million decrease would trim aid to the United Nations Children's Fund and the U.N. Development Program, among other things. A $28 million cut would come from development efforts, such as child-nutrition and family-planning programs.
Politicians who want credit for doing something about drugs should put more money into programs that work in America. They should also reverse the Coverdell amendment.

HEADLINE: Once in Big Demand, Nurses Are Targets for Hospital Cuts

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
As New York hospitals frantically cut costs to survive in the world of managed care, they have begun trying to rein in their biggest single expense: their nursing staffs.
Five years ago, during a severe nursing shortage, jobs were plentiful, signing bonuses were common, and union contracts were doubling nurses' starting salaries at many hospitals to more than $50,000 in just two years. 
 But today the newly powerful health maintenance organizations are demanding shorter hospital stays and paying hospitals discounted rates, putting stress on budgets. And hospitals that once fought one another to attract nurses now see their large nursing staffs as costly burdens.
In the name of greater efficiency, most hospitals today are seeking to reduce, or "consolidate," their nursing staffs. Some are offering buyouts and early retirement plans. Many, most notably public hospitals, have exhausted those avenues and have turned to layoffs.
"Hospitals are under pressure from managed care to reduce costs, and they are looking at nurses as their highest cost line item," said Howard Berliner, professor of health policy at the New School for Social Research, who predicted that nursing layoffs would "greatly accelerate" this year.
From February 1995 to February 1996, 1,316 nursing jobs, 3 percent of the total, were lost in the New York area, according to the Greater New York Hospital Association, an industry group. It was the first decrease in more than a decade.
Since the number of hospital patients dropped 8 percent that year and many nurses moved to outpatient clinics, the effect of the changes on the ratio of nurses to patients in any given ward is difficult to determine, the hospital association said. And the hospitals insist that care is not being compromised in their quest for greater efficiency.
But many nurses say the reductions have hurt the care patients receive. They complain that the remaining nurses are overworked: a floor that previously had four nurses might now have three, with a nursing technician newly hired to perform tasks like taking temperatures or cardiograms. They also express concern that the technicians, who may have as little as a few weeks of training, are not always up to their new tasks. At Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, 1,500 nurses staged a one-day strike last month to protest the hiring of technicians.
"There has definitely been a decline in quality from right-sizing, downsizing, streamlining -- whatever you want to call it," said Marva Wade, an operating room nurse at Mount Sinai Medical Center and the president of the New York State Nurses' Association, the state's largest nurses' union. "There are fewer of us here, so patients may have to wait longer for a pain medication, or it may take longer for a patient's problem to be noticed."
Hospitals say such complaints are predictable as nurses adjust to a new way of doing business. "This is a new way of delivering health care, and it may be difficult for some nurses to deal with that," said Peggy McNally of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "Maybe they know someone who has been laid off and they're adjusting."
A number of doctors and experts on the health care industry say pressure from managed care will inevitably reduce the number of nurses here, as it has in other parts of the country. But they say that the current downsizing has been far too fast and chaotic, in part because the rapid growth of managed care has taken hospitals by surprise, and because union contracts and civil service rules -- rather than health care needs -- have determined which nurses leave.
Some hospital departments have lost large numbers of trained nurses overnight, nurses say. And in the reshuffling that follows each buyout or layoff, nurses are often transferred from, say, surgical floors to psychiatric units, or from emergency rooms to delivery floors, with little training in between.
"There is this attitude that a nurse is a nurse is a nurse," said Ms. Wade, "but the health system has demanded that we be very specialized."
At Harlem Hospital, 40 out of 230 intensive care nurses lost their jobs at the end of June, resulting in an immediate shortage of nurses experienced in taking care of the sickest patients. Doctors at the hospital were so concerned that they joined the doctors' union, community groups and local politicians, including Representative Charles B. Rangel, in seeking a court order barring the layoffs.
"You can't just lay off 40 special-care nurses and expect care to continue as usual," said Dr. John Herbert, the hospital's director of anesthesia and president of its medical board.
The judge ruled that she could not prevent the dismissals, but she encouraged the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's public hospitals, to pay for outside intensive care nurses until Harlem Hospital had time to train more of its own nurses to work in intensive care. The hospital agreed, and an immediate crisis was averted.
Nursing cutbacks have been particularly striking in public hospitals, which laid off 562 nurses at the end of June, a move that the hospitals corporation ascribed to a declining patient population but that also helped close a projected $550 million budget gap at the corporation for the current fiscal year.
Private hospitals are looking to reduce nursing staffs as well, in part because they, too, have suffered from a sharp decline in Medicaid rates and are trying to lower their costs to be more attractive to H.M.O.'s.
St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center has laid off more than 100 nurses in the last two years. The administration at Flushing Hospital had planned layoffs earlier this year but averted them when the nurses agreed to reduced hours and a buyout. Mount Sinai Hospital has offered more than 100 nurses early retirement.
While there have been relatively few outright layoffs in the private sector, many hospitals are cutting nursing staffs through attrition, said Barry Waldman, a spokesman for the New York State Nurses' Association. Although the union has organized several new hospitals in the last 12 months, its membership is actually down, to 34,500, compared with 36,000 a year ago.
Hospital administrators, doctors and nurses disagree on whether the recent changes have affected patient care. The administrators say that with fewer people receiving inpatient care they are merely redeploying nurses to better meet patients' needs and that nursing technicians should be able to take up the slack. They point out that for many years, nurses begged for assistants who could help out with more mundane tasks.
But nurses say the reductions have outpaced the number of beds that have been eliminated so that there are far fewer nurses per patient now. They add that in the topsy-turvy world of downsizing nurses have often been asked to take on the responsibilities of those who have been laid off. St. Luke's-Roosevelt dismissed all of its phlebotomists as of July 1, so nurses now draw all patient blood there.
Nurses say that such situations will become more common as their ranks are spread increasingly thin. Ms. Wade of Mount Sinai said that at her hospital, floors that once had eight nurses now have six and two nurses aides and that the operating room staff now consists of only 75 percent registered nurses, down from about 85 percent a year ago.
She said that while the newly minted technicians were able to gather data -- like blood sugar levels and temperatures -- they did not necessarily understand them and might not recognize emergency situations.
A number of doctors and nurses also said hospitals had failed to plan for the transition. But hospital officials complain that union and civil service rules have made such planning next to impossible.
Instead of being able to cut nursing jobs where they are no longer needed, hospital officials say, union contracts force them to eliminate jobs based on seniority. So, for example, a hospital that wanted to close a drug unit could not simply dismiss the dozen nurses who worked there. Instead, the hospital has to lay off the 12 most junior nurses in a hospital and then "bump" nurses from the drug unit into those slots.
Such bumping is an everyday occurrence at hospitals, leaving some nurses ricocheting around hospitals -- from the operating room to the labor floor, from an AIDS unit to a surgical team, said Ann Bove, a senior nurse at Bellevue Medical Center.
Marion Spector, a nursing instructor at Bellevue, said that after the hospital laid off 36 nurses in late June, she was told that she had five days to train an assistant head nurse from a psychiatric ward to work on a unit for prisoners with serious medical problems.
Instead of running therapy sessions, the nurse would suddenly be dressing surgical wounds. Instead of passing out Thorazine, she would be hanging blood transfusion bags and tending patients with IV's.
One nurse who was bumped from a medical floor to a drug and alcohol detoxification unit at St. Luke's-Roosevelt said his training for the new job consisted primarily of watching a series of videotapes.
At Harlem Hospital's intensive-care unit, a combination of buyouts, layoffs and union work rules has decimated the nursing staff.
In 1995, the unit lost a large number of experienced nurses as the result of a buyout and early retirement offer from the Health and Hospitals Corporation. The hospital hired new nurses to replace them.
But last June, many of these recently hired nurses were laid off with little notice because they had no seniority. And the hospital's medical staff felt it was unsafe to bump regular floor nurses into the technological jungle of intensive care, a transition that usually takes four to six months of training.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said more nurses were likely to lose their jobs. "Whatever we've seen so far is just the tip of the iceberg," he said.
Health care experts say half the nurses who lose hospital jobs will find work in outpatient clinics or in home care.
But nurses say they live in fear of pink slips. With 5,000 still coming out of nursing schools in New York State each year, the job market is flooded.
Keith Hensen left a private hospital to work in a long-term care facility one year ago. "The hospital was on the verge of collapse," he said, "and I didn't want to be out on the street unemployed with 500 other nurses."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Remarks by Lamm to Reform Party Convention in Valley Forge

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Following are remarks yesterday by Richard D. Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, at the Reform Party National Convention in Valley Forge, Pa., as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House: 
 I went to Los Angeles 78 days ago to make a speech. It's been like riding a tiger ever since. It's been like drinking out of a fire hydrant. But I don't regret a moment of it. It's been wonderful, and thank you all for making it possible.
I should like to begin -- or I'd like to end, I guess, as I began, talking passionately about the issues.
And add, actually, to it why I've come so firmly to believe in the whole Reform Party. I see it now so clearly. The two major political parties are not going to reform our campaign and election system.
Our two major political parties are not going to be able to govern in the long-term interests of our children.
We have America caught in this very strange Catch-22, where the best politics is the worst public policy.
A great nation is not always lucky enough to have politically popular solutions to its problems. No great nation in history has even borrowed its way to greatness.
A gentleman over here says, "But we're trying."
And boy, is that true. But no great nation in history has made their elections into public auctions and remained a great country.
What better place than Valley Forge to recognize again that sometimes freedom needs sacrifice.
Half a mile away from where we meet tonight, brave soldiers froze at Valley Forge 220 years ago. And the next generation accepted and paid off the debts that they ran up in fighting for our independence.
But not my generation. Oh, no. We just kept borrowing and borrowing and borrowing. We add to the nation's debt for programs that we ourselves do not earn. . . .
We can reform and renew America, but it will not be done by politics as usual.
You know, Yogi Berra said, "I'm for leaving the status quo as it is."
But we can't. That's not an option. A great country either moves or forward or it moves backwards.
Let me urge you, however, to add one additional issue to your platform. And that's the issue of immigration.
A sensitive issue, but one of those that America must face.
There is no essential difference, in my mind, between exporting a job and importing a new worker. . . .
I'm back to the immigration. The question I believe that we have to face is how many people can we accept in the United States in a world of limited resources.
Do I have the next slide? I'm sorry. I can't -- the first census was about the same time as Valley Forge and it found four million Americans -- Europeans in America. So, we've had six doublings of the United States in our short 220-year history.
We've gone from 4, 8, 16 -- you see it up to approximately 260 million right now. What I would ask you to think about is two more doublings just, just two more -- we've already had six -- two more doublings gives us more people in the United States than are today in India. Is that really what we want?
I think we should be pro-immigrant, that people that already here -- we've -- of course, we accept and they're good people. And we want them to contribute to our society and assimilate into our society and into our economy.
But, the question is, do we want to have as many people as they do in India? How many workers? How many jobs? . . .
Essentially, this shows that America is going to stabilize its population by about 305 million people in about 2040, without -- just by our natural birth rate. And so the question about our demographic future is how many people do we want living in America? How big a size? . . .
The U.S. Labor Department estimates that we will create 18 million new jobs in the 1990's. Does it really make any sense to bring in 13 million new immigrants?
We've got our own poor that we have to start up the economic ladder.
We all now agree that there's been something fundamentally wrong in our welfare system. Let's start our own people having those unskilled and turn them into skilled jobs and turn them into better jobs. . . .
Let me just say that I do believe it's immensely important that -- that the Reform Party add in an appropriate way, and a way that really is accepting of the people that are already here, but start raising the question -- how many workers, how many people do we want to import?
So, thank you for this opportunity. Congratulations.
I want to congratulate Ross Perot. I want to thank my workers. They were terrific. I want to thank Ed Zschau, because one of the more decent and wonderful people that I've run into in public policy.
And I want to thank you, because America needs reform. Thank you.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;
Breaking the mold again, Whole Earth Review is asking subscribers for charity.

BYLINE: By Robin Pogrebin 

 BODY:
WHEN magazines hit the financial skids, they are generally either sold or killed; there is very little hope of finding an alternative. One tactic that would likely never occur to big magazine companies like Conde Nast or Hachette Filipacchi is to canvas subscribers for contributions.
But Whole Earth Review has never been like most magazine companies. Throughout the 25 years of its existence, the touchy-feely, techno-savvy publication has exploded one convention after another. 
 It has refused to accept any display advertising on the principle that it compromises editorial freedom and subscribers are a more important source of income. All staff members have been paid the same salary, no matter what their positions. And the magazine has featured controversial cover topics like "Doing Drag and Male Identity."
The magazine, based in Sausalito, Calif., grew out of the Whole Earth Catalog -- once a hugely popular almanac of products for the 1960's back-to-the-land generation -- and has long promoted a philosophy of individual responsibility and personal empowerment.
"We are as gods and might as well get good at it,"founder Stewart Brand wrote in his statement of purpose for the catalogue, adding that one "realm of intimate, personal power is developing the power of individuals to conduct their own education, find their own inspiration, shape their own environment and share the adventure with whoever is interested."
Since then, the staff of the magazine has refined that statement slightly: "We are dedicated to self-teaching, and to encouraging people to think for themselves.
"Our publications are a call to, and support for, individual action."
It was little wonder that when Whole Earth Review found its survival in jeopardy, the magazine made that call to action on its own behalf. In a letter to "subscribers and friends" dated Summer Solstice 1996, the Review's management laid out its financial troubles. The nonprofit quarterly publication had been running a deficit of $20,000 a month, the letter explained. It could not pay the printer or its 10 employees.
"We're not dead yet," the letter said. "We intend to come back -- with your help."
To come back, the magazine needs to raise $600,000 in the next 18 months, with $150,000 of that to come from its base of about 16,000 subscribers. The letter sought minimum donations of $35 from readers, as well as feedback. "What do you value about Whole Earth Review?" it asked. "What would you want to change?"
The Review -- published by the Point Foundation, a not-for-profit educational organization -- also said it would be taking a six-month break to sort out the magazine's financial troubles. There would be no summer and fall issues. During the hiatus, those staff members who were not laid off would consider several options, including merging with another magazine, beginning to carry advertising or throwing in the towel.
"It was a decision based on economics," said Michael Stone, the Review's general manager. "We were not taking in enough income to sustain the publication and really needed to step back, raise some money and look at the organization and its financial viability."
The magazine blames its struggles in part on paper and postage costs, as well as on the diminishing success of its catalogues, which over the years had offered practical information -- but no longer products -- for everything from how to build a windmill to beekeeping to goat farming to how to prepare a neighborhood disaster tool box in anticipation of an earthquake or hurricane.
The organization said it would only break even on its Millennium Whole Earth Catalog, published by HarperCollins in 1994. And while the Point's sale of its on-line service, the WELL (Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link), helped pay the bills for 1993 and 1994, those funds have now run out.
True to Whole Earth's power-of-the-individual philosophy, the magazine's readers have rallied. In the last two months, the magazine has raised $112,000 in donations, two-thirds of its stated goal for subscribers. It hopes that, with the additional help of foundation money, it will be back on its feet in time to publish a winter issue. "We are not folding," said David Katz, the Review's interim publisher. "We foresee a rebirth."
The Review has also received some 2,000 responses from subscribers offering support and ideas. "This magazine is very important to people and their lives," Mr. Katz said.
The Review has long been a favorite of subscribers who have looked forward to its irreverent articles on topics natural and technological. Its most recent issue, published in March, included an excerpt from a book about how Buckminster Fuller's ideas are relevant today, a piece on lessons from Biosphere 2 and an article on the Conference for the Society of Ecological Restoration.
The magazine has always been just plain off-beat. It categorizes its donors with quirky names: Perpetual Supporter ($10,000 -- Marlon Brando has long been one of those); Angelic ($5,000); Maniacal ($1,000); Munificent ($250); Sustaining ($100); Retaining ($50).
"It feels like a relationship to me," said Cliff Martin, a longtime subscriber and sometime writer for the Review who lives in Oregon. "When there was an article on urban growth in the Midwest or how to keep a human head alive after someone is dead, I wasn't interested, but then there would be an article on how the World Wide Web is going to affect the next election.
"It's very sad that this wonderful icon might fall apart," Mr. Martin said. "I think it's going to leave a real gap in contemporary journalism."
As to whether or not readers could tolerate the introduction of advertising into the Review -- heretofore supported by $20 subscriptions, donations and the catalogues -- most have responded in the affirmative. "The vast majority of people who comment on advertising say, 'Hey, we can handle it,' " Mr. Katz said.
Still, there inevitably is something poignant about the magazine's current predicament; to stay alive, it will have to abandon much of its very essence. The magazine will probably end up accepting advertising. It may merge with another publishing company. And it is likely to become a for-profit operation.
"It's been a difficult time," Mr. Stone said. "This is not a move anybody wanted to have to make."

HEADLINE: State Tuition Rose Faster Than Inflation

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Tuition at four-year, public colleges over the last 14 years has increased nearly three times as fast as household income and more than three times the rate of consumer price inflation, according to Congressional auditors.
The General Accounting Office said in a report requested by 23 members of Congress and released on Thursday that college tuitions on average jumped 234 percent between the 1980-81 and 1994-95 school years. 
 That compares with an 82 percent increase in median household income over the same period and a 74 percent increase in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index.
Two factors were at work, the report said: rising expenditures by schools and an increasing reliance on tuition increases as support from state governments declined.
State support for colleges dropped 14 percent over the 14 years. As a result, tuition accounted for 23 percent of schools' total revenue in 1994-95, up from 16 percent in 1980-81.
At the same time, school spending rose 121 percent. The increase was driven primarily by faculty salaries, which rose 97 percent, and other instructional costs, the accounting office said. Administrative costs, meanwhile, rose 131 percent.
In recent years, in fact, there has been a move by some colleges and universities -- particularly small regional institutions seeking an advantage -- to lower costs. Even some elite colleges have sought to at least keep increases small. Princeton University, for instance, announced earlier this year that the price of tuition, room and board this year would increase by 4.6 percent to $28,325. It is the lowest rate of increase at the university since 1967-68.
Tuition for the 1995-96 school year ranged from $1,524 to $5,521 for in-state students, the report said. The average cost was $2,865.
In general, the highest tuitions were in the Northeast and the lowest in the South and the West.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Perot's Acceptance Speech at Reform Party Convention

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Ross Perot accepting the Reform Party's Presidential nomination in Valley Forge, Pa., as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House: 
 Thank you for creating the Reform Party. It's an historic event. It only happens once every hundred years in this country.
You're great. Thank you.
I am honored and I am humbled that you have chosen me as your candidate to be President.
And you have my solemn promise that I will only act in the best interest of our country.
This is your country. I will be your servant.
I will only belong to you, the people.
And I am absolutely committed, irrevocably committed, to passing on a better world to our children and grandchildren.
After watching this introduction, surely you will agree that I have literally lived the American Dream.
I want to make sure that some other kid who's a nobody from nowhere has that same opportunity.
I'm here today because I'm absolutely determined to keep the dream alive. And we will pass on a better, stronger country to the next generation.
I would like to compliment Governor Lamm on his speech and thank him for his participation. Thank you, Dick.
Have you listened to the messages from the other parties during the last few weeks?
Do their promises for 1996 sound familiar?
Who first brought these issues to the American people? You did!
Isn't it terrific that in just four years, they've repented, been reborn. And you are setting the agenda for '96? God bless you.
Now, here is the question for everybody in the good old U.S.A. Do you think they will keep those promises?
Remember Lech Walesa's message to our Congress when he said words are plentiful, but deeds are precious? We are here in Valley Forge tonight to remind everybody that the people who created this country made incredible sacrifices. That's why we have the convention here.
They fought barefooted in the snow in this part of Pennsylvania.
Has anybody here ever heard the name Benjamin Fell? Somebody has. Wonderful.
He manufactured shoes and leather goods in the Valley Forge area during the Revolution. He was shocked when he saw George Washington's men barefoot and suffering in December 1777. He immediately started making shoes for the soldiers. He filled his house and attic with soldiers. He was expelled from the Quaker Church for participating in the war.
The British posted a reward for his capture, but he kept on making shoes for Washington's soldiers.
Now, that's what we need. His modest tombstone carries this inscription, "To the memory of Benjamin Fell, a patriot and a Christian, a friend of George Washington, and a friend of God." . . .
Our ancestors came across the ocean in sailing ships you wouldn't go across a lake in.
When they arrived there was nothing here. They built their tiny little cabins and they did it with neighbors helping one another, not Federal grants.
They came here because they wanted to be free and they wanted to practice the religion of their choice. And after 200 years too many of us take those privileges for granted. We must not forget they are precious and they are fragile.
Now the immigrants who came later applied to become American citizens, waited their turn, and then came through Ellis Island.
Once they left Ellis Island they were on their own. There were no social programs to take care of them. They scrambled. They made do. They built the greatest country in the history of man.
It's important for all of you to know that I'm a very ordinary person of average intelligence and all of my success has come from surrounding myself with people who are far more intelligent than I am. And they have carried me from victory to victory to victory to victory. . . .
Think of the pioneers who headed West in covered wagons.
Where did they eat? There were no McDonald's restaurants.
At the end of the day, they hunted for food. Some found food, others did not find food. And guess what?
Those who found food shared it with those who did not. Now, that's a great country.
Well, surely there was a network of Holiday Inns across the country for these people to stop at night and have a good night's sleep. No. They circled the wagons. They slept on the ground. And they took turns standing guard, protecting one another.
No wonder we're such a great nation. It's built on solid granite.
 
A Matter of Self-Reliance
Our ancestors came to this great country with a huge land mass, a tiny population, and far more than our share of minerals and other natural resources. In the old days, our ancestors would move into an area, creatively strip it of its natural resources, and then the word would go out, "Go West, young man. Go West."
Well, we've now got over 260 million people in this country. We've populated it from coast to coast.
We cannot leave our problems behind. We have to solve them where we are; and we're not. But you and I, millions of us together will, right?
The Pilgrims, the pioneers and those who survived the Depression were proud, independent people who took care of themselves and looked after one another. They were hunters. They were survivors.
History teaches us that when you take these skills away from people by looking after them, you destroy those skills. But more importantly, you destroy their self-respect, their pride and their dignity. And you also do that when you take a good person's job away from them and send it over to Asia to 25 cents an hour children. Thank you.
And if you want an example nobody can argue with, let's take the American Indian. Look at what the Indians accomplished before we put them on the reservation and look at the damage we did to these great people by taking care of people who had been proud, independent hunters, warriors, survivors and empire builders.
As you think about the future of our great country with all the facts that you have in your head, and we are dedicated to getting into the heads of every single American before November, I'd like you to consider these words written by the Scottish historian Alexander Tyler in 1787. He said, a democracy can only exist until the voters discover that they can vote themselves money from the public treasury.
From that moment on, the majority always will vote for candidates who promise the people benefits from the public treasury with the result that a democracy always collapses over loose fiscal product -- policy.
Does that seem familiar to you here?
O.K. But here's the most telling thing he said. He says the average age of the world's democracies has been 200 years.
George Washington, our first President, was sworn in 207 years ago. The clock is ticking. You are the Minutemen. You've got to stop plowing and pick up and get organized and vote in November to make sure that doesn't happen.
The future of our country rests in our hands. We have to decide who we are. Are we a proud, free, independent people? Or in the words of the song, "Someone to Watch Over Me," are we little sheep who are lost in the wood? But we would be good if we had someone to watch over us?
We are proud, free, independent people. Shouldn't we go back to principles this great country was founded on, that we take care of ourselves?
And then, then we go out and take care of people who can't take care of themselves and need our help, right?
Now we have big government taking care of us. Isn't that wonderful?
But do they do a very good job?
We haven't figured out that big government doesn't have any more to take care of us until we send taxes to Washington, where the special interests, who pay for their Hollywood-style political campaigns to manipulate our votes then decide how our money will be spent. And that's the reason you're not getting your dollar's worth out of that routine. . . .
 
False Promises of Reform
In 1995 the elected leaders from both of the parties publicly shook hands on national television and agreed to form a task force on campaign-finance reform and lobbying. Remember that?
God bless them, they were going to hit the line and do it because they knew they had to do it to get your vote. The bad news is they never did it. They just shook hands.
Where I come from -- as a boy, particularly -- a handshake was worth more than a written contract is today.
And a handshake at that level ought to be worth that for now.
So after sending us that feel-good message, they went out and spent the year raising money for 1996 from the special interests. And as we sit here tonight, there is a big party at the Waldorf-Astoria, and I know the room.
It may hold about 800 people. And I heard over television today that they're going to raise $8 million. I'll let you figure out what they're charging per plate for that.
Isn't this a compelling argument that the people who own this country should have their own political party with no special interests controlling it? . . .
Our country's major problems are caused by huge social programs that were never designed to work properly, and have generated major cost overruns. These major cost overruns have created a massive debt.
In addition, we have seriously damaged our job base with very poorly negotiated trade agreements. And that has caused our tax base to deteriorate.
You see, it all fits together like pieces in a puzzle. They just look at the problems individually. You've got to look at them all at once.
Today, the two political parties have created -- here's the good news -- America's No. 1 growth industry -- and I want to give them full credit for that.
It's up there. You can see it. I can't.
The U.S. Government makes our other major industries look insignificant. But as practical business people, you're saying, what product do they make, Ross? They don't make one.
Well, then where do they get the money for this great new industry? From you.
Well, how do the customers feel about this giant new industry?
Only 19 percent of the American people trust this giant new industry. That's how they feel. . . .
Let's look on page 18 of the President's 1997 budget. And here is the record. We have assets of $2.3 trillion. We have liabilities of $5.2 trillion. We have a negative net worth in the Federal Government of $2.9 trillion. And guess who's going to have to pick up all of that? We are. You see, you're the only source of money. Well -- but they left something out. They left out $17 trillion worth of guarantees.
So, that negative net worth is almost $20 trillion. So, that's where we are today.
Now, do you get this kind of blunt, straight talk from the other political parties?
Would you rather hear this kind of talk from me or do you want me to get tears in my eyes, lean into the audience, and say, "I feel your pain?" . . .
 
'Kill That Little Snake'
Can we count on the two political parties to solve these problems?
They are the problem, right?
Now, if you got a friend that's drinking too much, the first thing he's got to do is admit it, right?
They won't admit we have a problem, and therefore they cannot come up with real solutions. Instead of giving you advice, they hire professional speech writers and seek help from Hollywood's finest to manipulate you into casting an emotional vote.
And boy, has it been working. But you and I are going to get the facts out to the American people, and we're going to kill that little snake this time, right? . . .
How big is $5 trillion? Nobody can relate to it. Here's a way you figure it out. We don't have $5 trillion of currency in print. And I think that if you took all the money that existed to go pay the debt, you wouldn't have $5 trillion.
And that's just no -- that's just too much debt, right?
And now that you know that is nothing compared to what will happen in the 21st century if we don't stop the bleeding now. Let's go get a tourniquet and stop the bleeding in November of 1996.
And if you don't, the debt will climb to $7 trillion by the year 2000. So we have to.
We all know about the budget deficit, but we've got two deficits. We never talk about the other one because they really have worked hard -- the special interests demanded it in return for their campaign money. And the boys in Washington delivered it.
And that is the trade deficit.
Now, the U.S. merchandise trade deficit last year was $174 billion. That's the largest of any nation in the history of man. In 1950, 90 percent of the goods sold in this country were made in the U.S.A. Today, less than 50 percent of the goods sold in this country are made in the U.S.A.
Two million manufacturing jobs have gone to Asia. Five hundred thousand jobs have gone to Mexico -- the cumulative Nafta trade deficit.
Nafta was supposed to be a money-maker, right?
No wonder the guys who voted for it are now telling you they're against it because the cumulative Nafta trade deficit is $52 billion and growing like a weed. Did Nafta cause a giant sucking sound?
O.K. Do you remember how we were ridiculed and derided? Somebody said I'd rather be right than President. In this situation, we've got to be right and President to clean up this mess. . . .
Our conventions cost about $800,000 together. They spent over $30 million on theirs. I think ours are better than theirs.
Don't you think if we had that kind of plain thinking in Washington, if we can do -- keep in mind I remember last -- in '92, they had spent $20 million, $30 million a piece. We had spent $1.5 million getting petitions signed.
I think we've made the point that we're more cost effective than they are. But now, everywhere I go, people ask me, Ross, what's the problem with Medicare and Medicaid?
In 1965, when we created Medicaid, the spending forecast for 1990 was $9 billion. The actual spending was $98 billion. The reason it's in trouble is that they never designed it to work.
 
Dealing With the Details
Now, let's go to Medicaid. It was a noble goal -- massive legislation, massive funding failure. You wouldn't make a screwdriver that way, right?
Medicare and Medicaid are more complex than putting a man on the moon. But in the 1960's when Medicaid was created, they told the taxpayers in 1990, it won't cost you more than $1 billion. It cost you $41 billion.
The annual cost of Medicare and Medicaid today is at $250 billion a year. The two parties let this happen.
Why? And they let it keep on happening. The special interests who fund their campaigns are making huge amounts of money at your expense.
We'll stop it. . . .
What's the problem with Social Security?
Everybody thinks it's a pension fund. No. It's pay-as-you go. The money comes in this week; it goes out next week to retired people. Then how did it ever work?
In 1945 we had 42 people that worked for every person retired. By 1950 that number dropped to 16 people that worked for every person retired. But we raised rates, expanded benefits, kept on working
But today we only have 3.3 people at work for every person retired. And we're headed for two people at work, for every person retired in the year 2020.
We must transition Social Security from a pay-as-you go fund to a true pension fund. And nobody in the Reform Party would ever tolerate taking Social Security away from retired people. Let me make that point.
Everybody ---- But the sooner we start to transition the better we'll be. The most unselfish people in this country are the retired people. They are our eagles. They survived the Depression. They fought in World War I, World War II and Korea, and on and on and on and on.
They are our heroes. I rejoice that they're living longer. I hope they live forever.
But if you really care about other people, than you put together plans that will work for those people, right?
And you don't sit there with tears in your eyes and say, "I'll protect Social Security as you know it."
Because you can't. You can through your term, but that won't work over the long term.
Why didn't they face this issue? They think it will it cost them votes. I'd rather lose the election than lie about Social Security. . . .
Now, all the political experts across the country who are watching this program, will be shocked and are shocked already that I am talking about real problems and the fact that we have to face them and solve them in an acceptance speech.
This is supposed to be morning in America. You're supposed to leave feeling giddy and good because I just whistled good news all night.
That's not what we're about. We're about getting the facts, taking action, producing results.
I want you all to know the only reason I do this and the only reason I asked my family to go through all this unpleasantness, unfortunately, that goes with politics, is that I am absolutely devoted to solving these problems. . . .
Get the facts. And we must have a new tax system. We know that.
The first step in solving any problem is to define the problem. Watch my lips, Washington.
If you want to solve a problem carefully, thoughtfully and rationally define it. Well, one of the things to do is look at history. You ain't going to believe this one.
Before our nation was formed the total cost to run our Government was 67 cents per person a year. Then after our nation was formed it went up to a dollar a year. Then 120 years later, in 1910, it was up to $6.75 per person a year. Now we're getting to be a pretty big nation, right? -- $6.75 a year.
Then we passed the income tax law -- amendment in 1913. And 16 years later it had gone from $6.75 to $29 per person a year.
Now strap in your seat belt and don't eject because you can't. Today it's $5,700 a year per person.
I hope I've made the point that when you've got a tax law that Congress can raise, it will. . . .
I will not run up and down the streets of America promising you hope, opportunity, and growth, flat tax, flat tax, flat tax.
If that is the best tax, that's the one we'll do. But we're going to look at all of them carefully, thoughtfully and rationally. We're going to use the computer as our wind tunnel.
We'll nail it, give it you and then move on to our next problem.
But I am sick and tired of having a Government where the benefits of our congressmen and the retirement plans of our congressmen and the people in the White House are better than those of the ordinary American citizen.
They are your servants.
Now, if you want them to feel your pain, let them have retirement and health insurance like yours, right? . . .
As we approach the 1996 election, they've proposed solving these financial problems with a big tax cut.
Since we cannot pay our bills, wouldn't it make a lot more sense to have a big spending cut first? . . .
Now, we have tried this supply-side economics in the '80's. It gave us the biggest increase in the deficit we ever had in our country's history. Even the people in the party that created it called it voodoo economics.
I said in 1992 if we ever do this again, we'll be in deep voodoo.
And there we are.
I've got to talk to you about our public schools. It's brains and wits time as we approach the 21st century. We've got to have the greatest public schools in the world. . . .
We have the largest number of functional illiterates in the industrialized world. At the 12th grade level, I'm sad to report that 66 percent can't meet the reading and writing standards, 73 percent can't meet the geography standards, 84 percent can't meet the mathematics standards, and 89 percent can't meet the history standards.
The major discipline problems in our school in the 1940's were talking, chewing gum, making noise, running in the halls, getting out of line, wearing improper clothing, and not putting paper in the waste baskets.
I can live with those, right?
Here are our major discipline problems today: children carrying guns to school, drug abuse, pregnancy, suicide, rape, robbery, and assault. Isn't that sad?
Learning cannot occur in that environment. More importantly, why do parents allow their children to act this way?
In a free society, isn't it our job as parents to teach our children to behave and keep our children under control?
When I was bad in school, what they did to me there wasn't nearly as significant as what they did to me when I got home. My parents never read my Miranda rights.
And if we want our children to be competitive we've got to have the finest schools in the world. That simple. This will have to come from us, the people. . . .
 
Plea to Ordinary People
The only reason I am here tonight is I want to solve those problems for the great people in this country.
Thank you. Ordinary people in this country are capable of extraordinary achievements. You know that, and I do. There's nothing we can't do.
Keep in mind it's going to be tough for the next few months, but the same blow that shatters glass hardens steel. You've been here. You've been through the fight. And you are hard as steel. And boy, am I proud of you.
The other parties have a fortune to spend from now on. They have almost $100 million under the Federal election laws. We only get $29 million.
I've got to go to the men and women across this country and ask them for their support.
I particularly go to the people who own the 6 million small businesses and the 80 million people who work for them and ask them to send in small contributions.
I go to all of you and say, if this is worth fighting, you will have to contribute so that we can get a semi-level playing field so that we can compete from now until November.
If you want to send in a contribution, just send it to Perot '96, Post Office Box 96, Dallas, Tex. You don't even have to write that down, right? Fine.
As we work together, I ask all of you to remember it is better to light a candle than to curse the darkness.
The shadows will fall behind you if you walk into the light. All the darkness in the world cannot put out the light of one little candle.
Millions of good, decent people like you must light these candles that will lead us to victory in the light in 1996. You are the wind beneath the Reform Party's wings. It would be nothing without you.
As we march forward together we will need the Spirit of '76 in '96. And in the middle of the effort when things get tougher and tougher -- and they will -- just remember this, a bell is no bell until you ring it.
Think of the Liberty Bell.
And a song is no song until you sing it.
Think of the Star-Spangled Banner.
Love in your heart isn't put there to stay. Think of your children and grandchildren. Love isn't love until you give it away.
Think of the millions of people you can help. God bless you all. Thank you very much.
A privilege to be with you. Thank you.

HEADLINE: Footnotes Remain Part of Scholarly Life;
Humanities at Risk
To the Editor:
Your article "Footnotes Offering Fewer Insights" (Education Page, Aug. 14) itself offers valuable insights into the crisis facing the humanities.

 BODY:
 The art of the footnote suffers only in part from lazy or fame-seeking scholars. Rather, market forces -- which have cut off state funding to accessible libraries, enabled the power of book chains and impelled university presses to package pulp scholarship -- alter the presentation of scholarly inquiry for the sake of commerce.
By weakening libraries and privatizing knowledge, such forces sap the vitality of the humanist mission, the fostering of public dialogue and accountability. With its reference to a community of scholars past and present, the footnote dramatizes themes of conversation and responsibility. Its loss reflects the value at which the free market holds such traditions of thought.
In reportage on the humanities, the footnote is like its distant academic cousin, "political correctness." Both topics divert attention from economic problems with humanities education that deserve scrutiny.
 
MATTHEW P. BROWN
Cedar Rapids, Iowa, Aug. 14, 1996

HEADLINE: Blackout May Be Caution Sign on Road to Utility Deregulation

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18

 BODY:
As a handful of electrical lines in southern Oregon sagged in the summer heat last weekend and then began shutting down in a chain of short circuits that blacked out power to more than four million people in nine states, there was a brief telephone call that engineers at the Federal power authority in Oregon neglected to make.
It remains unclear whether that call -- to warn the Northern California utility company that was buying some of Oregon's electricity about problems on the lines -- would have averted what soon became the second major power blackout in six weeks on the largest regional power grid. 
 But even so, the momentary lack of coordination between big utility companies has emerged as a warning to energy officials and utility company executives about the vulnerabilities of a huge regional grid that is moving quickly toward an uncharted future of deregulation and competition.
"The system relies now on voluntary cooperation among the utilities," said the Deputy Secretary of Energy, Charles B. Curtis. With the advent of deregulation, he added, "there is a concern that the voluntary cooperation and the informal structures that underlie the reliability of the system are going to come under pressure."
The coming deregulation of California's $20 billion electrical power industry will effectively begin to split the generation and transmission of electricity into separate businesses. California's move is being closely watched in the 40 other states that are considering or planning the breakup of their utility monopolies.
The arrangement is supposed to be a boon to California's consumers, who now pay almost 50 percent above the national average for their power. Consumers will eventually be able to choose who supplies their electricity, even as big utility companies continue to own the power lines. Many analysts say the plan, which is to take effect in January 1998, will be a model for deregulation elsewhere in the West and around the country.
But it is also an arrangement that will involve a much more complicated system of energy transactions among newly competing companies, one that some officials fear could undermine incentives for the maintenance, expansion and coordinated operation of the power grid itself.
"We're already having some problems," said Randy Hardy, the chief executive officer of the Bonneville Power Administration, the Federal power-marketing agency in Oregon that operates part of the grid, "and we're moving toward a deregulated marketplace where right now, you could have little or no incentive for the utilities to invest in their transmission systems. That's a risky situation to be in."
While Mr. Hardy's engineers continue to run elaborate computer models in an effort to determine the precise causes of the power failure that began on the afternoon of Aug. 10 with a short circuit on a transmission line near the Columbia River, the officials have assembled a general picture of the problems that the episode exposed.
Its backdrop is one that has become familiar throughout the West in recent years, as pressure from ratepayers, regulatory changes and community opposition to the construction of new generating plants and transmission lines have led utility companies to hunt farther afield for cheap power. After a long, wet winter that filled the hydroelectric dams of the Northwest, and in the middle of a hot summer that was straining air-conditioners across the Southwest, heavy loads of electricity were being shipped relatively long distances over lines that some officials say have not been adequately maintained.
Near Oregon's northern border with Washington, a 500,000-volt transmission line known as the Big Eddy sagged onto a tree and shorted out at 2:01 P.M. As engineers at Oregon's Bonneville Power Administration struggled to bring the line back up, two other 500,000-volt lines in the area apparently became overloaded by power displaced from the Big Eddy and shut down as well.
Bonneville officials said they had thought at the time that they would be able to bring the system under control without consequences for their customers in the Southwest. Dennis Eyre, the executive director of the Western Systems Coordinating Council, the regional agency that oversees the reliability of the grid, said there was "no question" that Bonneville should have alerted its chief customer to the south, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. Officials at that utility have insisted that they could have avoided the blackout if they had been warned.
Within an hour, three more transmission lines overloaded and shut down, followed by the McNary hydroelectric station on the Columbia River, which was supposed to help stabilize the grid in case of such emergencies. Backup support for the thinly stretched grid would normally have come from a dam just upriver at The Dalles, Ore.; on that Saturday afternoon, it happened to be mostly shut down in a routine step to protect the run of chinook and sockeye salmon covered by the Endangered Species Act.
A minute later, the power surges forced the shutdown of the Pacific Intertie, the main power artery between the Northwest and California. Its collapse led to other shutdowns across California.
The immediate steps taken by energy officials to try to restore the system's reliability were straightforward: power flows on the Intertie are now being held to almost 40 percent below the lines' capacity, an emergency tree-trimming program was begun, and Bonneville agreed to report any future problems on its 500,000-volt lines.
The engineers' investigation continues. But energy officials, utility executives and others suggested that regardless of the problems uncovered, answers would need to be found to address a broader set of issues involving the reliability of the grid in a deregulated market for power.
"This is just a hint of what's to come if we don't strengthen the transmission systems," said Karl Stahlkopf, the vice president for power delivery issues at the Electric Power Research Institute in Palo Alto, Calif.
Under a plan approved last December by California's Public Utilities Commission and now being translated into legislation, power generation in California would begin in January 1998 with the creation of a wholesale power pool, into which big utilities, local power companies and other generators would all be able to sell their electricity.
The transmission lines would still belong to the utilities that now own them, but a so-called independent system operator would be set up to run the grid throughout the state.
Most of the political struggle in California has focused on how the utilities would recover the cost of their capital investments, which they have, until now, passed on to customers, and the terms under which utility companies are to sell some power plants to some of the other, mostly smaller, companies with which they will be competing. Comparatively little attention has been paid to the fact that the competition could mean an explosion in the number of companies selling power on the grid, greater reliance on long-distance transmissions and fewer incentives to avoid the sort of coordination and maintenance problems pointed out by the blackout on Aug. 10 and the earlier one, on July 2.
"If you're the separate transmission company, you're going to want to load up your lines to the maximum utilization possible and you'll want to minimize your costs," Mr. Hardy, the Bonneville administrator, said, noting that the utilities now had clear obligations to both their customers and the government to keep up their lines. "You're going to have a geometric increase in the number of players. And with the short-term commodity focus of the market, that is a real mismatch."
Edward Kahn, a vice president of National Economic Research Associates, a consulting group that works with investor-owned utilities, compared the establishment of system operators in the states to run a grid that is already integrated at regional levels to having separate air traffic control systems in different regions.
While some experts have advocated that regional system operators be established in place of the nine relatively weak coordinating councils set up after the 1965 New York blackout to oversee different parts of the grid, others doubt the viability of such a plan because of the sweeping reorganization it would entail. Yet Mr. Curtis, the second-ranking official in the Energy Department, said that whether the solution was stricter regulations or stronger incentives for the power companies to insure the reliability of the grid, a solution would eventually have to be found at the regional level.
"We are evolving toward an electric utility system that will be operated more and more on a regional basis," he said in an interview. "That is just the physical fact."

HEADLINE: Bay Inhabitants Are Mostly Aliens

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
FROM the vantage point of the Berkeley Marina one recent morning, San Francisco stood sharply etched against a fog bank nestling along the Pacific shore like a gigantic roll of cotton candy, a recurring tableau essentially unchanged since Tony Bennett first left his heart in the city across the bay.
But ecologically speaking, the broad, aquamarine expanse of San Francisco Bay itself has been drastically reinvented. 
 Every 12 weeks on average, a new species of aquatic animal, plant or microbe from somewhere else in the world takes up residence in the bay. It has become what one expert, Dr. James T. Carlton of the Williams College Maritime Studies Program at Mystic, Conn., calls "an accidental zoo" -- a churning, chaotic cauldron of life in which scores of weird, wonderful creatures of ancient lineage that "never before met each other until just a moment ago in ecological time" have been thrown together.
So far as is known, ecologists say, the bay is the estuary most invaded by exotic species in the world, and estuaries in general are the earth's most invaded marine ecosystems.
On that recent morning, Dr. Andrew N. Cohen, a marine biologist at the University of California at Berkeley who works closely with Dr. Carlton, directed a visitor's attention to an especially revealing gauge.
It was a block of orange Styrofoam, perhaps 3.5 feet by 1.5 feet, of the type that buoys the floating docks of Berkeley and other marinas. When lifted from the water, the block's underside appeared covered by a mass of multicolored moss and lettuce, black, brown, green, tan and yellow. But the plantlike organisms were actually colonies of marine animals, among them sponges and sea squirts, that cling to underwater surfaces around the bay in great masses. About a dozen species were visible, and invisible, uncounted microorganisms raised the total considerably.
"Virtually everything you see has arrived in San Francisco Bay from some other part of the world," Dr. Cohen said. That is the way it is the length and breadth of the bay's food web, from top predators like striped bass (introduced on purpose from the Atlantic Ocean more than a century ago) to microscopic protozoa from Japan.
Invasive species are seen almost everywhere in the world as human activity persistently rearranges the earth's flora and fauna. But San Francisco Bay offers a special window on where the global game of mix and match is leading at its most extreme. Species from other oceans now dominate the bay, and more are being crammed in all the time. They cover the bay's bottom virtually wall to wall, and no part of the larger bay ecosystem has escaped their impact; in some places they appear to account for all life.
They have, in fact, created a brand new ecosystem and perhaps, in time, will write a new chapter in evolution.
These exotic invaders (scientists have identified 212 such species so far, and the origins of 123 others are unknown) have arrived by a variety of avenues, from piggybacking on imported oysters to deliberate introduction to hitchhiking in boxes of fish bait. But the biggest single mechanism, scientists believe, is the ballast water from ships. Discharged routinely and daily into the bay in larger quantities from bigger vessels, ballast water is believed to have caused a marked acceleration of the invasion in the last decade.
Continuing invasions are changing the ecosystem so fast that scientists are doing well just to keep up with the growing inventory and distribution of species. Understanding the organisms' interactions and the characteristics of the new system has proved more elusive. Each new introduced species "can send it off in a different direction," Dr. Carlton said of the ecosystem, "and because I don't know what my next species is tomorrow, I don't know what to predict."
Ecologists like Dr. Cohen and Dr. Carlton, the authors of an exhaustive study of the bay this year for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, know that there are both positive and negative effects. For openers, there are many more species in the bay than before the invasions; the rich new ecosystem is in some measure a showcase of life's inventive variety.
But similar groupings of species are also being assembled in other estuaries around the globe while the bay's native flora and fauna dwindle in the face of the invasion from abroad. At least one bay species, the thicktail chub, has been driven to extinction. Another, the delta smelt, is endangered. A third, the Sacramento perch, can no longer be found in local waters. And many other native populations have been diminished. Invading predators may have contributed to the losses, Dr. Cohen said.
The bay has "lost the distinctive faunal characteristics and the web of community relationships that it had developed since its post-ice age origin, and which distinguished it from the other great estuaries of the world," the two ecologists wrote in a report last year.
While the worldwide conveyor belt has transferred at least a handful of San Francisco Bay species to distant estuaries, Dr. Cohen said, the extent and volume of the outbound transfer are not known. For terrestrial species, the flow is heavily from Europe and Asia to other parts of the world. For estuarine species, he said, "we don't have a handle on the preponderance one way or the other."
For good or ill, signs of the bay's transformation are everywhere.
"Oh, yes, all right!" Dr. Cohen exclaimed as he examined a tiny isopod, similar to the American pillbug that rolls up into a ball, that he had just extracted from a glob of biological material clinging to a dock at the Coast Guard station in Oakland. Dr. Cohen's excitement was the scientist's excitement over discovery, in this case directed at a recent arrival of Australian origin. But some of the isopod's relatives appear to be boring into and severely damaging the Styrofoam underpinnings of some docks, causing them to sink slowly.
At an arm of the bay within sight of the Oakland Coliseum, littleneck clams from Japan, exposed at low tide, cover the mud like smooth, gray stones. Some people harvest and eat them.
On Bay Farm Island, ribbed horse mussels, natives of the Atlantic, burrow into the mud between the low and high tide marks. They are in the bay by the millions, forming dense colonies. On Bay Farm Island, they bury themselves with just the tips of their double shells exposed and slightly separated. Scientists say they often clamp shut on the toes or bills of the endangered California clapper rail, sometimes causing adult birds to starve and chicks to drown. On the other hand, the mussels have become the rails' main food.
The rails' life is made further hazardous by two introduced land predators, the Norway rat and the red fox. Some measure of refuge from them has been provided by yet another aquatic invader -- Atlantic cordgrass, which thickly covers the shore of Bay Farm Island with a tall, thick protective blanket. But whether it is better habitat than the sparser Pacific cordgrass it is replacing is not known. Nor is it clear just how all of this ecological pulling and hauling will ultimately affect the endangered bird.
Farther south, on the bay shore near Hayward, Dr. Cohen reaches down with a long-handled net and brings up a haul of what look like black-eyed peas. They are tiny Asian clams, invaders that have covered large stretches of the bay's bottom at a peak density of more than 4,000 a square foot since their introduction a mere decade ago, probably as larvae in ballast water.
The clams are too small to have any economic value, but their effect on the life of the bay is enormous. They subsist on microscopic animals and plants, called zooplankton and phytoplankton, which form the basis of the bay's food chain. Scientists calculate that in the northern bay, where the clams are particularly dense, they can filter plankton from all the water in the deep channels more than once a day and all the water in the shallows, where phytoplankton especially abound, nearly 13 times a day. It is feared that the clams will permanently reduce the plankton, to the detriment of fish that feed in open water.
Another recent arrival from Asia, the Chinese mitten crab, so called because of its hairy claws, conjures fears of another sort. A native of Korea and China, it may have been planted in the bay as a food source. But its behavior when introduced outside its native range has sometimes been disturbing. In Germany in the 1930's, Dr. Cohen and Dr. Carlton wrote in their report, the invading crabs became "phenomenally abundant," with masses of them "migrating up the main rivers, piling up against dams, climbing spillways and swarming over the banks onto shore, sometimes wandering onto city streets and entering houses." No such onslaught has yet taken place here, but the crabs were first identified in the bay only two years ago.
An arrival in the late 1980's was the Atlantic green crab, a true aquatic Attila. "It eats virtually everything," Dr. Cohen said. A native of Europe, it made its North American landfall in New England, where in the 1950's it destroyed the soft-shell clam fishery. It may have been introduced here either in ballast water or, as in the case of some other species, as larvae in algae used to pack shipments of bait worms from New England.
Here, the green crab has shown itself capable of eating the Dungeness crab, a valuable food species, and there is concern that it may eliminate the Dungeness from the bay. The green crab is too small to be a marketable replacement. In Bodega Harbor, green crabs can be collected by the score. There they eat the same shellfish that are eaten by native birds, and the concern is that the impact of the crab's depredations will cascade unpredictably through the food web.
Biological transformation has also overtaken the free-swimming creatures of the deep, open water. Gobies from Japan and shrimp from Korea, for instance, have joined the striped bass. In the fresher water of the delta at the northern end of the bay live species like goldfish, carp, threadfin shad and, from eastern North America, six species of catfish and four species each of sunfish and bass.
The economic effects of the introductions of new species have been little studied, but Dr. Cohen and Dr. Carlton say they are clearly substantial, though mixed. On one hand, according to their study, some introduced fish and shellfish have become valuable food and sportfishing species. Some, like mosquitofish, control nuisance insect populations. On the other hand, many of the exotics foul waterways and water delivery systems, damage docks, increase the cost of removing encrusting organisms from ships and prey on valuable native commercial and sport species.
Except in the Great Lakes, the Hudson River and Alaska, there are no government controls on the discharge of ballast water. Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, introduced a bill this year to extend regulations to all United States ports.
Even if all introductions stopped tomorrow, San Francisco Bay would hardly return to its former condition. While the settling-out of its new ecology is not yet complete, Dr. Cohen believes it might eventually fall into a pattern similar to that observed in terrestrial areas disturbed by humans. There, a relatively few hardy, adaptable, "weedy" species that thrive on disturbance tend to take over.
Stepping back and taking a philosophical look, Dr. Carlton predicted that whatever the character of the new ecosystem, it will in time come to be accepted as natural. No matter how great a creature's impact on the bay, he said, over the years it will gradually be seen as a normal part of the environment by people who do not realize it was an immigrant.
"Three or four generations into the future," he said, "it won't be an issue. Time heals all."

HEADLINE: Development Zones Program Corrected Flaws

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Questions Raised on Development Zones" (news article, Aug. 8), on New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's audit of the state's Economic Development Zones, contains a quoted assertion that New York State subsidizes the relocation of businesses within the state. The zones law forbids such subsidies. 
 A suggestion is also made that inflated job estimates have resulted in excessive costs to taxpayers. The overestimates were reported during the past administration (1991 through 1994). Any zone-based business that overstates job creation results (off which the incentives are based) is under law subject to penalty for fraud. The Department of Economic Development has recently decertified 488 companies for cause or because they no longer claim zone benefits.
Mr. McCall ignored the Pataki administration's reorganization of zone oversight, including sanctions for zones that fail to file complete reports; annual site visits, and decertification of businesses that fail mandatory reporting requirements.
The changes made by Gov. George E. Pataki in the way New York State conducts business have corrected the inherited deficiencies in the zones program. It is now a stronger, more important tool for job creation during New York's economic revival.
 
CHARLES A. GARGANO
Chairman and Chief Executive
Empire State Development Corp.
New York, Aug. 10, 1996
