HEADLINE: On My Mind;
President Dole's Duty

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"And when I am President, every man and every woman in our armed forces will know the President is their Commander in Chief," said Bob Dole in his acceptance speech in San Diego. The next words were underlined in his text and voice. "Not Boutros Boutros-Ghali or any other U.N. Secretary General."
That got a big hand at the convention. In fact, it always got a nice hand, whenever Mr. Dole and other Republican politicians said it, in or out of the convention hall. Hasn't failed for years. 
 Said once, it would be kind of comical. Here he comes, the Secretary General, patrolling the U.N. corridors, one day in U.S. fatigues, another in the turban of a Sikh general in the Indian Army, or the dress uniform of a Russian admiral. If he is Commander in Chief of American forces he must be the same for all U.N. members, nein, cher Marechal?
But said over and over, it is scare propaganda -- a crazy-mirror distortion not only of the Secretary Generalship but of the entire concept and operation of the U.N.
The U.N. does not exist as Mr. Dole and the platform committee wanted Americans to see it: a strange foreign apparition floating out there whose chief bureaucrat can tell the U.S. what to do. It is a conference center right here in an American city, where a majority of nations decide what economic, military or political action they might take, give instructions to the U.N. staff, which then wanly hopes that the governments will pay up for everything they ordered.
No nation has more often or more successfully used the U.N. to get international support for military operations than the U.S. President Truman outwitted the Soviet Union to get the U.N. umbrella for the decision he had already taken to resist the Communist invasion of South Korea. President Bush got U.N. support for a coalition to defeat Saddam Hussein. The U.S. did not then tell the U.N. that it would permit Saddam Hussein to stay in power if he lost the war. Mr. Bush let that be a neat surprise.
President Clinton got the U.N. to approve the U.S. going into Haiti -- and to take over when he wanted to get out. In Bosnia, the U.S. and its allies used the U.N. when it suited them and then bounced it in favor of a NATO military operation to stop the killing, plus make Bosnians love each other.
Each time, U.S. combat troops were under U.S. command, platoon to President. That was true too about U.S. combat troops killed in Somalia, whose deaths were used in San Diego to demonize not the enemy but the U.N.
Yes, there are small units of U.S. soldiers assigned to observer or other "peacekeeping" duties under U.N. operational control. Of 28,000 troops from 71 countries, serving in scores of places around the world, only 786 are American. They were dispatched not by Cosmos Commander Boutros-Ghali but by U.S. Presidents for U.S. interests -- political, military or intelligence. Sometimes they report to a general of an allied nation. These U.S. units are officered by Americans responsible through the U.S. chain of command to the President.
The Republican position leaves a hole that James P. Rubin, the new foreign policy spokesman for the Clinton re-election campaign, drove right through: if carried out as policy, America would "lose an important tool to share the burden of solving problems of the new world, alienate key allies and have to choose between doing everything or doing nothing when the inevitable crisis affecting American interests arises."
The U.S. is the chief political and military beneficiary of the U.N. and also earns a pretty dollar from having U.N. headquarters in the U.S. It is also the chief deadbeat, more than $1 billion behind in dues, as usual.
And because of the Clintonians' sudden arrogant announcement that Washington would veto the re-election of Mr. Boutros-Ghali, the U.S. has rarely been more resented nor the Secretary General more popular. U.N. diplomats interpret the mugging of Mr. Boutros-Ghali as I do: a timorous act taken in fear that the Republicans might get some votes from their attacks against the U.N. and its Secretary General.
If Mr. Dole wins, and one day has to commit troops to action, he will surely not fail to seek a U.N. endorsement that could help U.S. forces win. The sensible time for Republicans to think of that is now, not when it becomes his duty.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed Amid Uncertainty Over Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher against the yen but lower against most leading currencies yesterday in trading driven by uncertainty over whether the United States and German central banks would adjust interest rates this week.
Currency traders generally expected Federal Reserve policy makers to leave rates unchanged today, while many expected that the Bundesbank's central council might lower a key rate at its meeting on Thursday. But no traders were making any extraordinary bets ahead of either event. 
 "It's hard, this close to all that data, to take a position," said Graham Broyd, senior vice president-foreign exchange at NatWest Markets in New York. "We're in a holding pattern."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 1.4872 marks, down from 1.4918 marks on Friday. The dollar traded at 107.81 yen, up from 107.70. The British pound fell to $1.5450 from $1.5481.
The dollar strengthened against the yen in Asian trading after the Japanese Finance Ministry said the July trade surplus fell by 38 percent from a year ago, reflecting the impact of growing imports in Japan. Its trade surplus has been shrinking sharply all year.
The trend has weakened the yen by decreasing demand for the currency from Japanese exporters returning profits from sales abroad.
"When the Japanese trade number came out people sold the yen on it," said Kisoo Park, senior dealer at the Bank of Boston. That strengthened the dollar and other currencies against the yen, Mr. Park said, "and basically that's been the whole day."
The mark's strength against the yen partly accounted for the dollar's weakness against the mark.
The mark also benefited from a selloff in the Italian lira on worries of a clash between the Government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi and the Communist Refounding Party.
Some traders also sold dollars to lock in profits from Friday, when the dollar hit its highest level against the mark since July 18 on speculation that the Bundesbank would lower its securities repurchase, or repo, rate, a key short-term rate that has stood at 3.3 percent since February.
Lower rates would help stimulate Germany's economy but hurt the mark by making holdings denominated in the currency less attractive.

HEADLINE: The Spoiler Returns

 BODY:
The political party that Ross Perot created one year ago to find and bankroll "someone who could really be a great President but doesn't have the financial resources" has located its man. He is Ross Perot, who has never doubted his potential for greatness but has chosen, this time around, to use less of his own money and more of the taxpayers' to achieve his goal. That may be a wise move on Mr. Perot's part, since his already slim chances have presumably been diminished by the fact that he is no longer a novelty.
With his folksy metaphors and his staccato speaking style, Mr. Perot added spice to the 1992 campaign. Whether he can be anything more than an annoyance this time around remains to be seen, but he is already irritating the Republicans. A deficit hawk, he adds an insistent whine to the chorus of criticism aimed at Bob Dole's and Jack Kemp's supply-side notion that they can return the country to solvency with a big tax cut. 
 There have always been two big questions about Mr. Perot. One is whether he has the temperament for the job. For all his homespun directness on economic issues, his behavior in 1992 reflected a manipulative, impatient, imperious man, poorly versed in the arts of compromise and negotiation. He does not seem to have changed much. No sooner had Richard Lamm announced his candidacy for the Reform Party's nomination than Mr. Perot proclaimed that the nomination was his by divine right or something close to it. "The American people want me to do this," he said. "If anybody should do it, I should do it."
The other question involves his willingness to make choices. He speaks sparingly about important issues like civil rights, education, the environment and foreign policy. But even on economic questions, he is still promising to assemble the experts to peer under the hood to find out where the trouble is -- exactly what he said four years ago. On taxes, for example, he pledged in Sunday's acceptance speech to examine all the options "carefully, thoughtfully and rationally. We're going to use the computer as our wind tunnel. We'll nail it, give it to you and then move on to our next problem." Mr. Perot claims to be a man of action, but his favorite form of action is to appoint a study group.
He is expected to make a big issue of campaign finance reform and the need to restore the power of ordinary citizens by breaking the link between wealthy donors and legislative outcomes. That is an important matter that both major parties have ducked, but the process that produced Mr. Perot's nomination makes one wonder how serious he really is about participatory democracy.
First, Mr. Lamm had a terrible time getting his hands on a party membership list so he could send out some literature. Then many of the mail ballots arrived late. Mr. Lamm said that with less than a week to go before the nominating convention, neither he nor his daughter had received ballots. The telephone voting system also failed, in part because callers were not told how to identify themselves properly.
In any case, the process produced an astonishingly low turnout -- 49,226 valid votes, less than 5 percent of the total party membership. There may have been no foul play here, but for a man like Ross Perot who puts so much faith in technology and rhapsodizes about "electronic town halls" and push-button plebiscites, this display of ineptitude must have been mightily embarrassing.
The latest polls suggest Mr. Perot would get about 10 percent of the votes. He spent $60 million of his own money in 1992, and clawed his way back from 7 percent in the October polls to 18.9 percent on Election Day. This year he will spend $30 million in Federal money and whatever he can raise. That is still enough to underwrite the ads and the 30-minute infomercials that served him so well last time. He also has a knack for wheedling free TV time and is no slouch on the debating platform.
All of this makes him a possible spoiler -- but not a plausible or desirable alternative.

HEADLINE: The Republican Riverboat Gamble

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, a professor of economics at Princeton, was vice chairman of the Federal Reserve and a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N. J.

 BODY:
When Bob Dole decided to make a 15 percent across-the-board tax cut the centerpiece of his campaign, he must have been banking on a serious case of collective amnesia. America ran a huge supply-side experiment in the 1980's. The "riverboat gamble," as it was called by Howard H. Baker Jr., then the Senate majority leader, proved to be a losing one. The big tax cuts increased the deficit rather than economic growth.
Yet last week I listened as the Republican challenger attacked the alleged "slow growth" record of President Clinton and promised large tax cuts to fuel growth, increased defense outlays and spending cuts (which he couldn't specify) large enough to balance the budget. For a moment, I thought my TV was tuned to a 16-year-old rerun. 
 History has already rendered its verdict on supply-side economics, which holds that large tax cuts can substantially increase economic growth. But revisionists are rewriting the text. According to this new version, it all worked beautifully. Wait a minute. Earth to San Diego. A brief historical review is in order.
During the 1980 campaign, candidate Ronald Reagan endorsed supply-side economics, along with a proposal, sponsored by Representative Jack Kemp and Senator William V. Roth, for a 30 percent across-the-board reduction in income tax rates. Congress enacted a 25 percent cut in August 1981, with a few more goodies thrown in. Let's compare the promises with what actually happened.
Real growth. I still have a copy of the February 1981 White House document outlining the economic plan. It claimed that supply-side incentives would spectacularly raise the average growth rate of the gross domestic product over the coming years to more than 4 percent. But the facts turned out quite differently.
First, we suffered through the worst recession since the Great Depression, with unemployment soaring higher than 10 percent in 1982 and 1983. The tax cuts did not cause the recession; mostly, it was caused by the tight-fisted monetary policy of the Federal Reserve.
But let's not forget that the growing budget deficits of the 1980's contributed to the Fed's tight fists. And let's not forget, either, that long-term interest rates soared from about 10 percent in the summer of 1980 to more than 15 percent following the passage of the Reagan economic plan in August 1981, in part because investors were spooked by the prospect of mammoth deficits. That probably deepened the recession.
Supply-side revisionists have a favorite statistic: Growth following the recession was strong and sustained -- averaging 3.5 percent from 1983 to 1990. It's true. And the tax cuts played a role by raising consumer spending. But achieving rapid growth is no great feat when you start from a position of widespread unemployment. Raising the economy's long-run, sustainable growth rate -- what economists call "trend growth" -- is much harder, and was not done.
Focusing on growth from 1983 to 1990 is statistical sleight of hand, because economic conditions in those two years differed vastly. The unemployment rate averaged 9.6 percent in the recession year of 1983 and 5.5 percent in the peak year of 1990. The economy grew so rapidly between these years because the nation was snapping back from a deep recession, not because trend growth was higher. For a more honest estimate of growth, choose years with approximately equal unemployment -- say, 1981 (with 7.6 percent unemployment) and 1992 (with 7.4 percent). Growth over this 11-year period averaged only about 2.6 percent.
We can also use a common economic rule of thumb to measure this 1983 to 1990 growth rate. Each percentage point of unemployment represents about a two percentage point loss in gross domestic product. So the 4.1 point decline in unemployment from 1983 to 1990 can be seen as accounting for about 8.2 percent of growth over the seven years. Allowing for compounding, that is the equivalent of about 1.1 percentage points per year. Subtracting this from that boasted-about 3.5 percent average yields a reasonable estimate of trend growth in the seven years: 2.4 percent.
The conclusion is hard to escape. Sustainable growth in the 1980's was about 2.5 percent -- the same as, or even lower than, it had been before the big tax cuts.
The budget. The 1981 Republican team promised a balanced budget by fiscal 1984 despite huge tax cuts and increased defense spending. Tax revenues generated by rapid growth, we were told, would fill the budget gap. Yet the deficit in 1984 came in at $185 billion. What happened?
According to another favorite revisionist myth, the deficit ballooned not because tax receipts fell but because Congress failed to control spending. Let's ignore the inconvenient fact that Congress consistently appropriated about the amount that President Reagan's budgets requested, and look at the numbers.
The 1981 budget plan said receipts and outlays would balance in fiscal 1984 -- at about $772 billion each. But in 1984, actual receipts were only $667 billion, a $105 billion shortfall. It is true that at the same time outlays exceeded their target by $80 billion. But a good deal of this was the interest bill on the growing national debt. Interest payments rose by $42 billion from fiscal 1981 to fiscal 1984.
In short, the supply-side miracle failed to materialize, leaving revenues much lower and deficits vastly higher than promised.
Working and saving. Supply-side economics derives its name from the idea that lower tax rates will stimulate savings (and thus a larger supply of capital) and more work from the population (a larger labor supply). Did it work that way in the 1980's?
No. The personal savings rate fell -- from 8.2 percent of disposable income in 1982 to 6.9 percent in 1986 and 4.8 percent in 1989. Nor was there a larger labor supply. The labor force grew at an average rate of 1.6 percent over those seven years, about the same as during the preceding four years.
In other words, the "supply" responses to lower tax rates -- which are the heart and soul of supply-side economics -- were a no-show in the 1980's. Consequently, growth did not accelerate, leaving an enormous revenue shortfall that expenditure cuts could not, or did not, cover. The failed experiment blew a giant hole in the budget that took 15 years to patch up. And it should have destroyed the credibility of supply-siders forever.
However, Mr. Dole, who was among the sternest critics of supply-side economics, has now become a believer. As a responsible Senate leader, he was instrumental in raising taxes and cutting spending to reverse the excesses of 1981. Yet now that the Government has finally gotten its deficit under control, he is urging us once again to take the riverboat gamble.
Perhaps he thinks that American voters, having forgotten the past, are condemned to repeat it. But perhaps they have not forgotten. We will find out in November.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE BACKGROUND;
Kemp's Legacy as Housing Secretary: One of Ideas, Not Accomplishments

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
As President Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack Kemp was known as an innovative thinker and virtually the only voice for the inner-city poor in an Administration with priorities elsewhere.
But a look at his record at the Housing Department shows that Mr. Kemp was unable to translate his ideas into solid accomplishments -- although others, after him, have begun to do so. 
 Instead of setting in place creative policies that would help the inner- city poor, Mr. Kemp often found that his ideas and policies were thwarted by a hostile, Democratic-controlled Congress, an uninterested Bush Administration, and what many saw as his own bureaucratic and managerial shortcomings and an unwillingness to compromise, even with potential allies.
"He was much more interested in the ideas he was promoting than he was in the nuts and bolts of how you get from point A to point B," said Cushing Dolbeare, a longtime advocate for low-income housing.
Nowhere was Mr. Kemp's failure more evident than in his highly touted program to encourage public-housing tenants to buy their apartments, an effort he advocated with the fervor of a Southern Baptist preacher and one that he declared would help poor tenants break the shackles of dependency.
But in the four years he headed the Housing Department, the agency succeeded in selling only 135 units -- all but three located in one apartment house in Washington -- out of a total public-housing inventory of 1.3 million apartments, town houses and single-family homes.
At the same time, as the only major official in the Bush Administration exhorting Republicans to be concerned about the problems of minorities and poor people, Mr. Kemp was popular with liberal black and Hispanic civil rights leaders.
"He talked that kind of inclusive, expansive talk," said the Rev. Jesse Jackson. "That's how he developed a reputation that gained him disfavor among the right-wing types and gained him an appreciation with people beyond his type."
Mr. Kemp is given credit for restoring integrity and morale to a department that had been ignored by President Reagan and battered by influence-peddling scandals under Mr. Reagan's Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. After taking over the department in 1989, Mr. Kemp abolished a number of programs that were badly abused under Mr. Pierce's tenure, including an account that could be spent at the discretion of the Housing Secretary.
"It changed during Jack's tenure from an agency which was known for political wheeling and dealing to one that was squeaky clean," said Anna Kondratas, a former Assistant Housing Secretary under Mr. Kemp.
He also set about lifting sagging morale within the agency, sprucing up HUD's drab headquarters, making sure the cafeteria offered better food, even organizing and attending agency picnics that included everyone from undersecretaries to mail room clerks.
But beyond cleaning up the Housing Department, Mr. Kemp was largely ineffective in getting his pet projects implemented.
Housing experts say the program to sell public-housing units to the tenants who occupied them failed because the potential buyers were too poor to afford them or did not want to buy an apartment that usually needed extensive renovation, often in a crime-ridden, drug-infested development.
"He had this wild theory that all of the residents were sitting on the edge of their seats waiting to purchase the units they were living in," said Richard Nelson, executive director of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment, a group representing agencies that manage public-housing and community redevelopment programs. "The condition of public housing is misunderstood by many. While there are units that are livable and decent, they are generally not what people necessarily want to have as their permanent home."
Mr. Kemp was also unable to win approval in Congress of his other major policy initiative: enterprise zones in cities, in which, he hoped, tax incentives would revitalize blighted neighborhoods. That failure, some critics said, stemmed as much as anything from Mr. Kemp's unwillingness to compromise.
He insisted that cuts in taxes, particularly on capital gains, be the only incentive.
But many Democrats in Congress, and city officials, thought that a mix of tax incentives, government money and social-service programs were needed.
"Kemp has little credibility in this field because at every opportunity to choose between practical political compromise to benefit low-income communities and his supply-side dogma, he consistently chose the latter," said Richard H. Cowden, executive director of the American Association of Enterprise Zones, which represents cities and states that have set up enterprise zones. "He actually set back the clock in this field by staking out a position that guaranteed a political stalemate on policies towards cities."
In keeping with his professed concern about civil rights, Mr. Kemp initiated a number of innovative programs to root out discrimination against blacks and Hispanics by insurance companies and mortgage lenders. Those programs led to suits against such insurance giants as State Farm and Allstate, the largest provider of homeowners' insurance in the country.
But under Mr. Kemp, the Housing Department, never developed efficient means to investigate complaints of housing discrimination, a role Congress had given the agency in 1988. As a result, by the time Mr. Kemp left office, a backlog had built up of more than 480 complaints that had not been investigated.
But if he lacked follow-through, Mr. Kemp is acknowledged to have been a visionary who promoted ideas that eventually became Federal and state policy.
States have set up more than 800 enterprise zones since, as Housing Secretary, Mr. Kemp became the first Federal official to advocate them. Last year the Clinton Administration designated "empowerment zones" -- enterprise zones by another name -- in 12 cities.
Last week, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros announced a new initiative to help 25,000 tenants in public housing buy homes by the year 2000. Unlike Mr. Kemp's program, however, these tenants would not necessarily buy the apartments they are renting.
But backers and critics agree that Mr. Kemp's most important legacy was fighting to prevent the agency and, by extension the plight of big cities, from being forgotten.
"I think Jack Kemp was good because he was outspoken for the department," said Shanna Smith, executive director of the National Fair Housing Alliance. "He wasn't ashamed to be working there."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Dole's Plan and Its High Hurdles

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Since unveiling his plan to slash taxes and still balance the Federal budget by 2002, Bob Dole has argued that overcoming the economic and political hurdles in its way is simply a question of Presidential will. "I have it," he said. "I will do it."
But if he defeats President Clinton and wants to keep the promises that he has placed at the heart of his campaign, Mr. Dole will have to translate his fortitude into far deeper reductions in Federal spending than anything contemplated so far by even the most fervent Republican budget cutters. 
 By his own accounting, Mr. Dole would have to cut so deeply into a whole array of domestic programs that he would effectively be asking the electorate to accept a far more modest vision of government, and one able to make harder choices than the political system has yet been willing to confront.
Mr. Dole has made his already daunting task even more difficult by exempting from any cuts roughly two-thirds of Federal spending, on Social Security, Medicare (except for the reductions in projected spending that are outlined by the Republican Congress in its current budget proposal), the military and interest payments on the national debt.
All that is left are the basic domestic operations of the Government, a broad range of programs that would have to be cut by about 37 percent from current levels by 2002, after accounting for inflation, to meet Mr. Dole's goal, budget analysts say.
The current Republican budget proposal in Congress, by contrast, would cut these so-called domestic discretionary programs by 24 percent, and even at that level is widely considered to be at the high end of what is politically feasible, or beyond.
If the arguably optimistic economic assumptions that Mr. Dole's plan rests on do not pan out, the need for spending cuts would become that much greater. The plan assumes, for example, that tax cuts can pay in part for themselves, by generating greater economic activity; that some categories of tax receipts can be maintained at their current high levels, and that there will be no recession in the next six years.
As it is, Mr. Dole's budget plan makes no provision for the cost of another campaign promise, a national anti-missile defense, a program that at a minimum would cost tens of billions of dollars. And while Mr. Dole has pledged not to touch Social Security or to reduce Medicare spending below the levels contemplated in the current Republican budget, even some of his former Congressional colleagues, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, have suggested that these politically sensitive entitlement programs would have to be a part of any credible package of cuts, because of their sheer size.
"The Dole people will maintain with straight faces from now until November that the necessary cuts will be anonymous, painless reductions that will not affect you or anyone you know and that will come out of waste, fraud and abuse and excessive administrative costs," said Martha Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group with bipartisan backing.
"People who have been around the budget process know that the easy savings were used in the 1980's," she said. "We're now talking about going deeply into all the services and other kinds of benefits that people think of as being their government: the air traffic controllers, the national parks, the immigration service, aid to education, agricultural and medical research, law enforcement. We would need to make the decision that government should not be in certain activities."
Democrats are already asking whether Republicans would be willing to vote for reducing the number of F.B.I. or Border Patrol agents, or to eliminate road-building projects in their home districts, or to eliminate tax breaks for their biggest campaign contributors.
White House officials are planning to use the budget-cutting issue against Mr. Dole, saying the Republican candidate's plan will give voters a choice between cuts far more extreme than most Americans are willing to tolerate and the risk that the budget deficit will expand once more.
Even some Republicans are urging caution. In his speech to the Republican National Convention last week, Colin L. Powell urged the party never to "step back from compassion," and added, "We must make sure that reduced government spending doesn't single out just the poor and the middle class."
Mr. Dole has said he would use the line-item veto, which will be available to the next President, to enforce the fiscal discipline he is calling for. On the campaign trail in the last few days, he maintained that the necessary spending cuts could be enacted without the pain that Democrats are arguing would be necessary.
"The scaremongers are working overtime," Mr. Dole said at a campaign stop on Sunday. "We're going to balance the budget and cut your taxes without touching Social Security or Medicare, and don't let them try to scare you."
But Mr. Dole has offered only a few details of where he would find the savings necessary to pay for his $548 billion tax cut and a balanced budget.
He has proposed cutting $32 billion from the Energy Department's budget over the next six years, a level that would correspond roughly to eliminating the department's nonmilitary activities, including all research into energy conservation and alternative energy sources. And he has proposed taking $15 billion from the Commerce Department over six years, more than half its budget and a level that would force difficult decisions about financing the Census Bureau, the National Weather Service, the gathering of basic economic statistics and aid to exporters, among other programs.
The Dole plan starts by assuming a $147 billion gain in revenue over six years from a spurt in economic growth resulting from tax reduction and other elements of the candidate's program. The plan also counts on all the cuts included in the current Republican Congressional budget resolution, $393 billion over six years, among them a reduction of $158 billion in previously projected spending on Medicare and other cuts that Democrats have been arguing, to some political effect, are extreme.
The plan then goes on to require an additional $183 billion in spending cuts, plus $34 billion in new revenue from the sale of broadcast frequencies (on top of $19 billion from frequency sales already counted on in the current budget resolution).
A report on the Dole plan by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization, said, "If some activities" in discretionary domestic spending "are not cut 37 percent -- for example, activities such as border patrols, veterans' health care, administering Social Security and the operations of Federal prisons -- other programs in this area would have to be cut substantially deeper."

HEADLINE: Russia Outstrips U.S. as Chief Arms Seller to Developing Nations

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Russia, eager to bolster its economy with the hard currency it earns from the sale of everything from bullets to jet fighters, surpassed the United States and France last year as the largest arms seller to the developing world, according to a new Congressional report.
The report by the Congressional Research Service calculated that Russian arms sales to developing nations rebounded from a slump that set in after the breakup of the Soviet Union, growing by 62 percent last year -- to $6 billion in 1995 from $3.7 billion in 1994 -- and that its most important buyer was China. 
 "Russia has made significant efforts to gain arms agreements with developing nations that can pay cash for their purchases," the report said. "With Russia now having an emerging market economy, domestic defense industries also have greater freedom to promote the sale of their weaponry."
Russian arms merchants had a banner year even as the overall market for arms in the developing world continued to shrink, falling to $15.4 billion last year, the fifth consecutive year that total arms sales have shown a decline. As recently as 1988, arms sales to developing countries totaled $61 billion.
According to the annual study by the research service, an arm of Congress, sales by American defense contractors to developing nations fell from $6.3 billion in 1994 to $3.8 billion last year, which left the United States in second place among the world's arms merchants. French sales to the developing world dropped to $2.7 billion last year from $8.9 billion in 1994, pushing it to third place.
While the report offered little analysis of the strategic implications of these shifts among arms sellers, it made clear that some nations are so eager for their share of a shrinking international arms market that they may be selling destabilizing weapons, including ballistic missiles, to developing nations.
The report singled out China as a nation that has "demonstrated its readiness to sell such weapons to any state that sought them," even if that meant violating international accords on arms transfers. In recent years, China has sold missiles to Iran, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.
The report defined the developing world as all nations except the United States, Russia, Western Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand. The developing nations, it said, accounted for slightly more than half of all arms purchases worldwide last year.
The report's author, Richard F. Grimmett, said the sharp drop in weapons sales to the developing world reflected the end both of the cold war and of a period of rearmament in the Middle East after the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf.
"As competition over a shrinking international arms market intensifies, it is likely that suppliers such as France, Russia and the United Kingdom may routinely shift in their rankings relative to one another and to the United States," the report said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Economy Grew 7.2% in Mexico Last Quarter, a Sign of Revival

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19

 BODY:
In its latest and strongest indication that a long-awaited recovery was solidly under way, Mexico announced late Sunday that the economy grew by 7.2 percent in the second quarter.
The figure, which was based on a comparison with the second quarter of 1995, exceeded analysts' expectations and was the first economic growth Mexico had reported since the beginning of the devastating crisis that followed the peso's devaluation in December 1994. 
 The economic surge was a vindication of the harsh financial-stabilization program pursued by President Ernesto Zedillo, whose policies have had strong backing from the Clinton Administration, including an emergency loan last year of $12.5 billion. Despite skepticism on Wall Street, Mexican officials have insisted for the last nine months that growth would resume in the first half of 1996 and reach at least 3 percent for the year.
Given Sunday's report, such annual growth seems clearly possible. The 7.2 percent figure is the highest quarterly increase in output Mexico has had since the end of 1990, at the start of a four-year boom. Market analysts were predicting 5.8 percent.
"The question now is not whether this country will grow 3 percent this year, but how it can sustain the even faster rates of growth it needs," said Deputy Finance Minister Jose Sidaoui Dib. Over all, the economy shrank nearly 7 percent last year. And economists noted that the comparable period in 1995 had been the worst in the crisis, with a nearly 10 percent contraction.
As a sign that the markets had already expected stronger growth in Mexico, the main stock market index here fell 1.09 percent today to finish at 3,324.67, as traders focused on whether the Federal Reserve would change interest rates in the United States. The Mexican market hit a high for the year on Friday and has been rallying since for several weeks. Late today, the peso traded at 7.4850 to the dollar.
The resumption of growth in Mexico is a happy prospect for the United States. American exports here, which had been expected to flourish with the North American Free Trade Agreement, have been as depressed as the Mexican economy. But Mexico's exports have thrived, with this country reporting an overall trade surplus for the first half of the year of $4.13 billion, up 29 percent from the first half of 1995. American officials expect that the signs of reviving demand will translate before the end of the year into record imports of goods from the United States.
The growth was led by areas like manufacturing that are heavily oriented toward exports and had already showed strong signs of life. But there were surprises, too. A category including retailers that do business with average consumers jumped 7.9 percent, suggesting that the severe pinch in family budgets was beginning to ease.
The crisis was deepened because many middle-class Mexicans had begun to spend on credit for the first time and were caught by the devaluation with personal and home loans they could not repay.
Although nearly 48 percent of bank loans were past due at the end of July, the overdue-loan portfolio not only stopped growing but showed a small decrease last month, according to SAC International, which monitors the Mexican banking system. Consumers are getting some relief from a gradual decline in interest rates, though the benchmark 28-day Mexican Treasury certificate is still at 26.63 percent.
In other good economic news, the census bureau reported that unemployment continued to fall in July -- to 5.8 percent from 7.3 percent a year ago. Those figures, however, include only the hard-core unemployed and do not tell anything about the millions of Mexicans who moonlight as cab drivers, sell windshield covers at street corners, or have taken up other informal work to make ends meet.
In addition, inflation is slowing, rising 1.4 percent in July compared with June. Economists predict that it will increase less in August.
Probably the most important effect of all this is to enhance the credibility of Mr. Zedillo's Government among foreign investors and officials. This growing confidence allowed Mexico to refinance through private foreign banks, at more favorable terms, all but $3.5 billion of the bailout money the Clinton Administration provided last year and to pay down $1 billion of $12.7 billion owed to the International Monetary Fund. Mexican markets have stabilized, and the turbulence of most of 1995 seems gone.
"This Government has demonstrated it has a sound approach to managing its liabilities," said Lawrence Goodman, head of Latin American economic research for Salomon Brothers.
Lately, Mr. Zedillo and top finance officials have been more cautious than many Wall Street analysts in describing Mexico's state of affairs. The President paid a steep price for the approach of his predecessor, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who had touted Mexico's rapid development when much of the capital came from volatile portfolio investments that vanished when the peso fell into trouble.
Earlier this month, Mr. Zedillo warned a gathering of state governors that it would take several more years for Mexico to climb back to the standard of living before the crisis. The President said he would be "cheating the people" to suggest that they would see full recovery in their day-to-day lives before then.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Life Deal Cleared by New York

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
New York State officials have approved a merger of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, removing the last significant hurdle the deal faces.
A spokesman for the Department of Insurance said yesterday that the agency had notified Met Life of its approval on Friday. Officials of both companies said a formal closing was scheduled for Aug. 30. It will be the largest merger ever in the mutual life insurance field, industry officials say. 
 Met Life, the second-largest American life insurer, brought to the deal about $150 billion in insurance assets. The new company will have more than $166 billion in assets, still trailing the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest, officials of the merging firms said.
"We think it's good for policyholders and for both companies," said Terry Lennon, the senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions at Met Life. "The two companies really complement each other very well. They are very strong in the small- business market and we are strong in the large institutional market. They sell to high-net-worth individuals where our strength is in the middle-income market."
Met Life has 40 million policyholders and New England Mutual has about one million, company officials said.
The merger had been threatened by an advocacy group in Boston, the Center for Insurance Research, which contended that a consolidation would diminish the financial value and voting power of New England policyholders. But a Massachusetts state judge refused to issue an injunction and that state's insurance department gave the merger its approval last Wednesday.
John Calagna, the spokesman for New York's insurance department, said that state regulators did not consider the objections of the Center for Insurance Research when they reviewed the merger.
"That litigation was against the Massachusetts insurance department," he said. "Our job was to look at whether it made sense for the two corporate entities and whether it made sense for the policyholders."
Met Life officials said that a handful of the other 48 states in which the two companies do business were required to endorse the plan, but one official said there was "no reason to expect that they won't."
Consolidations have been occurring throughout the industry as insurers try to amass greater pools of capital and market share to become efficient and improve their ratings.
Eric N. Berg, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, said the merger would lead to significant economies by eliminating overlapping positions. "It means your unit costs of administering a policy falls," he said. "This means either more profit or you can cut your price and be more competitive."
Peter Harrington, a vice president of New England Mutual, said Met Life's great financial strength would raise the ratings his company receives from insurance-rating agencies. The ratings for New England Mutual, which will continue to operate as an independent unit, slipped from the highest level in 1992 as its real estate holdings lost value and its investment income fell.
"We deal with a lot of third-party advisers -- lawyers and accountants -- and they are very impressed with ratings," Mr. Harrington said. "Our sales are up 10 percent just in anticipation of the merger."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE GREEN PARTY;
Ralph Nader Is Nominated for President, but Vows He Will Ignore His Party's Platform

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19

 BODY:
In a political development with a long-shot potential to cause President Clinton some re-election trouble, the Green Party, an offspring of the anti-nuclear and environmental movements, today nominated Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, to carry its banner in the fall.
Mr. Nader, somewhat out of the national limelight in recent years, readily accepted the nomination, whose November portent lies in the fact that in the dozen or so states where the Green Party is on the ballot, most notably California, he still has good name recognition and a following that, while small, could be crucial in a close Clinton-Dole-Perot race. 
 But ever the iconoclast, Mr. Nader picked up the Green banner without facing any opposition, then promptly declared that he would neither join the Green Party nor run on its platform, which calls for things like "ecological wisdom," "gender cooperation" and "future focus."
Further, he said, he will neither raise nor accept any campaign financing -- and most definitely will take no contributions from corporate America, which he termed the enemy of voters and the real target of his campaign, much as it was 30 years ago, when he first captured the national limelight with his crusade for automobile safety.
Mr. Nader promised to put up $5,000 of his own money (though not to disclose how he got it) so he could make "some very brief sojourns" around the country in search of free campaign publicity, giving interviews to any and all media comers.
"I'm an independent," he said in what may have been the most obvious political statement uttered to date in the '96 campaign.
Three hundred or so Greens gathered here from around the country for their first national nominating convention; the party claims a membership of 100,000, most of them Californians. Mr. Nader told the gathering that he did not hold out any hope that he would make it to the White House next January or, for that matter, that he would make it onto the ballot in all 50 states in November, but that was not the real point of the exercise. The Greens, like Mr. Nader, are in something of a state of political transition, looking for new causes and venues.
"What we're doing is building for the future," Mr. Nader said. "It's gotten so you can't tell Democrats from Republicans anymore in this country. They're both totally beholden to corporate America, and the great American public be dammed. We intend to offer a realistic third choice -- if not this year, then in the next election. That's what the people want, more and more."
While Mr. Nader had plenty of harsh words for Republicans and Democrats alike, he saved the harshest for the Democrats, and for President Clinton in particular, labeling him a "Rep-Dem hybrid."
In the few election polls that have included Mr. Nader as a candidate, he has seldom broken into double digits. What support he has shown has tended to come at Mr. Clinton's expense rather than Bob Dole's.
Mike Feinstein, a Green Party organizer from Santa Monica, Calif., praised Mr. Nader as someone who was not so much a Presidential candidate as the catalyst of revolutionary change, someone deep in the process of saving the American political system from collapse.
"Ralph is forcing people in this country to think what they want to do about the two-party system," Mr. Feinstein said. "That's what this convention is really all about."
Cris Moore, attending the convention from Santa Fe, N.M., agreed, saying the Green Party was no longer "a single-issue environmental party."
"What we starting to do," Mr. Moore said, "is combine social and economic concerns. The biggest issue in the country now is corporate power, and Ralph and the rest of us are facing up to that. The other parties just aren't addressing it."
The conventioneers here were not delegates in the traditional sense, just as the convention here was absent of most of the hoopla usually associated with nominating gatherings. In each of the 12 states where the Green Party is on the ballot, party members held their own nominating caucuses and then sent representatives to Los Angeles to report on the results -- that is, that Mr. Nader was their choice.
Mr. Feinstein predicted that his party and Mr. Nader would be on the fall ballot in at least 30 states by the end of the summer, perhaps more. He said the states that had already listed the party are Alaska, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Iowa, Maine, Nevada, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Utah.
Richard Winger, a San Franciscan who monitors ballot access nationally and publishes a newsletter called Ballot Access News, questioned whether the party would make it onto 30 ballots.
"They're not that well organized," Mr. Winger said, "and they don't have any money. My guess is they'll be lucky to make 20 ballots. And if Nader doesn't campaign hard, which is the way he's been talking, I don't seen where the momentum is going to come from for the fall campaign."
 
RALPH NADER
At his nomination yesterday as the Green Party's Presidential candidate in Los Angeles:
"Many Americans who call themselves liberals have so lowered their expectations about what politics can mean to this nation's future that they are settling for diminishing returns. Politics has been corrupted not just by money but by being trivialized out of addressing the great, enduring issues of who controls, who decides, who owns, who pays, who has a voice and access, and why solutions available on the shelf are not applied to the existing and looming crises of our society, both local and global.
One thing politicians do understand is rejection. When voters are deciding how they wish to use their vote, they should ask themselves how best to send a clear message. The Greens and other progressives are in the early building stages of a people-first, democratic political movement for future years. They deserve our attention because they are centering on the basic issues of representative government, one of whose purposes is to strengthen the usable tools of democracy, the other, in Thomas Jefferson's prophetic words, is "to curb the excesses of the monied interests."

HEADLINE: Anticipting the Fed: Moods Swing With the Data

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
Maybe the inflation wolf wasn't baying at the door after all.
 The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee meets today and is widely expected to leave short-term interest rates as they are, just as it did at its meeting in early July. But the consensus opinion about what the Fed would do has doen a lot of gyrating in between.
 When the committee wrapped up business the afternoon before the Fourth of July, the Fed's inaction seemed to say the economy was growing moderately and inflation was safely in check.
 Then, right after the holiday, the Labor Department released a surprisingly strong employment report for June, including sharp increases in total employment and in average wages. Analysts immediately speculated that a too-sanguine Fed committee had been caught off balance by the strong jobs data; interest rates would have to be raised at the next meeting to keep the economy from overheating. Both the stock and bond markets plunged that Friday in thin trading.
 With six more weeks of data to examine, though, it now appears that the instant analysis was overheated, not the economy. Growth looks moderate again, and threats of inflation seem muted and distant.
 Here are some economic tea leaves that have swirled since the great inflation flap of early July and how the markets read them. PATRICK J. LYONS

HEADLINE: Balkan Economies Stagnate In Grip of Political Leaders

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
When Western powers look at the Balkans these days, they often gauge progress by the number of weapons stilled, roads opened and refugees trudging home.
An equally important measure has received little attention: the liberalizing of economies that are largely Government-run and, in a sense, balkanized. 
 Though the Dayton peace accords have stopped the military conflict, the leaders of Bosnia, Serbia and Croatia have refused to loosen their grip on the economies that gave each of them a power base during the war, say Western economists, business leaders and Government officials.
By perpetuating their fiefs built on spoils and patronage, the politicians are obstructing the economic changes -- and development of entrepreneurs and regional markets -- that could help dilute the virulent nationalism that propelled the conflict.
"Nationalist desires are totally inconsistent with the needs of economic integration," said Milan Panic, the corporate leader who served as Prime Minister of what remained of Yugoslavia in 1992, before he fell out with the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic.
Mr. Panic, the chief executive of ICN Pharmaceuticals, a California-based manufacturer, argues that Western assistance to the Balkans should be granted only on the condition that the countries open up their economies.
"Economic prosperity is the prerequisite for long-term peace, and expanding trade among all the Balkan states will lead to that prosperity," Mr. Panic said during a recent visit to Belgrade to see how his factories in Serbia fared during three years of United Nations sanctions.
Foreign investors flocked to Serbia early this year when peace was new, and left disappointed that the economy remained under Goverment control. And even now, Mr. Panic, who describes himself as an optimist, said he did not see reforms happening soon.
In Serbia and Bosnia, the top political leaders are resisting privatization. A plan by Dragoslav Avramovic to revive a Serbian economy shattered by sanctions led to his abrupt dismissal as head of the Central Bank because he called for an end to state monopolies and the creation of a privatization program.
In Croatia, privatization of state property is moving ahead a little faster but often favors leading members of President Franjo Tudjman's party, the Croatian Democratic Union, at the expense of outside bidders, Western economists say.
All over the region, loans for business start-ups remain almost unattainable from Government-controlled banks. Import-export licenses and the tariff barriers from which politicians-cum-war-profiteers made fortunes persist.
Air, rail and telephone links that would help citizens move about and foster business are slow in coming because of fear of competition against Government monopolies.
A trade delegation of senior Bosnian officials that went to Belgrade in July, the first since the start of the war four years ago, was seen as a symbolic start to re-establishing old trade networks. But it produced few concrete results.
"There is no economy in Bosnia, because there is a general feeling here that broken-down state companies are an asset when in fact they are a liability," said Kevin Mannion, director of the International Management Group, a United Nations reconstruction agency that has been working in Sarajevo for three years.
Foreign investment has failed to materialize because Western companies and financial institutions are leery of sinking money into bankrupt state-run agencies, Mr. Mannion said. In general, Western financial assistance to Bosnia has been far lower than was envisioned immediately after the Dayton accords, but donor countries were dissuaded by the fact that the Government remained in firm control of the economy and there were no signs of imminent privatization.
In many instances, the heads of Bosnia's important Government agencies, like the major utility, Electropiverta, are also senior members of the governing political party, the Party of Democratic Action.
Officials close to President Alija Izetbegovic run the state television and have effectively blocked the start-up of an independent, Western-financed television network, American officials said.
The Bosnian officials' refusal, which has become an issue between the State Department and the Bosnian Government, is based on the fear that Mr. Izetbegovic and his party would lose control and lose money in the face of a viable commercial television network, the Americans said.
In Serbia, the stranglehold on the economy exercised by Mr. Milosevic, a former Communist banker, is even more stark. Rather than forget his old ideology, as some Western negotiators hoped after the Dayton accords, he has reverted to a more tightly controlled state-run economy.
That is because Mr. Milosevic believes that economic power, even in the debilitated Serbian economy, is the most certain method of keeping political control, his critics assert.
Mr. Milosevic gets strong support in his economic policies from his wife, Mirjana Markovic, the head of the largest political group in Serbia, the Yugoslav United Left.
Mrs. Markovic, who has described herself as an admirer of the Chinese Government but criticizes its economic program as being too market-oriented, has said privatization is unconstitutional in Serbia.
Key elements of the Serbian economy -- fuel, agriculture, exports-imports -- were controlled by Mr. Milosevic's cronies during the war and remain so.
The general manager of Progres, Serbia's biggest export firm and the leading importer of Russian gas, is the Prime Minister, Mirko Marjanovic. The speaker of Parliament, Dragan Tomic, is the head of Jugopetrol, Serbia's biggest fuel distributor.
Because these companies represent an enormous source of wealth for these politicians, they oppose any notion of a market economy, Serbian economists say.
When United Nations sanctions were suspended earlier this year, Western economists hoped that the Serbian economy would perk up. Instead, while the Milosevic coterie -- including the President's son, who recently opened a disco called Madonna -- gets richer, daily life for ordinary Serbs hovers at a subsistence level. Unemployment remains around 50 percent, and workers in state companies, where production is often at a standstill, are left unpaid for months on end.
Emboldened by popular support, Mr. Avramovic, a former World Bank official who is well respected in the West, pleaded for economic reforms to attract new capital while he served in the Serbian Government. Official foreign currency reserves slumped to less than $300 million this year, the lowest figure in Europe, including Albania, the banker warned.
But Mr. Avramovic was humiliated by Mr. Milosevic, who engineered a vote in Parliament to dismiss him.
"They want things to stay as they are because they have the best of all worlds," Mr. Avramovic said in an interview. "You have companies run by general managers appointed by one political leader. These are feudal fiefs held by one man. If you privatize, you lose control -- you convert your country from a tightly controlled society to an amorphous society where you don't know what to expect."
Under Mr. Milosevic's guidance, the economic system was dominated by 120 companies, Mr. Avramovic said. The heads of these concerns were all Government and political appointees and represented Serbia's main producers, exporters, importers and the banks, he said.
Several Western diplomats said that in recent negotiations, Mr. Milosevic had repeatedly asked for the lifting of the "outer wall" of sanctions that prevent Serbia from joining the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
But since financial help from these institutions requires economic reforms, it remains a mystery how Mr. Milosevic proposed to meet these demands, a diplomat said.
A Serbian economist at the Vienna Institute for Comparative Economics, Vladimir Gligorov, said he believed that the Serbian leader was tightening his control of the state-run economy and parts of the huge black market as November elections approach.
Under those circumstances, Mr. Gligorov said, the financial needs of Serbia will continue to be met by offshore banks in Cyprus. There, Borka Vucic, a close colleague of the Serbian leader, heads the branch of Beobanka, Serbia's biggest bank, where Mr. Milosevic was a director before he devoted himself to stoking the fires of nationalism.

HEADLINE: Black Buying Power Spurts, Study Finds

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Black Americans' buying power increased sharply last year, helping black households outpace white households in the increase on spending for cars, children's clothing and perishable foods, a new study has found.
The findings show that black consumers are becoming increasingly important to the American economy, said Ken Smikle, editor of the study, which was performed by Target Market News Inc., a Chicago company that specializes in analyzing the black consumer market. 
 "Even though African-Americans are only roughly 13 percent of the population, they're starting to have a significant influence on many categories," Mr. Smikle said. "When you're talking about billions of dollars to be made or lost, businesses have to sit up and take notice."
The study estimated that personal income among blacks rose to $324 billion in 1995, from $304.5 billion a year earlier.
It found that black households spent $10.8 billion on new cars and trucks last year, a 163 percent increase over the $4.1 billion spent a year earlier. While white households spent more in the aggregate on cars and trucks, the increase among them was just 9 percent from a year earlier.
The study also found that the average black household spent $1,592 a year on clothing, somewhat less than the $1,650 in clothing purchases by the average white household.
But on clothing for children under 15, the black household outspent the white household by about 10 percent, $292 to $265.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip as Traders Wait on Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in a quiet session yesterday, as market participants awaited today's Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates.
Though few traders expected the Fed's Open Market Committee to raise rates, a small number of them bid prices down to protect against the possibility of an increase. Traders said that other market influences yesterday included hedge funds, which were said to be selling Treasury securities, and the thin trading volume, which was said to exaggerate the price drops. 
 By the close of trading in New York, the 30-year Treasury bond was down 13/32 to a price of 99 15/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.79 percent, from 6.76 percent on Friday.
"That the market is backing up today, ahead of tomorrow's Federal Open Market Committee meeting is not that shocking," said David Shabelman, an analyst with MMS International in San Francisco. "Although no one expects the Fed to tighten rates, that is where the risk is."
A case could be made for a rate increase as a pre-emptive measure against inflation, he said: "Given today's losses, a steady policy decision would now lead to more of a relief rally than may have otherwise been seen."
"Many people weren't in to buy," Mr. Shabelman added, "even though they aren't expecting the Fed to do anything. And the reasoning behind that is, you just don't want to be on the wrong side in the event they do do something."
Even though commodity prices moved higher yesterday, they only had a limited impact. The Commodity Research Bureau index surged nearly 2.5 points.
While a sharp rise in the September crude oil contract to $23 a barrel did contribute to a rise in the index, oil gains were mostly limited to the September contract, which expires today. Moreover, there are those who still expect prices to retreat when oil from Iraq reaches the market.
Still, the bond market has not been paying attention because it has been more interested in the core rates of inflation, which exclude the volatile prices for oil and food.
Short-term rates at the Treasury's regular weekly sale of bills yesterday were up slightly in what was described as a well-bid auction. The average rate for a three-month maturity was 5.06 percent, up from 5.04 percent last week, while the rate for a six-month maturity was 5.13 percent, up from 5.08 percent.
Analysts said the market focused on the Fed's rate-policy meeting because no important data were scheduled to be released until Friday, when durable-goods orders for July are expected.
In the corporate market, the volume of issuance is expected to slow this week since many corporations have already taken advantage of lower rates. Tepid investor demand forced Sprint Spectrum L.P., a wireless telecommunications company, to revamp and scale back its plans to raise as much as $650 million.
Owned by a partnership of the Sprint Corporation, Tele-Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation, and the Cox Communications arm of Cox Enterprises, Sprint Sectrum is now trying to raise $520 million through the issuance of junk bonds. The issue is rated B-2 by Moody's and B+ by Standard & Poor's. Bonds that carry ratings of less than Baa-3 and BBB- respectively, are considered below investment grade, or junk.

Sun International in Deal For Merv Griffin's Concern
Sun International Hotels agreed to acquire Griffin Gaming and Entertainment for $210 million in stock. Merv Griffin controls a quarter of the company and could realize about $52.5 million from the deal. The acquisition would give Sun ownership of the Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City. [Page D4.]
 
Rival Offers in Mobile Homes
Manufactured Home Communities, controlled by Sam Zell, has offered to buy a rival, Chateau Properties, for $387.3 million. The offer seeks to derail Chateau's plans to merge with another rival, ROC Communities. [D5.]
 
$1 Million Deal for Cancer Society
SmithKline Beecham will pay $1 million a year to the American Cancer Society and put the society's name on its Nicoderm patches. [D2.]
 
Machines the Size of Bugs
Japanese companies are producing machines that are the size of a grain of rice. The companies, including Toyota, are hoping that miniature machines will become a booming business. [C1.]
 
Maybe Not Just a Question of Will
Bob Dole has argued that balancing the budget while cutting taxes is a question of Presidential will. But to keep his promises, Mr. Dole will need to make far deeper reductions in Federal spending than anything contemplated so far. News analysis. [A15.]
 
Insurance Merger Is Approved
New York regulators approved Metropolitan Life Insurance's merger with New England Mutual Life Insurance. [D2.]
 
Dow Industrials Up 9.99 Points
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.99 points, to 5,699.44 in lackluster trading, as investors awaited today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.74 points, to 1,130.91, reflecting continued weakness in technology shares. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dropped slightly, sending the yield on the 30-year bond up to 6.79 percent ahead of the Fed meeting. [D15.]
 
Balkan Economies Stagnate
Despite the cessation of fighting in the Balkans, many of the economies in the region are still suffering, under the tight control of politicians exploiting bureaucratic and nationalist advantages. [A1.]
 
 
Toys 'R' Us Earnings Rise
Toys "R" Us said that its second-quarter earnings jumped 72 percent, to $27.1 million, or 10 cents a share, exceeding estimates. In the second quarter of 1995, the international toy store chain earned $15.8 million, or 8 cents a share. [D4.]
 
Big Blue vs. Kasparov II
It may not be rematch of the century, but I.B.M.'s chess playing computer will try again to beat the world chess champion. [B1.]
 
Takeover Defense Is Challenged
A money manager is challenging Wallace Computer Services' takeover defense. [D18.]
 
Battle for B. B. King's Name
After 50 years of singing the blues, B. B. King is so successful that people are fighting over the use of his name on blues clubs. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Ochs Honored by City With Street of His Own

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The occupation of 43d Street off Times Square by The New York Times is a nightly affair as oversize delivery trucks groan and grind their way into narrow bays at the newspaper's loading dock to carry away bundles of the next day's issue.
Yesterday, on the 100th anniversary of the first issue of The Times published under the ownership of Adolph S. Ochs, the newspaper took over the street again, but in a much more genteel fashion. There was a box-lunch picnic for 2,000 employees, a Dixieland jazz band and a ceremony in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani renamed the block Adolph S. Ochs Street. 
 "Mr. Ochs used the words 'entirely fearless' to describe the manner in which he wanted his newspaper published," the Mayor said, recalling the risk and innovation that marked Mr. Ochs's career. "These are the words that he lived by, and this is the legacy that he's left to this great newspaper."
Mr. Giuliani said that like the Yankees, the Stock Exchange and other institutions bearing the New York name, The Times helps to define the city and enhance its reputation around the world. He said that since Times Square was named 92 years ago for The Times, it has become one of New York City's most recognizable places and that re-naming the street symbolizes "the very, very strong, inextricable connection between" the newspaper and the city.
The ceremony and picnic were the latest events marking the 100 years that the newspaper has been controlled by Mr. Ochs and his descendants, the Sulzberger family. There have been dinners, breakfasts and receptions, and exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, the Pierpont Morgan Library, the New York Public Library and the American Museum of Natural History.
Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the newspaper's publisher, welcomed the company's employees to the "urban picnic" commemorating "that young entrepreneur whose vision changed the face of journalism."
He said Mr. Ochs "taught us the lesson we live by, that great journalism is great business; that a newspaper must be economically viable, but that it must also be more than that, for a newspaper -- certainly this newspaper -- is a public trust."
Yesterday, it was a picnic.
Sitting at round outdoor tables sheltered from the sun by white umbrellas, the paper's employees dined leisurely in the middle of 43d Street, as the Muskrat Dixieland band pleasantly muted the usual cacophony from Times Square.
Bernadette Lin, a 26-year employee in the corporate controller's office, came downtown on her day off to join her co-workers at the picnic and even pose for a few pictures. "It's a centennial," she said. "It's not going to come around for another 100 years."
Nina Robinson, who works in corporate communications and was snapping pictures of Ms. Lin and her co-workers, said, "We're not going to be around for the next one."
John Nardone, wearing reflector sunglasses and sipping a bottle of natural spring water, marveled at how the midtown street had been transformed into a relatively serene setting, complete with an arch of blue and white balloons. He and other employees, who now work at the company's printing plant in Edison, N.J., said they had strong memories of watching the varied street life on 43d Street, which they said became more varied in the early morning hours.
"Who would think we'd be having lunch out in front of The Times," Mr. Nardone said.
Mr. Nardone and his co-workers said they felt a hint of nostalgia about the paper emerging from the heart of the city each night, even with all the traffic tie-ups and blaring horns. The company is constructing a new printing plant in College Point, Queens, which is to open next year, replacing the presses in the 43d Street building.
"It's an era that's ending," said Bob Brown, a packaging supervisor.
But yesterday, the life of the paper and the life of the city swirled together. A couple visiting from Italy strolled by and snapped some pictures. Orlando Godoy, a bank employee wandering around on his lunch hour, said the music caught his attention and "I stayed for the whole show." And Sharon Cullen, who works at a nearby single-room-occupancy residential hotel, said she was standing just outside the police barricades hoping a spare box lunch would come her way. Just then, a piece of a cake depicting a front page of The Times was handed her.
As things happen in the city, a man with a saxophone happened to be walking by as the picnic was in full swing. He listened for a while, then took his instrument out of his case and sat in with the four-piece band for a round of "Basin Street Blues." He took his applause, packed up his sax and wandered off.
"This is New York," said Bob Leive, the band's cornet player. "Isn't this lovely?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: West 43d Street from Broadway to Eighth Avenue was renamed Adolph S. Ochs Street yesterday at a ceremony marking the century since Mr. Ochs took over The New York Times. As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani applauded, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times, handed Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the Times Company chairman, a box of stationery with the new address. (Paula Giannini/The New York Times)
