HEADLINE: A Jazz Club, A Lingerie Shop And the Gap Vie For Harlem Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
For Melba Wilson, a Harlem restaurateur, it means a chance to resurrect Minton's Playhouse jazz club, where be-bop was born. For John Bolt, manager of the Dyckman Street Marina, it could mean 105 new boat slips at the northern tip of Manhattan.
And for the Gap, the clothing store chain based in San Francisco, it opens a tantalizing new market. "We think Harlem is retailing's best-kept secret," said Beverly Butler, a Gap spokeswoman. 
 Such are the attitudes of three of the early contenders for funds from one of New York City's largest and most eagerly awaited economic development programs in decades, the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, in which more than $250 million is to be distributed to businesses and not-for-profit social service organizations over the next 10 years.
The first applications for the program, which was nearly killed in a bitter stand-off between economic advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, were due on Friday. Applications can be submitted each quarter. Officials said yesterday that they had counted 188 applications, requesting a total of $185 million of the city, state and Federal funds.
"We are flooded," said Deborah C. Wright, the former City Housing Commissioner who was hired a year ago to be the zone's director. Among the applications were proposals for a broad spectrum of new businesses and service organizations, ranging from a small lingerie store that wants $20,000 in government loans to Harlem U.S.A., a huge retail complex for 125th Street that would include outlets of the Gap and the Disney Store. It wants $11.2 million.
According to several officials involved in the zone, other large applications are expected soon from such companies as Greyhound Lines Inc., which hopes to operate an employee training center in Harlem, and the Sony Corporation, which with a company owned by Magic Johnson wants to build a movie house with 20 or more screens.
"We've got entrepreneurs competing with each other, and it's the most exciting thing I've ever seen," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat who sponsored legislation in 1994 that led to the creation of empowerment zones in six cities, including New York.
Despite the enthusiasm of the entrepreneurs and business owners, the birth of the empowerment zone has not occurred without complications. The loans and grants that the businesses are seeking have already been delayed for more than a year because of the squabble between the aides to the Mayor and the Governor, both Republicans who had inherited the program from their Democratic predecessors.
In addition, tensions have persisted among factions of Harlem's civic leaders, some of whom chafe at the idea of outside business interests -- particularly those not owned by blacks -- moving into Harlem.
"There is a weird combination of arrogance, distrust and fear of gentrification," Ms. Wright said. "People have got to get beyond that attitude, because it has hurt everything uptown."
The program is also being created after a legacy of failed efforts to bring economic renewal to Harlem. One of the neighborhood's most celebrated economic development proposals, the Harlem International Trade Center, was abandoned in 1994 after nearly a decade of futile efforts to attract private investment, despite the promise of large government grants.
And few merchants who are considering investments in Harlem can forget the 1995 firebombing of Freddy's, a clothing store on 125th Street owned by a Jewish retailer who wanted to expand his business into space leased by a black-owned record store. The incident underscored the deep mistrust by some Harlem residents of outside investment.
But even without the empowerment zone, experts say the tide of business investment in Harlem is about to turn. Some suggest that the political battles and the delays they have produced may even have enhanced the zone's prospects, because it is starting at a time when many retailers have begun to recognize the commercial potential of Harlem.
"The timing is fortuitous" said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. He said interest in Harlem had been heightened, particularly among retailers, because of the sharp decline in crime and recent investments by some chain stores and other big retailers -- like Blockbuster Video and Fairway Market -- that had been conspicuously absent from the neighborhood.
In another widely expected boost for retailing in the neighborhood, a not-for-profit development group said yesterday that it had completed a financing agreement, including a $1.5 million loan from New York State, to build a new Pathmark supermarket on 125th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues.
"To tell you the truth, we'd be looking at Harlem even without the empowerment zone," said Keith Emerson, vice president of Ecomat Inc., a four-year-old chain of cleaners based on West 72d Street in Manhattan that applied on Friday for $300,000 in loans or grants from the empowerment zone funds.
Ecomat, which uses a European cleaning process that it says is less damaging to the environment than dry cleaning, said it wanted to open a training center and a cleaning outlet, and chose Harlem because of its large number of workers.
Despite the many applications that were submitted before the Friday deadline, Ms. Wright said most would be summarily rejected because they did not provide enough information about their business plans or simply proposed ideas that were unacceptable.
Although Ms. Wright said applicants would be subjected to stringent review, the zone has been set up to allow broad discretion in the types of businesses and service organizations it can assist. It can also dispense Government money in the form of low-interest loans, outright grants or more complicated financing plans involving the sale of stocks.
A quick review of the submissions that was made over the weekend suggested that only about 20 percent would receive serious consideration, she said.
Those that are considered must first be approved by the Upper Manhattan Zone's 23-member board, including business executives, members of the clergy and civic leaders. Then, recommendations of that board must be approved by a larger New York City Empowerment Zone board, including representatives of the Mayor, the Governor and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Renewal.
The larger New York City board will also preside over a separate empowerment zone in sections of the South Bronx. That zone, created by the same Federal, city and state agreement responsible for the upper Manhattan zone, has not yet sought its first applications.
Although most of the applications received by the deadline were for businesses or social service organizations in Harlem, others extended to the northern border of the zone in Inwood.
"People up here have just as much right to good quality food, clothing stores and recreation as anyone in Manhattan," said Mr. Bolt, one of six partners who in 1990 opened the Dyckman Street Marina on decrepit city-owned waterfront property with a 20-year lease from the Department of Parks and Recreation.
He said his group hopes the empowerment zone will approve $2 million in loans or grants to expand a small snack bar at the marina, and increase the number of its boat slips to 127 from 22.
Although the empowerment zone clearly has an economic motive, at least one of the proposals would help revive a bit of the neighborhood's history. Ms. Wilson, the restaurateur, and two partners -- the actor Robert De Niro and Drew Nieporent, who operates the TriBeCa Grill and several other restaurants -- have been working for more than two years to attract other private investors to restore and reopen Minton's Playhouse, at 118th Street and Seventh Avenue, a treasured jazz institution where Charlie Parker and others created be-bop and other jazz forms in the 1940's and 1950's. It closed in 1974.
"Harlem has always been rich in culture, and to bring some of it back would be a dream come true," said Ms. Wilson, whose group applied for $300,000 from the zone to help renovate the Minton's building.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Many Drawn to Harlem Program
One of New York City's largest and most eagerly awaited economic development programs in decades, the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, has received a torrent of applications from entrepreneurs, officials said. Under the program, more than $250 million in city, state and Federal funds are to be distributed to businesses and nonprofit social service organizations over the next 10 years. The program was nearly killed in a bitter standoff between economic advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki. Officials overseeing the program said they had received 188 applications, requesting a total of $185 million in government aid. [Page B1.]
 
Round Two: Man vs. Machine
Rivalries demand rematches, and here comes another one: Garry Kasparov-Deep Blue, the world chess champion vs. the world's most accomplished chess computer. Mr. Kasparov and International Business Machines, the creators of Deep Blue, have announced a second six-game match May 3 to 10 at the Millennium Hotel. The $1.1 million prize fund will be put up by I.B.M., perhaps a measure of the company's confidence, with $700,000 earmarked for the winner. In February, Mr. Kasparov beat Deep Blue, 4-2, in a landmark six-game series. [B1.]
 
A Renewed Call for Justice
Five years to the day after a Hasidic Jew was fatally stabbed during racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the streets are no doubt quieter. But the killing continues to reverberate through the city, and yesterday -- the anniversary of the attack -- some of New York's top political leaders returned to the scene of the killing, saying that justice still had not been achieved. [B1.]
 
A New Name on the Block
On the 100th anniversary of the first issue of The New York Times published under the ownership of Adolph S. Ochs, the newspaper took over the street with a box-lunch picnic for 2,000 employees, a four-piece Dixieland jazz band and a ceremony in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani renamed the block Adolph S. Ochs Street. The street-naming ceremony and picnic were the latest events marking the 100 years that the paper has been controlled by Mr. Ochs and his descendants, the Sulzberger family. [B3.]
 
Federal prosecutors widened their drug case against the Manhattan nightclub owner Peter Gatien, adding cocaine distribution charges to an earlier indictment, and arresting two of his top aides, including the general manager of his largest club, the Tunnel. [B3.]
 
A Pennsylvania teen-ager was still missing after she failed to return to her father at the 27th Woodstock anniversary celebration in Bethel, N.Y., last week, the New York State police said. And officials reported two deaths in connection with a concert in Plattsburgh. [B2.]
 
REGION
 
Jet's Center Section Sought
They have the cockpit. They have the baggage containers. They have all four engines, most of the right wing and thousands of fragments. What they don't have is the answer. And so the men and women investigating the downing of T.W.A. Flight 800 are intensifying their efforts to recover and examine the remains of the jumbo jet's center section. Somewhere in that section of the plane, investigators believe, is the epicenter of the explosion that broke the Boeing 747 into two pieces. The hope is that when the metal is finally pulled from the water and reassembled in a hangar, it will tell a story. [B4.]
 
Putting motorists' fingerprints on driver's licenses, as is done in California, would help in identifying disaster victims, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner told a County Legislature committee. [B4.]
 
Judge Assails Shelter Crowding
A State Supreme Court justice castigated city officials for what she called continued overcrowding and dangerous conditions at a bunkerlike housing intake center in the South Bronx, where homeless families with children come seeking shelter but often end up spending days sleeping on floors and chairs. Unless the city can prove by Thursday that it has improved conditions at the office by making more emergency housing available for homeless families, Justice Helen E. Freedman said that it must re-open a similar housing office in Manhattan to relieve the press of people. [B1.]
 
Grumpy Judge Faces Censure
A town justice who grumbled about having to get out of bed for an arraignment and used obscenities to describe the county sheriff should be censured, a state panel said. The recommendation from the panel, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, against Justice James McKevitt of Malta town court in Saratoga County now goes to the state's top court, the Court of Appeals. Judge McKevitt has 30 days to challenge the recommendation, which amounts to a public slap on the wrist. [B4.]
 
A man who pleaded guilty to robbing the mother of the accused Genovese crime boss Vincent Gigante was in a Manhattan courtroom to be sentenced to one and a half to three years. [B5.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Theme Park Is Planned
Just weeks after a Six Flags amusement park was proposed for southeastern Connecticut, another theme park company has announced plans to build a multimillion-dollar complex in the area. Fun-Plex America, a private company with offices in New Canaan, Conn., and New York City, and First H&M Corporation, a holding company, have reached a preliminary agreement to build the park, which would be housed in giant domes. [B4.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
POLL SHOWS DOLE SLICING AWAY LEAD CLINTON HAD HELD

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
After a week in the limelight at the Republican National Convention, Bob Dole has sliced President Clinton's lead in half, and more than twice as many people have a clear view of what he would do as President, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
But the survey, conducted after the convention ended, found that many are skeptical about his signature tax-cut proposal and remain sharply split in their opinion of Mr. Dole himself. 
 More broadly, the poll showed that after several politically turbulent days that included the rolling out of Mr. Dole's plan for a 15 percent tax cut, the selection of Jack Kemp as his running mate, the upbeat convention in San Diego and Ross Perot's nomination as the Reform Party's candidate, Mr. Clinton still stands solidly ahead of his opponents.
The survey of 1,138 adults nationwide, interviewed Friday through Sunday, found that 50 percent of registered voters surveyed said they would support Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore if the election were held today, while 39 percent favored Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp -- a gap of 11 points.
That represents a gain of five points for Mr. Dole and a loss of six points for Mr. Clinton compared with a Times/CBS News poll taken shortly before the convention. Both polls had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
It is common for candidates to leave their conventions with a significant "bounce" in the polls. But often such bursts of support are short lived. Four years ago, President George Bush enjoyed a momentary bump in the wake of his party's convention, but he fell behind several days later and never recovered.
Over the weekend, Mr. Dole's advisers touted a poll by Newsweek that showed the race was a virtual tie. But that survey included interviews on Thursday night, the peak of the convention, and may have reflected excitement from the convention that has since ebbed.
In fact, there were indications that Mr. Dole's bounce had already begun to shrink. On Friday night, the first day the Times/CBS poll was conducted, preliminary findings suggested that the race was a virtual tie. But by Saturday and Sunday, Mr. Clinton had bounced back into a commanding position. The President will have an even better opportunity to mold public opinion to his advantage because of the sustained coverage he will draw at the Democratic National Convention that opens on Monday in Chicago.
It was unclear from the findings how television coverage of the Republican convention affected the standings of Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton. Those who tuned in were disproportionately Republicans who were already predisposed to Mr. Dole -- and more likely to vote for him than Republicans who did not tune in. Among Republicans, 72 percent said they had watched some of the convention; as did 58 percent of Democrats, and 61 percent of independents.
But Mr. Dole did better among self-described independents who watched the convention than those who did not. Independents who watched were divided in their opinion of Mr. Dole, while those who did not were four times more likely to have an unfavorable opinion of Mr. Dole.
Among all voters, Mr. Dole is hardly a beloved politician. While he lowered his unfavorability ratings, his image is now split between favorable and unfavorable.
Fifty-four percent of respondents said Mr. Dole had made it clear what he wants to accomplish as President -- a jump of 30 points since the last Times/CBS poll. Yet of that group, only half said they planned to vote for Mr. Dole; 4 out of 10 are Clinton voters.
With Mr. Perot formally in the race, the survey found that he would take support about evenly from those who would otherwise support Mr. Dole and those who would favor Mr. Clinton. But at least for now, before his multimillion-dollar advertising campaign begins, Mr. Perot is nowhere near the 18.9 percent he won in his independent bid four years ago. Forty-nine percent of the respondents said that if the election were held today, they would back Mr. Clinton; 37 percent said Mr. Dole and 8 percent said Mr. Perot.
And as Mr. Perot has begun to re-emerge into public view, people hold an increasingly unfavorably view of him. His unfavorable rating stands at 59 percent, up from 48 percent in the poll taken just before the Republican convention.
After a week of prime-time attacks against him in San Diego, Mr. Clinton emerged largely, but not completely, unscathed. Fifty-one percent approve of the way Mr. Clinton is handling his job as President, just at the crucial 50 percent threshold that his advisers do not like him to sink below. That is down from 58 percent in the last poll, two weeks ago. Twenty-eight percent said Mr. Clinton has kept "hardly any" of his campaign promises from 1992; a five-point increase from the last poll. And while Mr. Clinton's rating on handling the economy was down 5 points, his rating on foreign policy -- which was not a central focus of attacks at the Republican convention -- was unchanged.
Each camp, of course, gave its own interpretation to the poll.
"Clearly, the trend is powerfully in the direction of Bob Dole, Jack Kemp and taxpayers who want a 15 percent tax cut," said Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's press secretary. "We have plenty to be happy about today -- and the Clinton campaign has plenty to be worried about."
Asked about Mr. Warfield's comment, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's senior adviser, broke out laughing. "The only people who should be worried by Senator Dole's bounce are those who depend on Medicare and Medicaid, because Dole's plan would decimate them." He dismissed Mr. Dole's gains as "the standard cotton-candy bounce."
To a significant extent, Mr. Dole is staking his candidacy on support for his proposal to cut taxes by 15 percent and balance the budget. At first blush, the notion of tax cuts is very popular, with 61 percent favoring the concept.
Dick Whitney, 63, a Dole supporter from Toledo, Ohio, who took part in the poll, said in a follow-up interview that he has become more excited about Mr. Dole. "I feel more strongly about him now because he was adrift," said Mr. Whitney, a retired manufacturer's representative. "He had no clear-cut direction. I like his ideas on the tax cut and balancing the budget."
But respondents leaning toward Mr. Clinton did not seem swayed by the tax plan. "Decreasing taxes by 15 percent is unrealistic," said Elise Roth, 27, a marketing-firm coordinator in Atlanta. "It would probably cut needed programs and increase the deficit. You have to pay taxes. That's reality."
Indeed, the danger for Mr. Dole is that the more they hear about the plan and its possible consequences, the less voters seem to like it. Only 22 percent said they would support the cut if it would mean increasing the Federal budget deficit.
And perhaps reflecting less on Mr. Dole than on voters' mistrust of politicians, only 38 percent said Mr. Dole actually would cut taxes if elected; 51 percent said he would not.
Even as Mr. Dole and leading Republicans have strenuously argued in the last two weeks that it is possible to balance the budget and cut taxes, a 53-percent majority said that it was not possible to do both. That reflects an increase of 9 points since the last poll.
Still, there may be room for Mr. Dole to sell his tax-cut plan. Asked whether Mr. Dole had explained enough specifics of the plan so that respondents understood what it meant for them and their families, 63 percent said no.
Mr. Dole's choice of Mr. Kemp, a former Congressman and Housing Secretary, was relatively well received, but it did not seem to make a significant difference in the Republican ticket's standing. Nineteen percent said that the choice of Mr. Kemp made them more likely to vote for Mr. Dole; but half of those people are Republicans, many of whom would probably back the ticket anyway.
Over all, 30 percent expressed a favorable opinion of Mr. Kemp, while 15 percent held an unfavorable view and 55 percent had no opinion of him at all.
James Hilty, 59, a retired botany professor from Knoxville, said he had positive feelings toward Mr. Kemp, but not enough to sway him from backing Mr. Clinton.
"I like him," Mr. Hilty said in a follow-up interview. "He's a straightforward, no-nonsense guy. I can't see him with Dole though. They're like two step-children, they don't fit together. But I don't know who would fit with Dole. He has honorable intentions, but I think he's too old for the job." He said he watched the convention but that he found it "easy to switch off" because it was "canned and corny."
But Mr. Whitney spoke highly of Mr. Kemp. "Choosing Kemp has influenced me -- he's not a weasel," he said. "He's got some definite ideas about how the Government should run and what course of action to take on taxes and the budget."
Still, the public is sharply divided over Mr. Dole. The 29 percent of voters who held a favorable opinion of Mr. Dole, a Kansan who retired from the Senate in June, were countered by 32 percent who expressed an unfavorable view.
Other Republican figures enjoyed a rise in popularity from the convention. Elizabeth Hanford Dole, who captured attention when she abandoned the rostrum and praised her husband's accomplishments from the floor of the hall, had a 10-point increase in her favorability ratings, to 39 points, since the last survey. Gen. Colin L. Powell's already impressive rating rose to 61 points, from 55 points. And after Nancy Reagan's tribute to her husband, former President Ronald Reagan's retrospective job approval rating rose to 64 points from 58 points.
The broad image of the Republican Party improved after a convention in which party leaders sought to convey the party as friendly and inclusive. In heartening news for Republican Congressional candidates, who were concerned that Mr. Dole's popularity could drag them down in November, the poll found voters split when asked which candidate they would support in House races. Only two weeks ago, the Democrats held a seven-point advantage.
The Republican Party also made modest improvements in its popularity. Fifty-two percent of voters expressed a favorable opinion of the Republican Party, up from 46 percent two weeks ago. But the Republicans were not entirely successful in turning around the party's image. While 65 percent said the Democratic Party welcomes people with different views on issues, only 45 percent said that of the Republicans.
And though the gap has narrowed somewhat in the last two weeks, public expectations of who will eventually win the White House still favor Mr. Clinton over Mr. Dole, 62 percent to 26 percent.
Even Republican supporters of Mr. Dole who were questioned in this survey acknowledged that he needs to work on his delivery. "Unfortunately he's not a performer like some of these other guys are," said Violet Savocchia, 73, a retired nurse from Elmwood Park, Ill. "He's a stoic individual, and he has had some trouble getting his message across. His word is his bond. I think he will try to cut taxes. And, believe me, 15 percent means a lot to me."
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Friday through Sunday with 1,138 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 856 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans or independents taken as a separate group.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR GAINS SENTENCING DELAY IN ARKANSAS TRIAL

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 19

 BODY:
A Federal District judge delayed sentencing for James B. McDougal in the Whitewater case today, suggesting that Mr. McDougal has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and that they hope he has information that will move the case forward.
Mr. McDougal, President and Mrs. Clinton's partner in the Whitewater real estate deal, had been scheduled for sentencing on fraud and conspiracy charges this afternoon before Judge George Howard Jr. But at midmorning he announced that the sentencing would be delayed until November. Judge Howard immediately imposed a gag order on Mr. McDougal, his lawyers and the prosecutors involved in the case. 
 A second defendant, former Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, was sentenced to probation and community service on related charges.
Neither Mr. McDougal nor his lawyer was at the courthouse today. But a person involved in the case said that Mr. McDougal agreed on Aug. 9 to cooperate with prosecutors and that the judge ordered a 90-day sentencing delay then. That order was sealed until today.
Mr. McDougal was a political ally and a business partner when Mr. Clinton was Governor of Arkansas in the 1980's. When the Whitewater matter became an issue in the 1992 Presidential race, Clinton campaign aides urged the garrulous Mr. McDougal not to talk to reporters.
Still, it is far from clear that he has anything damaging to say about the Clintons or that he would be a credible witness if he did. Before the gag order was imposed, lawyers in the case had speculated that he would be most valuable to prosecutors if he could provide documents to point them toward new investigative trails or bolster leads they were pursuing.
People who spoke on the condition of anonymity said a deal between Mr. McDougal and the prosecutors might involve information he could offer about loans for another land development that figures in the Whitewater case, Castle Grande. Mrs. Clinton, then a lawyer in Little Rock, did some legal work on the Castle Grande development, but the extent and nature of her involvement is a subject of much dispute.
Investigators found the Castle Grande deal to be riddled with fraud, but Mrs. Clinton has never been accused of any wrongdoing.
Citing the gag order, the chief Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, refused today to talk about Mr. McDougal. He said, "I am not confirming and I am not denying."
Mr. McDougal was convicted on 18 felony counts of conspiracy and fraud relating to Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, a savings association he owned. It failed in 1989 at a cost to taxpayers of more than $60 million. Some of the charges against him relate to a fraudulent loan that was used in part, prosecutors say, to pay expenses for the Whitewater land development. Mr. McDougal, his wife at the time and the Clintons were partners in that venture.
Fifteen of the counts carry a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. The remaining three counts carry a maximum sentence of two years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000.
Mr. Tucker's four years of probation includes 18 months under a modified form of house arrest. Under the house arrest, he would be allowed to leave home only for work, church or medical treatment. He was also ordered to give lectures on family, educational and social values at Arkansas high schools and junior high schools to pay a fine of $25,000 and restitution of nearly $300,000, including interest, to the Small Business Administration.
His voice trembling, Mr. Tucker, 53, pleaded for leniency today on the grounds of his health. He is on the waiting list for a liver transplant at the Mayo Clinic. Judge Howard acceded to his request, saying, "A sanction of prison would be as cruel as the grave." Mr. McDougal's former wife, Susan, is to be sentenced on Tuesday on four felony counts in the case. She faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000 on each of three of the counts against her, and two years in prison and a fine of $250,000 on the fourth count.
Prosecutors had pressed for the maximum sentence against Mr. Tucker, in hopes that a harsh sentence would encourage him and his two co-defendants to cooperate. Prosecutors appeared dumbfounded by Judge Howard's lenient sentencing. He had wide discretion in sentencing because the crimes were committed before the enactment of Federal sentencing guidelines.
The 230-acre development is in the Arkansas Ozarks at the juncture of Crooked Creek and the White River. Mr. McDougal dubbed it Whitewater.
There are mixed views on just how valuable Mr. McDougal would be to prosecutors. He has demonstrated that he has intimate knowledge of some of the Clintons' business dealings, including Mrs. Clinton's lucrative trading in commodity futures. In the late 1970's, she parlayed a $1,000 investment into nearly $100,000.
But Mr. McDougal proved dismal on the witness stand, offering occasionally inconsistent testimony.
He was the only one of the three defendants to take the stand and some jurors said after the trial that they would have acquitted him and his two co-defendants on many of the charges had they not heard his testimony.
Mr. McDougal suffered a mental breakdown in the 1980's. And his conviction on 18 felony counts goes to the heart of his credibility. Mr. Tucker, a Democrat who succeeded Mr. Clinton as Governor, has already announced that he would appeal his conviction, based on the fact that one of the jurors was married to a man whose 40-year sentence on a drug conviction Mr. Tucker refused to commute in 1992. Mr. Tucker, who is awaiting a liver transplant, is also facing a second criminal trial on charges that he evaded taxes and committed bankruptcy fraud.
Mr. Tucker, 53, resigned as Governor on July 15, and Lieut. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, was sworn in to complete the two and a half years remaining in the four-year term.
From the outset, it has been clear that Mr. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has been trying to follow a paper trail that he believes leads to Mr. Clinton. In the last week, speculation has turned to what part Mr. McDougal can play in keeping alive that investigation.
In 1994, prosecutors subpoenaed Mrs. Clinton's law records on Castle Grande, but were told that she had destroyed most of the records of her work in 1988. And she said that summaries of her bills on that and other accounts had vanished from the Rose firm during or after the 1992 Presidential elections.
Nearly two years after the first subpoena was issued for them, the records were turned over to investigators earlier this year. A White House aide said she had found the documents in August 1995 in the book room of the White House, a few paces from Mrs. Clinton's office.
The main prosecution witness in the Whitewater trial was David Hale, who had headed Capital Management Services, the federally backed company that made $300,000 in loans to Mrs. McDougal in 1986. He testified that he issued the $50,000 loan after Mr. Clinton requested it but insisted that his name not appear on any documents linked to the transaction. Mr. Hale also testified that Mr. McDougal had sought that loan and others to take care of the "political family" in Arkansas.
At the time the loan was made, Federal regulations permitted such loans only for economically disadvantaged borrowers, under a Federal program.
Mr. Hale is serving a 28-month prison term for two felony counts.
Mr. Clinton was not charged in the case, but he was compelled to testify as a witness for Mr. McDougal. During his two and a half hours of videotaped testimony, which was played for the nine women and three men on the jury on the last day of the trial, Mr. Clinton adamantly denied Mr. Hale's allegations.

HEADLINE: The Cassoulet Lacked One Ingredient

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
IT was the moment everyone dreams of. Lying on a beach in Martinique, George and Helen Studley, who had owned La Colombe d'Or, a New York fixture near Gramercy Park since 1976, turned to each other and laughed.
"You know that Belmondo movie when he robs a bank and escapes to the tropics?" Mr. Studley asks now, recalling the start of their fantasy retirement. "That was it. We had sold the restaurant. It was great." 
 That was in March 1994, when their memories of frozen pipes in the winters and no-show customers on the weekends were fading fast. They visited France: Paris, Avignon, Montpellier and Toulouse. They went, as Mrs. Studley says, "cassoulet hunting" for weeks on end.
They checked out Florida -- Key West and Vero Beach -- and even considered settling in Sarasota. At least, Mr. Studley considered it. Mrs. Studley was not so sure. "It really scared me there," she says. "Everyone looked the same. They all wore pink." The couple traveled to Scandinavia; she went to Greece and he sailed his boat off Shelter Island. They reveled in Oaxaca, Mexico, surrounded by mountains, where dinner for two was never more than $12.
But by March of this year, all roads to Shangri-La led back to 134 East 26th Street. The Studleys have retired from retirement, resuming ownership of La Colombe d'Or. Their choice was one part business, two parts emotion: when the business declined after their departure, they could have just as easily turned the restaurant over to new owners and continued -- blissfully -- on their wanderings. After all, they had waited a lifetime for the freedom to pursue, as Mr. Studley says, "Helen's idea that there's some kind of paradise."
But maybe, they figured, they had inadvertently left it behind. After all those weeks of tasting cassoulets, Mrs. Studley says, "we thought the ones we had produced here were the best."
Sitting in the restaurant's bar on a drab, rainy afternoon, they say they're convinced they made the right choice. Mr. Studley, 65, tall and stately with a trim white mustache, says: "I guess it was a challenge too sweet to turn down. One more time!" Mrs. Studley, who is slight and tightly wound, refuses to give her age, though she acknowledges collecting Social Security payments. She looks at her husband. "I think maybe you should also say you can only sail so much," she offers.
What happened, exactly? In 1994, the Studleys sold the restaurant to Wayne Nish, the celebrated chef at March who had got his start at La Colombe d'Or in 1988, and Joseph Scalice, a former Colombe d'Or general manager. The sale was, as Mr. Studley calls it, "an easy deal," with monthly payments rather than one down payment.
But recently, he says, as the restaurant started to falter, the payments came later and later. "There was no owner presence here," he says. "They had March and they had Team B handling this restaurant, with nobody at the door to welcome people. Whatever success we've had is that people like to see us here, a ma and pa restaurant scene."
Mr. Nish, responding in a telephone interview, says the reasons for the drop in business were more complicated, citing first the large number of companies in the area that moved or folded with the downturn in the economy, directly affecting the restaurant's lunch traffic.
"Also," he says, "between the time I left in 1990 to open March and came back to Colombe d'Or in 1994, there had been a huge proliferation of competition from the new restaurants on Park Avenue South. There must have been 22 new, larger places, all with models at the door.
"The concept we had agreed to maintain at Colombe d'Or, which was part of our deal, became dated in the face of that competition."
But isn't there still a place in New York for a restaurant that cooks classic dishes in a homey setting with no models at the door? Clark Wolf, a New York-based food and restaurant consultant who is not affiliated with Colombe d'Or, says yes. "The groovy thing doesn't always work," he notes. "Cutting edge can be critically successful and not a business. There will always be room for French style mom and pops. This town has loved them forever."
Mr. Studley says, "When you reopen a book on a restaurant you have a million options. I think we have to make some changes, but it really boils down to doing something that we know. It's in our blood, so to say."
The newly reopened Colombe d'Or has borrowed a concept from the hot Gramercy Tavern, serving prix fixe dinners in its dining room ($45 for four courses, $29 for three courses) and a lighter menu at the bar. Then there is a private dining room that seats up to 28. Already, Mr. Studley categorizes its business as "brisk."
"We know what we want to do," he says. "We need to give it time to prove itself one way or the other."
Unfortunately, no one told Corby Kummer, a restaurant reviewer for New York magazine, who visited La Colombe D'or twice in its first week of reopening on July 8. His review was negative, calling the food "surprisingly spotty" and the service "rude." But the Studleys were not thrown.
"He was right on 90 percent of the food," Mr. Studley concedes. "You have to work out the kinks -- you change it. The menu has changed since then. He was right about the maitre d' being rude, too. By the time the piece ran, he had been let go two weeks."
In addition to a new maitre d'hotel, Mrs. Studley is at the door five nights a week. Alexandra Studley, the couple's grown daughter, substitutes for her one night a week; by day she is a special events planner for Ark Restaurants. ("She started here as a hatcheck girl because we didn't have a baby sitter for her," Mrs. Studley says.) The Studleys' son, Jonathan, is a chef in Alaska.
The couple celebrated their 40th wedding anniversary in May; they first met in night school at City College. But they arrived in Manhattan by very different routes.
Mr. Studley was born to a Jewish family in Belgium. During World War II, he fled with his parents and older brother, Julien, now a real estate executive, "in an old Buick, with mattresses on the roof to guard against machine gun bullets, and we ended up in Nice for two years.
"We couldn't get American visas," he recalls, "so we bought Cuban visas and spent another two years in Havana, waiting." When the family moved to Manhattan in December 1943, Mr. Studley enrolled at the High School of Music and Art. After graduating he took courses at City College and became a travel agent. He saw his future wife again, by chance, in front of the New York Public Library in 1954. "This time it clicked," he says.
Mrs. Studley's journey to the library was a more painful one. She was born near Hamburg, Germany, also to a Jewish family. Her mother died when she was 6; her two older sisters left before the war. She stayed behind with her father, and a Christian family in Berlin hid them for two years.
"The first year, we never left the room, ever," she says. But as the bombing intensified and the building became too damaged to hide anyone, she pretended to go to school each morning, even joining a church choir. "I wanted to be a musician," she says, in a voice both small and tough. "They taught me to play the organ. But I got caught. Somebody recognized me. It was 1944, when theoretically there were no more Jews around." She was transported to Auschwitz. Her father had no idea where she was, whether she was alive or dead.
"But the good part," Mrs. Studley says, "is that it was only a year. There was no way to survive more. I found my father after the war, from a posting on a bulletin board." Shifting in her seat, she tries turning the conversation back to something manageable and almost succeeds. "Sometimes, when I say to the waiter, 'Give me water without the ice,' I can't believe I'm saying that," she says. Her smile covers the bottom of her face, completely missing her bright eyes, suddenly sunken and black.
After the war, she and her father came to New York to join her married sisters. "I hadn't gone to school from the age of 12," she says, "and I was determined to go. I also had to work, and I didn't speak English." She got a part-time office job in the mornings, studied piano in the afternoons and went to school in the evenings. After attending City College, she graduated from Hunter College, married Mr. Studley in 1956, had her children and wrote about music on a freelance basis. "But I really didn't like the idea of staying home," she says. "The minute I got my citizenship, I went back to Europe and traveled. Then I went into the travel business. I still had my agency when we opened the restaurant in 1976."
Mr. Studley smiles gently. "Our careers are such a reaction to the war," he notes. "We couldn't eat and we couldn't travel."
Mr. Studley gave up his own travel career shortly after his marriage and joined his brother's real estate firm. After the couple took a year's sabbatical in Provence in the early 1970's, they decided to give their own restaurant a try. "We knew what we didn't like about New York restaurants and could do differently," he says. "We wanted to do it from the consumer's point of view, starting a restaurant from table height."
They both look up as a young Evian deliveryman saunters into the bar, his long hair falling across his eyes. When his receipt has been signed, he turns to go. "Au revoir," he declares in an atrocious accent. The Studleys wave, amused.
"We're really doing what we want to do now," she says. "It's so delicious." He adds, "As complicated as it is to get a restaurant going, once it is you can take days off."
She nods. "We'll travel again for sure," she says, though she is also busy writing her memoirs, having recently published "Life of a Restaurant: Tales and Recipes from La Colombe d'Or" (Crown).
"When we sold the restaurant, I thought I'd literally fall off a cliff," she says. "It was so much a part of me. Then, I had a rather good time. We went to concerts together. If the weather was horrible, we could stay home. Things normal people do.
"But when George said we had the restaurant back, there was no question we wouldn't do it together. I guess I was intrigued by it, too. I never felt I was sacrificing something." She glances sideways at her husband. "Which I would have felt if we had moved to Florida."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches 4-Week High Against Yen on Rate Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit a four-week high against the yen yesterday after a Bank of Japan report suggested that interest rates would stay low and a top Japanese official said that a weaker yen would not hurt the country's economy.
The dollar ended slightly higher against the mark and little changed against other currencies, steadied by a Bundesbank report that showed German money supply growth in July fell to an 8.6 percent rate from 9.6 percent in June. 
 That report bolstered the view that the German central bank might move to reduce interest rates at its council meeting tomorrow to stimulate the economy without fear of aggravating inflation. Lower interest rates in Germany would diminish the demand for marks.
There was little reaction in the currency market after the Federal Reserve, as expected, left interest rates unchanged yesterday.
In late trading in New York, the dollar stood at 108.35 yen, up from 107.81 yen on Monday. The dollar traded at 1.4885 marks, up from 1.4872 marks. The British pound edged up to $1.5475 from $1.5450.
The dollar started strengthening against the yen overnight after the Japanese Finance Ministry's top currency policy maker, Eisuke Sakakibara, was quoted in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the country's leading financial newspaper, as saying that the Japanese economy would not suffer if the dollar were worth 110 yen or more. Mr. Sakakibara is known for his ability to influence exchange rates.
"There was yen-selling across the board today after that," said Thomas Arnold, a trader at the New York branch of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd.
The yen was also weakened by a Bank of Japan annual review of the economy for the fiscal year ended March 31, which said the pace of recovery from a prolonged slump was likely to remain modest compared with past recoveries.
The report dampened expectations that Japanese interest rates would rise before the end of the year.
"A lot of people who have expected the Bank of Japan to raise rates down the road now think they won't raise rates until next year," said Jeffrey Yu, a senior dealer at the New York branch of Sanwa Bank.
Others said the yen weakened on the narrowing Japanese trade surplus with the United States.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Who Lost Turkey?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Frank Rich is on vacation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Not "Who lost Russia?" Not "Who lost Bosnia?" Not "Who lost China?" Not "Who lost Saudi Arabia?" No, the most heated foreign policy debate this election might turn out to be: "Who lost Turkey?"
Turkey's new Islamist Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, signed a $23 billion deal with Iran last week calling for construction of a natural-gas pipeline between the two countries and a long-term contract for Iran to keep that pipeline flowing with gas. Such a deal with Iran by a NATO ally, coming just after President Clinton signed a bill sanctioning any country making new energy investments in Iran, amounts to a direct challenge to the Clinton policy of containing Teheran. And Mr. Erbakan's call for a Turkey-Iran-Iraq-Syria summit meeting to deal with the Kurdish problem challenges the Clinton policy of containing Iraq as well. Suddenly Turkey's Government, a longtime pillar of U.S. policy at the crossroads of Asia and Europe, is becoming, under Mr. Erbakan, an unreliable ally at best and a threat to U.S. interests at worst. 
 "Erbakan's visit to Iran had a sort of finger-in-the-U.S.-eye aspect to it," says Richard N. Perle, a former Pentagon official and Dole foreign policy adviser. "But it was a result of the fact that the pro-U.S. faction inside Turkey has been shamed into silence, because of the indifference with which the Clinton Administration has treated Turkey. The Congress has not been helpful either, but previous Administrations fought for Turkey's interests in Congress in a way this Administration has not. I don't see Dole giving a major foreign policy speech without mentioning how Turkey has been mishandled."
But the looming "Who lost Turkey?" debate is more complicated than just Clinton Administration indifference. At least part of the blame for Turkey's drift away from Washington has to be placed at the doorstep of the Bush Administration for the way it ended the gulf war -- with Saddam Hussein left in power. With Saddam alive and well in Baghdad, the U.S. was forced to set up a no-fly zone over northern Iraq, to protect Iraq's Kurdish minority from further abuse by the Iraqi dictator. The only way the U.S. could enforce that protection was by flying fighter planes out of Turkey's nearby Incirlik air base. This became known as "Operation Provide Comfort." It was supposed to be temporary but has lasted five years, because Saddam is still in power. The Turks hate Provide Comfort. It costs them money, because they can't trade with Iraq, and it has left a power vacuum in northern Iraq in which Turkey's Kurdish opponents can operate.
One reason the Clinton team initially took a tolerant line toward Mr. Erbakan was that, like the Bush team, it was obsessed with winning Turkey's support for another six-month extension of Provide Comfort. Mr. Erbakan seems to have misread this friendly initial overture from the Clinton Administration and thought that if he just renewed Provide Comfort, he could get away with everything else. So he extended Provide Comfort and then followed it up with his overtures to Iran and Iraq.
Also, no one has played a bigger role in losing Turkey than Turkey's own greedy, cynical, myopic political elite. Mr. Erbakan won only 21 percent of the vote. The only reason he is in power is that Turkey's secular politicians, representing the other 79 percent, wouldn't work together.
Finally, the Clinton Administration did not lose Turkey. It never found it. Secretary of State Warren Christopher has spent virtually no time in Turkey in four years. Turkey was taken for granted.
If Mr. Erbakan continues with his present policies, either the global economy, to which Turkey is intimately linked, or the Turkish Army could depose him. Standard & Poor's, the global credit-rating agency, is already threatening to downgrade Turkey's credit rating, which would boost inflation and interest rates even further; the I.M.F. just canceled a visit to Turkey; and the Turkish Army just forced Mr. Erbakan to move ahead on a military cooperation deal with Israel. If the Turkish Army does step in, though, or if the Turkish lira goes into a tailspin, things are going to get very messy.
And if that happens, there is only one thing you can be sure of: No matter who is at fault, the U.S. will be blamed. So pull up a chair, get yourself a scorecard and choose up sides. The "Who lost Turkey?" debate may be just around the corner.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: AT DINNER WITH: Kweisi Mfume;
Not How You Start, But How You Finish

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
KWEISI MFUME was running late for a dinner meeting.
Rushing off to appointments, to airports, to hotels and to new challenges has been standard for Mr. Mfume, the president since February of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, America's oldest civil-rights organization, which is trying to regain its pre-eminence. 
 But running late is a rarity in the repertory of polish, poise and exactitude of Mr. Mfume, the former representative from Maryland.
Yet, the dinner bread at Cafe Centro, a stylish bistro in midtown Manhattan, was getting cold.
Both elegant and eloquent, Kweisi Mfume (pronounced kwah-EE-see oom-FOO-may) is, by all accounts, appearances and accomplishments, an intensely serious man. His compact frame, his boxer's carriage, the lionlike set of his jaw suggest no nonsense. The name, which he adopted as a young man in Baltimore, means "conquering son of kings" in a Ghanaian language.
Mr. Mfume, the former globe-trotting chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, counts among his friends political figures ranging from Nelson Mandela to Jack Kemp.
(He holds no grudge against Bob Dole, who spurned his invitation to speak at the N.A.A.C.P.'s national convention in July. "I've been around the block too many times for that," he said.)
He threw his considerable influence behind Lani Guinier's nomination for Attorney General, even after President Clinton withdrew her name.
And despite the reluctance of many well-known African-Americans to participate in Louis Farrakhan's Million Man March last October, Mr. Mfume attended with three of his five grown sons. He gave a speech that day on the Mall.
"Everyone said: 'It was Louis Farrakhan's march. How could you go?' " Mr. Mfume recalled this week. "I said: 'If he's got a million legs, then it is his march. If he doesn't, I'm going.' "
His voice was low and tired when he arrived for dinner. For most of the previous eight hours, Mr. Mfume had been ensconced in a cramped studio on East 43d Street, recording an audio version of "No Free Ride: From the Mean Streets to the Mainstream" (One World/Ballantine Books). The demands of recording the book in a single day delayed his dinner plans more than an hour.
With the publication of "No Free Ride," his first book, much of his week was a rush of breakfast meetings, television and radio interviews and book signings. Mr. Mfume, a former radio disk jockey, Baltimore City Councilman and five-term Democratic Congressman, found himself facing another challenge in promoting and explaining his 373-page memoir, which was written with Ron Stodgill 2d, a journalist on the staff of Business Week.
The book offers an intimate look into Mr. Mfume's journey through poverty, pathology and, finally, power. It is especially frank in portraying someone who can seem at times ill at ease talking about his past.
The book tells of Frizzell Gray, as Mr. Mfume began life on Oct. 24, 1948, born in Turners Corner, Md., a black community literally on the other side of the railroad tracks from white Baltimore. There was an abusive stepfather, Clifton Gray, a hulking man who for years drifted, like thunder, in and out of Frizzell's life. Shortly after one brutal confrontation, in which Frizzell, then 11, attempted to protect his mother from the man, whom he long believed to be his father, Clifton Gray disappeared.
The family of five (Mr. Mfume has three younger sisters) soon moved to West Baltimore. And Frizzell, a small boy known as Pee Wee, drew even closer to his mother, Mary Gray, whom he describes as a spiritual and hard-working woman who raised him well.
But by his mid-teens, his mother told him that she was dying of cancer. When he was 16, she died in his arms, and his life plunged into despair, confusion and anger.
A short time later, he and his sisters were split up, sent to relatives to live. He had little choice but to live with two bachelor uncles who, he writes in the book, could hardly take care of themselves.
The next thing he knew, Mr. Mfume said, he was a fixture on the mean streets of West Baltimore: hanging out, drinking wine, smoking marijuana, shooting craps, carrying a pistol and running in a gang. He dropped out of the 10th grade and developed a coveted street reputation for "being crazy."
By the time he was 22, this man, who at 14 lost his virginity to two prostitutes he befriended on the way to school, had fathered five children out of wedlock by four women.
But his transformation is the soul of his story, Mr. Mfume says. It is the reason he carved 18 months out of his workaholic life to write it.
"The book is about obstacles, and obstacles are part of every generation," he said, as he settled behind a tiered serving tray of broiled lobster, shrimp, scallops and oysters on the half shell. "This book is about triumph. My hope is that young people will read it and recognize one very basic and simple lesson that goes throughout the writing of the book, and that is that it is not how you start in life that counts, but rather it's how you finish."
Today, he lives alone in a house just outside Baltimore. Mr. Mfume says he is especially close to his sons, Donald, Kevin, Keith, Michael and Ronald. But he is chiefly driven, he says, by a keen appreciation of the woes of America's poor and most troubled, coupled with an understanding that his time on earth will never be long enough for him to help all of those he believes he must help. So he routinely pushes a schedule as heavy as Sisyphus's rock.
"Life is a very short commodity," Mr. Mfume said. "I had people come and go in my life, whose lives were claimed in one way or the other."
As a result, he said, "that gave me the sense of the fragility of life." He continued: "I love and appreciate the past because it keeps me rooted in who I am today. But most of my energy is devoted to the future and what I can do to have an impact on that future, to change, to shape it."
One of the things Mr. Mfume says he most wants to change and shape is the gut belief by many young Americans -- black, white and Latino -- that the future is bleak because the larger society does not offer them much hope and opportunity. To that larger society he said: "You can't create within a subculture a people that you have written off and expect that you will never encounter them. Why condemn yourself to the fate of potentially having to be the victims of their anger when you can try to do something about it?"
One of the key goals for the N.A.A.C.P. is to attract young people, Mr. Mfume says, especially those between 18 and 24. The association, he says, will emphasize educational excellence, economic opportunity and values for the young, to whom he wants to give hope.
He remembers the time when he had little of it, when he was a regular in Baltimore at the rundown intersection of Laurens and Division Streets, which his buddies called Hankin's Corner for the seedy liquor store that dominated the lives of the young men who stood around it.
"I had sunk about far as you could go," Mr. Mfume said. Then on a summer evening in 1972, one that he said started no differently from many others, he was gripped in an explosion of epiphany.
Without explanation, then or now, he said he went into some "kind of trance that said to me that death was very, very near." He said he sensed his mother's presence and the hard-work values that she and a handful of male mentors had instilled in him as a boy.
He knew, he said, that "if I did not change from that point on, I would never have a chance to do it again."
He left the gang, earning the scorn of its members and months of beatings. He worked several jobs -- including operating a machine that sliced bread in a commercial bakery -- to pay for tutoring that helped him get a high school equivalency diploma. After starting in a Baltimore community college, he transferred to Morgan State University, a black school, where he developed a militant student voice. In 1976, Mr. Mfume graduated magna cum laude with a bachelor's degree in urban planning.
Next, he tackled Johns Hopkins University, where he received a master's degree in liberal arts with a focus on international studies.
Along the way he worked as a disk jockey for WEBB-AM, a Baltimore station owned by the entertainer James Brown, who often did not appreciate the young Mr. Mfume's giving his political views on the air.
In 1979 Mr. Mfume, a popular figure in black Baltimore, ran for the City Council, winning by a mere 3 of the almost 12,000 votes cast. Then to Congress in 1986.
His transformation doesn't surprise him. "You can't run too far from your root," he said. "You always find it gnawing at you and pulling at you until you do what you ought to do in terms of living out the true meaning of your creed."
Supporters say that he was chosen for the N.A.A.C.P. for his history as a leader and strategist. He inherited the organization's $3.2 million debt, which he said is already down to $800,000, and he expects it to be eliminated by the fall. Asked at a book signing on the Upper West Side on Monday night how he felt about leaving Congress for the N.A.A.C.P., he said, "I feel more optimistic and hopeful and energized about what I can do outside of it.
"My mother always taught me that when God closes one door he opens another, so as I walk through this, with all the uncertainty that it brings with it, I know things will, in the end, work out just right."
Diamond Jim Sears, a mentor from his radio days, says he is amazed at Mr. Mfume's success. "We had no idea he was going to be where he is," he said. "When I see him speaking, I think of it as nothing less than a miracle. Have mercy."

HEADLINE: U.S. May Halt Sale of Jets To Indonesia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, which has agreed to sell Indonesia at least nine F-16 fighter jets, is now debating whether to delay or cancel the sale as a response to a serious crackdown on political dissent.
Human rights officials in the Government and some prominent members of Congress think the sale should not go forward while President Suharto of Indonesia and his Government are raiding the headquarters of legal opposition parties, trying to replace the leadership of another party and arresting as many as 250 political activists, human-rights workers and labororganizers. 
 "It would be an unhelpful signal when Indonesia is engaged in a fairly major crackdown, which we believe to be widening, to send them fighter planes, and it will be sensitive on the Hill," a senior Administration official said.
The Administration will have to make its decision by about Labor Day if it hopes sell the planes this year, because Congress adjourns in October for the elections. Congress traditionally gets a 30-day notice of major arms sales.
A few days ago, Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, wrote to Secretary of State Warren Christopher opposing the sale now because of violations of human and political rights. Administration officials concede that Congressional opposition will grow when legislators return to Washington from the current recess, and though the sale could be pushed through, it would require a considerable expense of political capital.
Other officials, including some at the National Security Council, want to go ahead with the sale, estimated to be worth $200 million. They say they fear that to delay the sale would be to kill it, that Indonesia is likely to buy more of the planes later and that F-16's are not the sort of weapons used to repress dissent.
Maintaining good relations with energy-rich Indonesia is one reason to go ahead with the sale, but the planes' role in relations with Pakistan may be even more important, in large part because of President Clinton's promise to Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto last year to solve an embarrassing quandary.
The nine planes had orginally been part of a package of weaponry promised to Pakistan, which bought and paid for more than $1 billion worth of military equipment -- including $650 million for a total of 28 F-16's. But the transaction was put on hold in 1990, when Senator Larry Pressler of South Dakota put through an amendment that bars direct economic aid and sales of military equipment so long as the White House cannot certify that Pakistan does not possess nuclear weapons.
Mrs. Bhutto demanded that Washington either deliver the equipment or refund the money. Last April, President Clinton decided to deliver some equipment and repay some of the money. But Congress insisted that the F-16's could not be delivered, and the Administration has been trying to sell them to another country, and then give Pakistan the proceeds.
The Administration finally succeeded in finding a buyer in Indonesia, whose Southeast Asian neighbors, including Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, all have F-16's or equivalent planes. Indonesia, which has eight F-16's, wants the nine more with modernized avionics and some spare engines, parts and technical support, according to the U.S. Naval Institute Military Database. Indonesian officials say they are considering buying even more of the planes.
The sale was essentially finalized last month during the meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Jakarta, which Mr. Christopher attended, though there have been some final negotiations about price, American officials say.
The United States has formally criticized the Indonesian crackdown and urged Jakarta to allow access to arrested individuals by independent human rights monitors and to account for those people who have been reported missing and presumed arrested. The Indonesian Government maneuvered last month to oust Megawati Sukarnoputri, daughter of the country's first President, Sukarno, as head of a political party, which sparked rioting on July 27.
The police have since questioned her, and have arrested Budiman Sudjatmiko, 27, the leader of a small radical workers' party, for subversion, a capital crime. On Friday, Mr. Suharto linked the new unrest to the revival of Communism, evoking memories of a blood bath in 1965, when at least 500,000 people were killed and the powerful Indonesian Communist Party was crushed.
Opposition leaders say the unrest expresses dissatisfaction with poverty, corruption, nepotism and lack of political freedom, and that Mr. Suharto is nervous about succession. Elections are expected in mid-1997.

HEADLINE: Tuition Prepayment Gains Favor as College Costs Skyrocket

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Their 1-year-old granddaughter was in diapers when Marilyn McKinney and her husband paid $7,000 under Michigan's pioneering prepaid college tuition program.
The state-run program let the couple pay tuition and fees for their daughter's entire college education at 1980's prices. The amount -- which was discounted depending on a child's age -- was their hedge against inflation and the rising cost of tuition. In the past school year, tuition and fees at a Michigan public state college would have cost an average of $3,789. 
 "She's 9 now. We've had it eight years," said Mrs. McKinney, assistant admissions director at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor.
Prepaid tuition plans, an option for nearly 10 years, are continuing to grow in popularity among parents and grandparents seeking relief from skyrocketing college costs. In 1995, only seven states -- Alabama, Alaska, Florida, Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wyoming -- offered the service. Now two more, Texas and Massachusetts, do, too. In addition, because of recent action by Congress and the Internal Revenue Service, a dozen other states are considering joining them.
At the same time, individual colleges and universities like the University of Virginia and Michigan State University are offering parents guarantees that tuition will not rise faster than inflation. Still other institutions, like the State University of New York, offer three-year accelerated degree programs so students can finish college early and save money.
States began to set up prepaid tuition programs in the 1980's as a result of parents' anxiety about tuition, said David Longanecker, assistant secretary for postsecondary education in the Education Department.
According to the College Board, tuition has risen 6 percent to 8 percent over the last three years at four-year public colleges.
"I'm glad we have the plans," Mr. Longanecker said. "I'm sorry we need them."
Although it is difficult to determine how many people are taking advantage of these plans, one expert last summer estimated that more than 400,000 American families were already enrolled in such plans. Florida has one of the largest programs in the nation with more than 300,000 participants this year.
Among the key components of the plans:
*In some state-run programs, parents can prepay tuition in a lump sum, or in installments. Some cover just tuition and fees while others include room and board. Prepayment, however, does not guarantee admission.
*If a child does not go to college, the money often can be transferred to a sibling, or refunded.
*Some state programs require that students attend public colleges and universities within the state. In others, students can use the tuition money at any public or private school in the nation.
*Prepayments made to the programs are invested, and the money is used to cover future tuition hikes. So far, the plans have been able to earn enough investment income to cover rises in inflation and tuition and fees on American campuses, said Bill Montjoy, executive director of Florida's prepaid tuition program.The states, Mr. Montjoy said, typically charge application fees, but generally do not charge annual administrative fees.
In 1986, Michigan became the first state to pass a law setting up a prepaid tuition program. But the program landed in litigation when the I.R.S. ruled that the investment income could be taxed.
A Federal judge sided with the I.R.S., but the state appealed. An appellate court ruled in 1994 that Michigan's program was not required to pay Federal income tax.
Other states, however, continued to worry. Their misgivings were fueled by I.R.S. discussion of rules that would have forced participating parents to pay taxes on their investment income. The I.R.S. recently decided to exempt them.
And in Congress, Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, pushed legislation to allow state prepaid programs to qualify for tax-exempt status. The provision was in the minimum-wage law that Congress passed this month.
In most states, students have to pay state taxes on the interest when they begin to use the money for college. Students, however, typically are in lower tax brackets than their parents, so the family still saves on taxes.
Of course, a lot can happen between the years of tricycles and the time of caps and gowns that can alter the potential usefulness of such investments.
James Connelly 3d and his wife, who live in Port Charlotte, Fla., enrolled their 4-year-old son, Jamie, in Florida's program when he was 6 months old.
The Connellys recently learned that their son is severely deaf, and they are no longer certain he will go to college. Even so, for now, they said, they will continue to tuck away $50 a month.

HEADLINE: Blue Chips Up; Broader Stock Indexes Ebb

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended higher yesterday as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged.
But the widely anticipated decision -- already cited as a catalyst for several recent rallies -- left other stock markets mixed in another sluggish summer session. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.82, to 5,721.26. It was the third consecutive gain for the blue-chip indicator, which has crept back within striking distance of its record high of 5,778.00, set on May 22.
The Dow was led by heavy-industry components like the chemical maker Du Pont and the Aluminum Company of America, which suffer the most when borrowing becomes more expensive, slowing spending on big purchases like housing and cars.
"The Fed's not going to raise interest rates," said Richard A. Dickson, a technical analyst at Scott & Stringfellow in Richmond, "so the economy can continue to cook along. All the cyclical stocks that got sold off can be bought again."
Broader market measures were lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.89 point, to 665.69. The Nasdaq composite index fell 6.24, to 1,124.67, its third straightloss. Trading volume was moderate.
A recent stream of tame economic readings had made yesterday's decision by the Federal Reserve a foregone conclusion for many investors, whose recovering confidence had already spurred a quick rebound from the bruising selloff last month. At that time, inflation jitters plagued the markets, making an interest-rate increase by the Fed seem likely.
Yesterday, advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly a 7-to-6 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 334.96 million shares. That was up from Monday's pace, the second slowest all year, but it was the ninth consecutive session in which volume was below 350 million shares.
The Nasdaq market was again the weakest, weighed down by technology shares, which have struggled to rebound as fully as the rest of the market from July's drop. "Investors remain skittish about the more volatile stocks," said Robert Streed, senior investment adviser at Northern Trust in Chicago. "I'm worried about tough earnings comparisons for technology stocks. There might be some disappointments out there."
Among its leading technology issues, Cisco Systems fell 1, to 55, and Intel lost 1 1/4, closing at 79 1/2.
HBO & Company, a maker of medical-industry software, tumbled 5 1/4, to 56 1/2, after Morgan Keegan began coverage of the stock with a rating of "underperform." Cheyenne Software fell 1 1/4, to 19, even after issuing a strong earnings report.
Griffin Gaming and Entertainment jumped 7 1/8, to 19 3/8, on news of its merger with Sun International Hotels. Sun International fell 3 5/8, to 48 1/8.
Tylan General rose 2 7/8, to 13 1/8. The company said it was putting itself up for sale, adding that it had received some inquiries from potential buyers.
First Data fell 3 1/2, to 77 3/8. Morgan Stanley trimmed its 1996 and 1997 earnings estimates for the company.
Tobacco stocks were mostly higher. Philip Morris rose 1 5/8, to 91 1/2, and RJR Nabisco Holdings slipped1/8, to 26 5/8.
In Mexico City, stocks soared to a new record after the Government's announcement of resumed economic growth last quarter. The main market index rose 77.12 points, or 2.32 percent, to close at 3,401.79.

HEADLINE: Clinton Signs a Bill Raising Minimum Wage by 90 Cents

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Ending a political battle Democrats had played to their advantage for months, President Clinton signed legislation today raising the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over the next year, saying the measure would give 10 million workers "a chance to raise stronger families and build better futures."
The increase will raise the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour, from $4.25, in two steps, the first being an increase of 50 cents an hour in paychecks effective Oct. 1, a month before Election Day. 
 Sounding a theme that will be central to his re-election campaign, Mr. Clinton said the increase was part of his Administration's record of improving conditions for working Americans.
"These 10 million Americans will become part of America's economic success story," Mr. Clinton declared at a ceremony on the South Lawn attended by labor leaders, Vice President Gore and a group of children of minimum-wage workers.
For a full-time worker earning the current minimum, the new law, when fully phased in with a 40-cents-an-hour increase on Sept. 1, 1997, will mean an annual raise of $1,800 before taxes, to $10,300.
Mr. Clinton used the occasion to credit his Administration with the creation of 10 million new jobs, a steep reduction in the Federal budget deficit and signs that a long period of wage stagnation is ending. The signing is the first of a series of events this week that he hopes will both burnish his Presidential image and emphasize his campaign message that he is the best protector of the economic interests of average Americans.
Mr. Clinton was also clearly seeking to give himself some political momentum in the days leading up to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next week. He is scheduled to sign legislation on Wednesday to improve access to health insurance, and he will sign the bill overhauling the welfare system later in the week, probably on Thursday.
Although the minimum-wage increase was largely the work of Democrats in Congress, the legislation also contained many provisions demanded by Republicans to help small businesses. Several Republican legislators were present at the ceremony. Mr. Clinton did not once mention his Republican challenger, Bob Dole, who as Senate majority leader opposed raising the minimum wage.
But he alluded to his campaign's strident criticisms of Mr. Dole's plan to slash taxes as fiscally irresponsible and a threat to Medicare and other politically sensitive programs.
"A minimum-wage increase, portable health care, pension security, welfare-to-work opportunities -- that's a plan that's putting America on the right track," Mr. Clinton said.
"Now we have to press forward," he said, "giving tax cuts for education and child rearing and child care, buying a first home, finishing that job of balancing the budget without violating our obligations to our parents and our children and the disabled and health care, to education and the environment and to our future."
The Dole campaign issued a statement calling the minimum-wage bill a "helpful, but small, step toward addressing the economic anxiety of American workers."
"Remember, a tax cut is a raise, and that is exactly what Bob Dole will give Americans," said Christina Martin, a spokeswoman for the Dole campaign. "Fair tax cuts, a balanced budget and spurred job growth will be the mainstays of a Dole Administration."
The minimum-wage legislation was among the most hotly debated bills of the current Congress, and one that for months seemed doomed by strong opposition from the Republican majority. Many Republicans argued that raising the minimum wage would destroy jobs by making it too expensive for employers, especially small-business owners, to keep on as many workers.
But the wage increase won overwhelming public support in opinion polls, and Republicans largely gave in after it was tied to a measure offsetting some of the costs to small business owners, partly through tax breaks valued at $21 billion over 10 years.
The breaks include more generous provisions for writing off the cost of investments. The measure also simplifies requirements for small-business pension programs. In addition, it contains an unrelated provision establishing a $5,000 tax credit for couples who adopt a child.
Kathy Wilkinson, a lab assistant and student from Wheeling, W.Va., who is a single parent of two daughters and earns the minimum wage, said at today's signing ceremony that the law would have a "phenomenal" effect on her life.
"It's going to be such a relief to be able to pay the gas and the electric all within one month because I've got that little bit extra in my paycheck," Ms. Wilkinson said. "And for my children, both of whom want to be in the school band, I can now afford to put some money away to get them the instruments."
