HEADLINE: Business Travel;
A victory may be near in efforts to end the liability limit for international airline passengers.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
VICTORY finally appears in sight after a decades-long battle by United States airlines to raise or eliminate the $75,000 liability limit for passengers killed or injured on international flights to and from this country.
If the Department of Transportation approves, as expected, beginning Nov. 1 plaintiffs will be able to recover the full amount of their provable damages, without any applicable limit, and carriers would be liable up to about $146,000 a passenger, even if they were not negligent. 
 "Both carriers and their passengers will benefit from the new system," said Carol Hallett, the chief executive of the United States Air Transport Association. Led by AMR's American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, the association has long sought to raise the 30-year-old liability limit -- set in 1966 under the auspices of the Warsaw Convention -- or abolish it altogether.
Yet the limit endured, because of what the department recently described as "the major divergence of views of interested parties." Those parties include carriers from poorer nations and airplane manufacturers from developed nations.
But last year the Air Transport Association teamed up with the International Air Transport Association to develop a consensus among the world's major airlines on waiving the limit.
Under current regulations, plaintiffs can collect more than $75,000 only if they can prove that a carrier has been guilty of "willful misconduct," but many airlines have been paying more than $75,000 rather than be branded negligent. In 1992, Japanese airlines agreed to waive all limits, and a dozen other international carriers followed suit last year.
Both air transport associations have filed documents seeking Transportation Department approval. But while the international agreements will require additional approvals before becoming law, the agreement among American carriers requires only the one approval to become effective.
 
The Chain Gang
Hotel chains for business travelers are springing up all over the landscape. HFS's Wingate Inns, which caters to business travelers on a budget, recently opened sites in Sevierville, Tenn., Alpharetta, Ga., and Madison, Wis. Marriott International's economy Fairfield Suites, aimed at both business and leisure travelers, broke ground last week in Eagan, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis-St. Paul. And the first Club Hotel by Doubletree, midscale properties with 24-hour business centers, opened a hotel with appropriate fanfare last week in Jacksonville, Fla.
 
Frequent-Flier Update
If it is not getting any easier to swap frequent-flier miles for flights to popular destinations, it is easier than ever to earn those miles. American Airlines, the originator of frequent-flier miles, not only awards a mile for every $10 invested in its family of mutual funds, it awards one mile for every dollar of mortgage interest spent financing or refinancing a home. Those who sell their current home, or buy a new one, through the airline's AAdvantage Program for Mortgages can earn 15,000 miles per $100,000, pro-rated, based on the purchase price at the time of purchase or sale.
Those who are are skittish about mixing frequent-flier miles with high finance or real estate can still earn miles the traditional way.
Ladbroke Group's Hilton International is offering 1,000 miles a stay (double the usual award) to frequent fliers of UAL's United Airlines who pay corporate rates or higher at any of 59 participating hotels worldwide, and to American Airlines' frequent fliers at 72 hotels. Twenty-one Hilton International hotels will award 1,000 miles on Delta Air Lines to guests who buy a special three-night package rate that includes breakfast for two. All three offers are good through Aug. 31.
To celebrate its recent frequent-flier partnership with British Airways, Inter-Continental Hotels -- a unit of the Saison Group of Japan -- is offering British Airways Executive Club members double miles, or 1,000 miles a stay, at any of its properties through the end of the year. That airline partnership, incidentally, is Inter-Continental's 25th, which it says is a record. If so, it somehow seems fitting for the hotel chain founded 50 years ago by Pan American World Airways.
 
Hotel Habits
In an age when ordinary folks are eager to tell their most intimate secrets to nationwide television audiences, it is hardly surprising that many travelers have no inhibitions discussing their hotel-room sleeping habits. In a national survey conducted for Manor Care's Sleep Inn, 32 percent of travelers said they brought their own pillows, 9 percent brought a night-light, 7 percent their own blanket and 4 percent a sleep mask. And 79 percent sleep on the same side of a hotel bed as they do in their beds at home; 14 percent leave the bathroom light on all night.
In a recent survey conducted by Fodor's Travel Publications, 59 percent of hotel guests said they checked the bed sheets for cleanliness, and 33 percent of men and 19 percent of women used the mini-bar. Twenty-three percent of travelers say they read the Gideon Bibles, while 4 percent admit to stealing the towels.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE LANGUAGE;
Metaphor! Hut, Hut ... Go, Team, Go!

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20

 BODY:
His vocabulary is often cribbed straight from a play book. His frame of reference is frequently bounded by the gridiron, with football serving as a metaphor for everything from race relations to economic policy. An imaginary football forever in his hand, he throws not air kisses but air passes to the crowds.
It may have been more than a quarter of a century since Jack Kemp played professional football, but as he scrambles across the country in the hopes of an electoral touchdown, it sometimes seems as if he never left the field. 
 "It's nice to be introduced as a former quarterback," Mr. Kemp said in his opening remarks to an audience of veterans here today, mentioning the athletic element of his resume before the legislative one.
In other cities, Mr. Kemp, who played for the San Diego Chargers and the Buffalo Bills, has bragged about having two sons who went into professional football, cited football right alongside 18 years in Congress as a prime educational force in his life, and, time and again, invoked football positions to define the role he would play for Mr. Dole.
"Can Kemp play second string?" Mr. Kemp said on Sunday at a rally in a football stadium near Buffalo. "I can do better than that. I'm going to be Bob Dole's blocking back for the next four to eight years."
Caught up in the football fever, Mr. Dole has joined the scrimmage with his own athletic bravado. "Jack was never in a Super Bowl," he told the crowd near Buffalo. "But we're going to be in a Super Bowl on Nov. 5."
Whether it is a tactic or just a tic, the pigskin politics of the Dole-Kemp campaign clearly works to showcase the candidates as unaffected champions of unassuming folk, as rough-and-tumble contrasts to the cerebral elitists that they accuse the Democrats in Washington of being.
But some political analysts wonder how well it's playing.
"It's probably heavier on the male jock talk than strategy would dictate for them," said Paul Begala, a political consultant who was a senior adviser in Bill Clinton's 1992 Presidential campaign. "I hear it, and I like it, but my wife hears it and rolls her eyes. And the key swing voters in this election are more women than men."
Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, whose rousing oratory marked a high point of the Republican National Convention, said that in his 1994 campaign for Congress, he studiously avoided mention of his days as a star quarterback at the University of Oklahoma, then with the Canadian Football League.
"I wanted people to know that I was more than just a guy who went out and bumped heads with other guys on a Saturday afternoon," Mr. Watts said.
Aides and advisers to the Dole-Kemp campaign said that Mr. Kemp's blitz of football references, while unrehearsed, would die off as the campaign proceeded, particularly when Mr. Kemp ventures out on his own and has more time at the podium to discuss issues at length.
But the voters who have attended Mr. Kemp's campaign appearances so far hardly seem concerned. "It's great that he talks about being a quarterback," said Cathy Willinger, who stood in a small crowd at the airport here today so that she could get Mr. Kemp to sign a football.
"It says that he's a team player," said Ms. Willinger, 37.
When Mr. Kemp crouched down to greet Ms. Willinger's 4-year-old daughter, Emma, he said, "I have a grandson about your age -- good-looking, great football player."
Football has been a visual as well as verbal motif. In the stadium outside Buffalo, the stage sat astride the 50-yard line, and former and current Bills players climbed onto it at the climax of the rally.
In a park in Pittsburgh later that day, a football as big as a small house flanked the right side of the platform on which Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp stood.
The sport has been prominent in this campaign from the moment that Mr. Dole announced his selection of Mr. Kemp as a running mate, saying that he had wanted a person who rated a 10 and got a 15, the number on Mr. Kemp's jersey during his days with the Bills.
With that kickoff, the ball kept right on rolling.
Mr. Kemp managed to fit football into an articulation of economic policy, alluding to the career of his son, Jimmy, a professional quarterback in Canada. "We believe so much in free trade," Mr. Kemp said of himself and his wife, Joanne, "we exported our youngest son."
Mr. Dole framed his proposed tax cut in sports terms. After he and Mr. Kemp take office, he said, "One of the first things we're going to do is send the I.R.S. to the showers."
George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to President Clinton, said that he smelled a whiff of strategy in the sweaty verbiage.
"I think they're trying to say youth, vigor," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "You go with what you've got."

HEADLINE: Sprint to Offer Internet Service to Residential Customers

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would gradually begin offering low-cost Internet service to its residential customers later this year, becoming the third and last of the country's large long-distance telephone companies to expand into what has been a treacherous consumer Internet market.
Executives of the company said the belated and cautious entry into the consumer Internet market was part of a deliberate strategy to avoid the initial Internet missteps of its rivals, the MCI Communications Corporation and the AT&T Corporation. 
 Although widely expected to push scores of smaller local and regional Internet service providers out of the market, the large phone companies have so far won the business of only a few hundred thousand of the millions of residential customers who currently tap into the global computer network.
Jim Dodd, vice president of Internet access services at Sprint's Multimedia Group, said that to make sure its customer support and technical capacities were able to meet demand, no more than 200,000 Sprint customers would be invited to test the new Internet Passport service without charge before it is offered to the general public.
When the system is proven and the Internet Passport service is formally introduced later this year in more than 200 cities, Mr. Dodd said, unlimited access to the Internet would cost $19.95 a month, while more casual users would be able to pay $1.50 an hour with no minimum. The monthly fee matches the rates of AT&T Worldnet, but the $1.50 hourly rate is substantially less expensive than the $2.50 an hour charged by AT&T Worldnet and Internet MCI.
Mr. Dodd said yesterday that he believed that even with lower rates, Sprint's consumer Internet venture would be more profitable than AT&T Worldnet and Internet MCI because Sprint already has an extensive network infrastructure in place. Other Sprint executives have said they expect Sprint to capture quickly as much as 20 percent of the total consumer market for Internet access. Sprint's plans were reported by The Wall Street Journal yesterday.
Sprint's late entrance into the consumer market was seen as surprising by some analysts, because Sprint has long been the primary carrier of Internet data traffic in the United States. Scores of smaller Internet service providers (or I.S.P.'s), as well as larger companies like America Online Inc., buy excess network capacity from Sprint and resell it to their own customers.
Thus, Sprint's entry into the consumer market would seem to put it in direct competition with many of its own customers.
"My observation of the I.S.P. landscape is that they are not afraid," said Gordon Cook, editor and publisher of The Cook Report on the Internet, a monthly publication that focuses on the Internet's technical infrastructure. "The economies of scale at the lower end of the market still favor the I.S.P.'s. I have yet to see that AT&T Worldnet has caused any problems for them, and I wouldn't consider MCI to be a major player at this point. Their service has been a belly flop."
Ullas Naik, a vice president at First Albany Technology Research in Boston, said he was surprised that Sprint took the risky approach of building a customer service and technical system from scratch rather than acquire one of the larger regional Internet service providers.
"Well, better late than never, I suppose," Mr. Naik said. "They say the reason they held off was to see what mistakes the other guys made, but I'm not sure I buy that. For a company looking to enter the consumer Internet market, the safest and fastest course of action is to acquire an established company."

HEADLINE: Lions Plan a New Den In Downtown Detroit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Detroit Lions football team announced today that after more than 20 years in the suburbs, it planned to move back into its namesake city.
The plans unveiled today call for the city and the team to build a $245 million domed stadium next to a $240 million open-air baseball stadium that the Detroit Tigers recently said they would build in the inner city. The adjacent stadiums, which would be one of the largest entertainment complexes in the United States, are the latest of several large investments in a city that has recently been showing signs of an economic revival. 
 The domed stadium would hold 65,000 to 75,000 for football. Officials of the Lions said they planned to build it and move in after completing the 2004 season in suburban Pontiac, and earlier if they can break their lease. The new stadium could also be used for concerts and possibly national political conventions, Mayor Dennis Archer said.
Charles R. Schmidt, the Lions' chief operating officer, said the team's owners, a branch of the Ford family, would reconsider the plan in November if several conditions were not met, including the acquisition of land for the stadium. But Mr. Schmidt and local officials expressed strong confidence that the conditions could be met.
The Ford family and local corporate sponsors will pay nearly half the bill for the new stadium, which the Lions are expected to occupy free of rent while receiving revenue from other events like conventions. State, county and local government agencies will pay the other half of the stadium's cost and own it.
Sports industry analysts said that today's deal could signal a new restraint by local governments, after several years when Baltimore, Cleveland, Cincinnati and St. Louis have agreed to pay virtually all the cost of new stadiums.
"It's not as sweetheart a lease as most of the recent football stadiums' have been," said Michael K. Ozanian, the editor of Sportsvalue, a bimonthly newsletter on professional athletic franchises.
Marc S. Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Ltd., a consulting firm in Chicago, said the participation of corporate sponsors in the initial construction of a stadium could be copied elsewhere as a way to reduce the cost to local governments.
Government agencies are also carrying slightly less than half the expense of building the new Tiger stadium, with the team's owners, the Ilitch family, bearing the rest. And in another deal this year, the San Francisco Giants committed itself to build a new baseball stadium entirely with private money.
But sports industry analysts cautioned that these three deals had special details that might not be duplicated elsewhere. The Giants agreed to rely on private money only after the defeat of several referendums that would have used tax money for a new stadium.
The Tigers and Lions are owned by families who are very wealthy even by professional sports standards and who have unusually strong personal ties to the Detroit area. The Ilitch family, which founded Little Caesar Enterprises and its pizza chain. and has since moved into real estate development, owns the Detroit Tigers.
The Detroit Lions are owned by a branch of the Ford family, which still controls a significant portion of the Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest corporation. William C. Ford Jr., the Lions' vice chairman and a great-grandson of Henry Ford, made clear in an interview this afternoon that family issues played a large role in the decision to bring the team into Detroit without even seeking possibly more generous stadium bids from sports-hungry cities elsewhere.
"My children and my grandchildren are going to live in this area. and without a vital city center, this area is greatly diminished," Mr. Ford said. "Our family has had a long history with this city whether it's the Model T, Ford Hospital, Ford Auditorium or the Renaissance Center," the city's biggest office complex.
The announcement today angered officials in Pontiac, who have been feuding with the Ford family for years over a lease that allows the Lions to keep revenues only from football games at the city's Silverdome. But Mr. Ganis said the Pontiac dome was "economically obsolete" because it did not have enough suites for corporations and because the stadium's roof is held up by air pressure, slowing rock bands and convention organizers in moving equipment in because air locks must be used.
Mr. Ford said his family was completely committed to moving the team into Detroit and was not trying to negotiate a better deal with Pontiac.
The family had moved the Lions from Detroit to the Silverdome in 1975, a move that Mr. Ford described at a press conference this morning as a sign that the family had lost confidence then in the city's future and leadership. Detroit had been badly scarred by race riots in 1967, and its politics became acrimonious when Coleman A. Young became Mayor in 1974 and pursued a confrontational approach to racial and economic issues.
Mr. Young retired in early 1994 and was succeeded by Mr. Archer, a Democrat who has strong support from business leaders. The city's health has since improved, with the General Motors Corporation announcing earlier this summer that it had bought the Renaissance Center and would move its headquarters there from midtown Detroit. The Chrysler Corporation has also recently expanded a Jeep factory here, and a Germany steel company, Thyssen A.G., is building a $100 million steel processing center here.
The Detroit Lions left themselves with three loopholes today that might yet result in their staying in Pontiac.
One condition is that voters approve on Nov. 6 a referendum setting a 1 percent tax on hotels and a 2 percent tax on rental cars to raise $80 million locally for the stadium. Michael Duggan, the deputy executive of Wayne County, which includes Detroit, predicted little difficulty with acceptance of the referendum.,
Another condition is that local corporations agree to contribute $50 million to the project. Mr. Schmidt said that local companies had already informally expressed their willingness to contribute.
Mr. Ford, who is also the chairman of the powerful finance committee on Ford's board, said the Ford Motor Company had not yet been asked for any contribution because of the potential for a conflict of interest involving the family. The company will be asked later to contribute, but Mr. Ford said he would not take part in that process.
The last condition, and potentially the trickiest, lies in persuading local landowners not to raise prices too much before selling their land on the proposed site, which lies to the east of the city's main artery, Woodward Avenue, and just south of Interstate 75. While the county already owns part of the land and will donate it to the stadium project, the rest of the open-air parking lots and mostly deserted buildings in the area are in private hands.
"I am really sick of the way development in this city has been thwarted by a few people trying to get rich quick" on previous deals, Mr. Duggan said. He promised that local government leaders and the city's close-knit business community would put pressure on any holdouts.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Officials Say Mafia Infiltrated Health-Care Industry

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In what authorities described as evidence that the Mafia had infiltrated the health-care industry, New Jersey officials said yesterday that they had smashed a ring that siphoned money from group health-care programs serving a million patients.
Law-enforcement officials say that mob families have for decades been secret partners or controlled companies in many lawful industries, including food distribution, trucking, garbage removal, garment manufacturing, construction and the entertainment industry. But they said the mob's entry into the nation's rapidly expanding field of group care poses an ominous threat. 
 "We are alleging for the first time the involvement of organized crime in the health-care industry," Peter G. Verniero, the Attorney General of New Jersey, said in an interview. "We hope it's not a national trend, but we cannot dismiss that possibility."
Investigators in Mr. Verniero's office warned that the medical industry was a potential treasure-trove for mobsters who could use sensitive and personal information gleaned from group-care programs to blackmail and exploit patients and health-care providers.
Though he said there was no evidence of such misuse of records in this case, Robert T. Buccino, the deputy chief of the State Organized Crime Bureau, said, "They did have access to medical records, and it could be used for extortion and other criminal purposes."
The assertion from the officials came as 12 men were arrested on state charges that they were linked to a Genovese crime family gang that defrauded medical programs and engaged in the more common mob crimes of illegal gambling, loansharking and labor racketeering.
One defendant, Dr. Angelo A. Caprio, a physician in Jersey City, was accused of submitting fraudulent medical claims for a union official who prosecutors said was a member of the gang.
New Jersey State investigators said that in 1994, the mobsters gained control of Tri-Con Associates, a New Jersey company that arranged and managed group medical, dental and optical programs for employers and unions with networks of health-care providers. The companies and unions normally paid a fixed annual fee for each patient in the program and Tri-Con's fees came from the health-care providers.
Health-care experts said Tri-Con entered a comparatively new but growing practice in which health-care brokers create networks of doctors and hospitals who provide services to employers and unions at reduced rates.
According to investigators, Tri-Con inflated fees that providers paid for its managerial services and threatened some plan administrators to approve the costs. The extra money was passed on to the Mafia. The investigators refused to identify the administrators or the plans.
Mr. Verniero declined to estimate the amount of money siphoned by the mobsters.
"But we think it was substantial because of the number of clients and customers," he said.
"Ultimately, all honest consumers of medical care have to bear the cost of these inflated and unneeded charges placed on health programs."
Investigators said the Genovese gang -- known as a crew -- used Tri-Con in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and two hangouts in Hoboken, N.J., the Monroe Buddies Club and the Fifth and Madison Avenue Club, to plan their operations.
A central figure in the gang's health-care infiltration, investigators said, was Stefano Mazzola, a former Passaic, N.J., police officer who served 10 years in prison for armed robbery extortion and racketeering. Shortly after Mr. Mazzola was paroled in 1993, he became the chief economic officer of Tri-Con.
In addition to allegations of skimming profits for the mob, he is accused of surreptitiously allowing Genovese gangsters to get free medical care from some plans.
State officials said they had no information about Tri-Con's ownership or any other official in the company except Mr. Mazzola. Mr. Mazzola, 52, who lives in a $275,000 condominium apartment in Rockaway, N.J., was identified in the charges as an associate and enforcer in the Genovese family who worked for Michael A. Borelli Jr., 59, of Fort Lee, N.J., a soldier in the family who ran a powerful crew based in Hoboken.
In a brochure published last year, "Taking Health Care into the Next Century," a Tri-Con subsidiary, Medical Integrated Systems, said that its client list covered more than one million patients, including public employees in Florida and Oklahoma and 11 unions in New Jersey and New York, mainly on Long Island. Investigators said that some Oklahoma state police officers were covered by plans arranged by Medical Integrated Systems.
Two unions covered by Tri-Con, Local 1298 and Local 66, are affiliated with the Laborers International Union of North America, which is being monitored by the United States Department of Justice because of possible organized-crime ties. New Jersey investigators said there was no evidence of wrongdoing by union officials who were solicited by Tri-Con.
Mr. Verniero said he notified law-enforcement officials yesterday in New York, Florida and Oklahoma about the investigation and the possible implications for their states.
Mr. Verniero said no state regulatory laws covered Tri-Con and its subsidiaries since they were not health-care providers or insurers. The offices of Tri-Con were raided yesterday and its records seized by the state police, but no other employees were accused of wrongdoing.
Tri-Con shared a fourth-floor office on Route 17 and the same telephone number with another company, Medical Imaging Systems Inc. James J. Guida, a lawyer for Medical Imaging, said that it provided radiology services and that it used Tri-Con only for "marketing purposes" and had no other business relationship with it.
Terrence P. Farley, director of New Jersey's Division of Criminal Justice, said that the investigation began two years ago and that a cooperating witness had secretly recorded conversations with several defendants. Other officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the witness was an associate in Mr. Borelli's crew who "flipped" -- volunteered to work undercover -- and the authorities were not aware of Tri-Con when the inquiry into the crew's activities began.
The officials said that in a taped conversation, Mr. Mazzola mentioned that he got up to $100 from providers for each patient he brought into a plan and 28 percent of the fees paid by the employer or union for each participant. Mr. Mazzola and Mr. Borelli were overheard talking about plans to threaten a top official of a Hudson County hospital whom they wanted to join one of their health-care networks.
The officials declined to identify the hospital or the hospital administrator.
Investigators said it was unclear how Mr. Mazzola, who had no background in health care, got involved in the business.
In criminal complaints filed yesterday, prosecutors said that the Genovese crew influenced two unions in Northern New Jersey, Local 560 of the United Brotherhood of Teamsters in Union City and Local 69 of the Hotel, Restaurant and Bartenders Employees in Secaucus. Michael C. Sciarra, of Pompton Plains, N.J., a former Local 560 president, was accused of accepting bribes to obtain memberships in the local.
Dr. Caprio, the Jersey City physician, was identified by prosecutors as a Genovese associate, or someone who works for the family. He was accused of accepting kickbacks from another defendant, John R. Agathos, a local 69 official, in exchange for submitting false medical claims.
The 12 defendants each pleaded not guilty to racketeering and conspiracy charges and were released on bail pending hearings.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Attacks Foe on Military And Defends Own Tax Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20

 BODY:
With Gen. Colin L. Powell at his side, Bob Dole today went before the Veterans of Foreign Wars to assail President Clinton as being weak on defense and to pledge that veterans would not be hurt by his own plan to cut taxes while still balancing the budget by 2002.
Mr. Dole's remarks to an audience of fellow veterans, which he delivered in strong and emotional language, seemed to add another Government program to those he has said are off limits for budget cuts. 
 Mr. Dole has already said he will "not touch" Social Security, Medicare and military spending to obtain the savings to help pay for a $548 billion tax cut he has proposed. Even before Mr. Dole's statements today, the White House and some independent budget analysts had suggested that Mr. Dole had set parameters that would greatly complicate his effort to meet his tax and deficit goals if he is elected President.
A V.F.W. cap from Post 6240 in Kansas was perched on his head and Mr. Dole's voice quavered with emotion as he gazed over an audience that included many men who, like him, had fought in World War II and who, like him, had been injured in battle. Mr. Powell's surprise appearance with the candidate added drama and emotion to the moment, particularly as he introduced Mr. Dole to the veterans.
Mr. Dole spoke clearly and passionately, comfortable with an audience that included many friends who knew him from past conventions, as he assured them they had nothing to worry about if he became President.
"Do you think for one minute -- and a lot of you here are in the same category -- that someone who spent three years of his life in an Army hospital, someone who owes his education to the G.I. Bill, would stand by and allow the budget to be balanced on the back of America's veterans?" Mr. Dole asked. "No way. No way will that happen when Bob Dole is President of the United States."
Mr. Dole's aides seemed taken aback by the candidate's remarks, and there was confusion among his senior aides at first over whether an exemption for veterans programs was included in his original tax cutting plan. It was not.
Later, a spokesman said Mr. Dole had not intended to suggest to his audience here that veterans' programs would be spared budget cuts, but only that the cuts would not fall disproportionately on them. "Vets will be treated with the utmost fairness, so that even if these programs aren't completely off the table, they're certainly on the edge of the table," said Mr. Dole's spokesman, Nelson Warfield.
It was a distinction that Mr. Dole did not make for his audience.
"All my life I've remembered veterans," Mr. Dole said, recalling his lifelong membership in the organization. He went on to suggest that veterans' programs would, in fact, be dramatically improved if he is elected. "My goal is a veterans' health-care delivery system that reflects 21st century health care advances, not the old stuff, but the new stuff."
And Mr. Dole bristled at the recent charges by President Clinton that the Republican's economic plan would, his assurances to the contrary, force cuts in programs that are popular with middle-class voters.
"There are those who believe we can't do it -- that we can't cut taxes, that we can't balance the budget," Mr. Dole said. "They also want you to believe -- and this is the point I want to make -- that our plan will mean drastic cuts in programs like Medicare and Social Security and veterans' benefits."
"Well, let me respond to this because I want to offer my official response to this outstanding audience," he continued. He went on to quote Brig. Gen. Anthony McAuliffe, who was commanding the 101st Airborne in Bastogne when the Germans demanded he surrender the important crossroads during the Battle of the Bulge.
"The general said, and I quote, 'Nuts,' " Mr. Dole said. "That was his response, and that is my response."
In the scope of the entire budget, spending on veterans is comparatively quite small: About $18.6 billion this year, mostly covering the costs of 174 veterans hospitals and clinics, which serve about 3 million veterans a year. Another $20 billion goes to veterans' entitlements, including veterans pensions.
But his remarks suggest the difficulty he faces in trying to adhere to his twin economic goals of cutting taxes and balancing the budget, without offending groups of voters.
"Oh, my God -- the noose tightens," said Martha Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan organization which advocates fiscal restraint. "Where is he going to get the money?"
Mr. Dole's aides said today it was highly unlikely that the campaign would provide a detailed list of the $217 billion in spending cuts needed to finance the tax cut, which includes a 15-percent across-the-board cut in personal income tax rates and halving the capital gains tax. "Dole is not submitting an F.Y. '98 plan in a stump speech," his communications director, John Buckley, said, referring to a budget for the fiscal year beginning in Septermber 1998.
Mr. Dole made his remarks on a day intended to contrast once again his military service with President Clinton's avoidance of service during in the war in Vietnam. To do that, Mr. Dole invited Mr. Powell, the Republican whom Mr. Dole had sought energetically, and without success, to recruit as a running mate, to join him on this trip.
The joint appearance by the two men was also noteworthy because it came at a time when Mr. Dole's aides are debating whether Mr. Dole should, in the next few weeks, announce that Mr. Powell would serve as his Secretary of State, as a way of recruiting a particularly energetic campaigner with a moderate appeal. "We haven't had any discussion about it," Mr. Dole said today. Mr. Powell said: "Anything's open. But right now, the more important thing is to get the team elected."
One result of Mr. Powell's appearance was that Jack Kemp, Mr. Dole's running mate, was overshadowed for the first time since the convention. Mr. Kemp obtained a medical exemption from Army doctors in 1961 for a shoulder injury that did not prevent his playing professional football for several more years, and he also appeared on stage today but did not wear a V.F.W. cap.

HEADLINE: Debating Workfare: Mayor's Effort Raises Questions Over Impact on Poor

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
When a State Supreme Court justice interfered on Monday with the Giuliani administration's plans to put homeless mothers to work for their welfare benefits, the resulting brushfire quickly illuminated some of the issues raised by workfare's swift expansion through New York.
The arguments in the bitter legal quarrel between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Justice Helen E. Freedman go to the very nature of workfare and the reasons that both local and national officials have been so quick to embrace it. Those reasons will only become more intense as the new Federal welfare bill produces even larger workfare programs in New York City and the nation. 
 For Justice Freedman, workfare disrupts the already disordered lives of homeless people, taking children away from parents who are required to report to jobs at a time they cannot even find shelter. Until the city can find a better place for families to sleep than the tables and floors of a city office, she ruled, it cannot use that office to begin the process of putting mothers to work cleaning the city's streets and parks or performing clerical tasks.
Advocates for the poor, whose position Justice Freedman has thus far championed, go even further, saying the city is deliberately using workfare to deter homeless families from seeking welfare and housing. When the city is under increasing legal pressure to find shelter for more homeless families, they say, it is no coincidence that the city has begun rapidly expanding its workfare program to include the homeless.
"The idea is to make seeking assistance so miserable that families won't seek it anymore," said Steven Banks, the Legal Aid lawyer who successfully persuaded Justice Freedman to issue her ruling. "It's out-and-out deterrence."
The Mayor, however, said yesterday that workfare has a very different purpose, one intended to elevate the lives of those on public assistance and eventually move them back into the economic mainstream.
"Work is an important part, an integral part of moving someone off welfare," he said. "I believe this will help them in a very deep and profound sense. It will help them have some control over their lives. It'll help them stay in the work force. It'll help them maintain work discipline. It'll maintain self-respect. And it's precisely the thing that's been missing from this system for 20 or 30 years, which are concepts that seem to be unknown to Judge Freedman."
The idea that work somehow interferes with families is "astounding" and "perverse," he said, going against the country's basic philosophy and prevailing political winds as embodied in the new welfare bill and the electorate's increasingly skeptical view of public assistance.
Nonetheless, Mr. Giuliani has previously acknowledged that workfare and other changes he has made in welfare procedures, like finger-imaging, have acted as a deterrent, reducing the welfare rolls by 155,000. Last year, shortly after the programs began, he said that welfare in New York City had always been too "user friendly," and that workfare and the new screening procedures would cut down the rolls to those who absolutely required welfare. He even said it could prompt many welfare recipients to move out of New York State.
Pleased with how workfare has reduced the welfare rolls and put 34,000 people to work over the last two years, city administration officials last week tried to portray the sudden expansion of the program to the homeless as a natural extension. But several city employees who were present at internal planning meetings last week said the orders from City Hall were rushed, intended to begin quickly moving those who arrived at the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx into the workfare program.
The unit is an office of the city's Department of Homeless Services, where adults and children in dire need of shelter often sleep for days at a time on tables, chairs and the floor. The city has been repeatedly cited for contempt by Justice Freedman for continuing the practice, and faces mounting fines if it does not either find a better way to house the people in the office or find a way to keep them from coming in.
The city is also under pressure to stop sending homeless people to live in hotel rooms without kitchens, where families are sometimes sent after leaving the emergency unit. Under a law that the Mayor signed last year, the City Council can close down the Department of Homeless Services in October if the practice does not end. Currently, there are about 300 families in the hotel rooms at 5 different hotels around the city.
The Mayor's critics suggested that it was these pressures that forced the city to threaten homelesss families with workfare in the hope they would not seek housing.
"They have to come up with a solution quickly, and this is what they used," said Julie Levine, director of social services for the city's Public Advocate, Mark Green. "The idea was to dissuade people from even coming in."
But the Mayor said the intent was nothing of the kind. New York City provides more benefits to the homeless than any other city in the country, Mr. Giuliani asserted last night, and those who partake of those benefits should be asked to work part time in exchange.
"The city has the right and the taxpayers of the city have the right to ask that they do something in return for that, and that is to work part time," the Mayor said. "That's all they're being asked to do."

HEADLINE: CHINA HAS BECOME CHIEF CONTRIBUTOR TO U.S. TRADE GAP

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
For the first time on record, China has surpassed Japan as the largest source of the American trade deficit, a development that could further strain relations with Beijing over what the Clinton Administration contends are unfair limits on products made in the United States.
Economists have seen this milestone coming for some time as a consequence of China's expanding role as a major Asian launching pad for exports combined with Japan's increased imports and a gradual shift of certain industrial operations to other nations. 
 Its arrival came as the Commerce Department reported a surprisingly large shrinkage in the nation's overall trade gap for June, down to $8.1 billion from $10.5 billion in May. The United States trade deficit for the first six months of the year was 14.2 percent lower than in the corresponding 1995 period.
The Clinton Administration pounced on the overall results to boast of its efforts to open foreign markets and enhance the competitiveness of American industry. The figures, declared Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, "show the continuing pattern of improved international performance of the U.S. economy."
The deficit with China climbed in June to $3.3 billion, or 40 percent of the total American imbalance, driven mainly by American imports of toys, apparel, footwear and household goods. While the long-term trend has been clear, the Administration and other analysts said that the trade gap with China was quite volatile. It could retreat in future months, in part because China's export boom may be slackening. Moreover, much of the reason for the sharp rise in the deficit with China recently is a result of production shifts from other countries in Asia.
At the same time, the American deficit with Japan has diminished rapidly, to $3.2 billion in June from $5.3 billion a year earlier, as that country has emerged from a lengthy recession and stepped up its demand for foreign goods.
Analysts said the smaller trade deficit would add about a half of a percentage point to the 4.2 percent United States growth rate that the Commerce Department has estimated for the April-June period. This potential upward revision, however, could be mostly offset by downward revisions for other items, particularly inventories.
The narrowing of the deficit in June was almost entirely caused by a $2.6 billion drop in imports, with the greatest reductions evident in motor vehicles and parts and industrial supplies and materials.
But Mr. Stiglitz and private specialists resisted suggestions that the lower import total reflected a slowing of the economy. They noted that trade figures are unreliable guidesmonth to month, citing the fact that June's import drop followed a $1.8 billion surge in May.
Exports, meanwhile, edged down $200 million. This followed a very brisk pace in May, and left sales of goods and services to foreigners 8 percent higher for the first six months of the year than in the corresponding 1995 period.
"Our exports just keep growing," commented H. Erich Heinemann, an economist affiliated with Brimberg & Company, a New York investment house. He said this was particularly impressive at a time when many of America's major trading partners were economically weak and thus less likely to demand foreign goods. In addition, the price of exports has been falling, meaning that it takes a greater quantity of shipments to sustain the totals reported in dollars.
The deficit with China was up 8 percent in the first half but this was substantially less rapid growth than in recent years, Mickey Kantor, the Commerce Secretary, said.
China and the United States have repeatedly been at odds over a variety of trade issues. Most recently, Washington threatened to impose sanctions against Beijing for pirating computer software, movies and music but retreated at the last moment when China promised to crack down on illegal counterfeiting. Despite the continuing tensions, the Clinton Administration pushed hard to renew China's preferential trade status, arguing that cutting off the trade benefits would irreparably harm the relationship between the two nations.
Analysts were divided today as to whether China would remain the country running the largest trade surplus with the United States, or whether Japan would retake its long-held No. 1 position, at least over the next few months.
Among other factors, the Chinese are trying hard to rein in their surging economy, which is driven to a large degree by exports. American imports of Chinese goods also tend to be concentrated seasonally in the first half of the year. In addition, figures for individual pairs of trading partners swing erratically in the short run and are not adjusted for seasonal variations.
The accuracy of the figures is somewhat suspect as well, analysts noted, because a lot of Chinese trade goes through Hong Kong and may be mislabeled.
The rise of the Chinese deficit, to some extent, also reflects a structural readjustment of the American trade deficit because of the transfer to China of production formerly conducted in more advanced Asian economies, along with Japan's own efforts to remain competitive by shifting plants elsewhere.
Indeed, today's report showed that the United States is now running hefty surpluses, totaling $1.1 billion in June, with South Korea and Hong Kong and that its deficit with Singapore shrank to $48 million.
The deficit with Mexico narrowed about $100 million in June, to about $1.5 billion, with first-half exports to that country 19 percent higher than in 1995 and 27 percent higher than in 1993, the year before the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect. Imports from Mexico have soared for more than a year, reflecting the collapse of the peso that makes those goods particularly inexpensive in the United States. The deficit with Canada, the largest United States trading partner, also eased, to $2.4 billion.
Today's report also showed that the trade deficit was $9.4 billion on a three-month moving average in June, the same as in May, and that the United States had a $2.6 billion surplus in trade in advanced-technology products, up from $2.4 billion in May and in sharp contrast to last October and November when this account fell into negative territory.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Officials Across Europe Watch Bundesbank Talks

BYLINE: International Herald Tribune 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The meeting Thursday of Germany's Bundesbank central council is being watched by politicians, government officials and bankers across Europe with the hope that a rate cut could spur the Continent's economies.
Meetings of the Bundesbank council are always closely watched by financial markets, but this time the stakes are sharply higher, officials said today. 
 A German rate cut would give European economies some breathing room in their efforts to cut budget deficits and trim unemployment. The Bundesbank, because of the size of the German economy and the bank's reputation as a bulwark against inflation, has great influence in European economics.
By keeping rates high, the bank forces other countries to adopt tight money policies, choking off economic recovery, to prevent their currencies from falling versus the mark.
In France, the Government faces "an ominous autumn because nothing really positive has turned up to change expectations since the social turmoil last year," an official in Paris said.
Anticipation that the Bundesbank can brighten the overall outlook centers on expectations that "a small cut could be the first of a series that could add up to a dramatic change" in the overall climate, according to Fred Irwin, an executive at Citibank in Frankfurt.
The Bundesbank has often disappointed expectations, so European officials were loath today to discuss their governments' hopes in detail. But several pointed out that there are new German domestic pressures favoring a rate cut -- notably from industrialists anxious to see the German mark continue dropping against the United States dollar, a benefit for Germany's exports.
A move by Germany to start shaving interest rates would be a political gift to leaders straining to cut spending without setting off social unrest in most European countries. Lower German rates would help Rome by strengthening the Italian currency and thus helping hold down inflation. Spain and France might be able to lower their own rates in tandem, bankers said.
Falling interest rates reduce government borrowing costs, making debt lower than it would otherwise be. In the private sector, companies are encouraged to borrow and invest in modernizing equipment, expanding businesses and creating jobs.
The possibility of reductions -- even a single percentage point over several months, which is thought to be a maximum cut since German rates are already at historic lows -- could significantly improve the prospects for Bonn and Paris to reach the targets next year qualifying them for the European Monetary Union.
"We're running out of time for governments to meet the Maastricht criteria, so people are watching the Bundesbank with particular interest this week," said Paul Horne, chief international economist at Smith Barney in Paris.
If German rates start to drop, he said, it should embolden France's central bank to cut rates, perhaps even slightly faster than Germany. That should stabilize the French franc.
A strong speculative threat looms for the franc next month, when Prime Minister Alain Juppe is due to announce an austere budget as the Government tries to catch up in its deficit-cutting program despite the failure of predicted growth to materialize so far this year. The Government already faces a threat of protest actions by public-sector unions when workers return from their summer holidays.
For markets and voters to get a sense of an improving European outlook, according to Paul Donovan, chief international economist at UBS in London, the Bundesbank needs to "engineer a cut in interest rates that keeps expectations that more cuts are coming."
Too sharp a drop, he said, "would suggest a one-time adjustment, but a small cut would send a powerful signal about a new trend." Other bankers agreed that the Bundesbank was likely to want to see the German economy digest an initial cut before lowering rates further.
Rate-cut expectations were fueled today when the German central bank reported that money-supply growth slowed last month, a sign of low inflationary pressure. The Bundesbank said that annualized growth in the M-3 money supply, its main policy guide, fell to 8.6 percent from 9.3 percent in June.
Unlike the Federal Reserve, which sets monetary policy partly with an eye to the overall health of the American economy, the Bundesbank has a narrow mandate to fight inflation and safeguard the value of the mark.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Under the Hood With Perot's Data

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Ross Perot's statistics are generally accurate. But their relevance is sometimes less than clear.
"Before our nation was formed," he declared in his speech to the Reform Party in Valley Forge, Pa., on Sunday night, "the total cost to run our government was 67 cents per person a year. Then after our nation was formed, it went up to a dollar a year. Then 120 years later, in 1910, it was up to $6.75 per person a year." 
 Mr. Perot continued: "Then we passed the income tax law amendment in 1913, and 16 years later it had gone from $6.75 to $29 per person a year. Now, strap in your seat belt and don't eject, because you can't -- today it's $5,700 a year per person."
The numbers are indisputable. What Mr. Perot has apparently done is to take the Federal budget at various points in history and divide that figure by the population. (Rounded off, the Government is spending $1.5 trillion this year, and the population is 265 million, for a per-person expenditure of $5,660.)
The question, said Charles L. Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was President Lyndon B. Johnson's budget director and President Jimmy Carter's chief economic adviser, is, "So what?"
Yes, the Government has grown since the Revolutionary War. The United States now has Social Security and Medicare and veterans benefits. There are aircraft carriers and fighter planes and the Green Berets. The country has a national highway system and national parks and a National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It has an F.B.I., a C.I.A. and a Border Patrol. It even has special prosecutors, five of them active at last count.
Which of these activities would Mr. Perot eliminate? Would he really like to return to a Government whose main activities were subduing Indians and taxing rum? He never says.
"The first step in solving any problem is to define the problem," Mr. Perot told the Reform Party delegates. But comparing the per-person cost of the Government with the cost more than 200 years ago is hardly defining the problem.
Few economists take issue with Mr. Perot's main point, which is that Government programs, and what they imply about future levels of spending and taxation, must eventually be changed if the economy is to remain healthy. "If he wants to say we have a serious long-term problem, I completely agree," said Mr. Schultze.
The Federal budget deficit this year (the difference between the Government's expenditures and its revenue) is less than half of what it was four years ago, when Mr. Perot began calling attention to the Government's fiscal mess. President Clinton and his Republican opponents now say they are dedicated to balancing the budget by 2002.
Still, Mr. Perot is right when he says the two major parties are not addressing the crisis that lies ahead. By the second or third decade of the next century, when the baby boomers begin to retire, the Government will no longer be able to afford Social Security and Medicare payments unless big changes are made in the retirement programs or onerous taxes are levied on workers.
But after describing the crisis in anecdotal terms, Mr. Perot goes no further than Bill Clinton or Bob Dole in saying how he would solve it. In an interview last month with The New York Times, President Clinton said that what was needed was "a bipartisan group that really tries outside the heat of the election to look at what the long-term demographic trends are and make sure we can finance what we're doing and take care of the real fundamental needs of the American people." That is pretty close to Mr. Perot's getting the best minds together to look under the hood.
Mr. Perot likes to describe the Government's finances in terms of assets and liabilities. In his speech in Valley Forge, he pointed to a page in the Clinton Administration's budget for the 1997 fiscal year. It shows that the Government's assets are $2.3 trillion and its liabilities $5.2 trillion. "We have a negative net worth in the Federal Government of $2.9 trillion," Mr. Perot said.
So if the Government were a business, it would be bankrupt. But the Government is not a business. "This is an absolutely ridiculous calculation," said Robert D. Reischauer, another Brookings economist, who was director of the Congressional Budget Office for eight years. "Unlike a business, the Government has the sovereign authority to meet its liabilities with its power to tax."
Moreover, as the budget explicitly makes clear, the value of many Government assets is incalculable. What, for instance, is the Grand Canyon worth? Or Lake Michigan? Or the continental shelf? How does one measure the economic value of the education of American citizens?
Here is still another way Mr. Perot made his point in Valley Forge: If Government programs are not changed, he said, people born today will have to pay taxes at rates higher than 80 percent over their working lifetimes to meet the Government's obligations.
This calculation is based on the theory of generational accounting developed by the economist Laurence J. Kotlikoff. It is valuable as a tool of analysis, said Mr. Reischauer, "but it's nothing you would want to base policy on."
Government policies, Mr. Reischauer said, would certainly be changed long before the tax rate was allowed to exceed 80 percent. Herbert Stein, who was President Richard M. Nixon's chief economic adviser and is now at the American Enterprise Institute, postulated a law that seems to apply: "If something cannot go on forever, it will stop."
Sometimes Mr. Perot's statistics do not quite prove what he says they prove. A case in point is his statement on Sunday that "since 1980, the standard of living is down for four out of five working Americans."
Officials at the Census Bureau and the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis said they had no official measurement of the standard of living.
Sharon Holman, a spokeswoman for Mr. Perot, said the data came from a Census study this summer of the share of aggregate income received by each fifth of the population. The study showed that the share of income received by the top fifth (46.9 percent) had grown since 1980 and that the share of each of the remaining four fifths had fallen.
But standard of living and income are not the same thing. For instance, families' standard of living is improved if technology brings them more conveniences at home (microwave ovens and computers, for instance), if they get more benefits from their employers (better health coverage and longer vacations) and if their necessities are acquired at less expense (lower long-distance telephone rates and gasoline prices), even if their incomes do not rise.
Moreover, some families' actual incomes may have grown since 1980 even if their share of the total national income has fallen, if others' incomes have grown even more.
To buttress his position in favor of trade restrictions, Mr. Perot said that 90 percent of the goods sold in the United States in 1950 were made here and that the figure was now below 50 percent. He also said two million manufacturing jobs had gone to Asia and 500,000 to Mexico.
Administration officials said they did not know where Mr. Perot got those figures. But they insisted that many more jobs had been created in export industries than had been lost to free trade and that the new jobs paid an average of 15 percent more than the ones lost.
One set of Mr. Perot's statistics is used on the stump by Mr. Dole as well. It is that Americans pay more in taxes than they spend for food, clothing and shelter combined.
According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, whether this is precisely correct depends on whether one counts as a shelter expense the amount spent by investors in residential real estate.
In any event, the total amount of Federal, state and local taxes collected each year and the total amount Americans spend on food, clothing and shelter is about the same, roughly $2.2 trillion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Trade Deficit Shrinks, But Gap With China Surges
China passed Japan in June as the largest single source of the United States trade deficit, a development that could further strain relations with Beijing over what the Clinton Administration says are unfair limits by the Chinese on the sale of American products.
The deficit with China -- $3.3 billion, or 40 percent of the total American deficit -- came as the Commerce Department reported a surprisingly large decrease in the nation's overall trade gap for June, down to $8.1 billion from $10.5 billion in May. [Page A1.]
 
CBS to Enter Cable
CBS announced a new cable channel, called Eye on People, about three years after the other networks began establishing cable programming channels. [D5.]
 
Retailers Report Profit Gains
Ann Taylor reported a small second-quarter profit, in contrast to a loss in the second quarter of last year, as sales improved. Other retailers also had strong gains aided by higher sales, including Dayton Hudson and the Limited. But Talbots had a loss of 20 percent for the quarter. [D4.]
 
Blue Chips Rise, as Others Fall
Blue-chip stocks rose as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, as expected. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.82 points to 5,721.26, within striking distance of its record of 5,778.00, set May 22. But the S.& P. 500 stock index fell 0.89 point, to 665.69, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.24 points, to 1,124.67. [D8.]
 
Clinton Signs Minimum-Wage Bill
President Clinton signed legislation raising the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour, to $5.15, over the next year. [B6.]
 
Sprint Joins the Fray on the Internet
Sprint said it would begin offering Internet services to its customers later this year, becoming the last large long-distance company to enter the Internet market. [D4.]
 
Agreement Stalls on Open Skies
British Airways shares slipped after a report that London was taking a tough line in open-skies talks with the United States. [D6.]
 
Waiting on the Bundesbank
A meeting on Thursday of the German central bank is being watched by Government officials and bankers across Europe in the hope that an interest-rate cut in Germany could help lift other economies, as well. [D2.]
 
Tasting a Fine Pinot Across Cyberspace
Wine experts in New York and California got together on Sunday to taste pinot noir -- on the Internet. It was, they said, the first such tasting. The linkage allowed tasters at both sites to discuss the wines and compare notes. The tasting was billed as a serious inquiry into the importance of growing conditions for wines, but in New York, it was the Internet technology that caught the group's interest. [C7.]
 
British Agency Expands in New York
More O'Ferrall, one of the world's largest outdoor-advertising companies, is opening its first American office as it prepares to compete for "street furniture" accounts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Two Sport Utility Vehicles May Roll
Consumers Union said that two sport utility vehicles, an Isuzu Trooper and an Acura SLX, could roll over during quick turns at low speed, and it demanded a recall. [A13.]
 
The Mob Infiltrates Managed Care
Law-enforcement authorities in New Jersey said they had smashed an organized-crime ring that siphoned money from group health care programs. [A1.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL CHECK PRINTING UNIT

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Rogers Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its Davis & Henderson unit, a check-printing business, to the MDC Communications Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Rogers, a diversified communications company based in Toronto, acquired Davis & Henderson as part of the purchase of Maclean Hunter Ltd. in 1994. Davis & Henderson has a nearly 50 percent share of the Canadian check market, and it is expected to generate revenue in excess of $80 million (Canadian) in the current fiscal year. It employs more than 750 people at seven plants in Canada and one in the United States. Through its United States subsidiary, Check Gallery Inc., Davis & Henderson is also involved in the check business in the United States. MDC is also based in Toronto.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Dole, Kemp and Their Tax Plan Make First Commercial Foray

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Armed with a straightforward theme, a Vice-Presidential candidate and Federal financing, the Dole campaign today began broadcasting a new commercial featuring the Republican ticket and its tax plan, while attacking President Clinton on the state of the economy.
Aides to Mr. Dole said the commercial, to be broadcast in 15 states, was the first in a planned $2 million campaign through the November election. 
 With fleeting images and staccato statements reminiscent of Mr. Dole's speaking style, the advertisement distills the message he has made the center of his campaign. "Bob Dole," the narrator says. "Cut taxes. Balance the budget. Raise take-home pay. Tell the truth."
The Dole campaign, which reached Federal spending limits before the Republican convention last week, has not paid for a commercial since March 18. But the Republican National Committee has been advertising on Mr. Dole's behalf.
Broadening the attack on Mr. Clinton, a newly formed coalition of conservative groups plans to unveil an advertising campaign on Wednesday featuring women complaining about their taxes. That campaign is scheduled to begin during the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next week.
The Dole campaign said it would also have a "heavy buy" for its new advertisement in Chicago during the Democrats' convention.
The Dole advertisement tries to capitalize on the energy that Jack Kemp, the Vice-Presidential nominee, brought to the Republican convention in San Diego. Mr. Kemp is shown once in close-up -- as the terse narrator says "Jack Kemp" -- and again at the end of the advertisement, standing in a shower of confetti with Mr. Dole at the convention.
Elizabeth Dole also appears in the commercial, standing beside Mr. Dole in one image.
The Clinton campaign pointed out that Mr. Dole had not detailed how he would "balance the budget." It also challenged two other assertions in the commercial.
First, the commercial opens with the statement "Today, taxes are the highest in American history." To back that up, the Dole campaign supplied figures from the Department of Commerce listing tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product.
But the numbers included state and local taxes. The Federal burden was higher in 1981, according to a breakdown of the Commerce Department figures supplied by the Dole campaign itself. Further, the Clinton campaign argued, the Federal tax rate for a typical family is lower now than when Mr. Clinton took office.
The commercial continues: "Bill Clinton says we have the healthiest economy in 'three decades.' Believe that?"
The Clinton campaign pointed to a speech Mr. Dole gave before the New Hampshire Legislature on Feb. 13. In his prepared remarks for that speech, Mr. Dole said, "Our economy is the strongest it's been in 30 years."
The Clinton campaign said it had a videotape of the actual speech, in which Mr. Dole changed the words but not the thrust of the comment. Tonight the campaign was considering including that footage in a new commercial.
But in his speech, Mr. Dole went on to argue that despite record corporate profits, "middle-class families feel less and less secure about the future." He called for "a balanced budget with real tax relief."
In its advertisement, the Dole campaign, which has been trying to appeal to female voters, uses a male narrator with a slightly gravelly, older-sounding voice. By contrast, a newly formed group, Women for Tax Reform, plans to feature a woman criticizing Mr. Clinton in its new advertisement, to be broadcast next week. "I'm scared he's going to raise my taxes -- again," the woman says.
Lisa Kruska, a spokeswoman for the group, said it would spend $50,000 broadcasting the commercial in Chicago and nationally next week.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1206 words

HEADLINE: The Vision Thing

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is managing editor of Foreign Affairs.

 BODY:
The Republican Party has been bush-whacked on foreign policy. Still scarred by the fate of George Bush, whom the public faulted for his focus on crises abroad at the expense of problems at home, the G.O.P. has been inarticulate about one of its cardinal strengths.
The San Diego convention mimicked the silence of the primaries. The few short speeches devoted to foreign policy seemed more an effort to build a case against President Clinton than to present a Republican agenda for America's role in the world. Foreign policy may not be a vote-getter, but if Mr. Dole continues to ignore it, his candidacy, his party and the country will be hurt. 
 There is nothing wrong with an unabashedly partisan attack on the Administration's foreign policy, as James Baker's spirited convention speech demonstrated. That's what democratic politics is all about. And there is much to criticize -- the focus on peripheral countries like Haiti, the casual use of threats and promises in Bosnia and the I-love-you, I-love-you-not flip-flops on China.
But the Republican Party must put forth its own ideas -- sensible, hardheaded ideas, not mere bluster about American hegemony. As his speech at the convention showed, Bob Dole has good instincts on foreign policy -- his vow to follow through on commitments or not make them at all, for example. Still, they are no more than instincts.
Without a set of principles, Republicans are already floundering. Their foreign policy is becoming a collection of knee-jerk reactions to Mr. Clinton. If the President imposes a ban on trade with Cuba, Republicans clamor that they want an even bigger ban. If he orders sanctions against Libya and Iran, Republicans call for more sanctions. If he is in favor of NATO expansion, Republicans want NATO expansion, now!
Some of these policies are wise, some silly. But all are born of a reflexive desire to outflank the President. In the 1950's, a similar inability to construct a foreign policy caused Congressional Republicans to advocate extreme positions intended to outflank Harry Truman. They accused Secretary of State Dean Acheson of appeasing the Soviet Union. And Senator Joseph McCarthy launched his hunt for Communists at home.
The danger of a vacuum is that it will be filled. If Bob Dole and Jack Kemp do not define Republican principles of foreign policy, Patrick Buchanan and Pat Robertson will. Brimming with phony solutions to imaginary problems, Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Robertson will use their persistence and eloquence to shift the terms of debate, even if party leaders keep them out of the limelight. Then, mainstream internationalist Republicans will have to spend their time explaining why they do not believe that the North American Free Trade Agreement is a fiendish Wall Street plot to impoverish the American worker or that the United States has ceded its sovereignty to an international cartel headed by David Rockefeller.
If such a transformation seems far-fetched, remember that it has happened before. In 1910, the Republican Party was the party of internationalism and resolve. Its leading lights were men like Theodore Roosevelt, Henry Cabot Lodge, John Hay and Elihu Root, all of them passionate about America's rising place in the world. Yet some 15 years later, the Republican Party had become the party of isolationism and neutrality. G.O.P. luminaries like Col. Robert McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, and Senators Gerald Nye and William E. Borah passionately called for America to withdraw from the world.
These two competing traditions -- not so much isolationism versus internationalism as paranoid nativism versus responsible internationalism -- have always vied for primacy within the G.O.P. The party of Henry Stimson, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry Kissinger, Ronald Reagan and George Bush is also the party of Robert Taft, Joseph McCarthy and Patrick Buchanan. The cold war insured that common sense usually triumphed, but that is not guaranteed in a world without a threat like the Soviet Union. It will certainly not happen without leadership.
What should the Republican Party stand for in foreign affairs? It should, of course, emphasize consistency, credibility and realism, as Mr. Dole promises to do. But it must also embrace a larger conception of America's role in the world.
Some Republicans, most notably William Kristol, editor of the Weekly Standard, and Robert Kagan, a former policy analyst for the Bush Administration, urge a return to Ronald Reagan's idea of that broader role. In a recent article in Foreign Affairs, they advocated a "neo-Reaganite" policy that combines a huge military buildup with the worldwide export of American democracy.
They are right to advocate a larger vision, but to make the goal "American hegemony," as they do, is self-defeating. The surest way to invite challenges to our leadership is to gloat about American dominance. Our allies -- not to mention China -- are now wealthier, more confident and no longer threatened by an "evil empire." Their response to American "leadership" on sanctions on Cuba, Libya and Iran has been to reject our calls for unity and busily trade with all these countries.
So to ask for a Reaganite foreign policy today is to forget that Ronald Reagan operated in a world with a Soviet threat that is now history. What's more, an agenda that puts international social engineering (the promotion of democracy) at the top of the list would seem to embrace the fanciful dreams of Woodrow Wilson (and Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser) rather than the hardheaded Republican realism of Theodore Roosevelt.
A more reasonable, if no less ambitious, foreign policy goal is to place the post-1945 world that America shaped on a firm footing. The United States must renew the institutions, alliances and policies that can maintain or even strengthen the global economy and peace among the great powers.
Relations with the great powers must be a priority. (If this seems obvious, consider that Secretary of State Warren Christopher has traveled to Damascus more often than he has to Tokyo or Bonn.) As the second and third largest economies in the world, Germany and Japan must be enlisted in the enormous task of reforming the Bretton Woods system, which sustains the open world economy.
The two countries must also be given permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council. Or perhaps some other organization, such as an expanded Group of Seven, should be used as a vehicle for big-power decision-making. Russia and China must be deterred from external aggression, but we cannot respond to every action they take along their borders. Unless we intend to be the world's policeman, our goal must be the creation of regional powers.
Finally, a sound Republican foreign policy would maintain not only America's military might but also its economic vitality. Domestic measures to raise national productivity, for example, would help shrink the trade deficit, easing the pressure for self-defeating protectionism.
This is an ambitious agenda, but one rooted in the realities of power. As Jack Kemp said, quoting Abraham Lincoln, Republicans can serve their party best by serving their country.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 21 by Fareed Zakaria incorrectly identified Robert Kagan. He was a State Department policy planner in the Reagan Administration.

HEADLINE: I.R.S., Now Meet the Reasonable Man

 BODY:
To the Editor:
J. D. Foster, in "Tax Man Blues" (Op-Ed, Aug. 19), paints a sympathetic portrait of Internal Revenue Service examiners as helpless agents forced by Congress and the President to rigidly administer a cumbersome and anachronistic tax code, thereby engendering undeserved animosity from the public. 
 What Mr. Foster fails to mention, however, is that I.R.S. caseworkers actually have a great deal of de facto discretion in administering the code. Unfortunately, they all too often fail to adopt the flexible, "reasonable man" approach necessary to reach constructive solutions for small and midsize businesses, which have increasingly become the engine of American economic growth.
I.R.S. officials should remember that they are civil servants whose job is to keep America in business. Bankrupting viable concerns through mechanistic imposition of onerous penalties is a Pyrrhic victory achieved at taxpayer expense. So drop the Nuremberg defense, Mr. Foster. It went out with World War II.
 
TERESA H. WYSZOMIERSKI
Maspeth, Queens, Aug. 19, 1996
 
The writer is a lawyer.

HEADLINE: U.S. Still Leads Field in Arms Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Russia Outstrips U.S. as Chief Arms Seller to Developing Nations" (news article, Aug. 20) needs to be put in context. 
 While Russia took the lead in new arms sales agreements to the third world during 1995, roughly two-thirds of its $6 billion in sales represented just one large deal with China to buy Russian fighter aircraft and related equipment. By other measures of the world arms trade, the United States remains the leader.
While Russia led in new sales agreements, the United States delivered more weaponry to the third world than any other nation in 1995. Over the last four years, the United States has concluded roughly half of all arms sales worldwide, more than all other major suppliers combined.
The real news from this report is that selling arms to the third world is a dead-end market economically; at $15 billion for 1995, the developing world's arms imports dropped to just one-quarter of their peak in 1988. Before the Clinton Administration and Congress listen to the cries of arms makers for more subsidies to help them "catch up with the Russians" in the arms trade, we should consider that the shrinking demand for high-tech armaments represents an unprecedented opportunity for controlling the arms trade.
To do so, governments should cut subsidies for arms sales ($7.6 billion in the United States last year) and adhere to a strict code of conduct on weapons exports modeled on legislation sponsored by Senator Mark Hatfield and Representative Cynthia McKinney. The code would curtail the President's ability to send weaponry to governments that engage in aggression against their neighbors, violate the human rights of their own citizenry or come to power through undemocratic means.
Rather than view Russia's modest success in a depressed market as a call to promote American weaponry more aggressively, the Clinton Administration or its successor should face up to the economic and political realities of the post-cold-war arms market and press for controls that will serve the long-term economic and security interests of all nations.
 
WILLIAM D. HARTUNG
New York, Aug. 21, 1996
 
The writer is a senior research fellow at the World Policy Institute of the New School for Social Research.
