HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Against the Mark As Rate-Cut Hopes Diminish

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark and most other currencies yesterday after a German research group reported a sharp rise in business confidence, dimming expectations for lower interest rates in Germany.
The unexpectedly strong data from the Ifo Economic Research Institute came one day before the Bundesbank's policy-making council was to meet for the first time since a monthlong summer break. There has been widespread expectation that the central bank will lower rates to stimulate the economy. 
 "The Ifo survey definitely had an impact," said Charles Spence, director of Treasury sales at the New York branch of Standard Chartered Bank of Britain. "Everyone has been looking for the Bundesbank to ease rates, and this number has created a bit of concern."
The mark strengthened broadly on the report, particularly against the Japanese yen. The weakness in the yen partly helped the dollar advance for the third straight day against the Japanese currency but the dollar was generally lower otherwise.
As of 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar traded at 108.46 yen, up from 108.35 yen Tuesday. The dollar traded at 1.4825 marks, down from 1.4885. The British pound cost $1.5500, up from $1.5475.
The foreign-exchange market had anticipated only a slight rise in the German indicator, consistent with other evidence that Germany is recovering slowly from a prolonged slump. But the size of the increase may have convinced Bundesbank policy makers that a decrease in interest rates is not needed.
"We sort of keep swinging back and forth on this question: Are they going to cut or not cut?" said Roger Chapin, foreign-exchange manager at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio.
The prevailing view had been that the Bundesbank would cut 10 to 15 basis points from its securities repurchase rate, an important short-term rate that has remained at 3.30 percent since February. Lower rates would make mark-denominated holdings worth less. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"A 10-to-15-basis-point cut is already built into the market," said Ronald Simpson, vice president-foreign exchange at the New York Branch of the Industrial Bank of Japan. "If for whatever reason the Bundesbank doesn't cut, the dollar could get trashed."

HEADLINE: Tobacco Shares Lead Drop As Dow Falls 31.44 Points

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks were generally lower yesterday for the first time in nearly a week, hurt by rising interest rates and a slump in tobacco shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.44 points, to 5,689.82, led by Philip Morris, which accounted for more than a third of the Dow's decline. 
 Philip Morris, the nation's biggest cigarette company, fell 3 7/8, to 87 5/8, after Michigan, Kansas and Arizona joined 11 other states suing tobacco companies for the cost of caring for ailing smokers.
As the stock market closed, White House officials said President Clinton would announce Food and Drug Administration rules governing tobacco on Friday. The rules might regulate tobacco as a drug and further limit advertising.
Other tobacco shares slid, too. RJR Nabisco Holding, maker of Camel cigarettes, dropped 1 3/8, to 25 1/4; Loews, which owns Lorillard, the maker of Kent cigarettes, dropped 1 1/4, to 76 5/8; the Universal Corporation, a tobacco processor, fell 3/4, to 26 1/8, and UST Inc., a snuff maker, fell 7/8, to 30 7/8.
"I don't think it's over yet" for tobacco stocks, said Cummins Catherwood, manager of $350 million in assets at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood in Philadelphia. "This is ugly; let's face it. It's a pile-on."
Broader indexes were mostly lower, though the Nasdaq index eked out a small gain. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.33 points, then rallied to 665.07, a 0.62-point loss for the day. The Nasdaq also rebounded late in the day to 1,126.84, up 2.17, from a 5.86-point loss.
Software stocks skidded for a second day, after Goldman, Sachs & Company removed the Oracle Corporation from its list of recommended stocks. Oracle, the second-most-active stock, with 7.4 million shares traded, dropped 1 1/8, to 37 7/8. Goldman cited weaker-than-expected sales of Oracle's data base management software in Europe for its lower rating.
Stocks were hurt by a reversal in the bond market, as prices fell on concern that the Federal Reserve would still need to raise short-term interest rates, even after leaving rates unchanged on Tuesday. The yield on the 30-year bond -- a benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- rose to 6.83 percent from 6.79 percent on Tuesday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
Without the fuel provided by lower or at least steady interest rates, investors may find little reason to send share prices higher, money managers said.
"If we should see any pronounced weakness in the bond market, then I think the stock market would have a very hard time," said George Mairs, president of Mairs & Power in Minneapolis, with $500 million under management. "It would be very difficult for the market to make new highs."
Among the biggest gainers today, Newbridge Networks soared 9 3/8, to 59 3/8. First-quarter earnings at Newbridge, a Canadian maker of telephone equipment, jumped 64 percent because of surging sales of switching devices. Analysts at Cowen & Company and J. P. Morgan raised their investment recommendations on Newbridge.
Wet Seal surged 4 5/8, to an all-time high of 34 3/8. The company, a retailer of casual clothing, earned 25 cents a share in its second quarter, in contrast to a loss of 6 cents a share a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 12 cents a share.
Jenny Craig Inc. fell 5 5/8, to 11 1/2. The company, a franchiser of weight-loss centers, said publicity about new diet drugs had hurt its business this summer.
Compuserve tumbled 1 5/8, to 11 7/8. The company, which provides computer on-line services, reported a fiscal first-quarter loss and warned of another loss in its second quarter. H& R Block Inc., which plans to spin off to shareholders its 80.1 percent stake in Compuserve in early November, fell 3/4, to 27 5/8.
Players International slid 13/16, to 6 1/16, after Salomon Brothers lowered its rating on the company to "hold" from "buy" because of weaker revenues at its casinos in Louisiana and Illinois.
TSX Corp. sank 2 3/16 to 11 13/16. The company said earnings in its fiscal first quarter rose to 22 cents a share from 20 cents a year earlier, matching analysts' expectations. Still, sales and earnings at the company's advertisement insertion business dropped from a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Many Women On Workfare Express Hope

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
IT seems that everybody has an opinion on whether welfare mothers should work. The Mayor and Congress do. So do social workers, welfare advocates and an occasional judge.
But what of welfare recipients themselves? What do they think about local -- and now national -- requirements that they work in exchange for their benefits? It depends. The welfare population is no more monolithic than any other. 
 Many of the people crammed into the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx expressed rage when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said this week that they had to work even though they were homeless. The Mayor quickly reversed himself, which was a wise move because many in the Bronx office are deeply troubled and burdened, unlikely to hold a job no matter what their accommodations.
But welfare mothers from more stable circumstances have started to join the childless adults now in the city's expanding workfare program, and in interviews this week, several women voiced a notable level of support for the idea of working. They said that they want to work, that most welfare recipients should work, and they even suggested that their lives might have taken a different course had welfare rules been made stricter sooner.
There was certainly nothing scientific about the interviews, but they were unrehearsed, and the women seemed to be speaking from the heart.
THEY should've done this a long time ago," said Elizabeth Elder, who works in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, picking up trash. "If they had, there wouldn't be children having children. Maybe if they knew they had to come to work every morning, it would make them more ambitious." Ms. Elder, 29, has four children, ages 12, 8, 7 and 5. Had rules been stricter when she was younger, she said, she might have "thought twice" about some of the choices she made.
Ms. Elder, on welfare since the mid-1980's, works four hours a day in the workfare program while an aunt looks after the children. But women without a relative to help, or the money for child care, may face serious problems, since the new Federal welfare legislation does not provide enough money to guarantee child care.
Wanda Baez could have a child care problem soon. The unemployed father of her three young children cares for them when she works in the park, but he is so impatient with them, she said, that the arrangement may not last. Still, Ms. Baez, like Ms. Elder, approves of the new approach to welfare. "A lot of people, knowing they have to work for welfare, they'll stay in school," she explained. Had she been required to work earlier, said Ms. Baez, 21, she might have had just one child.
Gloria L., a shy woman of 39 who asked that her last name not appear in print, has two children, 14 and 5. A friend takes care of them while she works. Gloria hasn't been able to find a job since coming to New York in 1992 from Florida, where she worked in a clothing factory. "If only welfare gave training," she said. But she calls the new work policy the "right" one: "Welfare is abused. I know many people who have part-time jobs and they still get the welfare. It is a problem."
LIKE Gloria, Martha Carter wants a real job. Ms. Carter, 33, works in the kitchen at the Pelham-Fritz Recreation Center in Harlem for the Department of the Aging. "I really want to be on the payroll," she said. Ms. Carter works four hours a day; her son, 8, is in a summer program and in the fall, her work schedule will coincide with his school hours.
Elizabeth Washington expects to have a similar set-up in the fall, when her two youngest children go back to elementary school and she continues at her new workfare job in Mt. Morris Park. Not that Ms. Washington intends to be doing that for very long. The 45-year-old mother of six, on welfare for 10 years -- "too long," she said yesterday -- has been studying at Touro College, and wants to work with the elderly or the disabled. She would prefer to earn a regular salary, but in the meantime, cleaning the park 20 hours a week -- for a "salary" of her benefits and carfare -- is all right with her. "I don't have a problem," she said. "If people can work they should, and not just rely on free money."
The city began assigning welfare mothers -- and some fathers -- to jobs only last month. Many may become disillusioned if, as expected, workfare does not lead to permanent employment. But for now, among some welfare recipients, at least, the stricter policies of states, cities and Washington seem to have engendered something oddly resembling optimism.

HEADLINE: $100 Million Fund Will Finance Java-Based Ventures

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21

 BODY:
A leading venture capital firm has formed a $100 million fund to invest in companies that will create software and related products based on the Java programming language developed by Sun Microsystems Inc.
Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the Menlo Park, Calif., firm that was the primary backer of the Netscape Communications Corporation, as well as an early investor in Sun, has attracted a parade of high-technology giants to the fund. Along with Sun Microsystems, other investors are Cisco Systems, Comcast, Compaq Computer, I.B.M., Itochu, Netscape, Oracle, Tele-Communications Inc.,Technology Ventures and the U S West Media Group. 
 But most of the capital in the KPCB Java Fund will come from Kleiner Perkins' usual limited partners, which are primarily endowments and institutions.
Shares of Sun rose 50 cents, to $53.75, in Nasdaq trading. Plans for the fund were reported in an article in The Wall Street Journal today.
"This fund is about investing in companies that are going to build applications," John Doerr, a general partner in Kleiner Perkins, said today in a phone interview. Those applications need not be written entirely in Java, and the companies are free to use rival products as well, like the Microsoft Corporation's Activex.
"This is not some kind of anti-Microsoft coalition," Mr. Doerr said. "Some of Microsoft's strongest partners as well as some of their strongest foes are in the fund." He noted that Microsoft was already a co-investor with Kleiner Perkins in four start-up companies.
Still, other venture capitalists said the fund was likely to run up against Microsoft. "If you're talking about Java with a capital 'J' as the structure for a new operating system, that's a challenge," said John Hummer, general partner in Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, a venture capital firm in Emeryville, Calif.
Pam Edstrom, a spokeswoman for Microsoft, declined to address the question of the Java fund directly, saying that "Microsoft believes the Internet will spawn a whole host of venture funds and companies."
 Part of Java's appeal is that programs created with it can run on a multitude of operating systems, thus weakening, at least in theory, Microsoft's stranglehold on that part of the software market. Java also allows the distribution across the Internet of tiny "applets," small programs that customers could pay for as used or as needed, with the potential to change the economic model of the software industry.
But to date, most programs created with Java have been whimsical bits of animation and other demonstration projects. For Sun, the fund is a way to promote the production of industrial-strength applications using its tools.
"When Java was really taking off, the question was how do you get applications going," Eric Schmidt, Sun's chief technical officer, said in a phone interview. "We could have funded companies ourselves, but we don't have that kind of expertise."
While Sun expects a positive return on its investment, "the real goal is to continue the Java momentum," he said.
The fund has already invested in three companies: Active Software, Calico Technology and Marimba. Active's software allows dissimilar programs like applications, data bases and Java-enabled browsers to exchange data across corporate intranets and the Internet. Calico's products automate the configuration and quotation of build-to-order products and services. Marimba is producing technologies for deploying network-aware Java applications.
Mr. Doerr said that the fund would ultimately invest in 20 to 30 companies in the next three to four years, and that it would be a minority investor in each company.
Though Kleiner Perkins has already experienced a deluge of Java-based business models from would-be entrepreneurs, Mr. Doerr said he believed the creation of the fund would lead to more investment in the most viable companies.
"In our judgment, the best opportunity right now is in making intranet enterprise applications" for corporate computing, Mr. Doerr said. "I think this has moved well beyond the hype-and-fad phase."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economists' anti-regulatory rationale is facing a change.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT is hardly news that mainstream economists think regulation often does more harm than good. After all, liberals joined conservatives in efforts to deregulate the airline, trucking and rail industries. And economists have been the most constant allies of trade liberalization. What may come as a surprise, though, is how their rationale is changing.
The argument that regulators too often become servants to those they are supposed to control is being displaced by an older objection to regulation. A new book by Peter Pitsch, an economist and lawyer who cut his own regulatory teeth on the staff of the Federal Communications Commission, draws on the ideas of the economists Joseph Schumpeter and Friedrich von Hayek to argue that the likely benefits in taming corporate power pale beside the costs in delaying and distorting innovation. 
 While not everyone will swallow it, Mr. Pitsch's analysis of telecommunications regulation in "The Innovation Age" (Hudson Institute) offers an easy introduction to what is becoming the new orthodoxy.
The classic defense of regulation in free markets is straightforward: regulators are like sports referees, making sure no one cheats and adjudicating the close calls. So, too, is the explanation for why the best intentions of the New Dealers who put most of the regulation in place have gone awry. Interests ranging from truckers to power utilities to local building contractors have managed to co-opt regulation, using it to feather their own nests at the expense of consumers and potential competitors.
Regulated airline travel, for example, was a delight, if you happened to be an airline pilot or had a generous expense account. The scramble that followed deregulation may have reduced the standard airline meal to a bag of pretzels, but it also transformed air travel from a luxury to a right of middle-class life.
The new critique of regulation is quite different. At its very best, the argument goes, regulation works by preventing monopolists from pushing prices above costs and reasonable profits. But the "static" gains in curbing monopolistic practices are likely to be small compared with the "dynamic" losses from slowing technological change and distorting its direction.
Mr. Pitsch cites the case of cable television, where local systems are often monopolies because it rarely pays to string a second set of wires. Not surprisingly, rates rose after cable was deregulated in 1986. But research by Thomas Hazlett of the University of California at Davis suggests that consumers were still better off because the dynamic efficiency gains exceeded static losses: deregulation stimulated investment in programming that more than offset the price increases. By the same token, Mr. Pitsch argues that re-regulation in 1992 stopped the proliferation of new cable channels.
Or consider allocation of the airwaves. Until last year, Washington assigned specific uses to the radio spectrum -- television, radio, cellular phones -- and gave away the right to use it to companies deemed most worthy. The F.C.C. is now authorized to recoup windfalls for the taxpayers by auctioning the spectrum to the highest bidders. But Mr. Pitsch notes that reformers have thus far neglected the more important issue of insuring highest and best use by letting markets rather than bureaucrats determine how the spectrum will be employed.
The resulting losses, he argues, have been enormous. In the 1950's and 1960's a shortage of spectrum for VHF television limited programming diversity by preventing the creation of a fourth network. In the 1970's, delays in spectrum allocation slowed cellular phone development and inhibited competition once the systems were in place -- at a cost of $86 billion, according to an analysis by the National Economic Research Associates.
Mr. Pitsch does not counsel abandonment of Government oversight of free enterprise. But he persuasively argues that regulators should stay far above the fray -- for example, capping average prices for phone service, but allowing flexibility in the pricing of individual services.
The weak link here is in the setting of technical standards -- for example, the rules that allow tens of thousands of separately designed types of telephone equipment to interconnect. Mr. Pitsch is rightly critical of Japan's premature commitment to a standard for high-definition television that was obsolete before the first sets were sold. But his insistence on the superiority of letting markets set their own standards seems glib when the very biggest players in the technology game -- the Microsofts, Intels and Motorolas -- may have both the incentives and the muscle to impose inferior standards.
But this is a small blemish to the case that less is more. "The Innovation Age" is a handy guide to the frontier of telecommunications policy. More important, it is a painless introduction to the way economists are now rethinking regulation.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Yields At Highest In 3 Weeks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of government securities fell yesterday, sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond up to its highest point in three weeks, as concern persisted that the Federal Reserve might still raise interest rates this year.
The decision not to raise rates on Tuesday at a meeting of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee left many bond analysts and traders worried that the Fed might have missed an opportunity to stay ahead of inflationary pressures. Inflation is not seen as a problem right now, but the market trades on expectations. 
 Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said, "The market should have done better on Tuesday, after the Fed passed on changing its monetary policy, and the fact that we didn't is a negative."
So, he said, yesterday's selling reflected a general concern that there was no rally and on anticipation of future Fed action, either before or after the election on Nov. 5.
The Fed last adjusted interest rates in January when it lowered the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, by 25 basis points, to its current level of 5.25 percent.
By the close of the New York cash market yesterday, the 30-year bond was down 14/32 to a price of 99 to yield 6.83 percent, up from 6.79 percent on Tuesday. The yield is at its highest point since Aug. 1, when it was also 6.83 percent.
Traders said another reason bond prices were under pressure was the Treasury's announcement yesterday that it planned to sell $31.25 billion in two- and five-year notes next week. With many prospective buyers away on vacation, there is some worry that the market may have a difficult time absorbing this fresh supply of debt.
Moreover, investors are reluctant to take positions for fear that crucial August economic data still to be reported, including nonfarm payrolls and the National Association of Purchasing Management index, could be stronger than expected, increasing the risk of inflationary pressure.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, the new two-year note was being offered to prospective buyers at a price to yield 6 percent, while the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.36 percent.
Today's report on weekly jobless claims could be a potential market mover, if the claims continue to decline substantially, convincing traders that recent declines -- which have evoked little response -- were not a fluke.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president for government trading at Everen Securities in Chicago, said volume yesterday was quite low with shorter-maturity issues holding steady, while longer issues gave up ground.
"One explanation is that there is some investor nervousness over the perception that both political parties are advocating pro-growth agendas," he said. "In that environment, they believe inflation has a better chance of picking up."
"We did hear of some people taking profits, with some hedge funds selling in the 10-year sector," Mr. Davis said. "Our customers have been better buyers of paper with maturities of five years and shorter." He added that the Fed could still act to push up rates this year, despite the political fallout in doing so before an election.
Looking ahead, Mr. Davis said that given the poor performance at the recent refunding, particularly the 10-year notes, buyers would try to get a bigger concession for the two- and five-year debt.
Yesterday, without the benefit of important economic data to give it direction, the cash market took its cue from the technical side of trading. Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said that since Aug. 13, the bulk of trading in the September bond futures contract had been contained between prices of 110 24/32 and 111 4/32. "Today, market activity was successful in moving beyond these constraints," she said, "but given that volume was light, the bearish tone of today's trading may be ephemeral and would evaporate with a rally to as little as 110 31/32."
"We see more range trading for Thursday, and doubt if the market can break further than 110 4/32-to-110 8/32," Ms. Mesch said. Yesterday, the September contact closed at 110 21/32, after opening to the downside -- below the buyers' and sellers' consensus point of fair-market value at 110 31/32.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IOWA -- The Race for Congress;
Surprise Winner in '94 Becomes a Target in '96

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
Decked out in cowboy boots and blue jeans and carrying a pitcher in each hand, Dr. Greg Ganske, the Representative of Iowa's Fourth Congressional District, was looking to harvest a few votes recently by playing waiter at the pork tent at the Iowa State Fair.
Dr. Ganske, a 47-year-old plastic surgeon turned freshman Republican Congressman, was going from table to table, pouring water and iced tea, shaking hands and swapping stories about crop prices and greased pigs. It was back in 1994, while on his way to an upset victory over Neil Smith, the Democrat who had represented the district since the Eisenhower Administration, that Dr. Ganske pulled a hamstring chasing greased pigs in a campaign stop at a county fair, somewhere else in the state. 
 "But I didn't quit," Dr. Ganske said in a recent interview. "I saw it as being emblematic of my promise to fight pork in Washington."
Not far away, Connie McBurney, a former Des Moines television weathercaster who is Dr. Ganske's Democratic challenger, was working the fairgrounds, too. At one point, the candidates passed each another inside an exhibition building full of shiny tractors, although they did not exchange a glance.
But these days Dr. Ganske is in the cross-hairs of Iowa Democrats, who have spent the last two years stewing over their loss of a district that had been on their side of the House for 36 years. Among party strategists in Washington, Dr. Ganske is near the top of the list of freshmen Republicans marked for defeat in November, marked as a loyal foot soldier in the Republican revolution led by Speaker Newt Gingrich.
To that end, party allies in the labor movement have unrolled a series of radio and television advertisements in the district attacking Dr. Ganske's voting record on everything from the environment to pensions. As in other districts, the advertisements, financed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., also accuse Dr. Ganske of trying to cripple Medicare, fighting words in a state where 15.2 percent of the population is over age 65, one of the highest percentages in the nation.
The Fourth District stretches from central Iowa to the Missouri River on the west and includes farm towns and the city of Des Moines in Polk County -- the state capital and the district's heart and soul. Nearly 60 percent of the district's voters live in Polk County.
Since 1991, when the district's lines were redrawn, the Fourth has included Council Bluffs on its western edge, where the politics are more conservative.
The district also has 11 mostly rural counties, where it pays for a candidate to know a thing or two about life on the farm. Both Dr. Ganske and Ms. McBurney do: He owns a 160-acre farm outside Des Moines, while she is quick to point out that she comes from four generations of farmers.
Polk County supported Bill Clinton in 1992 and Michael S. Dukakis before him. Still, the state's Republican Governor, Terry E. Branstad, carried the county in 1994, although not as handily as elsewhere in the state. Dr. Ganske also did well in Polk County in 1994, losing it by less than 5,000 votes. His stronghold was Council Bluffs.
"Des Moines tends to lean towards the Democrats," said Peverill Squire, a professor of political science at the University of Iowa in Iowa City. "The suburbs went heavily for Ganske last time. It's going to be interesting around here this year. It's going to be a very close race."
No one around here thought Dr. Ganske had a chance two years ago against Mr. Smith, who had represented the district for 36 years.
Mr. Smith, a liberal and the third-ranking Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, apparently did not think Dr. Ganske had much of a chance either. He ran an indifferent campaign, experts say, opening the door for Dr. Ganske, who spent $500,000 of his own money on the race. The doctor also drove throughout the district in a DeSoto, vintage 1958, the year that Mr. Smith first went to Washington.
"Ganske promised his own money for what seemed like a suicide mission and then lightning struck," said Dennis Goldfold, professor of political science at Drake University in Des Moines. "Ganske was at the right place at the right time."
Since going to Washington, Dr. Ganske has signed the Contract With America and, until recently, was a loyal Gingrich follower. But along with other Gingrich Republicans running for re-election, he has tried to distance himself from the Speaker on some issues, including Medicaid financing for rural hospitals, with yet-to-be-determined success.
"The reason I got into this race," Ms. McBurney said in an interview, "was because I felt very strongly that the direction this particular Congress was going was wrong. And Mr. Ganske has supported the Gingrich agenda right down the line."
Ms. McBurney, 56, has never run for political office before. After 24 years as a weathercaster for a CBS-TV affiliate in Des Moines, she has spent the last two years as a children's advocate in the lone children's hospital in the state, lecturing citizens groups and politicians on children's health and welfare issues. Her expertise has become a bulwark of her campaign. But her television career has provided her with her strongest asset in the race, instant name recognition.
" 'Here's Connie with the weather,' was kind of a household phrase around here," said Ron Eckles, a Ganske supporter who was renting parking spaces in his backyard across from the fairgrounds. "But I think Ganske is sincere. He's a doctor. He could make a lot more money with a shingle than a title."
The air smelled like rain, and that reminded Mr. Eckles of one more reason he planned to vote for Dr. Ganske. "Connie couldn't get the weather right," he said. "And you have a 50-50 chance."
But Dr. Ganske knows that name recognition is almost as good as money in the bank. "It's going to be a vigorous campaign," he said.
Dr. Ganske so far has the advantage in fund raising. The latest figures provided by the two campaigns show him with $300,000 on hand and his opponent with $70,000.
In its 150-year history, Iowa has never sent a woman to Congress. Marti Rivers, 44, who was eating at the pork tent, said she thought that Dr. Ganske was a nice man, but that it was time to give the seat to a woman.
"I'd like to see more women in Congress," Ms. Rivers said. "But I think it will be a very, very close race. I think either one of them could do the job just as well."
Ms. McBurney intends to prove that she can do it better. But first she had to hurry over to the celebrity cow-milking contest. As she weaved and waved her way through the crowd, it was clear why the race is so close. People repeatedly called out, "Hi, Connie!" as though she were an old friend.
"Ganske has the money," she said. "But I have the popular support."
At the milking contest, Ms. McBurney and her teammate placed fourth.
"I came in second in a goat-milking contest once," Ms. McBurney said. "But I'm not very good with cows. I don't know why. I think it's all in the wrist."
Still, she did better than the Dairy Princess. The cow knocked over her bucket, which is precisely what Ms. McBurney and Dr. Ganske are trying to do to each other's campaign.

HEADLINE: Official Says Man Told Mob To 'Get a Jew'

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
Shouting "Let's go get a Jew" and "I'm going to get a Jew; who's with me?" Charles Price whipped a group of blacks in Crown Heights into a murderous frenzy five years ago, a prosecutor charged yesterday, also suggesting for the first time in court that Mr. Price directed the mob to kill a Hasidic scholar.
Speaking at a bail hearing, the prosecutor gave the most detailed account yet of the Government's case against Mr. Price, the new suspect in the 1991 violence that led to the death of Yankel Rosenbaum. Mr. Rosenbaum's death came on the first of four nights of racial violence in the streets of Brooklyn. 
 The prosecutor, Valerie Caproni, chief of the criminal division in the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn, said a man, who investigators believe was Mr. Price, shouted, "There's one; let's go get him," in urging the crowd to attack Mr. Rosenbaum.
But the judge at the hearing expressed skepticism about Government attempts to link Mr. Price to the killing, questioning whether prosecutors had more specific evidence to support their assertions. The indictment charging Mr. Price with violating Mr. Rosenbaum's civil rights was unsealed just one week ago, days before the five-year statute of limitations on most Federal crimes runs out. Along with Lemrick Nelson Jr., he became the second person charged with a Federal crime in the case. Mr. Nelson, who was also accused of a civil rights violation in the inflicting of one of the stab wounds that killed Mr. Rosenbaum, was acquitted of murder charges in a state court in 1992.
For years, investigators had been searching for a central figure in the events that night who was identified by witnesses as a "bald black man" and who incited the crowd to kill Mr. Rosenbaum. Prosecutors now say Mr. Price, 43, was that man. Said to have been sweating and "agitated" with his clothes stained with blood by night's end, Mr. Price was depicted by Ms. Caproni yesterday as the galvanizing figure in the attack on Mr. Rosenbaum.
"The crowd went from milling about, to violence," the prosecutor said, asserting that Mr. Price, with shouts and exhortations, was responsible for Mr. Rosenbaum's death. "It was Mr. Price who walked through the crowd, inciting and exhorting the crowd to violence," Ms. Caproni said. In addition, she said Mr. Price had been observed attacking another Hasidic man, not Mr. Rosenbaum, along with other crowd members.
Ms. Caproni argued yesterday that Mr. Price should not be released on bail. The judge, Federal Magistrate John L. Caden, ordered Mr. Price kept in jail, but agreed to hear a defense lawyer, Darrell L. Paster, again on the matter on Friday.
Mr. Price, tall and bald-headed, and, Mr. Paster said, still in pain from an old gunshot wound, walked stiffly into the courtroom yesterday. He scowled as Ms. Caproni described what the judge referred to as a "very substantial criminal record," including 10 misdemeanor convictions and a felony. The prosecutor said Mr. Price was chronically unemployed, "nomadic" and a heroin addict.
Despite what appeared to be a considerable accumulation of witness testimony placing Mr. Price near the center of events in 1991, there were hints yesterday that prosecutors may face some obstacles trying to prosecute Mr. Price. That would follow the pattern in this difficult case, which has already seen two acquittals -- one of a man described as bald and black -- and the abandonment of the prosecution against another thought to have stabbed Mr. Rosenbaum.
At one point yesterday, the magistrate, referring to Mr. Price, interjected, "I'm very, very unclear as to what specifically he did in terms of causing the death of Mr. Rosenbaum." Later, the magistrate said there were "very serious questions of fact" in the new case.
But Ms. Caproni contended flatly that "he incited the crowd specifically to go after a Jew." She described two categories of witnesses: one that remembered Mr. Price as the man making the inflammatory statements to go after Jews, and a second that recalled a "bald black man" as making the statements.
The witnesses who knew Mr. Price identified him as "the bald black man" in a videotape made shortly after the traffic accident that touched off the violence.
Three witnesses who have known Mr. Price for 10 years identified him as the man inciting the crowd, Ms. Caproni said.
Several of the witnesses, she said, identified the bald black man as the one who kept the crowd stirred up near the scene of the accident, saying, "No, not that way, we're going to a Jewish neighborhood."
Legal experts have said that the more closely prosecutors can connect Mr. Price's words to the actual stabbing, the easier it will be for them to obtain a conviction. Here, the Government may run into some difficulty, at least based on what was revealed in court yesterday.
The witness who heard the statement, "There's one; let's go get him" -- words referring specifically to Mr. Rosenbaum -- falls into the second category, those who identified the speaker but not by name. Still, Ms. Caproni took pains to say that "all the witnesses, collectively" identified the inciter as bald and black.
Magistrate Caden, perhaps questioning the weight of the Government's evidence, asked, "Who exactly caused the death of Yankel Rosenbaum?"
To which, Ms. Caproni replied that it was "not necessary for the Government to put a knife in Mr. Price's hand."
"It doesn't have to be a specific intent to kill," she said.
The magistrate then asked: "This defendant precipitated harm to a Jewish person, and someone under his direction did so?"
The prosecutor replied in the affirmative.

HEADLINE: Child Rapist Stuns Belgium: What Punishment?

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 21

 BODY:
It is a horror story told many times in many places. A convicted child kidnapper and rapist serves time in prison. He is let off early for good behavior. The pedophile, unable or unwilling to control his demons, strikes again.
Marc Dutroux, 39, an unemployed electrician in Belgium who was previously convicted of abusing children, has followed the pattern to the letter, and now he is back in police custody after having confessed to another series of crimes. 
 He was charged on Friday after the police descended on a house in Charleroi, one of several he owns. Locked in a hidden dungeon were two pallid girls, aged 12 and 14, who the police said had been sexually abused.
Then he led the police to the secret backyard graves of two 8-year-old girls who he said had starved to death while in his home, but not under his care.
After pornographic films and photographs were found in another house he owns, the police said he confessed to a third crime, his role in the kidnapping of two teen-age friends, who were 17 and 19 at the time. They are still missing, exactly a year later, but the authorities say it is possible that they are alive.
As the story unfolded in ever more gruesome detail this week, the case has commanded front-page attention across Europe, where it has revived the debate over how to punish or control known offenders, and what degree of freedom they should have after serving sentences.
In Belgium, where the faces of the victims are familiar from the ubiquitous "missing" posters, people have begun circulating petitions about measures for dealing with sex offenders and calling for restoring the death penalty.
And in the United States the issue of whether to notify a community that a sex offender released from prison is living in the area has been the subject of legislation.
The fate of the six girls has engendered a sense of national mourning in Belgium, with television images from across the country today showing cars driving around with black ribbons and demonstrators carrying signs saying, "To death."
In Sars-la-Buissiere, a small village near Charleroi, in the south of the country, the home of the two dead girls and the site of one of Mr. Dutroux's houses, thousands have already filed past the girls' white coffins. Their bodies were exhumed from their clandestine grave but are to be formally buried on Thursday.
In the grave in the Dutroux backyard, the police also found the body of Bernard Weinstein, an associate of Mr. Dutroux. He told the police that he killed Mr. Weinstein in a rage because he had given him money to feed the two 8-year-olds while he served a brief jail sentence. He blamed Mr. Weinstein for their deaths.
The parents of the dead girls are also demanding access to police files and explanations of how the police could overlook important leads, like the fact that Mr. Dutroux, his wife and three children were apparently living on unemployment checks, yet he owned at least six houses and as many cars. The police now suspect that Mr. Dutroux may have profited from selling both children and child pornography.
Some human rights groups argue that the industry of sexually exploiting children is expanding, made easier through videos, computer links and cheap travel to countries where poor children can be bought with relative impunity.
Several European countries, including France and Germany, have hardened their sentences for child abusers in recent years, while some, including the Netherlands, insist on supervision and counseling after a convict's release and in some cases resort to chemical "castration," administering hormones to inhibit the abuser's libido.
In Belgium, however, laws are more lenient. Mr. Dutroux was sentenced in 1989 to 13 years in prison on multiple counts of rape and child abuse. But he was released after three years for good behavior, even though his own mother warned of the risks of recidivism.
Belgians are also venting their anger against what they see as police bungling. Belgian newspapers today published leaked police documents showing that the police had been receiving tip-offs from an informer since 1993, warning that Mr. Dutroux was "building cells" to hold kidnapped children.
The police this year made two visits to the house where the two girls were held captive and said they believed Mr. Dutroux when he said the voices they heard were those of his own children, the documents said.
Three other adults, including Mr. Dutroux's second wife, Michelle Martin, have been arrested as accomplices in the abduction and illegal imprisonment of children.
The police are now hunting for the two teen-agers, whom Mr. Dutroux said he and an associate kidnapped in Ostend, a coastal resort. Belgium's Attorney General said today that there was reason to believe that they might be alive and in the hands of a prostitution ring elsewhere in Europe.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Dole's Capital-Gains Tax Plan Aims to Woo the Middle Class

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
As the self-proclaimed candidate of a financially squeezed middle class, Bob Dole is proposing a drastic cut in a tax that he says hits hard at the very core of the American work force -- the small, growing businesses that create most of the nation's new jobs.
That, at least, is how Mr. Dole describes his proposal. Many Democrats call it a sop to the wealthy. And if history is any gauge, the debate over its merits will probably surface in the two parties' battle this fall for the hearts of middle-class voters. 
 The tax Mr. Dole seeks to cut most deeply is the tax on capital gains, the profits that investors realize when they sell stocks, bonds, real estate and most other staples of American finance. Since 1986, when a Democratic Congress raised it over President Reagan's objections, the rate has stood at a maximum of 28 percent.
Mr. Dole wants to cut income-tax rates by 15 percent. But he wants to cut the capital gains tax in half, or by even more for people of more modest means. Starting in 2001, he also would tie it to the inflation rate, meaning that the tax would apply only to profits that did not stem from inflation.
Wall Street, small-business groups and real estate executives in particular have pressed passionately, and for years, for a rate cut. Republicans need little prodding; the provision is a party axiom and has been for decades. President Bush made a capital-gains cut a centerpiece of his domestic agenda. A provision similar to Mr. Dole's was at the heart of the Republican Congress's Contract With America.
Republicans argue that a capital-gains cut would pump up the economy, unleashing a burst of entrepreneurial energy by businesses willing to take greater risks for the prospect of a greater payoff should they succeed. Mr. Dole feels so strongly about it that he briefly threatened in 1994 to hold up approval of a global trade agreement unless Congress and the White House tacked the provision onto it.
The Clinton White House, perhaps noting the ballooning number of average Americans with a toe in the stock market, has been mostly mum on the subject. But traditional Democrats say the provision is nothing more than trickle-down economics, in which the vast bulk of benefits flow to the wealthy who own and sell the vast bulk of assets subject to the tax.
They agree only on this much: the cut that Mr. Dole proposes would initially make the Government a lot of money, as investors sell off long-held assets to take advantage of the new, lower tax rate. After that, it would be a consistent money-loser.
Under existing law, taxes on capital gains are capped at 28 percent. The tax rate on ordinary income ranges from 15 percent for low-income households to almost 40 percent for the wealthiest.
There are some loopholes. The biggest involves homeowners, who generally pay the tax on home sales only if they fail to buy another house within two years, or if they still have profits after buying a new home. Even then, many taxpayers can exclude the first $125,000 in profit from taxation.
Mr. Dole would immediately cut the maximum tax rate on capital gains from 28 to 14 percent and the minimum tax from 15 to 7.5 percent. And he would increase the $125,000 exclusion for homeowners to a minimum of $250,000, rising to $500,000 for taxpayers who have lived in their homes for 20 years or more.
The tax rate would be indexed to inflation beginning in 2001 for assets that have been held for more than three years.
Mr. Dole's advisers estimate that those provisions would cost the Government $13 billion in forgone revenues from 1997 to 2002, a relative pittance in a campaign that proposes to cut $535 billion in other taxes.
Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee are more specific. They predicted this month that the changes would increase capital-gains tax revenues by a total of $3 billion in the 1997 and 1998 fiscal years, as the tax income from the increased sale of assets overwhelmed the losses from rate cuts.
From 1999 forward, the provisions would lose money -- $17.2 billion over four years, the panel estimated.
Moreover, the $3 billion gain in the first two years is an illusion because it represents the early sale of assets that eventually would have been sold off anyway. In effect, the Government takes an early tax profit at the expense of revenues that it would have picked up later.
That most of those billions would go to the well-heeled is indisputable. A 1994 report by the Senate Budget Committee estimated that 55 percent of capital-gains taxes are paid by people with incomes exceeding $200,000 a year, or roughly 1 percent of households. The share rises to 75 percent if households with earnings over $100,000 are included.
But the root of the debate over a capital-gains tax cut is not over who would get the money but what they would do with it.
Critics argue that the money would mostly go into the pockets of the wealthy, perhaps to be passed on as a lightly taxed inheritance, but not to any good economic purpose. "It mainly goes to rich people," said Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-supported advocacy group in Washington. "It's serendipity, maybe, but they're the ones who are making the case that a cut will help the economy."
Republicans take the opposite view. Indeed, many of them argue that any tax losses from a rate cut would be made up elsewhere in the economy, as businesses use their savings to invest in new equipment, increase productivity and generate new, taxable profits.
In an October 1995 monograph on the capital-gains proposal in the Contract With America, the Cato Institute, a Washington research group with strong free-market leanings, argued that the proposal would "unlock" hundreds of billions of dollars that have been sunk into stocks, property and other assets that investors have held onto, not wanting to pay a high tax on their profits. That money then could be used for more productive purposes.
Mr. Dole makes many of the same arguments in describing the rate reduction as a tonic for the middle class.
"The capital gains tax hits smaller and growing businesses hardest, and they're the ones who will create most of the new jobs in the decade ahead," he said in a Chicago speech earlier this month. "I want those businesses to use their growing value to give people better jobs, better opportunities and better incomes, not just to pay more taxes."
In the end, the argument may be impossible to settle. The multi-trillion-dollar economy is such a hulking creature, moved by so many currents, that economists have not definitively sorted out the true impact of a tax cut.

HEADLINE: Japan's New Latin Look

 BODY:
Japanese leaders do not often visit Latin America, a region historically more attuned to the United States. But Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is now on a 10-day trip to Mexico, Peru, Chile, Brazil and Costa Rica.
The prospect of heightened Japanese competition may not delight American businesses operating in these countries. But those companies should recognize that it is healthy for Latin America to broaden its international economic partnerships. Welcoming Japanese involvement in this region also sets a good precedent for insisting that Japanese companies not try to lock American businesses out of Japan's booming East Asian neighborhood. 
 For the past decade or so, Japan has been modestly increasing its exports, direct investment and development aid to Latin America. Meanwhile other economic powers, notably the United States, have moved in faster as the region's main countries have liberalized their economies. Japan accounts for a smaller share of Latin America's trade and investment today than it did in the 1980's.
Prime Minister Hashimoto's trip is meant to change this, using generous offers of government loans and grants to spur new trade and investment. Japanese producers would like to sell more of their wares to the expanding middle classes of fast-growing countries like Peru and Chile and the huge potential markets of Brazil and Mexico. The region also appeals to Japanese manufacturers, including auto makers, as a source of relatively cheap labor.
Japanese companies are especially eager to establish manufacturing plants in Mexico to avail themselves of the benefits of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Latin America also has abundant supplies of oil, minerals and timber that are attractive to resource-poor Japan.
Several of the countries Mr. Hashimoto is visiting have significant Japanese immigrant populations, notably Brazil, which has 1.3 million citizens of Japanese descent, and Peru, whose President, Alberto Fujimori, is the child of Japanese immigrants. Prime Minister Hashimoto also hopes to line up support throughout the region for Japan's effort to win a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council.
Until recently, most of the countries Mr. Hashimoto is visiting followed protectionist policies intended to favor local businesses and keep United States-based corporations at a distance. Those policies mainly resulted in stagnation, poverty and underdevelopment. Now economic liberalization has begun to revitalize the region. But it has also revived historical fears of American economic domination, a particularly appealing theme to those who have so far failed to benefit from economic change.
Japan's new interest in Latin America could provide a symbolic and practical answer to these anxieties, accelerating economic growth as businesses from all parts of the developed world compete more vigorously for the services of the region's workers and the buying power of its consumers.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
New Jersey Script for Dole's Tax Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The Republican challenger, far behind in the polls, promised to slash taxes and reinvigorate the economy, then stormed back to defeat an incumbent Democrat who had raised taxes.
That was how it worked for Christine Todd Whitman in defeating Jim Florio nearly three years ago to become Governor of New Jersey, and it is the script that Bob Dole is trying to impose on this year's Presidential campaign. 
 Both Mr. Dole and Mrs. Whitman are sure to emphasize the parallels when the Republican Presidential nominee campaigns in New Jersey today to showcase his tax-cutting plan and argue that it will generate more jobs and income for hard-pressed families.
"The people of New Jersey responded favorably to my tax cut and spending reduction proposals, and I am confident that the American people will respond in a similar fashion to the Dole proposal," Mrs. Whitman told reporters at the Republican convention in San Diego last week.
But if New Jersey has become a template for Republican strategy, the state has so far yielded a mixed record as a laboratory for the tax-cutting, deregulatory policies that Mrs. Whitman ran on and that are now being offered as a national economic prescription by Mr. Dole.
Mrs. Whitman made good on her pledge to cut personal income taxes by 30 percent, reduce environmental regulation of business and begin limiting lawsuits against companies, and since January 1994, when she took office, her policies have given New Jersey a modest boost relative to New York, Pennsylvania and other nearby states, economists said.
"It takes time to put these kinds of changes in place," said New Jersey's Commerce Commissioner, Gil Medina. "We're already seeing the effects in terms of pretty dramatic job growth. The best is yet to come."
But New Jersey remains an economic laggard compared with the nation as a whole, and it is still in shock from a wave of corporate layoffs that struck many of its biggest employers, including AT&T. And analysts said there is little prospect that the Governor's policies can reverse long-term national trends that have hurt New Jersey, including a decline in manufacturing and a migration of jobs toward lower-cost areas of the nation, and the world.
"New Jersey is still going to be a below-average economy," said Mark Zandi, an economist at Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm that tracks state economies. "That's not to say that what Governor Whitman has done has not resulted in some benefit to the business community and economic development. But while New Jersey may be a low-cost state in a high-cost region, the state is in no way competitive, even after tax cutting, with the South or parts of the West."
Moreover, in paying for tax cuts in part through changes to the state's pension system and capping aid to municipalities, the Governor has drawn criticism for potentially pushing more financial burden onto future generations and local governments. And her effort to lift some of the regulatory burden from businesses has drawn fire for weakening the state's commitment to cleaning up its air and water.
"The income tax cuts did not work politically and they did not work economically," said State Senator Bernard Kenny, a Hoboken Democrat who has been a leading critic of Mrs. Whitman's policies. "We're lagging behind the nation, and that wasn't supposed to happen."
Mrs. Whitman's approach has been strongly supported by the business community, and many business owners and executives say the economic environment is slowly improving in ways that should help speed job creation.
At Atlantic Industrial Hardware, a construction-supply company in Atlantic City, the owner, Carole Iannelli, said sales this year could reach $2 million, up from $1.2 million last year, and that she is thinking about an expansion plan that would involve adding more employees to her current work force of eight.
Much of the gain, she said, has come from a general economic rebound in the state, and specifically from a construction boom in Atlantic City. But she said Mrs. Whitman's economic approach is playing an important role. Her employees, she said, have noticed the added take-home pay resulting from the income tax cuts.
"I have single parents here, and they're very aware of every penny in their paychecks," she said.
The effort to reduce and streamline regulations on building and manufacturing activities has meant more construction projects and faster approval times, Ms. Iannelli said, generating more business for her company. And by making a commitment to solve problems faced by small business, the Governor has helped create more optimism among entrepreneurs, she said.
"When you feel that somebody at the top has thought about you and put policies in place to help, it makes you more willing to take a risk," Ms. Iannelli continued. "There's an energy now, a feeling that there's a larger pie to split up. We have a shot at doing more than surviving."
The best gauge of economic activity in states is job creation. While the rate of employment growth in the nation as a whole has been running at slightly more than 2 percent annually in recent months, job creation in New Jersey has been hovering at about 1 percent.
But job growth in New Jersey is still stronger than in its most direct competitors, New York, Pennsylvania and Connecticut. In June, for example, employment in New Jersey was nearly 1.2 percent higher than in June 1995, while the comparable figure for New York and Connecticut was nine-tenths of 1 percent, and for Pennsylvania six-tenths of 1 percent.
An analysis in May by Salomon Brothers, the investment firm, found that New Jersey ranked 38th among the states over the previous 12 months in job creation, with Connecticut ranking 42d, New York 44th and Pennsylvania 48th.
It is unclear how much of New Jersey's advantage relative to its neighbors derives from Mrs. Whitman's policies and how much from the fact that the state was hit harder than the others by the last recession, and then rebounded more sharply.
Indeed, the most recent peak in job growth in New Jersey came in 1994, when the number of jobs increased 2.2 percent as the economy continued a long climb out of the recession.
Mrs. Whitman's defenders and business leaders in New Jersey said her policies were having a profound effect on the state's economic environment, but that the benefits would take time to appear.
They said that by accelerating a process begun under Mr. Florio of reducing New Jersey's regulatory requirements on businesses -- widely seen as among the nation's costliest and most restrictive -- she was making New Jersey a far more attractive place for companies to locate and expand.
And they said the combination of income- and business-tax reductions was freeing more money for private investment without forcing wholesale cuts in state spending.

HEADLINE: Clinton Signs Bill to Give Portability In Insurance

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
In a South Lawn ceremony filled with both celebration and the ghosts of unmet goals, President Clinton signed a bill today to expand access to health insurance. And though the bill falls far short of his hope of insuring all Americans, he called it "a long step toward the kind of health care reform our nation needs."
Mr. Clinton used the occasion to declare a partial vindication for his and Hillary Rodham Clinton's own failed efforts to overhaul the health insurance system, saying the bill shows what can happen "when we cross party lines and put the interests of the American people first." 
 Mrs. Clinton, who retreated to the background after the effort she led turned into the Administration's biggest policy debacle, had a front-row seat for the signing ceremony, but not a seat on the platform with the President.
Asking the guests to "forgive me a personal note," Mr. Clinton looked toward his wife and said: "I believe, Hillary, that this justifies all those days on the road and all those nights you stayed up reading the incomprehensibly complex issues of health care. Thank you."
The audience responded with a standing ovation as Mrs. Clinton nodded silent thanks in reply. It was the first time in many months that "health care" had been uttered at the White House with such happiness. Left unsaid today were the Administration's dire warnings of two years ago that such incremental changes in the system could do more harm than good, and Mr. Clinton's repeated threats to veto any bill that did not provide health insurance for all Americans.
But Mr. Clinton's Republican opponent, Bob Dole, issued a statement harking back to those days, saying the new law "should end once and for all the Clinton prescription of big Government health care."
Mr. Dole added, "The American people should ask why it took President Clinton more than three years to support these common sense reforms which he previously threatened to veto."
The new law, which passed the Senate unanimously and drew only two dissenting votes in the House, allows workers to maintain health insurance coverage if they change or lose their jobs.
It effectively bars insurance companies from denying coverage to people who have pre-existing medical conditions.
The legislation was co-sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and both today praised Mr. Clinton for helping jump start support for the bill by pressing for its passage in his State of the Union address in January.
Mr. Kennedy said, "Every valuable part of this legislation -- from insurance reform, to help with long-term care, to assistance for the self-employed -- was originally conceived and contained in the broad-based health reform proposal that you submitted to Congress in 1993."
Today's ceremony was part of a trio of bill-signings this week -- including an increase in the minimum wage on Tuesday and welfare overhaul on Thursday -- intended to showcase both the powers of incumbency and Mr. Clinton's ability to get things done, all on the eve of the Democratic Convention next week.
But health care holds a bittersweet place in the politics of the Administration. Top advisers to the President have long acknowledged that the failure of his original bill in 1994 came to be seen as the failure of his overall domestic policy on the eve of the midterm elections, in which Republicans won control of Congress.
Today's flag-draped ceremony was the culmination of a months-long effort to redress that perception. Among those in the audience was Ira Magaziner, who was seated in the second row, and who was the main architect of the failed effort.
Besides assuring expanded access to insurance, the new law makes it easier for self-employed workers to afford their own insurance, by increasing the share of its cost they can deduct from their income taxes to 80 percent, from 30.
It toughens penalties for Medicare and Medicaid fraud, reduces paperwork and offers tax breaks for long-term care.
"It seals the cracks that swallow as many as 25 million Americans who can't get insurance or fear they will lose it," Mr. Clinton said of the bill, most of which takes effect next July. "Now, they will be protected."
But Mr. Clinton made it clear he believed that much work remained to be done, including expanding coverage for the unemployed and treating mental health coverage the same way physical ailments are treated, a provision that was dropped from the final bill.
While the legislation requires companies to offer the same access to coverage to people with pre-existing conditions that they offer to the general public, it does not set price limits on individual policies or guarantee that premiums will be affordable.
Perhaps the most contentious provision of the law also allows people who work in small businesses or who are self-employed to buy a high deductible health insurance policy for catastrophic illness and set aside other money, pre-tax, in a "medical savings account" for routine or long-term care.
Mr. Clinton and many Democrats opposed such a provision on the ground that the accounts would be most attractive to healthy, well-off people, leaving the traditional insurance pool to the sick and poor. In a compromise, the law allows 750,000 such accounts to be established in a nationwide pilot program.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill protested outside the White House against a health care bill that does not give them equal coverage. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ellsworth Raymond Dies at 84; Kremlin Watcher of Stalin Era

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Ellsworth Lester Raymond, a Soviet-era Kremlinologist who served at the United States Embassy in Moscow during World War II and taught for 29 years at New York University, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 and lived in Greenwich Village.
The cause was a pulmonary embolism, his family said. 
 Mr. Raymond served as a research analyst, political and economic adviser as well as chief translator in the embassy from 1938 to 1943. The experience left him highly critical of the Stalin Government.
Born in Fort Ann, N.Y., he received his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan. He entered the Foreign Service and was sent to Moscow in 1938. After the German invasion in 1941 he was one of the embassy staff who accompanied the American Ambassador at the time, Adm. William H. Standley, to the provincial town of Kuybyshev once the Soviet capital came under siege.
While in the provinces, he met and married a Russian ballet dancer, Anna Palasova. Over Soviet objections, he took her and their infant son back to the United States on a Navy vessel through submarine-infested waters in 1943.
He then went to work as a civilian for the Army, heading the Soviet economic section in military intelligence at the Army General Staff in Washington. But he was given to understand by his superiors that marrying a Soviet citizen had not been a wise career move; so he quit Goverment service and turned to academic life.
Mr. Raymond joined the faculty of the department of politics at N.Y.U. in 1949 and eventually became a full professor and head of the Russian area studies. He retired in 1978, having been chosen for three years in a row as one of the "Golden Dozen," an accolade bestowed by graduating seniors upon favorite teachers.
He wrote "The Soviet State" (N.Y.U. Press; 2d ed., 1977), edited scholarly books and contributed articles to various publications and sections on Soviet affairs in the Americana and Colliers enyclopedias.
Dr. Raymond's wife died in 1994 after 52 years of marriage. He is survived by a son, Alan G., of Manhattan; a daughter, Cathy Ann Raymond of Topanga, Calif.; and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Biggest Rally in 3 Weeks Lifts Dow 43.65

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The stock market staged its biggest rally in three weeks as an unexpectedly large cut in German interest rates promised faster economic growth in Europe and a jump in orders for American exporters.
Shares of the General Electric Company, the Hewlett-Packard Company, Caterpillar Inc. and Intel Corporation led the advance, as investors speculated that those companies would benefit from enhanced growth abroad. 
 "We're living in a global economy, so if you get a revival somewhere else it helps us," said Mark Stumpp, chief investment officer at PDI Strategies in Short Hills, N.J., which manages assets of $22 billion. "Look at the U.S. economy. Roughly 20 percent of G.D.P. is related in some way to exports, and a fair chunk of that obviously is related to Europe." Mr. Stumpp's reference was to the gross domestic product.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 43.65, to 5,733.47, its highest since May 24, when it closed at 5,762.86. The average is less than 45 points from its all-time high.
The Philip Morris Companies was one of only three Dow stocks that fell, as concern spread that the pace of litigation against cigarette makers would pick up. The Standard & Poor's 500 index jumped 5.61, or 0.84 percent, to 670.68, bolstered mostly by oil, beverage and regional bank stocks. As with the Dow, yesterday's jump was the biggest in the index since Aug. 2. Hewlett-Packard rose 1 1/8, to 43, Wells Fargo added 1 1/2, to 255 1/2, and Cabletron Systems rose 2 3/4, to 62 1/2.
The Nasdaq composite index extended Wednesday's late rally, rising 17.15, to 1,143.96, as Intel, Amgen, Cisco Systems Inc. and Microsoft all advanced. The index is up 1.7 percent in the last two days.
Oil stocks soared as the price of Texas crude oil surged 58 cents, to $22.30 a barrel. Mobil gained 2 3/8, to 115 1/4; Texaco climbed 1 1/8, to 91 1/8, and Exxon rose 3/4, to 83 5/8.
About 1,482 stocks advanced and 865 issues fell on the New York Stock Exchange, where some 354.5 million shares traded, below the three-month daily average of 382 million shares for an 11th consecutive day.
Germany lowered its target money rate to 3 percent from 3.3 percent. The move will help stimulate European economies and demand for United States goods, analysts said. France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Austria lowered their own interest rates after Germany's move. China and the Bank of Canada also cut key lending rates yesterday.
General Electric rose 5/8, to 84 5/8, Caterpillar climbed1/2, to 71 7/8, and Deere rose 3/4, to 40 3/4. Coca-Cola, which derives about 79 percent of its operating profit from outside the United States, climbed 1 1/8, to 52.
Tobacco issues fell further yesterday in anticipation of new regulations governing tobacco that are expected to be released by the White House today. Philip Morris fell 7/8, to 86 3/4, after falling 3 7/8 Wednesday; the Universal Corporation, a tobacco processor, fell 7/8, to 25 1/4, extending Wednesday's 3/4-point slide; Loews which makes Newport and Kent cigarettes, dropped 1 1/2, to 75 1/8.
"You've got all these lawsuits, and the F.D.A.," said John Maxwell, an analyst at Wheat, First, Butcher Singer, referring to the Food and Drug Administration. "It's just got people confused."
In addition, Kansas, Arizona and Michigan all sued the tobacco industry this week to recover the millions of dollars they spend treating smoking-related illnesses, joining 10 other states that have already sued. Another development unnerving investors is an individual smoker's liability suit in Indiana expected to go to jury deliberation today.

HEADLINE: Rewarding Indonesian Repression

 BODY:
President Clinton should heed those in his Administration who counsel against the planned sale of F-16 fighter jets at bargain prices to Indonesia. Financial terms for the sale were recently completed and the Administration need only notify Congress now before going ahead with the transfer.
This is no time to be selling high-performance warplanes to Indonesia. President Suharto has jailed hundreds of political opponents this summer in a new wave of repression. Delaying the sale a few months, one option under consideration in Washington, will not help. Selling fighter jets to Indonesia before Mr. Suharto institutes serious political reforms would seem a blanket American endorsement of an autocratic and corrupt Government. It would throw away one of Washington's few clear opportunities to press Indonesia's leaders for democratic change. 
 Indonesia's vibrant economic growth has not yet been accompanied by democratic reforms. The 75-year-old Mr. Suharto has indicated he hopes to pass the presidency to a relative. The press is controlled and political activity is tightly limited by the military.
The recent crackdown began after the Government ousted Megawati Sukarnoputri from the leadership of the authorized opposition party. Ms. Megawati is the daughter of the country's founding President, Sukarno, whom Mr. Suharto overthrew in a 1965 military coup that led to massacres of hundreds of thousands of supposed Communists.
Ms. Megawati has never criticized Mr. Suharto, but has called for democratic reforms. When the Government replaced her with its backers, her followers occupied party headquarters in Jakarta, the capital. On July 27, army-backed vigilantes and police entered the headquarters and threw them out. Riots began that killed four people, injured dozens and destroyed at least 20 buildings.
In words that echo 1965, Government officials have blamed the riots on Communists. Student activists have been arrested and are held incommunicado and without access to lawyers. The 27-year-old leader of an unauthorized leftist party and the head of the country's only independent labor union are charged with subversion, a capital offense. The Government is intimidating Ms. Megawati by summoning her and her family members for questioning. The Minister of Home Affairs announced that all non-governmental organizations must register with the police or be banned.
Washington has been looking for a buyer for 28 F-16's originally sold to Pakistan. They were never delivered, because of Congressional concerns about Pakistan's secret nuclear weapons program. When President Clinton agreed last year to repay Pakistan, the planes, which lack the most advanced electronics, went back on the market. Indonesia offered to buy nine of them at $8 million apiece.
Though the Clinton Administration has sometimes scolded Indonesia for human rights abuses, it has been so intent on expanding economic ties that Mr. Suharto has felt little pressure to change his autocratic ways. This docile American policy seems even more misplaced after the summer's events. If there is to be an F-16 sale, it should be conditioned on a speedy end to the repression and the institution of democratic reforms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Market Place;
It's Not a Real Bull Unless Investors Jump On

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average is within one good day of setting a record, having wiped out nearly all of the sharp fall in prices that took place in early July. But the stock market is not nearly as healthy as that would indicate.
While the entire market never rises or falls in unison, the current recovery is unusual for its narrowness. It is being led by big, presumably safe companies, with investors nervous about rushing back into the speculative stocks that were so popular earlier this year. 
 That pattern indicates that investors remain much more concerned about recession than about the prospect of higher interest rates. Bank stocks, which benefit from lower interest rates, are the stars. Consumer stocks -- companies that sell to consumers year in and year out -- have done much better than cyclical stocks, which are more dependent on a vibrant economy for good earnings.
In the narrowness of the rebound, this market differs markedly from the pattern that prevailed after the only two other significant downturns of the 1990's -- the 1990 plunge that coincided with the beginning of that year's recession and the 1994 slide that began when the Federal Reserve stunned Wall Street by raising interest rates. In both of those episodes, smaller stocks recovered at close to the same pace as blue chips.
Not this time. Through yesterday's close, the Dow had regained 89.7 percent of what it lost in the plunge, and it stands just eight-tenths of 1 percent from the peak of May. But the Nasdaq composite has regained only 49.1 percent of its loss, and is 8.4 percent below its June peak.
The market on which a stock trades is, of course, less important than the nature of its business or the size and influence of the company. In general, technology companies have made up only a fraction of what they lost. The Pacific Stock Exchange technology index is down 10.3 percent from its high, set in May, and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange index of semiconductor stocks is off 19.8 percent from its 1996 high and a stunning 42.6 percent from its peak, set nearly a year ago. But both Intel and Microsoft have set records this month, having more than recovered from their July dips.
One of the oldest technical indicators for the stock market is the Dow Theory, developed by Charles Dow, a founder of Dow Jones. It originally held that the economy could be deemed to be doing well only if the Dow industrials, which make the goods, were doing well along with the Dow transports, which move the goods. It was later turned into a market indicator, holding that a bull market was in place only if both indexes were moving upward.
The Dow industrials, as noted, look very good. In fact, absent the latest tobacco stock scare, that index could easily have already set a record. Had Philip Morris stayed where it was on Aug. 8, rather than dropping almost $19, the Dow industrials would have closed yesterday at 5,788.22, more than 10 points above the old high.
But the story of the transports is far different. That index has been damaged by weakness in the share prices of trucking and airline companies. The Dow transportation average, which fell almost 6 points yesterday even as most indexes rose, stands 9.8 percent below its peak and has regained only about one-third of the ground it lost in the drop.
But it is in onetime market favorites that the carnage is clearest. Many technology stocks have come down so far that their highs seem hard to believe. Iomega, a disk-drive maker, is down 72 percent from the high it set three months ago. The Chicago Board Options Exchange's index of casino stocks is off 26.4 percent from its June high.
To some extent, this represents a decline in the willingness of investors to take risks. There was a brief period in July when mutual fund investors took cash out of stock funds. That has ended, but conservative funds are now getting the bulk of the incoming cash, in sharp contrast to earlier in the year, when the riskiest funds drew in the most cash. So perhaps it should be no surprise that the kinds of stocks that conservative funds are most likely to buy are doing the best.
It is, of course, possible that the recovery will broaden. Indeed, the Nasdaq market has done better than the Dow has in the last two days. But until it happens, it will be too soon to announce that the bull market is alive and well, no matter how many records the Dow manages to set.
