HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Dole's Plan for Economy Could Be Hard to Fulfill

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Many voters say they doubt that Bob Dole can fulfill his pledge to cut taxes while still balancing the budget, but his economic plan makes another promise that could prove even more difficult to keep: to improve the nation's growth capacity to 3.5 percent a year from its current level of less than 2.5 percent.
No other Presidential candidate has ever put so specific a number on his aspirations for growth, never mind one that economists characterize as anything from highly ambitious to totally unrealistic. 
 The political calculus for Mr. Dole is clear. Publicly setting such a lofty goal allows him to portray himself as a can-do optimist intent on restoring the economy to its glory days, breaking a pattern of wage stagnation in the process, while suggesting that President Clinton has passively accepted the lower growth rates and attendant economic insecurity that have prevailed in recent years as the best the nation can do. (The Clinton Administration, of course, has a different story to tell, and is presenting itself as the guardian of steady growth, low unemployment, quiescent inflation and a reduced Federal budget deficit.)
Already, the theme that more growth is the best cure for the nation's social and economic ills, from urban poverty to the budget deficit, has become central to the Republican campaign strategy. In choosing Jack Kemp as his running mate, Mr. Dole selected his party's best-known advocate of the belief that freeing individuals and businesses from disincentives like higher taxes will lead to a boom in growth and increased prosperity for rich and poor alike.
"The President is content with the way things are," Mr. Dole said last week in accepting his party's nomination "I am not. We must commit ourselves to a far more ambitious path that puts growth-expanding opportunities, rising incomes and soaring prosperity at the heart of national policy."
But while everyone would agree that more growth is a good thing, the economic justification for Mr. Dole's target of 3.5 percent a year is less clear.
"The objective is noble," said Lyle E. Gramley, an economist and a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board. "How we get there is more difficult to see. Certainly a claim that we can increase the growth rate to 3.5 percent is not at all likely to come true in my lifetime, almost no matter what."
Most economists agree that the American economy cannot currently grow much faster than 2.5 percent a year over the long run without igniting inflation.
Mr. Dole's target is not just to increase growth for a quarter or two. Indeed, the economy grew 4.2 percent this spring, and it could well grow at a 3 percent rate or higher during the current quarter. In growing at those rates, however, the economy is like a factory that is running flat out, creating strains and bottlenecks that will eventually lead to inflation if output is not throttled back.
Mr. Dole's goal is instead to modernize and expand the factory, allowing it to run at higher rates of output without overheating. To do so, however, would require solving one of the knottiest economic policy dilemmas the United States has faced: how to improve the rate of growth in productivity, which is the measure of how much each worker produces per period of time worked.
Economists have boiled the nation's capacity for economic growth down to a simple equation: the sum of labor force growth and productivity growth. The labor force is growing at just over 1 percent a year, a figure that is unlikely to increase anytime soon given the slow growth of the overall population.
To raise the economy's capacity for sustainable, non-inflationary growth to 3.5 percent, therefore, would require nearly doubling the rate of productivity growth, to more than 2 percent, economists said. Productivity has been stagnant for two decades, through Republican and Democratic Administrations alike, defying not only policy prescriptions but also the efforts of economists to pin down its cause.
While many economists said Mr. Dole's proposals to push up productivity by stimulating more investment and improving the skill and education levels of the work force made sense, and were, at root, little different from the approach taken by the Clinton Administration, they said there was little evidence that those policies could have the profound effect on growth he is promising.
Mr. Dole's plan is based on the idea that slashing taxes, eliminating regulations on many industries, freeing businesses from the threat of frivolous lawsuits and huge jury awards and providing better education and training to workers will make the economy more productive.
His economic advisers said they could not quantify precisely how tax cuts or deregulation, for example, would improve productivity and the growth rate. But they defended the 3.5 percent goal as realistic, especially since the nation's growth rate since World War II has averaged 3.3 percent despite the lower numbers of recent years. (Mr. Dole's plan to balance the budget assumes more conservative growth numbers and does not depend on meeting the 3.5 percent goal.)
Cutting personal income taxes and capital gains taxes will free more capital for investment and increase the incentives for people to work more and take chances on starting new businesses, the advisers said. Rolling back regulations will save industry billions of dollars each year in compliance costs, freeing up even more money for investment.
Overhauling the system of civil lawsuits would remove from business a fear of being sued that distorts decisions on what types of products to develop, produce and sell. Introducing more competition into the educational system through programs like vouchers would improve educational quality and the skill level within the American work force, they said.
"If we address the accumulation of human and physical capital and increased productivity, I do believe we can significantly improve the growth rate," said Gary Becker, the Nobel Prize-winning economist from the University of Chicago who helped draft the Dole plan. "I don't think 3.5 percent is an unattainable goal. Maybe we'll do better, maybe we won't quite make it, but it's a goal we can strive for."
To work, Mr. Dole's plan would have to be enacted in a way that did not cause the financial markets and the Federal Reserve to push interest rates up, choking growth. For starters, the plan would have to avoid being seen as inflationary, which it would be if taxes were cut more than Federal spending. Perhaps more importantly, it would require convincing the Federal Reserve, a tough audience, that the economy had been so fundamentally improved by the Dole plan that a higher speed limit for economic growth was justified.
It is also unclear whether voters will accept Mr. Dole's premise that President Clinton is doing nothing to improve the growth rate.
Indeed, the Administration and its supporters argue that Mr. Clinton has pursued a vigorous pro-growth agenda, even if he has not explicitly labeled it as such. The Administration's early success, they said, is evident in the 10 million new jobs the economy has created since Mr. Clinton took office, the deep reduction in the deficit and the absence of inflation.
By bringing down the budget deficit to an estimated $117 billion this year from $290 billion in 1992, Administration officials said, they have freed capital for private investment, helping to push business investment in new equipment up 37 percent since the beginning of 1993.
By pushing for more and better education and training programs, they said, the Administration has improved the nation's "human capital." Productivity has also been enhanced through the Administration's support for policies like free trade, which promotes more competition, and Federal support for research and development.
"It's certainly fair to have a debate about growth," said Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. "But you have to understand where the underpinnings of growth come from. We tried supply-side economics in the 1980's. It's been subjected to real live national experimentation, and it utterly failed."
Citing other Administration policies like raising the minimum wage and making health insurance and pension plans more portable, Mr. Reich said Mr. Clinton's team had made a good start both on improving growth and on addressing the insecurities of workers.
"No one has suggested we can turn around a 20-year trend in three and a half years," Mr. Reich said. "Waving a magic wand and calling for a tax cut that cannot be paid for is the last thing we need."

HEADLINE: Local Votes In Brazil Are a Test For Leader

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
Local races scheduled across the country in October, which will involve more than half a million candidates, are being considered a litmus test for the one issue that has come to absorb President Fernando Henrique Cardoso more than any other: his own re-election in 1998.
The Brazilian Constitution forbids consecutive terms for elected officials, assuring frequent opportunities for ambitious politicians. The President, who made known his interest in running for a second term late last year, has since then subordinated economic and political reforms to his electoral desires, experts here and abroad have said. 
 Mr. Cardoso remains highly popular domestically. His Real Plan -- named for the new Brazilian currency -- shrank the inflation rate from 900 percent to 12 percent in two years. He is seeking a Constitutional amendment to allow for re-election, which is expected to be the first order of business when Congress reconvenes after the final round of local elections takes place on Nov. 15.
But the local campaigns have revealed, too, the limits of President Cardoso's popularity, with Brazilians asking what comes after stabilization and foreign observers wondering when the President will make the serious structural changes, like cutting the public sector work force and reforming Social Security, to back up his tight monetary policy.
"The elections now, and the re-election bid, are really delaying the necessary steps, the tough choices," said Sebastian Edwards, a professor of economics at U.C.L.A. "The question is not whether the current policy stance is sustainable or not, because it's clearly not, the question is when are they going to start adjusting."
Mr. Cardoso and his supporters maintain that becoming eligible for a second term would give him the political weight to push his measures through Congress over the next two years, though outsiders worry that Mr. Cardoso's preoccupation with re-election is, at its most harmless, putting off unpopular measures.
"What makes us think that he will get a second term, and that he would move forward more forcefully if he does?" asked Rudiger Dornbush, an economist at M.I.T. who has criticized the Brazilian President for failing to capitalize on his early success in harnessing inflation. "I think you have in Brasilia a tendency to say if something's very difficult you find a way around it, and in the meantime, have good propaganda in New York so the money keeps coming."
The most important races in the country's eight largest cities are characterized not so much by support for the President's local favorites as by the strong showing of political unknowns who are backed by the current mayors.
"If you compare the support of people for low inflation and for the successful mayor, the mayor does better, because low inflation is considered something that's already been reached, while local conditions are seen as something that still need to be improved," said Walder de Goes, a political consultant here.
Because the mayors, too are forbidden to run for a second term, voter support for their hand-picked candidates is being seen as the closest approximation to re-election, bolstering the intellectual case for continuity, Mr. de Goes added. But they may also weaken the political case for presidential continuity.
The mayors' rising power is turning them into major power brokers in their own right. In Sao Paulo, especially, the current Mayor, Paulo Maluf, opposes the constitutional amendment and plans to run for President himself. Cesar Maia, the Mayor of Rio, has in recent days also emerged as a possible next president.
Under the pressure, Mr. Cardoso's early hesitation to enter the political fray has weakened. He recently unveiled a $54 billion program for public works , health and education projects, which will depend on some $10.3 billion in federal spending over the next two years. While the President insisted the projects were not an electioneering ploy -- indeed, they were largely repackaged from the array of projects prepared by federal planning agencies -- few could find any other reason for his decision to single them out as priorities.
Planning Minister Antonio Kandir said in an interview here that the projects signaled the second phase of the Real Plan -- preparing the infrastructure and educational systems for growth, relying largely on foreign investment.
A few days later, Mr. Cardoso extended the term for unemployment compensation, in an effort to improve the standing of his former Planning Minister, Jose Serra, who is trailing in the race for mayor in Sao Paulo, where the unemployment rate is nearing 16 percent.
"Right now, his popularity is personal," said Alexandre Barros, a political consultant to investors. "He's trying to transfer his popularity from himself to his party."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
New Building May Be Last of Its Kind

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The latest response to Manhattan's hearty rental market is the Strathmore, a slender 43-story apartment tower now nearing completion at 400 East 84th Street and First Avenue.
With 180 one- to three-bedroom apartments and penthouses, the building will open for leasing next month as the city's newest mixed-income rental. And because of more restrictive zoning laws passed in 1994, the $70 million project, developed by the Related Companies of Manhattan, may be the last hurrah for tall slender towers on an Upper East Side avenue. 
 Eighty percent of the apartments, averaging 725 to 2,000 square feet, will be rented at market rates, starting at $2,400 to $5,900 a month. Penthouses cost more. The remaining 20 percent will be made available to tenants whose annual income is $14,000 to $28,400, based on family size. Monthly rents for those apartments will be $426 to $590.
In return for the affordable apartment, the city or state issues tax- exempt bonds to provide permanent financing to builders of these so-called 80-20 projects. They are also eligible for a 20-year property tax abatement from the city. As a result, developer interest in the program has increased as has the competition, underscoring the reliance of new residential construction on public benefits.
The Strathmore received $60 million in bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency.
"Even with rents as high as they are in Manhattan, rental construction still is not economically possible just with conventional financing or the abatement," said Stephen M. Ross, Related's president.
Without this program, rents would have to be 20 percent higher to secure conventional financing, said David J. Wine, president of Related's management arm, the Related Management Company. But funds are limited, keeping production modest.
In the last three years the state agency has issued bonds for 15 projects, including the Strathmore, totaling 2,402 units statewide. The city's Housing Development Corporation, which also issues bonds, has financed two to three projects a year since 1993 for a total of 1,685 apartments.
Under the program developers must also obtain a credit enhancement -- mortgage insurance from the Federal Housing Administration or a letter of credit from a bank or pension fund -- to protect the bondholders against risk in the event of a default. For the Strathmore, Related secured a letter of credit from Fleet Bank and the New York branch of Hypo Bank. The company financed $10 million internally, Mr. Wine said.
Related has built five mixed-income rentals in Manhattan. Beyond 400 East 84th Street, the company plans to close on its tax-exempt financing within 60 days for two others. One is a 240-unit project on land south of Union Square on the block bounded by Broadway, Fourth Avenue and 13th and 14th Streets; the other is a 263-unit building on 89th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Financing for a 512-unit development in Battery Park City is to close by the end of the year.
There are other challenges to development, including zoning, which was a factor at the Strathmore.
In early 1994 while it was under construction, new zoning laws were passed to prohibit such tall slender buildings in an area of the East Side roughly bounded by York and Third Avenues, 57th and 96th Streets. To build under the old rules, which gave a 20 percent bonus for providing a plaza, Related had to have finished excavation and much of the foundation before the new zoning took effect.
The question of whether the company did enough work in time led to a legal fight with the East 84th Street Neighborhood Association. In January 1995 the Appellate Division of the State's Supreme Court found in Related's favor.
The Strathmore, designed by Costas Kondylis of Manhattan, has a light brick facade with rounded bands of tinted glass on five corners. That gives each apartment a sort of enclosed terrace with a floor-to-ceiling glass panel.
Not everyone is pleased with the results. "The building is overpowering for any neighborhood but we have to live with it," said Robert Riggs, president of the East 84th Street Neighborhood Association. "The hope is that an attempt will be made to assimilate it into this neighborhood."
For brokers, it is a welcome addition to the market. "The functional vacancy rate on the Upper East Side is zero," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a large rental brokerage company. For the first half of 1996 rents on the Upper East and West Sides rose by nearly 6 percent for an annualized increase of almost 12 percent, she said, adding that most of the demand was for smaller apartments.
Mr. Wine said a two-bedroom apartment on the 28th floor with river views at the Strathmore would rent for $4,350, which is on par with comparable buildings in the area. Amenities include a concierge and health club, with a children's playroom and squash court. There will also be a 65-car garage. Occupancy will start in November, and the building is to be completed by year-end.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says City May Sue Car Insurers

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked insurance companies yesterday, saying that automobile insurance rates for New Yorkers have not kept pace with falling rates of car thefts, which dropped 50 percent in the city from 1990 to 1995. Mr. Giuliani said the city was considering suing the insurers to obtain better rates for residents.
The Mayor said the Consumer Affairs Department would release a report next week showing that insurers had treated residents unfairly by not taking into account recent significant reductions in crime when setting rates. 
 After working on automobile insurance, Mr. Giuliani said, he will push for decreases in homeowners' insurance premiums, because home burglaries also have decreased, by about a third in recent years.
The attack is Mr. Giuliani's first attempt to turn gains in fighting crime into a pocketbook issue, which has particular resonance with residents of Queens and Staten Island, where the Mayor has always enjoyed heavy support. He is expected to run for re-election next year.
Automobile insurers and state insurance officials said that coverage for thefts represented a small segment of the insurance equation and that it would be unrealistic to expect rates to drop 50 percent just because the rates of thefts had declined by that factor. The insurers and officials also said the industry seldom reacted immediately to crime reductions or increases.
New Yorkers are required to buy no-fault insurance to cover physical injuries and lost wages and liability insurance to protect themselves against lawsuits. But residents are not required to obtain comprehensive coverage, which covers the cost of stolen or vandalized automobiles, as well as any collision damages. Many owners of older vehicles do not buy that insurance.
Insurance rates vary by location and by company. In Brooklyn, which has the highest insurance rates in the state, comprehensive coverage would generally double most insurance premiums. State records indicate that a 20-year-old male driver can expect to pay $1,877 a year for required coverage and $2,017 for comprehensive coverage. The rates would drop for a 35-year-old man, to $919 for the required coverage and $909 for comprehensive.
Mr. Giuliani said a possible suit "would deal with both future rates, as well as rebates for the unfair way in which the residents of New York City have been treated at least for two or three years." He said that the lower rate of car thefts in the city translated into considerably lower costs for insurance companies and that the companies should pass on those savings to consumers. "But rates have not gone down anywhere near like that," Mr. Giuliani said.
Sean Mooney, an economist with the Insurance Information Institute, said New York City's overall automobile insurance rates ranked near the top for big cities, but trailed far behind Los Angeles, which has the country's highest rates because its drivers are known for being litigious and it has a high rate of insurance fraud. Rates for the required segment of automobile insurance in New York City are generally comparable with other cities, partly because the costs for bodily injuries tend to be low, as New York City drivers can seldom drive fast, he said. But New York City's comprehensive insurance rates are extremely high, second to Philadelphia's, he added, because of theft and vandalism.
A high-ranking consumer-affairs official said the city's report would show that the number of reported car thefts dropped, to 71,543 last year from 146,925 in 1990, a decrease of more than 51 percent. The report, which Consumer Affairs Commissioner Jose Maldonado will release next week, would also indicate that insurers have seen profit margins from insurance premiums on physical damage to automobiles rise to 12 percent in 1994 from 8 percent in 1990. That makes that category one of the most profitable.
Alexander B. Grannis, Democrat of Manhattan and chairman of the Assembly Insurance Committee, said: "We ought to be demanding the State Insurance Department be at the forefront of investigating this, because they approve the rates for insurance companies. They are charged with protecting consumers, but they often times are more sympathetic to the insurers."
A spokesman for the State Insurance Department, John Calagna, said state and city officials had been working on the issue. "We support the concept that auto insurance rates should be as low as possible," he said. "And we have pledged to take a closer look at the rates."
Mr. Calagna stressed that the rates for comprehensive insurance, which includes problems like storm damage, had dropped 8 to 15 percent in the last three years. "You have to remember that auto theft is not the only category that is considered for comprehensive coverage," he said.
Mary A. Griffin, assistant vice president at the American Insurance Association, which represents 250 insurers in the state, agreed that changing trends did not result in immediate revisions by insurers. "Auto rates are based on a number of years of experience," she said. "So that a year, or even two, of a decrease in theft rates may not be borne out over the long haul."
The city records the highest number of car thefts in the state, and it has the highest insurance rates. Mr. Calagna said that eight or nine other states had higher rates than New York, but he did not compare rates between New York and other cities.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rose 6,000 Last Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
First-time claims for jobless benefits increased by 6,000 last week but remained well below the summer peak, in a range that analysts say suggests an improving labor market.
The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 327,000, up from 321,000 in the week that ended on Aug. 10. 
 The total was less than the 330,000 that many analysts had expected.
After sharply increasing to 370,000 in the week that ended on July 6, new jobless claims fell to 294,000 in three weeks as some manufacturers reopened factories from their customary summer shutdowns.
Some analysts, though, say that jobless claims in the lower-300,000 range reflect a tightening employment market.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims edged up by 1,500, to 314,000 last week. It was the first increase in five weeks. Many analysts prefer to track the less volatile four-week average because it smoothens out the highs and lows in weekly reports.

HEADLINE: Germans Cut a Major Rate; Other Europeans Follow

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Germany's central bank reduced a principal short-term interest rate more than expected yesterday, setting off rate cuts elsewhere in Europe and sending the dollar higher.
Analysts said the move would bolster economic recovery in Germany and, in turn, help the rest of Europe, which is showing signs of rebounding. But many of them also said that the German rate cut might be the last for some time. And it may be that the Bundesbank's move is more important to the prospects for a common European currency system at the turn of the century than for its immediate stimulative effects. 
 Though the German bank did not single out the exchange value of the mark in explaining the rate cut, a rise in the dollar against the mark and other European currencies appears to have been one of its goals.
This is because Germany and much of the rest of Europe depend heavily on exports to spur growth. But the recent strength of some European currencies has raised doubts about the sustainability of the rebound, because exports have become more expensive abroad. Just since mid-July, the mark has risen about 3 percent against the dollar.
Bundesbank officials had made their concern about the strength of the mark clear in recent comments that led many analysts to predict that a rate cut was in the offing. But the size of the cut -- a reduction of three-tenths of a percentage point in the 14-day securities-repurchase rate, to 3 percent from 3.3 percent -- was more than had been expected.
"They needed to do it for the currency," said James S. Fralick, director of European Economics at Morgan Stanley and Company in London.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the size of the reduction also appeared to be a move to encourage Germany and other European nations, especially France, to make the budget cuts and tax increases needed to lower their deficits to the levels required to join in the European single currency in 1999. The repurchase-rate cut yesterday might be expected to offset some of the economic drag from these spending cuts and tax increases.
"Whether by design or by coincidence, the Bundesbank's actions are more congenial for its neighbors that sometimes in the past," Mr. Lipsky said, noting that in the early 1990's, the Bundesbank's refusal to heed the difficulties of Germany's neighbors led to a near-breakup of the European Monetary System.
But a one-day decline in currency values will not be sufficient to revive Europe. Some think that the German mark has to weaken enough to raise the value of the dollar to a range of 1.5 to 1.55 marks, where it was from mid-April to mid-July, before the economy will get a significant lift. Late in New York trading yesterday, the dollar was at 1.4918 marks, up more than one-half of 1 percent.
"The German recovery and continuing European growth seem assured," Mr. Lipsky said. "But if fiscal measures are implemented as planned, there is little reason to believe that growth will exceed trend," which is about 2 percent in Germany. "So there is little reason to expect that Europe's expansion will be sufficient to reduce Europe's high unemployment rates any time soon."
Darren Williams, European economist at UBS Ltd. in London, said that "the rate cut today helps us, but it doesn't insure a recovery."
The lowering of the German securities-repurchase rate, which, like the Federal funds rate in the United States, is an important central-bank instrument in setting monetary and interest-rate policy, brought it to its lowest level since 1979.
The Bundesbank left both German benchmark rates unchanged. The discount rate, now 2.5 percent, is generally the floor for money market rates. The Lombard rate, the ceiling on such rates, is at 4.5 percent. They were last reduced on April 18.
The other nations that followed with cuts yesterday were France, which lowered its "intervention rate" 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, and Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands.
In announcing the reduction, the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, indicated that another rate cut was not likely in the near term. "With the decision today," he said, "we have established clarity for the foreseeable future."
In the markets, the yield on the 10-year German bond fell to 6.29 percent from 6.34 percent. In France, where the German rate cut is expected to release some pressure on the franc, the 10-year bond yield fell to 6.34 percent from 6.41 percent. The franc slipped moderately against the dollar. Leading European stock indexes rose.
The immediate impact on the United States from the German rate cut is minimal. It may make it easier for the Federal Reserve to hold off on a rate increase because the dollar has rallied a little as the difference between German and American rates has narrowed, making American investments more attractive. But over the years, the Fed has not paid much attention to the value of the dollar in making its policy decisions.
For the American economy, a rebounding Europe would mean more exports. But many forecasters have already assumed a rebound in Europe in their outlook for the economy here next year, so the German rate cut yesterday may just help confirm expectations rather than raise them.

HEADLINE: Chase Forms Venture Fund With Softbank

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Softbank Corporation of Japan have agreed to invest $25 million each in a new venture-capital fund focused on Internet companies that are based in New York, an executive close to the deal said yesterday.
So far Chase's venture arm, Chase Capital Partners, and Softbank, which has been spending billions of dollars lately on information technology investments, are the only investors in the fund, called Flatiron Partners. 
 The fund means to nurture promising new companies on the East Coast in general. But the emphasis will be on new-media and Internet-related companies in the so-called Silicon Alley business community that is springing up in Manhattan, centered on the Flatiron and SoHo districts.
For New York City, Flatiron is the second venture-capital fund with at least $50 million that has been formed this summer. In June, the financier Henry R. Kravis and other investors announced a fund they hope will eventually grow to $100 million, which would be used to create a large, privately run economic development authority for lower-income portions of upper Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.
But unlike that fund, from which investors do not intend to take out any profits, Flatiron would hope to enrich its backers.
Flatiron is managed by Jerry Colonna, a former partner in the CMG @Ventures Fund, which financed the World Wide Web search company Lycos before it went public earlier this year, and Fred Wilson, a former partner in Euclid Partners, a New York venture fund. Chase and Softbank may also invest up to an additional $50 million each in companies financed by Flatiron, the executive said.
Officials at Flatiron, Chase and Softbank declined to comment, but the executive familiar with the deal said that it had been signed and that the fund had already invested $4 million in Yoyodyne Entertainment Inc., a company based in Irvington, N.Y., that is developing sweepstakes and promotional games on the Web.
Venture-capital funds provide money for start-up companies with an eye toward nurturing them into thriving businesses that can eventually yield big payoffs for the investors by issuing publicly traded shares in the stock market. Though only 1 of every 5 or 10 companies backed by venture funds typically can hope to reach that level of success, the availability of tens of millions of dollars of fresh capital could provide at least a short-term stimulus to New York's new-media economy.
And yet, some people involved in the venture-capital business say region-specific funds or narrowly sector-specific funds may be more a marketing gimmick, aimed at attracting capital to a new fund, than a viable strategy for investment.
The Flatiron deal follows the announcement on Wednesday of a fund created by the big Silicon Valley venture firm of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers to create companies that will produce programs using the Java programming language developed at Sun Microsystems Inc. A host of high-profile computer companies, including I.B.M., Compaq Computer and Cisco Systems, joined Sun in putting up somewhat less than half of the $100 million fund, which is called the KPCB Java Fund and expects to finance 20 to 30 companies over the next three to four years.
No one is betting against Kleiner Perkins, which was the primary backer of the Netscape Communications Corporation and an early investor in a score of successful technology companies. But since 1994, at least six multimedia venture funds have been formed, so far without much to show for their efforts.
"With one exception, they have done poorly," said Richard Shaffer, publisher of Venture Finance, an industry newsletter. That exception, he said, is Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, a small fund based in Emeryville, Calif., with a successful track record of backing only software companies. The fund's success stories include Powersoft Inc., the Arbor Software Corporation and Farallon Computing Inc.
Hummer Winblad, with the participation of Neil Weintraut, a former analyst for Hambrecht & Quist, recently started a separate, Internet-only venture fund, which, like Flatiron, is starting out with $50 million in capital.
But the special opportunity that backers of Flatiron see, according to the executive close to the firm, is that the rapid proliferation of Internet start-ups in Manhattan has been largely ignored by traditional venture-capital firms. With many venture-capital firms based either in Menlo Park, Calif., about 30 miles south of San Francisco, or in Boston, those regions over the years have received a disproportionate share of venture financing. And so far that has remained true in the Internet era.
"Half of the seed deals in the most recent round are Internet-related, but it's mostly in California," Mr. Shaffer said.
But while Northern California remains the main locus of Internet technology companies, New York fosters "content" creators -- companies that produce the publications, games, music and video material that finds its way onto CD-ROM's and into cyberspace.
The New York region is home to a sprawling collection of more than 4,200 concerns -- mainly small, entrepreneurial companies that develop and market Internet sites, multimedia software, on-line entertainment and other digital offerings.
The hub of this regional industry is Silicon Alley, which a recent study by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand estimated as having 700 new-media companies.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Steady; Early Rally Proves Brief

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were virtually unchanged yesterday as the market again appeared unprepared to push higher without further evidence of a slower economy.
The price of the 30-year bond ended down 2/32, to 9830/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.83 percent. 
 The bond market opened higher after Treasury securities gained in European trading as the Bundesbank cut the German repurchase rate to 3 percent from 3.3 percent.
The unexpectedly large rate cut by the German central bank bolstered the dollar against the mark and made United States securities more attractive to foreign investors, analysts said.
Treasury prices held steady when the Government reported that initial unemployment claims rose 6,000, to 327,000, in the latest week. A slightly greater rise to 331,000 had been forecast. But hedge fund selling, aggressive early in the week, was also in evidence yesterday, although at a slower pace, analysts said.
And prices turned lower after Israel priced a $1 billion debt offering, backed by the United States Agency for International Development, through Lehman Brothers Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company. The debt offering drew buyers out of the Treasury market.
Patrick Dimick, an analyst with CS First Boston, said there appeared to have been "significant selling" in 10- and 30-year futures against the Israeli debt.
Kevin Flanagan, first vice president and money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the market had recovered some ground in the afternoon as a few investors bought on dips in prices. Volume looked thin, he noted. Over all, he said, the market's meager performance yesterday after the German rate cut was disappointing.
"What's occurring is that people are expecting that the next economic reports won't support the view of an economy that is slowing that much," he said. "The anecdotal evidence is suggesting that maybe some of these reports will be a little more robust than what the market has priced in."
Samuel Kahan, president of A.S.K. Financial Research, agreed that the credit market was concerned about whether the slowdown in the economy that apparently occurred in July would continue.
'We've seen some signs of deceleration -- but only some," Mr. Kahan said. "The major fly in the ointment has been the decline in initial claims for unemployment. The current level is still well below the the range we've been at for the last two years. The question is whether that is just a statistical aberration or a sign that the labor market is heating up."
Today, the market will turn its attention to data on July durable goods orders. Economists expect an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in July after a decline of six-tenth of 1 percent in June.
Mr. Kahan said that if the durable- goods data instead showed a decline, it "would go a long way" toward reassuring people that the deceleration process was continuing.
The market also faces a new supply of Treasury notes coming to the market next week. In when-issued trading, the new two-year note to be sold next week was offered at a price to yield 6 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.37 percent.
In the corporate bond market, prices were also little changed, with the exception of tobacco company debt, which fell further as the industry continued to feel legislative and litigious pressure.
Elsewhere, Citicorp Securities sold $200 million of 12-year notes. The 7.25 percent notes were priced to yield 7.362 percent.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PLAYERS;
Clinton and the Daleys: Friends Again

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
There is no better index of the shifting political fortunes of Bill Clinton than his up-and-down relationship with the Daleys of Chicago, his hosts for the Democratic National Convention next week.
In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton counted on their support in the Illinois primary and in the general election and borrowed some of their aides to give his campaign political savvy. But in 1993 and 1994, the President delivered less than the Daleys thought he had promised in terms of jobs and Federal money for urban problems. They complained publicly about his leadership and privately about his politics, grumbling that he had moved too far left, lost his focus and confused his priorities. 
 "They don't know what they're doing at the White House," William M. Daley said one night several weeks before the 1994 elections. "The Democrats are going to lose the House and the Senate."
Now the Chicago pols and the man from Hope are buddies once more.
For Richard M. Daley, the 54-year-old Mayor of Chicago, and his brother William, 48, the Mayor's chief strategist, the return of the Democrats to their city for the first time since the violent, divisive 1968 convention is a heaven-sent opportunity. Their father, Richard J. Daley, was the Mayor then, and he and his city are remembered by much of the nation and the world for the blood that flowed in the streets as the police battled antiwar demonstrators.
"They want to expunge '68 from people's minds," said a longtime family friend, "and show the world this is a cosmopolitan, progressive city."
To that end, the Mayor has used his clout to round up contributions from businessmen, Republicans prominent among them. And Bill Daley, a prominent lawyer, has served as co-chairman of the host committee for the convention. He has worked hard; by early this week, he had lost almost 15 pounds in the process.
Relations between the White House and the Loop, as Chicagoans call the center of the city, started to improve when Chicago was awarded the convention. They turned even warmer when Mr. Clinton, under the tutelage of his new adviser, Richard Morris, began to sound more like the Democratic centrist he had promised to be -- and the Daleys, like their father, have been since the beginning.
"They agree with what Dick Morris is telling Clinton," said Newton N. Minow, a Chicago lawyer who has been deeply involved in Illinois politics since the Stevenson era. "Get off the crazy stuff. Sign welfare reform, even if it's not perfect. Get back into the middle. That's where you win elections."
Bad feelings between the President and the Daleys began when Bill Daley was passed over for Secretary of Transportation in favor of Federico F. Pena, who was chosen as part of Mr. Clinton's diversity program. Mr. Daley was a good soldier. He swallowed his hurt feelings and went to Washington the next autumn to help push the North American free trade bill through Congress. But in Chicago, where such things matter, the episode was seen as an affront to the Mayor.
"He has to come back through Illinois four years from now," a Daley aide told The Chicago Tribune darkly.
Mayor Daley's candidate for United States Attorney for Northern Illinois, Richard Devine, a longtime friend, also lost out. Frank Kruesi, a former Daley policy chief, got a lesser job in the Transportation Department than he had wanted. And when the President's economic stimulus package failed, Chicago's hopes of money for 1,000 new police officers and $66 million in Federal community development block grants went down with it.
"If he keeps backing off, the people will lose confidence in him," the Mayor said of the President in June 1993. "People want a strong leader. You have to stand for something. What I am basically waiting for is money to put people to work, and money for health programs and education programs, which we were promised. We're still waiting."
That same month the Mayor complained about Mr. Clinton's health care proposals, at a time when the President needed all the friends he could get. A staunch ally of Chicago business, Mr. Daley maintained that requiring even small companies to provide health care coverage would only stunt their growth or drive them out of business completely and thereby add to the welfare rolls.
The next summer, just as negotiations for the convention were about to culminate, David Wilhelm, the Mayor's former campaign manager, was forced out as chairman of the Democratic National Committee by Leon E. Panetta, the new White House chief of staff. Mr. Wilhelm, once hailed as a young spark, at the end was derided as too young at 37 to do the job.
Mayor Daley spoke with considerable resentment about Harold M. Ickes, a top White House official who was often seen as a Wilhelm rival. Far more liberal than either Mr. Morris, his rival at the moment for the President's ear, or the Daleys, Mr. Ickes continues to arouse their suspicions.
But the convention made it necessary to smooth such things over. It was a good deal for both Washington and Chicago, the President wanting to court the electorally pivotal Midwest and the Daleys wanting to showcase the city on national and international television.
Richard M. Daley looks a bit like his father and shares his social awkwardness and predisposition for malapropisms, if not his iron-fisted control of city and state political organizations. Bald, measured and well-spoken, William Daley is not so evidently a chip off the old block. But both resent any suggestion that they have anything to apologize for when it comes to 1968.
When State Senator Tom Hayden of California, one of the Chicago Seven who organized the 1968 protests, proposed to plant a commemorative weeping willow in Grant Park, the staging area for the protesters, the Mayor declined to attend. But he accepted an invitation to a concert from Mr. Hayden, who is a delegate to this year's convention.
Still, it seems unlikely the Daleys will ever eradicate, at least for the generation that was involved, memories of the most dramatic confrontation in a year that was full of them.
It happened on the third night of the convention. On the podium, the dapper, silver-haired Abraham Ribicoff, Senator from Connecticut, was denouncing what he termed the "Gestapo tactics" of the police, who that evening had clubbed antiwar protesters and innocent bystanders in downtown Chicago.
Below him, on the floor of the convention, was Mayor Richard J. Daley, beefy and bellicose, the chairman of his state's delegation to the convention. The television cameras picked up his image as he cupped his hands to his mouth and shouted an epithet at his fellow Democrat. The sound of his words was lost in the turbulence of the moment, but it was not hard to read his lips.
Mayor Richard M. Daley, though a delegate this year, has chosen not to head the delegation.

Daley of Chicago chatted with Carmen Lomelin, a former member of his staff who is now a Presidential aide, on a visit yesterday to the United Center, site of the Democratic National Convention. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: With Welfare Overhaul Now Law, States Grapple With the Consequences

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Even as President Clinton signed the welfare bill, the biggest shift in social policy since the Depression, many state officials across the country say they are nowhere near ready to assume the greater control the measure grants them of the nation's vast welfare system.
Many state officials who supported the law now acknowledge, as they read the fine print, that it is in some ways tougher on recipients, and in other ways less flexible for state governments, than some had envisioned. Some provisions did not coalesce until the final hours in negotiations with the White House and Congressional leaders. 
 For one thing, even the 45 states that have already received permission to experiment with their own welfare programs will have to meet a strict standard of having a quarter of their welfare recipients working by next year, or face losing some of their Federal financing. In the first weeks after the bill was passed, officials in some of those states had thought they would be exempt from that provision for several years, until their Federally approved experiments ended.
It is also unclear whether states will be able to keep recipients on the rolls beyond the new law's five-year lifetime limit.
Other officials, in interviews, said they were still confused by the nuts and bolts of the final bill, with its host of riders they are still examining. "I don't think anyone out there has the whole bill figured out yet," said Douglas Howard, administrator of the Iowa Division of Economic Assistance. "I think there's a lot of anxiety."
Marilynn Knipp, an associate director of the Missouri Department of Social Services said, "It's a maze and a tangle." Jack Tweedie, welfare policy specialist at the National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver, said, "The word is confusion."
Typical of the confusion is a part of the legislation that would seem simple -- the definition of "work." The ultimate purpose of the law is to put able-bodied welfare recipients to work. But many states count a broad array of job-training and education programs as work, while the new law's definition is much more restrictive.
 
Turmoil Ahead In States and Cities
As they parse the technicalities, officials are contemplating a new chapter in the welfare debate, one that will be waged outside of Washington.
By all accounts, there will be political battles in capitals across the country, as big cities like New York, Chicago and Detroit compete with suburban and rural communities for resources. Many will have to make tough choices that will certainly provoke debate, particularly whether to extend support to people whom the Federal system will no longer fully protect, like impoverished childless adults, noncitizens, and children whose parents refuse to get jobs or fail to get work by the deadline.
Some states are far along in getting ready for the changes. For example, in Wisconsin and Michigan, whose welfare systems were the prototypes for the new law, officials say they will be ready by this fall to submit plans describing how they will comply, and to start tapping the block grants Washington will allot them. "We will be sending our plan out for comment even as the President signs the bill," said Gerald H. Miller, director of Michigan's Family Independence Agency.
But interviews with welfare officials in more than 20 states, and with groups that track state politics, show that most states are far from drafting plans that all must submit to the Department of Health and Human Services by July 1. "We're going to have to go through months and months of discussions," said Ronald L. Rhodes, spokesman for the Ohio Department of Social Services.
And even though they have most of a year to submit proposals, now that Mr. Clinton has signed the bill, they must immediately begin dealing with some of the law's provisions, like those cutting aid the Federal Government will still provide -- food stamps and disability checks -- to legal immigrants who have been in the country for less than 10 years.
In other provisions, the legislation requires that recipients be working within two years of receiving their first welfare check; if not, they lose their benefits. It also places a five-year lifetime limit on cash benefits, except for the 20 percent of the welfare cases that states may determine to have special hardships, like the burden of caring for a disabled child. States can pay for more aid if they want, but the money must come from their own resources.
Vera Blakes, an assistant secretary of the Social Services Department in Louisiana, a poor and generally conservative state that supports lowering the welfare rolls, described what the bill's provisions could mean. "A child could very well have to go to foster care," she said. "Parents will say, 'I have a six-year education, and I can't find a job. I can't afford to care for this child.' "
"It takes a lot to give up a child," she continued. "But imagine a child sitting over there with no place to sleep. It sounds like Charles Dickens, but people will have to make those decisions."
With the ink on Mr. Clinton's signature barely dry, some officials in the Administration and Congress are suggesting that during the new term after the election, Congress may decide to modify the provisions affecting legal immigrants. "We can change what is wrong," the President said during the signing ceremony in reiterating his discomfort with the bill's curbs on aid to legal immigrants. Indeed, many of the President's liberal political supporters have said all along that they are hoping the bill will be softened after this year's election.
Two possible approaches are to establish a fund of several billion dollars that states could use to help immigrants move from welfare to jobs, or to delay the immigrant provisions by a year.
But the immigrant provisions offer major budget savings in the bill, and so changing them may be difficult to accomplish.
In most states, the main effects of the law's principal provision -- replacing Federal cash assistance to welfare recipients with block grants to states over which they have more control -- will not be felt immediately. Indeed, over the next two years, because of various technicalities, most states will actually get more in their block grants than they did under the old program.
But the total amount for all block grants, $16.4 billion, will remain the same until 2002, with no allowance for either inflation or population growth, so states will feel the pinch within a few years.
 
Coming to Terms With the Details
 At this point, most states are still just grappling with the details. All agree that the welfare system needed an overhaul to promote jobs and and self-sufficiency instead of lifetime dependence. Many complain about some features of the law but see them in the context of a change they all endorse.
"There's a lot of different attitudes, from, 'Oh, my God, this is a disaster,' to 'It's about time we made recipients go to work,' " Mr. Tweedie said. "This is a huge task, but they're very interested in ideas on how to accomplish it."
From the moment three weeks ago when the President said he would sign the bill, states have been hounding the Administration for guidance.
"We've been talking with H.H.S. on a daily basis," Claudette Beaulieu, spokeswoman for Connecticut's Social Services Department, said of the Federal Department of Health and Human Services. Since last week, Mary Jo Bane, the assistant secretary at the Federal agency who oversees welfare, has been conducting conference calls with state officials.
But Peter Leousis, North Carolina's assistant secretary for children, youth and family in the state's Human Resources Department, said the Federal agency often did not have the answers. "In some respects they know no more than we do."
To help states understand the law, the National Governors' Association, the National Conference of State Legislatures and the American Public Welfare Association have called a special conference here of 300 to 400 state administrators for Sept. 9 and 10. Regional conferences are scheduled, too. "I'm taking 40 to 50 calls a day," said Elaine Ryan, the welfare association's expert on the law.
One of the major problems has to do with how the bill defines work. The definition is crucial because the law will cut 5 percent from a state's block grant unless 25 percent of its welfare recipients are "working," according to the law's meaning, at least 20 hours a week by next year. Each year after that, the state can lose an additional 2 percent if it does not place more people in "work."
The bill takes a more restrictive view than many state officials do of what is "work." For example, the bill counts no more than four consecutive weeks of job hunting as work, while many state officials, who say finding a job can take much longer, would prefer to permit several months of job searching as work.
Many states also disagree with how the bill counts training and education as work. The legislation considers training in a specific skill as work, while some states count as work a wide range of job-training programs, including a two- to four-year liberal-arts education.
Deborah Huskins, assistant commissioner in Minnesota's Department of Human Services, raised another, quite different, issue, concerning how the law determines who is working. If welfare recipients get jobs that pay well enough to free them of all public assistance, they would not be counted, under the law, among the 25 percent of the state caseload that must be working. Ms. Huskins said states will have no reason to help people get well-paid jobs if such employment leads to cuts in Federal money to the state.
She said the law "has set up a perverse incentive for states to keep people on public assistance and in low-paying jobs because that counts toward meeting the work percentages."
Many state officials are also concerned about the law's work requirements because the economy could fall into a recession, making jobs harder to get, and because employers often are not eager to hire long-term welfare recipients who never learned the disciplines of work.
"We've been looking at job projections," said Jean Ross, executive director of the California Budget Project, a nonpartisan research group in Sacramento. "The question nobody has asked is, 'Are there jobs for these people?' "
 
Questions Linger Over Time Limits
Another contentious issue concerns the general five-year lifetime limit on welfare. Through waivers, some states have established different time limits, some longer and some shorter, but under the new law, the longer limits are no longer valid. Although earlier this week, the District of Columbia received permission to keep recipients on the rolls longer, it is still unclear whether other states will either seek or be granted such permission.
Meanwhile, the bill contains some provisions that venture into social engineering by encouraging both marriage and abstinence. Under one provision, the Government will pay $20 million in annual bonuses to each of the five states that record the sharpest reductions in illegitimate births each year from 1999 to 2002. Under another, the law allocates $400 million to states to teach abstinence and nothing for other means of birch control.
Officials are also concerned that the new law will foster tensions among cities, counties and statehouses as people are shed from the welfare rolls, and turn up at the shelters and soup kitchens of local charities and governments.
"I'm concerned," said Reagan Wilson, chief executive of Stanislaus County, California. He said 85,000 people in a county population of 425,000 are on some form of welfare. "The most immediate impact will be on legal immigrants," he said.
Ms. Huskins said, "The old program doesn't work for families," adding, "We certainly endorse the overall direction toward work."
"But it's hard to become enthusiastic," she continued. "We were willing to take the block grant as long as we had flexibility to decide what we should be doing. Instead we got a great deal of prescriptions and a lot of details as far as what counts as work and what counts as success" in moving recipients into jobs.

HEADLINE: Supply-Side Policy Wrecked U.S. Exports

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alan S. Blinder's critique of Bob Dole's supply-side revisionism ("The Republican Riverboat Gamble," Op-Ed, Aug. 20) is right on target.
However, he fails to mention the one additional devastating consequence of the Reagan tax cuts during the early 1980's: the dramatic 35 percent real appreciation of the United States dollar against the Japanese yen and currencies of Western Europe. 
 This appreciation, which resulted from the increased real growth and the high real interest rates induced by President Reagan's supply-side policies, effectively decimated the United States export sector in the 1980's. It was like handing a 35 percent pricing advantage to our German and Japanese competitors worldwide, thus rendering uncompetitive many export-based United States companies.
The one bright spot in the recent recovery has been the re-emergence of export-based manufacturing, especially in the former rust belt. However, these sectors are now under increased pressure because of the recent reversal in the value of the dollar.
Mr. Dole's promised tax cuts and the predictable response of the Federal Reserve on interest rates may well wreck the resurgence of his "heartland" with their likely adverse impact on the dollar's value.
 
ANANT K. SUNDARAM
Glendale, Ariz., Aug. 20, 1996

HEADLINE: Abortion Debate Isn't Fueled by Economics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Susan Faludi, in "The G.O.P.'s Back Stairs" (Op-Ed, Aug. 18), rightly calls attention to the rarely mentioned class factor in the abortion debate. Her reasoning seems tortured, however, in arguing that economic resentments are fundamental to the mind-set of the anti-abortion movement. If they were, most anti-abortionists would be Socialists or at least welfare-state liberals.
In fact, most agree with the Republican Party on economic as well as social issues. No group promoted Newt Gingrich's Contract With America more than the Christian Coalition. An employee may resent his boss's power over him, but that power doesn't depend on her position on abortion. 
 Moreover, millions of anti-abortionists are neither poorer nor more religious nor less educated than average Americans, just as millions of pro-choicers are neither richer nor less religious nor more educated than average.
The resentment that drives anti-abortionists is of a different character. It is not directed chiefly against economic privilege but is rooted in a puritanism whose political manifestations have been America's myriad prohibitionist crusades that have sought to outlaw acts that take place between consenting adults and harm no one's person or property.
The most important thread running through such crusades is neither religious fanaticism nor resentment of economic power by the powerless, though both are factors, but rather a puritan resentment of those who partake of a wide variety of pleasures generally foreign to the experience, if not the capacity, of the resentful.
That resentment seeks to punish deviations from the morality prescribed. It also explains why many of today's anti-abortionists think abortion should be legal when pregnancies result from rape or incest.
 
BRADLEY MILLER
Washington, Aug. 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COMPANY: CHRISTIAN COALITION (57%); CHRISTIAN COALITION (57%);

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against the Mark On Interest Rate Cut in Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the mark and most other currencies yesterday after Germany's central bank made a surprisingly large cut in an important short-term interest rate.
The cut in the Bundesbank's securities repurchase, or repo, rate, to 3 percent from 3.30 percent, was intended to stimulate the German economy, the biggest in Europe. It was the first decrease in German rates in four months. 
 There had been widespread expectations that the rate would be reduced because German growth has been slow and inflation has been subdued. But the size of the reduction was double what the foreign-exchange market had anticipated.
Some traders had prepared for the possibility that the Bundesbank's policy-making council might leave rates unchanged because of anecdotal evidence that the economic recovery was accelerating.
"I'd say the cut was the big catalyst today," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "The size of the cut certainly surprised the market to a degree."
Lower rates weaken the mark by diminishing demand for mark-denominated assets. But they can stimulate Germany's economy by lowering borrowing costs and helping exporters. A cheaper mark makes German goods more affordable abroad.
The dollar hit a high of 1.4960 marks before retreating a bit in the afternoon as traders sought to lock in profits. The dollar also ended slightly lower against the yen, partly because the Japanese currency also rebounded against the mark on the Bundesbank's decision.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4918 marks, up from 1.4825 on Wednesday. The dollar stood at 108.20 yen, down from 108.46 Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.5505 from $1.5500.
Though the Bundesbank's action vindicated forecasts of a rate cut, many traders said the size of the reduction suggested that it was the final step in a series of cuts made intermittently by the central bank since 1992. This partly explained why the dollar did not rally further and remains within the 1.4700-1.5000 mark range where it has been for the last few months.

HEADLINE: Despite Drop, Rate of Layoffs Remains High

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The layoff rate in the mid-1990's declined slightly from the early years of the decade but remained well above a comparable period a decade earlier, the Labor Department reported today.
The department's survey, done every two years and the most comprehensive count available of jobs lost in this downsizing era, portrayed a work force still experiencing frequent job losses even as unemployment has shrunk and the economy has expanded at a steady pace. A total of 8.4 million people were pushed out of their jobs involuntarily from 1993 through 1995, the Labor Department reported. That represented 1 out of every 14 jobholders, compared with 1 out of 12 in the early 1990's. 
 Americans who lost jobs found new ones more easily and in larger numbers than in the early 1990's. Indeed, the economy has added more than 10 million new jobs since 1993. But those who were laid off for good from their jobs showed little progress in trying to match their old wages. Only 33 percent earned as much as or more than they had before.
"You still have many layoffs," Thomas Nardone, a supervising economist at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, said, "and if you lose your job, most people don't end up in situations that are as good in terms of earnings as the jobs they lost."
The much-awaited survey results, considered a bedrock statistic in the debate over economic insecurity, immediately entered the election campaign. Advisers to Bob Dole's Presidential campaign declared that the survey reflected a work force still suffering from job insecurity and wage stagnation. The Clinton Administration cited the survey as evidence that "times are better" and the worst of the job losses were over.
The 8.4 million jobs eliminated represented a decline of 7 percent from the 9 million lost in the three years ending in 1993, the Bureau of Labor Statistics calculated. The earlier years were mostly a time of recession and sluggish economic growth. But while the number of jobs lost fell, it did not decline by as much as it had in the mid-1980's, when the economy was at a similar stage following a recession.
"Basically, we are living in a situation in which the public mood is that jobs are at risk," said Henry Farber, a Princeton University labor economist. But he added that the latest data showed that the situation was not as bad as some people thought. "There is absolutely no evidence here for people who take the gloomy view that job loss rates are up."
The Labor Department began its "job displacement" surveys in 1984, when widespread permanent layoffs were just becoming a national issue. Those surveys, which measured the elimination of jobs beginning in 1979, found that permanent job losses fell sharply after the 1981-1982 recession, then rose again for the 1990-1991 recession. (Temporary layoffs are not counted.)
But after the early 1990's recession, they failed to ease by as much as they had before. The data released today showed that from 1993 through 1995, the jobs of about 7.2 percent of the work force were eliminated, the Bureau of Labor Statistics calculated. By comparison, at the same stage in the recovery after the early 1980's recession, between 5.5 percent and 6.5 percent of the nation's jobholders were laid off.
"These numbers suggest a long-term upward trend as a natural cost of having a more competitive economy," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The New York Times, in a series of articles on downsizing in March, combined the Government's job displacement data into a single set of figures that reconciled overlapping numbers from different surveys. Using this data, and employing a moving average technique, The Times estimated that a total of 43.5 million job losses occurred from 1979 through 1995. That series included projections for the years 1994 and 1995 that showed a modest decline in the number of jobs lost. Substituting the actual data for the projections produced a total of 43.3 million jobs lost for the 17-year period, including nearly 10 million from 1993 through 1995.
The Times' series on downsizing and the projections on job loss drew criticism for exaggerating the problem. An article in The New Yorker quoted the White House's chief economist, Joseph E. Stiglitz, as saying that The Times' projections for the years 1994 and 1995 should be taken "with a grain of salt."
In fact, the newly released figures show that the number of jobs lost was not quite as high as The Times projected in March -- 2.7 percent fewer in 1994 and 4.7 percent fewer in 1995. But the rates of job loss remained noticeably above those for the years 1986 and 1987, when the economy was at a similar point of recovery from a recession. A major point of The Times series was that job loss, measured as a percentage of the work force, had remained higher than in past recoveries.
The writer of the New Yorker article, John Cassidy, did not reply to two telephone messages left late today.
The survey showed that job loss in the mid-1990's continued to display the characteristics that first showed up in the late 1980's and early 1990's. White-collar workers represented 52 percent of those who lost jobs and blue-collar workers 35 percent, much different from the early 1980's, when layoffs were largely a blue-collar phenomenon. Men still edged out women, 56 percent to 44 percent, but women edged up two percentage points from the early 1990's while men slipped by the same amount.
People in their prime working years, 25 to 54, still represented the overwhelming majority of those laid off: 78 percent, up a percentage point from the early 1990's. Only older men, 55 to 64 years old, showed slightly more resistance to layoffs than they had shown in the early 1990's, falling to 8 percent from 9 percent.
The survey, covering 50,000 representative households, found that 73 percent of those who lost their jobs from 1993 through 1995 were employed again when the survey was done last February, compared with 68 percent in the early 1990's. Only 9.8 percent listed themselves as job-hunting and unemployed, down from 13.1 percent in the earlier period.
"Things are better," Mr. Stiglitz said, crediting the Administration's economic policies. The American labor market, he said, "is creating enough jobs for new entrants to the labor force and almost three-quarters of all displaced workers."
But he acknowledged that wages were another matter. Of those who lost full-time jobs in 1993 and 1994, some 33 percent had landed new full-time jobs by last February that paid as much or more as the ones they had lost, the report found. That was up slightly from 31 percent in the early 1990's.
Nearly 27 percent, the same percentage as in the early 1990's, had taken jobs that paid less than what they had earned before. Most of the remaining 40 percent were unemployed, or had given up job hunting and had dropped out of the labor force, or were self-employed.
But while Mr. Stiglitz highlighted the rise in the re-employment rate from the early 1990's and the decline in permanent layoffs, a dimmer view came from John B. Taylor, a Stanford University economist and a chief Dole economic adviser. "The job loss rate is high for this stage of a recovery," he said. "It is hard to see any of the improvement that the Administration claims. Job insecurity is still widespread."

HEADLINE: Cyber-House Financing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was shocked to see Karl E. Meyer describe my house as a "charmless techno-villa" that is the result of "Reagan-era tax cuts" (Editorial Notebook, Aug. 18). While your esthetic interest is flattering, I must protest your maligning the Reagan revolution. But shouldn't this be beside the point in any case? 
 For the sake of the Republic, I hope that the continuing debate on tax policies will focus on societal and economic effects, rather than on architectural arcana.
 
CHARLES SIMONYI

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cotton Prices Surge on Concerns About Rainfall From Hurricane

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Cotton prices surged yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange over concern that Hurricane Dolly could bring unwanted rain to southern Texas and Arizona, possibly hurting crops.
On other markets, crude oil prices fell while copper rose. 
 The hurricane, which reached land near Tampico, Mexico, yesterday morning, was expected to bring more than an inch of rain to farmland in southeastern Texas and could cause heavy showers in areas as far west as Arizona.
While those areas have suffered from dry weather, the rains come after the cotton bolls have opened, potentially reducing the size of the crop and its quality.
At the same time, consumption by American textile mills has increased, and exports began to pick up after disappointing traders earlier his year.
"There's a little bit of concern coming out of that hurricane; it's certainly not beneficial," said Scott Coleman, vice president at the Coleman Brothers Cotton Company in Memphis. "Also, you had decent exports and better-than-expected consumption, so there's been a small flurry of bullish news."
Cotton for December delivery rose 1.5 cents. to 74.95 cents a pound.
Crude oil prices fell, retreating from Thursday's gains, after Mexico's state oil company said it had reopened three export terminals as the hurricane passed.
The storm's path across the Yucatan peninsula and up the Gulf of Mexico had prompted Petroleos Mexicanos to shut its three main ports for three days as a precaution.
The company said yesterday that it had reopened the ports, and exports to the United States had resumed.
October crude oil fell 34 cents, to $21.96 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Copper rose after a report showed a jump in demand for durable goods, products that include communications equipment, aircraft and automobiles, which contain large amounts of copper. Orders for durable goods rose 1.6 percent in July, the Commerce Department said.
September copper rose 1.05 cents, to 91.7 cents a pound, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
