HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
For most Americans, the only good tax is a smaller one. Not only is it every American's unalienable right to speak evil of taxation, in election season it is every politician's duty.
Most voters might be surprised to discover how little support this ingrained attitude gets from the nation's three longstanding religious traditions. 
 Rabbi David Wolpe, for example, came to the phone just after watching a speaker declare on C-Span recently that taxation is thievery. "Judaism's view is just the opposite," said Rabbi Wolpe, the assistant to the chancellor at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York. "As far back as the Bible, where you owed tithes of all sorts, there has always been an obligation to contribute to the good of the whole."
What the Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, a former official at the National Conference of Catholic Bishops who teaches social ethics at Harvard Divinity School, said that Roman Catholics' attitudes toward paying taxes was probably true of most Americans: "It's always news to Catholics to hear that something they regard as (a) totally secular and (b) nothing but a burden, is in fact the exercise of a virtue."
For Father Hehir, the key is the Catholic belief that the human person is inherently a social creature and has natural duties toward others. The state, using taxes, is one vehicle, though not the only one, that fulfills those duties.
As for what the Rev. Max Stackhouse, the Stephen Colwell Professor of Christian Ethics at Princeton Theological Seminary, calls the "classical tradition" in Protestantism, it has almost always taught that "there is a positive duty to support the political powers."
Only the sectarian, generally pacifist wing of Protestantism has radically challenged Christians' involvement with the state, he said.
James Skillen, the director of the Center for Public Justice, a religious research and educational group based in Annapolis, Md., even questioned the religious basis for Bob Dole's declaration that "it's your money" that government is spending as it wishes. The center has working ties with conservative evangelicals as well as centrist denominations.
Government, Mr. Skillen said, has been ordained by God to carry out certain tasks of protecting the society and assuring justice. What citizens owe for those tasks is not, in fact, their own money but the government's -- and how it is to be spent is quite properly decided by the political process and public officials.
"The prejudice that we can start with the assumption that someone is stealing your money," he said, "seems to me to be the wrong place to start."
None of these authorities pretend that his own religious tradition dictates a specific tax system or whether to increase the exemption for children or reduce the tax rate on capital gains. And though the traditions do insist that government must be limited, they do not prescribe exactly where the limits should fall. All that is the legitimate stuff of campaign debate.
What campaign debate often fosters, however, is less legitimate in the eyes of these traditions: the attitude that taxes are nothing but an unavoidable evil, or at least as unavoidable as one's tax lawyer can make them.
One person who has studied these questions in detail is Rabbi Aaron Levine, the Samson and Halina Bitensky Professor of Economics at Yeshiva University and the author of three books jointly published by KTAV Publishing House and Yeshiva University Press ("Free Enterprise and Jewish Law," 1980; "Economics and Jewish Law," 1987, and "Economic Public Policy and Jewish Law," 1993).
From the first century of this era, Jewish sages discussed the principles of levying taxes for building a town wall, the ancient equivalent of national defense. Could everyone be compelled to pay? Should everyone pay equally, or should wealthy households, with more at risk, pay more? What about those closer to the wall who would otherwise be especially vulnerable to marauders? Should the rules be different if the town abutted on enemy territory or was far from it?
Needless to say, the Talmudic commentators so thoroughly explored every argument that Rabbi Levine can easily link their reasoning to modern economic concepts of public goods, Pareto Optimality, free riders and intertemporal resource allocation.
For those not absorbed by the thrust and parry of Talmudic texts, the ethical bottom line, Rabbi Levine said, is that taxation is not only justified for governmental responsibilities like national defense and police protection but also for a wider range of social welfare measures, including the prevention and relief of poverty. And the rabbis said this taxation should be "proportional."
Prevention of poverty by generating employment has a higher priority than relief, Rabbi Levine argues, in keeping with Maimonides's teaching that the highest form of charity is helping the needy help themselves. As a rabbi, the Yeshiva professor said that "workfare is right on the mark"; but as an economist he rejected Mr. Dole's supply-side strategy for generating growth and jobs, calling it "totally repudiated by the record."
So what about flattening the tax rate? All of these religious leaders thought their traditions leaned toward a progressive system in which not just the amount but also the proportion one pays increases with income. But they acknowledged that this preference might be outweighed by practical considerations of economic efficiency.
Rabbi Levine said that Judaism's sages had taught that the tax burden ought to be shared "proportionally" without ever clarifying what that meant. He said he believed that the case for a progressive tax system, because it built in "automatic stabilizers" against economic tailspins or overheating, derived from Jewish law's injunction that government maintain economic stability.
To the extent that the state can assure social welfare in ways the private sector cannot, Americans should pay their taxes "with equanimity," Rabbi Levine said. Indeed, within a minute or so of conversation, he said it again. Equanimity? Taxes? Americans? There is a man who believes in the power of God.

HEADLINE: Replenishing Beaches Protects Mainland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Fire Island is not eroding as "the inevitable effect of a rising sea level" as Orrin Pilkey suggests ("Sand-Castle Mentality on Fire Island," Op-Ed, Aug. 18).
The highest observed rate of sea-level rise is less than a foot a century, and even that estimate is subject to question, as Mr. Pilkey's own book, "The Corps and the Shore," notes. 
 The real cause of erosion on Fire Island is blockage of sand by the Westhampton groin field and failure to bypass sand around Moriches Inlet's jetties and deltas.
Nor does the Army Corps of Engineers want "to help homeowners by bringing in new sand." The proposed project, justified on the protection it will provide to the mainland, is based on a cost-benefit analysis. The recreational value of Fire Island is not even considered.
Mr. Pilkey would plug holes in the island as they occur. But engineers say a hole in western Fire Island, near the lighthouse, would cause its inlet to close and a new inlet would have to be stabilized. This would cost far more than replenishing the beaches.
Mr. Pilkey supports the Corps' Breach Contingency Plan, which was based on a recommendation of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Coastal Erosion Task Force.
But the task force recognized that if the sand nature intended to move along barrier islands is not there, breaches (and mainland flooding) are inevitable. Thus, the other recommendations of the task force -- modification of the Westhampton groin field, bypassing sand at inlets and replenishment of the island -- equally deserve his support.
Fire Island's 32 miles of beach are open to the public and are used by millions each year. Add to that economic estimates that the island accounts for $1 billion a year to Long Island's $10 billion tourist industry and it is clear that Mr. Pilkey's theories of coastal retreat are not relevant to New York.
With the exception of erosion control, New York State has done a good job of preserving its beaches and shores and is improving on public accessibility. Mr. Pilkey's theories would be the ruination of those beaches.
 
GERARD STODDARD
New York, Aug. 19, 1996
 
The writer is president of the Fire Island Association, a property owners' group.

HEADLINE: Bonds Fall After Durable Goods Orders Surge

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Probably the last thing investors wanted to see yesterday, was strong economic data showing the manufacturing sector expanding at a brisk pace, even though there were suspicions. But it happened, and prices of government securities fell sharply as a result.
Investors sold the long maturities, moving to the short end of the market, fearing the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates sooner rather than later. 
 To be sure, there were also other dynamics at work in the market -- options expirations, repositioning of portfolios by dealers ahead of Treasury auctions next week and a glut of fresh numbers late in the week.
The 30-year bond fell 110/32 to a price of 9715/32 to yield 6.95 percent, up from 6.83 percent on Thursday and the highest since July 31, when it was 6.97 percent.
In futures trading, which affects the cash market for current issues, traders said the September bond contract might have lost more were it not for options expirations yesterday. "Nevertheless," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston, "the September bond futures contract was moving in only one direction yesterday, and it wasn't up. The session's high price was 11016/32 , and at the close it was 10917/32 , down a full point from the previous day."
Jack Regan, chief derivatives strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the latest data would seem to indicate that the early June and July numbers that caused perceptions of a weakening economy may have been an aberration.
"The July durable goods order today showed strength across the board," Mr. Regan said. "And amidst the slow summer trade we have supply looming next week in the way of two- and five-year notes. With many traders as well as investors on holiday, the demand may very well be on the light side."
Between options expiration and dealers repositioning themselves for next week, market volume was higher than an average summer Friday, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service. "In fact," said Maureen Mooney, market analyst with the firm, "it was 18 percent higher." She noted that activity in the two-year when-issued note was heavy and was about 66 percent higher than normal volume on a Friday before an auction. The two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.10 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.48 percent.
Behind much of yesterday's activity was the Commerce Department's report that durable goods orders for July were up a strong 1.6 percent from June. That leaves the Fed policy outlook uncertain at best.
"Benign inflation has allowed the Fed to be patient in its wait for signs of an economic slowdown, and this trend should persist," said Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco. "Yet, the Fed may lose patience. Upcoming data from the National Association of Purchasing Management and the employment report will be crucial for the Fed," in deciding whether to tighten monetary policy in September, she continued, "especially prices, vendor deliveries and wages."
Yesterday's report raised fears that recent strong statistics coupled with an expected sharp rise in August payrolls could lead to another bout of selling for fear of a rate increase.
Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York, noted that there was aggressive selling before the durables report, and said she had heard rumors of a leak. "Over all," Ms. Adolfson said, "the feeling was that durable goods cemented the view that July might have been an aberration. But now I think we have already seen weak retail sales bounce back, and housing is moderate. Now the durable goods numbers tell us that there is strength across the board."
She also pointed to overseas markets getting stronger, suggesting that exports will soon add to growth. "Jobless claims numbers continue to be low and are still at 1989 prerecession levels, showing good jobs growth," she added. "But with that comes income, supporting consumer expansion."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RANK AND FILE;
Democrats' Left Wing Keeps Its Power Dry

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Haunting the Democratic Presidential convention next week in Chicago will be the liberal impulse of stormy conventions past.
"I expect people, liberals, to come out protesting," said Jack Sheinkman, president of Americans for Democratic Action, the liberal lobby. 
 Mr. Sheinkman is a strong supporter of President Clinton who would nevertheless welcome some unscripted heat in protest of the President's acceptance of the Republican-led Congress's severe changes in the welfare system.
"Outside the hall, inside the hall, I expect it," said Mr. Sheinkman, a lifelong liberal and textile union organizer. He fondly recalls a time when liberals had not yet retreated to the label "progressives" in the face of Republican attack advertisements, popular skepticism and the Democrats' fall from majority power in Congress.
George Stephanopoulos, the President's senior adviser whose mother's milk in politics was the liberal agenda of local candidates, expects some protests over welfare next week, saying, "It will be hard to avoid."
But Mr. Stephanopoulos argues that in accepting and altering the Republicans' welfare overhaul, the President eliminated "the battering ram of words that for years was used to beat liberals over the head" -- the widespread stereotype of liberals' genuflecting at the altar of preserving welfare, if not enlarging it.
"The caricature of liberalism is dead," Mr. Stephanopoulos insisted. "We had to kill the caricature to save the essentials."
That thesis might fascinate such memorable convention speakers as former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, one of the most articulate liberals. But Mr. Cuomo, a proponent of the President's candidacy but decidedly not of his welfare bill, does not yet have final approval to speak. Campaign managers are considering an outline of his likely remarks.
Mr. Stephanopoulos defended the President's election-year profile as a centrist compromiser rather than the sort of intransigent liberal image that led to routs of Democrats in four of the last six Presidential elections. True liberalism is alive, if not strutting, at the party convention and can be found in a raft of Clinton initiatives, from gun controls to judgeship appointments, he said.
John Lewis, a young civil rights insurgent at the 1968 convention and now a Congressman from Georgia, agreed with that, even as he denounced the President's decision not to veto the welfare overhaul. "I don't think we as liberals will be in retreat next week," Mr. Lewis said. "Many of the same liberals who led causes at the '68 convention will be back playing major roles this time inside the hall, very much in force."
Mr. Clinton's convention managers have made clear that, far from tolerating any floor-baiting by dissatisfied delegates, liberal or otherwise, they are intent on duplicating the telegenic sheen of the Republicans' recent convention, where seldom was heard a discouraging prime-time word. The sort of liberal anti-Vietnam War insurgency that rocked the 1968 Chicago convention would present a public relations nightmare for the Clinton agents planning a tableau of unity, even if honest, untoward protest might re-arouse the curiosity of Ted Koppell and other journalists left glassy-eyed in San Diego.
A baseline measure of the current state of liberalism may be that there has not been a whimper of an election-year challenge to the President from within the party. Mr. Clinton's careful self-design as a venturesome moderate showed he learned the lesson of 1984, when Walter F. Mondale, the last down-the-line liberal to win the Democratic nomination, lost 49 states to Ronald Reagan.
In that campaign, the Republicans hammered home the stereotype of the liberal as a naive moralizer and Big Government grifter -- the straw man Tolstoy skewered a century ago: "I sit on a man's back, choking him and making him carry me, and yet assure myself and others that I am very sorry for him and wish to ease his lot by all possible means -- except by getting off his back."
"Most liberals use the word 'progressive' now," said Robert Borosage, co-director of the Campaign for America's Future, a progressive group designed to counter the President's moderate Democratic Leadership Council. "That took place after a combination of the Mondale and Dukakis debacles, where liberals got defined in part by their failure to defend themselves from Republican attacks that they were more concerned with a civil liberty, social elite agenda, as opposed to bread-and-butter populist economics."
Far from scandalized at the disappearance of the L-word, Mr. Borosage finds it a "good reflection" of a history in which, he said, progressives return to the political forefront at times of economic distress, when -- as Mr. Borosage says is happening now -- working-class voters become incensed at the increased power of business and income disparity.
No less an authority than Hillary Rodham Clinton looked askance in a television interview last May at the very suggestion of hidden liberal influences on the President.
"There is no left wing of the Clinton White House," she emphasized.
Lately, pickets furious at the President's welfare action have confronted him at public events. Some of the most unabashed liberals expect little more in Chicago than discreet protests in the designated pens, off camera beyond the hall, with scant disruption of a television show rich in determined unity and the quietude of non-controversy.
"Just as the Republicans switched in San Diego to what we always did -- showing diversity by showcasing their few blacks and women," said Representative Carrie P. Meek of Florida, "so we're switching the other way toward their thing, moderate stuff, squarely to the middle, a little to the right."
Ms. Meek accepts that for the sake of the President's re-election, guessing that Mr. Clinton does have a liberal heart even if he dares not speak that word. But she warned that she might be caught yawning amid the truly "radical" environment of Democratic harmony.
"I very definitely regret it," she said, nostalgic for bare-knuckled conventioneering.

HEADLINE: Strong Durable Goods Data Revive Fear of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods surged in July, jumping 1.6 percent. That was considerably more than analysts had expected and cast new doubt on assumptions that the economy was slowing from its unsustainable fast pace of the spring.
The broadly based advance, which would have been more than twice as large had it not been for a plunge in orders from the Pentagon, drove bond prices lower, raising interest rates. Traders feared the report would make the Federal Reserve more likely to tighten monetary policy. The stock market also fell. 
 Indeed, after the close of trading on the East Coast, the central bank disclosed that at its policy meeting in early July it had shifted to a bias toward tightening, with one member favoring an immediate increase in short-term interest rates.
"The most likely outcome was a slowing of the expansion to a more sustainable pace and a continuation of subdued inflation," the central bank's minutes showed, summarizing majority opinion of the 12 voting members of its Open Market Committee. "Nevertheless," the summary added, "they were concerned that the risks to that outcome were tilted toward higher inflation."
In the seven weeks since that meeting, evidence has mounted that the economy is throttling back as desired, and the Fed held off raising rates when it met last Tuesday. But the strong orders for long-lived goods like cars and machinery reported by the Commerce Department today caused some analysts to rethink their positions.
"The durable goods report certainly increases the likelihood that the data in early August sent the wrong signal about growth slowing," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan.
Nancy Lazar of the I.S.I. Group, a New York securities firm, said she was sticking to her view that the Fed would find it unnecessary to raise rates this year, despite what she said had become a less convincing argument that the economy was slowing sufficiently on its own.
"One data point doesn't make a trend," Ms. Lazar said of today's report. "But it's not slowing very quickly."
Although the monthly report on orders for durables covers only about one-sixth of the economy, it is closely watched for clues about future business conditions because many of these items take months, sometimes years, to produce. And since purchases of these goods can often be easily deferred, swings in orders tend to be pronounced and to show up quickly.
Orders for electrical machinery jumped 4.7 percent last month, while primary metals and nonelectrical machinery both advanced 2.1 percent, the Commerce Department found. Transportation equipment showed no change as an increase for motor vehicles was offset by a large drop for ships and tanks.
Overall military orders dived 36.5 percent following a 26.4 percent leap in June. Had it not been for this drag, the nation's factories would have seen a 3.5 percent advance in orders for durable goods, defined as items intended to last at least three years.
Another sign of vigor last month was a solid 3.6 percent climb by nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft -- a gauge of the business sector's own expansion plans -- following a 2.5 percent increase in June. This was in sharp contrast to declines for March, April and May.
The report also showed that shipments of durable goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in July and that backlogs of unfilled orders advanced 1 percent.
Kathryn Eickhoff, who runs a New York consulting firm that bears her name, said today's results were in conflict with most other recent figures, although for several weeks now first-time claims for unemployment insurance have also suggested continued economic vigor. "There's more strength to the July data" than had been supposed, she said.
The Federal Reserve's minutes described an overriding concern that inflation must be kept low enough to safeguard economic expansion. But the dominant view at the sessions on July 2 and July 3 was that "any tendency for price pressures to mount was likely to emerge only gradually and be reversible through a relatively limited" adjustment in policy.
Another reason for not raising rates then was that members feared it could have a "more pronounced effect" than usual, because a policy reversal "might generate expectations of further tightening." The preceding move, at the beginning of the year, was to trim interest rates by making money more available.
The vote last month to lean toward tightening -- but not actually do it -- was 11 to 1. Gary H. Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, dissented. Mr. Stern was said to favor immediate action on the ground that the economy's momentum and strains in the labor and other markets suggested a pickup in inflation.
For the last year, the committee had maintained a symmetrical directive, meaning that it regarded the chances of its next move, in either direction, to be equally likely. The modified policy, employing the usual terminology, stated that "somewhat greater reserve restraint would, or slightly lesser reserve restraint might, be acceptable in the intermeeting period."
On a separate vote involving target ranges for monetary growth through 1997 two governors, Lawrence B. Lindsey and Janet L. Yellen, dissented because they preferred somewhat higher ranges for M-2 and M-3.

HEADLINE: As the West Hesitates on Burundi, Leaders in Africa Make a Stand

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: MUSOMA, Tanzania Aug. 22

 BODY:
Outsiders have often criticized African governments for doing little to halt disasters in their midst, such as the large-scale massacres in Rwanda and Burundi, let alone to oppose military coups and support democracy. But now in East Africa, regional leaders are making a serious effort to confront the leaders of the recent coup in Burundi by imposing a trade embargo on the country.
The driving force behind the embargo is Julius K. Nyerere, the former President of Tanzania and an elder statesman in African politics. Mr. Nyerere had been trying to mediate an impasse between Tutsi and Hutu parties in Burundi since February, and had persuaded regional leaders to agree in June to a plan to send peacekeeping troops into the country to stop massacres. 
 And when Maj. Pierre Buyoya, a Tutsi leader and former Burundian President, ousted the sitting President, a Hutu, and dismantled the Government a month ago, Mr. Nyerere led the drive for an embargo.
"The East African leaders said, one, we are not going to accept the idea that this is a coup by a nice man," Mr. Nyerere, 74, said in an hour-long interview at his home near here this week. "Secondly, they did not want to simply issue another statement of strong words. They really felt action was necessary."
The decision by Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and Zaire to impose trade sanctions on Burundi two weeks ago caught many Western diplomats by surprise.
For once, African countries had taken the initiative and staked the high moral ground, while the United States and Europe hesitated. Some Western diplomats argued an embargo might provoke more violence and would hurt the poor. They also viewed Mr. Buyoya as a moderate, a better alternative than more extremist Tutsi military commanders who might have seized power, and argued that the previous Government had not been stemming the ethnic warfare there in any case.
Mr. Nyerere said the decision to impose sanctions was "a completely new development in Africa during my phase of leadership."
In the past, he said, African nations had been loathe to interfere in the affairs of their neighbors. Indeed, the charter of the Organization of African Unity prohibits any intervention in the affairs of other African nations. Neighbors usually accepted most coups without a whimper. Or they paid lip service to condemning them without taking concrete action.
Mr. Nyerere broke that tradition in 1979, when he sent 50,000 Tanzanian troops into Uganda to end Idi Amin's murderous dictatorship. The invasion was warranted, he argued, because Mr. Amin had tried the year before to occupy a sliver of Tanzania.
The tradition of non-interference was also broken in Liberia, where an 8,000-strong peacekeeping force led by Nigeria has been trying since 1990 to halt the civil war there. But the force has been criticized for having less than lofty motives, since some say it has looted the country of goods from machinery to minerals.
The embargo of Burundi seems to have purer roots here, diplomats said. Democracy has grown stronger in East Africa in recent years, and many leaders now see coups as a threat, Mr. Nyerere said. In May, Uganda held its first presidential election ever, giving a strong mandate to President Yoweri K. Museveni.
In the last four years, both Kenya and Tanzania have also held multiparty elections for the first time. Even Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, is planning to hold elections next year.
None of these elections has been a flawless democratic exercise, Mr. Nyerere acknowledged. None has even led to a change of leadership. But they have given leaders in the region what they see as a democratic mandate, he said, and so they can no longer so easily accept coups meant to cancel out the voters' wishes.
In addition, Mr. Nyerere said, the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 has deeply affected the politics of the region. In hindsight, he said, many regional leaders believe they should have intervened to stop Hutu supremacists from massacring at least 500,000 Tutsi, instead of watching from the sidelines, as much of the world did.
"There is a new leadership developing in Africa," he said. "They are saying 'What does this mean? This non-interference. What does it mean? Who is sovereign in the country. The people? Or the junta?"
Mr. Nyerere said he was slightly surprised by the lack of support the East African leaders have gotten from Western diplomats, who have balked at joining the embargo or condemning the coup.
The Western nations were worried sanctions had been applied too quickly and might provoke more violence in Burundi, where more than 150,000 people are estimated to have been killed since 1993 in clashes between the mostly Tutsi army and Hutu rebels or in the widespread abuses of civilians committed by both sides.
Some Western diplomats also wanted to give Major Buyoya more time, to see what he would do with his position, Mr. Nyerere said. They saw him as a moderate man, more likely to make peace with Hutu leaders than some other more militant Tutsi military leaders.
"East African leaders are not totally convinced of this," Mr. Nyerere said.
The embargo's purpose is to force Major Buyoya and other members of the Tutsi elite to sit down at the bargaining table with the Hutu rebels in Zaire and the main Hutu party, which won the first presidential election in 1993, Mr. Nyerere said.
To be successful, he said, the talks must find solutions to two problems: that the Hutu have been politically disenfranchised since independence 35 years ago, and secondly, that many Tutsi genuinely fear they will be massacred if Hutu come to power.
So far, the embargo seems to be holding, diplomats and journalists in Bujumbura say. Salt has tripled in price. Gasoline is being rationed, with only 20 liters for each car every week. Businessmen are complaining that they are losing thousands of dollars, as their goods rot on piers in Dar Es Salaam and Mombasa.
Still, it will take more time before the sanctions begin to cut deeply into the economy, diplomats say. Food is still plentiful in the market, and traffic is still moving. Most of the goods are being carried by hand into the capital by farmers from the surrounding countryside.
Beyond the principles of democracy, each country had other reasons to join in the blockade as well, several diplomats said. Both Zaire and Tanzania are sheltering 1.7 million Burundian and Rwandan refugees, a constant strain on resources and a source of crime. The refugees are unlikely to return home unless peace is made between Hutu and Tutsi factions in both countries.
In Kenya, President Daniel T. Arap Moi has had an aversion to coups since he was almost overthrown in 1982. In addition, there is no love lost between Mr. Moi and Tutsi leaders in both Rwanda and Burundi. He has close ties to the former Hutu Government in Rwanda.
In Uganda, President Yoweri K. Museveni has just recently won a mandate from his country in last May's election, after fighting his way to power 10 years ago in a civil war. Since then, he has taken pains to say in almost every public speech that the cycle of coup and counter coup must be broken.
Rwanda's decision to join the blockade was perhaps the most puzzling. The Government in Kigali is dominated by Tutsi who invaded from Uganda in 1991, put an end to the Hutu-sponsored genocide against Tutsi and then drove the former Hutu-led Government and army into Zaire. They were thought to sympathize with the Tutsi politicians in Burundi, who are also fighting Hutu insurgents in Zaire.
But Paul Kagame, the Tutsi Vice President who is the defacto head of state in Rwanda, opted instead to stand on principle, after wavering for nearly two weeks. In this, he joined his longtime friend and ally, Mr. Museveni. He may have had little choice, however. Rwanda is landlocked and could easily have been added to the embargo.
Still, diplomats say the sanctions are a hopeful sign that democracy is taking root. Leaders appear more frightened now than ever before of the sort of military coup common in the 1970's, like the coups that put Samuel K. Doe in charge of Liberia and allowed Idi Amin to take over Uganda.
"The ballgame has changed," said one diplomat in Nairobi. "What you have seen is more and more governments elected by the people. You do see a surge of democracy on the continent and that has changed the context in which people view these coups."

HEADLINE: Benefit of Dole Tax Plan Is Hotly Debated

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Do tax cuts stimulate growth?
That question, which was shunted to the sidelines when reducing the budget deficit became the No. 1 priority in Washington in the late 1980's, has returned to center stage with Bob Dole's proposal to reduce Federal income taxes by at least 15 percent. The answer is complex, for while tax cuts can clearly give a boost to an economy suffering from weak output and high unemployment, there is little evidence that lowering taxes has significantly improved the ability of the economy to expand over the longer run. 
 "Even fundamental tax reform," said Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan Business School, "is unlikely to add more than a few tenths of a percentage point to the growth rate."
By the same token, though, some very reputable economists who once scoffed at those who believed that supply-side economics was the cure for all ailments now argue that radical policy changes could make a big difference in the growth rate. "I think 3.5 percent is a very ambitious but achievable goal," said John Taylor, an economist at Stanford University and a former aide to President George Bush who is now a principal adviser to Mr. Dole.
Exhibit A in the case for tax cuts rests on the 1980's: growth from 1983, shortly after the first of the Reagan-era income-tax cuts went into effect, through 1990, when President Bush pushed through a tax increase, averaged 3.5 percent. If we could do it then, supporters contend, why can't we do it now?
Exhibit A in the case against tax cuts also relies on the experience of the last decade: the initial surge in growth was nothing more than a catch-up from the deep recession of the early 1980's and once that occurred the economy settled back into the slower-paced rut it has been in for two decades or more. And with the economy currently enjoying low unemployment and steady growth, most analysts say, there is no reason to expect tax cuts today to markedly improve the economy's performance. Indeed, unless they are offset by spending cuts aimed at consumption rather than investment, they could do more harm than good.
Some basics are necessary to sort out the argument. Charles Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution and chief economic adviser to President Jimmy Carter, draws a crucial distinction between pro-growth policies that work by stimulating demand and those that stimulate supply. When the economy is in recession, tax and monetary policies that encourage private spending can produce very rapid growth for brief periods as idle people and machines are put back to work. But once the economy reaches its productive capacity, the long-term growth rate depends on improvements in savings, investment, work effort and technology.
The story of growth in the American economy in the last quarter century is thus one of a fall from grace. For while ups and downs in output and employment have become less frequent and less severe, the long-term trend in growth has slowed sharply. From 1946 through 1973, output per worker rose by an average annual rate of 2.7 percent. From 1974 through 1995, by contrast, growth in labor productivity averaged just 1.1 percent annually.
From this perspective, the Reagan revolution -- at least as it pertains to economic growth -- seems much ado about nothing. The big tax cuts in 1982 yielded an average of 5 percent growth in 1983 and 1984 because they stimulated demand in the midst of a deep recession. Indeed, in the first quarter of 1984, output rose at an annual rate of 11.4 percent.
But once the gap between actual and potential output was closed, growth settled back to the familiar post-1973 path. Labor productivity rose at an average 1.3 percent in 1985 through 1988, compared with 2.3 percent during the 1983-84 recovery.
"Nothing Government has done -- for good or evil -- seems to have mattered," concluded Paul Krugman, an economist at Stanford University. Given the size of the American economy and the difficulty of altering its course, "it's like using a water pistol to shoot an elephant."
What, then, gives Mr. Dole reason to hope he could break out of the slow-growth trap? Martin Feldstein, an economist at Harvard University who is advising the Republican candidate, points to the incentive of lowering tax rates and allowing workers to keep more of their earnings.
Mr. Feldstein, while acknowledging that the total work effort of all employees is unlikely to go up by much, argues that the productivity of high-income workers -- especially those with considerable discretion in how hard they work -- could rise sharply. "All the studies of labor supply response ignore the intangibles," Mr. Feldstein said. The Dole plan would also halve the maximum tax on capital gains to 14 percent from 28 percent, he noted, increasing the incentives for those with new money-making ideas to take risks.
Mr. Feldstein's optimism about what is achievable, however, is not shared by many of his colleagues.
"Getting anywhere near 3.5 percent growth would require Asian-level investment rates," replied Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution. And if the experience of the 1980's is evidence, that would take a near-miracle: the array of incentives to invest offered in the 1982 Reagan tax cut hardly budged the rate of spending on business equipment. In 1979, business invested 6.1 percent of the gross domestic product in new equipment; six years later, at the height of the Reagan boom, it invested 6.4 percent.
The Dole plan, of course, includes more than just tax cuts. Changes in Government regulation, along with sweeping reform of the civil justice system, would pare business costs and presumably raise output. A variety of financial incentives would encourage college attendance and on-the-job training.
But Mr. Bosworth points out that balancing the budget with as-yet-unspecified budget cuts could actually have a perverse effect on growth if it reduced productive Government spending on things like university-based research, which would be under great pressure because Mr. Dole has declared so much of the budget off-limits. Worse, but hardly out of the question in light of the experience of the Reagan years, is what would happen if the deficit was not checked when taxes were reduced. The result, economists agree, would be higher interest rates or rising inflation, either of which would soon cause the economy to slow.
The real surprise, perhaps, is that many economists are still inclined to give the benefit of a doubt to Mr. Dole's plan for spurring growth. In part, this is probably related to unstated agendas. Many economists who are not directly involved in the Presidential campaign argue that slowing the growth of spending on Social Security and Medicare is the nation's biggest problem and they suspect that Mr. Dole is more likely to tackle that challenge head on than Mr. Clinton is.
"At least," said Paul Romer, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and an expert on why economies grow, "the Dole people are asking the right questions."

HEADLINE: Welfare Law Could Bring A Windfall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 23

 BODY:
While some other states, notably New York and California, are sounding alarms about the new Federal welfare law's dire effects, state officials here are cautiously anticipating a windfall of as much as $90 million in Federal aid for the poor over the next year. That would mean at least a 50 percent increase over what the state would have received under the old system.
"It certainly is a pleasant surprise," said Robert Harris, assistant director of the Legislature's Office of Fiscal Analysis, a nonpartisan agency, though he noted that calculations were not yet completed and that the picture would change substantially in future years. 
 While many officials cautioned that the aid estimates might be overstated, Connecticut may still fare better than other states next year, for several reasons. Its caseload has relatively few legal immigrant noncitizens, who no longer are eligible for food stamps and other Federal aid under the new law. For instance, Federal statistics show that in 1994, 2.5 percent of Connecticut's families on welfare were legal immigrants, less than one-fourth the percentage in New York.
The new law may also weigh less heavily on Connecticut because the state has already taken substantial steps to force more welfare recipients to find work. Accordingly, it may not have to increase spending dramatically to meet new Federal goals to move people off the dole and into jobs.
But perhaps most important, Connecticut, like many states, benefits from the way Congress established the new block grant -- Temporary Assistance for Needy Families -- that replaces the old Federal reimbursement system.
In determining the amount of Federal aid to states under the new law, Congress decided that the figure would be equal to the maximum Federal welfare payments each state had received in either fiscal year 1994, fiscal year 1995 or the average of expenditures from 1992 through 1994.
For Connecticut and many other states, where welfare expenditures and caseloads have dropped in the last two years, this formula appears to be a blessing. Although 40 states have reported that they have fewer people on family welfare today, they will still be getting the amount of Federal aid they received a few years ago when the rolls had more people.
In Connecticut, the family welfare caseload is 55,763, a 7 percent drop from the July 1994 level of 59,800 families. At the same time, the state is paying less in benefits, with the average monthly check for a family of three down to $540 from $583.
Under the old law, Connecticut could have expected roughly 50 percent of its expenditures on family welfare to be reimbursed by the Federal Government. Before the law was changed, the state had projected it would receive $171 million from the Federal Government for three programs -- Aid to Families with Dependent Children, Job Opportunities and Basic Skills and Emergency Assistance to Families.
Last month, the Congressional Research Service, a nonpartisan arm of the Library of Congress, estimated that Connecticut would receive roughly $96 million more than that -- about $267 million -- after the new law takes effect.
According to the Congressional Research Service, it is also possible that Connecticut will receive $35 million in Federal child care assistance, about $4 million more than the state had expected if the old law remained in place. This number, however, is not final, and is subject to changes by Congress and the State Legislature.
Claudette Beaulieu, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Social Services, noted that roughly $10 million will be deducted from the block grant for child support payments the state owes the Federal Government. She also said that the $267 million figure may be too high, as the state and Federal governments are embroiled in a dispute over how much Connecticut spent on welfare programs in 1994, which is the basis for that estimate.
Still, Ms. Beaulieu added, "There's no question we're going to see more money coming into the state next year."
Yet some welfare experts caution that the boost that Connecticut and other states may receive next year is offset by a host of negatives.
Although many states will be getting more from the family assistance block grant, most will be seeing less Federal money for the food stamp and Supplemental Security Income programs. For instance, the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization, estimates that Connecticut will lose $286 million over the next six years in Federal assistance to its food stamp program.
Ms. Beaulieu said that seemed high, though the state has not yet determined the impact of the new law on its food stamp recipients.
Welfare analysts also say that while Connecticut and other states may find themselves ahead next year in Federal funding, the new Federal block grant will not grow. In a few years, states may find that they are actually receiving less than they would have if the old reimbursement system had remained.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Orders for Durables Surge, Raising Interest Rate Fears
Orders for durable goods surged 1.6 percent in July. That was considerably more than analysts expected and cast new doubt on assumptions that the economy is slowing from its unsustainably fast pace of the spring.
The broadly based advance, which would have been more than twice as large had it not been for a plunge in orders from the Pentagon, raised fears that the Federal Reserve would push up interest rates fairly soon. That fear was heightened by a report after the close of New York trading that at a policy meeting in early July the Fed had moved toward a bias in favor of monetary tightening. [Page 36.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply as a result of the strong economic data. The 30-year bond fell 1 10/32 to a price of 97 15/32 to yield 6.95 percent, up from 6.83 percent on Thursday and the highest since July 31. [38.]
 
Stocks Fall; Dow Off 10.73
The evidence of a robust economy also tripped up stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.73 points, to 5,722.74, although it was still up 33.29 points for the week. The S.& P. 500 stock index fell 3.65 points, to 667.03, and the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.91, to 1,143.05. The interest-rate-sensitive financial sector met some brisk selling. [39.]
 
Fed Proposes Bank Rule Overhaul
The Fed proposed new rules that would make it much easier for banks to make acquisitions and enter new businesses. But they could curb community groups' pressure on banks. [38.]
 
Clinton Unveils Tobacco Curbs
President Clinton unveiled a long list of curbs intended to stop tobacco companies from encouraging young people to smoke. [1.]
 
Jury Favors Tobacco Industry
In a victory for the tobacco industry, an Indianapolis jury refused to award damages to the family of an Indianapolis man who died of lung cancer in 1987. [8.]
 
A Pilot's Fatal Computer Error
American Airlines traced last December's fatal crash in Colombia to a pilot's error in entering a computer code and warned pilots not to let automation take over in flying. [9.]
 
Doctors Find Lucrative Niches
Across the nation, thousands of doctors, frustrated by the price controls, red tape and sometimes intrusive oversight of managed care, are building lucrative practices in fields like cosmetic surgery and infertility treatment, where affluent patients will pay even when their insurers will not. [1.]
 
Humana in Sale to Kaiser
In the latest H.M.O. consolidation, Humana Inc. said that it was selling its Washington network to Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest not-for-profit H.M.O., and PacifiCare Health Systems said it was considering the sale of its Florida operations. [37.]
 
Abercrombie Plans to Go Public
Abercrombie & Fitch filed to sell 7 million shares for $14 to $16 each in an initial public offering that could raise as much as $112 million. The retailer, which outfitted Teddy Roosevelt and Ernest Hemingway for safari, is a unit of Limited Inc. [36.]
 
Honda's Profit Nearly Quadruples
Honda Motor reported that its first-quarter profit nearly quadrupled, to 45.71 billion yen ($417.4 million) from 11.92 billion yen ($108.9 million) a year earlier, spurred by strong Japanese sales of sport utility vehicles and mini-vans, as well as solid sales in the United States, particularly of the remodeled Civic, and a weaker yen. Sales surged 30 percent. [47.]
 
Settlement for Defrauded Charities
Nonprofit organizations victimized by the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy in the biggest charity fraud in U.S. history will receive as much 65 percent of their invested money back under a $39 million settlement approved by a Federal judge. [39.]

HEADLINE: As Insurers Cut Fees, Doctors Shift to Elective Procedures

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Dr. Phillip Haeck, a Seattle plastic surgeon, used to spend half his working hours rebuilding the breasts of cancer patients and performing other reconstructive procedures. Then managed-care companies started to cut his fees by 60 percent or more.
So Dr. Haeck switched to cosmetic procedures that insurers do not cover, like breast enlargement. No longer restricted to the $1,980 fee that insurers allowed him for a six- to eight-hour breast restoration, he can now earn $3,800 for inserting saline breast implants, which takes two hours or less. 
 He was surprised by how many women were willing to pay. His income has already recovered, he said, and his working day now ends an hour earlier because he deals with far fewer insurance forms.
Just as Dr. Haeck has done, thousands of doctors, frustrated by the price controls, red tape and sometimes intrusive oversight of managed care, have begun building lucrative practices in fields like cosmetic surgery, correcting myopia with lasers, and infertility treatment, where patients will pay even when insurers will not.
Insurance companies refuse to pay for many of these elective procedures, arguing that they are not medically necessary or are still experimental. But a growing number of Americans are willing to spring for them -- at handsome prices. Indeed, while it used to be assumed that a doctor could charge a higher fee when an insurer was helping to foot the bill, the opposite is now true in many cases. Fees are often far higher than those doctors can charge under managed care for work requiring comparable skill and time.
The doctors increasing their emphasis on such procedures include:
*Physicians doing more cosmetic surgery, including plastic surgeons, dermatologists, ophthalmologists, ear, nose and throat specialists, dentists, gynecologists and general practitioners. Among the most common procedures are breast enlargement; removal of wrinkles, furrows and bags under the eyes; face lifts; nose jobs; hair transplants for men; vein surgery; chemical peels of unsightly skin, and liposuction to remove fatty tissue. The fee for such procedures can range from a few hundred dollars to more than $20,000.
*Ophthalmologists, who typically receive less than half the $2,000 that they used to get for each lens implant for cataract patients, shifting to a new surgery that uses lasers to correct nearsightedness -- and charging $1,500 to $2,000 an eye.
*Some ear, nose and throat specialists -- whose fees have been cut 40 percent to 60 percent under managed care -- now capitalizing on a new technique: using lasers to eliminate snoring by removing tissue from the uvula at the back of the tongue. A typical fee is $2,500.
*Some obstetrician-gynecologists with special training in infertility services now averaging $2,000 and more for in vitro fertilizations.
*Some urologists, whose surgical fees have dropped to $600 from $1,400 for treating enlarged prostate glands, now making a business of penis-enlargement surgery. Those fees range from $4,800 to $7,000.
To be sure, the overwhelming majority of the nation's 650,000 physicians are still deeply enmeshed in managed care and are not reaching out for more lucrative niches like these. But there is wide agreement in the medical community that as the number of procedures that do not qualify for insurance coverage -- and the popularity of such procedures -- grow, a rising number of doctors are making the most of this.
One reason that these specialists can find enough takers paying out of their own pockets is the stunning increase in family income of the wealthiest Americans. The average income for the top 20 percent of households grew to $105,945 in 1994 from $73,754 in 1968, a jump of 44 percent after adjusting for inflation, according to the Census Bureau. That has occurred even as the number of uninsured people grows and as many people see their own medical benefits reduced.
Also, some doctors and patients have found imaginative ways to get insurers to pay part of the bill. Nose jobs can get some insurance coverage if the doctor indicates that the patient has had trouble breathing. Some dermatologists who remove spider veins can get insurers to pay by calling them artery-blocking varicose veins.
The physicians' rush to such procedures is not surprising. Managed care has been cutting the flow of patients and sharply reducing fees for many specialists, notably dermatologists, ophthalmologists, ear, nose and throat specialists, general surgeons, cardiac and vascular surgeons, cardiologists, anesthesiologists and gastroenterologists, said Dr. Richard Doyle, a management consultant in St. Louis with the Milliman & Robertson consulting firm.
No one tracks the number of doctors performing procedures not covered by insurance or how that number has changed, but there are many indications that it is growing. For example, the number of board-certified plastic surgeons rose 75 percent, to 5,200 in 1994, from 2,980 in 1980, according to the latest available surveys by the American Medical Association. And last year 40 percent of plastic surgeons said cosmetic work was now their main business, up from 32 percent in 1991, according to the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons.
The American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery said the number of commonly performed cosmetic procedures doubled, to 1.09 million, between 1990 and 1994, the latest available year.
Dr. Randal Haworth, a Beverly Hills, Calif., plastic surgeon, said that by concentrating on cosmetic surgery, "We are not held fiscal and emotional hostage by these people in managed care; secondly, by refusing to join their plan, you are not obligated to accept what they pay."
Dr. Haeck, the Seattle plastic surgeon, said he shifted to 90 percent cosmetic surgery from a practice that was half cosmetic and half reconstructive, after price-cutting insurers threatened to reduce his income by 30 percent. For instance, he said, his share of fees for breast reconstruction after cancer surgery dropped to $1,980 from $3,800.
Dr. Haeck resigned from eight managed-care networks, freeing more time for breast-enlargement procedures that he said bring in around $3,800 each.
He hired a marketing expert to, as he put it, "ramp up that side of the business." Dr. Haeck also began giving seminars at a local athletic club and appearing on local television, and he changed his advertisements to feature his cosmetic services.
Dr. Gwendolyn Maxwell Davis, a cosmetic surgeon in Tucson, Ariz., took one look at the field of plastic surgery when she finished her training and decided to devote herself exclusively to cosmetic procedures. She charges $6,000 for a face lift, $4,500 for breast enlargement, and $4,500 for a "tummy tuck." All told, she expects to net $450,000 this year, after only two years in practice.
Another fast-growing niche is infertility treatment. The American Society for Reproductive Medicine reported 32,000 cycles of in vitro fertilization were initiated in 1993, the most recent year for which numbers were available, up 76 percent from 1989. And physicians say that the number has grown significantly since then.
"From a purely financial point of view, I'd rather not have managed care involved," said Dr. Ira Charlip, a San Francisco urologist who specializes in infertility. "I can charge the patient a reasonable amount and they pay 100 percent of it."
Advances in laser technology have opened numerous new medical opportunities as well, many not covered by insurance. Some are cosmetic, like burning off tattoos and age spots, zapping wrinkles and removing hair.
Other procedures, which some insurers cover, include removal of disfiguring birthmarks. New laser procedures are growing much faster than older procedures covered by managed care, Irving Arons, managing director of Spectrum Consulting in Peabody, Mass., said.
"Doctors are looking for new ways of generating revenue," said Larry Haimovitch, a medical technology consultant in San Francisco. "If they can buy a laser machine and pay it back quickly, they do it."
Some of the newest lasers are used to treat myopia by changing the shape of the eyeball. Dr. Frank O'Donnell, a St. Louis ophthalmologist, had encountered big reductions in what insurers allowed for cataract surgery. "It's pretty hard to scramble to replace a 50 percent reduction in reimbursement," he said.
Now, Dr. O'Donnell specializes in laser treatments for myopia at $1,500 to $2,000 an eye. He is also chairman of Lasersight Inc., a start-up company that he said was testing a second-generation laser for myopia.
Dr. O'Donnell laments the changes in the medical business brought on by managed care, and says he worries about whether the most talented doctors will flee to other professions.
"Ophthalmology has gone from being an exciting, very valued specialty to something that is not very desirable anymore," he said. "It's painful -- we used to be able to attract some of the very best doctors."
Mr. Arons of Spectrum Consulting said that there were at least 50 laser vision centers in the country, each with several physicians. He projects 200 centers by the end of the year and a million procedures a year by 2000 at $1,000 each as the price of the equipment comes down -- a $1 billion market.
Dr. Roy Geronemus, director of the Laser and Skin Center of New York, which does both insured and uninsured procedures, said attendance had increased sharply for his course in new laser techniques at New York University Medical Center. Some of his students, he said, are physicians "who are looking for ways to circumvent the constraints on medical practice."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Remarks by Dole and Kemp to Black Journalists' Convention

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by Jack Kemp and Bob Dole yesterday to the annual convention of the National Association of Black Journalists in Nashville, and from the two men's answers to questions that followed, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private company in Washington.
 
 BY JACK KEMP
 
 How can your heart not break in America when you read the account, as I have, of Alex Kotlowitz's story in his book "There Are No Children Here," about the young boys growing up in Henry Horner public housing in Chicago? 
 One little boy was asked by Kotlowitz what he wanted to be when he grew up. He said, "Well, if I grow up, I want to be a bus driver." He didn't say "when I grow up." He said "if I grow up."
We've reached a time, dear friends, when out of mouths of children comes a reality so tragic in America that some adults want to close their ears. We must open our eyes and open our ears and know that if America does not have an answer for that child and for his family, our nation is diminished. And it is my belief, as it is in Bob Dole's soul, that if the Republican Party does not have a heart for that child, our party will be incomplete. . . .
As I told the N.A.A.C.P. convention in Detroit a few years ago, I wasn't there when Rosa Parks took a stand by remaining in her seat on Cleveland Avenue in Montgomery, Ala., in December of 1955. And I wasn't there when my friend John Lewis was beaten, or when Dr. King was in a jail, or marched to Selma.
But I'm here today, and I'm here with Bob Dole to help forge a new civil rights agenda, an agenda of expanded ownership and empowerment, with jobs and educational choice and entrepreneurship, and the equality of opportunity in which any child of God can rise to his or her potential.
My friends, Bob Dole has no tolerance of intolerance, no patience for prejudice. He has a passion for equality. They're deeply rooted in the lessons of his life and the American Dream.
And he and I are committed to creating a new generation of opportunity in America that can be shared by every American man, woman and child, leaving no one behind.
 
 BY BOB DOLE
We've missed opportunities as a party from time to time. I missed one by not going to the N.A.A.C.P. convention. And I'm sorry about that. Our candidate for President in 1964, Barry Goldwater, missed an opportunity by opposing the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
We don't try to miss any opportunities. We're trying to create opportunities. And not long ago, the contest for the votes of black Americans held the answer on who would win the Presidential election.
Republicans and Democrats alike fought for the support of African-Americans, neither party taking it for granted, and neither party writing it off. But these days, we're told that the votes of black Americans are held by the Democrats, and there's little or no chance that Jack Kemp or Bob Dole can do much about it or win a sizable percentage. Now I don't believe for one minute that this is the case.
In my races for the Senate in the state of Kansas, I received 27 to 30-some percent of the black vote in my state. I had the respect of black voters and others who voted against me. And I can think of few better outcomes of this election -- not just for the black community but for all Americans -- than to have Bill Clinton and Al Gore and Bob Dole and Jack Kemp competing, truly competing, for the votes of African-Americans. . . .
I think it was said a long time ago, you go hunting where the ducks are. Or somebody who used to rob banks said, Go where the money is.
The fact is, as Jack has just indicated, we are going to ask for every single vote in America on Nov. 5, 1996. We are going to earn it.
I deeply believe that the Republican Party will never be whole until it earns the broad support of African-Americans and others by speaking to their hopes. And we're going to continue that message day after day after day after day. . . .
As I said in my acceptance speech just a week ago, it has been my goal as long as I've been in politics, and before, to talk about one America, not black Americans, white Americans, or urban Americans, rural Americans.
It's my view that we're going to have success in America if we're together.
And I know of some of the problems, obviously. I don't know as well as many in this audience do and wouldn't profess to know.
But I know that when black soldiers returned from World War II, they came back to a society where discrimination was still the norm. But I really believe the experience of that war changed most of us who were in it forever.
And I became a member of a minority group called the disabled. And I gained an understanding of hardship. And I guess -- I don't -- I hope it's not just because of that -- but those years in the service . . . left me with an abiding conviction.
People who are willing to die or risk their lives for their country must share fully in its rights. That has to be a basic premise in America.
They left me with a simple vision for America. While we cannot guarantee the outcomes in our society, we shall guarantee equality of opportunity. And there can be no doubt that some do not share that conviction or that vision. And while we've made tremendous progress in America since World War II, many black Americans, as well as others, still do not share fully in America's bounties and still lack the opportunities that most others have.
And some believe the solution to these problems is quotas and preferences and set-asides. And I've supported race-based preferences in the past. But over time I realized that preferences created with the best of intentions were dividing America, instead of bringing us or bringing them together.
What I do support and what I do define as real affirmative action is aggressive, determined and persistent recruitment of minorities and women by business, government and universities. It also means identifying barriers to advancement of women and minorities in corporate America, a task performed by the Glass Ceiling Commission created by legislation that I sponsored, that my wife, in fact, advocated when she was Secretary of Labor.
Simply put, I believe in outreach to give people the opportunity to compete, not preset outcomes that determine the results of that competition. This is a line I would preserve in our laws. And I know that there are some on the left and there are some on the right who are losing faith in a common American future. . . . They are convinced that division is our destiny. But we cannot surrender on this point, in my view, because our fragile unity is a source of everything good and noble in our nation.
And as William Julius Wilson writes in his new book, "When Work Disappears: The World of the New Urban Poor," and I quote: "High neighborhood joblessness has a far more devastating effect than high neighborhood poverty. A neighborhood in which people are poor but employed is different from a neighborhood in which people are poor and jobless."
It sort of sums it up. So what do we want to do? We want to unleash the hidden economic potential found everywhere in our society, particularly in the inner cities, and create new jobs. . . .
And in this process I can do just one thing, but it is a big thing, because I now speak for the Republican Party. Bob Dole is the nominee. Jack Kemp is my running mate. We believe our records give us this opportunity maybe the two other nominees would not have had to renew the commitment of the party I lead to these enduring dreams. And together we can make them endure a while longer.
Our goal is a nation with the shared prosperity of a growing economy, a nation where crime is confronted and family is honored and education succeeds for every child, an America without any limitation on opportunity and without the barriers of bigotry. So we've set a high but a simple standard for our success, and we will accept nothing less than a nation that rewards every American and rewards every American dream. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. What is going to be the economic support system for the inner cities and the poor without the safety net of welfare?
MR. DOLE. I think welfare will be the safety net.
If you take a look at the bill the President's signed, one that we had sent him before, which he vetoed -- pretty much the same -- there's what we call a maintenance-of-effort provision in that bill.
And Congress meets every year, and if I'm President of the United States, and I find that some state is abusing some part of that system ----. There's also about $12 billion in the bill for child care. There's also a $2 billion, what we call an emergency fund. If, let's say, they had a calamity in, say, New York, or Tennessee, where you needed $100 million quick. It's there. . . .
Q. How will you provide jobs for people in the inner city? Where would these jobs come from?
A. When you have economic growth, when you create wealth, you create opportunity. I can give you case after case after case. If you lower the cost of capital for somebody out there -- black, white, Asian, Hispanic -- creating a business or wanting to expand a business, lower the capital gains rate. That's how you create jobs in the private sector.
Q. For generations, white children of white immigrants, regardless of their status, enjoyed citizenship. Now that the new immigrants are black and brown, would you support a constitutional amendment to deny them citizenship?
A. With due respect to the platform, I read a lot of the parts that I thought were essential. I approved a lot of parts that I thought were essential. That was not one of them. I would not support that part of the platform.
Q. What credibility do you now have with African-American voters after turning your back on affirmative action in this mere space of two days?
MR. KEMP. I believe with all my heart that affirmative action is very much needed, but the right kind of affirmative action, small "a," is affirmative efforts to open up the type of educational opportunity, the type of access to credit and capital, the type of access to ownership and housing, the type of an access to the American Dream that every child of God has a right to expect in the United States of America now that the cold war is over, . . .
The greatest goal of this country on the eve of the 21st century is the type of reconciliation to which Bob Dole has committed his life, and I've committed mine.
I'll close with this thought. All government action is affirmative. Some has been right. Bob and I have pointed out some that has been wrong. But we believe, coming here today, as Kweisi Mfume said when he was sworn in as president of the N.A.A.C.P., that the single greatest deterrent to black progress in the United States of America today is the lack of access to capital, credit, ownership, education, and opportunity.
And Kemp and Dole are standing before this vast audience to tell you that we want to open up in this country once again that type of an America in which any man, any woman, of any color, can get that education, get that access to credit and capital, get that housing, get that ownership, and get that which Bob and I have been speaking about.
So that to me is an affirmative action program that goes beyond set-asides or preferences. It goes to the heart of the high moral ground for which we want this country to set a standard. Because I believe with all my heart we cannot preach democracy in East Europe if we're not making it work in east Harlem, and we can't preach democracy for South Africa unless it works in south central L.A. That is my pledge to you, and we will keep that pledge of reaffirming that type of affirmative action for America.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole, in Change of Focus, Appeals for Black Votes

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Aug. 23

 BODY:
In a direct and explicit appeal for black support, Bob Dole today declared that the Republican Party had needlessly abandoned black voters to the Democratic Party, and he promised to challenge President Clinton for a bloc of voters who have reliably supported Democrats for more than a generation.
Mr. Dole, speaking to a black journalists' organization here -- the first black audience he has addressed in his 18-month-long campaign, his aides said -- presented what he called a "new civil rights agenda" as he defended his support for ending affirmative action programs. 
 Mr. Dole, who has come to oppose traditional measures to combat discrimination, said his agenda of dealing with the economy, education and crime would ultimately prove best at improving the status of black Americans. He also used renounced a Republican platform plank to withhold citizenship from children of illegal immigrants born in the United States. [Page 10.]
"We will only find support in the black community if Republicans do something simple and rare: We must have the courtesy to ask, and that's exactly what Jack and I want to do today," he told the National Association of Black Journalists. "I can't think of two better outcomes of this election -- not just for the black community, but for all Americans -- than to have Bill Clinton and Al Gore, and Bob Dole and Jack Kemp, compete, truly competing, for the votes of African-Americans."
The Republican Presidential candidate went on to deplore what he called "missed opportunities" by his party. He recalled a time -- apparently referring to the 1950's -- when the major parties had competed for black support. "But these days," he said, "we are told that the votes of black Americans are held by the Democrats."
Mr. Dole expressed regret that he had not spoken at a N.A.A.C.P. convention earlier this summer.
He added, "I deeply believe that the Republican Party will never be whole until it earns the broad support of African-Americans and others by speaking to their hopes."
Looking across a hall of mostly black faces, Mr. Dole recounted growing up in Russell, Kan., a community with few blacks. But he pointed to his World War II experience as the source of his understanding of the difficulties blacks faced in this country -- both because he saw the way returning black soldiers had been discriminated against but also because of a war injury that left his right arm useless.
"And I became a member of a minority group called the disabled," Mr. Dole said. "And I gained an understanding of hardship."
In a rare but brief question-and-answer period with the journalists, Mr. Dole renounced a plank in the Republican Party platform that calls for legislation to prohibit the children of illegal immigrants from becoming naturalized citizens. Mr. Dole rebuffed his party with one word -- "no" -- after a radio reporter from WLIB in New York, Jane Tillman Irving, asked if he agreed with a policy that treated present-day immigrants, many of whom are black and Hispanic, differently from earlier waves of white immigrants.
It remains to be seen how much success Mr. Dole will have in his effort to win black support or what steps he will take to seek the black vote. Mr. Clinton has regularly outpolled Mr. Dole by margins of about 10 to 1 in voter surveys of blacks this year. Since 1976, the highest level of support any Republican has received from black voters, according to exit polls, has been 16 percent, for President Gerald Ford in 1976. His opponent, Jimmy Carter, got 83 percent of the black vote.
But Mr. Dole's challenge could force Mr. Clinton to devote resources and attention to a group of voters that gave him 82 percent of their votes in 1992 after he had done relatively little campaigning to seek their support. Mr. Dole's speech today, combined with Mr. Kemp's intention to campaign in black neighborhoods, could also complicate what has been a central element of Mr. Clinton's electoral strategy: to present himself as a moderate appealing for support among white middle-class voters.
Before Mr. Dole could even leave Washington, a Clinton campaign aide met reporters as they boarded the Dole plane and handed out information criticizing the civil rights legislative records of both Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp. After the speech, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, Joe Lockhart, pointed out Mr. Dole's change in position on affirmative action and asserted: "Bob Dole has once again showed why he has a credibility problem with Americans."
Arguing that blacks would do better under Republican policies then Democratic ones, Mr. Dole implicitly apologized for the lack of Republican attention to the civil rights struggle.
Mr. Dole said said that Barry Goldwater "missed an opportunity" by opposing the 1964 Civil Rights Act that was pushed through Congress by President Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. Dole did not note how that action by Mr. Johnson had angered white voters, as Mr. Johnson predicted at the time that it would, and ultimately led to the current Republican dominance in the South in Presidential elections.
Mr. Dole was particularly passionate as he defended his opposition to affirmative action, pounding the lectern as he explained a change in position that had led him from supporting affirmative action to supporting efforts, from the halls of Congress to a pending state initiative in California, that would eliminate it.
"Some believe the solution to these problems is quotas and preferences and set-asides," Mr. Dole said. "And I've supported race-based preferences in the past. But over time, I realized that preferences created with the best of intentions were dividing America." He said what he supported instead was "aggressive, determined and persistent recruitment of minorities and women."
"Simply put, I believe in outreach to give people the opportunity to compete, and not preset outcomes to determine the results of that competition," Mr. Dole said. "This is the line I would preserve in our laws."
Mr. Dole, in explaining his decision in July not to appear before the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said at the time that its president, Kweisi Mfume, was a "very liberal Democrat" who was "trying to set me up" and that he preferred an audience "I can relate to." Today, Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp received a comparatively restrained reception.
Since Mr. Kemp joined Mr. Dole on the ticket, they have said that Mr. Kemp would campaign for minority votes, and Mr. Kemp has invoked in every speech the names of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Abraham Lincoln. But Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp have drawn few blacks to rallies this week. Mr. Dole's senior staff includes no black members. Today, he brought along a black woman, Pam Rucker, who had worked as an assistant press secretary for Mr. Dole in the Senate. He pointed to her when a questioner asked for the blacks he turns to for advice.
And Mr. Kemp was challenged about switching his position to conform with Mr. Dole's opposition to affirmative action.
Jesse Jackson, the black leader and Democrat who has often criticized Mr. Clinton's positions on civil rights issues, suggested today that he was doubtful about what Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp were trying to do. "Republicans are still doing more in symbolism and gestures than substance," Mr. Jackson said.
In Mr. Dole's address, he sought common ground with his audience today. He said that while he was recovering in a hospital in Battle Creek, Mich., he had seen blood marked "black blood." He said that when he voted in Congress for the Civil Rights Act of 1964, members had come up to him to ask how many blacks lived in his district. "Well, not many," he said. (In Kansas, 5.8 percent of the residents are black). He spoke about how he had managed, legislation establishing Dr. King's birthday as a national holiday.
"Democratic leaders simply assume ownership of the African-American vote, and we're not going to let that happen," Mr. Dole said. "We're going to fight for it."
