HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Playing 'Beat the Index'? This Time, You Might Win

BYLINE: BY CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
There are plenty of reasons to own a fund that tracks the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and they may have seemed particularly compelling in recent years. Just buy the market, proponents argue, and after 10 years you will beat 70 percent of managed mutual funds and have fewer fund distributions to cope with. How can you go wrong?
You can go wrong if your index fund pays too much for the stocks, argues Jack Bowers, who edits Fidelity Monitor, an independent newsletter in Rocklin, Calif, that follows Fidelity funds. And the S.& P. 500 is too expensive, Mr. Bowers says, based on the theory that a stock is overpriced if its price-to-earnings ratio exceeds its long-term earnings growth rate. The S.& P. 500's price-to-earnings ratio is 19, well above its 10-year earnings growth of about 9 percent. 
 There are, in fact, many expensive stocks in the index's top 25, including Coca-Cola, Microsoft and Merck. And the huge valuations are a result of too much money chasing the index stocks lately, he wrote in the July issue of his newsletter. The premiums are not justified, he contends, and at some point, the market will recognize that many mid-cap, small-cap and foreign companies offer better values.
Mr. Bowers concludes that the S.& P. 500 could be on the verge of a long dry spell, compared with other market segments.
Here is his prediction: Japan and Europe, which have been struggling with increases in unemployment and stalled deregulation, will succeed in their current campaigns to revive their economies through deficit spending and low interest rates. Then their government debt will get out of hand, as it did in the United States in the mid-1980's. As world financial markets react, the dollar will rise against both the German mark and the Japanese yen. Foreign revenues will then fall for companies doing business overseas, putting earnings pressure on many large multinational companies in the S.& P.
Eventually, he says, disenchanted indexers will move back to actively managed funds, as most begin to beat the index.
To avoid the current pitfall of paying too much for an index fund, Mr. Bowers recommends going with actively managed funds that use a value approach to picking index stocks, sidestepping the more expensive ones. Two such funds: Fidelity Value and Fidelity Equity-Income. He also likes a growth portfolio of four Fidelity funds: Emerging Markets, Low-Priced Stock, Value and Contrafund.
If you must index, he says, use a mix of mid-cap, small-cap and overseas index funds from Vanguard, an inexpensive indexer.
 
Performance Data: How Old Is Too Old?
Ten years ago, it was difficult to find basic mutual fund performance data. Now most daily newspapers devote many pages to performance statistics, magazines are full of mutual fund articles and portfolio managers appear frequently on television.
Still, much of the basic information shareholders must use for investment decisions is "hopelessly old and out of touch," Amy C. Arnott, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, wrote in a recent editorial.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, she noted, forces funds to disclose portfolio information only twice a year, and few funds do more than that. At Morningstar, the Chicago fund researchers, only about 10 percent of the funds in the company's data base report to their shareholders quarterly.
In addition, the quality of survey information that fund companies send to financial publications varies widely. Investors can call a fund directly to request updated portfolios, but few companies will send them.
That raises a fiduciary issue, as more investors are relying on professional planners who lack the information they need to do the best job possible.
The fund companies argue that the cost of printing and mailing quarterly or monthly reports would cut into shareholder returns. But Ms. Arnott counters that improvements in technology have made the costs much smaller. Moreover, the companies could provide monthly portfolios at extremely low costs by filing them electronically on the S.E.C. system called Edgar, for Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis and Retrieval.
Another industry objection, Ms. Arnott said, is that more-frequent portfolio information would attract short-sellers and market timers. But with thousands of traders already watching for significant buyers and sellers, she asks, why would reports that certain funds owned certain securities at a certain date make a difference?
For its part, the industry says that releasing portfolio information more than twice a year would require funds to reveal their trading strategies, which would, in effect, harm fund shareholders. Moreover, publicly reporting portfolio information would be "misleading because funds are actively managed and the portfolios change from day to day," said a spokeswoman for the Investment Company Institute, the Washington trade group.
As for Ms. Arnott's argument that when the market gets rough, unknowing investors are likely to bail out at inopportune times, the I.C.I. spokeswoman cited a study that found that a majority of shareholders expect to hold their investments for the long term.
 
New Managers
Mario Gabelli is the new sub-adviser to the Enterprise Small Company Portfolio and Enterprise Accumulation Trust Small Cap Portfolio, replacing Fisher Investments and Opcap Advisers, respectively.
Van Harissis, associate portfolio manager of Phoenix Small Cap, has taken the reins of Phoenix Growth from Bill Newman, the chief investment strategist for Phoenix Duff & Phelps, who was running the fund on an interim basis. Matthew Considine, an analyst with Phoenix Duff & Phelps, has taken over Phoenix Mid Cap (formerly called Phoenix Capital Appreciation) from John Wilson, who left the firm.
 
In Brief
IBC Financial Data has a money fund monitoring service on the Internet (http://www.ibcdata.com) that provides seven-day simple yields daily for 10 categories of taxable and tax-exempt money funds, weekly yield rankings by category, as well as portfolio composition and other data intended for money fund professionals. It is available without charge through September; the annual rate is $1,800 thereafter.
Prudential Securities has extended to Sept. 30 its program waiving the annual I.R.A. custodial fee for rollovers or transfers of more than $25,000. To become eligible, investors must transfer or roll over the money from an existing individual retirement account or employer-sponsored retirement plan to a Prudential I.R.A.
The Kemper Retirement Plans Group has added outside funds to its 401(k) program for small businesses, the company said.

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS;
In This Garden, Hardy Cyclamens Are the Muses

BYLINE: By Anne Raver 

 BODY:
Nancy Goodwin saw her first hardy cyclamen in Surrey, England, more than 20 years ago.
"We were sitting by a large rock, and here was this incredible plant," Mrs. Goodwin said. "The flower was so elegant, and it looked so small against the great big rock." 
 It was Cyclamen hederifolia, a hardy species with delicate pink or white flowers that rise, one to a five-inch stem, long before the leaves appear. Its petals are thrown back, so the flowers look a bit like gossamer butterflies hovering low to the earth. When the leaves finally appear, they can be rounded or lance-shaped and are often swirled with silver.
No wonder she was smitten.
"I got some seeds from Thompson & Morgan and started them when we got back to North Carolina," said Mrs. Goodwin, a plantswoman known for her Montrose Nursery.
In 1977, she and her husband, Craufurd, who teaches economics at Duke University, moved to an estate called Montrose, on the outskirts of Hillsborough, N.C., about 14 miles west of Durham. They were taken with the big white 19th-century house, but it was the towering oaks and metasequoias, the old beeches and magnolias and a serpentine boxwood border that won their hearts. There was an enormous vegetable garden south of the house, and woods sloping down to a stream that fed a pond.
"My father always said the best dirt was Hillsborough clay loam," Mrs. Goodwin said last Sunday afternoon over dinner.
The trees and boxwoods had been planted by William Alexander Graham, who bought the place in 1830.
"He served as Governor, and Senator, and Secretary of the Navy under Millard Fillmore," Mr. Goodwin said. "He was the one who sent Commodore Perry to Japan to open up the port -- and he came back bearing plants. We think the lycoris in the rock garden is one of them."
But to get back to that first cyclamen in Surrey, it began an adventure with rare and endangered plants that Mrs. Goodwin soon turned into Montrose Nursery.
"I wanted to grow all of the 19 species of cyclamens," said Mrs. Goodwin, who has 18 thriving in her garden. "But when I tried to import some of the plants from England, I got stopped at customs because of the Cites requirements for endangered plants."
Cites, or the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, was trying to stop the tide of millions of cyclamen tubers, illegally collected in the wild in Turkey, from being sold in the United States.
The situation gave Mrs. Goodwin a mission: "I started building up my collection from seeds," she said.
At the time, Mrs. Goodwin was giving piano and harpsichord lessons to uninspired students.
"I wanted to be in the garden," she said. "It's a magnet. And I thought that having a nursery would get me out of the music room and into the garden."
So in 1984, she sent out a mimeographed plant list to about 25 friends. "I had a lot of cyclamens and some heat-tolerant primulas I'd stumbled on," she said. "And I'd also rooted cuttings from the old boxwoods."
By 1993, Mrs. Goodwin's low-key catalogue (no pictures, just honest descriptions of plants by the one who loved them) was a near bible for serious gardeners.
And Montrose was becoming a kind of mecca for plant lovers, who would wander with their notebooks down the dianthus walk. Thyme-like flowers of Calamintha nepeta lounge among old-fashioned pinks with names like Essex Witch and Agatha, ranging in color from satiny pink to salmon and burgundy, white and crimson.
Visitors might head for the cyclamens growing beneath the venerable magnolia, or the deodar cedar, or explore the hellebores and heucheras and epimediums that thrive beneath the shade of the oaks that lead to the rock garden. Or maybe they would head past the serpentine boxwood border to a tumble of sun-loving perennials, from New England asters in shades of white, pink and purple, to verbena bonariensis, butterfly bushes, magenta waves of Petunia integrafolia, blue-gray plectranthus, purple barberry, deep-violet ironweed, salvias of all kinds and colors, purple-leafed cannas and tall smoke trees.
Tall white lilies (Lilium formosanum) have naturalized all over this sunny garden, and down a few stairs, where melons once grew, is a blue and yellow garden stuffed with lespedezas, caryopteris, blue fescues and limegrass, helianthus and rudbeckias and countless other plants.
But the nursery became too successful, and Mrs. Goodwin said she was "working night and day filling orders and packing up the plants." Managing a nursery didn't leave much time for being in the garden.
And in 1992, one of her dearest helpers, Jo Petty, died in a car crash.
"She was 19," said Mrs. Goodwin, 60. "I thought of all the things she would have done -- and all the things I wanted to do. I think that, more than anything, is what made me close the nursery."
So in 1993, Mrs. Goodwin stopped putting out her catalogue. But the inveterate plant lover still sells a limited number of plants to visitors, and the garden is open for tours, at $6 a person, Tuesdays through Thursdays. She also gives seminars on propagation and design with her colleagues, Doug Ruhren and Gabrielle McDermit. But call first for an appointment; (919) 732-7787.
"I don't like coming home and finding people strolling across the lawn," said Mrs. Goodwin, who treasures her privacy -- and time with her plants.
 
From Seedlings To Success
Here's how Nancy Goodwin starts cyclamen from seed: Soak the seeds for 6 to 24 hours in warm water, then drain. (Best results can be expected from sowing fresh seeds, in which case no soaking is required.) Plant in a gritty mix, covering with about a quarter-inch of soil or grit. Place the pots in total darkness. Germination should begin in about six weeks. Move them into the light as soon as the seeds germinate, and let the young seedlings grow for about a year. Then, transplant into the garden in a well-drained, semi-shady spot. Most cyclamens like to stay dry, so don't kill them by overwatering.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Pact Could Quiet Helicopter War

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The air war between helicopter operators and Manhattan residents appears to be on the verge of an armistice. After nearly six months of sparring, the main operators, National Helicopter and Liberty Helicopter, have drafted a tentative agreement to make their routes higher than before, mainly over water and away from most Upper West Side, Upper East Side and midtown residential areas.
The Federal Aviation Administration now has the agreement under review, but, barring some conflict with aviation rules or a last-minute objection by the parties, the pact will go into effect on Sept. 3. A spokeswoman for Peter McGann, president of National Helicopter, said that no helicopter operator has signed the agreement. 
 Meanwhile, the choice of a new operator for Manhattan's busiest heliport, at 34th Street and the East River, is still up in the air. So, too, are the sharp reductions in the number of hours, takeoffs and landings mandated by the City Council in March.
In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in May, the current operator, National Helicopter, argued that the City Council did not have the authority to impose the restrictions, which the company described as unconstitutional and arbitrary. National's lease expired on July 31, but it plans to make a bid to continue as the new operator.
Last year, there were nearly 141,000 takeoffs and landings at Manhattan's four principal heliports, averaging nearly 400 a day, according to a study by the Economic Development Corporation.
Residents had accused operators of flying as low as 500 feet; operators denied this. "But we meant what we said," said Matthew S. Zuccaro, an official with the Eastern Region Helicopter Council, a Newark trade group that coordinated the helicopter operators' side of the negotiations. "We are committed to working with the community."
Perry Luntz, a member of Community Board 6 whose Turtle Bay neighborhood has complained about helicopter noise, said, "The agreement does not go far enough, and I have to approach it with a grain of salt, but it is a great improvement."
Under the agreement, which was negotiated with the help of Borough President Ruth W. Messinger's office, National and Liberty will fly at least 100 feet higher than the 1,400 feet now required.
But Thomas Bock, an F.A.A. official specializing in helicopter-noise disputes, said: "What is significant about this agreement is that 1,500 feet is a minimum altitude based on jet traffic above that level. It could be as high as 2,000 feet," which would result in a substantial reduction in noise.
The operators agreed to fly north over the East River, instead of over Second Avenue, then west across Central Park at 86th Street, instead of anywhere in the park. Activists like Marnie Mueller said operators flew as far north as 106th Street and as far south as 59th, as well as along Fifth Avenue. The operators denied the charge.
The operators also agreed to establish a toll-free complaint line, (888) 374-2463, which is now operational, and to give a distinctive paint scheme to Liberty and National's helicopters to make identification easier. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: The Dark Side of a Magical Metal

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
AROUND 1986, Dr. Lee Newman and fellow researchers in Denver got the first warnings of a troubling discovery: A workplace illness thought to have been largely defeated was flourishing.
The resurgent health threat was chronic beryllium disease, or C.B.D., a potentially fatal lung ailment that afflicts only the small minority of people whose immune systems are susceptible to beryllium, apparently because of their genetic makeup. Beryllium, a naturally occurring metal, is used to make components and alloys for car ignition systems, computers, spacecraft and nuclear bombs. 
 In the 20 years leading up to Dr. Newman's findings, only a handful of C.B.D. cases among workers were reported annually to health authorities.
But as researchers began to examine workers in factories and clinics, they discovered that hundreds of them either had symptoms of C.B.D., also known as berylliosis, or had immune reactions to the presence of beryllium, a process that can lead to development of the disease.
"Every place we are looking for the disease, we are finding it," Dr. Newman said in a recent interview. A pulmonologist, he specializes in occupational and environmental medicine at the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine in Denver.
Many trails in this medical mystery lead back to Brush Wellman Inc., a Cleveland-based company that is the leading producer of beryllium in the United States and whose stock has a value of $325 million on the New York Stock Exchange. For nearly 50 years, Brush Wellman has maintained that Federal workplace standards on beryllium exposure were sufficient to protect workers against C.B.D. Today, company officials acknowledge that exceptions to that rule may exist, but they say they only began to suspect so in recent years.
Scores of documents recently disclosed in mounting litigation against Brush Wellman tell a far more complex story. They provide a window into how a company, seeing a profitable product threatened, can turn its energies not only to solving that dilemma quickly but also to defending a scientific line in the sand and limiting its liabilities. The Brush Wellman problems also illustrate what other companies might face as researchers increasingly find that some workers, because of their genetic makeup, are susceptible to occupational ills.
For two decades, Brush Wellman disputed reports that workers were being sickened by beryllium at minimal exposures and, in one case, did not tell regulators about those findings, court documents indicate. With the number of C.B.D. cases growing and a company consultant questioning the adequacy of Federal exposure limits, a top company executive told Brush Wellman directors in 1990 that maintaining Federal standards as the legal authority on beryllium's toxicity was essential to "successfully defending" the company against lawsuits, according to a copy of the presentation. Brush Wellman also considered genetic testing to screen out vulnerable employees; in recent years those workers affected by beryllium exposure have had to make painful decisions about whether to quit.
Brush Wellman officials deny that they did anything wrong and maintain that for decades they have been at the forefront of C.B.D. research. And independent scientists say they have seen a new openness in management in recent years.
But some company executives acknowledge that with the re-emergence of C.B.D., Brush Wellman has been forced to be much more aggressive in trying to learn how workers are sickened by beryllium.
"This is something that concerns us all greatly," said Martin B. Powers, a former vice president at Brush Wellman and currently a member of the Beryllium Industry Scientific Advisory Panel, a consulting group principally financed by the company.
The workers exposed to beryllium are far fewer than those affected by asbestos exposure. Nonetheless, some of their stories appear to be equally tragic.
As for exposure outside the workplace, experts say that finished products containing beryllium do not pose health threats to consumers; it is an industrial threat.
In an annual filing recently to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Brush Wellman said it was a defendant in numerous lawsuits filed by employees, former employees and employees of customers claiming health problems from beryllium exposure. Timothy Reed, a company spokesman, said several of those actions, including one that sought class-action status, were recently dismissed. About 14 lawsuits, filed largely by employees of industrial customers, are pending, he said.
Beryllium, which is extracted from ore and processed into various forms, is an extraordinary material, lighter than aluminum and six times stiffer than steel. But this magical metal has a treacherous aspect; the 1 to 5 percent of the population that is genetically susceptible can have a devastating immunological reaction.
The reaction involves the same biological phenomena that occur in allergies like hay fever. But exposure to beryllium dust in those who have become sensitized to it can lead to a buildup of scar tissue in the lungs that can reduce their capacity to process oxygen and ultimately result in death.
While most people can tolerate beryllium, others can be laid low by minute traces of it. In 1980, for instance, a furnace exploded at Brush Wellman's plant in Elmore, Ohio, severely burning Carolyn Mason's husband and coating him with beryllium dust. Mrs. Mason said she had nursed him at home.
"For days, I cleaned this stuff out of his skin and his hair," Mrs. Mason said.
Her husband, who still works at the Elmore plant, has not developed C.B.D. But the cost of Mrs. Mason's exposure to much smaller doses of the metallic dust became apparent in 1989. She said she experienced severe rib pain and eventually was sent to see Dr. Newman after she had been misdiagnosed several times. She soon learned she had C.B.D., for which there is no known cure.
In an effort to control the disease, she now takes steroids, which can have severe side effects, and she must be on an oxygen unit 24 hours a day. "I'll never be off of it," said Mrs. Mason, who eventually sued Brush Wellman. The case was settled out of court for an undisclosed sum, she said.

A Disease Seems to Disappear
Recognizing beryllium's extreme toxicity, Federal officials set a tough workplace standard in 1949, limiting average workday exposure to the metal to two micrograms per cubic meter of air, the equivalent of dispersing the dust from a lead pencil's tip evenly through a six-foot-high box the size of a football field.
The results were dramatic. Cases of acute beryllium poisoning, a disease bought on quickly by extremely high exposures to the material, disappeared and, by the early 1960's, the more insidious cases of C.B.D. appeared to slow to a trickle. Brush Wellman officials were so confident of the Federal standard's effectiveness that they repeatedly declared in the mid-1980's that only three C.B.D. cases had been found among company employees hired after 1960.
"We thought the problem was largely licked," said Merril Eisenbud, a professor emeritus at New York University Medical Center who became a paid consultant to Brush Wellman around 1990.
But even as they were declaring victory over the disease in the 1980's, Brush Wellman officials had reason to suspect that all might not be as it seemed. Fully a decade earlier, they had received a study from a Japanese researcher that raised troubling questions about the Federal standards.
Dr. Shogo Shima, a medical consultant to NGK Industries, a Japanese beryllium producer, reported that he had found five Japanese workers with advanced cases of C.B.D. whose earlier exposures to beryllium had apparently been below the American limit.
The company received the report in 1974. Shortly after, Mr. Shima met with top managers, including Mr. Powers, and reiterated his findings, according to court documents. And yet, in testimony three years later at a Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration hearing, top company officials declared that they did not know of a single study that had detected C.B.D. in workers who had been exposed to beryllium levels below the Federal limit.
In an interview, Mr. Powers said he and others had not mentioned the Japanese findings during the inquiry, largely because the hearing had focused on beryllium's cancer threat rather than on C.B.D. He added that company officials also believed that Dr. Shima's research methodology was faulty.
"At that time we didn't take this very seriously," Mr. Powers said, referring to Dr. Shima's work.
But that work may hold the answer to the riddle of why C.B.D. seemingly disappeared in this country, only to reappear: a lack of routine follow-up testing of exposed workers. Dr. Shima said NGK began giving regular follow-up physicals to retired employees in the mid-1970's. Such monitoring is necessary to chart the course of the disease, in his opinion, because C.B.D. can lie dormant for so long. In addition, C.B.D. symptoms can be easily confused with those of other respiratory illnesses.
Brush Wellman, however, did not give former workers such regular follow-up exams. Instead, it encouraged them to get in touch with the company if they experienced health problems, Mr. Powers said.
"Beyond that, the responsibility was on the former employee," he said.

Better Tests Emerge
In the mid-1980's, just as Brush Wellman was celebrating C.B.D.'s supposed eradication, events were already unfolding that would shatter that assumption.
Around 1985, Dr. Kathleen Kreiss, a colleague of Dr. Newman who was then at the National Jewish Center, received a call from the medical department at the Rocky Flats nuclear-weapons plant outside Denver. The question for her was simple: Could pregnant employees at the plant who faced dangers from radiation exposure be safely shifted to areas where beryllium was used?
At the time, Dr. Newman was experimenting with a refined beryllium blood test on laboratory animals. In response to the inquiry from Rocky Flats, he and Dr. Kreiss administered it to workers there.
The test, though not 100 percent accurate, allowed the researchers to screen large numbers of people for early signs of C.B.D. rather than wait for years for severe symptoms to develop. In cases where the blood test indicated a problem, a lung test was performed to detect disease.
"We realized we didn't have to wait 10 years" to find C.B.D., said Dr. Kreiss, now a professor of occupational medicine at the University of Colorado.
Dr. Kreiss and Dr. Newman initially found a cluster of several Rocky Flats workers with C.B.D. The tests continued, and to date have identified about 200 workers at Department of Energy facilities with blood or chest abnormalities associated with beryllium exposure, including more than 50 cases of full-fledged C.B.D., according to Federal statistics.
After the first Rocky Flats data were made public in the late 1980's, the Coors Ceramics Company, a unit of ACX Technologies Inc. that purchased beryllium from Brush Wellman, took up the question of whether to test its employees. But Beverly Obenchain, a former director of environmental health and safety at Coors, said that when she asked Brush Wellman officials for their opinion, their reaction was cautious.
"Brush was concerned that we could give validity to Lee's test because it was the new test on the block," Ms. Obenchain recalled. "It was very difficult for me to understand. It would definitely increase costs but in the long run it might minimize treatments." Coors did test and found nine cases of C.B.D. among current and former employees.
Robert H. Rozek, senior vice president for Brush Wellman's international operation, said the company had legitimate concerns about the test's accuracy. But by 1989, Mr. Eisenbud, the Brush Wellman adviser, was also questioning the Federal standard, pointing to C.B.D. cases among secretaries and other employees who spent little time in factories, court documents indicate. He soon told other Brush Wellman consultants that he "knew of no other occupational illness with so many cases in clerical rather than production workers," according to minutes of that meeting.
In retrospect, some Government officials said they believed that some evidence questioning the Federal standard had emerged years ago. For example, Dr. Tara O'Toole, the Department of Energy's assistant secretary for environment, safety and health, said 10 workers at Government nuclear weapons plants had immunological reactions to beryllium even though their jobs apparently did not bring them into direct contact with the material. "It was probably clear by the late 1980's and early 1990's that the existing standard was not protecting workers," Dr. O'Toole said.
 
A Company on the Defensive
Brush Wellman officials were also becoming aware that the problem was worse than they had thought. Diagnosed cases of C.B.D. within the company had also started to swell, including some at a relatively new plant in Tucson, Ariz., considered to have up-to-date safety equipment.
With questions building over the Federal standards, the mood within the company grew increasingly defensive, and officials dug in to protect their principal product, ward off lawsuits and limit liabilities, court papers indicate.
In 1990, Brush Wellman executives told the company's board that preventing any tightening of the Federal exposure standard was "fundamental to our defense against product liability lawsuits," according to a presentation made at that meeting. And despite mounting scientific evidence to the contrary, company officials continued to tell customers in 1991 that the standard appeared to protect even the most "hypersensitive" workers.
Brush Wellman officials had long argued that their confidence in the standard was based on two related and, they contended, unrefuted premises. The first was that any worker who developed C.B.D. had been suddenly exposed to higher-than-allowed beryllium levels, either through equipment failure or carelessness. The other was that no one had shown that a worker who had been exposed solely to conditions that fell within the Federal standard had developed C.B.D.
There appear to be several problems with the company's contentions. For one, Mr. Eisenbud said it seemed highly unlikely that every case of C.B.D. suffered by a secretary or other nonfactory employee could be attributable to a sudden, high exposure to beryllium, given the rarity of their contact with it.
Also, no one really knows at what level the disease process can be initiated. The company's own executives acknowledged in an interview that they could not measure with accuracy the exposure to the metal by workers with C.B.D. because such exposure occurs years before the disease appears.
"There was no way of knowing what the actual exposure level of an individual was," Mr. Powers said.
Further muddying the scientific debate over safety was another little-mentioned factor. Brush Wellman apparently had little idea of the extent of the beryllium contamination inside its own factories, according to a 1989 report by a panel of the National Research Council, which advises the Government on science and technology issues.
The group, sponsored jointly by the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering, also questioned the Federal standard's safety.
"Sufficient and accurate background exposure data are lacking" in beryllium production facilities, the report found. "These would provide a sound scientific data base for establishing recommended exposure limits."

The Liability Issues
By 1990, it was becoming increasingly clear to Brush Wellman officials that they would have to deal with a new generation of workers affected by beryllium exposure, court papers indicated.
In the past, Brush Wellman had supplemented the salary of an employee unable to work because of C.B.D. until retirement age. But now, with a test able to detect blood abnormalities and other early signs of the disease, the company faced new questions, including how to compensate afflicted workers who were not disabled.
Experts like Dr. Newman and Dr. Kreiss did not know whether removing affected workers from further contact with beryllium would affect the progress of C.B.D., but they, like other doctors, believed that it was the medically prudent course. Still, as the two Denver doctors in 1991 laid plans to conduct a large-scale health screening of Brush Wellman workers, company executives apparently had their own thoughts, court papers indicate.
In a strategic plan presented at a 1991 board meeting, one item advocated efforts to "pre-empt" doctors' recommendations to C.B.D. sufferers to avoid any further beryllium exposure. "Such a process attacks the efficacy of the existing standard," the document states.
Mr. Rozek said the company was concerned at the time that if many doctors who had little knowledge about C.B.D. recommended that their patients stop working, such suggestions could be misperceived as evidence that the standard was not working.
The refined blood test also had other implications: The potential cost of compensating all the workers diagnosed with the disease, as opposed to those actually disabled by it, could open a financial black hole, company officials worried.
To avoid that, they established a limited compensation policy: Employees who showed blood abnormalities or other signs of early-stage C.B.D. would receive up to one year in salary and benefits if they left the company and would qualify for full health care benefits if they later became unable to work because of the disease. Workers like Galen Lemke of Elmore, who had left the company before 1993 without any symptoms, might qualify for small cash payments if they ultimately came down with the disease, but those were not guaranteed.
"To lock yourself into a commitment to a policy to an unknown population didn't make economic sense to us," said Daniel A. Skoch, the company's vice president for human resources and administration.
Dr. Newman said he is now conducting a Government-financed study to determine what percentage of beryllium-sensitized workers will develop C.B.D. In those studied so far, the ratio was about 1 of every 4 affected workers.
With such uncertainty hanging over them, Brush Wellman workers recently faced difficult decisions when the results of their tests became known. At the company's Elmore plant, surrounded by farmland 30 miles east of Toledo, 6 of the 50 workers who had become sensitized to beryllium or showed early disease symptoms decided to take the company's severance package last year, even though that meant giving up some of the highest wages in the area.
Mr. Reed, the company spokesman, said the majority of cases had occurred among company workers handling pure beryllium metal or ceramic materials rather than beryllium copper, which accounts for the majority of the company's sales. Christine Toth, who worked in secretarial and clerical jobs for Brush Wellman for 16 years, said she decided to leave because of health concerns after a test last year showed that she had become sensitized to beryllium. But like other former company employees, she quickly became concerned about discrimination by insurers or prospective employers who learned of the test results.
"When I first started looking for a new job I told the truth about the test and no one would hire me," said Ms. Toth, whose lawsuit against Brush Wellman was dismissed this year, before trial. "But when I stopped telling the truth, I got the job."

The Lingering Questions
Today, Brush Wellman officials, while emphasizing their belief that the Federal standard is safe for most people, said they were reducing exposure levels at their facilities to the lowest feasible levels. And researchers like Dr. Kreiss are evaluating why certain processes pose particularly high risk to workers.
Hovering in the background is another big issue: whether genetic testing should be used to screen out people susceptible to a workplace hazard before they are hired.
The issue goes beyond beryllium. Some workers, apparently because of their genetic makeup, are also suspectible to airborne particles in the workplace like cotton dust and some chemicals.
Advocates of genetic screening say that tests could be used to identify susceptible individuals and keep them out of harm's way -- and possibly off payrolls. But many scientists, labor leaders and ethicists have decried the use of genetic screening in the workplace, arguing it is discriminatory and that companies have an obligation to make conditions safe for all workers.
For years, Brush Wellman financed research to develop a genetic test, court papers indicate. And in 1992, its hopes were apparently so high that actuarial projections were run to show the impact of genetic testing on future C.B.D.-related costs to the company, the court documents indicate.
A test of 35 workers with C.B.D. found that 34 shared a specific genetic marker. There was, however, a complicating factor: A similar test of workers without C.B.D. found that about one of every three had the same marker.
Dr. Cesare Saltini, the test's developer, said the results indicated that the test alone was not suitable as a screening tool. But he said he believed it might prove helpful to understand the biological mechanism of C.B.D. and other occupational ills, a project that Brush Wellman officials say they continue to support.
"We are looking at beryllium as a model to look at allergies to metals and chemicals," said Dr. Saltini, a professor at the University of Modena in Italy.
Dealing with the re-emergence of C.B.D. appears to have been a sobering experience for some Brush Wellman officials. Dr. Kreiss said, for example, that after a change in company management in the early 1990's she noticed a change in Brush Wellman's attitude toward its beryllium problem and a receptiveness to new ideas.
Brush Wellman's stock price has fallen steadily over the last decade. One analyst said that he had dropped coverage of the company recently, dismayed by its slow pace of profit growth rather than because of concerns about litigation. "In terms of litigation, I did not factor that in as one of the great problems," said the analyst, Kemp Fuller Jr. of LT Lawrence & Company.
A spokesman for OSHA said that the agency did not have any immediate plans to revise the beryllium standard but that it continues to review new scientific data as they become available. For its part, the Energy Department, which initially considered cutting the OSHA standard in half at its facilities, expects to issue a rule next year requiring that beryllium exposure be limited to the lowest feasible level and that all exposed workers wear respirators, Dr. O'Toole said.
Mr. Eisenbud, who helped create the original Federal standard nearly 50 years ago, says that he believes it can still serve as a target for employers but that there is plenty of anecdotal evidence that it may not be safe for everyone. He also says he believes the Federal Government has largely forsaken its role in conducting the necessary scientific research to resolve the debate.
"Though 50 years, this has been a scientific mystery," Mr. Eisenbud said. "There is no other toxic substance that would not come under control when you applied standards of industrial hygiene to it."
For his part, Dr. Newman, who has agreed to testify against Brush Wellman as an expert witness on behalf of his patients, sees other lessons in the episode. He said he did not believe that Brush Wellman fit a cardboard stereotype of corporate wrongdoing. But he added that he thought company officials in the past reacted to their dilemma as other executives elsewhere had done and as other companies undoubtedly would do again in the future.
"There were plenty of red flags along the line," he said. "They didn't react quickly to those red flags and that only compounded the problem."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Perennial Candidate

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
NO one would call Samuel D. Morell a sore loser. As a pesky perennial candidate who has run for the Council from the Upper East Side nine times in 20 years, Mr. Morell has been roundly trounced, ridiculed and just plain ignored by a political system that favors well-connected candidates over cash-strapped outsiders. After each bruising loss, Mr. Morell, an itinerant liquor salesman who is seldom without his trademark cowboy boots and BMW motorcycle, just gets up, brushes himself off and does it all over again. "What can I say?" he asked. "I'm a glutton for punishment."
This year, Mr. Morell, 54, a garrulous, heavyset man who can't sit still very long, is at it again. Although his opponent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, Councilman A. Gifford Miller, has the backing of every Democratic official and political club in Council District 5, Mr. Morell thinks that this time, he may have a chance. "Gifford is a pompous 26-year-old Princeton grad," he said last week, as he drove a reporter through the streets of Yorkville on the back of his motorcycle. "Me, I'm a common guy, a pit bull who isn't afraid to make waves. I think the voters can appreciate that." 
 Appreciation -- and money -- are two things Mr. Morell desperately longs for. As in years past, he is struggling to get out his homemade campaign literature. So far, he has less than half the $11,000 needed to print, label and mail out his fliers. With no headquarters, no organization and few resources, Mr. Morell relies on a handful of friends to help get his message out.
"Sam doesn't stand a chance of winning, but I think he's good for the political system," said Christopher Lynn, the city's Transportation Commissioner, who donated $100 to Mr. Morell's campaign this year. "He's unbossed, unbought and he's as honest as the day is long."
Others view Mr. Morell with bemusement and scorn. "Sam is a personable guy, but his campaigns never get any better and no one ever flocks to his side," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Democrat who represents the area. "I can't figure out why he runs." Robert J. Dryfoos, the district's former Councilman, said he believed that Mr. Morell runs to gratify his ego and to meet women while gathering petitions. "Sam Morell is like a perennial flower that expires a few weeks after it blooms," he said. "He comes back again when it serves his purposes."
Mr. Morell is used to questions about his motivation, and his response is typically florid. "I've got blood in my veins, a big mouth and I see problems I know how to fix," he said. Politics, he says, has been in his blood since his mother dragged him to Democratic rallies in the Bronx as a child. During one such event, he met then-Senator Jacob K. Javits, who patted him on the head and said: "Nice kid. You should run for office," Mr. Morell recalled. Those words of encouragement stuck.
Born and raised on Allerton Avenue in the Bronx, Mr. Morell gets teary-eyed when speaking of his mother, who raised six children alone by taking in boarders. "She taught me to always do the right thing even if it costs you money," he said. His formal education ended with high school and Mr. Morell points to the Woodstock music festival in 1969 as a formative learning experience. But unlike thousands of other youths, who were indulging in free love and psychedelic drugs, Mr. Morell was racing to sell 45,000 ice cream pops before they melted. With the $4,200 he earned at the event, he opened a clothing store on East 81st Street, which he lost during the economic downturn of the mid-1970's.
His first bid for public office came in 1973, when he tried to tackle the incumbent Councilman, Carter Burden, a wealthy scion of the Vanderbilt family. But the Board of Elections disqualified his candidacy after failing to find proof of his party registration. The ensuing legal battle to gain legitimacy was a seminal event in his would-be political career. Unwilling to spend money on a lawyer, Mr. Morell steeped himself in the arcane world of New York election law and successfully beat the board in Federal court. By then, however, there was no time to collect the required batch of signatures for getting on the ballot. In the following years, Mr. Morell has been forced to defend his signatures many times, making him something of an election law expert.
During the five races in which he actually made it on the Democratic primary ballot, Mr. Morell says he has been daunted by the task of campaigning while holding a full-time job. "There are some days I'm so exhausted," he said, "I find it hard to get out of bed in the morning."
But such tribulations have had little effect on his formidable verbal skills. Mr. Morell requires little prompting on the subjects of taxes, transportation and parking. His quirky platform includes proposals to abolish the city's Water Board, to increase off-street parking and tighten restrictions on street vendors who sell food.
He brags that he'll never tell voters what they want to hear just to win their support and describes a candidates' forum on Roosevelt Island several years ago at which Council hopefuls promised a roomful of anxious residents that if elected, they would make the island's financial troubles disappear. When Mr. Morell stood before the gathering, his remarks were brief and unforgiving. "Get off your butt, people, and have a bake sale," he shouted. "You've got to help yourself."
With two weeks until election day, Mr. Morell has a familiar sinking feeling. "All I need is a little support," he said. If he loses badly, he swears that it will be his last race. "Everyone thinks I'm crazy for running again, but what really matters to me is that when I die, I want this to be carved on my tombstone," he said, pausing to gather his thoughts. "Sam Morell, he was fearless and he did the right thing."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Why America Pays To Play Top Executives

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
WHEN Alex J. Mandl got a $20 million signing bonus last week for quitting AT&T to run an obscure wireless telephone company, he did more than raise the salary sweepstakes for other top executives. He also ignited a fresh debate about how to measure worth in corporate America.
Mr. Mandl's gravity-defying compensation puts him in the realm of superstar athletes like Michael Jordan, who is earning $25 million for one season with the Chicago Bulls, or Shaquille O'Neal, who has a seven-year, $120 million deal with the Los Angeles Lakers. 
 Mr. Mandl, however, is not the best person to ever play the corporate game. While the Austrian-born executive may have been in line to succeed AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, his colleagues describe him as a sturdy, single-minded businessman.
Hardly grounds for a $20 million paycheck.
What Mr. Mandl has is an exquisite sense of timing. The business world now yearns for marquee executives -- and is increasingly willing to compensate them like film stars or franchise players. It's not that the executives are any better. It's just that technology and the dismantling of Government regulations have turned the marketplace upside down.

 
 
The 'Great Man' Theory
 In such a vertiginous environment, where new industries seem to spring up overnight while old ones are snuffed out, big-name executives act as anchors. They can soothe shareholders and, even more important, lure new capital from investors who would otherwise shy away from complex or unproven technologies.
"Academics, journalists and securities analysts have all become bewitched with the 'great man' theory of business," said Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld, the director of the Center for Leadership and Career Studies at Emory University. "We have developed such a cult of personality that we think the chief executive personifies the firm."
In corporate America, what separates stars from working stiffs is not always clear. As AT&T's president, the 52-year-old Mr. Mandl had just enough heft to make the cut. Before joining AT&T, he ran Sea-Land Services, a giant shipping company, and more than doubled the company's revenues in three years.
Perception matters as much as reality, though, and in Mr. Mandl's case, a dollop of myth-making helped. Newspaper and magazine articles routinely refer to him as a brash leader who chafed in the stodgy confines of AT&T. Throw in his stocky build and silvery hair, and Mr. Mandl comes across almost like a Jack Kemp for the Rotary Club crowd.
In reality, he is rather low-key and reserved. One senior AT&T executive said Mr. Mandl was so aloof he had trouble galvanizing his colleagues behind his strategy for propelling AT&T into the newly deregulated telecommunications market.
But Mr. Mandl's skills are almost beside the point. The owners of his new company, Associated Communications, would like to take their venture public in the next year or so. Wall Street analysts said that the mere fact Mr. Mandl was involved could double the value of the stock offering -- from $250 million to $500 million.
"What you need is a signal that you have what it takes to succeed," said Robert H. Frank, an economist at Cornell University and the co-author, with Philip J. Cook, of "The Winner Takes All Society" (Martin Kessler/Free Press, 1995). "Now you've got a guy who is willing to give up his future at AT&T to bet on this technology. That's all the market needs to know."

 
 
The Flop Threat
 The danger in hiring celebrity executives is that -- much as a star athlete can get injured or a blockbuster actor can make a flop -- the big-name boss may never end up building a good company.
Barry Diller, the creator of the Fox network, brought Hollywood glamor to the dowdy business of home shopping when he became chairman of the QVC cable channel in 1992. Mr. Diller promised to transform QVC from a peddler of pillow covers to a high-tech electronic bazaar. That was enough to drive its stock through the roof, and Mr. Diller pocketed more than $100 million in profits. But while QVC remains successful, his loftier ambitions for home shopping fizzled, and Mr. Diller moved on.
John Sculley, the charismatic former chairman of Apple Computer, resigned in 1993 to run a small wireless company, Spectrum Information Technologies. Mr. Sculley left several months later, unable to fix problems that ranged from financial losses to criminal dealings by managers.
Such horror stories aside, Mr. Mandl's new employers may have already made the right decision in hiring him. The shares of Associated Group, which owns 55 percent of Mr. Mandl's venture, rose $6.75 in the 48 hours after his appointment was announced. That makes Mr. Mandl's employers roughly $120 million richer. At those numbers, a $20 million signing bonus looks like chump change.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

REPUBLICANS
A Tax-Cut Pilgrimage
 
It wasn't a quiet week, in Lake Wobegon or anywhere else, as the Republicans endlessly sang their new tax-cut anthem. With a capital-gains tax cut, Jack Kemp vowed, "Everyone can get rich" (just as all the Lake Wobegon children are above average). He and Bob Dole had traveled to that tax-cut shrine called New Jersey, clearly hoping that a bit of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's magic dust -- it was, of course, on tax-cut wings that she flew from behind to victory a few years back -- would rub off. Yes, he told his audience, they could have it all: lower taxes, a balanced budget and stronger Social Security and Medicare. As for Democrats who say it won't add up, they're just trying to "scare people," Mr. Dole said. But there were questions in the audience like "How realistic is it?" or "Can he really come through?"
 
DEMOCRATS
The Presidential Inkwell
 
Bill Clinton, meanwhile, just couldn't stop signing things, wielding his tireless pen in an undisguised effort to prance into Chicago looking ever so Presidential. It was an odd mix, though: First came the minimum-wage bill, firmly in the liberal tradition of helping those at the bottom; then came a bill to expand access to health insurance, an inevitable reminder that this was a mere shadow of the revolution the Clintons had dreamed of, and finally the welfare bill, a scrapping of bedrock New Deal philosophy that outraged diehard liberals. It's a "moment of shame," said Marion Wright Edelman, a children's advocate. "This isn't welfare reform; it's welfare denial," said Senator Paul Simon of Illinois. And Bob Dole chimed in that the President "is ideologically adrift."
 
INSURANCE
Is Lloyd's Lloyd's Again?
 
Lloyd's of London. It still has a solid ring to it, doesn't it? It still evokes images of sober, whiskered gentlemen in top hats telling you in soothing, Gielgudian tones that all will be well. But all is not well, of course. The insurer is in an epic financial mess. Many people who've long pledged their assets to back its policies -- "names," they're called (translation: rich people) -- seemed in danger of being wiped out by a flood of claims. But now, we're told, it has all been worked out. On Wednesday the "names" will pay modest sums to a new company called Equitas and rid themselves of dark visions of Dickensian ruin. And Equitas, magically, will be able to deal with those vast liabilities. Will it work? "Our official position is that Equitas has plenty of money," one insider said. "But our fingers are crossed." But a Dow Corning executive wanted nothing of stiff upper lips, calling the deal "a giant international insurance shell game."
 
LEAVING AT&T
And It Isn't Even the N.B.A.
 
For a business executive, the pinnacle, naturally, is to run a giant company. That's the big leagues, the Broadway spotlight, the ultimate medal to pin on the ego. Executives down the ladder may hop off on some quixotic adventure, but what about someone on the doorstep of the chairman's office? Never. No, make that hardly ever. Alex Mandl, the AT&T president, seemed the heir apparent to Robert Allen, the chairman. But Mr. Mandl, 52, hopped off last week, taking the top job at tiny Associated Communications, which has big, big plans in wireless communications. What's the lesson here? (There must always be a lesson.) Well, it could be something profound about the fast-shifting horizons of the new, deregulated world of communications. Or, perhaps, it has something to do with the new company dangling a check in front of Mr. Mandl that looked as if it should have had Michael Jordan's name on it: a $20 million signing bonus.
 
LOTTERIES
Fantasies, Tamed
 
With a lottery, the house always wins. That's the point. And in New York, it wins big -- the state doesn't spend $42 million a year on ads for nothing. So what does it take to get the huddled masses, yearning to spend free, to plunk down precious dollars when the odds are so miserable? Simple: those ads, which have raised the selling of fantasies to an art form. "Hey, you never know," the sirens call; that mansion is just waiting for you. Enter Gov. George E. Pataki, worried that the ads promised too much. (Ads exaggerate? Never!) Scrap the mansions, he said. So the new ads feature winners boasting of the new blenders they received, or the new shoes. Honest, yes, but only a real blender freak would have to be strapped to the mast to resist that siren song.
 
TRADE
A New Deficit Champ
 
Well-trained newspaper readers know that if the first sentence is about the dreaded trade deficit, the second sentence will be about Japan -- about, yet again, how we buy so much from the Japanese and sell them so little. Year after year after year. Well, brace yourself (drums and cymbals, please): For the first time ever, Japan is not the largest source of the American deficit. In June, the figure for China rose to $3.3 billion, while for Japan it fell to $3.2 billion. Why? Well, China is selling us a lot of toys, clothes and other stuff, while Japan, emerging from recession, can afford more stuff for itself -- often foreign stuff. But one thing is the same: Though the deficit fell in June, America continues to devour the world's goods.
 
PROSTATE TROUBLE
What Works, What Doesn't
 
So: Bill Clinton is 50. More yesterdays than tomorrows and all that. Also, perhaps, more prostate trouble -- it hits half of men over 50. And as it happens, prostate remedies were also in the news in the Birthday Week. The New England Journal of Medicine reported that Hytrin, from Abbott Laboratories, was effective against an enlarged prostate, while Merck's drug, Proscar, did little better than a placebo. Merck, which had approved the study's methods, now says the study wasn't designed properly after all.
 
 
PRISONS
A Grim Success Story
 
When a business takes off, it's normally a cause for rejoicing. Jobs are created, widgets abound, economists smile. But at least one of today's hot industries must bring little joy: the prison business. Can anyone truly applaud when a society, whether concerned with safety, politics or morality, feels it must lock up a huge proportion of its citizens? Any doubt that prisons are indeed booming were surely dispelled last week when the American Correctional Association put on what had to be the world's largest prison trade show. There were more than 600 booths and 5,000 conventioneers at the vast Nashville show, which featured everything from $40,000 temporary cells to $250 ballistic batons to razor wire that comes in so many varieties you'd think cereal companies were making it.

HEADLINE: Recession Proofed;
How Both Sides Joined the Supply Side

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
BOB DOLE and Bill Clinton are counting on finishing out the century without a recession. The word rarely, if ever, comes up in their election campaigns. Both candidates are pitching economic policies that assume that Americans, no matter how debt-laden or uncertain about the future, will go on buying all that this economy can produce.
The two political parties have arrived at an unusual, unstated consensus. They have both decided, in effect, that demand is simply not going to falter enough to drop the nation into recession. The issue, instead, for this election is not demand but supply -- producing more for the nation's ever-eager buyers. And Bill Clinton has joined Bob Dole as a supply sider, Democratic style. 
 "Our growth policies are supply side," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
"Supply side," popularized by Republicans, has come to mean cutting taxes. Lower taxes, the Republicans insist, will encourage wage earners to work harder and businesses to invest more in machinery and equipment. But "supply side" is actually a broader term meaning any policy intended to increase the capacity of the economy to produce more -- a goal that everyone wants but no supply-side policy has yet clearly achieved.
The Clinton Administration pushes supply-side outlays for education and training to make workers more productive. The centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's economic policy is deficit reduction, a supply-side attempt to shift money from government to private hands, where it would be invested more productively.

 
 
So Long, Keynes
 "What is peculiar is that both the Democrats and the Republicans are campaigning on the assumption that the problem of demand has been solved," said Paul David, a Stanford University economist, "and full employment" -- meaning plenty of demand -- "can be maintained."
Coming to such a conclusion means putting aside an array of "demand-side" policies stretching back to John Maynard Keynes and the Depression. Out of this period came the view that supply was not the problem. The economy too often produced more than people could buy. The issue was helping to increase demand, with the Government often stepping in as a public spender to give the economy a boost.
The demand-side approach has been dying for 20 years. In its place, supply-side policies, unproven yet, are nevertheless embraced by politicians with sunny optimism, as if they were advocating blue skies for July 4. Everyone is for productivity and expansion, in effect synonyms for supply side. On the other hand, talking about what to do to increase demand if a recession develops can be thorny, although pertinent. Getting through the next Presidential term without a recession would mean a record 10 years without one -- not impossible, but hardly a sure thing.
"It is pretty clear there won't be a recession before the election in November," said Robert M. Solow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "So if you were to force the question on either candidate, either can say, 'The history of capitalism suggests there will be a downturn and we will meet it when it comes.' "
Debating solutions in advance means reminding voters that things could get bad soon, a pessimism no Presidential candidate wants to indulge in. It also means debating whether the Federal Reserve is manipulating interest rates properly, keeping them low enough to encourage borrowing and spending. That debate makes the stock and bond markets nervous, at a moment when both parties, in deference to Wall Street, shy away from challenging the Fed.
Then there is the issue of whether to increase public spending, an inevitable theme in any discussion of how to avoid a recession. But public spending means more government, just when both parties are advocating less. In the 1992 campaign, in the aftermath of the last recession, Mr. Clinton called for $16 billion in public works spending. He wanted, among other things, to stimulate the economy by supplementing the spending of the still-reluctant private sector. But after he took office, the economy revived and the Administration dropped this demand-side proposal in favor of deficit reduction.

 
 
Expansion Forever
 No wonder, then, that Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who presides over the National Economic Council at the White House, said in an interview, "There is no reason to predict the end of this economic expansion." And John B. Taylor, a Stanford University economist and a chief economic adviser to Mr. Dole, said, "At this point, the economy is expanding and there is nothing in the Dole package that would come close to a recession."
Most economists are happy to see supply-side economics front and center. Over the last 15 years, they say, the economic system has learned to keep demand robust so that Americans are busy, most of the time, buying all the nation can produce. The Federal Reserve has become the main agent in regulating this process, and recessions are viewed as short, accidental events, the aftershock of a an oil crisis or a mistake by the Fed, which somehow fails to lower interest rates just when it should. "Right now, the view is that not only can we manage demand," said Richard Nelsen, a Columbia University economist, "but recession is an insignificant problem that the Fed can reverse."
There are dissenters, of course. The National Association of Manufacturers says supply is not the immediate problem; its members can produce more than Americans are buying. The Fed therefore should hold down interest rates to increase demand. Unions also dissent. They see in mass layoffs and persistent wage stagnation too big a supply of labor, so they, too, are demand-siders.
Even Mr. Solow, who shares the view that the economy today is responding to demand with all its capacity, nevertheless would not mind testing to see if there just might be room for more demand. But he was a member of John F. Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers in the early 1960's, when demand-side policies were all the rage. "If those days were these days," Mr. Solow said, "we would be exploring the gap and trying to understand if there was a gap left."
That sort of talk is not likely at the Democratic convention in Chicago this week. Nor is recession policy likely to surface, although some in the Administration are toying with the thought of accusing Mr. Dole of advocating irresponsible tax cuts that would bring on a recession. The scenario would go like this: tax cuts would not be matched by spending cuts, the deficit would rise, and so would interest rates, spending would slow, and a recession would arrive.
Ms. Tyson comes close to making the accusation, even using the "R" word. "If we change course," she said, meaning change course from Mr. Clinton's "even-keeled" policies, "if we move off a credible path to balancing the budget, to continued deficit reduction, that would cause interest rates to rise, slowing the economy and risking a recession."

HEADLINE: The Day of the WASP;
Is It Time for an Epitaph to the Ruling Elite?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
THE caricature is clearly etched in the public mind. The classic WASP is severely repressed, polite to a fault and so afraid of causing a scene that he can barely wave for a waiter. He is marginally articulate and blissfully unaware of things like shopping malls and "Oprah" and rap music. He probably has a silly nickname. He is keen on golf, sailing and tennis. He summers in Maine. In short, he is George Herbert Walker Bush, plus gin and tonics.
The term WASP was not invented by sociologist E. Digby Baltzell, but it might as well have been. 
 In works like "The Protestant Establishment," "Philadelphia Gentleman" and "Puritan Boston and Quaker Philadelphia," Mr. Baltzell, who died last week at the age of 80, established WASP as a brand name. With a sure hand, he traced the contours of America's aristocracy, the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant leadership class that held sway in the United States until well into the 20th century.
As an upper-crust Philadelphian, he knew his subject from the inside. He believed in the value of an enlightened ruling class, and he lived long enough to watch it evaporate.

 
 
Who's Who and Who's Rich
 Mr. Baltzell defined the WASP establishment as the list of names that apeared in both the Social Register (the privileged) and Who's Who (the doers).
It was, he argued, a class in crisis, content to relinquish its leadership role but hell-bent on retaining its social privileges, largely by exluding others. This state of affairs could not continue. Either the establishment could renew itself by admitting new members from outside its ranks, Mr. Baltzell argued, or it could wither and die, a victim of what he called the "the caste ideas of the country club set."
"I think Baltzell himself thought it was all over" by the time he wrote his first WASP book, in 1964, said Howard G. Schneiderman, a professor of sociology at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., and the editor of Mr. Baltzell's papers.
"He was writing an epitaph to the WASP, and that epitaph was 'Death by Ethnicity,' " said Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., the author of "Old Money: The Mythology of America's Upper Class."
As immigration changed the complexion of American life and began to transform its politics the ruling elite came to see itself as an ethnic group. "This attitude deepened over the years and encouraged a withdrawal from public life that proved to be its death as a class," Mr. Aldrich said.
Is the day of the WASP over?
In "Crashing the Gates: The De-WASPing of America's Power Elite," the late Robert C. Christopher catalogued the declining influence of WASP's in nine categories of American life, showing that they were no longer dominant in big business, education, journalism and other professions.
He could have added that institutions like the elite private schools of the Northeast, the Ivy League universities and social clubs no longer exist to perpetuate a WASP elite, as they once did. While the manners and the style remain, the infrastructure of power and influence has largely disappeared.
"We do have an elite," said Mr. Scheiderman, "but it doesn't form a consanguine class of interconnected families who intermarry and pass power along from generation to generation." Huddled in their country clubs, losing their hold on the levers of economic and political power, WASP's now find themselves objects of scorn, the last ethnic group that it is still permissible to mock.
"In America generally there's a feeling of contemptuous disdain toward WASP's," said Roxana Robinson, whose novels and short stories probe the inner recesses of the WASP character.

 
 
Inner Lives
 "I encounter resistance to the idea that people who belong to clubs, or have several houses and a duplex on Park Avenue, can actually suffer and have complex emotional lives."
It may be a little early to inscribe the epitaph for the WASP, however. Although the road to the State Department no longer runs through Andover and Yale, and the Brahmins of John P. Marquand's novels may no longer exercise financial power, the heyday of WASP influence, from just after the Civil War to the end of World War II, has left a deep impression on the national life and character.
"They left an imprint that will never be effaced, barring a major upheaval like conquest by a foreign power, revolution or civil war," said Richard Brookhiser, a contributing editor of the National Review and The New York Observer. "You can't just decide you're going to change the behavior patterns of a nation."

 
 
How American
 In "The Way of the WASP: How It Made America, and How It Can Save It, So to Speak," Mr. Broohkiser argues that the WASP code is, in fact, the American Way. It may have been battered and bruised in the 1960's, but in its broad outlines it remains the template for American success: conscience, hard work, civic-mindedness, a desire to succeed and a distrust of sensual pleasure and anything that isn't useful.
This is the way of the WASP, and Mr. Brookhiser strongly recommends it, despite the regimen of stingy, ill-cooked meals and the lack of amenities that outsiders find so shocking.
"In the country clubs, there's three limp towels in a corner, no showers and no attendants," said Ms. Robinson. "The floors are wood, with some cotton rag rugs. There is no sumptuousness or luxury there, and there isn't about WASP life generally."
When it comes to fashion and manners, the way of the WASP needs no defenders.
Ralph Lauren has built an empire on the quasi-English look that American WASP's made their own. And it doesn't take a Baltzell to see in the cinematic vogue for Jane Austen and Edith Wharton, soon to be followed by Henry James, whose "Portrait of a Lady" will light up the screen at Christmas, a swelling of nostalgia for manners and civility, not to mention a social hierarchy.
"The idea of a family that has been in the same town and the same house, that has vacationed in the same place, for five generations, that solid connection to a cultural past, is very appealing," said Ms. Robinson.
Of course, it's all a distant memory. Or is it?
If the WASP's were to rise up and seize power again, they would be the last ones to announce the fact. After all, it might create a fuss.

HEADLINE: The World;
Asia's Path to More Equality and More Money for All

BYLINE: By PETER PASSEL 

 BODY:
BOB DOLE says he wants to cut taxes, proposing a 15 percent across-the-board cut in income taxes. And he wants to give the rich a bigger cut: he has proposed halving the capital gains tax, from 28 percent to 14 percent. The rationale? Cutting taxes on investment income means that there will be more savings to invest, translating into more risk-taking enterprise, more innovation and, utlimately, more growth.
Most Americans remember this idea from the Reagan era, when it was dismissed as "trickle-down economics" by liberals -- who were, in turn, accused of fomenting class warfare. But few know that it was manifestation of a broader, long-running debate in economic circles: is the care and pampering of a wealthy, productive elite the key to economic development, or does it pay to spread wealth around more evenly? 
 For all of the evidence available from 50 years of postwar economic history, the United States and Europe are still perplexed by this question; market forces are exacerbating inequality in Western nations -- most notably the United States, which is growing more rapidly than Japan or Europe.
But now there is new evidence undermining -- no, burying -- the theory that growth and economic equality don't mix. The proof is in East Asia, in the economies that have seen startling growth in the last 15 years.
For much of this century, most Western economists studying the patterns of growth came down on the side of the rich. The thinking, best articulated by the British economist Nicholas Kaldor in the 1950's, was that in poor societies, only the rich can afford to save. And since capital is the elixir of growth, it was a matter of arithmetic that societies that allowed the concentration of wealth would see faster development.
Simon Kuznets, a Nobel Prize winner who taught at Harvard, elaborated on the process by which wealth would trickle down. He theorized that as nations switched from agriculture to industry, gaps in the distribution of income would widen until the rural poor were absorbed into the more productive industrial sector.
Latin America and the Caribbean once seemed to make the case for the concentration of wealth. Growth in those countries was brisk in the 1960's and 70's, before their economies stalled after the oil crisis and the subsequent third world debt crisis.
But little of their wealth trickled down. Indeed, Brazil, with its grinding rural poverty and violent slums, became the poster boy for development with Dickensian results. Statistics in the 1996 United Nations Human Development Report show that while the average income in Latin America's largest economy has quadrupled and the average living standard has probably reached the level enjoyed by Americans in the 1950's, people in the bottom fifth of the income scale still average just two years of schooling and still drink polluted water.
But in East Asia -- roughly, the arc from Japan to Thailand -- income growth in the 1980's and 1990's has been greater than that of Latin America two decades earlier, while income disparity has narrowed. When China is included, average incomes in East Asia are still just half that of Latin America. But nutrition and life expectancy are virtually identical. And strikingly, the most successful East Asian economies are also the most egalitarian. In South Korea, the richest fifth of the population averaged 5.7 times more income than the poorest fifth, as against 32 times more in Brazil, 30 times more in Guatemala and 18 times more in Chile. In the United States, the ratio is 14 to 1.

 
 
Blame the Conquistadors
 Why did East Asia and Latin America take such radically different paths? Some sociologists cite Latin America's conquistador tradition, in which descendants of European colonizers owned the land and the indigenous majority worked it. East Asia's natural wealth was far more modest than, say, Venezuela's. Hence Asia did not have the easy income from raw materials to shield the ruling class from having to produce goods for competitive world markets.
Many economists, including Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, see other differences between the Latin American and Asian economic models. "Begin with the fact that East Asia started out more equal," he noted; in Asia, almost everyone was poor after World War II, and postwar policies largely reinforced equality.
"Unlike Latin America, you had successful land reform," said Albert Fishlow, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. In Japan, reform was demanded by the American occupiers; in China it was imposed by revolutionaries. And in much of the rest of East Asia it was dictated by governments that brooked no opposition from former colonial powers.

 
 
Stuck at the Top
 There were other factors in the failure of Latin American wealth to trickle down. Education, for example. Latin America squandered resources on universities that served only the children of the elite.
East Asia, by contrast, invested heavily in mass education, which can either be viewed as social enlightenment or a matter of necessity. "When the only resource is people, you invest in people," said Gustav Ranis, an economist at Yale.
Then there's the colonial legacy. While the Japanese were hardly a benevolent bunch, their occupation left parts of East Asia with railroads, telephone systems and roads that made industrialization easier. What's more, notes Alice Amsden, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Taiwan and Korea inherited Japanese-created banking systems that were far more effective in allocating capital to productive enterprise than the banks in Latin America.
Asia's leveled playing field has produced a far larger middle class. And this group defies the assumption that savings comes easier in societies with highly concentrated wealth. East Asians save a high proportion of their income, while in Latin America growth has been constrained by very low savings rates.
Why did economists swallow the idea that social justice was the enemy of growth? Perhaps it was the not-so-subtle impact of the cold war, of a time when the West found it convenient to rationalize the excesses of anti-Communist regimes. But the obvious success of East Asia is forcing economists toward subtler interpretations of the relationship between income distribution and a strong economy. Perhaps economists are not the only people who can take lessons away from Asia's model.
