HEADLINE: The 'Nonworking Class'

 BODY:
Proponents of the draconian welfare reform just enacted in Washington say the bill will help the poor to exchange "welfare checks for paychecks." But this welfare reform will do nothing of the kind. It will terminate welfare benefits after five years -- throwing perhaps a million children into poverty -- while doing little to create jobs in distressed areas where work does not exist. Having revoked Federal support, the country has an obligation to find or help to create jobs.
"When Work Disappears," a new book by the Harvard sociologist William Julius Wilson, offers a sobering look at the obstacles ahead, as well as several proposals for government and private-sector action. Mr. Wilson focuses on the dismal job market in Chicago's Black Belt, but his observations apply to dozens of cities across the country. 
 Mr. Wilson argues persuasively that urban social pathologies are related not to declining values, but to the disappearance of jobs and the social coherence they provide. One community he studied had 800 businesses 50 years ago but only 100 today. The community grew poorer as the businesses fled to the suburbs, beyond the reach of inner-city residents.
Mr. Wilson writes that, "for the first time in the twentieth century, most adults in many inner-city ghetto neighborhoods are not working." Widespread joblessness has given rise to a "nonworking class," living in segregated neighborhoods where most residents can't find work or have given up looking. Single-parent families have become the norm, in part because "marriageable men" -- men who work -- have become scarce.
In the absence of work, people have lost the skills and concentration that work requires and employers write them off in advance. Mr. Wilson tells us that 40 percent of Chicago's businesses screen out the urban poor by not advertising entry-level jobs in the city newspapers. Most companies that do advertise choose ethnic and suburban newspapers that bypass black neighborhoods. In other words, the poor are sealed off from both jobs and information about them.
Deepening urban poverty worsens racial tensions and threatens the fiscal future of the cities. By way of solutions, Mr. Wilson suggests creating higher standards for inner-city schools, restoring aid to cities to 1980 levels, expanding the employment base through a system of public-private and city-suburban collaborations, and expanding the earned-income tax credit. His most far-reaching suggestion is to revive the Depression-era W.P.A., providing useful public employment to every American over 18 who wants it.
This would involve political and administrative difficulties that Mr. Wilson does not begin to address. It would also be expensive. He estimates it would cost $12 billion to create only a million jobs. The program would be aimed not just at the urban poor, he writes, but at a broad swath of the population, possibly attracting popular support. Those who would reject Mr. Wilson's solutions have an obligation to do better.

HEADLINE: Democrats Return to Chicago

 BODY:
As the Democrats open their convention in Chicago tomorrow, President Clinton is still the front-runner, but his once-easy cruise toward re-election has run into turbulence. One of the biggest challenges facing Mr. Clinton and his party now is to make their meeting -- all four days of it -- interesting. They also have to figure out ways to snuff the political spark that Bob Dole got at his convention in San Diego. Perhaps most important, Mr. Clinton must clarify his goals and define his principles for voters worried that he stands for little more than winning re-election.
Democrats have long predicted that Mr. Clinton's gravity-defying lead over Mr. Dole would drop. Nevertheless, the White House seemed surprised by the lift Mr. Dole got from selecting Jack Kemp as a running mate, emphasizing tax cuts and erecting a facade of moderation on social issues. In response, the President held a flurry of bill-signings last week to appeal to interest groups and plans to announce additional initiatives during the convention. Hillary Clinton will also get a bigger role in Chicago than originally planned. 
 Chicago was a nervy choice for a party with strong memories of the violence and discord at the 1968 convention, where the culture of dissent reached its high-water mark. An irony of history is that Mr. Clinton, a child of that earlier era, is now rushing to embrace resurgent traditional culture. He remains handicapped, however, by widespread doubts about which tradition he represents.
On specific issues, few would describe Mr. Clinton's record as consistent. He campaigned as a new kind of centrist Democrat but veered left upon taking office, raising taxes and embracing a gigantic government role in health care. Stunned by the Republican landslide in 1994, he has moved to the right on welfare, deficit reduction and social issues, from crime to schools.
There is talk of dissent among Democrats in Chicago over welfare, abortion and perhaps other causes. Mr. Clinton has promised not to copy the Republican script from San Diego and says he will let dissidents have a say. Like others, we lament that conventions have become places of happy talk and calculated image-making, but at least the Republicans aired their differences in a vigorous primary campaign. Surely the Democrats can admit their differences without projecting an air of chaos that convention planners always dread.
Republicans spent much of their convention re-introducing Mr. Dole to the public in sepia tones. But many voters have had enough of which candidate has the more inspiring life story and which most loves the values of family, work and neighborhood. It is time to discuss ideas and programs. Voters want to know what Mr. Clinton has in mind for the economy and the budget, as well as in the unmet agenda for welfare, health and education.
Having taken the expedient path in signing a welfare measure more likely to punish the poor than help them, Mr. Clinton needs to tell how he will insure that jobs are available for people who want to work, whether they are on welfare or not. He has talked of investing in education and training for the next generation. Where will he get the money? His pledge to balance the budget in seven years is vague about spending cuts down the road. How much more can the role of the Government be cut back?
As Democrats converge on Chicago, it is worth remembering that no American city has a richer history as a backdrop for the party's struggles. It was in Chicago that Adlai Stevenson elevated national discourse in 1952 by promising to "talk sense to the American people." It was where Franklin Roosevelt pledged "a new deal" in 1932 and where, a century ago, William Jennings Bryan invented the modern Democratic Party by wresting it from decades of devotion to big business.
Mr. Clinton has to make his own mark on history. He deserves great credit for his political skills and for presiding over strong economic growth and peace abroad. But voters remain anxious about the economy and other signs of decline in American life. They want a clear picture of where he will go in the future and what principles will guide him.

HEADLINE: Merlyn Stuart Pitzele, 85, Labor Union Specialist

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Merlyn Stuart Pitzele, a onetime student radical who grew up to advise the Republicans Thomas E. Dewey and Dwight D. Eisenhower on labor issues during their respective campaigns for the Presidency, died on Aug. 13 at home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 85.
The cause was complications from a fall, said his son, Peter. 
 Mr. Pitzele (pronounced PIT-zell-ee) worked -- at times concurrently -- as a labor organizer, economics teacher, management consultant, labor arbitrator, editor, author, adviser to future pensioners, drug fighter and group therapist.
A product of the Great Depression, he first turned to the union movement to teach at a union-run school in Chicago and help organize steel workers.
He moved to New York in 1940 to become a management consultant and the labor editor of Business Week, where he became senior editor in 1955.
His speeches at industry meetings caught the attention of Mr. Dewey, who made him principal labor adviser when he campaigned for President in 1944 and 1948. Mr. Pitzele played the same role in the Eisenhower campaigns of 1952 and 1956.
He was a member of the State Mediation Board from 1945 to 1957 and served as its chairman for seven of those years. The board is New York's labor peacemaker. Its members deal with critical situations while holding their regular jobs.
He was on the faculty of Columbia University Teachers College and lectured at Princeton, Harvard and other universities. He wrote articles and special reports on labor, economics and aging. In 1960 he founded Retirement Advisors Inc., which advised unions and businesses on life in retirement, and ran it until 1975.
He then held managing positions in Daytop Village, which operates drug-rehabilitation centers, and the Moreno Institute in Beacon, N.Y., where patients with emotional disorders act out difficult situations in their lives.
Born in Chicago, he graduated from the University of Chicago in 1933 and did post-graduate work there and at the University of Wisconsin.
In addition to his son, of Poughkeepsie, Mr. Pitzele is survived by two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: WELFARE CLIENTS OUTNUMBER JOBS THEY MIGHT FILL

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
It will be virtually impossible for New York City and State to move hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers from public assistance into full-time jobs over the next few years, as the new Federal law overhauling welfare intends, according to many economists and job-training experts.
There are nearly 470,000 adults on welfare in New York City, and many experts say that only a small number are likely to find permanent jobs. The reason is simple: the city's economy is growing much too slowly to absorb so many inexperienced, unskilled people in a short time. The sheer number of welfare recipients in New York City, when compared with the size of the local job market, makes the task of finding real jobs, primarily in the private sector, very daunting. 
 But there is a mismatch, as well, between most of the sectors of the city's economy that are growing -- business services, media, computer and data services, the securities industry -- and the unskilled welfare recipients who will soon be thrust into the job market.
Under provisions approved last month by Congress and signed into law on Thursday by President Clinton, most people on welfare will receive benefits for a maximum of five years. Once their time limits are up, most recipients will lose all benefits and be on their own. Up to 20 percent of those on public assistance -- the ones who are least employable -- will be allowed to remain on welfare beyond the limit. (Even while receiving benefits, most people on public assistance will have to enroll in workfare.)
Critics of the law have long argued that there are not nearly enough entry-level jobs in New York and other large cities with sluggish economies, high unemployment and large concentrations of poor people -- like Detroit, Chicago and Los Angeles -- to accommodate everyone on public assistance.
Even some proponents of overhauling welfare say that New York's economy cannot provide jobs for so many people so quickly.
Consider this: There are 3.3 million jobs in New York City, and since the city's recession ended late in 1992 there has been a net gain of 88,000 jobs. At that slow rate of growth, if every job gained by the local economy were given to a New Yorker now on welfare, it would take 21 years for all 470,000 adults to be absorbed into the economy.
"You've got a problem," said Robert Lerman, an economist at the Urban Institute, a Washington think tank.
William J. Grinker, a former commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, said that the local economy could not, on its own, provide employment to so many unskilled people.
"With a growing economy, I suppose eventually you'd be able to do it," he said. "But in the short term it logically leads you to understand that a massive job creation effort beyond anything the Government's done since the Great Depression would have to go on to provide work for all those people.
"It's not that it can't be done, but certainly not within the time frames of the law," said Mr. Grinker, who is now a consultant in health and social services, including job training for welfare recipients. "It's a big, big, big hit."
The relationship between people on welfare and the local economy is more complicated, and in many ways even more problematic, than can be understood by looking only at net job gains in the last four years.
The labor market is fluid, and at any time thousands of jobs are being created and thousands of others are disappearing. So there are many opportunities available to an individual on welfare, at least in theory. But most job openings are not appropriate for someone with no high school diploma, a spotty work history and limited skills. And even when entry-level jobs are available, thousands of people in addition to welfare recipients compete for them. Right now, there are 271,000 New York City residents who are unemployed and looking for work, but who are not on welfare. (New York City's unemployment rate, which is 8.5 percent, is 57 percent higher than the national average, 5.4 percent.)
New York also has a smaller portion of people employed, compared with its overall working-age population, than many other large cities. That means there are tens of thousands of New Yorkers who are not actively seeking work, but who might compete for future job openings.
To this grim mix must be added the fact that about 15 percent of the 3.3 million jobs in New York City are part time, according to Census Bureau surveys. And more than 20 percent of the jobs in the city have been held in recent years by people who live in the suburbs, according to Rosemary Scanlon, the Deputy State Comptroller for New York City.
Of the remaining jobs, many and probably most require more education and skill than the average welfare recipient possesses. The industries that have served traditionally as entry points for unskilled and low-skilled workers -- manufacturing, construction and government -- have declined or remained static in New York even while the economy has grown in the last four years. However, several sectors of the local economy that have grown, including retailing, restaurants and home health care, are believed to have provided new entry-level jobs.
Overall, though, even enthusiastic supporters of the central thrust of the welfare overhaul -- ending long-term dependency -- say that only a small fraction of New Yorkers on welfare are likely to find jobs in the private sector when their eligibility runs out after five years.
"There is no doubt that New York City and other cities don't have the jobs anymore," said Michael D. Tanner, director of health and welfare studies at the Cato Institute, a research organization in Washington that generally promotes free-market policies. "One of the things that welfare has masked is normal migration patterns."
Mr. Tanner, while endorsing the law's basic direction, said he was "a little bit concerned at the basic idea of moving large numbers of people who are currently on welfare out all at one time. There is a possibility of overburdening the system if you flood it all at once."
But Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, contends that the welfare overhaul, by cutting the cost of government, will lead to tax reductions and an expansion of New York's private sector. "If you limit the burdens on businesses," he said, "they will stay in New York and expand and hopefully will be able to absorb the larger work force."
"I believe that that, coupled with the increase in the minimum wage, which is very important for entry-level jobs, will make the market much better than some people fear," he said.
Mr. D'Amato also said he expected such a major change in social policy to take time to put into effect. "There will be some hardships and some dislocation," he said. "No doubt there will be some who fall through the cracks. We will watch out for problems, but we should not allow that to prevent us from moving forward."
Those opposed to the welfare changes envision nightmarish scenarios, with tens of thousands of poor single mothers and their children being thrown out on the streets if their benefits run out and they cannot find work.
"I think it is going to look like it did in the Depression in the city," said Liz Krueger, associate director of the Community Food Resource Center, a welfare advocacy group. "We'll have tent camps. I think we will have a boom in homelessness so extreme that nobody in modern times could have even imagined it. I think there will be an increase in crime in poor communities, because that will be the only option some people will have. I think we will see landlords running away from buildings in poor communities, because people will not have the incomes to pay rents that would enable landlords to keep their buildings up."
Some people wonder if the city and state will be forced to step in to prevent large numbers of welfare mothers and children from becoming destitute and homeless. Under the new law, 80 percent of those on welfare will have their benefits cut off after five years; the other 20 percent are assumed to be permanently unemployable because of disabilities and other serious problems.
The city and state, which now pay half the cost of welfare, with the Federal Government paying the other half, could decide in five years to take up the entire burden, to prevent welfare recipients who are unable to find work from becoming homeless.
But to do so, the city and state would have to raise taxes or cut other government services even more than they already have.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall predicted that after Election Day, as the full implications of the welfare overhaul become more clear, Washington may re-examine it. "When the heat of the political moment cools off, there are people who will look at this a little differently," Mr. McCall said. "Politically, it is very popular to talk about reducing welfare. But there hasn't been a lot of thought on policy, in terms of a comprehensive policy that makes sense."
Among other things, he said, if Congress and the President really want to move people into permanent jobs, they will have to take regional economic differences into account.
Nationally, there are 4.5 million adults on welfare and 126 million jobs. But the jobs and the welfare recipients are not distributed equally. In New York, there are 470,000 adults on welfare and 3.3 million jobs -- a ratio of welfare recipients to jobs four times the national average.
It is no accident that midwestern states like Wisconsin and Michigan have been in the forefront of prodding people from welfare to work. The economies of these states have been strong, with low unemployment and surging job growth, and they have had some success in reducing their welfare roles and finding permanent jobs for people.
"The Congress has looked at states which really are at full employment," said Mr. Lerman, the economist at the Urban Institute. "I think it's going to be quite difficult in New York City, unless there is a resurgence."
Some New Yorkers contend that significant numbers of welfare recipients can be assimilated into the city's economy only with major new public investments in education and job creation.
"In another era, our parents created the G.I. Bill and made available affordable housing and education," said Harvey Robins, a former aide to Mayors Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins who once served as acting commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration. "Why not a new millennium bill for New York City that creates jobs at living wages and with health care benefits to meet the needs of the city: transportation and education."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CITY;
Chicago Prepares and Promises No Repeat of 1968

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 24

 BODY:
As part of their training to keep the streets calm and the ghosts in the graveyard, 2,500 local police officers recently prepared for the Democratic National Convention here by sitting in the dark. In groups of 50, they watched a documentary of the bloody clashes between the police and antiwar demonstrators in 1968, the last time the Democrats had the courage to hold a convention in the Windy City.
"The average age on the department is 40," said Paul Jenkins, the Police Department's spokesman. "Most of our officers now don't know much about '68. They were little kids then. It's not something they really teach in Chicago schools, so we wanted to make sure they know what happened." 
 The brass also wanted to make sure that the rank and file saw what not to do. It has taken the city nearly 30 years to get the Democrats back to town after its downtown streets were turned into a battlefield, shrouded in a fog of tear gas and the sound of police billy clubs striking the heads of protesters. Chicago and the Democratic Party do not want to be that embarrassed ever again.
But the Democrats are returning to a much different Chicago, even though the city is once again being run by a man named Daley. The city is smaller, calmer, less white and more open to change. A new generation is operating the city more like a business than a back room. Hispanics head both the Fire and Police Departments, whose members are better trained and educated than ever before. The black middle class has exploded in size and influence. And the city has had a woman mayor and two black mayors.
Still, in some ways Chicago is much the same, as if time had been frozen in the city's wicked winters.
Local pols are still going to jail for corruption in a parade of civic shame. The Cubs have not won a pennant, many of the schools are factories of failure, and Chicago remains one of the most segregated big cities in the nation, with bulging pockets of poverty that breed fierce street gangs and busy undertakers.
The bridge connecting these two Chicagos is the name Daley. In 1968, Richard J. Daley -- the Boss -- played host to the Democrats in the old International Amphitheater near the stockyards. Today the stockyards are gone and the Boss's son, Richard M. Daley, is Mayor and will welcome his fellow Democrats at the shiny new United Center, the House that Jordan built, the arena where the Chicago Bulls and Michael Jordan play basketball.
"What we had in 1968 was municipal totalitarianism," said Leon Despres, a former member of the Chicago City Council and often the only voice of opposition to Richard J. Daley. "The local government we have today is not utopian and not a great reform movement, but there is much more freedom and fairness in government. The city is much more relaxed than it was 30 years ago."
The city is also smaller. At 2.8 million residents, Chicago has about 700,000 fewer people than it did in the late 60's, and there are now almost as many blacks as whites. Chicago has nearly 550,000 Hispanic residents, the fastest growing ethnic group in the city.
One of the biggest changes in Chicago came in 1983, when a multiracial coalition elected the city's first black Mayor, Harold Washington.
Under Mayor Washington, significant numbers of blacks, gays and women got high-ranking jobs and city contracts, making government more reflective of the population.
"I think Daley would admit he learned an awful lot from Harold Washington," said Paul Green, a professor of political science at Governors State University in University Park, Ill.
The history of '68 was not the only reason the Democrats stayed away from Chicago. During the 1980's, the city's raw racial politics turned Chicago into "Beirut by the Lake," when white aldermen opposed Mr. Washington at almost every turn.
The racial rhetoric by Mayor Daley and others has cooled considerably in recent years, but Chicago has a long way to go before it reaches any hilltops of understanding. Just the other night, a swastika was burned into the ceiling over the door of a Lutheran church and anti-black graffiti was scrawled on the door of an elementary school in a largely white section of the city's South Side.
"Racism is still very prevalent in Chicago," said Dick Simpson, a professor of political science at the University of Illinois and former member of the City Council. But less prevalent these days are blue-collar jobs. About 2,000 factories, big and small, have closed or left town in the last 30 years, taking with them about 300,000 manufacturing jobs. Those jobs have largely been replaced by jobs in the service and health industries and government. The Chicago of today has about the same number of jobs -- 1.3 million -- as it did when the Democrats last came to town.
"The economy has rebounded pretty well," Professor Simpson said. "The difficulty is it depends so much on the service economy. The average wage for service employees is $15,000 a year with no benefits."
But some people are making plenty of money. Almost overnight, middle-class and upper-middle-class neighborhoods have sprung up in areas where the poor struggled to survive, among abandoned buildings and vacant lots.
Indeed, much of the Chicago the delegates will see has never looked better. The lakefront has always been the stuff of postcards and lovers. But to welcome the Democrats, Mr. Daley ordered city work crews to spruce up the town by painting buildings, highway ramps and fences. Streets have been repaved and new street lamps installed, and Mr. Daley has had many trees and flowers planted.
At a news conference the other day, Mayor Daley asked any modern-day demonstrators to please be "nice citizens." In the old days, the Boss controlled the streets with an iron hand and an even stronger will. He did not do a lot of asking. His son is a man of the 90's, willing even to cry in public, as he did when his son got into trouble with the law several years ago.
"We have more civilized, more enlightened, more up-to-date people running the city today," said Eppie Lederer, better known as Ann Landers, the advice columnist who is one of Chicago's most beloved exports. "Police brutality was part of the way in the 1960's."
Most of the police officers involved in the '68 riots are now in their 50's and 60's, riding desk jobs or lawn chairs in retirement. And many of the demonstrators have children and mortgages, with a President of their generation coming here to be nominated for a second term to lead a country at peace with the world.
Still, thousands of demonstrators are expected to hit town again, some of them, the Mayor says, coming with images of '68 dancing in their heads. He said that his department would treat everyone professionally and that his officers had been thoroughly instructed on respecting First Amendment rights. But the name of the game is still control.
Demonstrators will have to sign up to protest at two designated spots. Each group will get one hour, and the city will supply the microphones.
Mr. Daley likes to remind people that by the time the Democrats and demonstrators rolled into town 28 years ago, much of the planet was reeling from a year of violence and sorrow. Every night on the news, the sons of Iowa, Illinois, New York and every other patch of the country were being loaded into body bags for the long trip home from Vietnam. Back home, the war was dividing the country and the Democratic Party. Then in April, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, and in June, Senator Robert F. Kennedy was gunned down in Los Angeles.
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson was living in Chicago in 1968, but he did not demonstrate at the convention. He will address the delegates at this one on Tuesday night. He said he did not expect much trouble outside because times have changed -- for the better and for the worse.
"The party is going to have to address the radical division of wealth in this country," he said in an interview. "The roof has been removed for the rich, and the floor has been removed for the poor. The gap between the haves and the have-nots is greater now than the gap between black and white."
If the delegates want to see examples, they do not have to travel far from the United Center.
On the West Side, they might see the massive addition to the Cook County Jail, one of the newest, busiest, biggest and nicest-looking buildings in the neighborhood.
On the South Side, they might see the Robert Taylor Homes, one of the largest public housing developments in the country, a bleak world of high-rise towers of poverty that no one has bothered to spruce up.
"Chicago is a tale of two cities," said Salim Muwakkil, a local writer and editor. "The downtown is vibrant and bustling and clean. In the ghetto, the underground economy is just about the only place to make any money."
The ghosts of '68 are clearly on the Mayor's mind. He told 89 new police officers at their graduation ceremony on Wednesday that even though more than half of them had not even been born the last time Chicago was the host of a Democratic convention, they and the rest of the department would be the focus of worldwide attention.
"Next week," he said, "once again the whole world will be watching Chicago."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2526 words

HEADLINE: THE DEBT TRAP -- A special report.;
Personal Bankruptcies Surging as Economy Hums

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
It was not long after Christine Olander moved to New Jersey from Chicago in 1987 that she got her first auto loan. Then came a department store card and then a Visa card. It was, as she sees it now, "a vicious circle."
In nine years, Ms. Olander, who is 34 years old, accumulated some 35 cards and $60,000 in debt. 
 Over the same period, she lost her job as a home-health-care aide and turned to working as a waitress for $2 an hour plus tips, hardly enough to make her minimum credit card payments, let alone to pay the rent. It took a card of a different sort to show her the way off this treadmill: A lawyer's business card, stacked up in a diner, with a toll-free number and the heading "Bankruptcy."
Christine Olander's experience is a flesh-and-blood profile of the forces that have produced an explosion of personal bankruptcies in the United States.
If the current torrid pace continues, about 1.1 million Americans will file to have their debts wiped away this year under Federal bankruptcy laws, up 25 percent from 1995 and far surpassing the record of 900,000 cases in 1992.
Unlike the previous surge in bankruptcy, which took place in the wake of a severe recession, the current epidemic coincides with the fifth year of an economic recovery. Unemployment and inflation are low, a record number of people are working and the stock market is bounding back to its record highs.
How to explain the anomaly? In part it is because many individual households, despite the robust economy, are still being shattered by job loss or an uninsured medical emergency that pushes them over the edge.
"People don't have a safety net," said Jeannie Seeliger, a lawyer in Jersey City who specializes in bankruptcy. "They have high credit-card balances at high interest rates and they don't save any money. When the layoff hits or there is a large medical bill or a divorce, they have no cushion."
At the same time, bankruptcy no longer carries the stigma it once did, making it far easier for those who have simply accumulated too much debt to repudiate their obligations with only modest adverse consequences. But most of all, the bankruptcy surge reflects the payback from the wave of unsolicited credit-card offers that banks and card companies have showered on many more Americans than ever before.
Indeed, though sudden tragedy still pushes a lot of people over the edge, even more are drifting almost casually into insolvency. Alan A. Aaron, a lawyer who has practiced in Midland, Tex., for 15 years, said that the vast majority of his new bankruptcy cases were "a husband and wife working where everything seems to be going the right way, except they have more money going out than coming in."
Not only will 1 in 100 households declare bankruptcy this year, their debt will be higher than ever before -- 5.3 times their annual income, compared with only 3.5 times in 1988, according to Visa International.
All these bankruptcies cost banks and other lenders an estimated $10 billion last year, a cost they passed on to their other customers in the form of higher interest rates. But far from being a painful drain on their profitability, the added expense is in fact a planned consequence of their efforts to win business in an increasingly crowded market by making higher-risk loans. The banks are allowing far higher credit limits than their customers' incomes would have warranted in the past. And they are giving new credit to people they previously would have shunned, including those in their first jobs, those with low incomes and even those who have just emerged from bankruptcy.
"Nowadays a credit granter can dip into a risky class of borrower," said Robert Johnson, a researcher with the Purdue University Center for the Study of Consumer Credit. "Even if 8 out of 100 will go bad, they can charge enough interest to make a profit."
Many industry experts wonder whether the banks are playing a big game of musical chairs, with more money lent out and circling from one card to another than can ever possibly be paid back. And they envision a mad scramble when the music stops.
"We don't want to have a severe economic downturn with so many people on the edge," said Fred C. Allvine, a marketing professor at Georgia Tech. "If unemployment rose by 50 or 100 percent, bankruptcies would soar and the banks' portfolios would be highly questionable." He fears consequences far beyond the banking sector. "Consumer credit has been the tail that has been wagging the dog in the economy," Mr. Allvine added, "so we have to ask whether we have been sucking the consumer so far into debt that a mild recession could become a major downturn,"
 
Pushed to the Edge
From Medical Bills To Downsizing
For many people, the descent into bankruptcy is less of a sickening plunge than a slow, almost imperceptible slide. Consider the case of Irene, an 84-year-old resident of Bogota, N.J., who, as did many people interviewed for this article, spoke on the condition that her last name not be printed. She first went into debt in 1989 when her husband was found to have Parkinson's disease. Her insurance would not cover the $300 a month in drugs he needed, but her Visa account would. Over six years, the couple ran up a debt of $19,000, using their combined Social Security checks to diligently make the required monthly minimum payments. When her husband died last February, Irene filed for bankruptcy protection.
"I don't like the idea," she said. "But I had reached a point where we weren't even able to make the minimum payments."
In fact, a new survey by Visa shows that more people are citing excessive spending as the chief cause of their bankruptcy, instead of job problems or family emergencies, as was the case only a few years ago. When asked the "main reason" for taking the action, 29 percent said they were "overextended," 17 percent cited medical problems, 15 percent blamed unemployment, 12 percent divorce and 6 percent collection tactics by bill collectors. The results contrasted sharply with a 1991 survey by the bankruptcy court system in which nearly half of the respondents blamed job problems, including unemployment and loss of income.
Other national trends feeding the bankruptcy courts, experts say, include increased payments due on variable-rate loans and mortgages, the spread of casino gambling into almost every corner of the country and the increase in the number of entrepreneurs who finance their start-ups with credit cards.
The range of people's breaking points can be seen in the windowless hearing room in a Newark skyscraper where two dozen people wait for their bankruptcy court hearing. On a recent August morning, some look as if they are dressed for church, though T-shirts and jeans predominate. Lawyers herd groups of half a dozen clients at a time, and the court accommodates them by holding their hearings in blocks.
"We have people who have lost jobs in banking, on Wall Street, you name it, every field I can think of, and it has a ripple effect," said Ms. Seeliger, the Jersey City lawyer, who this morning has five clients on the docket.
One by one, they are called to a rectangular table to be examined by the bankruptcy trustee, a private lawyer acting on behalf of the court. The stories of their monetary misfortunes spill out: A doctor hit by the plummeting value of his $300,000 home. A salesman who plunged into debt when his company took away his commissions. A man who could not pay his taxes after his divorce. A young woman with a half-dozen silver rings in her left ear whose long struggle with the disorder lupus bankrupted first her parents and now her.
"I used to see a lot of people who got burned by buying real estate in a declining market," said Jonathan Kohn, one of the trustees in Newark. "Downsizing is the current theme here. People who have been let go from good-paying jobs have to settle for jobs paying much less. They start using their credit cards to meet ordinary living expenses."
These cases fall under Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code, the most commonly invoked, which will wipe away most unsecured debts except for student loans and back taxes. If there are any assets -- and there usually are not -- they are distributed to the creditors. But personal effects, including a car and accumulated home equity up to certain limits, can be retained. (Individuals can also file for protection under Chapter 13, in which they can keep more of their assets but must make partial payments toward their debts in a three- to five-year plan.)
The trustee quickly examines each person's bankruptcy petition -- including a statement of his or her assets and liabilities -- and then fires off a routine series of questions: Have you recently transferred any assets to someone else? Have you omitted from the list something of value, coins or stamps perhaps? The interrogation lasts three or four minutes, and if nothing irregular is found and no creditors raise objections, the debtor is told he or she will receive a discharge of debts in the mail in a few months.

The Onus Is Gone
'Bad Credit No Problem'
Greasing the wheels of this process is a society that increasingly prods people to spend borrowed money and then makes it easy to have the debt forgiven.
For Ms. Olander, the New Jersey waitress with $60,000 in debt, credit cards provided a ticket to a fashionable wardrobe and fancy perfume that would otherwise have been out of reach. But she even used them to buy necessities like food for her dog and an air-conditioner for her mobile home in Long Valley.
"I was the queen of credit cards," Ms. Olander said. "It was like a sickness. I would see something I wanted and I would buy it. If a new gold card came in the mail, I would break it in by taking a vacation."
Bankruptcy lawyers around the country say that many of their clients tell similar stories.
"There is a lid on earnings, but meanwhile, people's cost of living and their desire for fancier life styles go unabated," said A. Stevens Quigley, a Seattle bankruptcy lawyer.
Once many of these people realize that they have borrowed more than they can repay, they display a surprising lack of shame about reneging on their financial obligations, bankruptcy lawyers and court officials say. After all, the newspapers are filled with prominent role models -- like Macy's and the actress Kim Basinger -- who blithely disavow their debts without feeling the sting of public disapproval.
"I remember worrying about whether to file for bankruptcy, thinking about how I was going to break it to my Dad," said Tom, a practical nurse in Cambridge Springs, Pa., who had racked up $100,000 in debt, half from a failed contracting business. "Then on TV I saw that Rockefeller Center was declaring bankruptcy, so I said, 'Hey, I've got good company.'
"I don't look at it as a cop-out," he added. "I'm just taking advantage of one of the opportunities the Government offers. It doesn't have the stigma it had."
Bankruptcy often looks like a good deal. Lawyers advertise fast and painless filings for fees that are often less than $1,000. In fact, many lenders argue, it is too painless. Visa calculates that 30 percent of the people who have all of their debts wiped away under Chapter 7 could in fact make partial payments under a Chapter 13 bankruptcy plan.
But the lenders themselves may be most responsible for bankruptcy's growing appeal by removing what used to be its biggest penalty -- the denial of future credit. Instead, they are falling over themselves to trumpet "bad credit no problem" loans. These come at a price, of course; someone who has just emerged from bankruptcy can pay interest in excess of 25 percent a year for a car loan. Such onerous terms increase the likelihood that the recipient will find himself back in the same financial hole out from which he just emerged.
Some experts say the industry ought to be rethinking its all-is-forgiven message. "If the credit industry wants repayments, it should put some teeth into the incentives for people to pay them back," said Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard Law School professor who has studied bankruptcy.
 
Quantity, Not Quality
Credit Grows; So Do Risks
After the catastrophic losses from bad real estate loans in the late 1980's, banks and other financial companies simultaneously concluded that lending to consumers would be the safest and the most lucrative use of their money. Then, with more players rushing into a more crowded market, the competition forced them to compromise on some longstanding watchwords of prudent banking.
The results can be seen in mailboxes stuffed with offers of "platinum" cards with credit lines of up to $100,000, or mere gold cards with 5.9 percent interest for loan balances transferred from other accounts. And on late-night television, movies are interrupted by commercials for instant home-equity loans.
The most recent statistics show that consumer credit is growing at a brisk 9 percent annual rate; it now totals nearly $1.2 trillion, of which $350 billion is on credit cards.
While banks are still earning record profits, there are increasing signs that the corners they have cut on credit quality are going to hurt them. Late payments and outright losses are up sharply this year.
"For the last two or three years, lenders have been more aggressive with the less creditworthy segments, and recently they have been surprised that their losses have been higher than they expected," said Alan Schiffres, a senior vice president of Portfolio Management Associates, a New York City consulting firm on credit quality.
Bankruptcy has proved to be particularly devilish for lenders these days because all the balance-transfer offers allow people in trouble to bounce debt from one card to another. So instead of seeing a customer slowly fall behind in payments, lenders now often get the first inkling that a credit-card holder is in financial straits by receiving a notice of a bankruptcy filing.
And banks have found that their high-technology computers are curiously impotent in helping them weed out likely candidates for insolvency. A model developed by Fair Isaac & Company, a consulting firm, finds that the characteristics of many people who are about to file for bankruptcy are also those of the most profitable customers: They take a lot of cash advances, borrow up to their credit limits and make only the minimum payments each month.
And so, while a few credit-card companies are cutting back credit limits on customers with a lot of outstanding debt, most are eagerly lending them more and more.
"What are you going to do, call up your customers and say, 'I think you are going to go bankrupt'?" asked Aviad Broshi, a credit-quality consultant and former Chase Manhattan executive.
Yes, that's exactly what some people think lenders should be doing.
"People are getting the wrong message," said Ms. Seelinger, the lawyer. "They are now getting letters saying, 'You are such a valuable customer that we are increasing your credit line.' If they got a warning instead, saying, 'You are borrowing too much,' there would be fewer bankruptcies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Personal bankruptcies are at a record level. Christine Olander, a waitress in New Jersey, filed for bankruptcy after accumulating $60,000 in debt for things like dog food and an air-conditioner for her home. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times) (pg. 38)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
The G.M.'s Ask: 'Hey, Who's the Kid on the Hill?'

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When Dallas Green expressed his candid assessment of the Mets' young pitchers last week, the overall theme of his comments was lost in the severity of his words about Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson. "These guys really don't belong in the big leagues," the outspoken manager said.
But in an honest, general look at the state of pitching, he also said: "The problem we have more and more is the speed-up type of baseball we've created. It's part of speed-up baseball. It's not the Mets' system. It's baseball's system." 
 Indeed, speed-up baseball is responsible for the influx into the major leagues in recent seasons of pitchers whose names are unfamiliar to fans when they arrive and, in many instances, still unfamiliar when they depart because they don't stay around long enough and certainly don't do enough while they're around to make themselves known.
Who could identify this potential starting rotation: Matt Ruebel, Elmer Dessens, Marc Wilkins, Chris Peters and Darrell May. And this one: Carlos Crawford, Mike Grace, Rafael Quirico, Rich Hunter and Lucas Beech.
The first group has started for the Pittsburgh Pirates this season, the second for the Philadelphia Phillies. Some remain with the teams; others made cameo appearances. All are rookies, like many other pitchers with unfamiliar names who have started in the majors this season. Rookie relief pitchers add to the confusion.
"They're new to me and I'm a general manager," the Rangers' Doug Melvin said of all the rookie pitchers. "I ask where does this guy come from. I'm not ashamed to say as a general manager it's hard to keep track of everyone. That's one reason I broke down our scouting into professional and amateur. I couldn't keep track of all the movement."
The number of rookie starters is certain to grow after Saturday because clubs can expand their rosters. Last season, 71 rookies started games before Sept. 1, and 16 more started after that. This season, 64 rookies have started. Texas, Cleveland and San Diego are the only teams that haven't used rookie starters. It is no coincidence that the Rangers, the Indians and the Padres are division leaders.
"Teams are always looking for pitching," said Jim Leyland, who manages one of those teams, the Pirates. "Guys are starting to take the attitude if a pitcher can throw strikes in the minors, give him a chance in the majors. It's necessary in our situation."
In the Pirates' case, four of the five rookies they have used as starters had not pitched above the Class AA level of the minor leagues before this season. The inexperience shows.
"The results are not so good," Leyland said. "I like some of the guys. But we have other guys so we say let's take a look at a couple others. We've kind of rotated to get a look at all of them to see what it looks like for our future. It's like Bill Virdon said: 'You try enough guys, something might stick.' That's what we've done. Not that we've been overly impressed or depressed. We're just giving guys a chance so we can see how they do."
Leyland readily acknowledged, though, that at least some of the rookie pitchers would fare better with better teams. "I think a lot of people," he said, "think a lot of our young pitching on a real good ball club, a team that scores runs and takes off the pressure, could be pretty good. We haven't given them that kind of support."
Nothing is guaranteed. The Atlanta Braves have used Jason Schmidt as their fifth starter -- he's now in the disabled list -- and he has a 3-4 record with a 6.75 earned run average. Baltimore tried Jimmy Haynes as their fifth, and he pitched himself back to the minors (3-6, 7.29 e.r.a.).
 The Yankees have tried three rookies as starters, and unlike two of their three rookie starters last season, Ramiro Mendoza, Mark Hutton and Brian Boehringer did not succeed. Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera started as rookies last season and have become the stars of this year's staff, Pettitte as the American League's No. 1 starting pitcher and Rivera as the league's best relief pitcher who isn't a closer.
The most successful rookie starters have been James Baldwin of the Chicago White Sox (9-3, 4.14), Donne Wall of Houston (7-4, 4.28), Alan Benes of St. Louis (11-7, 5.01), Ugueth Urbina of Montreal (7-5, 4.14), Rocky Coppinger of Baltimore (7-5, 5.25), Jose Rosado of Kansas City (4-3, 2.51) and Grace of Philadelphia (7-2, 3.49), who has been on the disabled list with a sore right shoulder for nearly three months.
Generally, the widespread use of rookies has become a nerve-racking part of a manager's job. "No question about that," Leyland said. "That's going to be tough not just on Jim Leyland but on any manager. In our situation you have to keep on trying people. It's fine to be pitching guys making $109,000, but it's going to be hard to win."
 
 
 
Are They Using a Super Ball
 In 1987, the major leagues' record year for homers, four players hit at least 40 homers, 24 others whacked 30 or more and 51 others hit 20 or more. Last week, Albert Belle of Cleveland and Sammy Sosa of the Cubs joined Mark McGwire of Oakland on the 40 plateau, five more players reached 30 for a total of 22, and 10 hit their 20th, raising that group's total to 44.
Reaching 30 last week were Terry Steinbach of Oakland, Ed Sprague of Toronto, Ryan Klesko of Atlanta, Dean Palmer of Texas and Alex Rodriguez of Seattle. Getting to 20 were Paul Sorrento of Seattle, Kevin Elster of Texas, Scott Brosius of Oakland, B. J. Surhoff of Baltimore, Jose Valentin of Milwaukee, Melvin Nieves of Detroit, Carlos Delgado of Toronto, Ray Lankford of St. Louis, Todd Zeile of Philadelphia and Bobby Higginson of Detroit.
In all, 69 players have hit 20 or more, compared with 79 in 1987. Of this season's 69, 34 have reached career highs, compared with 48 in 1987.
 
 
 
Nieves Fills a Void
 Cecil Fielder left a huge void in Detroit when the Tigers traded him to the Yankees, but Melvin Nieves, a 24-year-old outfielder, has shown signs of picking up the slack. Coming off the disabled list last Monday, Nieves got only a single in his first game but then slugged 4 home runs (for a season total of 21) and drove in 9 runs as he collected 5 hits in 12 at-bats in the next three games, all Detroit victories.
"The guy has a lot of potential," Fielder said. "He has probably the most power I've seen in a long time. He just has to put it together. Sometimes you don't mean to get hurt, but it happens. But he's got to be accountable every day. He has to find a way to keep himself healthy and be out there for the ball club."
Fielder alluded to Nieves's two visits to the disabled list this season. The Tigers are the third team Nieves has played for in his brief career. He spent five seasons in the Atlanta minor league system before joining the Braves for 10 games in 1992. He was traded to San Diego in 1993 and made brief visits to the Padres that season and the next before playing for them on a part-time basis all of last season.
 
 
 
Rookies Around the Horn
 The San Francisco Giants began the season with an infield of Mark Carreon at first, Robby Thompson at second, Shawon Dunston at short and Matt Williams at third. Carreon has since been traded to Cleveland, and the other three are on the disabled list. The Giants now have an infield basically of Desi Wilson at first, Jay Canizaro at second, Rich Aurilia at short and Bill Mueller (pronounced Miller) at third.
Rookies all, they entered the season with a total of 27 days of major league experience, all Aurilia's. Their four predecessors had combined for 34 years and 72 days in the majors.
 
 
 
Welcome to Talk Baseball
 The owners said Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, couldn't make a deal. Fehr has been waiting for two weeks to close a deal. They said the union was stalling. Union officials have sat virtually idle for two weeks waiting for the owners to hang up their phones.
The owners wanted a system that would retard salaries. The union has given them a luxury tax as well as other economic givebacks. The owners have never voluntarily given the players a system economically beneficial to them. When the owners agreed to the 1976 deal that created free agency, they did not act out of compassion for the underpaid players. They acted with arbitration and judicial rulings staring them in the wallet and granting players a wider form of free agency than they ultimately accepted.
In other words, it's time to make the deal that will assure skeptical fans it is safe to return to the ball parks and that will give prospective business partners the impetus to sign up. "We have some marketing deals just sitting there," a person on the owners' side said. "People want to make sure we won't have any stoppages."
Considering the strife-torn history of these negotiations, Randy Levine, the owners' chief labor executive, has done an award-winning job in getting to the brink of an agreement. If the owners let him, he could go the rest of the way and complete the talks with Fehr in a matter of hours. Just think of the possibility -- an agreement this week.

HEADLINE: Haiti's 'Little Kings' Again Terrorize Its People

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 23

 BODY:
During three decades of dictatorship, they were called "little kings" and used to intimidate and brutalize civilians. Now, nearly two years after the democratically elected Haitian Government disbanded the country's armed forces, these former soldiers are again being cited as a threat to security and political stability here.
Discharged troops have been blamed for an assault on police headquarters here earlier this week, in what the police say was revenge for the arrest of 20 other former soldiers last weekend. Haitian officials, from President Rene Preval on down, have also pointed to the involvement of former members of the armed forces in recent assassination plots, robberies, kidnappings and other crimes. 
 "The military are instruments of political destabilization," Mr. Preval said in an interview at the National Palace here today. "But behind them you will find the politicians who are pulling the strings, and the people who are really committing these actions, the economic sector."
About 6,500 Haitian soldiers and officers were demobilized after American troops landed here in September 1994 and restored Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power, three years after he had been overthrown in a military coup. Today, diplomats described the 5,000 cashiered enlisted men as a resentful, volatile mass with a long list of grievances, angry at the Haitian and American Governments, the officers who once led them and fellow citizens who despise and reject them.
"This is a problem that has become more urgent because of recent events," a Latin American diplomat here said. "These soldiers have never really been under duress or faced a challenge before. But now they have lost their status in the community and can be easily manipulated by anyone who offers money or leadership."
Concern about the danger posed by discharged soldiers has been continual since Mr. Aristide's return, but has grown considerably during the last month. In mid-July, Lieut. Gen. Claude Raymond, who was army chief of staff during the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, which ended in 1986, and still enjoys some prestige among the ranks, was arrested and charged with committing "terrorist acts in the framework of a process to destabilize public authority and order."
The same day General Raymond and three associates were jailed, Andre-Pierre Armand, leader of the Association of Unjustly Discharged Soldiers, which lobbies on behalf of the demobilized soldiers, denounced what he called "a plot to destabilize the Government" that entailed assassinating Mr. Aristide and Mr. Preval. Three days later, Mr. Armand was shot in the head and killed at his home.
"The plot is already completely organized," Mr. Armand told radio reporters here just before his death. "It only remains to be put into action."
One major source of discontent is financial. While many officers have either gone into exile or landed jobs with business groups still sympathetic to the old military Government, ordinary enlisted men have been largely frustrated in their efforts to recover the pensions, severance pay and military-bank savings accounts they say are due them.
"We're not asking for anything that is not ours," said Wilto Eliance, an eight-year veteran who said 20 percent of his $85-a-month salary had been withheld from him and deposited in such accounts. "With the money that is owed us, we can start our own businesses and feed our families."
The pension and savings funds were looted when Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and other members of the military high command fled the country in October 1994. Records, too, were destroyed, and the Ministry of Defense, which was in charge of those accounts, no longer exists.
Still other discharged soldiers, demanding that their military salaries continue to be paid, have demonstrated outside Government offices and the American Embassy. They argue that the formal dissolution of the armed forces in accordance with the Constitution is not yet complete and that they are therefore not cashiered but on a sort of extended leave.
"No decision has been taken, but there have been discussions with the Government of Haiti as to what further can be done to address the grievances" about pensions and savings "and set that right," William L. Swing, the American Ambassador here, said in an interview. But, he said, the United States supports Mr. Preval's position that the armed forces have been legally abolished.
Many of the former soldiers also served as members of the interim police forces set up after Mr. Aristide's return, and have been enraged to see former colleagues incorporated into the permanent force, known as the Haitian National Police, or even the palace guard. "They are no better than us," complained a veteran who is now studying computers.
Thus far, the Haitian Government appears to have done little to address the discontent, other than to criticize the soldiers and warn them of severe punishment if they take actions against the state. The only effort to "recycle" the cashiered soldiers into normal life and productive activities is a job-training course run by the International Organization for Migration, an independent group based in Geneva, with money from the United States and other international donors.
More than 4,500 former soldiers have enrolled in that six-month program, studying to become mechanics, plumbers, carpenters, welders or even computer operators while they earn "training stipends" close to their military salaries. But only 8 percent have been able to find jobs in their new trades after graduation, according to Marco Bourasso, the program's director.
"If we go to the owner of a business, he'll always think badly of us," said a 24-year-old former sergeant who has been looking for work as an electrician. "As soon as you say that you are former military, they tell you they wouldn't give you a job even if they had one."
There have been suggestions that the Government should create jobs in order to defuse the frustration of the discharged soldiers. But with the economy still staggering nearly two years after democracy was restored and unemployment running more than 50 percent, that would be an unpopular and politically costly measure.
"Why should Preval do anything to help those bullies and thieves?" asked Smith Philogene, an unemployed handyman who lives in a slum area known as La Saline. "If there are Government jobs to be handed out, they ought to go to decent folks who are truly part of the people and suffered at the hands of those beasts."
President Preval is very much aware of that sentiment and sympathizes with it. "If the people who were victimized for three years are patient enough to wait for justice, then the perpetrators, too, should be patient and wait for us to find a solution," he said.

HEADLINE: Silence Seen As Weapon For Terrorists

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI and RAYMOND BONNER 

 BODY:
Seven hours after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off the coast of Long Island, a television station in Tampa, Fla., received a phone call from a man who said he represented a "jihad" group. He claimed responsibility for the downing of the Boeing 747 and said more attacks were imminent.
Shortly afterward, Cable News Network received a fax in Arabic from an organization claiming responsibility for the attack. The group, which identified itself as the Movement for Islamic Change, the jihad wing, said the attack was part of an effort "to destroy the whore Israel and her mistress, the United States." 
 Over the next few days, these claims and a similar letter to an Arabic-language newspaper in London were evaluated by investigators and discounted. Since then, no group, notorious or unknown, has stepped forward to take responsibility for an explosion that investigators strongly suspect resulted from a bomb or missile attack.
But the lack of a credible claim of responsibility does not rule out the possibility that the plane was brought down by a terrorist, independent experts and officials investigating the T.W.A. crash say, because these days terrorist groups are just as likely to set off bombs and say nothing.
Bruce Hoffman, director of the Center for the Study of Terrorism and Political Violence at St. Andrews University in Scotland, called today's terrorist groups "more nihilistic" than their ideologically motivated predecessors of the 1970's and 80's.
Mr. Hoffman said a growing number of these groups have religious agendas. Their goals of inflicting punishment and undermining governmental authority -- particularly that of the United States and Israel -- can be accomplished and even enhanced by anonymity.
"If God tells you to do it, God knows you did it," said Brian Jenkins, a terrorism expert for Kroll Associates, a security firm in New York City. "So you don't have to issue a communique to let God know."
When Pan American World Airways Flight 103 was blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, the terrorist group that organized the attack never came forward, although United States intelligence officials eventually concluded that Iran's militant Islamic Government had set the plot in motion to avenge the accidental downing of an Iranian airbus six months earlier.
Aum Shinrikyo, a Japanese religious sect that was seeking to usher in the millennium by killing thousands with nerve gas last year, never claimed responsibility for the attacks, in which 11 people died. Nonetheless, the police discovered that the group was responsible.
The 1985 bombing of an Air-India jet over the Irish Sea was eventually attributed to a Sikh separatist group, even though none ever admitted to carrying out the attack.
The investigators in the T.W.A. crash face a different problem: conflicting claims from previously unknown and perhaps nonexistent groups.
All three claims -- in the letter to the London-based newspaper, the phone call to the Tampa TV station and the fax to CNN -- were discounted, investigators said, because of their timing and because they lacked telltale details that would have convinced the authorities of the purported culprits' inside knowledge about Flight 800's destruction.
"All of the claims we've had came after the crash, which naturally makes us suspicious," said a senior law enforcement official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "And none of them contained any of the kind of specifics that would indicate a real working knowledge about how or why this plane blew up. So you work from the assumption that it's just a group seeking publicity."
Law enforcement officials say a credible claim of responsibility would be a significant break, giving focus to an inquiry that for the moment encompasses every plausible motive, from plots against passengers to international terrorism.
Although investigators have found traces of explosive residue on wreckage from the cabin of Flight 800, they have not formally ruled out the possibility that mechanical failure caused the explosion on July 17, in which 230 died. "Maybe the fact that they didn't send a letter taking credit is because they're trying to say, 'We didn't do it,' " a law enforcement official said this week.
Other investigators have hoped in recent weeks that the long delay in gathering enough forensic evidence to declare the attack a bombing might have the side effect of flushing out the saboteurs. Week after week of public speculation about possible mechanical failure, investigators said, might eventually goad a terrorist into seeking public recognition for his prowess.
So far, that hope has been unmet.
"They have caught on that if they don't claim responsibility that makes it much harder for us," said Morris Busby, former coordinator of counterterrorism for the State Department. "If you claim responsibility for something we're going to come after you."
It was not always so.
Twenty years ago, an act of terrorism was almost always followed by a claim of responsibility from some radical group, which would issue a communique stating its aims and demands. Most terrorist acts of the 1970's and 80's were committed by secular organizations seeking to advance their goals; it did them no good if no one knew they had done it. For this reason, groups like the Irish Republican Army and Basque separatists still claim responsibility for terrorist attacks.
In some cases, especially during an organization's infancy, a terrorist act would bring the group to public attention and force a government to deal with it.
But recently, public outrage has increased the risks for terrorist groups claiming responsibility, making governments far more likely to retaliate with military strikes or economic sanctions against nations that sponsor attacks.
American prosecutors have been given new powers to hunt individual terrorism suspects around the world and have captured, tried and convicted several in recent years.
The World Trade Center attack in 1993 was followed by a letter to The New York Times and other messages from the bombers that read, "We can get you anytime." F.B.I. officials tracked suspects around the world.
Although the messages did not provide a break in the Trade Center case, the eventual arrest of suspects in Egypt and Pakistan sent a strong message to potential terrorists that they could not escape American justice, according to experts.
Self-preservation is not the only reason that suspects have kept a lower profile. Because many of today's terrorist groups are more religiously motivated than their predecessors, they have fewer reasons to seek notoriety.
"They are less interested in finding a place in the system than in tearing it down," said Mr. Hoffman of St. Andrews University. In 1968, he added, no known terrorist group had religious aims. Fifteen years ago, only two did. Today, he said, about a quarter of the 50 known terrorist organizations have religious roots.
The bombings that paralyzed Paris last summer and the nerve-gas attacks in Tokyo last year are typical of the modern breed of terrorism.
For three months in Paris, bombs went off in subways, in open-air markets, in front of schools, without anyone claiming responsibility for them. Finally, a radical Algerian Islamic organization issued a statement, because it wanted to make political demands of the French Government.
One of the primary motivations of religious terrorists is to embarrass governments, making them appear impotent to their citizens and to the world. Experts say this is accomplished by the act itself, regardless of who did it. The sense of incompetence deepens when the government cannot identify the perpetrator.
By remaining anonymous, the enemy is unseen, unknown, a mystery. If people don't know who their assailant is, how can they protect themselves? "It feeds the fear and paranoia," Mr. Hoffman said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RECORD;
A True Believer Who Has Won the Day

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
A onetime aide to a moderate Republican in the House of Representatives remembers when he first understood the essence of Representative Jack Kemp. It was the mid-1980's, and Mr. Kemp had once again drifted from the agenda of a meeting with his party's House leaders to lecture them on economic proposals.
The aide had heard it all before; Republican moderates generally regarded the proposals as silly and even dangerous. But as he sat there, he said this week, "it gradually dawned on me for the first time that he really believed this stuff." 
 It was the secret of Mr. Kemp's success in the House, where he served from 1971 to 1988, representing suburban Buffalo, but speaking mostly, and often, to the nation.
For him, everything was subsumed by some larger, evangelical, cause. The duties of representing a stumbling Rust Belt district were feedstock for broader theories on urban revival, free trade, education reform, labor relations, economic policy and even Central America.
Buffalo never seemed to mind; Mr. Kemp was almost always re-elected by landslides. He put an optimistic, populist face on ideas that were at their root deeply conservative. And his monologues, which so often struck his House colleagues as outlandish two decades ago, have to a surprising extent become Republican dogma. While he was not averse to getting Federal appropriations for his district, he was not so concerned with such practical matters.
"He took his share of grants like any Congressman, but it just wasn't his focus," Mary Cannon, an adviser to Mr. Kemp both in the House and later, when he was the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said in an interview. "He was really kind of the leader of the conservative opportunity wing of the party."
In his first decade or so in Congress, the House component of that wing comprised perhaps five Republicans: Mr. Kemp and Trent Lott of Mississippi, Connie Mack of Florida, Vin Weber of Minnesota and Newt Gingrich of Georgia. Mr. Weber now runs Empower America, a conservative policy group that Mr. Kemp helped direct before accepting the Vice-Presidential nomination; the other four have largely come to dominate elective Republican politics.
Mr. Kemp was perhaps the most hyperkinetic and least disciplined of them, qualities that seemed, until this month, to have made him a prophet without honor in his party.
The story of his swift rise in the House is familiar. A fading quarterback for the Buffalo Bills, Mr. Kemp was recruited by the city's Republicans for political office and squeezed into the House in a close 1970 race against a divided Democratic Party.
He was converted in the mid-1970's to supply-side economics and drafted legislation in 1978 with Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware that would have slashed Federal income taxes by 30 percent over three years.
Washington snickered. Then, in 1980, Mr. Kemp convinced the Republican Presidential nominee, Ronald Reagan, that the theory was sound, and two years later, a revised Kemp-Roth bill was the nation's law.
The two simple notions behind Kemp-Roth -- that the Government should create wealth instead of redistributing it and that lower taxes are the engine of growth -- have driven the Republican Party ever since. Mr. Kemp, however, proved to be more complex than that.
He favored a larger Federal role than did most of his conservative allies and fellow House Republicans in addressing social and economic problems, something he once attributed to his front-row seat at the collapse of industrial employment in Buffalo's Rust Belt years.
"That was a real blessing for me," he told The New York Times in 1985. "That disabused me very early about ideology winning campaigns. Those guys wanted answers; they wanted problems solved."
And unlike most Republicans in the House, he had few concerns about spending more Federal dollars for solutions, even at the expense of higher deficits. Supply-side theory said the economic spurt from lower taxes would generate enough new money to cover new expenses.
So Mr. Kemp began to march to his own Republican drummer on the House floor -- maddeningly persistent in defending his economic ideology and maddeningly heretical, in Republican eyes, in support of certain social spending.
Elected chairman in 1981 of the House Republican Conference -- a political student-council president, in effect -- he promptly rebelled in public against his elders when the White House agreed to reduce the Kemp-Roth tax cut to 25 percent, from 30 percent.
Then he rebelled again in 1982 when Bob Dole, then the Senate majority leader, and the Reagan Administration agreed to roll back some of the deepest cuts in business taxes. At the same time, he began to lobby, sometimes with Democrats, on behalf of programs that his colleagues either opposed or had no interest in.
Mr. Kemp led a fight early in President Reagan's first term to reverse cuts in Federal aid to magnet schools, then an experiment in promoting voluntary desegregation by creating schools with attractive programs in minority neighborhoods.
He joined Representative Robert Garcia, a Bronx Democrat, in promoting a plan to attract industry to poor neighborhoods by converting them to low-tax "enterprise zones." (Congress passed a version of the plan in 1993, about five years after Mr. Kemp left the House.)
He worked with black Democrats in the House on legislation to enable the poor to buy Federally renovated public-housing units. He chastised Republicans for their hard-line opposition to labor unions, and he spoke to union conventions.
In the mid-1980's, he urged Republicans to collaborate with Democrats on a bill to simplify the income-tax code, closing loopholes and lowering rates, an idea the White House later adopted. When talks collapsed in late 1985 and House Republicans killed the main tax-overhaul bill, Mr. Kemp made an end run. Meeting at the White House, he persuaded Mr. Reagan to support publicly a compromise that many Republicans in the House did not support.
"A lot of staff, myself included, thought he was crazy," John Mueller, then an economic adviser to Mr. Kemp , said in an interview. "It got him a lot of flak at the time."
Mr. Kemp took the House floor and allowed that he had broken ranks with his fellow legislators, but he argued that Mr. Reagan's pledge had changed things. The tactic worked. The House reversed itself, passing the same bill it had rejected, and the talks lurched forward.
By the summer of 1986, Mr. Kemp had played leading roles in two efforts that had cut the top income-tax rate, which had once been 70 percent, by half. It was all the more notable because Mr. Kemp did not sit on any tax-writing committee, but on an appropriations subcommittee and the relatively powerless Budget Committee.
Mr. Kemp's persistence in such causes could be his undoing. He lectured party leaders on his issues so often and so long that even supporters hooted him down, one top staff member at the time recalled.
He once caused a stir by writing under the banner of the House Republican Conference that the Federal deficit would vanish if Congress only cut taxes, returned to the gold standard and allowed the resulting boom to lift the economy out of its red ink. It was a position at odds with his party's and his President's demands for spending restraints.
Yet in many other ways, Mr. Kemp is the most orthodox of Reagan conservatives. He strongly opposes abortion in almost every form and strongly backs Israel.
He ardently backed Mr. Reagan's support of the rebellion against Nicaragua's Government, and the President appointed him in 1984 to a panel charged with finding a bipartisan policy on Central America. Typically, Mr. Kemp lined up behind a plan to pump aid into the region, reasoning that any military victory would be fleeting unless the economy offered people a decent living.
He used his post on the foreign operations subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee to promote what was, in the mid-1980's, still a novel idea: free-trade compacts between the United States and its Latin American neighbors to discourage trade wars and promote stability.
But his positions on contentious issues like school prayer, the equal-rights amendment for women, consumer protection, the environment and busing, for example, were deeply conservative and unadvertised.
For years, groups like the League of Conservation Voters, the Consumer Federation of America and the liberal Americans for Democratic Action viewed Mr. Kemp's voting record with dismay. But the American Conservative Union often awarded his votes a perfect 100.
It is a score today's post-revolutionary House Republicans might envy, and one of the reasons he is their national candidate today.
