HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
Kemp, Going Solo, Hawks Fiscal Remedies

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: VASHON ISLAND, Wash., Aug. 24

 BODY:
In his first solo campaign appearances since becoming Bob Dole's running mate, Jack Kemp struck out for the West today, visiting an isolated prairie town in South Dakota and later addressing several thousand Republicans at a party barbecue on this island suburb of Seattle.
In both places, Mr. Kemp sounded familiar themes of economic growth and interracial healing, and digressed noticeably from the script that he and Mr. Dole had refined since the Republican National Convention only on tax cuts, making loftier promises than Mr. Dole had. 
 In Watertown, S.D., this departure was a mistake: Mr. Kemp misspoke and called Mr. Dole's proposed 15 percent tax cut a 50 percent reduction, eliciting laughter and applause from the 1,200 people gathered on the town's green.
Mr. Kemp told several thousand Republican leaders and party stalwarts from the state of Washington that the tax cuts he and Mr. Dole had outlined so far were "just the start."
And although Mr. Dole has said balancing the budget is a priority he places above even tax cuts, Mr. Kemp said today that the cuts would be accomplished at the very beginning of a Dole-Kemp administration.
"Let me let you in on some really good news," Mr. Kemp said. "The tax cut and the tax relief and the cutting of capital gains rates by 15 percent and the estate tax relief -- that's just the start. We're going to do that in the first hundred days."
As the crowd roared, Mr. Kemp added, "Well, "maybe a couple hundred days." Aides to Mr. Kemp said later that he was just kidding.
He has long believed in tax cuts as the first course of treatment to invigorate the economy, while Mr. Dole has described deficit reduction and a balanced budget as equally important measures.
Even so, Mr. Kemp's comments today were too vague to be considered a clear contradiction of Mr. Dole's policies. And his first day alone on the stump since the convention was characterized for the most part by strongly adhering to the speeches and policies laid out in the campaign so far.
Both of Mr. Kemp's appearances today included personal touches that framed him as a family man. In Watertown, a town founded by his great-grandfather, Mr. Kemp strolled down Kemp Avenue.
Here on Vashon Island, he was introduced by his eldest son, Jeff, a former quarterback for the Seattle Seahawks who still lives in the area. Jeff's wife, Stacy, and his children, Kyle, Kory, Kolby and Keegan, were also on the stage with Mr. Kemp and his wife, Joanne.
Taking the microphone, Mr. Kemp said: "I just want to stand up in front of all of you and say that of all the titles that I have ever achieved -- the greatest title that I have ever achieved, the greatest name that I could ever be called -- is Dad. And now, of course, Grandfather."
In both campaign stops, even though the first was rural, the second suburban and the audiences in both places were almost entirely white, Mr. Kemp nonetheless spoke passionately and in some detail about the need for the Republican Party to reach out to minorities.
His comments affirmed his role in the Dole-Kemp ticket as the candidate sounding the loudest clarion call for inclusion and chiseling a new image for the Republican Party. Already in this campaign, that role has not been easy.
On Friday, when Mr. Kemp appeared before the National Association of Black Journalists in Nashville, one journalist accused him of turning his back on affirmative action. Before being chosen as Mr. Dole's running mate, Mr. Kemp supported affirmative action. Since then, Mr. Kemp has toned down or sidestepped that position.
His voice grew audibly squeaky and his face reddened slightly as he addressed that apparent change of course in Nashville, and the words with which he began his answer seemed revealing.
"I stand here today as a candidate for Vice President of the United States with my friend, the real quarterback of the Dole-Kemp team," Mr. Kemp said. "As I said in San Diego, I'm going to be a great blocker, but I'm on the inside of a very important team for America."
In an interview today aboard his campaign plane, which is named Partner Ship, Mr. Kemp elaborated slightly on that answer.
"I want to be of influence," he said of his decision to run with Mr. Dole. "You have to decide whether you're going to be on the inside working or on the outside throwing long passes."
Mr. Kemp said that on matters about which he feels strongly, he was indeed sharing his opinions with Mr. Dole, but that those conversations would remain private.
He said that he and Mr. Dole had discussed the problems with a proposed constitutional amendment denying automatic American citizenship to the children of illegal immigrants before Mr. Dole's repudiation of the measure on Friday. But he added that Mr. Dole had qualms about the issue even before their talk and that Mr. Dole's decision not to support it was entirely his own.
"I have the opportunity to speak to potentially the next President of the United States," Mr. Kemp said. "Can I do it? I have. Will I in the future? I plan to."
Although his schedule beyond today is still in flux, it now calls for him to visit a number of urban centers and even inner-city areas, including spots in Detroit, St. Louis and Los Angeles, in the next week and a half.
His campaign director, Wayne Berman, said, "Jack Kemp is a guy who can go places that Republican's haven't gone."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Cowboys Manage a Victory Without Their Missing Parts

BYLINE: By CHARLIE NOBLES 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 24

 BODY:
Dallas Cowboys Coach Barry Switzer told his players tonight in an emphatic post-game speech that it is time for them to quit worrying about a handful of key players who will not be in uniform when the regular season opens.
"We've been thinking too much about the missing parts," Switzer said. "We've got to focus on the players that are playing, and we've still got the football team to win." 
 The Cowboys tonight broke a three-game exhibition losing streak, defeating the Houston Oilers by 24-19 at the Citrus Bowl.
The victory was not a thing of beauty. Troy Aikman did not complete his first pass until 45 seconds into the second period.
Aikman was then through for the night. The Cowboys, down by 13-10 at halftime, needed a lift from a quarterback in his 16th National Football League season, Wade Wilson, and a tight end recently picked up off waivers, Derek Ware.
Wilson directed five drives, producing three touchdowns and a field goal. Ware caught the last two touchdowns.
"We put a lot more effort and up-tempo play into this game than earlier," Switzer said. "But we're glad to get the preseason over."
During the summer, whispers turned into shouts that the Cowboys, winners of three of the last four Super Bowls, were ripe to be beaten.
"I remember having this same uneasy feeling going into last season," safety Bill Bates said. "But that worked out O.K., and it makes me think this season will, too."
Certainly Dallas enters next week's regular season opener at Chicago in a weakened state, with two of last year's stars out and a third very doubtful.
Wide receiver Michael Irvin is serving a drug suspension until Oct. 1. Running back Emmitt Smith has a sprained left knee that could be problematic for another three weeks. And tight end Jay Novacek has a disk problem in his back that will probably make him iffy for much, if not all, of the season.
The Cowboys also lost four players to free agency -- defensive tackle Russell Maryland, cornerback Larry Brown and linebackers Robert Jones and Dixon Edwards.
The club did acquire two players through the same route -- linebackers Fred Strickland and Broderick Thomas. "The players we've added this year, unlike last year, are quality players," Bates said.
The Cowboys hope to utilize Deion Sanders in Irvin's spot as well as at his usual cornerback post.
"We have managed to keep our core of key players," the owner Jerry Jones said. "With the salary cap, that weakened us a little in our depth. But hopefully once the regular season comes and we get our people back, we'll be just fine."
 
AROUND THE LEAGUE
In a meeting of the teams that lost in last season's conference championship games, the Indianapolis Colts beat the Green Bay Packers, 30-6, behind JIM HARBAUGH, who was 11 of 15 for 223 yards and two touchdowns before leaing the game early in the third quarter. . . . The Steelers put receiver ERNIE MILLS, who tore a knee ligament in Pittsburgh's loss to Dallas in the Super Bowl, on the physically unable to perform list. Mills must stay on the list a minimum of six weeks. . . . The unemployed tight end ERIC GREEN, released by the Dolphins July 9, met for an hour Saturday with Miami Coach JIMMY JOHNSON. "The guy is an up-front guy," Green said. "I respect him and he respects me. I think this thing is going to come together."

HEADLINE: Dole's Economic Plan Is No Riverboat Gamble

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alan Blinder (Op-Ed, Aug. 20) resurrects an old comment I once made about President Reagan's economic program -- calling it a "riverboat gamble" -- to attack the economic plan put forward by Bob Dole. While Mr. Reagan's program was a gamble, it largely paid off. By contrast, I do not believe Mr. Dole's plan is a gamble at all. It is a good bet. 
 In early 1981 I thought it was a gamble to cut taxes, reinvigorate national defense, control inflation and balance the budget at the same time. Accomplishing even one of these would have been difficult. But Mr. Reagan succeeded on each point except balancing the budget.
It is legitimate to call attention to Mr. Reagan's inability to balance the budget. But it is wrong to say, as Mr. Blinder does, that this means Bob Dole will suffer a similar result if his plan is implemented.
The political landscape has changed radically. We now have Republican control of both houses of Congress for the first time in a generation. And Congressional Republicans have made it clear that whether Mr. Dole or Bill Clinton is President next year, they will continue to press for a balanced budget.
If Mr. Dole becomes President he will have something Ronald Reagan always wanted but never had: the line-item veto. This will insure that Congress cannot pad Presidential budgets with pork-barrel projects and other programs of dubious value.
Most of the growth in spending during the Reagan years came from uncontrolled entitlements. Today there is a much deeper understanding of this problem and a greater likelihood of achieving bipartisan solutions. Under the welfare bill passed by a Republican-led Congress and signed into law by President Clinton, we have reined in an entitlement program.
The end of the Soviet threat means that it will not be necessary for Mr. Dole to engage in a massive defense spending increase, as President Reagan had to do.
it will be much more achievable for a President Dole to keep to his promises to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes than for President Reagan. And we do need a tax cut. Federal taxes are now at their second-highest level in American history, at 20.5 percent of the gross domestic product.
The Dole plan is no "riverboat gamble." It is a responsible approach to the twin problems of excessive taxation and sluggish growth.
 
HOWARD BAKER
Washington, Aug. 21, 1996
 
The writer, Senate majority leader from 1981 to 1985, was Mr. Reagan's chief of staff, 1987-88.

HEADLINE: Dole's Economic Plan Is No Riverboat Gamble;
First Fix the Structure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Even if Bob Dole justifiably believes that the Federal budget can be balanced atop a 15 percent tax cut (news analysis, Aug. 20), his economic platform still fails to address the forces driving America's tenuous job market. 
 According to supply-siders, tax cuts stimulate growth and create new jobs. Our economic woes, however, extend more from the type of economy that is growing than from its rate of expansion.
Many large businesses, despite reaping record profits, are laying off employees to satisfy the stock market's preference for lean payrolls. While job growth has kept up with corporate downsizing, foreign competition and the economy's drift toward the service sector have spawned new jobs that are either low-paying or require skills that many displaced workers don't have.
Mr. Dole's prescription for the economy may give some temporary relief to strapped wage-earners. But a plan that grows the economy without attacking its structural problems will perpetuate the economic trends that have made Americans so anxious about the future.
 
 BEN KRULL
New York, Aug. 22, 1996

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS THEN AND NOW;
The Daleys of Chicago

BYLINE: By James Atlas; James Atlas, an editor of The New York Times Magazine, is at work on a biography of Saul Bellow.

 BODY:
On a rainy spring night early in May, a somber, wood-paneled reception room in the Rayburn House Office Building is decked out for a party billed as "A Taste of Chicago." Balloons hang from the ceiling and a blues band is riffing in the corner. The bar is jammed. In the center of the room is a long table heaped high with platters of Vienna hot dogs, spareribs and deep-dish pizza -- indigenous Chicago cuisine. The party is being given to introduce Washington to the host city of its forthcoming Democratic convention, the first to be held there since the debacle of 1968.
The Mayor of Chicago is busy working the room. At 54, Richard M. Daley doesn't carry his father's weight -- even in the most literal sense. Rich, Richie or Little Richie, as people around town call him -- or, more disparagingly still, R2D2 -- is trimmer than his bulky, monolithic father, Richard J. The scowling, bejowled face that used to fill the TV screen on the local news for two decades has been replaced by a less-minatory image -- a Daley for the 90's. 
 The Mayor's press secretary, Jim Williams, a polished former TV reporter, introduces me to the Mayor. Daley shakes my hand warily. Journalists make the Mayor nervous. They quote him. Like his father, Richard M. is famously inept with the English language: "The more killing and homicides you have, the more havoc it prevents"; "You've got to have your order in business." (Nothing, however, rivals his father's legendary proclamation, uttered in the wake of the '68 Democratic convention riot: "The policeman isn't there to create disorder. The policeman is there to preserve disorder.") "He's an incredibly inarticulate and awkward person, full of malapropisms like his dad," the Chicago-based writer Alex Kotlowitz had briefed me. "But he's also more sensitive." When the Mayor's son, Patrick, then a teen-ager, had a raucous party at the family's Michigan summer home and got into trouble with the cops four years ago, Daley wept at the news conference.
I also meet the Mayor's younger brother William, 48, a Clinton adviser widely credited with having pushed Nafta through a recalcitrant Congress. Bill, as everyone calls him, is the antithesis of Rich. Bald where his brother is full-haired, smooth-talking where his brother is not, he has been described as "the brains behind the Mayor." But the brothers are famously close; they go on fishing trips together. "It doesn't matter if they haven't talked for two days or two weeks, they're always there for each other," says Rahm Immanuel, a director of special projects in the White House (and a former Chicago boy: he was Richie's mayoral-campaign finance director).
An able strategist who knows his way around Washington, Bill Daley served as Clinton's Illinois chairman in the '92 election and was rumored to have been in the running for Secretary of Transportation. After that post failed to materialize and he finished with Nafta, he returned to his lucrative corporate law practice in Chicago, but he is still close to the President and is the co-chairman of the host committee of the '96 convention. We make arrangements to meet again in Chicago.
Surrounded by his entourage, the Mayor looks tense. For all the warm feelings in the room, the party is a reminder of what happened 28 years ago. The police riot that exploded in front of the Conrad Hilton Hotel in August 1968 has become part of the iconography of American history. "Everything since Chicago has had a new intensity -- that of polarization, of confrontation, of antagonism and fear," Tom Wicker wrote in this magazine on the first anniversary of the '68 convention.
Nineteen years old and home from college for the summer, I was a foot soldier for the counterculture during that memorable August week, skirmishing nightly with the cops in Lincoln Park, dodging canisters of tear gas, running through the glass-strewn streets in my Keds -- a warm-up for the big confrontation that would embarrass the Democrats and probably cost them the Presidency. The whole world is watching, we chanted as the National Guard jeeps with barbed wire on their front fenders rolled down Michigan Avenue. And it was. Meanwhile at the International Amphitheater, Senator Abe Ribicoff of Connecticut was denouncing the "Gestapo tactics in the streets of Chicago." (David Brinkley, who was covering the convention for NBC, confirms that the Mayor wasn't screaming "faker!" at Ribicoff on national television that night, as aides claimed, but a more pointed epithet.)
Daley, who at that point had ruled the city with an iron fist for more than a decade, never quite recovered from the blow. In its day, the formidable government apparatus he had built, known as the Machine, controlled tens of thousands of city workers; as chairman of the Cook County Democratic Party Central Committee, Daley commanded power equal to that post's Soviet-sounding name. When John F. Kennedy campaigned just four days before the 1960 election, Daley turned out a million people in the streets. But in 1972, Daley's Cook County delegation was unseated at the Democratic convention in Miami Beach by an Afro-adorned Jesse Jackson and what Jackson's biographer, Marshall Frady, calls "a troupe of liberal irregulars." Four years later, the Mayor died of a heart attack, ending a 21-year reign. In the years that followed, his fabled Machine was dismantled by a succession of mayors too hapless to control it. And the country itself changed; suddenly it was full of vocal, politically savvy constituencies that wouldn't allow themselves to be ruled.
As I gaze around the room at the "Taste of Chicago" wingding, I'm struck by the diversity of the crowd. On hand are plenty of "notables" -- as Chicagoans like to describe important people -- to confer legitimacy on the event, seasoned pols like Senators Paul Simon and Carol Moseley-Braun, the Reverend Jesse Jackson and Representative Henry Hyde, head of the Senate Judiciary Committee. "The roles that African-Americans are playing, the roles that women are playing -- unheard of," asserts Ertharin Cousin, director of the White House liaison office at the State Department. "We were all standing outside. Now we have positions inside." Richie Daley, she contends, is "an inclusive Mayor." It sure looks that way.
Around 7, Hillary Rodham Clinton makes an appearance. Raised in suburban Park Ridge, the First Lady is proud of her association with Chicago. She gives a boosterish speech and makes a sports joke to demonstrate her insider credentials. By the time of the convention, she says, "the Bulls will have won the championship and the Cubs will be in first place." The room breaks up: the Cubs haven't won a pennant since 1945.
After Hillary and her handlers sweep out the door, people begin to drift away. "Chicago really knows how to throw a party," declares Cardiss Collins, a black congresswoman from the West Side. It is a good party. I stay so long that by the time I look around to say goodbye to the Mayor, he has slipped off to Jesse Jackson's house for a visit.
STRIDING THROUGH THE VAULTED CORRIDORS OF O'HARE International Airport the next day, I glance at the local newspapers in the vending machines. "U.S. Audit Clears Moseley-Braun," reads the headline in The Chicago Tribune. She has been cleared of allegations that she spent campaign funds for her personal use. Robert Belcaster, the head of the Chicago Transit Authority, has been forced to resign after it was divulged that he purchased stock in a company commissioned by the C.T.A. to sell the city experimental "clean fuel" buses. I'm glad to see that Chicago hasn't lost its talent for political sleaze. (Chicagoans joke that the city slogan, Urbs in Horto -- City in a Garden -- should be changed to Ubi Est Mea?: Where's Mine?)
I head into town, stunned as always by the dramatic cluster of skyscrapers on the horizon. "Chicagoland," that mythic realm invoked in local ad campaigns, still seems intact -- "an enchanted place like Alice's Wonderland or the fairy tales' never-never land," as Saul Bellow has wryly written, "though it looks, at times, like the doughboys' no-man's-land." Michigan Avenue is spiffier than ever. Tiffany and Bulgari shops have moved in since my last visit. The limestone Water Tower, the only major structure to survive the fire supposedly started by Mrs. O'Leary's cow, has been sandblasted clean.
There are other big changes afoot, and they aren't only cosmetic. The Mayor has taken over the school board, after supporting a bill that gives him the right to pick not only the five members but also the superintendent, known in Chicago as the chief executive officer -- an impressive consolidation of power that is being closely monitored by Rudolph Giuliani (Giuliano, as the Mayor calls him) and other big-city mayors embattled with their school boards. He also endorsed the takeover of the troubled Chicago Housing Authority by Clinton's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros. Chicago is again becoming the city it had been in the original Daley's administration: The City That Works. Its population has shrunk by nearly a million in the last four decades, from 3.6 million to 2.8 million -- continued evidence of white flight. But as far as Daley is concerned, this exodus makes the city more manageable. "We don't need more people." For this guy, there is no bad news.
It is at the Mayor's daily news conference that I get my first real glimpse of Daley in action. He can thrust and parry as aggressively as his old man. Asked by a reporter what role Jesse Jackson might play at the convention, he answers, "He's always had a role in all the conventions," and adds with a laugh, "sometimes a different role," referring to Jackson's power play in the 1972 convention. What about the resignation of Robert Belcaster as head of the C.T.A.? An editorial in the morning's Chicago Tribune contended that Belcaster was a victim of "a political lynching" by Daley, who used the stock purchase as an excuse to push Belcaster "out the door."
"I had nothing to do with him purchasing stock," the Mayor says heatedly. "I hope that the ivory tower realizes this."
"He's gone because why?" shouts a reporter from the back of the room.
"Because he resigned," the Mayor answers.
He is less combative discussing his own agenda -- in this case unveiling a new system for issuing food-vending licenses to reduce the bureaucracy. "Our goal is to bring down the walls of regulation on businesses," he says. He recites a litany of redundant licenses that Chicago food-service businesses must obtain, then grows apoplectic as he inveighs against the absurdity of "gum-ball-machine permits."
"He thinks more like a businessman than a politician," Marshall M. Holleb, a lawyer active in development around the city, tells me. "His dad ran the city on patronage; he's running it like a business -- out-sourcing, privatizing. He hates studies and reports; he wants quick action."
When the conference is over, Daley strides to the elevator, eager to get away. After the doors shut, he leans back in the corner, closes his eyes and breathes a heavy sigh.
T O UNDERSTAND THE MAYOR'S "ALL POLITICS IS LOCAL" mentality you have to go back to the brown bungalow on South Lowe Avenue in the Bridgeport neighborhood where he was born and raised. Five miles southwest of the Loop, the city's business district, it's a neighborhood that has changed less than just about any other in Chicago over the last century, a white, working-class community of close-knit Italian, Polish, German and Irish families. Many of its residents work in City Hall, the County Building, the fire and police departments. They're the essence of blue-collar Chicago.
The Mayor's father was a family man, a devout Irish Catholic married to the same woman -- Eleanor, better known as "Sis" -- all his life. Obedient to routine, he rarely traveled and made a point of having dinner at home with his seven children. (Rich was the oldest son.) Every morning before work, Daley pere stopped in at St. Peter's Church on Madison Street in the Loop. A favorite social activity was attending wakes.
His son has emulated this pattern of stability. He left his hometown only briefly -- for a two-year stint at Providence College in Rhode Island -- but earned his bachelor's and law degrees from DePaul University. (It took him three tries to pass his bar exam.) He raised his own family in a house just three blocks from where he was born. When he went into politics, he claims, he did it on his own. His father never encouraged him to follow in his footsteps? "No. He said: 'I never want to see you on my doorstep complaining about your decision -- whatever you want to do, you do. But you have to make up your mind.' " The Mayor has given his own three children the same advice -- and so far they have not been tempted by politics. His oldest daughter, Nora, is in the art business in New York; Patrick is a college student; the youngest, Elizabeth, is still in elementary school.
We head west in the Mayor's Town Car on our way to visit the Terraces of Old Irving Park, a new development for young middle-class professionals improbably situated right next to the Kennedy Expressway. As he expounds his urban policy, the Mayor returns obsessively to certain themes. "Immediate tow, immediate tow," he keeps repeating. It's not until the third or fourth time that I even understand what he's saying: abandoned cars should be promptly removed from the streets.
We turn off the expressway onto a residential street. From the living rooms of these new homes -- they cost up to $325,000 -- residents can hear the roar and grind of heavy trucks and can see the trucks through the window. There's also a proposal to build an asphalt plant nearby, which has caused the neighborhood great consternation. But half of the 68 units have been sold. "It's like a little Lincoln Park," says the developer, referring to the city's premier yuppie address. He is moving there himself. "The whole idea is to get the middle class back into the city." And not just the middle class: the Mayor has become deeply involved in renovation projects on both the West and the South Sides, providing incentives for private developers to build low-cost housing in poor black neighborhoods. This has been "the most active, supportive administration I've known in 36 years," says Bishop Arthur Brazier of the Apostolic Church of God.
Our next stop is the Vienna Sausage Factory, which has the reverse problem of the Irving Park development: here developers had threatened to put in residential units that would have forced the factory to relocate to the suburbs. The Mayor negotiated a deal that provided compensation for the developers, enabling the factory to remain, and the workers are grateful. As we tour the floor in our white coats and gauze caps, picking our way through puddles of blood past stainless-steel tables where men are carving up huge slabs of meat, a burst of applause rings out.
It's like this everywhere we go: the Mayor is greeted as a hero. No doubt this reflects a selective itinerary; I know there are pockets of opposition. But not many. Daley, in office since 1989, won the last election with 73 percent of the vote, and some people are starting to call him what they called his father: Mayor for Life. He has made a lot of ineffectual moves: failing to build a new airport; failing to renovate the Bears' stadium, Soldier Field; failing -- so far -- to make more than symbolic inroads in the slums (the slums that his father insisted weren't there). But he has done what Richard J. Daley could never do: he has if not unified at least pacified the city. Unlike faction-riven New York, Chicago operates on the principles of a mom-and-pop shop.
Not that he doesn't have his critics. The former Black Panther Bobby Rush, now a Democratic congressman from Chicago, insists that blacks are worse off than ever. "There's a growing sense of unfairness as it relates to empowerment issues," he maintains, pointing out that there are fewer high-ranking blacks in city government jobs than there were under Harold Washington, the city's first black mayor. "I think we're losing ground." Others remark on the Mayor's willingness to employ his father's hardball tactics. "You can't get on the wrong side of the guy," observes the Chicago lawyer-author and "notable" Scott Turow. "When you cross him you have made an enemy of real stature."
On the way back to City Hall, we drive past a huddle of low red-brick apartment buildings with broken windows and garbage-strewn playgrounds. What are you going to do about places like this? I ask the Mayor. "It seemed like a good idea at the time," he says of the projects that his father's administration built all over Chicago during the 50's and early 60's, segregating blacks in hulking apartment blocks miles from downtown. (Chicago is one of the most segregated big cities in the country.) "When they were built, they were like the Taj Mahal. It worked for two generations, but people didn't stay. They forgot about social services." But what now? How to integrate these disenfranchised communities into the booming corporate economy? The Mayor is vague. "You cannot put people in housing without jobs. You can build all the homes in America, but you've got to have jobs."
It's nearly 5 o'clock. I decide to pass up the Greek Independence Day reception and the 6:45 "infrastructure meeting" with members of the Mayor's cabinet. Another thing that amazes me about this Mayor: his sitzfleisch, his capacity for sitting in a chair and working. He claims to need only three or four hours of sleep. Late at night he reads -- sometimes mysteries, sometimes more substantial fare. He has just finished "Hitler's Willing Executioners," by Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, and David Herbert Donald's enormous biography of Lincoln. He works out daily, even when he's on the road. His job infuses him with energy; like Clinton, he loves to go among the people, soaking up adulation. His stamina is incredible.
I, though, am ready to pack it in for the day. I have an invitation to the gala opening of "Art 1996 Chicago" at Navy Pier. When I inform the Mayor that I'm peeling off, he looks crestfallen. An art fair? How could art -- how could anything? -- compete with attending receptions and visiting sausage factories?
At "Art 1996 Chicago," the works on the hardwood walls -- by Hockney, Giacometti, Dubuffet -- are going for $40,000 and up, and selling briskly. To this well-heeled crowd, Daley is a savior. He encouraged development, established the city as a world financial center, made some peace with minority groups. "He saved the city," a scion of one of the leading real-estate dynasties attests -- a common refrain. "The signal that's going out loud and clear is that Chicago is pro-business," a local entrepreneur testified at the morning news conference. And it is so: I see that for the businessmen of Chicago it is good.
Some businessmen, though, are more equal than others. The next morning I arrive at the Bismarck Hotel, a pols hangout since the 20's, to attend a breakfast the Mayor is having with 15 leaders from Chicago's African and Caribbean community. Among those present are Sandy Osei-Agyeman of AFAM Concept Inc., a hair products company; Augustine Afriyie of the Oakley Construction Company; Felicia Johnson, a neighborhood activist from the South Side. (Chicago's large black community includes 15,000 Ghanians, 40,000 Nigerians and 100,000 Caribbeans.)
Their grievances are straightforward: why haven't Africans been appointed to positions in the Daley administration? Why have they been virtually left out of the hiring and contract-awards processes in Chicago? Afriyie notes that his company submitted a proposal to the Board of Education to do construction work on city schools and has been chosen only for maintenance contracts worth less than $5,000. "We are not asking for a handout," insists Femi Odere, the founder of New Africa Publications. "We are asking for an opportunity."
The Mayor is gracious in return, but when it comes to details, he responds with a barrage of generalities: "I will look at that. . . ." "Economic opportunity is the key. . . ." "Building the bridge stronger and widening it. . . ." The Mayor is asked if he will commit to a breakfast next year. "Yes," he answers. "The breakfast was good." So it isn't a total loss.
As we walk back to City Hall, I ask the Mayor about Afriyie's complaint of not being allowed to bid on city construction contracts. "He got the contract," the Mayor says abruptly, then gives his mirthless laugh. "He wanted more. It's human nature."
W ILLIAM DALEY'S OFFICE AT THE law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt, just three blocks south of his brother's in a gleaming new office tower on LaSalle, Chicago's equivalent of Wall Street, is on the 33d floor. From its marble-floored lobby you can see out over the clustered high-rises of the Loop to the lake beyond, where sailboats glide on the horizon. After a few minutes' wait, Bill ushers me into his corner office. It's a busy day, he apologizes; the convention is approaching, and as co-host he is beginning to feel the crunch.
Was it hard to convince the Democrats to return to the scene of their debacle? He shakes his head. "It seemed smart for Rich to get the city back on the national map. And it was smart politics for Bill to be in the Midwest." Chicago is a key player in the election, he reminds me, quoting Mark Penn, of Penn & Schoen, the President's pollsters: "The votes Clinton needs to win are within 500 miles of Chicago."
Unlike his brother, who responds to questions about his past with monosyllabic retorts ("Education was the key -- school and sports"), Bill is expansive on the subject of his political childhood. The apparatchik-like figure who presided so menacingly over Chicago politics for two decades bears no resemblance to the father he knew. "My dad was tolerant. The truth is, he was very understanding. Whether it was people leaving the church or getting in trouble. He could be pretty tough, but in a personal sense he wasn't -- not to us."
Bill Daley has vivid memories of the '68 convention. "I was in the booth when Cronkite interviewed my dad," he says. Always a staunch Kennedy man, Daley was enthusiastically supportive of Robert Kennedy ("Daley means the ball game," Kennedy said); after Kennedy's assassination in June 1968, he switched his focus to Ted. With just a few hours to go before the convention opened in Chicago, the Mayor delayed endorsing the front-runner, Hubert H. Humphrey, anticipating that Ted might throw his hat into the ring. "My father told me there was a strong possibility that they would endorse Kennedy instead of Humphrey," he recalls. "He told me: 'Don't go out. I want you to stay home and answer the phone. There's gonna be a lot of calls.' "
But when Daley learned that Kennedy was definitely out of the race, he declared the Illinois caucus for Humphrey. "I remember it so well," Bill says. "My dad called up Humphrey and said: 'Be your own man, Hubert. And that goes for the war, too.' " (Humphrey failed to follow Daley's advice, delaying a statement of opposition to the Vietnam War until Sept. 30; many believe it cost him the election.)
How did the brothers end up in politics? "My dad never pushed it," Bill says genially, leaning back in his wing chair. "But he was such a force in our lives, in a positive way: if you called him, you never got told by a secretary that he was in a meeting. He had a positive attitude toward politics -- I wish I had one." After Bill Daley's Nafta victory, there were rumors that he would run for the Senate seat that fell vacant with Paul Simon's retirement, but he decided against it. "I'll be 48. If you're going to do it, you've got to do it for two terms. I kind of like the privacy I have. I got two brothers in politics, that's enough." (One brother, John, a former state senator, is now a county commissioner.)
Anyway, he has his hands full with Richie. Politics is a collaborative effort in the Daley family. When Rich Daley ran for Cook County State's Attorney in 1980, Bill managed his campaign. Three years later, when Rich made his first run for Mayor, against Harold Washington and Jane Byrne, Bill was again instrumental in setting a moderate course. Daley lost that election, but in 1989, two years after Washington died of a sudden heart attack, he triumphed against Eugene Sawyer, a black alderman who had become the interim Mayor. Refusing to play the race card, Daley defined himself as a candidate determined to calm Chicago's racial jitters. "The nerves of the city were frayed from racial confrontation," David Axelrod, Daley's media adviser, told the political correspondent (and Chicago boy) Sidney Blumenthal. "The margin for error was small. People needed to know Daley was a conciliator." He won with less than 10 percent of the black vote.
Two decades earlier, when the city went up in flames after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., his father had issued notorious orders to "shoot to kill any arsonist" and "shoot to maim or cripple any one looting." Rich Daley inhabits a different era. To remain a player, he was forced to modernize himself. "The tension's down," Bill says. "He's made a consistent effort to lower the rhetoric."
How are the two brothers different? "Richie's a lot more visceral," Bill says. "I've never met anybody in politics who has a better gut for what normal people are thinking." And how is Rich different from his father? "He probably shows his emotions more. Times have changed. Rich's big moves have been outside that structure -- the Organization." The Organization: I notice they don't refer to the Machine anymore. You know an institution is gone when it loses its name.
SINCE IT'S FRIDAY, THE MAYOR HAS A LESS-RIGOROUS schedule than usual -- a mere 10-hour day. The last event on his log is our interview. One subject I want to ask him about is the demolition of much of the Henry Horner Homes. Virtually adjacent to the United Center, Chicago's new stadium and the site of the convention, the project is a natural showcase for President Clinton's much-publicized campaign to change the face of public housing: it exemplifies the disastrous outcome of the now-discredited practice during the 50's and 60's of erecting massive high-rise developments deliberately isolated from the rest of the city. About $72 million in H.U.D. money has been allocated for the first phase of the Horner redevelopment plan. Demolition of gutted buildings began last year, and Secretary of Housing Cisneros, eager to demonstrate substantive achievement, has been pressing to get work -- visible construction work -- started before the convention.
"The only way to move ahead with H.H. is with the support of the people," the Mayor says, gesturing at me with the unlighted cigar he habitually chews. "No Federal official's gonna do it. So H.H. is the first one off the ground. That's how you rebuild a community. Someone doesn't come from Washington and say this, this and that."
The Mayor is preparing to assume the presidency of the United States Conference of Mayors in Cleveland the next month. What is his agenda? "Drug policy, jobs and economic development," he says firmly. "Empower the communities. Welfare is killing this country." But above all, he wants to instill in the mayors of America a sense of urgency about education. (Chicago is trying to reduce a 43 percent dropout rate in its high schools.) "An educated work force, that's what you need. I got business leaders saying, 'I got a hundred jobs, had a hundred people fill out applications and can't hire one.' Businesses are run by computers now; you have to be able to read and write. We're taking city colleges, making them part of the whole vocational training. School-to-work programs -- I call it 'windows of opportunity.' "
How has the city changed since '68? "A lot of people have died," Daley says with his brusque, snorting laugh -- the one he gives when he's uneasy. "It changes. Everything changes. That's the thing about America."
His own life has changed. Three years ago the Mayor gave up his house on South Emerald in Bridgeport and moved to a town house in the new Central Station development, south of the Loop. It was a controversial move; the Daleys had been in Bridgeport for a century. Critics charged that he was abandoning his constituency; the press pointed out that he was moving close to where he hoped to put up a $2 billion casino-entertainment complex and that the Mayor's former law firm, Daley & George, had done legal work on the zoning changes for the development.
It's not Daley's favorite subject. "I always kept my roots," he bristled when a Tribune reporter questioned the move. "First of all, my role as a mayor is to work with people from all walks of life. Also, I have a role as a father and husband. I cherish those things."
In other ways, too, he's kept his roots. Unlike so many big-city mayors, Daley has no larger political ambition; being Mayor of Chicago is an end in itself. Is he really Mayor for Life? "The day I don't have this fire in the belly, the day I don't enjoy this meeting, the day I don't have a dialogue with people, that's the day I'm gonna leave."
Suddenly the Mayor brings up something I had been reluctant to ask him about: his son Kevin, who died of spina bifada in 1981 at the age of 2. "One thing my father taught me: you can always lose. You act the same way when you win as when you lose. It's all part of life. I lost a son. The loss of my son had more effect than any loss of a lifetime. You can always lose an election, but when you lose a child it has an overwhelming impact on you and on your family. I had my priorities straightened out long before elections." (Bill Daley also had a son who died, of lung disease, when he was 8.)
I ask the Mayor about the upcoming Democratic convention. Is he worried about a repeat of '68? "Times are different," he says. "We're ready." He's looking forward to some heavy policy discussions with Clinton. "We talked a lot about these issues -- housing, education -- when he was here in '92." They still have regular conversations by phone.
Before I pack up my tape recorder, the Mayor wants to show off the black canvas briefcase that's been ordered for all Chicago police officers -- 14,000 briefcases. "This is important," he says in a low monotone, calling my attention to their dividers. "This way everyone can file their memos."
He goes and stands behind his father's desk, now his, leafing through his papers. He doesn't look up when I say goodbye.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3851 words

HEADLINE: Up In Smoke

BYLINE: By Luisita Lopez Torregrosa; Luisita Lopez Torregrosa, a writer in New York, lived in North Carolina for several years. This is her first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
ON THE LOW EDGE OF THE LUSH NORTH CAROLINA foothills, the flat countryside of Wayne County offers little to excite the eye. For miles there is nothing but scrub pines and hog farms, tract houses with satellite dishes and mobile homes on cinder blocks. Yet, this stretch of spare scenery does claim one distinction: it is tobacco country, perhaps the best in the world. It is where Randier Lee McCullen, 48, was born to tobacco, where he has grown it since he was a boy, as did his father and his grandfather, and four and five generations of thousands of other North Carolinians for whom tobacco is a birthright, their livelihood and their heritage.
The McCullen homestead appears suddenly, some 15 miles south of Goldsboro, a Bible-belt town of 30,000 that is the seat of Wayne County. The farmhouse stands back from a blacktop, two-lane road, a two-story antebellum white clapboard house that rises on a plain field that is red with canna lilies. 
 Randy McCullen's parents live there, on the western edge of the nearly 1,500 acres they co-own with their only son. But Randy runs the farm, where they grow corn and wheat as well as tobacco, and his office is set out half a mile from the house, down and around a winding dirt track that runs through the property.
"My parents and grandparents were tobacco farmers," he says. "And so were my wife's parents and grandparents." Johnnie Erastus McCullen, his paternal grandfather, started out growing potatoes and tobacco at the turn of the century in this county. Randy's father, R. E. McCullen, inherited his patch of tobacco, five acres near Dobbersville, in 1953, part of a 50-acre plot that Johnnie Erastus had bought in the early 40's for just $3,900. Now, more than 50 years later, the McCullens' holdings are worth close to $2 million.
"So, you see, we've been raising tobacco for a long time," Randy says. "But now there is a great deal of uncertainty because there are forces from all directions against tobacco. I tell you one thing -- the deck is stacked against the tobacco farmer. But we still feel like we grow the best tobacco in the world in eastern North Carolina, and we will continue to grow tobacco as long as we can."
When I bring up the more than 400,000 smoking-related deaths that occur in this nation every year, he tilts back in his chair, clasps his hands behind his neck and replies calmly, having expected the question. "We feel that in moderation -- a pack a day -- tobacco would not hurt you." But he wouldn't know himself; he has never smoked. "I do not feel, as a tobacco farmer -- and I think I speak for most of them -- that we are responsible for any disease. . . . We really don't see ourselves growing a product that's harmful to anyone. I don't think you'll find a farmer that'll feel guilty about growing tobacco."
We've already talked several times when we meet one morning at 5 at the Southern Belle coffee shop in Mount Olive, where his friends -- mostly everyone in business in the area -- gather at dawn on weekdays. Slowly, the crowd grows. With nods and mumbled hellos, they hunch down over their coffee and biscuits, occasionally offering up a wry comment. Except for a machine-shop owner, an old-timer who sits frowning at the far end of the table, no one smokes.
There's rambling talk about the business that's on everyone's mind, the run of bad news about the tobacco industry. The gathering storm could ruin these folks, and they know it. But at the Southern Belle this morning the dozen men at the table are putting the best face on things, scoffing at the anti-tobacco forces as maniacal, obsessed enemies of freedom of choice and the free market. Keith Beavers, a fifth-generation tobacco grower, sums up with what is, I strongly suspect, a well-rehearsed line. "Corn feeds the nation," he says, "but tobacco pays the bills."
Ruddy-faced and broad-backed, his black-and-red flannel shirt straining at his belly, Beavers, at 48, represents the new generation of tobacco farmers -- articulate, college-educated, media-wise, Republican, a tobacco activist who has joined hundreds of other farmers on bus trips to Washington to buttonhole and badger Congressmen. Beavers tends 70 acres of tobacco, well above the regional average of 25 acres. He also grows corn and sweet potatoes and has started raising beef cattle on his 1,000-acre farm in neighboring Duplin County. But tobacco is what he grew up on, what put food on the table, and to this day he identifies himself as a tobacco farmer. "It'll come to an end someday," he says resignedly. "But not in my lifetime. I tell you, without tobacco, I'd quit farming."
At the other side of the table, Dennis Goodwin, his dark pompadour slicked back and a paisley tie tucked in a tailored business suit, introduces himself -- the pastor of the local United Methodist Church and Mount Olive's "biggest S.O.B." He laughs as he says: "The national Methodist Church board opposes tobacco, but not alcohol. It opposes apple pie and baseball, all the good things." People are chuckling, eyes on him as he rises to go. "Look," he says to me, dead serious now, "tobacco is a big money crop. If something could take its place, people would grow it."
F ROM POINTS NORTH, WHERE THE antitobacco war has its high command, in the White House and in numerous legal, health and environmental organizations, the battle against the $45 billion industry has spread far and wide, from the marketplace to the workplace, from restaurants to airports to homes. Kicked into high gear by the Clinton Administration in the summer of 1995, the campaign has taken on the aspects of a crusade, nothing less than the largest and broadest attack ever on a single American industry.
All this comes about at a time when American cigarette production is actually greater than it was 10 years ago. "Exports -- mostly to Western Europe and Japan, the biggest foreign buyers of American tobacco -- have offset the decline in domestic consumption," says Blake Brown, an agricultural economist at North Carolina State University. Last year was a record year, he says, with probably the largest American cigarette production ever.
But out in the field the growers worry. They worry that the Food and Drug Administration will succeed in having tobacco declared a drug. And they worry that the American manufacturers will continue to expand their business overseas, buying more tobacco from Brazil and Zimbabwe and India and building factories in largely untapped smoking-friendly markets in regions like Southeast Asia. Already, American production of flue-cured tobacco has declined and constitutes just 9 percent of the world market. That is still more than anyone else produces, with the exception of China, which accounts for 40 percent of the world's tobacco (and consumes almost all of that amount).
What concerns tobacco growers, McCullen says, is losing the freedom to sell their crop. "If the cigarette manufacturers for some reason lose their market share or marketplace, that would affect the grower tremendously. . . . If Philip Morris has problems, the tobacco farmer has problems. We have to be able to market our tobacco. It's a chain, and everybody has to come together and support each other.
"We feel like we grow the best tobacco in the world" -- by that he means flue-cured tobacco, widely regarded by experts as the best cigarette tobacco because of its ideal balance of sugars and nicotine. "It's high in nicotine. Extremely high. It's high in tar, and it's quality. It's just high-quality tobacco." When I ask McCullen if he believes that what he calls the "negative forces" -- lawyers, the media, liberals, the medical establishment -- will prevail over the big tobacco allies in Congress, who are the beneficiaries of the more than $2 million that the tobacco companies have already forked over in political contributions since the beginning of 1995, he smiles.
Although McCullen is a Democrat and says he will vote for President Clinton, he points to Bob Dole's recent defense of the tobacco industry: "Dole is a tremendous supporter. He comes from a farm state and understands farmers." But there's another reason, he says, that big tobacco will survive: "Tobacco generates income. Tremendous amount of taxes."
In 1994, each acre of tobacco grown in the United States for domestic use brought in $43,000 in state and Federal excise taxes at the retail level. Some of that money trickles down to the farm. In fact, it more than trickles. Tobacco sells at around $1.80 a pound but it costs only $1 a pound to produce, and a single acre can yield as much as 2,500 pounds. While the McCullens grow only 70 to 75 acres of tobacco, they yield more revenue than their other crops -- around $4,000 per acre, an annual gross of $250,000 to $275,000.
That has made McCullen a big farmer in a region of small farmers and has given his family an ease of living that is not common in North Carolina, where median family income is $39,100. It pays for a private-college education for his daughter, for the McCullens' lakeside cedar house and for the middle-class amenities that they enjoy -- a fireplace-size television set, a Jet Ski, a $30,000 Chevy Suburban, a Corvette, a pickup truck for his son and Easter Week holidays with friends at Myrtle Beach, S.C.
As the bumper stickers say in eastern North Carolina: "Tobacco money pays my bills!"
IT WASN'T ALWAYS THAT WAY. BACK IN THE pre-Depression era, prices fluctuated wildly and growers floundered from season to season, at the mercy of the marketplace, the weather and the powerful cartel of cigarette manufacturers. But in the 1930's, at the height of the New Deal, the Federal Government stepped in and established allotments (the number of acres a farmer is allowed to plant) and price-support programs for a range of commodities with the idea of limiting supply in order to force prices up.
"The Government," says Blake Brown, "came in and said, 'It looks like you've been growing five acres of tobacco, so we're going to give you an allotment for five acres." Combined with a Government-guaranteed price floor -- around $1.60 a pound this year -- the allotments evolved into small gold mines. They became attached to farms, greatly enhancing their value, and were passed along like stocks and bonds through the generations. In effect, each tobacco farmer was issued a share in a Government-sponsored monopoly. "If corporations did this, they'd probably be subjected to anti-trust suits," Brown says.
The Federal Government's role is not restricted to allotments and price supports. The Agriculture Department determines tobacco grades, price supports and limits on acreage. But it also plays a more obscure, but perhaps even more crucial role. It can ban, as it did in 1957, any variety of tobacco that the cigarette manufacturers don't want to buy, even if the farmers themselves prefer to grow that variety.
Old hands recall the mysterious case of Coker 139, a tobacco seed produced by the Coker Pedigreed Seed Company of Hartsville, S.C., that became the rage among growers in the early 50's. "It was a perfect variety," Bill Lamm, a retired agricultural extension agent, told me when we first met. At the time of the Coker furor, Lamm was the tobacco agent in Wayne County. "It was chemically well balanced," he continued. "It cured easily. It yielded tremendous poundage per acre. It was very resistant to disease. It had moderate levels of nicotine. It was so popular that most of the tobacco acreage was planted with it. It looked like utopia."
But the Federal Government banned it in January 1957. The growers protested, and Coker became the hottest farm issue in the Carolinas, prompting the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, Olin D. Johnson, a firebrand South Carolina Democrat, to accuse the Agriculture Department of "Hitler tactics." Johnson, one of the great legends of Dixiecrat politics, was standing up for his constituents, the South Carolina company that produced Coker 139 and the Clemson University scientists who gave it their approval. But North Carolina officials and tobacco experts joined the cigarette companies and their partner, the Federal Government. Against that alliance, the farmers were impotent, and Coker 139 was finished.
The Agriculture Department classified Coker 139 as "low to lacking in flavor and aroma, generally of light body and currently with poor acceptance in the trade," meaning among cigarette makers. The tobacco companies had at that time begun to promote filter-tip cigarettes, in part to widen their sales among women, and according to Lamm and others, filter-tips required a darker, heavier type of leaf, presumably one with more nicotine than that produced by Coker 139.
"I don't want to imply that the companies wanted more nicotine," Lamm told me the first time we talked. But when we met a second time, he said: "You brought up the idea of Coker 139, why it was banned. No, I better not say that. . . ." He paused, took a sip of iced tea, and shaking his head, he said: "Well, yes. It was the nicotine. It had low nicotine, low nicotine."
That was seconded by Gerald F. Peedin, a crop-science professor at North Carolina State University and an expert on tobacco production. "Coker 139 was good yielding, but it had a leaf imbalance," he said. "High levels of sugar, low levels of nicotine. The companies didn't want it."
The demise of Coker 139 came at a bad time for small tobacco farmers. Labor costs were rising rapidly, as the traditional pool of black pickers dried up, and few of the farmers could afford the heavy investment in machinery needed to compete with the big growers. For many, it was the straw that broke the camel's back. Half a century ago, the state had 300,000 tobacco farms. Now it has 58,000. Yet the profits for those who grow it have not diminished, and tobacco pumps $1 billion a year into the state economy.
Across Wayne, which ranks ninth in production among North Carolina's tobacco counties, there are only 500 tobacco growers, planting around 8,500 acres. Yet, gross sales of tobacco in the county's warehouses will most likely match the gross sales of all other field crops combined. Just two years ago, tobacco brought in $32.4 million, compared with $33.6 million for all the other crops.
"Look around," says Bob Pleasants, the county agricultural extension agent. "This town was built with tobacco money." Goldsboro, named one of the 10 best cities in America by Money magazine in 1993, is indeed stocked with Wal-Marts and other discount stores, industrial parks, shopping centers, strip malls, cineplexes, fast-food drive-ins, even Chinese and Mexican restaurants. Tobacco is not, of course, the sole source of its prosperity -- turkey and hog farms bring in big money, and Seymour Johnson Air Force Base supplies a steady flow of Federal dollars -- but tobacco is at the core of its growth.
So, naturally, Pleasants defends tobacco. "I don't think that the tobacco producers are selfish," he says. "Tobacco production is their means of livelihood. It's fed and clothed them, and educated their children. It's their sustenance."
When I leave his office, he waves and says, "Be kind."
THE STORY OF TOBACCO IS NOT ONE OF plantations and columned mansions, Southern gallantry and ladies and gentlemen with pedigrees and social airs. Tobacco Road is, after all, synonymous with redneck Southern poverty. On the maps of tobacco history, there's no Savannah or Charleston, and certainly no Mississippi Delta, no afternoons of mint juleps on the veranda or rum toddies in the gazebos.
"This area was not the huge plantation kind of place," laments Sandra Raiford McCullen, Randy's wife, who has a doctorate in education from North Carolina State University and works for the county school district. "It was small family farming. Being self-sufficient. My father was seen as quite poor people. And I think it's amazing that in my lifetime I've gone from stoop labor to have some kind of job that benefits people."
While the history of tobacco is replete with legendary names, big fortunes and dynasties -- the Dukes of Durham, the Reynoldses of Winston-Salem and the great universities that tobacco money endowed -- the routine of life on the farm was hard and bare. Tenants and sharecroppers and small-time landowners worked from sunup to sundown over the long growing season.
Randy's 71-year-old mother, Julia Dildy McCullen, grew up on a farm in adjoining Greene County. "All our family worked in the fields," she says. A tiny woman with short, tightly curled hair, she's sitting in a rocking chair in the spacious living room of the white farmhouse. "I pulled tobacco plants. I picked weeds off them. And I harvested tobacco for years and years."
She married R. E. McCullen in 1947, after he came back from the war. Several years later, when he got his five-acre tobacco allotment (along with 45 acres of farmland) after his father died, R. E. began to expand their land holdings. Now Julia sits in a comfortable house with modern conveniences, even a cordless telephone. "Tobacco paid the bills," she keeps telling me. "Tobacco gave us all this." She stirs from her rocker and checks the stove, where she has been cooking lunch since early morning. Her husband walks in, spry, hospitable, with a wind-lashed face, thinning silver hair and a slow gait. His voice has a deep timbre; his drawl is pronounced.
We're talking about the land he inherited from his father, the plot that was worth less than $4,000 back in the 40's. "Today the 50 acres is worth -- let me see," he says, rising to get a pen and a legal pad. He jots down numbers. "You won't believe this," he says, grinning. "We paid $3,900. That is how much it cost when my parents bought it. Now it's worth $150,000."
"I'm not but 47 years old," he says, kidding (he's 74), when I ask him what's going to happen to the land. "I feel young. I don't take no medicine. Never smoked. Never drank. Never ran around with wild women." He has never thought of leaving his land and has never lived outside a 10-mile radius of his birthplace.
Would he ever sell the farm?
"No. Never."
With that, as if on cue, Randy walks in. Flipping through a farm journal, he tells me that he grows Norfolk King 326, the most popular tobacco seed. It costs $70 an ounce, and each ounce yields about 10 acres. He brings out a thumb-size plastic tube of seeds, which are the color of dark Colombian coffee beans and the size of fine sand grains.
As we talk, his mother sets the table -- chuck roast with carrots and onions, creamed corn and lima beans, iced tea. We take our places and there's a sudden pause. Randy bows his head, clasps his hands over his plate and barely moving his lips, says grace.
R ANDY MCCULLEN IS THE END OF THE line. He has two children, Amanda, a 19-year-old freshman at Meredith College in Raleigh, who wants a career in health care, and Chandler, a 15-year-old who likes to go hunting and keeps in his bedroom three shotguns, including a $100 Chinese-made S.K.S. semi-automatic rifle, and a display of Confederate flags.
"Our daughter, Mandy, she does not want to farm," Randy says. "Our son, I don't know. We want to send him to college but he prefers to start his own business. I don't know what that would be. Now, my son will be 16 and he will be assuming a different role."
It's clear where his hopes lie.
For Mandy McCullen, who persuaded her mother to quit smoking, tobacco farming is the past. But she struggles between her own ambition -- to help the ill -- and her heritage. "The farm has been such a tradition," she says. "It's our food, school and other things." I ask her if she would grow tobacco herself. "No, I wouldn't do it," she says after a long pause. "But as a family, it's been such a major part of my life. We can't give it up. It's our livelihood."
Hours later, I'm talking with her mother, Sandy, at their home in Sleepy Creek, a rural subdivision of bilevel homes circling a lake. Dark-eyed, with short, springy chestnut hair, Sandy McCullen is the director of secondary education with the Wayne County School District, a long way from the tobacco farm in Seven Springs, in southeast Wayne County, where she grew up.
Sandy, who at 47 has earned two master's degrees as well as her doctorate in 17 years of commuting from Goldsboro to East Carolina University and North Carolina State, seems to have grown distant from the land. "Randy makes his decisions about the farm," she says. "That's his domain. I also have a life of my own, too, you know. I feel that probably our relationship differs a lot from other tobacco farmers."
But "I love my roots," she says, and saddens visibly when she remembers her childhood -- running around shirtless, drinking lukewarm Pepsi-Colas and eating Nabs, peanut-butter-filled orange crackers, while riding on the back of a pickup truck. "My father and mother worked a farm together when they first got married. They bought and paid for it. Inherited some. My brother runs the farm today, near Seven Springs. My mother lives there, where her parents lived. And right across the road is a tobacco store, and those are my cousins, and that store belonged to my grandfather."
Around here, she says, it's tobacco and pork. "You eat pork every day. And the churches have these barbecue dinners. That's part of the culture. Pig-pickings and church barbecues. . . .
"I don't know if you can depend on tobacco anymore, and I think that's what's making people so nervous about it. All my aunts, who are in their 70's, they're living off their tobacco allotments. I mean, that's part of their estate. That's part of their heritage. And they depend on that for their own existence. Not just my aunts, but anyone who had any kind of tobacco allotment."
Sandy's father died when he was 65. "He died of a heart attack. He died probably from smoking cigarettes. He smoked five packs a day on the average, no filters. So I guess we could say we saw it firsthand, you know."
She blames the cigarette companies. "Oh, yeah, I think they are the main culprits. But you asked me how I felt about living off tobacco money. It's kind of hard to think that's what you've done. I do have sentiments about that, but I tuck it away and don't think about it.
"I look at this wonderful way of life we had that I see is kind of dying now. . . . I told Randy two years ago that tobacco was dying, that the life was gone."
One evening, we meet for dinner at Applebee's, a chain restaurant in Goldsboro. Sandy comes in a gold silk blouse and flowing midcalf deep-green skirt, the picture of a successful Southern professional woman. Their son, Chandler, has been brought along, and has the sullen look of teen-age boys, socially awkward, timid. Chubby-faced and blond, with a close-cropped military haircut, he's wearing his Southern Wayne High School leather jacket and a black T-shirt with gold lettering that proclaims, "Tobacco is not a drug, stupid."
I ask him if he wants to be a farmer like his father.
He looks away from them and says, "Hell, no!"

LENGTH: 279 words

HEADLINE: Sunday August 25, 1996: GAMBLING;
Jake Viarrial, Casino Zealot

 BODY:
Know what? Better drive around back, or I'll never get through the door," says Jake Viarrial as he points at a large edifice he built: the $25 million Cities of Gold Casino, a faux-adobe box a few miles north of Santa Fe, N.M. His stealth entrance doesn't work. Inside, the jovial, hefty Viarrial is mobbed by chatty gamblers, who offer bilingual variations on "Give 'em hell!" 
 Viarrial, the Pojoaque Indian pueblo's governor, is easily the most flamboyant figure in a nationally watched controversy that is lurching toward a messy conclusion. New Mexico is home to 11 Indian casinos -- grossing about $230 million last year -- which were made possible through agreements and "compacts" emanating from both the United States Attorney and the Governor's office. The current imbroglio began in 1995, when anti-gambling forces challenged the legality of these arrangements in court and started winning. If the Indians lose again (the Federal Appeals Court in Denver now has the case) they may get shut down, at least temporarily, leaving them stranded with $130 million worth of loans.
Amid the fray, Viarrial has often played it like a high-desert Al Sharpton. He once fasted for 21 days to dramatize his cause. Staring at a shutdown threat earlier this year, he vowed to set up toll booths on a state highway that passes through pueblo land. Ultimately, though, bluster won't help, and Viarrial knows that if the worst happens, "we may have to find a new economic resource." Like? He pauses, recalling an earlier threat that jolted the upscale citizens of Santa Fe. "Well," he says, smiling, "I'm really, really serious about having a nuclear-waste dump here."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Cezanne Gives a Boost To Philadelphia Tourism

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
O.K., Atlanta got all the attention -- for two Olympic weeks. But for month after non-Olympic month, day in and day out, another city has been America's most surprising summer magnet for tourism: Philadelphia.
"Cezanne," the immensely popular exhibition of 170 works by the Impressionist master at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, helped make the summer of 1996 "the best in Philadelphia since the capital moved in 1800," said R. C. Staab, vice president of tourism and communications for the Philadelphia Convention and Visitors Bureau. The show, which began May 30 and runs until Sept. 1, was sold out in late July except for a few tickets available through hotel packages. 
 The show will have attracted an estimated 700,000 visitors by its closing date, breaking all attendance and sales records at the Philadelphia Museum. Mr. Staab said the economic impact on the city will be $60 million in revenues generated from hotels, restaurants, shops and local transportation. The projected total number of visitors for the year will be 5 to 10 percent higher than the 4.8 million who came to Philadelphia in 1995. Hotel occupancy, which was 70 percent last year, is projected at 75 percent for 1996 because of "Cezanne" and a spate of other conventions and events. Some hotels that have appealed to Cezanne-lovers with special packages are currently 95 percent full.
"We never dreamed it would be this successful," Mr. Staab said. "I didn't believe that the name Cezanne held the same kind of strong recognition as Monet or van Gogh."
Moreover, Philadelphia has been swarming with visitors in "what is usually our slow time," said Georges Perrier, the French-born owner and chef of Le Bec-Fin, one of the city's grand restaurants. " 'Cezanne' has greatly increased our business -- and our knowledge. I've seen it five times and I must see it again."
The exhibition has taught Philadelphia's tourism establishment to pull together more effectively in marketing cultural institutions, tourism officials said. The city's first major cooperative marketing program was launched two years ago for the traveling exhibition of works from the Barnes Foundation at the Philadelphia Museum in 1995.
Emboldened by the success of that venture, a new cooperative marketing program was created for "Cezanne," enlisting the participation of the Philadelphia Museum, Advanta (the credit-card issuer that is the show's corporate sponsor), the Convention and Visitors Bureau, and the Museum of American Art of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. All told, the Philadelphia Museum and the show's sponsors spent more than $750,000 to advertise the exhibition.
To date, the hotels have sold about 20,000 packages, Mr. Staab said. Desperate "Cezanne" wannasees can check the city's Internet site for hotel availability. The address is http://www.libertynet.org/phila-visitor/ceztix.html
The first "Cezanne" retrospective in 60 years, the exhibition was hardly your garden-variety attraction. The show benefited from the buildup from Paris to London, its previous stops, said Sandra Horrocks, vice president of marketing and public relations at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. "When it arrived, it got the kind of critical acclaim it deserved," she said. "And it helped that it was the only stop in the United States for this exhibition."
"Cezanne" has persuaded Philadelphians that, in the quest for tourism, cultural resources can compete with the city's celebrated historical treasures. "We certainly will continue to market Philadelphia as a cultural destination along with our traditional American heritage sites," Mr. Staab said.
What can the museum do for an encore? It's offering a troika of shows: The first, "The Peale Family: Creation of an American Legacy 1770-1870," showcases the paintings of Philadelphia's first family of portraitists as a chronicle of American democracy; it will run from Nov. 3 to Jan. 5, 1997. The second, "Encounters with Modern Art: Works from the Rothschild Family Collections," presents futurist, Cubist, constructivist and other works; it will be on view from March 2 to May 11, 1997.
And from March 30 through June 22, 1997, the third show, "Michelangelo and Rodin," will offer 50 sculptures and drawings showing the influence of the Renaissance master on one of the most popular sculptors of the modern age. The show was conceived by the Casa Buonarotti in Florence; once again, the Philadelphia Museum is its only American stop.
The final lesson of "Cezanne" is that "cultural tourism really works," said Ms. Horrocks. "People will travel to see these very special events. So it is absolutely worthwhile for cities to make an investment to make sure that these shows happen."
