SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1921 words

HEADLINE: Final Judgments

BYLINE: By Christopher Buckley; Christopher Buckley's new collection of essays, "Wry Martinis," will be published this winter.

 BODY:

Nixon Off the Record
By Monica Crowley.
231 pp. New York:
Random House. $23.
He's baaack! 
 For the last five years of his life, Richard Nixon sipped tonic water and spilled the beans to a young assistant he hired right out of college after she wrote him a flattering letter about his book "1999." Monica Crowley was a steel-trap amanuensis, taking down every word with apparently astonishing precision -- she implies that she didn't use a tape recorder, but then perhaps Nixon's post-White House staff avoided tape recorders the way Count Dracula's assistants might avoid crucifixes.
After Nixon died in 1994, she says, William Safire, a former Nixon scribe, gave Ms. Crowley the ethical go-ahead to publish, telling her, "Nixon knew that when he spoke to you, he was speaking to history." The result is her first and Nixon's final book, a portrait of the most compelling, infuriating and fascinating American political figure of our half of the 20th century. Here he is in all his five-o'clock-shadowed glory, spinning not in the grave but from it: seething over the incompetence of the Bush re-election campaign, scheming to ingratiate himself with the Clintons -- not a pretty picture -- handicapping the current election and agonizing over his place in history, all the while serving up scathing assessments of all the players.
Richard Nixon hasn't been this interesting since the Oval Office bugging system was taking the dictation. In life we knew him as Tricky Dick. Now, in death, he gives us Dishy Dick.
A lot of the players will be going around airily pretending they haven't had time to read the book, then locking the doors to the den to look themselves up fretfully in the index to find out what he really thought about them. For George Bush, James A. Baker 3d, David Gergen, Robert A. Mosbacher, Nicholas Brady, Richard Darman, Jack Kemp and Pat Buchanan, reading this book will not be a pleasant experience -- a bit like attending the reading of a will in which they are left not the house, estate and trust funds but the deceased's diabetic cat, with contemptuous instructions for its care. "Withering" is not quite strong enough a word to describe Mr. Nixon's feelings toward many of the above. And those are the Republicans.
President and Mrs. Clinton would do well to search elsewhere for diverting reading on their vacation, as would his Cabinet. "Well! Look at that Cabinet. Aren't they an awful-looking group? My God! Shalala and Reno? They are so far to the left that I don't know what they are. And Hillary! She's so steely. She even claps in a controlled way." Secretary of State Warren Christopher is hereby advised to assume the fetal position if anyone within a hundred-yard radius brings up the book.
Who comes off well? It's a short but surprising list: Bob Dole, Mario Cuomo, H. R. Haldeman, Al Gore, Dan Quayle and Elliot Richardson. There's a fun dinner party for you.
The aggrieved will be able to take some comfort from the book's rather massive Achilles' heel, assuming it is that. Either Ms. Crowley, who occasionally gets a bit breathless about all the mentoring -- Michael Kinsley's line kept coming to me: He threw her over the desk and mentored her until dawn -- didn't catch the glaring fallacy in her argument, or something even more interesting is going on here.
At the outset of Part 1, she writes: "Above all for Nixon, leadership demanded a person secure in his abilities and in himself and who was, therefore, willing and able to take those risks. Of the many criticisms leveled at him, the one he found most egregious was that he was insecure. Politics, by its very nature, attracts the supremely secure."
As they say in the Valley, Hello? There's enough in that there asseveration to keep every pundit, political scientist and psychologist in America arguing for a month. Her book is a prosecutor's brief for the antithesis, at least in Nixon's case. Almost every page contains DNA evidence, supplied by her mentor himself, that for all his undeniable guts, his ability, again and again, to take a kicking and go on ticking, Richard Nixon was the most transparently insecure human being ever to reach the White House.
"Why the hell isn't he showing some leadership?" he fumes about George Bush's lack of vision. "I'll tell you something. When the [expletive deleted] and his gang come to me for advice, I am not going to provide it unless they are willing to thank me publicly. Neither Reagan nor Bush did that after all these years of my advice, and frankly I have had it. They'll find me when they need me, but I may not be available." You can hear the stamping of slippered feet on the study floor.
Twenty pages later he's bristling about the Bush campaign -- "All tactics and no vision. Nothing." In his histrionic, tautological way, he tells her: "I reiterate to you once again: I will not give them any advice unless they ask and unless they are willing to thank me publicly. I'm tired of being taken for granted. They all come to me on the sly when they are in big trouble -- well, no more. No more going in the back door of the White House -- middle of the night -- under the cloak of darkness. . . ." Wonderful image, that: Nixon being bundled into the side entrance under a raincoat.
Desperate to be a player again, he submits to the humiliation of a visit from the Presidential aspirant Ross Perot, calculating that the specter of his becoming a Perot shadow adviser might prompt Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton into bringing him in out of the cold. Mr. Perot makes the former President wait two hours, pleading New York City traffic. (To paraphrase Dana Carvey's Perot, "Isn't that just sad?") In one of the book's more amusing moments Nixon, convinced that his phones have been tapped, resolves to flush out the tappers with a prearranged call to Ms. Crowley, telling her that he's planning to come out publicly for Mr. Perot. First time as tragedy, second time as opera bouffe.
"I hope to God they don't ask me to speak at the [1992 Republican] convention," he says later. "I won't do it. It's a loser all around." He doth protest a bit too much here. Richard Nixon would have bicycled to Houston to speak at that convention in a New York minute, if asked. And too bad he wasn't. His take on Pat Buchanan's fateful speech at that convention: "He's so extreme; he's over there with the nuts. . . . Attacking the gays was wrong, wrong, wrong. Besides, they vote too."
Again and again he tells Ms. Crowley, in terms that would scorch paint off the walls, of his contempt for Bill Clinton. Then when Mr. Clinton wins, he sets out to cozy up to -- another less attractive phrase comes to mind -- the new President with such zeal that you find yourself mumbling, "Say it ain't so."
After Nixon had read her a copy of a letter to Mr. Clinton, she reports, "He said to me 'I know it goes a bit overboard, particularly on the character stuff, but the guy's got a big ego, and you've got to flatter the hell out of him if you are going to get anywhere.' " And there you have it in one excruciating sentence: Nixon so yearned to be a contender again that he was willing to bear any burden, pay any price, to get back in the ring. "I used the word 'character' not in the moral sense," he elaborates to a no doubt dumbstruck Ms. Crowley, "because he has no morals -- but in the strength sense. Adversity builds character. . . . I have to work with the guy, so I might as well start with this."
Mr. Clinton put him back in the (outer) loop with a few phone calls about foreign policy. Nixon tells Ms. Crowley that he told the President, "Foreign policy is just more interesting." No surprise there, but how delicious to find a few pages later all our suspicions confirmed: "Monica, history will not remember him [Mr. Clinton] for anything he does domestically. The economy will recover; it's all short-term and, let's face it, very boring."
For a time, Nixon was thrilled and energized by Mr. Clinton's attentions. "He invited me to the White House," he announces one day. "The sentence hung there in the air before he continued, 'In 12 years, neither Reagan nor Bush ever put me on the White House schedule or put a picture out.' " Just as it took Nixon to open China, so it took Mr. Clinton, whose own wife had served on the impeachment committee, to open the White House back up to Nixon. Amusingly, Nixon tried to keep Mr. Clinton from consulting with Henry Kissinger. But alas, the Rodney Dangerfield of Saddle River got no enduring respect from the Clintons. That realization came when they did not attend the funeral of Mrs. Nixon. It's a harrowing and poignant moment, Lear on the blasted heath, Monica Crowley in the role of Cordelia.
"Nixon, rocked with grief, exploded after the service. 'Vernon Jordan? The Clintons sent Vernon Jordan? He's a fine man, but come on. Hillary should have been there. That was inexcusable. He comes to me for advice . . . and he can't even send a Cabinet member to Mrs. Nixon's funeral?"
The disappointment and anger would turn out to be conclusive, yet when Mr. Clinton made his next State of the Union speech, promoting health care, he included a mention of Nixon's health care proposals. "Did you know," he says to Crowley, "that that was the first time a President ever mentioned me? Ford, Reagan and Bush never did."
In life, Nixon was famed as a 20-20 political handicapper. In death, it remains to be seen. Bob Dole "must really take over the party," he tells her. "He's the only one; no one else can do it." Later: "Dole is the only one who can lead. He is by far the smartest politician -- and Republican -- in the country." He advised his protege to wait until after 1994 and then "kick the hell out of Perot" (still waiting), to cultivate Colin Powell (done, to little avail), to avoid letting the religious right dictate the terms (yes and no), to be "conservative" on economic issues (done) but "compassionate" on welfare and health care (so-so), to "stay young" (he's trying) and -- the $64,000 question -- to "attack Clinton's policies and not him personally." In fairness, Nixon said this in 1993; now the character issue may really be Mr. Dole's only available red meat.
Mr. Dole, one of Nixon's most serious students, who eulogized him with the words, "The second half of the 20th century will be known as the age of Nixon," would surely have invited him to speak at the '96 Republican convention. What a pity he didn't live long enough for that final dispensation.
Whatever we thought of Nixon, he paid full fare for his sins. It's all here, the pain and humiliation of his 20-year exile from the arena. He made a fatal mistake not burning those tapes a quarter-century ago. It is inconceivable that he made a second fatal mistake letting it all hang out with Ms. Crowley. Mr. Safire was right: Nixon knew his soul-revealing musings would eventually see the light of day. "Nixon Off the Record" is a collaboration, not, as some suggest, a betrayal, and that makes the author's naive whoppers about her subject's confidence all the more charming, even endearing. Thank heavens Monica Crowley is a relative innocent. An older pro would have inserted 18-minute gaps and But that would be wrong's. Even so, it's doubtful Nixon expected her to perform such editorial services. He was many things, but naive he wasn't. This remarkable book is an act of catharsis, not hubris, Richard Nixon's final apologia. Tough as he was on everyone else, he was always toughest on himself.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Firms Look for Lawyers Who Arrive With Clients

BYLINE: By BARBARA B. BUCHHOLZ 

 BODY:
IN 1993, eight years out of law school, Douglas Skalka began to enjoy the fruits of his hard work.
A recently minted partner in the Greenwich, Conn., office of Whitman & Ransom, Mr. Skalka was given an enviable option when his firm, which is based in New York, merged with another New York legal giant, Breed, Abbott & Morgan. He had to choose the New York or Connecticut office, and he chose Greenwich. 
 Two years later, though, the partners voted to dissolve the Greenwich office. "I went from having to make a choice to not being wanted by either office," Mr. Skalka said. To top it off, his wife, Susan, had recently stopped working as a marketing representative at I.B.M. to care for their infant twin daughters.
After polishing his resume, he began a job search, but one question kept popping up: How much business -- or, as lawyers put it, "portable billings" -- could he bring with him?
Mr. Skalka's reply: "Not much."
His predicament has become common in the last decade or so. Law firms once assigned the same salaries to partners at the same level, but they eliminated this lockstep compensation in the late 1970's, intending to spur new business, shed deadwood, respond to client pressures on fees and increase revenues.
But this new order widened the gap between partners who generated much business and those who drew little, and this in turn made firms less stable. Partners with significant business became the equivalent of free agents in sports. Switching firms, once rare, became commonplace, and departments and offices sometimes moved en masse.
"The legal marketplace became a frictionless plane with few bonds holding anybody, anywhere," said Joel F. Henning, a consultant at Hildebrandt Inc. in Somerville, N.J.
Mr. Skalka was not among those who could switch easily. Though he billed a healthy 1,900 to 2,000 hours a year and was responsible for several high-profile bankruptcy cases, he worked mostly for other partners or for clients that had a long relationship with the firm. Thus he received no credit for originating business and had little possibility of taking clients with him.
"Anybody my age and 10 years out probably was more involved in carrying someone else's bags and developing their legal rather than business-getting skills," Mr. Skalka, who is 36, said. "Most firms I interviewed weren't willing to take a chance with someone who had the potential to develop business. They wanted to see numbers."
After a four-month search, the New Haven firm of Neubert, Pepe & Monteith offered him a job. "Although a large firm might have viewed his contacts as insignificant, we didn't," said Greg Pepe of the three-year-old, three-partner firm. "They dovetailed nicely with our transactions and litigation practices. Doug estimated he might generate $350,000, but did $500,000."
As many partners change firms, client loyalty often shifts to individual lawyers. When Bruce Meckler left Pope & John Ltd. in Chicago to form Bates Meckler Bulger & Tilson in February 1994, he took along clients like Tri-City Brokerage Inc., a commercial wholesale insurer in San Francisco.
"Our relationship with Pope & John primarily was Bruce," said Dan Real, a Tri-City executive vice president. "We had confidence in him. We also had spent time educating him and his lawyers about our practices, which isn't easy to transfer."
Because of this kind of loyalty, firms have sought partners from other firms, or "lateral" partners, who could bring immediate business and keep their other lawyers busy, particularly as legal work slowed in the late 1980's with the recession, the real estate crash and companies taking work in-house. "Many firms considered lateral partners the white knights who would save them," said David Maister, a consultant in Boston.
Today, lawyers with significant billings are more desirable than ever. The New York firm of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein eagerly hired Larry Rodman to obtain $750,000 to $1 million in securities and real estate work that he offered after practicing at Teitlebaum, Hiller, Rodman, Paden & Hibsher, also in New York.
The same climate has, with few exceptions, made switching tougher for partners without business. And the billings threshold that is needed to change firms is soaring. "The price of admission has gone up," said Tom Clay, a consultant at Altman, Weil & Pensa in Newtown Square, Pa.
While many firms and recruiters are reluctant to cite figures, $500,000 to $750,000 in portable billings for a midsize firm (50 to 100 lawyers) and $1 million to $1.5 million for a larger firm are in the ball park, said Laura Hagen, a recruiter at the Chicago office of Major, Hagen & Africa, a legal search firm.
The billings are linked to a lawyer's desired income. For example, if the lawyer's target income is $500,000 or more, the partner will have to have a couple of million dollars in billings, said Lynn Mestel, a New York recruiter.
Still, a single magic number will not provide an automatic open-sesame. Firms are putting newly hired lawyers under more intense scrutiny, after being burned by some firm-switchers' overly optimistic assessments and by the high cost to service certain clients.
"Many partners don't deliberately misrepresent what they have, but often it's based on prior years and they can't know what will follow," said Marty Fay Africa, a recruiter with Major, Hagen & Africa's San Francisco office.
Many firms are structuring new partners' earnings based on incentives akin to deals for sports stars. "We may set a lower base and if the person brings in the business, they get a bonus," said Lee Miller, managing partner of Chicago's Rudnick & Wolfe.
All this is causing ripples at law firms, prompting partners to guard their clients or share work only with associates.
"At my former firm, there were some jealous partners who didn't want you to phone their clients when you worked on a matter," said Mike Mueller, who switched to Much Shelist Freed Denenberg Ament Bell & Rubenstein in Chicago from the larger firm of Keck, Mahin & Cate. "There were also ones who, when you achieved a good result, they made the congratulatory call." At the associate level, getting business has become another factor in whether a person becomes a partner.
So what happens to law partners without clients? "They can stay where they are and hope they get work from colleagues, though their situation is precarious because of younger lawyers who bill at lower rates," Ms. Hagen said.
"Or, they may have to alter their goals," said John Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement firm. "We can place people, but it may not be at a comparable job."
Some are lucky, as one securities partner, Mike Gamsky, was when he was hired by Much Shelist a year ago. Though he wasn't thinking of leaving his firm, Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, Mr. Gamsky listened when a headhunter called. "It was a rare chance to move without business because the firm had the work," he said.
Mr. Henning offers this caveat to managing partners: "He who lives by the sword dies by the sword. The partner who will come to your firm for an extra $25,000 will leave your firm for another $25,000 to $30,000."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas Skalka landed a job with a small firm in New Haven after other firms with which he interviewed sought lawyers who could bring higher billings with them. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: The Frogs (and Spools) of Windham Bridge

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
MORE than 200 years ago Colonists ridiculed the people of Windham because they had been frightened by bullfrogs in the night. Now Windham -- and the frogs -- could have the last laugh.
The town has asked the State Department of Transportation to place four bronze frogs on a new bridge in the Willimantic section of town, to pay tribute to a local legend. The amphibians would tower over traffic from a height of more than 20 feet, from atop giant spools of thread. But that's another story. 
 "If it works out the way we think it will, the bridge will become something of a tourist attraction in its own right," said David E. Philips, a retired history professor turned professional storyteller, and chairman of the Windham Planning Commission.
Margaret P. Reich, executive director of the Windham Regional Planning Agency and one of the chief proponents of the project, said the community wants to avoid having what one critic called an "I-beam I-sore" type of bridge similar to the one constructed recently in nearby Norwich.
"We're not picking on that designer. He designed a functional bridge that filled a purpose, but it's ugly, and it's not pedestrian friendly, and it doesn't fit in the community," Ms. Reich said.
Years ago the state tried to give its bridges character, she noted. The Merritt Parkway, for instance, boasts a series of spans that were designed for specific settings.
"They're conversation pieces, they're art -- but they're also functional bridges," Ms. Reich said. "That's what we want here."
And she agreed it could become quite an attraction, as the state begins construction of a Heritage Corridor Park just downstream. People collect cows and pigs, she noted, "but frogs have a big following, too."
Although the town has not filed a formal request for the bridge adornments, it has discussed the matter informally with the department, and begun raising the $80,000 needed to commission the statues from the sculptor, Leo Jensen of Essex.
Arthur F. Butzgy, design engineer for the Transportation Department, said there was nothing in state regulations to prohibit that kind of decoration, and that the designer would incorporate bases for the statuary.
"We can't do the whole thing as part of our project," Mr. Butzgy said. "However, there's no reason the local community can't do it, and we would be happy to accommodate it."
The bridge project will go out to bid next year, and is expected to cost about $14 million. It will consist of four lanes, two in each direction, including two left-turn-only lanes, and will run from Jackson Street on one side of the Willimantic River, to South Street on the other.
Town leaders have been lobbying the state for a new bridge for many years, deeming the two bridges currently connecting the north and south ends of town inadequate.
The bridge at Jillson Hill, which runs through the middle of the old American Thread Company property, was built more than a century ago. It is just 22 feet wide, with an 11-foot, 6-inch underpass at the south end that frequently snags unsuspecting truckers. The Bridge Street bridge is even older, built in 1868. Both spans have to be closed in heavy rain because of fear that the water will rip them away, which means Route 32, one of the major north-south roads in the eastern part of the state, is impassable. William H. Grover, a partner in Centerbrook Architects in Essex, was called on to design the bridge. Residents were intrigued with his first proposal. It was largely Victorian in nature, reflecting the fact that Willimantic has one of the heaviest concentrations of intact Victorian architecture in the country. And he suggested giant spools mounted at each approach to the bridge, reflecting Willimantic's once being known as Thread City, and the American Thread Company's producing some of the finest thread in the world.
But Mr. Philips wanted to take it one step further, to frogs. His 1984 book, "Legendary Connecticut," documents almost 250 legends from around the state. No. 52 is the Windham Frog Fight.
On a June night in 1754 the residents of Windham Center were awakened by a tremendous ruckus. They rushed outside, some screaming, some running for their lives, others firing guns into the darkness. When morning came it was discovered that the noise was bullfrogs fighting over the last drops of water in a pond that had dried up in that rainless year.
"You have to put it in the context of the time," Mr. Philips said. "It was a very scary time. The French and Indian War was still on, and some people thought the French and Indians were around. And then there were Puritans in the area who were predicting the end of the world anyway, and when they heard this noise they were sure the end had arrived."
The townspeople were held up as the butt of jokes, but they refused to slink off in shame. The old Windham Bank soon issued currency with frogs on it. Residents wrote poems of the battle, produced an operetta -- "The Frogs of Windham" -- that has survived 100 years. Frogs became part of the official town seal, and the high school ring.
Mr. Grover said he agreed to the idea because he saw it was an important part of local history. "Progress cannot be measured simply by the number of lanes on a new bridge," Mr. Grover said. "People want it to 'fit' with a community."
But, he said, the state often does not have the option. "The D.O.T. gets jumped on by the community if they try to make a bridge too utilitarian, and by the media if they try to make it look nice," Mr. Grover said.
He got in touch with Mr. Jensen, a friend, who was also intrigued by the project. "I'm usually asked to do generals and politicians and the like, so I was really interested," Mr. Jensen said. "A big problem I had was, frogs are always seen from the top. A frog doesn't look like much from the bottom -- it looks like a beanbag."
He made a quarter-scale wooden model of his proposed design, with the frog perched lazily atop the spool of thread, one foot hanging down, the other knee bent and poked high into the air. The plan is for the frogs to be eight feet, nose to tail, sprawled on eight-foot spools, set on seven-foot piers.
"Just the body of the frog will be as big as a Volkswagen Beetle," Mr. Jensen said. "It's going to be a couple of tons of bronze on each spool."
The 14-inch-diameter eyes will be gilded, and reflect movement down on the street, so they look almost alive.
He has begun casting four-foot models at Cavalier Renaissance Foundry in Bridgeport for garden sculptures. The first one went to a home not in Windham, but distant Guilford.
"The interest in this has been amazing -- people from as far away as Newtown have called about it," Mr. Jensen said. "This is going to be something unique."
The frogs look pretty nonchalant, as though gazing into the distance for a fly, lacking the energy to actually go off in search of food.
"They're not real serious frogs," Mr. Grover said. "It's clear they're meant to be fun."
Residents are having a good time with the project as well. Ms. Reich said someone came back from Serbia with a travel guide that tells of a bridge with dragons on each end that are supposed to wag their tails when a virgin walks over it. "We'd like to create a similar urban legend, but with frogs -- and probably not involving virgins," she said.
But it is also a serious project, they say. "It's art and it's history rolled into one -- it's not 36 rocks lined up in a row. It's not forced," Ms. Reich said.
Laura Weir Clarke, executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, applauded the effort to integrate local history into the bridge project.
"What this bridge in Willimantic does is show that for a very tiny percentage of the budget, a bridge can be constructed that will add to the community, rather than detract from it," Ms. Clarke said.
She said it's a false, near-term economy to cut corners on appearances. She cited the case of the bridge over Lake Whitney in Hamden near the trust's headquarters, a circa-1930 concrete structure that had weathered into something that looked like old rock, and fit the landscape perfectly.
"What they were replaced with is out of scale with the landscape, and ugly," Ms. Clarke said. "It certainly means the traffic flows more smoothly, but the loss of beauty in the landscape in astonishing."
"In a small, historic town, to create a modern highway bridge is an insult," Ms. Clarke said. "The fight to save $100,000 now will be completely meaningless even 10 years from now. What will be left is what people see as they drive over it."

(George Ruhe for The New York Times) (pg. 6)

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2467 words

HEADLINE: What's the Catch?

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The fishing life, for better or worse, is not what it used to be.
In his 33 years on the waters off New Jersey, Richie Isaksen has dragged a net outside the Ambrose Channel for fluke and trawled for whiting and porgy. Now, faced with restrictions on those species, he has become a lobsterman. 
 But this been the worst summer for lobster that Mr. Isaksen has ever seen. On recent mornings, he has steered his 48-foot boat home to the worn docks of the Belford Seafood Cooperative with loads of 22, 25 and 30 pounds.
"We haven't made no money in two-and-a-half months," Mr. Isaksen said. "A lot of nights you sit and think, if they don't come in, what am I going to do then?"
Five miles down Raritan Bay, out by the brand new James T. White clam depuration plant in Highlands, the scene was considerably more cheerful. The surf behind Doris and Ed's restaurant was thick with soft-shelled clams, and nearly as thick with Hartsgroves. Eight of them, spanning three generations, stood waist-deep in the water. All except 9-year-old Troy Jr. were jigging cross-shaped hoes up and down like pogo sticks in the sandy muck, then scooping out basket after basket of blue-gray steamers.
Troy Hartsgrove Sr. emptied his metal basket into a bushel bag and said: "That's 35 bucks right there. Ten minutes."
To get a really good idea of the ups and downs of fishing in New Jersey today, though, talk to John Vona. He stood on the deck of the Crystal Ann at the dock outside a Cape May packing house as 90,000 pounds of squid were pumped out of the hold of his boat. As he watched countless limp white bodies fly up the conveyor belt to workers who would sort the $12,000, one-day haul into 22-pound boxes, Mr. Vona seemed decidedly underwhelmed.
"I'd rather be fluking," he said, sounding a little bit like a bumper sticker.
New Jersey's 300-year-old commercial fishing industry has been utterly transformed in recent years. Traditional in-shore fisheries like the ones Mr. Isaksen and his fellow Belford fishermen grew up in -- fluke, weakfish, porgy -- are either so depleted or so heavily regulated, or both, that it has become nearly impossible to make a decent living in them. Now bigger boats, like Mr. Vona's, venture 60 or 80 or 100 miles out to sea and gather up enormous quantities of squid or ocean quahog -- a jumbo clam used exclusively by canners and other processors -- or hundreds of miles out for mackerel.
The result is this: In the last five years, notwithstanding over-fished stocks, government quotas, creeping coastal development and increasing political pressure from environmental groups and the recreational fishing industry, New Jersey's 1,800-plus commercial fishing boats have caught more seafood, more consistently, than at any time since the early 1960's. More than 177 million pounds of fish and shellfish landed here last year, enough to make the state with the puny 127-mile coastline the country's ninth biggest seafood producer.
The value of the catch has risen steadily, too. Measured in constant dollars, the catch for the last few years has brought more money at the dock -- $95.3 million dollars in 1995 -- than at any time since World War II. With processing, retail sales and other multiplying effects taken into account, commercial fishing is now estimated to be worth about $600 million a year to the state's economy.
But this picture of growth is misleading. According to a report prepared by Rutgers University for the state Department of Agriculture last year, almost all the increase in catch has been in lower-priced species, while catches of high-value fish have declined. Menhaden or bunker, a bait fish that by itself accounted for the majority of the fin fish that landed here last year, is worth about five cents a pound. Atlantic mackerel, which has replaced fluke (about $1.50 a pound) and whiting as the state's leading edible fish, brought in about 12 cents a pound last year.
In 1993, according to the National Marine Fisheries Service, 80 percent of the nation's ocean quahogs (37 cents a pound that year), two-thirds of its surf clams (45 cents), a third of its squid (30 cents a pound then, now down to 12), and a quarter of its Atlantic mackerel (8 cents) landed in New Jersey. The state has become a leader in volume fishing.
Of course, it's nice to be a leader in something. Employment in the fishing industry has been stable at about 2,700 jobs for at least five years, according to the Department of Agriculture. The depression and massive unemployment found in former New England cod capitals or defunct salmon ports in the Northwest is not seen here.
And New Jersey has made the shift to a bulk-based seafood economy without becoming dominated by corporate fleets.
"You sort of can't call a 100-foot dragger with chilling capacity mom and pop, but that's what it is," said Nils Stolpe, executive director of the New Jersey Seafood Harvesters Association, referring to boats like Mr. Vona's. "It's family owned, family operated. People have grown up from smaller boats to bigger boats."
Nevertheless, though the fisherman may still be master of his own vessel, he is hardly master of his fate these days.
"It used to be," Mr. Stolpe said, "that a guy could go out and fish the kind of boat he wanted to fish, and fish the way he wanted to fish, and come back in, and make a good solid living. Today, they have to work harder, more hours, in ways they'd rather not work, in fisheries they'd rather not be fishing in, and probably get a lot less return on their investment."
More than 100 species of marketable seafood thrive in the waters off New Jersey, from scallops and sea bass to black drum, black whiting, cunner, cusk, John Dory, northern puffer, ocean pout, pigfish, porbeagle shark, smooth and spiny dogfish, spot and triggerfish.
But some fish are more popular than others, and fishermen -- whether foreign or domestic, commercial or recreational -- have over-harvested them. Since the late 1970's, the Federal and state governments, advised by regional management councils, have imposed strict limits on when, where, how much and what size fish may be caught, as well as on who may catch them and what gear they may use.
Some of these management plans have not worked, and others are still in their infancy. According to the Rutgers report to the state, of 32 main Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic commercial species, 24 are either over-fished or at their limit.
The eight species classified as "underexploited" -- skate, dogfish, squid and mackerel, among others -- do not fetch high prices (that is why they are underexploited). "Nevertheless," the report states, "it is likely that these will serve as the only available avenue for the growth/stability of state and regional fisheries for the rest of this century."
State agricultural officials are seeking new markets for these species at home and abroad. Linda O'Dierno, the state coordinator of fish and seafood development, was host to a delegation of fish buyers from China last year and led a trade mission there the year before.
The effort is paying off. Japan is New Jersey's biggest foreign customer, but local fishermen also send mackerel to Jamaica, skate wings to France, dogfish bellies to Germany, monkfish to Korea, squid to Spain and Italy and scallops to China. Much British fish and chips is made with New Jersey dogfish backs.
Persuading American consumers to take a chance on an unfamiliar fish is more difficult. "People are so into those same species -- flounder, fluke, swordfish," Ms. O'Dierno said. "It's a tough sell to get people to try different products." She recommends skate wings -- "the meat comes right off the bone and has a flavor like scallops" -- and red hake.
At Belford, the closest New Jersey port to Manhattan, some fishermen are doing more with less by selling their fish live. As the 57-foot steel dragger Nicole steamed into port on a recent afternoon, a Chinese immigrant who would not give his name was waiting at the dock beside a truck bearing the logo "Yuwah Seafood Corp., 29A Ludlow Street."
On board, the Nicole's mate, Robert Smith, reached into a tank full of water and filled several orange baskets with flapping, thrashing tautog, a big-headed, thick-lipped, snake-skinned fish well known to recreational anglers and often called blackfish.
As Mr. Smith handed the baskets up to the dock, the captain, Bern "Bobo" Yahara, took one handle and the man from Yuwah Seafood took the other, and together they walked back to the co-op's holding tanks, laughing and pausing every few steps to retrieve errant fish.
After inspection, the tautog were loaded into the truck, destined to spend the brief remainders of their lives swimming in aquariums in the windows of restaurants in Chinatown. Mr. Yahara would not say how much the man had paid but allowed that live tautog were worth a "few dollars a pound" more than dead ones, which sell for about $2.
A much more common sight, however, especially in bigger ports, is the fisherman's version of containerized shipping.
At Point Pleasant Packing in Point Pleasant Beach, the Debbie and Jeanette, a 110-foot clam dredger, arrives at the dock just before dawn from 70 miles offshore. A crane swings down into the hold and pulls up steel cages the size of household refrigerators, filled to bursting with quahogs. Each cage holds 32 bushels of clams, or about two tons. In a little more than an hour, 48 cages of clams are hauled out and raised by forklift onto tractor trailers bound for the Gorton's of Gloucester processing plant in Millville. By afternoon, the clams will have traded their shells for aluminum cans.
The owner of the Debbie and Jeanette sits in an office two hours south in Cape May, the largest of the state's six major fishing ports and the third highest-volume fishing port on the East Coast. Daniel Cohen, president of Atlantic Capes Fisheries, is one of the few people in the New Jersey fishing industry who controls more than a couple of boats. The company's nine vessels catch surf clams, quahogs, scallops, monkfish, squid, mackerel and butterfish.
Mr. Cohen, head of the Cape May Seafood Association, is also one of the few people in the industry who has anything nice to say about fishing quotas.
"Clams have come back," he said. "They went to a quota management system. and because of that, we've seen the resource rebound, the quotas increased. The government imposed major restrictions on fluke in 1991 and the resource has come back phenomenally. When we fish for them, we're catching so much so quickly."
But most fishermen are frustrated that they cannot catch the fish that are out there.
"This has been a really good year for weakfish, fluke, and bluefish and striped bass," said Mr. Stolpe of the state seafood association. "But striped bass are purely a recreational fish in New Jersey now, and the commercial fishermen in New Jersey are limited to 500 pounds of fluke on a trip."
In Belford, where fishermen have always relied on a mix of species finding their way into the nets, Richie Isaksen said the limits have been especially difficult to work around.
"When you're fishing a mixed trawl fishery," he said, "you catch whiting, squid, porgies, flounders, all in one net, and that's what makes your day. You get two or three boxes of flounders, they took them away. You catch some squid, and they took them away because the mesh size has to be bigger. So you got to deal with what you got left. But that two or three boxes of flounders or four or five boxes of squid, that was your day's work there."
When asked if they would want their young sons to follow them out to sea, Mr. Yahara and Mr. Smith of the Nicole differed only in their degree of pessimism.
"I wouldn't even let my kid down on the dock," Mr. Smith said. "I'd buy a boat tomorrow if I thought the industry was going to hold up, but it's a dying business."
Mr. Yahara said: "It's going to be up to him. I'll wait till he gets older and see if he likes working for nothing. If he does, I'll bring him on board."
Down behind the restaurant where the Hartsgrove clan was soft-clamming, though, Troy Hartsgrove Jr. was thrilled to be tagging along with the grownups, and they seemed happy to have him there, as long as he didn't wander into their clam trenches.
Monmouth County's in-shore fisheries for hard and soft clams (the soft shells are slightly crumbly, like limestone) have been revitalized in the past two years by the opening of clam purification plants in Highlands and Sea Bright that can process 360 bushels a day. (Hard clams, which are often eaten raw, and soft clams, which are often steamed, are separate from the industries in surf clams and ocean quahogs and command up to six times the price of those processing clams.)
Before the depuration plants were built, clammers had to take their catch about 50 miles down the coast to Barnegat Bay and bathe the clams in cleaner waters for 30 days to rinse out traces of coliform bacteria that are sometimes found near Sandy Hook.
Even better, improved sewage treatment in Monmouth County has elminated some of the need for purifying the clams: last week, the state ruled that clams in part of the Navesink River can be harvested right out of the water from November to April.
Reuben Hartsgrove Sr., 65, patriarch of the clan, a leather-faced man with forearms like Popeye's and a Marlboro permanently dangling from his lips, noted with deep satisfaction that this was the first time this particular clam bed had been dug in more than a decade.
"We had our eyes on these clams for two years!" he said.
As he scooped up another basket, he pronounced the future bright.
"There's plenty of seed out there," he said. "If they live, we'll do all right."
Most of Mr. Hartsgrove's colleagues in the fishing industry, though, are facing a difficult future. A new package of gear restrictions and size limits is due to be adopted by the end of the year, on crabbing in the Delaware Bay, on sea bass and porgy and tautog. The party and charter boat industry, which has seen its business fall by more than half since the early 1980's, has formed an aggressive new lobbying group, the Recreational Fishing Alliance, that turned out 2,800 anglers last year to block the reopening of commercial catches on striped bass.
None of which is enough to keep Joe Branin on dry land. Mr. Branin, a longtime Belford fluker, took over as manager of the Belford co-op's retail store last month and has spent most of his time since then trying to put the troubled store back on its feet. The other evening, though, as he packed the fish up in boxes and put them away, he had a thought.
"Think I'll go fishing Sunday night," he said. "They're starting to catch a few fish."

HEADLINE: Fitting the Mortgage to the Need

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
WHEN she first arrived from the Soviet Union seven years ago, Natalya Novikova cleaned other people's homes. Now she is president of a travel agency and owns her own $244,000 home in Brooklyn -- purchased with a mortgage that offers flexibility for even higher steps on America's ladder to success.
It was Mrs. Novikova who supported the family during those first years in the United States while her husband, Vlagimir, burrowed into his studies for re-certification as a medical doctor in their adopted country. The family came, Mrs. Novikova said, with traces of a newcomer's syntactical license, "because it is very difficult to live, Jewish people, in Russia." 
 "When I first come, I clean homes each day," Mrs. Novikova said. Then, for several years, she worked in a travel agency, learning the ropes. "Two years ago," she said, "I start my own business, Nataly's Travel, on Avenue U in Sheepshead Bay."
And now, with Dr. Novikova newly licensed and working two jobs (in a hospital and another doctor's office), the Novikovas are proud owners of a semi-attached, three-bedroom house on East 77th Street in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn.
They bought their house with a type of adjustable mortgage that holds the interest rate steady for the first five years, and then allows it to fluctuate. "Adjustable is good for us," Mrs. Novikova said of the deal she made with GFI Mortgage Bankers, "because I think we are going to move before five years. I am not going to be in my business my whole life. My husband will open a medical plaza, maybe on Long Island, and I will be the boss, like the manager."
Of their success and aspirations in a new land, Mrs. Novikova said, "It's just the American expression, meaning the grass is growing very fast on the other side."
The grass appears to be growing throughout the nation. The Novikovas, along with thousands of other first-time buyers and fence-straddlers who had been holding off on moving up to a better or larger house, are leaping into the market in growing numbers. And they are doing so by carefully calculating how long they are likely to stay in the house, and then selecting a mortgage suited to the calculation.
While the stable, standard 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage remains the dominant home-financing tool, more buyers than ever are choosing newer varieties of adjustable-rate mortgages that mesh a family's future with the promise of fixed-rate certainty for a set number of years, only then applying fluctuating rates. The adjustable loan gives them a lower interest rate initially, but is open to adjustment at specific intervals during the term of the loan.
For example, in the current market a borrower might pay about 8 percent in interest on a fixed-rate loan, but only about 7.5 percent for the first five years on a loan that adjusts every year thereafter.
On a $225,000 purchase with a $45,000, or 20 percent, down payment and a loan of $180,000, the monthly payment for a fixed-rate loan would be $1,321, But the rate for a loan with a fixed rate for only five years, adjusting each year thereafter, would be only $1,259, or $62 a month less. Because such a loan has both adjustable and fixed-rate features, it is sometimes called a hybrid adjustable.
Mortgage lenders point out that for younger buyers especially the difference of half a percentage point can be significant, making it possible for many to qualify for a mortgage and therefore buy a house that they might not otherwise be able to afford. "Many people's earnings are such that they need the lower payments," said William T. Schunk, president of National Standard Mortgage Corporation, a mortgage lender based in Tarrytown, N.Y.
THE downside is that once adjustments begin, they can be as large as 2 percentage points in a single year. The loans generally have an annual cap of 2 percentage points, and a total rate cap of 6 points over the initial rate. Adjustments can be of course in a downward direction at a time of falling interest rates. The term of the loan is normally 30 years.
"An older couple or people on a fixed income may not want to chance an adjustable-rate loan," said Thomas J. Riccobono, regional vice president of Intercounty Mortgage Inc., based in Westbury, L.I.
Mr. Riccobono also said that the typical first-time home buyer in the metropolitan area is making only a 5 to 10 percent down payment in their purchases, rather than the traditional 20 percent. "A minimum down payment is what most people want," he said.
Even some people who are refinancing their homes are choosing from the varied menu of adjustable mortgages. Among these are Marilyn and Richard Marcus. The Marcuses, who have lived on a tree-lined road in Scarsdale, N.Y., for eight years, recently refinanced with a mortgage that guarantees 10 years at a set rate before the adjustments start.
"Our kids are 7 and 15, and our long-range plan is to remain in Scarsdale, certainly through their education," Mrs. Marcus said. "So that's maybe 10 more years in the house."
The Novikovas and the Marcuses are participants in a gradually improving real estate market. Housing sales and starts were up in the first half of 1996, spurred, according to several market analysts, by relatively stable and still-manageable mortgage rates, a dose of consumer confidence and the leavening effect of those hybrid varieties of adjustable-rate mortgages.
"The residential market at this time is not really being driven by interest rate issues, because the rates are, in general, manageable," said Henry Wollman, director of the Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College. "So, as opposed to where we were during parts of the 80's when interest rates could be about 12 or 13 percent and still be considered favorable, in the current market, where rates are generally around 8 percent, the rate is not as formidable a factor in making a purchasing decision."
During the second quarter of this year, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board, the national average rate for a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage was 8.17 percent, an increase from 7.88 percent a year earlier and from 7.28 in January. The national average for all types of loans at the end of June was 7.77 percent, increasing from 7.61 percent in June 1995, after a drop to 7.17 percent in January.
(This and other surveys do not take into account whether the lenders are charging "points," or additional fees, at the closing. One point is one percent of the loan amount. If these fees are figured in, loan costs may actually be higher than the nominal interest rate makes them appear.)
While the Federal Housing Finance Board's numbers are for loans that were closed during the second quarter, HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J., surveys current rates offered by 2,500 lenders throughout the country. The HSH survey shows that the national average offering rate for a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage was 8.16 percent for the week that ended Aug. 16, down a bit from 8.2 percent a year earlier.
And in the metropolitan region, the HSH survey shows that, as of Aug. 16, the average rate being offered for a 30-year fixed mortgage was also 8.16 percent, up slightly from 8.13 the year before. HSH does not provide numbers that include all types of mortgages.
The relatively stable rates, said Walter Molony, a spokesman for the National Association of Realtors, are a key reason for a surge in home sales during the second quarter. And while sales are starting to ease off a bit, the association still expects this year to be the third best year for sales since it began keeping records in 1980. The projection for total sales, condominiums and co-ops included, is about 4.36 million for the year, which would be 3.2 percent above the total for 1995, Mr. Molony said.
"What we've had is kind of a fence-jumping effect," he said, "with people deciding to get into the market before rates move higher. And even though rates are up, they are still affordable in historic terms."
Much of the movement in the housing market, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, is coming from maturing baby boomers wanting to settle in for the long term. "So, if they find a house, they're going to make the move and they are not going to worry about a half-point on percentage rates," Dr. Hughes said.
The trend is mirrored, said Stanley Duobinis, director of forecasting for the National Association of Home Builders, by an orthodoxy-defying jump in housing starts.
"There is a connection, certainly, between the level of interest rates and the level of housing starts," Mr. Duobinis said. "The rule of thumb we use is that, if other things are unchanged, a 1 percent increase in interest rates will decrease housing starts across the country by 50,000."
Yet, even though interest rates rose by about 1 percentage point since the start of this year (while trailing off a bit in recent weeks), housing starts have thumbed a nose at the rule.
Single-family housing starts over the nation through May of this year, as measured by building permits granted, are up 18 percent over last year, with 453,800 starts this year compared with 384,400 last year, Mr. Duobinis said. The reasons are a stronger economy, rising consumer confidence and the availability of various types of mortgages suitable for a range of buyers, he said.
NOWADAYS, within the categories of standard residential mortgages -- fixed-rate, adjustable and hybrids -- the borrower finds certain standard variations. Fixed-rate loans generally run for 30-year or 15-year terms. The shorter the term, the higher the monthly payments. (As in all home mortgages, interest payments are tax deductible, although there have been periodic calls to restrict this benefit.)
Standard adjustable-rate mortgages offer a lower interest rate during the first year, as a kind of come-on, and rates that vary according to a set schedule in each of the remaining years of the term. The most common adjustable-rate mortgage by far is referred to as a 1/1 ARM, signifying that switch from the low, initial rate in the first year to a new rate each subsequent year. Nowadays the initial rate offered is about 6 percent, with no points.
In the hybrid variety, the initial rate is fixed for a set number of years. The most common are those that run for three, five, seven or ten years at a fixed rate, and then adjust each year during the remaining years of the 30-year term.
The Novikovas, for example, took a "5/1 hybrid ARM" on their $424,000 house, making a $25,000 down payment and paying off the principal, or the remaining amount owed, at 7.25 percent for the first five years. "It's good for me to take adjustable mortgage because my business is going to grow up and now I cannot afford a regular mortgage because my husband just start working as a doctor," Mrs. Novikova said.
For adjustable mortgages, when the annual adjustments begin to kick in, rates are usually based on the yield from a one-year Treasury note, with a profit margin tacked on. "That yield plus margin equals your new interest," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates.
Each lender sets the margin, but the most common is 2.75 percentage points. "So, if you started at 5 percent for the first year and the Treasury yield is at 6 percent, the lender can add 2.75 percentage points to arrive at the new interest -- 8.75 percent," Mr. Gumbinger said.
Buying a house is, for most people, the major financial decision of a lifetime. The experience can be fraught with anxiety, uncertainty and unexpected delays.
"The document assembly process is extraordinary," said one recent buyer, who did not want to be identified. "You have to be prepared to explain every transaction in any bank account, any financial account, your credit history -- if you paid on time, any defaults. It's like having someone look into your soul to see if you're credit worthy."
Joseph Bryant, executive vice president and chief mortgage officer for the Long Island Savings Bank, remarked that in some respects the mortgage industry is "still in the 19th century because we do things by the pound -- the loan application has to be two pounds before we will approve it."
"How is it," Mr. Bryant wondered, "that someone can go into a car dealership and buy or lease, let's say, a new Mercedes, title the car, insure the car, finance the car and drive it out within three hours, when a home purchase of a similar price takes 45 days to do the same thing? It doesn't make sense, and it drives everyone -- including employees of the mortgage company -- nuts."
And for those who are numerophobic, all those charts and tables, interest rates and points, can seem like a jumbled spool of data, when it is actually more like a series of push-pull strands. Among the trade-offs, for example, are these:
The more stability the buyer wants in the interest rate, the higher the rate is likely to be. In pricing -- meaning the combination of rates and points to be paid -- the fewer points the buyer can afford to pay initially, the higher the interest rate will be. Points are, effectively, a prepayment of interest, and therefore lower the interest rate.
Another trade-off is that the higher the down payment, the lower the monthly payment. But a countering trade-off is that one may wish to make a lower down payment and use some of the money saved for furnishings, or, perhaps, an emergency reserve.
Some hope for more effectively weighing all those trade-offs, as well as cutting through the often harrowing process of proving you are qualified for the loan, may be in the offing. Mr. Bryant of Long Island Savings Bank said that computer technology was coming to the market that allows a quick loan decision.
"We've had these programs for about six months," Mr. Bryant said, "and the best we have done to date, from time of loan application to approval, has been three days."
But computers or not, it is after juggling all those factors -- and, particularly, of course, the mesh between current interest rates and their effect on long-term family plans -- that buyers turn toward adjustable-rate mortgages.
ACCORDING to the Federal Housing Finance Board, 81 percent of all mortgages closed in the last quarter of 1993 were fixed-rate, while 19 percent were one variety of adjustable or another. At the end of the second quarter of this year, however, 72.6 percent were fixed-rate and the adjustable share had increased to 27.4 percent.
Joseph McKenzie, director of financial research for the housing finance board, said that the ARM share of the market has always been volatile. "When interest rates start rising, more and more consumers elect ARMs," Mr. McKenzie said.
And certain varieties of ARMs have particularly increased in popularity in recent years, he said. The three-year hybrid has gone from 1 percent of the ARMs market in 1993 to 8 percent in the second quarter of this year; the five-year hybrid has gone from 2.1 percent in 1993 to 18.6 percent in the last quarter.
"Definitely, the trend is for people to think precisely about how long they will keep their mortgage," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a Manhattan firm. "I would say that probably 75 percent of my mortgages are hybrids now, and three years ago it was probably 35 percent."
"Statistically, people stay in their home six or seven years," Ms. Scott said. "And when they buy, it's like opening a door: they think about going in a given direction, usually toward a 30-year fixed. But, if pressed, they will tell you it's going to be five years or seven years, and they can buy one of these hybrids."
The Marcuses went through that mental process. Mrs. Marcus, a lawyer, said she and her husband bought their five-bedroom, 4,500-square-foot Scarsdale home in 1988. She would not say how much they paid.
"We refinanced six months ago," Mrs. Marcus said. "We had taken out a mortgage, and also an equity line, which we used for business purposes. And the rate of interest and the equity line were higher than what the market was offering for a new mortgage.
"So what we did was wrap what was left on the mortgage and the equity line into a new mortgage, and we have been able to save a great deal of money each month."
With the children expected to be either in college or out on their own in 10 years, the Marcuses decided on a 10-year hybrid adjustable loan from the Poughkeepsie Savings Bank. "The rate was much better than the 30-year fixed," Mrs. Marcus said. "I don't remember what the 30-year fixed was at the time, but the 10/1 was just under 7 percent."
And what will they do in 10 years?
"Probably, we would be ready to move on," Mrs. Marcus said. "But who knows?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Low Down Payments Luring Renters to Ownership

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
THE scarcity and high cost of rentals in both Nassau and Suffolk, along with mortgage programs that allow buyers to purchase a house with a low cash outlay, is turning many renters into home buyers.
Shaun and Kathline Malone, for example, expect to move into their three-bedroom town house in the Meadows at Huntington Village development by the end of October. They are currently renting a one-bedroom apartment nearby for $850 a month, but they want something larger. Married in January, they are first-time buyers. 
 Their mortgage payments on the $196,000 house, on which they are getting 90 percent financing, will be $1,800 monthly, including taxes, said Mr. Malone, a lawyer who works in Manhattan. A three-bedroom apartment outside the complex would cost between $1,500 and $2,000, he noted, "so we are much better off buying something."
The Meadows, which opened for sales in July and now has all but three of 16 town houses sold, is being developed by Meadowood Properties of Islandia, which perceived a niche in the Huntington market for attached housing that sells below $200,000 and therefore can compete with nearby rentals.
"People want to stop the bloodbath of paying high rent and invest in their own homes," said James L. Neisloss, who is developing the Meadows with a partner, Donald S. Partrick.
To keep common charges as low as possible (each unit pays $110 monthly for those charges, plus $5,400 a year in taxes), the partners decided not to build any recreational facilities.
Prices for the town houses, which range in size from 1,740 square feet to 1,900 square feet, plus basement and a one-car garage, range from $189,990 to $196,990.
The Malones elected to make a 10 percent, $19,000 down payment, but down payments as low as 3 percent are allowed by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), which buys mortgages on the secondary market from lenders. Fannie Mae has a $207,000 mortgage limit on a single-family house.
Government-insured Federal Housing Administration loans are also available with only 3 percent down. Their advantage is that credit qualifications are somewhat less stringent than those of Fannie Mae loans. However, the F.H.A. loan limit in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for a one-family house is $155,250.
Under a State of York Mortgage Agency (Sonyma) loan program available for new houses called the Construction Incentive Program, purchasers can buy a house with no down payment. The only cash outlay is the buyer's closing costs. However, funding this year will result in only about 1,000 mortgages, said a Sonyma spokeswoman.
The initiative received a $100 million appropriation in March. It is designed to stimulate the construction of housing affordable to first-time low- and moderate-income buyers. The allocation has already resulted in statewide sales or contracts on 850 houses. The program, which was first introduced in 1994, is financed through the sale of tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds.
Interest rates currently are 5.5 percent for the first four years of a 30-year loan, and they step up to 7.5 percent for the remaining life of the mortgage.
In Nassau and Suffolk, the income limit for households of one or two persons is $63,000; households of three or more can earn up to $72,560. House prices in both Nassau and Suffolk cannot exceed $156,600. Guidelines are more liberal in special areas targeted for economic development programs; existing two-family houses in those areas can also be purchased.
IN all cases where down payments are under 20 percent, buyers pay a monthly mortgage insurance premium that ranges from 0.75 to 1 percent of the loan amount.
"Some people are aware of these programs, but many people are not," said Mark W. McAfee, group vice president of the residential mortgage division of EAB, a Uniondale bank.
Like many lenders on Long Island, EAB holds regular free home-buying seminars to educate would-be buyers. Residential First, the mortgage arm of the Roslyn Savings Bank, is also active in consumer-education programs. In addition, counseling is available through the Long Island Housing Partnership, based in Hauppauge.
Structural Technology, a developer with offices in Shirley, began using the Sonyma program in March at its 163-unit Village Green at Baiting Hollow development, where detached houses on 0.75-acre lots sell in the $134,900 to $179,900 price range.
It also has projects in Manorville and Center Moriches that qualify for the state loan program, said Chris Calderone, the sales director.
For a 1,250-square-foot, three-bedroom ranch with a basement and a one-car garage selling for $134,900 in the Baiting Hollow project, a buyer would need about $4,000 to close, he said. The $134,900 mortgage at 5.5 percent interest would cost $767 monthly for the first four years and $943 monthly thereafter. Taxes and private mortgage insurance add about $300 a month.
Joseph and Barbara Tuccio just moved into their three-bedroom contemporary at the development from a rental in Rocky Point. They paid $151,000 for the house. Although they took out a Sonyma mortgage, they elected to pay 3 percent down, which with closing costs brought their cash requirement to about $9,500, Mr. Tuccio said.
Their monthly costs including taxes will be $1,300. But in Rocky Point they would have had to pay at least $850 just for a two-bedroom apartment, said Mr. Tuccio, who is a mechanical engineer.
In some cases, developers are further assisting buyers by paying some of their closing costs.
At the 487-unit Park Row town-house complex in Central Islip, a homeowners' association where prices range from $143,990 to $179,990, the buyer of the $143,990 unit can move in with around $7,000 in cash, which would include a 3 percent down payment, said Meri Hartig, the sales manager.
The developer, the F.N. Development Company of Irvine, Calif., pays 3 percent of the purchase price toward closing costs -- in the case of the $143,990 unit, about $7,000. With only $2,700 needed for closing and $4,320 for the down payment, the buyer's cash outlay comes to $7,020, Ms. Hartig said.
Monthly costs are $1,400 based on a real estate tax abatement program currently in effect. As of Wednesday, seven houses were still available under the program.
AT the Silver Ponds town-house development in Manorville, 241 units have been built and sold and 125 are planned or under construction. The Silver Ponds Townhouse Corporation of Manorville is paying about $4,000 worth of closing costs for buyers purchasing houses in the current 24-unit phase under construction. Sixteen houses remain to be sold.
Not covered are such items as points, the homeowner's cost of title insurance and the fee charged by the buyer's lawyer.
With a 3 percent down payment, buyers need about $5,000 cash to purchase a $119,990 two-bedroom, 1,280-square-foot town house with a one-car garage, said Stephen R. Cody, director of operations for the developer. Payments of $1,300 a month, which include $3,090 in annual taxes, allow families with a $45,000 annual income to qualify, he said.
The F.H.A. allows sellers to finance some of the closing costs, as does Fannie Mae. The F.H.A. also allows some of the buyer's closing costs and an upfront mortgage insurance premium to be financed as part of the mortgage loan.
St. James Partners, a development group with offices in St. James, which builds houses on scattered lots in Wyandanch, pays up to $6,000 of a buyer's closing costs. Its houses range in price from $133,000 for a 1,150-square-foot three-bedroom ranch to $152,000 for a high ranch with 2,200 square feet and up to six bedrooms.
"If you can come up with a program under which people who pay $1,100 to $1,200 monthly to rent need no more in cash to buy as they would for security and rent, they will choose to buy," said Douglas Rotondi, one of the principals of the company.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
How Much Is Too Much in Retail-Rich Paramus?

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
A HUNDRED new retail outlets have opened or will soon open at the expanded Garden State Plaza in Paramus, which at 2 million square feet is among the largest malls on the East Coast.
Two anchors, Neiman Marcus and Lord & Taylor, opened earlier this month at the 700,000-square-foot, $240-million addition to the mall at Routes 4 and 17. This represents a significant increase to mall space in this Bergen County suburb, which has five malls totaling some 5 million square feet and myriad retail strips along the two highways. So how much is enough retail in Paramus? 
 "There has to be a point of no return," said Ted Kraus, who runs a real estate consulting firm in Mercerville, "But no one knows when it will be reached."
Apparently so. Two dormant or underdeveloped sites along Route 17 are being turned into more retail use or are in the planning stage for it. A third site has been purchased by a developer and the almost sure bet is that it will sprout retail, too, according to brokers, lawyers and industry experts. Collectively the sites could generate about 540,000 square feet of retail space.
They are occupied or were recently occupied by some of the last family-run businesses on the highway. When developed they would all but shut down such enterprises on the borough's major arteries.
"Most of the changeover is use-driven, the real estate is too valuable," said Stuart Liebman, a partner at the law firm of Wells, Jaworski, Liebman & Paton in Paramus. His firm represented the families in the lease or sale of their property.
One of the sites is occupied by the four-acre Bergen Bluestone Company site at Midland Avenue and northbound Route 17, where operations of the fourth-generation stone retailing and contracting business are winding down to make way for a 43,000-square-foot Office Depot outlet.
The other is the former 15-acre Faber Block and Cement site at the northbound entrance to Garden State Parkway on Route 17, which closed in the late 80's after being used to manufacture and sell bricks for four decades. The dormant site and five adjacent acres once owned by Faber and occupied by stores is now owned by Gabrellian Associates, a local developer.
Mr. Gabrellian said no plans had yet been made for the 20 acres. Current zoning would permit 150,000 square feet of retail space.
A third site is 40 acres occupied by the vacant Alexander's department store at the intersection of Routes 4 and 17 opposite Garden State Plaza. Several plans advanced in the last few years call for replacing the 350,000-square-foot building with a cluster of smaller retail structures.
The number of buildings and total amount of space has not been determined, though it will be more than the existing building, said Thomas Wells, the lawyer representing Alexander's. Up to 700,000 square feet of space is permitted under current zoning, he noted.
Progress on the site's redevelopment has been slowed by a $115-million road improvement project planned by the state's Transportation Department for the interchange at Routes 4 and 17, which requires about 10 acres of the Alexander's site. Mr. Wells said he was hopeful that negotiations with the state would be completed this year and that other state and local approvals needed for the project would quickly follow.
In most surveys of New Jersey's highway retail corridors Routes 4 and 17 in Paramus rank at or near the top in the state in terms of attracting retailers, despite the fact that the stores there are open only six days a week. Even in the wake of last year's wave of bankruptcy filings by retailers and weak consumer spending that hurt all markets, both did well.
IN a 1995 survey of the 10 major Northern and Central New Jersey corridors by R.J. Brunelli & Company, an Old Bridge-based retail brokerage, the vacancy rate in strip centers and free-standing stores along the entire 15-mile Route 17 corridor from Paramus to Mahwah was 4.6 percent. On a three-mile stretch of the Route 4 corridor from Paramus to Fair Lawn the rate was 6.8 percent.
Still, they were the second and fifth lowest, respectively, of the 10 corridors, where vacancies ranged from 3.8 percent on Route 18 in East Brunswick to 10.8 percent on Route 9 in central New Jersey.
The difference with the vacancies in Paramus, where the population swells during the day to 100,000 from 26,000, is that they do not last long. An example is the 40,000-square-foot Macy's furniture store on Route 4, which became available last year and created much of the corridor's vacancy.
It is now fully leased, reducing the rate to about 3 percent, said Richard Brunelli, president of the brokerage. He brokered a lease to Sneaker Stadium for half the building.
The key to this borough's appeal is demographics. For retailers who generally look at a five-mile trading area Paramus has some 525,343 people with an average household income of $55,820, Mr. Brunelli said. "Nowhere else in the state has that combination of income and tremendous population," he said.
Paramus, added Mr. Kraus, the Mercerville consultant, also attracts shoppers from Manhattan who are drawn by its accessibility and lower sales taxes.
But developers and retailers pay for those benefits. Land prices, which fell during the recession by 20 to 30 percent, have bounced back to $600,000 to $1 million an acre, said Michael N. Kasparian, a principal of Caspar Properties, a commercial real estate brokerage in Paramus. He said rents for blocks of retail space of 5,000 to 10,000 square feet range from $25 to $30 a square foot.
For Paramus, said Mayor Clifford Gennarelli, the taxes paid by the retail operations along Routes 4 and 17 make up 50 percent of the borough's tax base.
"What we do not want more of," he said, "is office buildings," explaining that they were a big contributor to the rush-hour traffic jams. The hope is that the road-improvement project at the Alexander's site, among other such projects, will help mitigate traffic problems.
The borough is also updating its master plan, including re-evaluating the zoning on sites at highway interchanges where retail use in prohibited in favor of offices. "The question now is whether to eliminate that zoning and let the market take its course," said Peter G. Steck, the borough's planning consultant. He said the market "seems to be pointing to big-box retailers and we want to evaluate if that is a healthy trend and if can do something about it."
While the heavy traffic is a bane to area residents it is a boon to retailers. National chains open stores on each highway or more than one store on the same highway, said Mr. Kasparian, pointing to Barnes & Noble, as an example.
It first opened a 17,000-square-foot store on Route 17 northbound just north of the Century Road interchange in early 1992. Two years later it opened a second, 40,000-square-foot store just north of Midland Avenue only to leave that space two years later to open a 60,000-square-foot store on Route 17 southbound just south of Linwood Avenue in the former Channel Home Center.
But while Barnes & Noble expands in the borough's retail hub, Bergen Bluestone is getting out of it.
"The economic realities are that the families see more income by leasing or selling their property than by operating their business on it," said Mr. Wells. He worked with the owners of Bergen Bluestone on an "over 50-year" lease of their four-acre site to Office Depot. It will be the third store in New Jersey for the chain, which is based in Del Ray Beach, Fla. The opening is set for late this year or early 1997, said Gary Schweikhart, a company spokesman.
Bluestone's president, Thomas C. Hansen, whose grandfather started Bergen Bluestone in 1932, said that no longer paid to be on what he called "the golden mile." Instead, he said he would continue to operate the business from a quarry site the family owns in Hancock, N.Y., and at a location elsewhere in the county, possibly on a less prominent part of Route 17.
"It is a tough chapter to close," he said, "but it is a good business deal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas C. Hansen of Bergen Bluestone is leaving a 4-acre site on Route 17 to lease it to an Office Depot store. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Japan's Lifetime Jobs: Foreigners Qualify, Too

BYLINE: By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IN a quiet change of culture, more Japanese companies have been extending to their foreign workers the special status of lifetime employment, which for the most part had been the exclusive right of Japanese-born employees for at least 30 years.
Media companies like NHK and Yomiuri Shimbun and giant corporations, including Mitsubishi, Nissho Iwai and Mitsui, are all adding foreigners to their permanent ranks. 
 "It's nice to know that I have my job next year and the year after that," said Joshua Adelstein, 27, an American reporter at Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest-circulation newspaper. "Job security provides an inner peace that many hours of meditation can't compete with."
Employment experts say Japanese companies have begun to embrace foreign workers as the companies increase their operations overseas and realize they need the skills and perspective of the foreigners to compete better around the world. Last year, the number of foreigners holding working visas was about 88,000, up from 30,000 in 1986, the Justice Ministry said.
"As firms shift their operations overseas more, realization spread that they must secure and deploy talents regardless of the citizenship," said Takanori Matsuura, a professor who specializes in corporate recruitment at Tama University.
In the 1970's, the Sony Corporation was a pioneer in having foreigners become lifetime employees. One of the first to obtain the status, an American, retired from Sony last year.
"We draw 80 percent of our revenue from our operations abroad, so it was a natural direction for us to follow," said Kazushi Anbe, manager of the overseas human resources division at Sony.
Yasuhiko Fujiki, director of recruitment at the Orix Corporation, a leasing company, has found many good international job candidates at Japanese universities. Last year, for the first time, the company offered lifetime positions to six foreign workers.
The new corporate attitudes also reflect an increasing mobility in Japan's work force. Young workers, for example, have been willing to walk away from their first jobs to seek better opportunities.
And while recent layoffs, during an economic downturn, have shown that many jobs are no longer guaranteed, winning lifetime status is still significant, experts said, because it can give foreigners increased opportunities for promotions.
Of course, not all foreign workers want to spend their lives with one company.
Irene Kuge, 27, a Japanese-American, joined Toyota Motor after graduating from UCLA in 1992. Two years later, Toyota made it clear she had a lifetime job.
Although Ms. Kuge said she liked the security, she and many foreign co-workers do not know if they will remain with the company. "It's not a huge consideration," she said, "because most of us don't know if we want to stay for life, and if we do, what will our opportunities in the company be?"
Sakie Fukushima, a partner at Korn/ Ferry International Japan, an executive search firm, expects the opportunities for foreign employees to keep improving, provided that Japanese attitudes toward the workers continue to change. She said she would not be surprised someday to see, for example, "a German national heading Mitsubishi Corporation."
"The question is: Is that going to happen 10 years, 20 years or 30 years from now?" she said. "I would like to think that manpower is an international resource that transcends national borders."
