HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
For These Democrats, It's Still the Economy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
NOW it is the Democrats' turn.
At the Democratic National Convention, which begins on Monday in Chicago, 120 delegates, plus 17 alternates, will represent New Jersey. State Democratic officials say the group reflects New Jersey's diverse population, with 28 black delegates, or 20 percent, and 19 Hispanic delegates, or 14 percent. And there is no gender gap in the Garden State group: 69 are women and 68 men. 
 The delegates come from many walks of life: law (17), labor (14), education (14) and health care (4). Five delegates described themselves as homemakers, one as a corporate executive and another as banker. Two, Brendan T. Byrne and Jim Florio, are former Governors. About 30 are current officeholders at the local, state or Federal level, including Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg.
"The whole message of the convention is going to be that we're the party of the mainstream," said Regan McGrory, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Democratic Committee. "It's real people. That's what this party's all about."
Among delegates profiled here are a health care worker of Puerto Rican descent who gives her time to boards in Highland Park and to women's issues; an Irish-American man who is a firefighter in Camden and the Mayor of Deptford, and a teacher of the blind, the first black woman ever elected to the Newark City Council.
All three expressed a real liking for President Clinton, brushing aside accusations by critics that he bends too easily with the political wind. Each said that creating jobs should be a priority for the country. (An interest in economic issues, "from jobs to being able to afford sending kids to college," is a constant theme in the delegation, said Jean Holtz, the state's delegate convention coordinator.)
And the three bring to the convention a sense of their own personal roots, a feeling that they have come far since their families first arrived in America, and that they should serve their country in return for their blessings.

CARMEN DIAZ
'It's My Civic Duty'
In 1992, Carmen Delia Diaz discovered that there were so many other volunteers at Clinton-Gore headquarters in New Brunswick, she had no desk or chair. So she went home, loaded a desk onto her old jalopy and carted it back.
With such dedication, she quickly rose to become deputy manager in the New Jersey campaign and a link to Hispanic voters. Ms. Diaz, who gives her age as 30-plus, attended the Democratic Convention that year as a member of the campaign finance committee. She is on the credentials committee this year.
For Ms. Diaz, who works as a coordinator in the emergency room at Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick, the convention is yet another step in a journey of self-discovery and political advocacy that took root when she became the first person in her family to attend college.
Her parents -- who left Puerto Rico in the early 1950's and bought a home in Perth Amboy, where her father worked for many years as a laborer in the American Smelting Company -- preached the value of getting an education.
She worked her way through Douglass College in New Brunswick, which she credits for giving her, aside from a B.A. in urban studies in 1987, the "confidence and courage to believe in myself to do anything I want to do."
There she spent a year in a leadership program for Hispanic women at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers. Her political involvement was sparked in 1989, when she joined the Women's Political Caucus of New Jersey.
She is currently president of the caucus's Middlesex County chapter. In Highland Park, she is chairwoman of the Human Rights Commission and a member of the planning board, and is also a member of Middlesex County Commission on the Status of Women.
She said she supported President Clinton because he "is for all Americans" and has an "unprecedented record of support" for issues vital to women.
Ms. Diaz, who is married, said she still felt like a "student of politics" who had much to learn.
"I feel it's my civic duty," she said, "as a woman, as a Latina, as an American citizen, that I should stay involved and participate."

WILLIAM W. BAIN JR.
Putting Jobs First
William W. Bain Jr., whose grandparents emigrated from County Cork and County Galway in Ireland, is a veteran firefighter whose firehouse on Broadway in downtown Camden is about three blocks from where he was born 48 years ago.
He is the son of a laborer who worked in the Camden Coke Plant for 43 years and is proud that one of his own children, Joel, followed him into the Camden Fire Department.
Since January he has also been the Mayor of Deptford Township, a community of 25,000 people about eight miles from Camden, where he moved in 1977 and became active in the local Democratic club, serving as secretary and vice president, and in activities of the Gloucester County Democrats. He entered public life as a councilman in 1990.
This will be the first convention for a "truly excited" Mr. Bain, who is on the rules committee.
Mr. Bain, who has been secretary of Local 788 of the International Association of Firefighters for most of his 27 years as a firefighter, with a stint as vice president, said he believed that union members who became so-called Reagan Democrats would abandon the Republican Party of Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich.
"The 104th Congress let everyone know who they were," Mr. Bain said. "This Republican Contract With America is killing the working man."
He said that he liked President Clinton personally, calling him "the best hope we have right now," and added that accusations calling Mr. Clinton's integrity into question were politically motivated and unproven.
The No. 1 issue? "Jobs," he said. "We need employment. We need to get good jobs."
Mr. Bain contributes half of his $3,800 salary as Mayor to a scholarship fund that he set up at the local high school. Among his charitable efforts was serving as president of the Southern New Jersey Chapter of the Muscular Dystrophy Association.
"That's what it's all about: trying to make it better for people," he said.
"I really hope, as God is my judge, that everything I tried to do makes a difference, whether helping someone down the street or picking the next president of the United States," Mr. Bain said. "As corny as that may sound, I really believe it."

MILDRED C. CRUMP
A Lifetime of Service
Mildred C. Crump, a teacher of the blind and the first black woman to be elected to the Newark City Council, said that political involvement was in her blood. It is, she believes, a characteristic passed down from her grandfather, who was a 6-year-old slave at the time of the Emancipation Proclamation and grew up to become a leader of the black community in Cuthbert, Ga., respected by residents both white and black.
"I don't remember when I wasn't involved in politics, because my Dad was a union organizer," said Mrs. Crump, whose late father was a sanitation worker in her native Detroit. "My dad believed politics was the engine that drove everything that happened to people."
A past president of the board of Habitat for Humanity in Newark, the organization that builds affordable housing for low-income families, and active in distributing food to the poor, she said of her civic activities: "It's all I've ever known. Be involved. Give back to the community."
Mrs. Crump, a 56-year-old widow with two grown children, was a delegate for Jesse Jackson in 1988.
"I'm as excited about being a delegate for Bill Clinton," said Mrs. Crump. "I don't think Bill Clinton is perfect, but for me, he speaks to the greatest percentage of issues that benefit the public."
In 1961, fresh out of Wayne State University with a degree in special education, she got involved in politics by running the State Senate campaign of a friend. After her late husband, Cecil, a linguist for AT&T, was transferred to New Jersey in 1965, settling in Newark, she campaigned for local candidates.
Noting an absence of women on the council, she ran herself in 1986, 1989, and 1990, but lost each time. In July 1994, after receiving the most votes of 13 candidates, including incumbents, she began serving as a Councilwoman at large. To do so full time, she took a leave of absence as a Braille teacher for the New Jersey Commission for the Blind.
As a delegate, she said, she hopes to influence policy on issues like education, jobs, health care and welfare reform that will "trickle down" to Newark.
"I believe," she says, "that what comes out of this convention will set the tone for years to come."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
What Slump? Garden State Plaza Adds More Mall Than Ever

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
For years the Garden State Plaza in Paramus has sat beside the traffic cloverleaf where Routes 4 and 17 meet, a growing retail behemoth that has been both an economic blessing to Bergen County, with sales of around $500 million a year, and a traffic curse.
Now it is expanding again. 
 On Aug. 15 the mall's owners, the Westfield Corporation and Rodamco, opened a $200 million expansion that is expected to add about 100 stores to the 200-store mall and increase its size by about 800,000 square feet, to 2 million square feet.
And as if to confirm the adage comparing retailing to warfare, two new competitors are threatening to add about 6 million square feet of retail and shopping space a short drive from the Paramus interchange.
Garden State Plaza, the state's first mall when it opened in 1957, has essentially charted a middle course on pricing since it became a covered mall in 1981. With Nordstrom, J.C. Penney and Macy's in place since 1991, it is less upscale than Riverside Square farther east on Route 4, but fancier than Paramus Park, which is north along Route 17.
The Garden State expansion, which was completed a few months ahead of schedule, will continue this strategy with the addition of the ritzy Neiman Marcus and the more mainstream Lord & Taylor. These two new anchors, as large department stores are called in the mall business, along with the three existing ones, will be supported by a wide variety of shops, from Henri Bendel to Champion sportswear to the Channel 13 Store of Knowledge.
"That's the formula we're going for," said Lucille DeHart, a spokeswoman for the mall. "It is unusual to be everything to everyone."
Representatives from retailers like Bendel and Neiman Marcus said that they were confident about their decisions to move into the new mall, which anticipates $700 million in annual sales. But they admitted that since 1991 malls have not done as well as in the boom years of the 1970's and 1980's.
"Regional shopping centers are in trouble," said Kurt Barnard, an industry analyst. "They are not easy to shop, too many stores look alike and it takes a long time to park. Today people want to get done quickly."
Ms. DeHart said the mall would try to help shoppers with shuttle buses to and from the far reaches of its 10,000-space parking lot, valet parking, customer service representatives at key locations and strollers and electric shopping carts for rent.
She said that Garden State Plaza had been generally immune to industry downturns because of its size, the $78,000 annual income of its average shopper, the 1.1 million people who live within 20 miles and the 200,000 cars that pass by it each day. In fact, traffic was already an issue when the mall was a mere 1.2 million square feet.
"The expansion is slightly controversial because of the fears of the residents about traffic," said Rich Lambert, who is the Police Commissioner and a committee member in the Borough of Paramus.
Both the mall and the government are taking steps to reduce the inevitable increase in traffic congestion. A new southbound lane has been built on the Route 17 bridge over Route 4. And Chester Mattson, the director of planning for Bergen County, said the state had a $90 million plan of its own that would include a figure-eight bridge from the mall to the parking lot across the highway that Alexander's department store once used. There will also be new northbound and southbound lanes on Route 17, and new bridges connecting Route 17 north and south to Route 4 west and east, respectively.
Once drivers get to the mall they will find 25 new stores in the expanded section, including both new anchors. The grand opening of the new section is to take place in November, and according to the mall there are no vacancies.
Meanwhile, to the north, just off the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Nyack, N.Y., developers want to expand Palisades Center Mall, which is not even scheduled to open until next spring. Counting entertainment and retail space, the mall would be nearly 4 million square feet, only 200,000 square feet smaller than the immense Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn., the country's largest.
To the south, near the Meadowlands Sports Complex, developers have proposed a project called Meadowlands Mills that would have 2.1 million square feet of retail space, plus office buildings.
"Some consumers say that malls are too big," said Mark Shoiffet, a spokesman for the mall industry. "But the most successful malls are the largest ones."

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL PREVIEW 1996;
Despite Complications, Big 12 Is Instant Commercial Hit

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
If you've run into the elephant statues, you're in the wrong place. The newest conference in America will be easy to spot on autumn Saturdays. For now, Mondays through Fridays present the only problem. Someday soon, the Big 12 Conference will occupy 16,500 square feet of 28th-story office space, a cost-free testament to the newfound collective clout of its membership, with 30-foot windows providing views of the Dallas skyline.
 
 For now, to find the Big 12 offices you look for the men's room off to the side in an expansive series of lobbies within a hotel complex, not far from one of the two Budd has but nowhere near the elephants. You turn left, go up a narrow stairwell, and discover the type of office environment that "60 Minutes" infiltrates with cameras hidden in briefcase. "We don't have the greatest office in the world," said Donnie Duncan, the senior associate commissioner. "But we have the greatest lobby."
 Welcome to the Big 12, where the lobby is just the beginning. With some staff business cards still sealed in fresh boxes, the conference possessed 6 of the top 24 football teams in the preseason Associated Press media poll, 3 of the top 8, and 2 of the top 5, including the two-time defending champion Nebraska Cornhuskers. It has exactly 30 months of tradition, a sometimes painful and often contentious period during which former members of the Big Eight plus the Southwest Conference evacuees Texas, Texas A&M, Texas Tech and Baylor created new working relationships, forfeited much of their old identities and grappled to arrive at a precise definition of their creation.
 Was it a merger?
 Is it a Big Eight expansion?
 "It is a new conference," said Steve Hatchell, the commissioner, who until July 1 was one of the conference's only two employees.
 That simple definition, and misunderstandings that grew from conflicting interpretations, created a threat to the existence of the conference before the first kickoff or jump ball. At its best, the Big 12 commands something that neither the Big Eight nor the S.W.C. ever could - the influence that accompanies 15 percent of the nation's TV sets. The struggle has been to achieve a consensus on a number of fundamental issues within a short period of time while establishing itself in the marketplace.
 The commercial success has exceeded the most optimistic expectations. An intense series of bids to house the conference offices, which included Kansas City, Mo. - the former big Eight site - plus Colorado Springs, Omaha and Lubbock, Tex., led to a five-year, $1.25 million agreement under which the city of Dallas will offset the conference's operating expenses.
 Gatorade will provide cups and coolers at championship events as part of a five-year, $1.33 million deal. Dr. Pepper will become the title sponsor of the football championship game for four years at $1 million per year. Phillips 66, Southwest Airlines and State Farm Insurance are among other sponsors.
 In addition to football, the conference expects to have at least eight championships sponsored during this academic year for a minimum total of $2.4 million.
 "The bottom line," Hatchell said, "is it's not going to cost us anything to do much of anything for 10 years."
 Other steps forward have not been quite as simple. Only 2 of 12 schools, Kansas State and Iowa State, are run by the same chief executive officer who was in place when the formation of the conference was first discussed. Dr. James Moeser, who became the Nebraska chancellor Feb. 1, is that school's third leader since the process began.
 Over the last two and a half years, in private conversations, coaches and officials at conference schools have occasionally sounded like wedding guests establishing an over-under on the divorfce date before the ceremony takes place.
 The former S.W.C. members, who operated under stricter academic guidelines than the Big Eight, created the perception of a serious enough threat that Tom Osborne, the Niebraska football coach, delivered a remarkable, unsolicited appeal for the conference to liberalize its proposed entrance requirements during a news conference immediately following his team's Fiesta Bowl victory over Florida last January.
 It was not persuasive enough. By an 11-1 vote, with Nebraska the lone dissenter, the conference determined that each year, members could admit no more than two partial qualifiers, who are students who fall to achieve the grade-point average, core requirement and standardized test score under National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Football teams are limited to one partial qualifier each year.
 "The conference has place itself in a noncompetitive position." Moeser said. "A prominent athlete who has an opportunity to play at Ohio State or Penn State or Southern California, if Nebraska says, 'We're not sure we can give you a scholarship,' is not going to come here."
 Nebraska's approach, according to Moeser, will be to wait for less successful conference teams to discover they ar elimited by the rule, and then support a revision.
 "We're not going to go out unflaterally," he said. "I think it was incorrectly seen as a self-serving, self-protecting mechanism to protect what kind of competitive advantage we have. Our position has been we were outvoted on this issue. We will play by the rules utnil the rules are charged."
 Osborne's position, however, has been to continue his offensive. During the first campus news conference at the start of practice, reporters were presented with charts showing a 46.9 percent average graduation rate among Big 12 programs - 17.1 percentage points less than Nebraska's in the most recent N.C.A.A. report. The average rate of junior college transfers at Big 12 schools was just 30.6 percent. Osborne feels that athletes with borderline academic credentials would have a greater chance of earning a degree if they could begin work immediately at a four-year school.
 Osborne maintained his appeal was not meant to gain access to athletes with lesser academic credentials, but to encourage each of the Big 12 members to provide opportunities to groups that are most adversely affected, particularly the economically disadvantaged.
 "A lot of folks think I'm doing all this talking to try to win football games," he said. "What I'm looking at is what this is doing to our country.
 "There are lot of kids that can use college athletics that are being denied an opportunity to go. If it was substantially improving the situation that would be one thing. But I'm a little apprehensive and concerned about what we're doing because it looks good."
 The issue is not going away and has not been fully accepted despite an 11-1 vote. "I get a lot of energy from the fact that these people aren't just going to line up and say, 'Oh, this sounds good,' and go on down the road," Hatchell said. "Egos don't fly in formation. These people are independent thinkers. There is great strength in that for the conference."
 "Everybody was forced to go from one major issue to another major issue, on and on, without taking a deep breath," Hatchell said. "I think after a while you lose sight of what the goal is. The goal is to put the conference together."

HEADLINE: Clinton Does Battle With Chicago '68

BYLINE: By Paul Berman; Paul Berman is the author of "A Tale of Two Utopias: The Political Journey of the Generation of 1968."

 BODY:
Every now and then, one of America's political parties finds a perfect accusation to throw at its electoral enemies -- an accusation so devastating and impressive that whole generations have to come and go before the charge loses force.
The greatest example was the accusation that was lodged against the Democrats in 1864, in the middle of the Civil War. Abraham Lincoln and the Republicans accused the Democrats of being the party of Southern secession, and the charge proved so effective at the polls that the Republicans kept repeating it for decades to come. In that manner, during the entire period from Lincoln's day until 1912, the Republicans won the White House in 11 out of 13 elections. 
 The Democrats came up with an accusation of their own in 1932, at the depth of the Great Depression. Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Democrats blamed Herbert Hoover and the Republican Party for the economic collapse. It was an excellent accusation. The Democrats stuck with it for 40 years and more. And never once did they have reason to regret doing so.
The grand accusation that figures in the politics of today -- the charge against which Bill Clinton has had to struggle (and lately he's done so with a lot of skill) -- got its start in 1968. The Vietnam War, the race riots, the university uprisings and the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy meant that once again the country was in a bad way.
In that context, Richard Nixon and the Republicans gazed at the Democrats' 1968 convention in Chicago. They watched a Democratic constituency -- the antiwar protesters -- taunt the Chicago cops and get brained for doing it. And the grand new accusation, the devastating and impressive charge that has lasted for decades, went spilling from Republican lips. It was the accusation that Democrats encouraged lawnessness, drugs, sex, draft-dodging and college layabouts.
The accusation has proved hardy. Elections have come and gone since then, but the accusation rests eternal. If the personal attacks on Mr. Clinton have radiated an exceptional nastiness over these past four years, it is because the particular charges against him -- the alleged womanizing, non-inhalation and draft-dodging -- draw strength from the original complaint of 1968. (In the typology of scandals, Whitewater figures as more of a Republican-type affair and has no ideological underpinning.)
When Bob Dole responds to Mr. Clinton's birthday celebration by accusing the White House of being run by people from an "elite" who have never suffered and have never grown up, he is merely hitting the old accusatory note and in its classic generational form: the World War II veteran fuming at the Vietnam War protester from a fancy university. And when Mr. Dole says that he remembers a better America, everybody knows precisely when that long-lost world of his imaginings used to exist: before 1968, before the elite layabouts with their low morals came on the national scene.
The charge that dates from 1968 differs from those of 1864 and 1932 in one important respect. In some corner of their partisan souls, the targets of those earlier accusations recognized their own guilt.
The 19th-century Democrats did bear a responsibility for the Civil War, as did the Republicans of the 1920's for the Great Depression, and there was no point in claiming otherwise.
But what does the accusation from 1968 specify? It says that the antiwar protest movement's low morals and lack of reverence for tradition and authority undid the culture of America, and that the consequences have been sociological: crime, illegitimacy, AIDS and so forth.
Yet when the former protesters and their cultural descendants, most of them currently incarnated as Democratic liberals, gaze back on the protest movements of the 1960's, they see something else.
They see two grand and admirable causes: the civil rights movement and the antiwar movement -- surrounded by a constellation of other movements and impulses, not all of them admirable (though there are some people who insist on viewing everything as admirable). They see several advances for democracy and individual liberty and a certain spirit of cultural mayhem. They see a puzzling fondness for political stances that were often self-defeating. But they do not see the caricature offered by their accusers.
On the other hand, they do see how even their own accusers have benefited from the radical past. They see how at San Diego the same Bob Dole who regrets the disappearance of the pre-1968 America surrounded himself with symbols of the post-1968 era. For there was Gen. Colin Powell, who has done honor to, among other things, affirmative action. And there was Representative Susan Molinari, who has enjoyed the freedom to experiment with drugs in college (even though she now claims to regret this action), the freedom to walk away from her first marriage without opprobrium and the freedom to pursue a professional career. She is, to Democratic eyes, someone who has lived the life of a liberated woman, post-'68.
So Democratic liberals examine the accusation against them and cannot really understand it; and they examine their accusers, whom they understand all too well, and they sputter. Which is to say the liberals are left befuddled and speechless, except for the feeble cry of hypocrisy, and they have been left that way since 1968.
In the years from 1968 until the Clinton era, the Democrats responded to the accusation against them by nominating, election after election, candidates of obvious rectitude. But having endured one too many electoral defeats, the Democrats came up with Mr. Clinton in 1992.
You might suppose that he would be the most vulnerable of candidates, since he is the first Democratic leader whose past even remotely resembles the Republican caricature. But Mr. Clinton has responded by adopting the sort of maneuverability that allows him, when the Republicans prattle about family values, to out-prattle the prattlers -- and, when the Republicans veer right, to veer one inch to their left.
The return to Chicago for this Democratic convention is bound to afford Mr. Clinton and his supporters a limitless opportunity for beating the Republicans to their own punch. For this week's scenes of former protesters hobnobbing with Chicago cops will be wondrous, and no room will be left for an angry accusation.
Naturally, Mr. Clinton's maneuverings do not always endear him to his party's traditional constituents -- me, for example. But Mr. Clinton has learned from Richard Nixon that winning and being loved are not the same thing.
The Republicans see that, too. They hurl the word "waffling" in Mr. Clinton's face. After the President signed the unfortunate welfare bill last Thursday, Mr. Dole complained that the President is "ideologically adrift." But Mr. Clinton is bound to think: So what? To accuse a man of drifting is not like accusing him of undermining the national morality.
On the contrary, the complaint about drifting shows that here is a genuinely clever politician, the first on the Democratic side in a long time -- someone with the talent to cope with the Republican accusation that for almost 30 years has dealt so many defeats to the Democrats.

LENGTH: 1488 words

HEADLINE: Westhampton Beach: Image and Reality

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
EACH village and hamlet in the Hamptons has its own personality, as insiders never tire of explaining to tourists.
East Hampton is regarded as arty. Southampton as the old guard's last bastion. Bridgehampton, once hardly more than a blur in the rear-view mirror en route from one to the other, has made a rapid ascent, establishing itself as a hot spot for the fashionably trendy. 
 Meanwhile, Westhampton Beach, by many accounts, has been slipping.
Even boosters acknowledge that the westernmost Hampton has problems. The first Hampton that New Yorkers encounter going east, it was the first in the building boom of the 70's and 80's.
Westhampton Beach was also the first community to attract house-sharing singles, thanks to its extensive inventory of lower-cost housing and beachfront condominiums. Now, it is once again in the forefront, many residents say, as the first to face the challenges of a new, post-development era.
Last February, concerned that Westhampton was developing a reputation as a second-rate Hampton that the fashionable people were bypassing, a group of residents decided to act. At the suggestion of Rabbi Marc Schneier, founding rabbi of the village's two-year-old Hampton Synagogue, they formed the Westhampton Beach Partnership. The group aims to restore economic and cultural vitality to the village and neighboring Quiogue, Quogue, Remsenburg and Westhampton.
Spearheaded largely by residents with close ties to the city, the group has modeled itself in at least one respect on similarly oriented non-governmental New York City initiatives. To help burnish the area's image, members agreed, as s one of their first acts, to hire a public-relations agency from Manhattan, Rubenstein Associates, whose clients include the Association for a Better New York and the New York City Partnership. According to the Rubenstein consultant on the account, Lonnie Soury, the firm is being paid $50,000 a year.
In meetings on alternating Sundays the partnership has drawn up two sets of objectives, Mr. Soury said. Short-term, he asserted, there are "some eyesores -- some empty lots and a gas station at the end of Main Street that has been empty for years." Those are proposed for beautification, he said.
In February the partnership placed a nightspot on Main Street, Marakesh, the site of a dispute in May that officials call racially motivated, "at the top of our list" of priorities, Mr. Soury said. Residents had criticized the nightclub, saying it attracted short-term visitors who drank too much, spent too little and sometimes made trouble. The State Liquor Authority has suspended the bar's license.
"We are hopeful that the State Liquor Authority will keep it closed," a member of the partnership, Leonard Conway, said. Mr. Conway, who operates an investment business, Conway & Company, from an office in his house, described the partnership's targets as "the typical problems of a resort-based community."
The most important objective, he said, may be to encourage a broad-based economy that can thrive, if not year-round, at least for an extended season of "six, seven or even eight months."
"None of these communities are ever going to be bustling 12 months a year," Mr. Conway said. "But there are things we can try to do to build more support."
One possibility, he said, might be the extension to Main Street of a canal that now stops 150 feet short of the main commercial strip. Some proponents believe it may be the best way to capitalize on an asset no other Hampton possesses -- a marine environment that melds with the village. Advocates point to Annapolis, Md., where commerce thrives around a lively marina, as an example of what they have in mind and they say that Westhampton Beach has always offered more for boaters than its Hamptons neighbors.
This fall, in place of the traditional Oktoberfest, the community will be host to a three-day maritime festival.
Mr. Conway acknowledged that the obstacles to an extended canal could be formidable. At this point, he said, the partnership was actively exploring the idea, talking to engineers and looking into options for financing the project. Mr. Conway added that the partnership was also eager to see a sewage system replace the cesspools in the Main Street area.
The group, he said, would also like to establish a year-round cultural center. The group, he added, has an eye on an Art Deco movie house.
Because of empty streets in the off season and a corresponding lack of broad-based yearlong attractions, the improvement effort faces a "cart-and-horse" problem, Mr. Conway said.
In the belief that the kinds of fashionable stores and restaurants they have pledged in their mission statement to encourage won't open in Westhampton Beach unless improvements to the infrastructure come first, members of the partnership have given the sewer improvements high priority.
Bartley Wilensky, who became mayor on July 1, said about the partnership, "I was one of those people sitting back, saying, 'Who are these people who are going to decide the fate of my village?' "
He now believes, he said, that "their hearts -- and their pocketbooks -- are in the village."
"They do have access to wealth," Mr. Wilensky said. "That's their game -- money, fund raising, bond issues."
That would be a boon, particularly for the sewage system, he said, noting that in the summer some businesses "have to pump just about daily when they have crowds"
That can cost $300 for each instance. One restaurateur, the Mayor said, reported spending $22,000 a year for pumping his cesspool.
"If the community is serious about expanding activities," Mr. Conway said, "it will have to support them financially. Nothing gets done these days without that kind of private support."
The partnership, he suggested, can help the community as "a vehicle to tap the experience and resources of residents."
In addition to "leading investment bankers," Rabbi Schneier said, the members of the partnership include the president of Donna Karan, Stephen L. Ruzow, and the chairman of a company that manufactures fashions under the Christian Dior label, Neal Hochman.
"It's all about using local resources," Rabbi Schneier said. And if the area is to shed what the rabbi referred to its image as the "stepchild of the Hamptons," it will not be a building boom.
"We're built," said Norma Reynolds, who was born in the town and has a real-estate business on Main Street. "We've done it. We're at the stage of renovation now."
Ms. Reynolds has seen it happen. First there was a fishing and farming community in Westhampton Beach. "Then we had the assault of building, when the local people made their money selling their land," Ms. Reynolds said. Now that is occurring further East, she added, "where the last farms are becoming more houses, sometimes vineyards. "
"You're seeing it in East Hampton and Southampton now," she added, "the growth that took place many years ago in Westhampton Beach."
Even the influx of singles that gave Westhampton Beach its reputation as a "groupie heaven" in the 70's and 80's has moved on, Ms. Reynolds said, added that "now they are going to Southampton, Bridgehampton and East Hampton, because they have to go where the social life is."
Ms. Reynolds predicted that the growth of hot spots would continue "until they can't move, until they're done, finished."
"Then everyone will settle down and decide what happened to their village," she said.
That is what Westhampton Beach is now undergoing, she said, adding:
"We lost our village. It is called growth, and it is not particularly attractive. But some good things have come of it."
The effects include an identity problem, Ms. Reynolds said, who regards the partnership as part of a larger effort to define the postdevelopment community and make it a desirable area for families to live in.
"Many people are coming back," she said about former residents whohad followed the spotlight east, only to be driven back by the crowds and the traffic. "They can't get there, and when they get there they can't go anywhere."
With sparse vacant land, Ms. Reynolds said, people are house hunting in the hedge-lined estate sections and renovating lovely old cottages. The newcomers are buying at what Ms. Reynolds said were extremely good prices because of the unfashionable image. "We are at a low," she said. "But we are going to go up. It's a buyer's market here. Out there, it's a seller's market."
Rabbi Schneier has perceived the same demographic shift, "with singles moving east and the Westhampton Beach area becoming the great family place." Walk down Main Street, he said, and 'all you see are families with children."
To the "water capital of the Hamptons," he said, add "the family community of the Hamptons."
It may sound like unabashed image building, but in the Hamptons reality can be less important than image.

HEADLINE: In U.S. Drug War, Battlefield Is Global

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Election-Year Posturing on Drugs" (editorial, Aug. 19) is flawed in calling for isolationist policies that are doomed to fail. When Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia sponsored an amendment to increase international counternarcotics funding, he did so in response to United States national security interests. 
 Drug abuse and its related crime and violence are wreaking havoc with our country, not least among the poorest segments of our society. While we must redouble our efforts at home, the most harmful drugs -- cocaine, heroin and most methamphetamines -- originate outside United States borders.
Given your use of statistics, readers could be forgiven for assuming that the focus of our fight against drugs is outside our borders. Funds allocated to combat drug trafficking overseas make up only 5 percent of the Federal drug budget. But that 5 percent enables overseas training and support for government institutions vital in defending against the drug trade -- police, customs, immigration and entire judicial systems. We also support efforts to eradicate drug crops and create alternative economic options.
These programs will not bring about an instant cure. But in the long run, they will benefit all countries involved by helping to stop drugs at the source and preventing drug traffickers from creating narco-democracies.
 
JANE E. BECKER
Acting Asst. Secretary of State
for International Narcotics
and Law Enforcement Affairs
Washington, Aug. 21, 1996

HEADLINE: After Wrack and Ruin, Tourism in California Rebounds

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
After a battering by earthquakes, urban riots and recession, California is in the midst of a tourist boom. Hotels, amusement parks and attractions from San Diego to San Francisco are racking up record numbers of visitors.
"This state is having just a land-office summer," said John Poimiroo, the state tourism director. 
 Although tourism nationwide will increase 2 percent this summer over last, according to D. K. Shifflet & Associates, a research concern in McLean, Va., it is expected to rise 6 percent in California.
With the summer waning, the state shows every sign of meeting if not exceeding those projections. In all, 1 in 6 tourist dollars nationwide is spent in the state.
Tourism in Southern California is especially strong, fueled by a steady influx of foreign visitors. The occupancy rate at hotels in Los Angeles climbed to 71 percent this year, the highest rate since 1989. It had plummeted to 57 percent in May 1992, the month after the riots that followed the acquittal of police officers in the beating of Rodney J. King. Hotels downtown registered a 21-percent gain in the first quarter compared with the same period in 1995 and a 55 percent gain in April over April 1995.
One reason for the bullish season is that "we haven't seen any disasters to scare off visitors in a few years," said Helen Chang, a spokeswoman for the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Those disasters included the San Francisco earthquake that killed 67 in 1989, the Los Angeles quake that killed 61 in 1994, and the 1992 riots.
California was also hit hard by the nationwide recession that helped shrink the number of visits by Americans to the state, to 183 million in 1993, from 192 million in 1992.
The new wave of tourism has been fed by the many low-cost airlines operating throughout the Western states, from which California derives most out-of-state visitors.
California has been on a roll for more than a year. Last year it attracted 197 million American tourists, 9 million more than in 1994 and 47 million more than runner-up Florida's 149.6 million last year.
The rise in California's share of the nation's tourists, to 10.9 percent last year from 10.4 percent in 1994, was the first increase in eight years.
Those figures are especially meaningful in a state that has known hard times and where tourism brought in $55.2 billion last year and accounted for almost 700,000 jobs, behind only health care and business services.
The state boasts 3 of the nation's 10 most popular theme parks, including Disneyland, a perennial leader. Attendance at Disneyland, in Anaheim, fell 20 percent from 1990 to 1994 and jumped 38 percent last year, to 14.1 million, according to Amusement Business, a trade magazine. Attendance is strong again this year.
Crowds have also been flocking to Universal Studios near Hollywood to experience a new $110 million "Jurassic Park" ride. Attendance is up an estimated 40 percent at the park this summer over last, and the 43,000 visitors on July 5 broke a 31-year-old single-day record by 22 percent.
"A friend from home visited Los Angeles a few months ago and told me not to miss Jurassic Park when I came," Manuel Gutierrez of Madrid said after a day at the park. "I've never been on a ride like that before. It was great."
Part of the comeback, especially among international tourists, can be credited to "Baywatch," a television program syndicated throughout much of the world that depicts adventures of lifeguards on a California beach. And streams of tourists are visiting sites that played roles in the the O. J. Simpson murder case.
"Lots of our guests, including lots of foreign guests, want to know where the jurors slept and how close is the courthouse," said Lew Fader, general manager of the Intercontinental Hotel, where the jury was sequestered. "They'll pull out maps and ask, 'Where's 875 South Bundy Drive?' " the scene of the slaying.
San Francisco's hotel occupancy rate of 74 percent last year led all California cities, Ms. Chang said. And it rose 5.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, she added.
Occupancy in the Fishermen's Wharf area, a leading attraction, increased 14.4 percent in the first quarter.
While studying a map to plot her route to Fishermen's Wharf, Hyazintha Borstner of Austria said her tour of American cities would not have been complete without San Francisco. The reason is that in Europe people do not usually see such a harmonious cultural mix, she said, citing the former Yugoslavia. "Here," she added, "you see how people of different origins and cultures live together in peace."
Even though the number of tourists from Mexico and Canada has fallen because of those countries' weak currencies, visitors from Japan, Germany and Britain continue to flock to San Francisco and Los Angeles. Foreigners make up almost 25 percent of the 22 million annual visitors to Los Angeles, and they generate 40 percent of its $9.7 billion in tourism revenues.
Many foreigners have been enticed by marketing trips that the state and some cities have made to Europe, Asia and South America. In the last year, West Hollywood, a 1.9-square-mile city in Los Angeles County, marketed its hotels and attractions in London, Berlin and Sydney. Two months ago it was host for 1,000 foreign tour operators and travel agents at a convention here.
After the riots, California sponsored a $20 million advertising campaign in Japan to lure free-spending Japanese tourists, whose numbers dropped from 1.1 million in 1989 to 785,000 in 1992. But although many Japanese travel elsewhere in the United States on their own or with family or friends, two-thirds of the Japanese tourists in Southern California arrive in tour groups, concerned about safety, experts say.
The passage of time has also helped increased tourism. "After the riots I was a little scared about going to Los Angeles," said Steven Jefferson, who was visiting from Miami. "But now, I don't hear as much about crime in Los Angeles, or at least I haven't read much about it lately."
"Something like 8 of the 10 safest cities in America are in California," Mr. Poimiroo said. "And Los Angeles is right in the middle of the safety ranking. But you wouldn't know it from what you see on TV."
But San Diegans are pleased with the television images of their city from the Republican National Convention. Even before the convention, the city had its highest hotel occupancies and largest attendance at conventions in recent years. "But because San Diego has been overshadowed by San Francisco and Los Angeles," said Reint Reinders, president of the San Diego Convention and Visitors Bureau, "we haven't been as well known as we would like."
San Diego will still probably be overshadowed by San Francisco and Los Angeles. But the favorable impression is expected to be a plus. "It probably won't create a big surge in visitors all at once," said Matt DeLine, president of San Diego Hotel Reservations. "But the effect of that publicity will be felt for a very long time."

HEADLINE: Israeli President Prods Netanyahu to Meet With Arafat

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's repeated refusal to meet with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, came under attack from an unexpected quarter today as President Ezer Weizman announced that he would meet with Mr. Arafat if Mr. Netanyahu did not.
Mr. Weizman confirmed his decision at a hastily called news conference with Mr. Netanyahu after the popular daily, Yediot Ahronot, today disclosed the plan to hold a meeting. 
 Several hours later, the Israeli state radio reported that Mr. Netanyahu would meet with Mr. Arafat, and the state television suggested that there was a possibility he would do so before a planned trip to the United States on Sept. 10. But Mr. Netanyahu refused to give a date in an interview with the television, saying that "the date depends on developments."
Since his election in 1993, Mr. Weizman, a 72-year-old former general, has often stepped out of his ceremonial role and into the tumult of Israeli politics. During the last Labor Government, he often irritated both the late Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and his successor, Shimon Peres, by repeatedly criticizing their peace efforts with the Palestinians and the importance they attributed to Mr. Arafat.
But this was the first time Mr. Weizman has entered the fray under Mr. Netanyahu, and instead of charging that the process was going too fast, this time he said it was approaching a dangerous halt.
The Yediot Ahronot report, which was effectively confirmed at the President's news conference, said that Mr. Arafat had sent an urgent appeal to Mr. Weizman to save the negotiating process. "The time has come to end the fight between the Palestinian people and the Israeli people and to transform it into love," Mr. Arafat wrote, according to the newspaper. "The time has come to stop the spilling of blood."
The note fom Mr. Arafat said that, "I am interested in meeting with you as soon as possible," the newspaper report said.
The newspaper said that Mr. Weizman decided to set up a meeting, believing that a continued freeze could lead to a deterioration of the security situation in Israel. The President then met with Mr. Netanyahu and told him of his intention, adding that he would agree to postpone the meeting if the Prime Minister agreed to "meet himself with Arafat within 10 days."
The President also advised Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Foreign Minister David Levy, the more moderate members of Mr. Netanyahu's Cabinet, of his plan. Mr. Weizman said the meeting would be in his private home in the resort city of Caesarea, not in his official residence in Jerusalem.
At his joint appearance with Mr. Weizman, Mr. Netanyahu was obviously irritated by the intervention from an unexpected and politically popular quarter. He reiterated that he was working "according to a planned and pre-set course," and, as he often did during his election campaign, assailed "certain elements in the media."
Adapting a line that worked well in his campaign, Mr. Netanyahu said, "I was not elected to be the Prime Minister of the Palestinians."
Later, in an interview on evening television news, Mr. Netanyahu said he was holding off meeting with Mr. Arafat to insure that the meeting would be substantive. "We have passed over the era of declarations," he said. "I would like a meeting that brings results."
Whatever Mr. Netanyahu's preferences or calculations, the intervention of the President was certain to add a major shove to the already considerable pressures on the Prime Minister to take some action on the two issues that have become something of a test of his intentions: the delayed withdrawal of Israeli troops from most of Hebron, and a meeting with Mr. Arafat.
Mr. Arafat has begun an aggressive campaign to gather support both within and outside Israel, including a highly publicized meeting earlier this week with Mr. Peres. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has threatened to cancel a regional economic summit meeting next month if Israel does not proceed with talks with the Palestinians. Jordan has announced plans to go ahead on building a joint dam with Syria that Israel strongly opposes, and Qatar froze the construction of a gas line to Israel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Ezer Weizman of Israel, left, at a news conference yesterday with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at which Mr. Weizman said that he would meet with Yasir Arafat if Mr. Netanyahu would not. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Lloyd's to Appeal a Reorganization Ruling

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Executives of Lloyd's of London, where juggling risks has been a tradition, worked through the weekend trying to overcome the latest obstacle to their effort to resolve the organization's financial crisis..
A plan to split off billions of dollars in debt and liabilities from the central organization was thrown into turmoil Friday evening by a Federal judge in Virginia who extended the deadline for American investors to join the plan until the end of October. 
 Next week, Lloyd's, the world's oldest insurance organization, must demonstrate fiscal solvency to British insurance regulators. And, Lloyd's officials said, it may not be able to do so without the participation of the Americans.
Lawyers for Lloyd's are scheduled to go before a panel of three Federal appellate judges on Tuesday morning in Baltimore. They will seek to reverse Friday's ruling by Federal District Judge Robert Payne, which permits American investors to ignore the deadline of Wednesday that Lloyd's had set for taking part in the rescue plan.
Through the weekend, Lloyd's executives in London conferred with their legal team in the United States in shaping the appeal and began working out plans for how to proceed if the appeal failed.
"This," said Nick Doak, a spokesman for Lloyd's in London, "is the most serious crisis we've seen."
The court decision also required Lloyd's to present extensive financial documents about the new company to its American investors -- documents that are required under Securities and Exchange Commission regulations. Lloyd's contended that the new venture was not subject to S.E.C. regulations.
Lloyd's, a group of 170 insurance syndicates with 34,000 investors, reported $12 billion in losses for five years ending in 1992 for huge claims resulting from hurricanes, earthquakes and explosions as well as from vast asbestos and other environmental liabilities. It faces billions more in possible future claims on policies underwritten decades ago.
Lloyd's solution to all the bad news has been to create a new insurance company called Equitas which would be a repository for all Lloyd's claims and debts up to 1992. That was the year in which the organization began, once again, to rake in profits.
With financing of $18 billion, the new company would not sell insurance, hoping to earn income through investments while paying off Lloyd's obligations. Lloyd's actuaries foresee obligations of $15.3 billion, giving Equitas $2.7 billion more than it needs, for the moment.
Part of the financing of Equitas is to come from Lloyd's investors, or "names," as Lloyd's calls them, including $250 million from the 2,700 investors in the United States. In exchange for agreeing to pay what Lloyd's has said was a fraction of the debt the American investors are responsible for, plus up to $150,000 in additional money, the investors would be absolved of all future obligations.
In New York, state insurance officials said they were ready to seize $12 billion of Lloyd's assets in a Citibank trust fund if a collapse became evident. "We're following these developments carefully," said John Calagna, the spokesman for Insurance Superintendent Edward J. Muhl.
In the Virginia case, which was brought by 93 of the 2,700 American investors, the plaintiffs contended that Lloyd's had not provided sufficient data for them to independently calculate their obligations and to calculate how much, if anything, they should contribute to the new company. In his decision on Friday, Judge Payne ordered Lloyd's to provide its investors the same detailed information the S.E.C. requires of securities transactions in the United States.
Richard D. Rosenblatt, the chairman of the American Names Association, which includes about 1,000 of the American investors, and A. Steve Clay, the lead lawyer on the Virginia suit, said that they did not believe that Lloyd's financing of the new insurance company would fall short without the Americans' $250 million.
"They're just fear-mongering," Mr. Rosenblatt said, and trying to pressure the court. He said any shortfall could be covered by a $450 million contingency fund that Lloyd's previously disclosed.
But in London, Mr. Doak said the $450 million had been set aside for bridge loans to the new company, to give it operating capital while awaiting money pledged by investors but not yet delivered. He said it was not to be used indefinitely as start-up capital for the new company.
The chairman of Lloyd's, David Rowland, announced that 75 percent of Lloyd's investors had agreed to the plan for the new company. But Mr. Doak said it was unclear whether that meant that the money for the new company was now assured.
Of the 34,000 investors, he said, only 21,400 were required to contribute to the Equitas fund. The others, Mr. Doak said, were due refunds. Mr. Doak said Lloyd's would not have a calculation of total contributions to Equitas until later in the week.
The focus of the Virginia suit has been a quest for financial information. All of Lloyd's investors, who were required to have a net worth of at least $375,000 each, signed contracts agreeing to resolve any legal disputes in London courts.
Lloyd's had interpreted that to mean that it was bound to provide the same financial data to all investors. Except in cases where fraud is proven, British disclosure requirements are much lower than those in the United States.
Moreover, according to Securities & Exchange Commission regulations, detailed financial reports are required of anyone attempting to raise large amounts of capital.
Mr. Clay said that Lloyd's had consistently provided the American investors with nothing more than generalities and approximate figures when they sought specifics about the new company's finances. Mr. Doak disagreed, saying that Lloyd's had provided two lengthy documents explaining the structure of the new company as well as detailed calculations of the investors' profits and losses on their original investments in Lloyd's.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Some Good News Is Seen For Cigarette Stocks
Wall Street analysts expect tobacco stocks to rise in response to a jury's ruling late Friday that the industry was not responsible for the cancer death of an Indianapolis lawyer.
Still, the verdict gives new attention to the wild card of the individual lawsuit in influencing the future value of tobacco shares. The stocks have been dropping since a similar suit in Florida went against the industry on Aug. 9. Market Place. [Page D3.]

Lloyd's Seeks a Reversal
Executives at Lloyd's of London worked through the weekend trying to overcome the latest obstacle to efforts to resolve the organization's financial crisis. A plan to split off billions of dollars in debt and liabilities was thrown into turmoil last week when a Federal judge extended the deadline for American investors to join in the plan. Lloyd's plans to argue for a quick reversal of the ruling. [D2.]
 
Tracking the Political Winds
ABC News used an electronic system to track, second by second, the responses of a group of uncommitted voters to speeches at the Republican National Convention. Though ABC will not use the system at the Democratic convention, which begins tonight, it will track opinions using focus groups. [D5.]
 
The Democrats have converged on Chicago, and so, it seems, have World Wide Web entrepreneurs. Sites provide everything from convention history to practical information about the city. Taking In the Sites. [D4.]
 
Making Machines, And Users, Smile
Macintosh owners may consider themselves to be iconoclasts, but they do rely on icons, those that give the computers a user-friendly face. Susan Kare, who designed the Mac icons, is busier than ever, but with other work. The growth of the World Wide Web has put a new premium on graphics like hers. [D5.]
 
How Best to Use the Web?
The rush to carve the Internet into multimedia fiefs by companies like Netscape and Microsoft is siphoning energy from what should be the goal: to help users and developers exploit the special interactive qualities of the World Wide Web.
Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D5.]
 
Criticism of Programming Deals
As mergers have reshaped communications, companies are flexing their programming muscles by putting shows they produce on cable services they own. Critics at outside companies say they are sometimes being shut out of the bidding. Broadcasting. [D7.]
 
Tourism Rebounds in California
After several years of battering by earthquakes, riots and recession, California is in the midst of a tourist boom. Hotels, amusement parks and attractions are racking up record numbers of visitors. [A7.]
 
Labor Bounces Back
Only two years after a descent into near irrelevance, organized labor is experiencing a resurgence in Democratic politics -- driven by aggressive new leadership and fear of the Republican legislative agenda. [A9.]
 
Special Effects Bulk Up
Movie magicians have taught pigs to talk and roaches to sing. Now they are developing more efficient ways to model the bodies and movements of human beings. One new approach was used in the movie "The Island of Dr. Moreau." [D7.]
 
Minute Maid Account Is Moved
The advertising account for Coca-Cola's Minute Maid line of juices has been shifted from Lowe & Partners/SMS to Leo Burnett. But, except for a slip-up in an unrelated news release, the move would not have been disclosed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 3092 words

HEADLINE: UNCERTAIN WELCOME: Immigrants and Welfare -- A special report.;
For New York's Newcomers, Anxiety Over Welfare Law

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
In New York City, where more than half the residents are immigrants or the children of immigrants, a sense of panic and confusion has rippled from the shores of Brighton Beach to the streets of Washington Heights as the sweeping Federal welfare bill has become law, affecting millions of people, but perhaps none so immediately as the foreign-born.
Ever since President Clinton promised earlier this month to sign the legislation, a vast overhaul of Federal welfare policy that includes severe limits on Government aid to noncitizens, the number of immigrants and refugees seeking naturalization has jumped sharply in New York City, straining the services of immigrant organizations. Rumors have swirled around the new law, sending some immigrants into community centers in tears. Others have spent their days in denial, refusing to believe that changes will take place at all. And advocates say that some desperate elderly immigrants even talk of suicide. 
 "We've been overwhelmed," said Manuel Matos, executive director of the Northern Manhattan Coalition for Immigrant Rights, which has seen the number of applicants for naturalization double in the last two weeks. "We don't have the capacity to meet the demand, and it hasn't been like this in the two and a half years I've been here."
Advocacy groups are expanding hours and staffing to meet the rising demand for help in seeking naturalization. Grass-roots organizations are trying to find money to create networks to distribute food and clothing to immigrants whose benefits are cut off. And still others are passing out fliers, planning forums and taping spots for television and radio programs to educate immigrants about the complicated changes.
The legislation, signed into law on Thursday, transfers control of much of the nation's welfare system from the Federal Government to the states and imposes many new restrictions on aid to legal immigrants who are not yet citizens. Among them:
*Legal immigrants will generally no longer be eligible for food stamps or Supplemental Security Income, the Federal cash support for the poor, elderly and disabled.
*States will be allowed, but not required, to deny noncitizens cash welfare, Medicaid, Title XX block grant benefits and other state and local public assistance.
*Immigrants currently receiving S.S.I. or food stamps will technically be allowed to do so for up to one year, but individual cut-off dates will depend on when they undergo annual reviews for benefits. Those now receiving cash welfare, Medicaid or Title XX services cannot be denied those benefits until after Jan. 1.
*Future legal immigrants will be denied most Federal benefits during their first five years in the United States, including Medicaid and public housing.
*Sponsorship documents will become legally enforceable, requiring for the first time that those who sponsor new immigrants pay back any public benefits the immigrants receive. And in assessing new immigrants' applications for most Federal aid, the Government will take into account their sponsors' income. States will be able to do the same.
The law has some exceptions: Legal immigrants who are veterans, in the military, or who have worked at least 10 years without receiving Federal benefits will be entitled to the same assistance as American citizens. And refugees granted asylum will also be exempt from the restrictions on legal immigrants, but only during their first five years in the United States.
President Clinton, who had criticized the legislation's restrictions on immigrants as having nothing to do with welfare reform, has said he will try to change them in the next legislative session, but such change may be difficult because the immigration provisions represent major budget savings.
New Jersey officials have said the state will try to pick up the cost of benefits for the 20,000 immigrant families now receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children, a bulwark of welfare that the new law abolishes. It is not clear whether New York State, which has long had the most generous and expansive poverty programs in the nation, will do the same. A task force is trying to determine how many legal immigrants are on the state's welfare rolls.
Scott Brenner, a spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, said that the new law merely reinforces existing -- but seldom enforced -- immigration policy, since noncitizens had technically never been entitled to public aid. He noted that legal immigrants would still be eligible for emergency medical services, school lunches and other specified Federal benefits.
But immigrant advocates say that the new law punishes lawful permanent residents, most of whom have worked and paid taxes as vigilantly as most citizens. And as harsh as the law will be for future immigrants, they say, it is particularly devastating for those already here.
"It's one thing to come in and know you're on your own no matter what," said Margie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigration Coalition, an umbrella organization for some 100 groups working with immigrants and refugees in the New York area. "It's another thing to yank the net out from under people who have been here 10 or 20 years, who often worked the lowest paid and most unsafe jobs, and now find themselves in need of these services."

Fear of the Unknown
Amid Confusion, Rumors Prevail
Roberto Quirico's early life in New York was laced with work and dreams for the future. Mr. Quirico, a 45-year-old immigrant from the Dominican Republic, held various jobs and read about historical figures like George Washington and Franklin D. Roosevelt. Then, in 1992, he suffered a stroke. Heart trouble followed. He could not work and needed frequent medical care. And his hopes began to unravel.
"I need a doctor to be by my side all the time," Mr. Quirico said through an interpreter, wiping tears from his eyes. "If there's no Medicaid, death would be better for me."
But the changes Mr. Quirico fears will not apply to him because he became a citizen in June. Such reassurances, however, do not calm him. "I heard that even the naturalized citizens will be affected," he said. "I came here to improve my life, to prosper. But I think all my dreams are falling apart."
There is widespread confusion among immigrants over what the new law means to them. Newspapers for immigrants, from The Carib News to The China Press, have run articles on the legislation, and grass-roots groups have been trying to clarify facts. But in these close-knit communities, where even the simplest messages can be lost in translation, the primary source of communication is word of mouth. And often rumor prevails.
"Word doesn't tend to filter through that accurately," Mr. Matos said. "So the word on the street is you're not going to be treated in the hospital if you're not a citizen. Word on the street is if you owe a couple dollars on a parking violation, you may be deported. So there's widespread panic."
The rumors are spoken like truths in front of bodegas, on street corners and along the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Some believe a trip to the emergency room could lead to deportation. Some believe the children of noncitizens will be put out of school.
"Everybody is talking about it," said Maria Lopez, 47, a Dominican immigrant who receives A.F.D.C. and food stamps to care for her three children. "They say there will be no welfare, no Medicaid, no help at all," she said through an interpreter. "We will wind up on the streets. So the future means death."
Some are already trying to take advantage of the fear, according to Alexander Kopelman, spokesman for the New York Association for New Americans, a refugee resettlement organization. "People are falling prey to scams around citizenship," he said. "There are always people out there who are ready to bamboozle people who are scared and don't understand what the law's about."
Immigrant advocates say that most people seeking citizenship are not doing so to get public assistance. And in fact, 12 percent of all households in the city headed by someone foreign-born receive public assistance, compared with 14 percent of households headed by native-born New Yorkers, according the Department of City Planning, citing 1990 census data.
Advocates say that many immigrants feel it is no longer safe to be a noncitizen, in the face of the new welfare law and a separate measure moving through Congress that would crack down on illegal immigration. Some want to protect their rights and benefits, while others are eager to voice their opinions at the ballot box.
The Shorefront Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Association in Brighton Beach normally gets three or four calls a week from people wanting information about citizenship classes. But the week after the President announced he would sign the welfare bill, the center received 90 calls in one day, and there is a waiting list of more than 200 people. "They all try to push their way into class, but each person's situation is as desperate as the next," said Larry Fish, coordinator of group's English language services.
But even as they try to ease fears, many immigrant advocates acknowledge that they themselves are unclear about a law they find vague and complicated. Some say it remains to be seen how many Federal benefits will become off-limits to new immigrants. And they are concerned that some who remain eligible for benefits might lose them prematurely or by mistake.
Many say they hope that the state will step in to offset the loss of Federal aid. They cite the State Constitution, which requires the state to provide for the "aid, care and support of the needy."
But for some immigrants, worry has already turned to despair. "A number of our groups have reported that some of their elderly clients have said that they are contemplating suicide," said Ms. McHugh of the New York Immigrant Coalition. "They simply have no means to support themselves and do not want to die on the streets."

A Helpless Feeling
No One to Lean On, Nowhere to Go
When How Chong Wong, 77, was a young girl in China, her family was the safety net.
"If you can't eat rice, you eat rice soup, but you share and take care of your parents," she said of those days. "But this generation is different. If there are no benefits, there is no food, there is no shelter."
Mrs. Wong's children have families of their own, so she and her 81-year-old husband live by themselves in a subsidized Brooklyn housing complex for the elderly. She is in frail health, with high blood pressure and glaucoma. And her husband's hearing and memory are fading. Sometimes he cannot hear her calling him. Sometimes he buys groceries in Chinatown, then forgets them on a subway car.
She skims the Chinese newspapers to learn of her fate as a legal immigrant. "I don't understand politics that much," she said through a translator. "We hope the Government will let us have our last years with secure income."
Chinese immigrants make up the third largest foreign-born group in New York City, and their naturalization rate, about 56 percent, is relatively high, city officials say. But some who work within the community say that there are many elderly Chinese who have not become citizens because they do not speak English well enough to pass the exam, or lack the desire to become citizens of a nation that once barred their ancestors.
Many also feel they cannot challenge the Government. "They just feel powerless," said Hong Shing Lee, director of the City Hall Senior Center, the city's oldest community center for elderly Chinese. "These people are generally coming from a background where they have to tolerate what the Government wants to do to them."
But Mrs. Wong said she hoped she could appeal to the Government to keep the $800 in S.S.I. and $60 in food stamps they receive. "My husband has become a citizen, but I cannot," said Mrs. Wong, who can barely read and write in her native tongue. "I tried to ask some of my friends to teach me English, but if they tell me last night, I forget this morning."
She has visited China once since immigrating to the United States nine years ago. But she does not believe she could live there again. "If this passes and the Government said we could not get benefits, that means they're trying to get us out." But, Mrs. Wong said, "I don't know where I'd be going."

Suspecting Bias
Feeling Unwanted, Some Long for Home
On a corner in Washington Heights, in upper Manhattan, is a newsstand where people gather. They buy copies of Listin Diario and Ultima Hora, newspapers from home, then stay awhile to muse about life in the Dominican Republic, and life here.
For months, the Dominican presidential race triggered the most passion in their street-corner debates. But now conversations inevitably turn to the welfare law and the discrimination many believe inspired it.
"I think there's some kind of racism behind it," said Israel Peguero, a cabdriver who came here in 1985. "There is a war against the Hispanic community."
Dominicans are the largest immigrant group in New York City, their numbers hovering at roughly half a million. And a strong bond remains between those who have come to the United States and those who stayed behind. So on a recent afternoon, a Dominican newspaper correspondent prepared to write an article on how the welfare bill would affect his former countrymen as some Dominican immigrants spoke of how, feeling unwelcome, they might return to the land of their birth.
"Because the situation is going down in the U.S., Dominicans are looking back to the country they came from like never before," said Effrem Ballenila, who helps prepare Hispanic immigrants for citizenship exams. "They don't focus only on the bill. They feel there's something behind it that's against the Latino community."
Maria Lopez came to New York in 1988. "In the Dominican Republic it was not possible to live a good life," she said. "We were only able to survive."
She found work as a machine operator in a Brooklyn factory. "At the beginning, I was very excited," she said. "I started working. I could deal with everything easier. But as time passed, it got difficult to get a good job. English is very hard for me to learn. The money I was making was not good enough to pay my rent, and to feed my children."
When the factory closed in 1992, she and her three children began to receive public aid. The family lives off $686 in A.F.D.C. payments, $310 in food stamps, and $50 a month in child support from her ex-husband.
Mrs. Lopez is taking citizenship classes, but her continuing struggle to learn English has made naturalization seem a distant possibility. "I don't know what my future's going to be like," said Mrs. Lopez, who said she worried most about her children. "My main fear is going into the streets, and the possibility of having no doctor for them."
So right now, she and many other mothers simply worry and wait. "All of us, when we get together we talk about the problems we're facing," she said. "That we're stuck, and there's no way to go further."

Stunned by Change
Legacy of Generosity Is Highly Regarded
The students sat in a classroom, speaking a new language at an old age, writing in notebooks with weathered hands.
They were Jewish refugees, gathered at the Shorefront Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association in Brighton Beach to study to become American citizens. In the Soviet Union, where they spent most of their lives they could not speak Yiddish in peace, or worship at a synagogue. But they say the United States gave them the freedom and the financial help to build new lives.
That is why many said they simply did not believe the welfare law would come to pass. Many of the refugees insisted that the new law did not signify hostility to them. "It is the economics," said Manya Drubetskya, 65, a refugee from Ukraine. "The United States maybe does not have enough money."
Nearly three years ago, Emilya Shershevskaya, 72, and her daughter fled Belarus with just enough money to pay for their passage. They were part of the flood of immigrants from the former Soviet Union, most of them Jewish refugees, who came to New York City by the tens of thousands in the 1990's. And she, too, has found it hard to imagine that the stroke of a President's pen could eliminate a legacy of generosity.
"It's impossible to believe that America is going to leave a 72-year-old woman and her disabled daughter without a piece of bread," Mrs. Shershevskaya said through a translator. "I can't believe that could happen."
But if it does, she will have few options. Mrs. Shershevskaya, a widow, lives with her 48-year-old daughter, Rosalya, in a one-bedroom apartment near Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. Her son, Ilya, works as a nursing home attendant, but makes little money and has no medical benefits. And Rosalya could not pass the citizenship test: she has the mental capacity of a 7-year-old child.
"My worry is not the present, because we make do," Mrs. Shershevskaya said. "It's the future, because if anything is to happen, I'm not able to take care of my daughter on my own. I'm not able to work, and my son is working but is not able to support us."
Nearly every dime of the $556 in S.S.I. payments she and her daughter each receive goes toward rent and bills. Food stamps, $138 worth, buy their groceries.
But Mrs. Shershevskaya is not complaining. "I am very grateful to America for sheltering us," she said. "We have safety and we have peace of mind. And I'm always grateful for this because it's not something that America owes us. It's something that the country does out of its goodness."
She has known persecution. She remembers how a bandit broke into a Jewish family's home in Minsk and killed all of its members. She speaks of the night four years ago when she and a friend cowered in her apartment as neighbors banged on the door and yelled terrible things.
"No, I don't feel immigrants are persecuted," she said of the United States and its various new laws. "But there is a sense we're not welcome. It's more a sense I sometimes get when people look at me when I pass them on the street. There's just a feeling of being unwelcome, when people seem like they move away from you because you are from Russia."
It is subtle, but haunting all the same. "In Minsk, I heard it first hand, when people would say 'You Jews should all go to Israel. What are you doing here?'
"Here, the feeling I sometimes get is not dissimilar."

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON
At a rally yesterday in Huntington, W.Va.: 
 "I want to tell you very briefly what we've done, remind you very briefly of what we wouldn't let be done and talk just a little bit about what we're going to do for the next four years. That's mostly what I want to do in Chicago. But I want you to be the vote and the voice and the steps of our movement, America Forward.
Just think of this: You heard about the 10 million new jobs. That's a lot of people. The 10 million new jobs came because, first, we decided we would cut the deficit in half to get interest rates down so people could invest in America again and afford to borrow money for businesses and homes. That's what we had to do.
This is the first time that the deficit has gone down all four years in a President's term since the 1840's, before the Civil War. . . .
We are moving this country in the right direction. We expanded the college loan program so all these students at Marshall and other places could have access to lower-cost loans with better repayment terms. And we created a national service program so children could earn their way through college by doing community service.
We're moving in the right direction. We're all on that right track."
