SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1381 words

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS: THE DELEGATES;
In Poll, Ardor For President, Faults and All

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Democratic delegates assembling for their convention here are not satisfied with Bill Clinton's efforts to help poor and middle-class Americans. But they are delighted with him nonetheless.
With only one candidate to choose among all year, most of the delegates say they support Mr. Clinton without reservations, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. 
 But a majority still says Mr. Clinton should be doing more to help the poor and middle class, and more than 1 in 4 say he was wrong to sign legislation changing the welfare system last week.
Despite Mr. Clinton's efforts to herd his party toward the ideological center, the poll indicates that the 4,320 delegates generally harbor an unreconstructed liberal faith in government's ability to improve American life.
"He's more moderate than I am," said Donel Wyman, a 69-year-old delegate from Oshkosh, Wis., who wore a "Boot Newt" cap to a party here on Saturday night. "But he'd never get elected if he was as liberal as I am."
In fact, on issue after issue, the delegates here present a reverse image of the generally conservative Republican delegates who convened in San Diego two weeks ago.
The survey shows that the Democratic delegates, who, like their Republican counterparts, represent the extreme ideological leanings of their party, are more liberal than the public at large or even the rest of their fellow Democrats. They want the government to do more to solve national problems and to regulate businesses to guard workers' safety and the environment. They support laws to protect the rights of racial minorities and homosexuals. They want most affirmative action programs left untouched. They favor the nationwide ban on assault weapons. They believe that the children of illegal immigrants should continue to attend public schools. And fully 86 percent say the government should guarantee health insurance for all Americans.
The delegates are the reverse image of the Republicans on another front as well: They say they think their candidate will win -- and win big.
Seventy-nine percent of them consider Mr. Clinton the favorite in their state, and 47 percent said he had a "big edge." Only 49 percent of the Republican delegates said they thought their nominee, Bob Dole, would carry their state, with only 25 percent saying he had a "big edge."
Further, most delegates polled say Mr. Clinton's fortunes will be unaffected by the addition of Jack Kemp to the Republican ticket. Forty-seven percent say Ross Perot's entry into the race will not affect Mr. Clinton in their state, while 46 percent say it will help him.
The poll surveyed 509 Democratic delegates by telephone, fax and mail from Aug. 8 to Aug. 22. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
In securing the affections of his party's delegates, Mr. Clinton had a significant advantage over Mr. Dole: numerous Republican candidates nicked and bruised Mr. Dole in the primaries earlier this year, and even as the Republican delegates met in San Diego, some were still wondering about the contenders who could have been. But Mr. Clinton ran unopposed within his party, which has spent millions of dollars advertising him as the bulwark against Republican extremists in Congress.
"I just like him, period," said Brenda Godsey, a delegate from Junction City, Kan., who cast her first Presidential ballot for John F. Kennedy. "It's the first time that I've been voting for President that I felt like I'm voting for a real person. He comes from a regular family. He has the common touch."
She added: "Everybody talks about his character, but he's still with his first wife. How many of us have had problems?"
Not that the delegates here are without worries about Mr. Clinton. Twenty-six percent of those polled said, using words they chose, that Mr. Clinton's main weakness was a tendency to compromise, pander or waffle on issues. Another 30 percent cited as his chief weakness his character in general, or Whitewater and other Administration scandals.
But 59 percent say they support Mr. Clinton without reservations, and 36 percent say they do so with only minor reservations. As his main strength, 17 percent cited Mr. Clinton's compassion and honesty, while 28 percent cited his record in general as well as on the economy and the deficit.
Most do not hold the President responsible for historic Democratic failures in his term. Only 2 percent of those surveyed place "a lot" of the blame on Mr. Clinton and his policies for the Democrats' losing control of the House and Senate in 1994. Twenty-seven percent place some of the blame on him, while 42 percent say he deserves only a little of it.
Fully 70 percent of those polled say that Mr. Clinton tried hard to pass health care reform but did not have Congressional support. But 21 percent say that while Mr. Clinton tried hard, he made too many mistakes.
Like the Republican delegates, the Democrats are better educated and wealthier than Americans generally. Eight percent reported net worths of more than a million dollars, compared with 18 percent of the Republican delegates. And almost half reported annual incomes greater than $75,000, compared with 11 percent of voters. Only about a quarter of voters are college graduates, but 69 percent of the delegates are.
Perhaps reflecting the prevailing political breeze, the Democratic delegates are far less likely to label themselves liberal than the Republican delegates were to call themselves conservative. About 43 percent say they are liberal, compared with the 70 percent of Republicans who called themselves conservative.
But, like the Republicans, the Democrats generally consider themselves more extreme ideologically than their own candidate, the survey showed. Forty-eight percent of the Democrats called themselves moderate, but 86 percent view Mr. Clinton that way. Forty-three percent call themselves liberals, but only 8 percent called Mr. Clinton a liberal.
Democratic delegates are selected through a bewildering process that varies from state to state, and even within states. Some are chosen in statewide elections, others at state conventions, and others in caucuses.
The Democratic National Committee requires each state to divide its delegation evenly between men and women, and it asks each state to promote racial diversity. "The D.N.C. doesn't require any outcome," said Andy Solomon, a party spokesman. "The D.N.C. simply requires them in advance to think about how they're going to achieve a diverse delegation."
As many women as men are Democratic delegates; about a third of the Republican delegates were women.
Like the Republican delegates, most of the Democrats are middle-aged, but they are otherwise more diverse. Seventy-one percent are white, and 17 percent are black, compared with 91 percent white delegates at the Republican convention and 3 percent black. Thirteen percent consider themselves evangelical or born-again Christians, compared with 31 percent of the Republican delegates.
Thirty-four percent of the delegates belong to labor unions, including the 11 percent who are members of the National Education Association, the teachers union, which Mr. Dole criticized in San Diego.
While 4 in 10 the delegates have attended previous conventions, most are too young to have been here for the 1968 convention, when the Vietnam War caused deep divisions. Only 2 percent of this year's delegates attended that convention.
 
How the Delegates Were Surveyed
The New York Times/CBS News survey of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention was conducted between Aug. 8 and Aug. 22 with 509 randomly selected delegates, mainly by telephone but also by fax or mail if individual delegates preferred. The sample was drawn from a list of the 4,320 delegates to the convention.
After the Republican National Convention ended, 509 Democratic delegates in the survey were recalled for brief follow-up interviews; 377 of them were successfully reached and re-interviewed, answering eight additional questions, by the end of the survey period.
The margin of sampling error for the Democratic delegates is plus or minus four percentage points overall, and plus or minus five points for the somewhat smaller follow-up group.

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS: THE LAST TIME IN CHICAGO;
28-Year-Old Snapshots Are Still Vivid, and Still Violent

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
"There was a very important melee over by that tree," recalled John Schultz, pointing through the sylvan calm of Lincoln Park.
"I was standing right here," Mr. Schultz remembered, as if 28 years ago was yesterday, positioning himself by a bush. "The park was absolutely jammed, thousands of people. 
 "The cops were beating a kid there, and the first camera was broken right beside me. A newspaper photographer was taking the picture, and a nightstick came down, and he said, 'They got my lens,' astonished. They had a kid across a car here; there were beatings, clubbings, screaming everywhere."
Back in the present, sailboats sparkled across Lake Michigan, Rollerbladers glided past and a rock band practiced an old song nearby, but for a moment Lincoln Park seemed to reverberate with the demonstrations that accompanied the 1968 Democratic convention.
The little brick building where the police gathered was in the same place, and so were the groves and stretches of grass where bongo drums throbbed and the hippies, Yippies, radicals and anti-war demonstrators argued among themselves until the police clubs and tear gas united them.
The police officers formed a skirmish line at the bottom of that little hill over there one night, menacing but incongruous in their baby-blue shirts and helmets, bulging bellies and snouted gas masks, the kind of vivid snapshot people who were on the streets here in 1968 still carry with them. Behind the officers, like a tank supporting infantry, was a city garbage truck, a street sweeper.
The poet Allen Ginsberg was sitting cross-legged, humming a mantra of "Ohm, ohhhmm," which he insisted would soothe away violence. (Untrue, it turned out.) Some liberal clergymen had erected a huge cross with a similar intent. Marijuana smoke wafted by. There were protesters in the trees.
As the police advanced, the street sweeper, whose water tanks had been converted to hold tear gas, began to spew gray clouds from underneath. The tear gas rolled forward, rising around the legs of the police, now running through the bushes and trees like some surreal production of Birnam Wood coming to Dunsinane in "Macbeth." Then everything went dark and choking with the gas, and people were stumbling, screaming and being clubbed down.
"There was just bedlam everywhere," Mr. Schultz went on, interrupting a visitor's reverie the other day as he rehearsed the three-hour bus tour he is offering for out-of-town journalists attending this week's return of the Democrats.
"People were being chased. There was a television cameraman with his camera broken in two pieces, holding it up."
 
Persistent Ghosts, Firmly Held Beliefs
The author of "No One Was Killed," a firsthand account of the chaos and carnage, Mr. Schultz is part of a cottage industry coming to the fore this week, remembering, commemorating or, in the case of Mayor Richard M. Daley, whose father, Mayor Richard J. Daley, became a glowering symbol of repression, trying to put to rest the ghosts of 1968.
The year 1968, historians have written, was extraordinary, with the United States riven by the Vietnam War and racial conflict. It is difficult now for anyone who was not here then to appreciate the passion that spilled into the Chicago streets that summer.
The Democrats convened that year shaken and divided. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy had both been assassinated. Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey was headed for the party's nomination, but the anti-war candidacy of Eugene McCarthy made the Democrats' convention a focal point for the tensions of the day.
"It's like the Civil War, 1968, everybody's position is unchanging," said Don Rose, then a spokesman for anti-war demonstrators, who today frequently participates in panel discussions with his old adversaries.
Marilyn Katz, then one of the heads of the radical Students for a Democratic Society's security team for demonstrations, declared with her customary gusto, "It was a great year, '68,"
While today's Chicago police have been shown television documentaries of 1968 as a cautionary lesson in preparation for convention week, many of the officers on the street then hold on to their own memories.
"The police department didn't start any riot; it was the other side," said John DiMaggio, a much-decorated retired sergeant. "Not only the hippies and Yippies, but other unruly groups that were planning to destroy our city.
"We had inside information. We had intelligence officers who infiltrated their meetings, who looked like bums and dressed like bums; they had the beards and the beads. "No unnecessary force was used. It was an insurrection, a planned assault on our city. We stopped our city from being destroyed."
Hank DeZutter, then a young reporter for The Chicago Daily News, remembered, "It was total war."
Chicago today is a vastly different city than it was then, and not only because of social and economic changes that have studded downtown with glistening new skyscrapers, gentrified decrepit industrial neighborhoods and turned a shot-and-a-beer town into the biggest sipper of Starbucks coffee outside Seattle.
As the once omnipotent Daley machine declined, Mr. Rose became one of the city's leading political operatives, helping elect the first black Mayor, Harold Washington, in 1983, a pivotal event in the city's history. And, contrary to the myth of burned-out 60's radicals, many of those who once demonstrated here are still working for change. Some find themselves in alliance with the new Mayor Daley.
Ms. Katz now has a public relations agency with major work from the city on an ambitious community policing program and the renewal of West Side areas that were burned in 1968 in the rioting after the King assassination. Her recollections of the cataclysmic 60's were frequently interrupted by business calls.
"Fiber optics; we're talking in terms of potential for a global communications infrastructure," she barked into the phone, discussing revisions on a pamphlet to attract business. "All right, take out 'rat-infested,' make it 'once-abandoned.' Nothing goes out without the city seal and Mayor's signature."
Mayor Daley's agenda for public schools draws on two other consultants: Mike Klonsky, who in 1968 was national chairman of the S.D.S. and a demonstration organizer here, and a University of Illinois professor named Bill Ayers.
In an earlier life, Mr. Ayers headed the violent Weather Underground faction of the S.D.S., whose members saw themselves as revolutionary street fighters. His wife, Bernardine Dohrn, an S.D.S. leader once among the Federal Bureau of Investigation's most wanted, is now a lawyer with a Northwestern University legal aid project for troubled youths.
A notice went out from the couple by E-mail a few days ago announcing the start, while the convention is here, of Democrats Online, a computer network.
"The progressive wing of the Democratic Party hasn't gone underground," the notice said. "We're on the Internet."
 The city's political monolith began to crumble, Mr. Rose and others recalled, in the aftermath of the 1969 killing of the Black Panther leader Fred Hampton, shot in his bed by police raiders from the Cook County District Attorney's squad. The solid black vote that had been a mainstay of the Democratic machine fragmented. Meanwhile, a series of court suits dismantled the patronage system that provided a payroller army of election workers, Mr. Rose said, so that by the time the younger Mr. Daley was elected Mayor in 1989, "he's got a changed city; to a large extent it's been reformed."
Whatever the changes, the wild days and nights of the '68 convention still have resonance here.
At first Chicago radicals, worried over police beatings during the West Side riots and an April peace march, tried to discourage the demonstrations, several people remembered. Stay away, warned The Seed, the local Yippie paper; Chicago will be "A Festival of Blood."
"But in the context of '68, the assassinations, the war, the uprisings, the counterculture, you just had to be there if you believed in any strain of the movement," said Abe Peck, then the editor of The Seed and now a journalism professor at Northwestern University.
The absurdist Yippies threatened to put LSD in the drinking water and seduce the delegates, their wives and daughters -- fanciful menaces that were taken gravely seriously by the authorities. Demonstration leaders haggled, unsuccessfully, for permits to march and sleep in Lincoln Park. The Yippies produced their Presidential candidate, a large pig. Then, on Sunday night, the eve of the convention, things got serious.
"Sunday set the tone," said Mike James, then an S.D.S organizer, recalling how a wedge of police officers charged into the crowd at a concert by the MC5, a rock group whose repertoire included "Motor City is Burning" honoring the Detroit riots of 1967. "The police were amok."
The tension increased as darkness fell and the park curfew hour of 11 o'clock drew near. Police officers with bullhorns ordered the park cleared. Wild debates over what to do raged among the protesters, with S.D.S. organizers shouting that resistance at this point was "suicide, man" and being swept aside by revolts with the revolution. The demonstration, as it would on succeeding days, took on a life of its own.
People charged about, some waving Vietcong flags. The police waded in, clubs swinging. Press photographers became particular targets from that night on; some 65 journalists were injured or arrested or had their equipment smashed. Local editors, Mr. Schultz recalled, "couldn't believe it; they thought there was some kind of mass hysteria among their reporters."
The action spilled into the streets of nearby Old Town. Sometimes rocks were thrown; more often the police clubbed down anyone they could get their hands on. Local residents and passers-by were beaten, and as the days and nights went on, the crowds and the outrage grew, drawing in particularly the now-embittered young supporters of Eugene McCarthy's peace candidacy. The pattern was set.
"It was the same dance every night," Mr. Peck said.
 
A Wednesday Like No Other
Wednesday, Aug. 28, the night Hubert Humphrey got the nomination, was the most spectacular. In front of the Conrad Hilton Hotel, convention headquarters, the police beat hundreds of people under the unblinking lenses of television cameras mounted on platforms. "The whole world is watching," the crowd chanted.
Ms. Katz recalled, "We were standing around in the hot sun in Grant Park, listening to dull speeches, when all of a sudden this huge wedge of cops just charged us."
The rampage was captured in a true piece of cinema verite by the film maker Haskell Wexler and used in his movie of the period, "Medium Cool."
As the afternoon wore on, some demonstrators were forced out toward Michigan Avenue, the main boulevard running past the Hilton. Others were blocked by arriving National Guardsmen with fixed bayonets. As demonstration leaders again negotiated in vain for a march permit, many protesters drifted north in the Grant Park, seeking a way out.
Suddenly, they came upon the mule train bearing Dr. King's successor, the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, which had a permit to go to the convention hall. Joyously they poured in behind the mule train, and Michigan Avenue was packed with protesters, chants of "peace now" and "dump the Hump" echoing.
"It was after 7 o'clock, still light but beginning to fade," Mr. DeZutter, the reporter, remembered, when he watched the police reinforcements fill Balbo Drive on the hotel's north side.
 
A Culture Clash Burned Into Memory
Moments after the police line hit the intersection, there was nothing on that stretch of Michigan but shoes and purses. Officers were lunging into the crowd and chasing demonstrators, conventioneers, onlookers, anyone. "Wahoo, wahoo," shouted an officer charging into the crowd on a three-wheeled motorcycle.
The Hilton's bar, curiously named the Haymarket Lounge, invoking an 1886 riot that pitted police against anarchists, was packed with political columnists and other assorted pundits. Suddenly one of its walls seemed to collapse as people were pushed through its covered-over windows, hurtling backward into the bar, with club-waving police officers leaping in after them.
"The dripping of blood was ubiquitous and impressive," recalled Dr. Quentin Young, who directed a corps of volunteer doctors and medical workers who patched up more than 1,000 injured people.
At 73, Dr. Young is planning to protest at this year's convention over the Democrats' health care policies.
Mr. James, one of the city's most unreconstructed radicals, said: "The police, they really were a nasty breed back then. I could say some nicer things about the police today."
Mr. James cherishes an old photograph of himself trying to tip a paddy wagon that drove into the crowd that Wednesday night, although he added that the effort failed.
Mr. James has for 20 years been running the Heartland Cafe, a combination vegetarian restaurant, bar, general store and theater that is a virtual shrine to 60's values. Posters for Mayor Washington occupy a place of honor, one next to a portrait of Chairman Mao.
"Hey, I'm just getting going; I figure long range," the 54-year-old Mr. James said. "The things that brought us together, except for the Vietnam War, are still here."
He shook his head and grinned. "I'm not into heal-ins," he said. "But, yeah, they should remember '68; it's part of this city's history. It's really right up there with the Haymarket."

PUB-DATE: August 26, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1147 words

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton, Setting Out for Chicago, Denounces G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: ASHLAND, Ky., Aug. 25

 BODY:
An exuberant President Clinton, beginning a four-day train trip to the Democratic National Convention, slammed the Republican Congress today and called on voters to re-elect him and send the message that "we are on the right track in this country and we're going forward."
As he began the general-election campaign, Mr. Clinton abruptly changed tone after months of avoiding overt partisanship. At stop after stop, he called for the election of a Democratic-controlled Congress and offered a blistering assessment of the budget the Republicans had tried to pass last year, before being stymied by his vetoes. 
 The President was in high spirits most of the afternoon, but in an interview with a CNN reporter broadcast tonight, he bristled when the reporter brought up the Whitewater controversies involving the President and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. The President said he was particularly upset that far-reaching accusations had caused members of his Administration to owe overwhelming legal bills. He said his aides had had their "lives wrecked by pure, naked, raw politics." [Page A13.]
At every stop, Mr. Clinton stood flanked by Democratic candidates for local offices and Congress and made an impassioned pitch for their election. "I want you to send them up there," he told the rapt audience here at his second stop. "We need some help."
In Chicago, Democrats preparing for the convention, including Vice President Al Gore, amplified this theme and lambasted Speaker Newt Gingrich and his Republican majority in Congress as extremist and out of touch with voters. [Page A9.]
On a gloriously sunny day in Huntington, W.Va., where nearly 10,000 people gathered outside the old C & O railroad station to see him off, Mr. Clinton urged his listeners to remember "the pivotal moment of 1995."
That was the moment, he said, when the Republicans told Democrats, "if you don't take our budget, if you don't walk away from the commitment of health care to the elderly in nursing homes," and "if you don't walk away from the commitment to invest in the environment and the education of our children and our future, we're going to shut the Government down."
"We said, 'Have at it,' " Mr. Clinton said. "We don't stand for blackmail. We stand for America."
After the rally in West Virginia, Mr. Clinton boarded a 3-locomotive, 13-car train. Two of the cars are old-fashioned Pullmans, including one used by Harry S. Truman, whose 1948 train tour brought him to a come-from-behind campaign victory. Mrs. Clinton attended today's rally, then flew on to the convention in her hometown, but the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea, stayed on the train.
Mr. Clinton's five-state train trip, covering more than 500 miles, is intended to build excitement as he makes his way to the Democratic National Convention, which starts on Monday. Along the route, the President is set to present a new initiative on each of the first three days of the convention to showcase his incumbency and generate news coverage.
Using two helicopters to help carry equipment for sending satellite pictures, the Democrats plan to beam live footage of the President's progress to the Chicago convention hall, where Democrats will be putting on an elaborate show emphasizing the themes of community, opportunity and responsibility. They hope it will give Mr. Clinton the same kind of lift in the polls that Bob Dole got from his own convention.
Today, Mr. Clinton passed from the Democratic stronghold of West Virginia into Kentucky, where he was welcomed by local Democrats despite his tough stand against tobacco, a local cash crop. "Mr. President, many of us disagree with you on tobacco," Gov. Paul Patton said, "but we love you." Mr. Clinton's train will wend its way through the industrial battlegrounds of Ohio and Michigan before arriving in Michigan City, Ind., where the President will get into a helicopter to fly into Chicago on Wednesday night.
All along the train's route, from the backyards of small frame homes and from overpass bridges, small crowds waved the President on and took snapshots. Emblazoned across the cars were "21st Century Express" and "On the Right Track for the 21st Century," slogans that contrasted oddly with the nostalgic return to campaigning by train. As the train passed, some onlookers hoisted Clinton-Gore signs and homemade placards like one proclaiming, "History Begins Here."
Mr. Clinton's aides said the train trip would expand the convention beyond Chicago and let Mr. Clinton travel though small towns that rarely become campaign stops in a time of air travel and media markets. "I come here to say to you, I'm on my way to Chicago and I'm going on a train," Mr. Clinton said in Huntington, "because I want to see the people like you that I've been working for, and fighting for, for four years."
He also said, "I want America to know we're on the right track in this country and we're going forward. We're not turning back."
More overtly than usual, health care was back on Mr. Clinton's agenda as he vowed to move beyond the incremental health-care measure he signed this week, a bill he said would "make it possible for people who are unemployed to keep their health insurance for at least six months." He singled out Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and Mrs. Clinton for fighting "for health care before it was popular."
Mr. Rockefeller, who is from one of the nation's wealthiest families, ridiculed the Republicans tax-cut proposals, pointing to the original House budget plan of 1995. "Remember when they wanted to cut $270 billion out of Medicare so they could give $245 billion in tax cuts to the rich?" he asked. He went on, deadpan, to say, "I don't need it."
Mr. Clinton compared Mr. Dole's campaign centerpiece -- a call for a sweeping $548 billion tax cut -- with a "pretty song" and tied it to the House Republicans' Contract With America. "Do you remember their contract?" he asked. "They never did say word one about it in San Diego, did they?
"Do you remember it sounded so pretty in 1994? And then the consequences came in '95 and '96.
"But if you give them the White House and the Congress, there won't be anybody to say no."
Borrowing a touch from President Ronald Reagan, the Democrats had local heroes introduce Mr. Clinton. In Huntington, it was Marilyn Milne, a single mother who overcame divorce and lack of child care to start a business. In Ashland, the hero was Kevin Gunderson, a paralyzed police officer shot in the line of duty, who called Mr. Clinton "the most pro-law-enforcement President."
Mr. Clinton referred to his opponent only to defend his wife against Mr. Dole's scathing ridicule at the Republican convention of her book, "It Takes a Village." "I think it does take a village," he said, "to raise a child, strengthen a family, build a community and build a country."

HEADLINE: Dole Promises Wider Role For Military In Drug War

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: PALOS PARK, Ill., Aug. 25

 BODY:
Declaring that President Clinton had "surrendered" in the war on drugs, Bob Dole vowed today to broaden the use of the nation's military against the influx of drugs and said he would prepare the National Guard to "move in" to help the fight.
"We will make drug interdiction a priority for our intelligence services, beefing up not just technical operations but also human intelligence operations," Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, said here in the shadow of the Democratic convention in Chicago. "We will expand our use of military technology, including reconnaissance and satellites and area surveillance and listening posts to track drug movements toward our borders." 
 It was not clear how sweeping the use of the military would be. Mr. Dole said that in his first 45 days in office, he would order military officials to come up with a specific plan.
Mr. Dole also acknowledged that using military forces for law-enforcement purposes was an idea to be approached warily. He said the threat of drugs, like the threat of terrorism from abroad, was an area where the military had a proper role.
Mr. Dole promised: "We will renew our commitment to our National Guard drug-interdiction efforts. Working with the governors, we will create designated National Guard units with appropriate training and equipment to provide a rapid-response capability." He added, "If we need the National Guard to move in, they'll have the training."
Mr. Dole said that under the Clinton Administration, Defense Department spending on drug interdiction had fallen sharply, with planes and ships spending less time hunting for suspected drug smugglers.
"The lack of Department of Defense resources committed to interdiction efforts has translated directly to the arrival of drugs on city streets all across America," he said.
Although the United States spends hundreds of millions of dollars each year on ships, planes, radar stations and even tethered surveillance balloons to track incoming drug shipments, the effort proved largely ineffective after it was begun in the Bush Administration and was criticized by Congressional auditors.
In 1993, the Pentagon and the White House National Security Council decided to shift some money away from the interception program and to place more emphasis on helping Latin American countries attack drug trafficking organizations.
Mr. Dole spoke in this suburb 17 miles southwest of Chicago, where the Democrats are to renominate Mr. Clinton at their convention.
Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's press secretary, said Mr. Dole had encroached upon the Democratic turf -- apparently a first in modern times for a nominee during another party's official anointment of its leader -- because he wanted to make a "bold and unprecedented" statement.
Mr. Dole, in shirt sleeves, told a crowd of about 1,500 people standing under the hot sun in the vast green expanse of the John Duffy Forest Park Reserve, "I heard there was a party happening somewhere in the area."
He said that while the Democrats would no doubt play their party's anthem, "Happy Days Are Here Again," his anthem would be "The Party's Over," and that he would dedicate it to drug dealers.
"As President of the United States, within my first 45 days at the White House, I will work with my Secretary of Defense and the Joint Chiefs of Staff to seek further ways to use our military power -- particularly technical capabilities -- to fight the war on drugs," he said.
"We will come up with a plan that focuses the appropriate military means to augment our Federal and state drug-enforcement agencies," he added.
The Dole campaign has long believed that Mr. Clinton is vulnerable on the drug issue, which Mr. Dole has tried to make his own for several weeks now, devoting one of his weekly radio messages to it and, in many campaign speeches, repeating the statistics that show an increase in drug use and what he calls a flagging effort by the Clinton Administration to respond to it.
Clinton campaign literature, distributed at the park today by the Democrats, says Republicans cut $767 million from the drug-control budget of 1996.
Apart from the anti-drug message, Mr. Dole took on skeptics who have said his economic plan cannot both balance the budget and cut taxes.
Sounding like a motivational speaker. Mr. Dole said: "Where there's a will, there's a way. Jack Kemp and I have will and we know the way. So when the other side says, 'It can't be done,' I say, 'Just watch us!"
In an interview with The Chicago Tribune, Mr. Dole said balancing the budget was his priority and cutting taxes was "No. 2," a ranking that his critics say more accurately reflects his long-time feelings as a deficit hawk. Asked about this today, he said, "They are both No. 1."

HEADLINE: The New York Film Festival's French Accent

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
The New York Film Festival, now in its 34th year, will lead off on Sept. 27 with Mike Leigh's "Secrets and Lies," winner of the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and will close 16 days later with the world premiere of "The People vs. Larry Flynt," Milos Forman's take on the very American story of a skin-magazine publisher who carries a First Amendment fight all the way to the Supreme Court.
The festival, which is organized by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will present 29 films and one short feature. "Les Voleurs," from Andre Techine, an erotic thriller that stars Catherine Deneuve and Daniel Auteuil, has been designated the festival's centerpiece film. 
 The festival includes two wild-card entries, billed as "special events," which will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater, rather than at Alice Tully Hall, where the rest of the films in the festival will be seen.
"The Rolling Stones Rock-and-Roll Circus," a television special that was filmed in 1968 but then sat in storage, will be seen at the festival for the first time. The film, which features performances by the Rolling Stones, the Who and a hastily organized supergroup that includes John Lennon and Eric Clapton, will be given seven screenings on Oct. 12 and 13.
The second special-event film is a newly restored 70-millimeter version of Alfred Hitchcock's "Vertigo." It has been painstakingly restored over the last two years by James C. Katz and Robert A. Harris, who carried out similar rescue operations on "Spartacus," "Lawrence of Arabia" and "My Fair Lady."
Although the prestige of the New York Film Festival gives its selection committee a certain power in attracting films, it is hostage to outside forces. Top film makers may simply not be ready to show their work. Political events and economic turbulence may lead to cutbacks in film production, as happened in Eastern Europe in 1989. This year the stars aligned properly, and the committee had rich pickings.
"We got a strong start in Cannes and a lot of good material to choose from," said Wendy Keys, the executive producer for programming at the film society and a member of the festival's selection committee. "We ended up turning away material that we would have been very proud to show, but we are limited by our format. We treat a limited number of films like little jewels and try to get them the maximum press exposure and possibility for distribution."
The festival includes several world premieres, including Richard Linklater's "Suburbia," a film about the denizens of a convenience-store parking lot, with a script that Eric Bogosian adapted from his stage drama of the same name.
As a sidebar to the festival, the Walter Reade Theater will show "Cinema as Weapon: Ritwik Ghatak's Unknown Masterworks," a program of eight films devoted to a Bengali contemporary of Satyajit Ray.
American and French films account for more than half the offerings at this year's festival, which for the first time has a corporate sponsor, Grand Marnier. The French presence is so strong, with 11 productions and co-productions, that it recalls the festivals of yore under Richard Roud, when Francophilia ran rampant. The French lineup includes old hands like Mr. Techine, a festival standby whose "Wild Reeds" played last year; Maurice Pialat, Raul Ruiz and younger film makers like Arnaud Desplechin and Jacques Audiard.
"What's particularly impressive is the French participation in non-French films," said Richard Pena, the chairman of this year's selection committee and the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. He pointed to Emir Kusturica's "Underground," which was completely French financed; Lars Von Trier's "Breaking the Waves," a Danish-French-Swedish co-production, and Merzak Allouache's "Salut Cousin!," a French-Algerian co-production. "France has become the real film power in Europe, not just in esthetic terms but financially as well," Mr. Pena said.
Along with economic power has come a certain confidence among French film makers. "My sense is that at the end of the 1980's, when the expansion of French television cut into the film audience and American competition loomed large, there were a couple of lean years," Mr. Pena said. "Now a new generation has grown up in a different reality, so people like Desplechin and Audiard are past all that; they're not so scared of TV. In a sense, Desplechin's 'How I Got Into an Argument' uses the language of television in a way that the previous generation of French film makers never would have."
Olivier Assayas, a former critic for the journal Cahiers du Cinema, has made only six films, but the film society is treating him like an old master. His film "Cold Water" was shown at the 1994 festival, and the society gave him a retrospective in April.
His film "Irma Vep" tells the story of a film crew attempting to remake a silent-film serial. Among its stars is the Hong Kong star Maggie Cheung. "It's a comedy about the travails of film making, but it also includes some wry observations about contemporary cinema, the place of American and French films and even something about Asian cinema," Mr. Pena said.
Mr. Forman's film, which stars Woody Harrelson as Mr. Flynt and the rock star Courtney Love as his wife, will be his fourth appearance in the New York Film Festival but his first since 1968, when "The Fireman's Ball" was the closing-night film.
The subject of the new Forman film, Mr. Pena said, is not as bizarre at it might seem. "It's a good match to his sensibility, if you think of 'Fireman's Ball' or 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,' " he said. "The screenwriters are the same ones who wrote 'Ed Wood,' and in a way this is also an only-in-America story."
In recent years, the festival has been strong on films from Iran, Taiwan and China, and this year continues that trend. Iran is represented by Mohsen Makhmalbaf's "Gabbeh," Taiwan by Hou Hsiao-hsien's "Goodbye South, Goodbye" and Edward Yang's "Mahjong," and China by Chen Kaige's "Temptress Moon," which stars Gong Li.
Ordinarily, the festival does not show films that have been shown in New York. This year it broke its rule for Mr. Kusturica's "Underground." The film, which the selection committee had hoped to include in last year's festival, was not completed in time. It was given one screening at the Walter Reade last February.
"We did that as a kind of sneak preview, thinking that it would go into U.S. distribution and everything would be fine," Mr. Pena said. "Unfortunately that didn't happen. We think it's a great film and we decided to break our own rule."
Mr. Linklater's film, his first since the highly praised "Slackers," will be watched with interest, but two other American films on the schedule, both of them dark and disturbing, have generated advance buzz. In "Illtown," Nick Gomez returns to the world of teens, violence and drugs that he navigated in "Laws of Gravity" and "New Jersey Drive," but in a glossy, almost surreal visual style.
"Reckoning," written and directed by Billy Bob Thornton, tells the story of a murderer, played by Mr. Thornton, who returns to his hometown after being released from an institution for the criminally insane. Mr. Thornton appeared as the same character in "Some Folks Call It a Sling Blade," a short film that was part of the 1994 New Directors/New Films series.
In addition to Mr. Pena and Ms. Keys, the members of this year's election committee were David Ansen, a senior writer for Newsweek; Jonathan Rosenbaum, a film critic for The Chicago Reader, and Robert Sklar, a film critic, historian and professor of cinema at New York University.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 28, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the New York Film Festival referred incompletely to the career of the director Richard Linklater. After his first film, "Slacker," Mr. Linklater made "Dazed and Confused" and "Before Sunrise." "Suburbia," in this year's festival, is his fourth feature, not his second. The article also misstated the year that Andre Techine's film "Wild Reeds" was shown at the festival. It was 1994, not last year.

HEADLINE: The Bottom Line in Basketball: The Fan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Although from an economic viewpoint it is easy to justify the $120 million deal that the Los Angeles Lakers recently made with Shaquille O'Neal ("The Real Deal on O'Neal," Business Day, Aug. 23), corporate executives and agents ought to be paying more attention to one crucial element: the basketball fans. 
 Ticket prices for the cheapest seats at a Laker game will rise from $9.50 last season to $21 because of Mr. O'Neal's arrival and other factors.
The average ticket price for a single game will be $38.50. Attending a sporting event like a Laker game, long an activity for America's middle-class and blue-collar families, will no longer be feasible as a result of such astronomical prices. As more and more fans become unable to make it to the arena and begin to realize that their team revolves exclusively around an economic bottom line, support for a team may wane.
The idea that athletes of the 90's are no longer athletes but rather "entertainment products" might make economic sense to the executives and agents who are looking only at the bottom line, but to the fans who remember the glory days when athletes competed for love of game and respect for the traditions of their team, this formula will work only for so long. One day, fans will unite and demand more.
 
GERALD SILK
New York, Aug. 23, 1996

HEADLINE: New York Fiscal Monitors Warn of Rising Debt Cost

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
In the years after it skirted bankruptcy in 1975, New York City restored its financial health in part by winnowing its sizable debt. But now the city's debt burden is growing again, threatening to overrun other areas of its $33 billion annual budget, sapping already dwindling resources like so much fiscal kudzu.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recently enacted spending plan calls for the city's annual borrowing costs, known as debt service, to be nearly 60 percent higher by the end of the decade than it was in 1990, when calculated as a percentage of the city's tax revenues. 
 New reports from fiscal monitors raise concerns about the city's borrowing, pointing out that by the year 2000, nearly one in every five dollars collected in taxes will go to pay for the cost of debt -- a precarious level that the city last hit only when it was recovering from the fiscal crisis. The figure for 1990 was a little more than one in 10 dollars.
"We see debt service eating up more and more of the city's dollars available for operating purposes," said Cornelius F. Healy, executive director of the Financial Control Board, the state agency that oversees the city's finances. "Regardless of how it got there, somebody better figure out how to deal with it."
The city's outstanding debt is about $30 billion, not much less than its $33 billion annual budget, officials said. In the current budget, the city is paying about $3 billion in borrowing costs. Both those figures are high, but what is more alarming to fiscal monitors is that they are rising faster than the city's tax revenues.
The increase in the debt burden stems largely from two factors. One is a stagnating local economy, which holds down tax revenues, reducing the amount of money that the city has available to pay for its borrowing. The other is an aging matrix of roadways, bridges and schools that were often neglected during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and are badly in need of repair.
Joseph J. Lhota, the Mayor's budget director, acknowledged that the city was shouldering heavy debt, but he said that the debt payments were not overwhelming. Over the last decade, he pointed out, the city has often had to borrow to make up for cuts in Federal and state aid.
"I don't think that anyone should be worried," Mr. Lhota said. "New York over the years has made a clear choice to fund its capital program to maintain the security and the safety of its very old infrastructure, and that choice has led us to incur debt to maintain the quality of life that we want for our people."
So, while the escalating debt service is seemingly an obscure aspect of the budget, it has important consequences, curbing Mr. Giuliani's ability to undertake projects that give residents a sense that their neighborhoods are not crumbling and that their city has a future.
It also diverts money that the Mayor might otherwise want to direct toward everyday expenses, from foster care to cleaning parks to picking up garbage. Or, as he has often said, toward reducing the city's high taxes.
Debt service played a major role in recent projections by the Giuliani administration that the budget gap in the year 2000 would reach $3.4 billion, the biggest since the fiscal crisis, both in absolute dollars and as a percentage of city spending. Since the city by law must balance its budget every year, that estimate spurred Mr. Giuliani earlier this month to order $500 million in new cuts at city agencies.
The Mayor's move showed how the cost of borrowing tends to crowd out other spending. It is far easier for the Mayor to reduce spending on programs carried out by city agencies than on debt service because once the city has promised to make payments to its bondholders, it cannot break its word without defaulting.
A default would all but destroy the city's ability to borrow money and would probably lead the state to take over its finances.
"Debt service is one of the more inflexible components of the budget," Mr. Lhota said.
At the same time, though, the pressure to spend on the kind of big projects that often require borrowing never lets up. Mr. Giuliani tried to cut $1 billion in borrowing over the next four years in his recent budget, seeking to reduce debt service, but he later put some of that back after the City Council proposed a $1.4 billion program to rebuild schools.
"The city can't afford to borrow more because its debt burden is high, but at the same time it can't not afford to borrow more because its infrastructure needs are so great," said Robert A. Kurtter, a vice president at Moody's Investors Service, a Wall Street bond-rating firm. "Clearly they are going to have to wrestle with that in the coming years."
The city could lower its debt service over the long term by paying for more projects from its operating budget -- that is, from the tax revenues that it harvests every year -- instead of borrowing. But the operating budget is so squeezed now that there is no room for more spending, unless the city raises taxes, which the Mayor opposes.
A vast majority of the city's borrowing is for capital projects, meaning construction and major repairs. It is generally considered poor fiscal practice to borrow for operating budgets, though Mr. Giuliani and other New York City mayors have occasionally done so.
Fiscal monitors blame Mr. Giuliani's predecessors as much as the Mayor himself for the current debt situation. The Mayor, the monitors note, is grappling with the effects of borrowing policies and sometimes questionable financial maneuvers that were set in motion as long as two decades ago.
No one is predicting that the city will default on its debt. In fact, the city's recent bond offerings have been snapped up by buyers, who apparently like the high interest rates that the city has to pay because its debt receives relatively low ratings from bond-rating firms.
Yet if not in a crisis, the city still faces serious problems. Its debt has climbed so high that it may soon be prevented from borrowing more because of a limit set by the State Constitution. The Mayor contends that that ceiling is arbitrary and outdated, and he has proposed a way to get around it.
He is asking the State Legislature to create a city agency, the Infrastructure Finance Authority, that would not be subject to the city's limit and would borrow money for projects. It is not yet clear whether the Legislature will approve the Mayor's plan.
Many fiscal monitors agree that the borrowing ceiling is obsolete. They also note, though, that by any standard, the city's debt is very high, particularly when compared with that of other major cities.
The city's $30 billion outstanding debt is not much less than that of New York State. The state, whose budget is double the city's, has $32 billion in outstanding debt, according to an analysis by Moody's Investors Service.
Fiscal monitors say they are worried about those figures. But Mr. Lhota said that even though the debt has climbed, the city cannot stop investing in rebuilding. If it did, he said, it would fall into decay, driving away residents and making its finances far worse.
"The demands on the city's infrastructure, whether school buildings or streets, are massive," he said. "Yes, we are showing that we are going to have a high debt burden. But no one out there is saying that we should be spending less."

HEADLINE: Stocks Follow Bonds Lower Over Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stock prices declined yesterday in sympathy with bonds, as concerns grew that economic strength might prod interest rates higher.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.85 points, to close at 5,693.89, led by declines in J. P. Morgan and Sears, Robeuck. But a rise in Philip Morris blunted the Dow's loss, following a product liability ruling in the tobacco industry's favor by an Indiana jury on Friday. 
 Broader market indexes also fell. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 3.15 points, to 663.88, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 3.83 points, to 1,139.22.
Declining issues led advancers by 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, but volume was the second lowest for a full session this year at 281.4 million shares, off significantly from Friday's total.
Traders and analysts described a typically slow late-summer session, with many market participants out on vacation and remaining investors looking for reasons to trade.
Weaker bonds provided a slight impetus to sell. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32, to 96 30/32, pushing up the bond's yield -- an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- to the psychologically important level of 7 percent from 6.95 percent on Friday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
Investors sent bond prices lower amid worries that the economy was growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.
After markets closed on Friday, the Federal Reserve released minutes of its July policy meeting indicating that at least one member, Gary Stern, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, believes that interest rates should be raised.
Leading the Dow industrials lower was J. P. Morgan, which fell 1 1/2, to 89 7/8. Banking stocks often fall if traders expect interest rates to rise. Close behind J. P. Morgan was Sears, which fell 1 1/2, to 45 7/8.
Oil stocks were also big decliners, with Exxon down 7/8, to 81 5/8, and Chevron down 5/8, to 59 1/4. Oil stocks have been falling lately in sympathy with oil prices, said Rao Chalasani of Everen Securities in Chicago.
But cigarette maker Philip Morris, another Dow index component, rose 2 1/4, to 90 1/4, trimming more than 6 points off the Dow's loss, in the highest volume on the New York Stock Exchange. RJR Nabisco, whose holdings include cigarette maker R. J. Reynolds, gained 1, to 26 1/2, while Loews rose 1 1/4, to 76, and Culbro advanced 3 1/4, to 57. American depository receipts of B.A.T. Industries, each representing two shares, rose 7/16, to 13 11/16.
Tobacco stocks gained after an Indianapolis jury on Friday denied damages to the family of a heavy smoker who died of lung cancer. Meanwhile, proposed Federal legislation would protect cigarette makers from smoking liability lawsuits and Food and Drug Administration regulation in exchange for yearly payments into anti-smoking efforts and health care programs.
Mergers and acquisitions provided some trading interest in isolated sectors. Shares of Worldcom dropped 3 5/8, to 22 3/4, in leading Nasdaq volume, while those of MFS Communications soared 9 15/16, to 44 13/16, in the second-highest Nasdaq volume. Worldcom agreed to purchase MFS for $12 billion, creating a phone company offering local, long distance and Internet services.
Conseco shot up 1 11/16, to 44, on the New York Stock Exchange after the insurance giant agreed to acquire Capitol American Financial, whose shares rose 9 7/8 on the Big Board, to 34 7/8, and American Travellers, whose shares rose 3 3/16, to 31 9/16 in Nasdaq trading.
